Africa News


September, 1995


Cote d'Ivoire Ivorians in Nine Foreign Countries to Vote


LENGTH: 644 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995

ABIDJAN - Ivorians in nine countries abroad will be able
to vote in their country's 20 October presidential election. 

The countries are Belgium, Britain, Canada, France,
Germany, Ghana, Italy, Senegal and the United States.

A government statement after a cabinet meeting Wednesday
said the nine countries had been chosen after a survey by
Cote d'Ivoire's missions abroad.

The voting will take place mainly in Cote d'Ivoire's
mission in the stated countries.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

2 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zaire Americans To Conduct Research On Ebola


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995

KINSHASA - The Disease Control and Prevention Centre (CDC)
in Atlanta, United States, says it will conduct researches on
the ebola virus which causes the type of diarrheal fever
which claimed 244 lives in Zaire between May and August this
year, diplomatic sources said in Kinshasa.

A Communique from the US embassy reaching PANA in Kinshasa
said CDC will in September organise a workshop for medical
staff in the Bandundu Province of central Zaire which was
most hit by the epidemic. 

The training will focus on new methods of gathering
samples from suspected patients to facilitate treatment, it
added.

The centre said If the pilot programme is executed
satisfactorily, it would extend it other ebola prone
provinces in Zaire.

The CDC said the programme would make it possible to
introduce an early warning system for the screening and
monitoring of the ebola adaptable to other epidemics in
Africa and elsewhere.

The American government is expected to fund the projects
as well as provide other logistics estimated to cost 929,032
dollars.

The disease which was noticed for the first time in Kitwit
in May, caused 244 deaths.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

3 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Average Rainfall Expected in Southern Africa


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995

HARARE - Preliminary indications point to a 'favourable'
rain season in Southern Africa, although warm sea
temperatures off the Angolan coast could affect seasonal
distribution, a South African weather expert said on
Thursday.

In an interview, a spokesman at Cape Town University's
Department of Oceanography, said indications at present
showed the region would experience average rainfall. 

However, he said, it was still too early to say which
parts of southern Africa, currently in the throes of another
devastating dry period, would have the heaviest rains.

'I would say the forecast for this year points to slightly
above normal rains in the late summer which should give good
maize yields. However, the sea temperatures off the Angolan
coast are still warm and this is not a good sign as it tends
to pull rain to Angola rather than to Zimbabwe,' said the
spokesman.

Maize is southern Africa's leading staple.

The spokesman said a detailed analysis of weather patterns
in the region would be presented at a major conference on
climatic change to be held in Harare, Zimbabwe, in the next
fortnight.

Last year, the department forecast below normal rainfall
in the region, mainly due to unfavourable wind movements
across the central Indian Ocean.

In Zimbabwe, the 1994/95 rain season ended more than two
months prematurely, leading to widespread crop failures, with
output of the staple maize crop cut by over 45 percent.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September, 1995


Sudan Country Warned To Expect Economic Embargo


LENGTH: 214 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995

KHARTOUM - A Sudanese cabinet minister has warned
nationals that the West could soon impose an economic embargo
on their country. 

The English language daily 'New Horizon' Thursday reported
the Minister of Justice Abdulaziz Shiddu as urging the
Sudanese to 'observe vigilance...during the coming period and
comprehend the aims of both internal and external
challenges.'

Shiddu, who addressed a mass rally in the Eastern Sudanese
town of Gedaref Wednesday, said the West would tighten an
already undeclared economic embargo on Sudan.

He said the undeclared embargo had been reflected in a
massive cut-back in Western aid to the country.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

5 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Opposition Party Opposes Registration Contract


LENGTH: 680 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995
by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA - Zambia's opposition Zambia Democratic Congress
(ZDC), Thursday criticised government's awarding of a
contract to update national voters registers to an Israeli
company and called for its immediate withdrawal.

Party vice president in charge of women's affairs Euleria
Zulu claimed at a press briefing in Lusaka Thursday that
government had fraudulently awarded the contract in order to
rig the country's scheduled 1996 presidential and general
elections.

President Frederick Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty
Democracy (MMD) government has announced that it had awarded
an Israeli company, 'Nikuv Computers Israel', the USD 18
million contract to update the voter's registers ahead of
this year's local government and the 1996 general elections. 

Zulu said Thursday that the contract was in breach of
Zambia's electoral laws which recognised the National
Electoral Commission as the only body allowed to deal with
electoral matters.

She accused some officials in Chiluba's government of
having influenced the contract for personal gain and
threatened that her party could consider boycotting the
elections if government did not relent.

'We are disturbed at the idea of awarding the tender to a
foreign company. Apart from subverting the electoral process,
it is also to benefit the MMD and a clique of known MMD
leaders to receive commissions and sub-contracts,' Zulu
charged.

Ten other companies, both local and foreign, had submitted
tenders at lower quotations than the Israeli firm, according
to figures given by the opposition party.

Government Wednesday announced the cancellation of a
scheduled emergency parliamentary session called for
September 23 which ZDC president Dean Mung'omba said Thursday
had been intended to amend the electoral law to regularise
the contract.

The main opposition United National Independence
Party(Unip) of former president Kenneth Kaunda had recently
sought a court injunction restraining government from
engaging a private firm to undertake the voters registration
exercise.

The injunction was subsequently dismissed after the courts
discovered that one of the petitioning parties had in fact
not signed the application.

Zambia has some 2 million registered voters of the
estimated population of 9 million. A similar figure is
expected to be added on to the registers following
government's decision to lower the voting age from 18 to 16.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September, 1995


Sudan Government Arrests Alleged Plotters


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995

KHARTOUM - The official Sudanese News Agency on Thursday
reported the arrest of an undisclosed number of people in
connection with the riots that have rocked Khartoum and its
environs.

It reported an official source as saying 'a number of
houses in Khartoum used as centres for subversive activity
and for planning demonstrations' had been spotted and their
occupants arrested. 

The agency quoted the source as saying 'firearms were
found with those arrested'.

There was no independent verification of the claim.

In another breath, the Sudanese government, after four
days of student rioting, has said it will seek national
reconciliation and the creation of a freer society.

A government statement, following a cabinet meeting
chaired Gen. Omar el Bashir, the Sudanese leader on
Wednesday, said 'the National Salvation Revolution will
continue to go ahead with its plan to achieve national
reconciliation and guarantee freedom of legitimate and
peaceful expression for all citizens.'

University students in and around Khartoum led the antithree people were killed while several others were injured in
government riots starting Saturday. Official sources said
the rioting.

The authorities accused student communists at the
University of Khartoum of formenting the turmoil which broke
out after the arrest of three students for planning to
demonstrate against government.

A peaceful demonstration demanding the release of the
students Friday degenerated into a full-scale riot and
clashes with police Saturday.

Public and private property was destroyed on the first day
of rioting.

Khartoum was reported calm Wednesday.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


7 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Officials Press For Improved Health Policies


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995

LIBREVILLE - African health officials resolved Wednesday
to improve facilities and provide the handicapped with
greater care.

This, along with other measures, was announced at the end
of the World Health Organisation's 45th meeting for Africa in
Libreville, Gabon. 

Delegates from the 46 countries also agreed to involve the
youth in making health policies and in drawing up programmes
aimed at teenagers.

The conference also called for national 'awareness days'
for the control of malaria. It said countries should plan to
immunise their populations against diseases and implement the
programme by the year 2,000.

Participants were asked to work toward eradicating the
guinea work. This is a common waterborne parasite of man
found in Asia and Africa.

The director of the World Health Organisation office in
Africa was also urged to strengthen technical support to
member countries in the fight against the disease.

Former United States President Jimmy Carter's Global 2000
project has been active in attempts to eradicate the disease
in Africa.

Conference delegates agreed to review progress in
implementing Wednesday's resolutions at their next scheduled
meeting September 1996 in Libreville.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September, 1995


Libya Deportation of Palestinians Postponed


LENGTH: 240 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995

TRIPOLI - The Libyan authorities have postponed, until
further notice, their planned expulsion of Palestinians in
Libya. 

The suspension was announced by Libya's deputy justice and
security minister, Mohammad Musrati, Wednesday night.

The Libyan leader Colonel Moammar Kadhafi had in a
traditional September 1 address urged Arab countries to
deport Palestinians on their territories.

Libya, together with Iraq and Sudan, is one of the few
Arab countries that rejected the agreement between Israel and
Palestine that led to the creation of Palestinian authority
in Gaza and Jericho.

Yasser Arafat, chairman of the PLO, Tuesday in Cairo,
urged the Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak to ask Col.
Khadafi to cancel the deportation.

9 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe Tourism Arrivals Increase


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995

HARARE - Tourist arrivals to Zimbabwe rose 18.1 percent
last year, with more of the visitors coming from Australia
and New Zealand following an increased number of flights to
Harare and Johannesburg by Quantas, the Australian airline.

Figures released by the Zimbabwe Tourist Development
Corporation (ZTDC) show that the total number of visitors to
Zimbabwe reached 1 039 013 in 1994 as compared to 879 501 in
1993. 

Tourist receipts amounted to Zimdollars 1.05 billion (USD
123.04 million), an increase of 5.5 percent over the previous
year.

Arrivals from Australia and New Zealand grew by a
remarkable 54.7 percent to 22 976.

'We have now more people coming from Australia and New
Zealand following the democratic elections in South Africa
last year that have seen Quantas increasing its flights to
Harare and Johannesburg,' ZTDC director general Nelson
Samkange said.

The positive political developments in South Africa had,
however, resulted in a 6.5 percent drop in the number of
arrivals to Zimbabwe from Britain and Ireland as many of
their tourists are attracted to the new South Africa.

There had also been a 3.7 percent fall in the number of
tourist arrivals from the United States and Canada.

'The industry is now very competitive with South Africa
coming in a bigger way,' Samkange said.

He urged better marketing of Zimbabwe as a tourist
destination.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


10 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Rwanda Amnesty International Calls For Action


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 15, 1995
by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent

UNITED NATIONS - Amnesty International, a human rights
organisation, has called for 'tough action' to prevent
further killings by the Rwandan army.

This demand came after some 100 people were shot dead
Monday in Kanama, Northwest Rwandan. 

'The Rwandan government should take immediate action to
prevent further extrajudicial executions by the Rwandan
Patriotic Army (RPA),' the agency said from its United
Nations office in New York. It welcomed statements by the
Rwandan Vice President and Defence Minister, Paul Kagame,
regretting the killings. The government has ordered an
inquiry into the shooting.

However, Amnesty said that investigation must conform to
international standards and its results implemented and made
public. 'As a minimum, the Rwandan government should make
clear all RPA officials that deliberate, arbitrary or
indiscriminate killings of unarmed civilians are grave
violations of human rights all will not be tolerated,' it
said. Civilians, mostly women and children, were killed when
soldiers reportedly opened fire on villagers in Kanama, near
the border with Zaire. Reports say that this was apparently
in reprisal for an ambush by Hutu militia who attacked
government soldiers, killing one lieutenant.

The shootings were the single largest of such incidents by
government soldiers since several thousand people were killed
at the Kibeho camp April 22. Monday's event, now being
described by the United Nations as a massacre, took place as
amnesty released a 45-page report recommending that the
international community prevent further human rights
violations in Rwanda and neighbouring Burundi. Both countries
are troubled by the same ethnic conflict.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Abacha Shuffles Ruling Military Council


LENGTH: 640 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 14, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani
Abacha Thursday shuffled the country's 26-member highest
decision making body, the Provisional Ruling Council (PRC),
which he chairs, bringing in six new members.

The six new members took the oath of office before a muchof a group of 40 people, including former head of state, Gen.
awaited meeting of the Council, expected to decide the fate
Olusegun Obasanjo convicted of involvement in an alleged plot
to topple Abacha in March.

The new Council members, who replace former members
appointed ministers, include Maj-Gen. Lawrence Onoja, the
General Officer Commanding (GOC) Three Division of the
Nigerian Army, Navy Commodore Victor Ombu, Flag Officer of
the Eastern Naval Command, and Air Commodore Emmanuel Edem,
Officer of the Tactical Air Command. 

The others are Air-Vice Marshal Yusuf Kontagora, officer
of Training Command, Air-Vice Marshal A. Dagash, Commandant,
Nigerian Defence Academy, and Maj. Gen. M.. Bologna, a
representative of the Nigerian Army.

The nineteen members retained in the Council include LtOfficial sources said the meeting was expected to discuss
Gen. Oladipo Diya, who remains deputy Head of State.
the sentences passed on the convicted coup suspects,
including Obasanjo and his former deputy, Maj. Gen. Musa
Shehu Yar'adua.

Since the defence headquarters announced their unspecified
sentences in June, appeals have been pouring in from within
and outside the country for a pardon of the coup suspects.

Obasanjo is Nigeria's only military ruler to have
voluntarily surrendered power to elected civilians in 1979.

Pleas for clemency for the convicts have come from among
others, the Vatican, the United Nations, the Commonwealth,
the European Union, the Organsation of African Unity, United
States, Zimbabwe, Uganda and South Africa, which sent several
envoys to Nigeria.

The PRC was also expected to consider government's
political transition programme due to be announced 1 October
following the submission in July of a new draft constitution
by partly elected and partly nominated members of a
constitutional conference.

PANA further learnt that the Council was expected to
examine the recommendations of the national budget review
panel and those of the federal executive council which met
Monday and Tuesday in Abuja, the capital.

Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large All Smiles as Top Athletes Participate


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 15, 1995

HARARE - Fears that some of Africa's top athletes may have
boycotted the All-Africa Games being held in Zimbabwe were
allayed on Friday following reports that South African poll
Volter Okkerts Britts and Namibian sprinter Frankie Frederiks
will now participate in the continent's sporting
extravaganza.

Both Britts and Frederiks are African record holders and
athletes of international acclaim having excelled in various
international meets. 

Britts, who cleared 6.03 metres earlier this year in a
poll vault event, is a strong contender for a gold medal at
the games.

A senior official of the games organising committee said
Britts, who was due to have attended an event on Friday in
Tokyo, Japan, would now be available for the Harare
competition.

'Pressure has been brought to bear on the two athletes
forcing them to reconsider their decisions not to participate
in this important event,' said the official.

Some of Africa's top athletes shunned the games opting to
participate in international competitions with prize money
which coincide with the 10-day all Africa games.

The international Olympic committee, embarrassed by the
boycott, said in future it will liaise with other sporting
federations to ensure the games do not coincide with the All
Africa Games.

September, 1995


Niger Prime Minister Calls For Resumption of Classes


LENGTH: 174 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 15, 1995

NIAMEY - Niger's prime minister, Hama Amadou, has appealed
to teachers to save the current school year by returning to
work, in spite government's difficulties in paying their
salaries. 
 Teachers in Niger refused to return to their classrooms at
the start of the school year Monday.

They are demanding the payment of their July and August
salaries.

The country's educational system, from university
downwards, has been rocked by intermittent closures.

Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Canadian Offers Food Aid


LENGTH: 200 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 15, 1995

LUSAKA - Canada has offered Zambia 3.2 million Canadian
dollars (USD 2.39 million) in food aid to help it overcome
the effects of a shortage caused by drought, Mrs Cristine
Stewart, the visiting Canadian Secretary of State for Latin
America and Africa announced Friday.

She said most of the assistance would be channeled through
the World Food Programme for the local purchase of maize, the
national staple, for distribution to the needy under a famine
relief programme in some parts of the country.

Stewart noted that southern Zambia had been particularly
hard-hit by the drought that had left many people in urgent
need of food aid.

15 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Ethiopia Illegal Immigrants Expelled


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 15, 1995
by Gabu Amacha, PANA Staff Correspondent)

ADDIS ABABA - Ethiopia has expelled 500 illegal immigrants
who entered the country through unguarded sections of its
borders, a government agency says.

The Security, Immigration and Refugees Affairs Authority
said Thursday that the immigrants had 'acquired' Ethiopian
identity cards from 'irresponsible local officials.' 

The head of the agency's main visa section, Gizachew
Adane, said that 100 local government officials had been
arrested and charged with wrongfully issuing identity cards.

He said these immigrants were responsible for increased
crime in the country. However, he did not give figures.

In July, the Immigration and Refugee Affairs Department
ordered illegal residents to report its offices in 30 days,
warning that legal action would be taken against those who
fail to meet the deadline.

The government did not give the number or the nationality
of foreigners in the country but said they were in their
thousands. Those expelled had been living in the capital,
Addis Ababa, and in the Somali region. Most crossed in from
Humera, Metema and Kurmuk bordering Sudan, and Zala Anbessa
as well as Rahman from Eritrea.

Some illegal immigrants are involved in unlicensed
business activities and in tax evasion. Ethiopians have been
warned against doing business with foreigners who do not hold
valid residence or working permits.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Military Ruling Council Keeps Country Guessing


LENGTH: 587 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 17, 1995
by Kate Ogbemudia, PANA Correspondent

ABUJA - Many Nigerians must have felt disappointed at the
inability of the country's Provisional Ruling Council (PRC)
to take a decision on the fate of 40 people convicted for
involvement in an alleged plot to topple military ruler, Gen.
Sani Abacha in March.

Abacha's Deputy, Lt. Gen. Oladipo Diya emerged from a
meeting of the reconstituted 26-member PRC to inform anxious
journalists late Friday the Council had yet to reach a
decision on the coup suspects.

Those convicted in July and given unspecified sentences
include former Head of State Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo and his
former deputy Maj. Gen. Shehu Musa Yar'adua. 

The sentences must be ratified by the PRC chaired by
Abacha.

Many Nigerians had thought the Council would reach a
decision on the suspects, to end a national suspense fuelled
by incessant pleas for clemency for the convicts, from within
and outside the country.

Diya said another PRC meeting is due soon to discuss the
matter.

Obasanjo is the only Nigerian military ruler to have
handed power back to elected civilians in October 1979.

In another development, Abacha while addressing
participants of Nigeria's National War College in Abuja, said
Friday the military should see itself as 'servants of the
nation and a tool for achieving political goals.'

'The military as an institution must necessarily
subordinate itself to the constitution of the Federal
Republic of Nigeria,' the general added.

The military is considered a major problem in the populous
west African country, which has seen some 10 failed and
successful coups and 25 years of army rule in its 35 years of
independence from Britain.

Pro-democracy groups at home and abroad are mounting
pressures on Abacha to return Nigeria to democratic rule
without delay.

The Abacha government has said it would announce its
transition programme on 1 October after he received a draft
constitution submitted in July by the National Constitutional
Conference.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Egypt Apologises to S.A. On Aids Report


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 17, 1995

HARARE - The Egyptian Boxing Federation says it had
nothing to do with a report in an Egyptian paper which said
the country's boxers at the ongoing All-Africa Games in
Zimbabwe were afraid of competing with South African Boxers
whom it said were infected with the human immunodeficiency
virus(HIV).

The federation wrote an apology to the South Africans. 
The General Manager of the South African team at the games
Oliver Hugo told a news conference Monday the South Africans
had accepted the apology. The article in question appeared
in the Egyptian English language weekly 'Al Ahram' and said
36 South African boxers had tested HIV positive. South
Africa's sporting officials said last week there were some
countries which were jealous of South African competition and
indirectly mentioned Egypt as one such country.

Egypt is one of the countries that has dominated the games
in the past.

Africa News


September, 1995


Sudan African Ombudsman Conference Opens in Khartoum


LENGTH: 307 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 18, 1995
KHARTOUM - The fourth African Ombudsman Conference opened
in Khartoum, Sudan, Monday under theme 'Towards a Straight
and Clean African Civil Service'. The conference, to run
through Thursday, will discuss implementation of the
recommendations of the third conference, held in Abuja,
Nigeria, in 1993 as well as African preparations for the
International Ombudsman Conference to be held in Argentina in
1996. Delegates from the Canary Islands, Ghana, Libya,
Malawi, Nigeria, Sudan, Tanzania and Zambia. Sudanese
president Omar el Bashir opened the conference. 'It is our
fate and the fate of this young continent to trod on thorns
while seeking the progress and renaissance of Africa,' he
said.

Bashir urged Africans to adhere 'to the values derived
from the African heritage, from the genuine African cultures
and from the sacred religions.' 'We in Sudan are inspired by
the great principles of Islam that have put the Sharia law in
a place superior to both rulers subjects,' he said. The
conference will come up with the 'Khartoum Declaration' on a
code of conduct for the public service in Africa.

19 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria New ID for UN Security Council Seat


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 18, 1995
by Paul Ejime, Pana Staff Correspondent

LAGOS - Nigeria is using the United Nations 50th
anniversary this year to reinforce its bid for permanent
membership of the security council, the country's information
minister Walter Ofonogaro said in Lagos Monday. In a
statement at a press conference announcing activities in
Nigeria to mark the golden jubilee of the world body, the
minister urged an enlarged UN Security Council to include the
populous West African country. 

Ofonagoro, represented by the director-general in his
ministry, Patrick Eta, said 'to have only five permanent
members in a council that determines the direction of global
peace and security, is undemocratic in the extreme.'

He said 'Nigeria's size, pivotal role in African affairs,
and past services to the world body suggest that in the
expected reconstitution of the security council, Nigeria has
a strong case...' According to Ofonagoro, other credentials
for Nigeria's bid for a permanent seat on the council include
active participation in UN activities and 'significant
contributions to the attainment of world peace and
development.'

The Nigerian minister said the present composition of the
security council 'no longer reflects current realities and is
viewed as unjust and unreasonable by the vast majority of UN
member nations.'

For instance, he said, although Asia, Africa and South
America constituted more than 85 per cent of the members of
the UN, these regions, with the exception of China, are not
represented at the council.

The two-day programme of events, from September 21-22,
includes the launching of special commemorative stamps and a
symposium under the theme 'uniting people for the better
world: the challenge of the UN in the 21st century' and
'Nigeria and the UN peace-keeping operations.'

The anniversary at the UN's New York headquarters is
planned for 24 October.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe Tobacco Sales Top $11 Million


LENGTH: 187 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 18, 1995

BULAWAYO - Zimbabwe earned Zimdollar 95.5 million (USD
11.2 million) from the sale of 10.3 million kilogrammes of
burley tobacco during the 1995 selling season which
officially closed last week. The country's burley producers
last year earned ZD 89.7 million (USD 10.6 million) from 7.8
million kg of the leaf that were sold.

Zimbabwe's Air Cured Tobacco Association, meanwhile, said
it was carrying out an exercise to convince growers to stick
to burley in the next farming season.

Many growers have threatened to switch to other lucrative
cash crops due to low prices that hit burley sales this year.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Govt. Denies Awarding Elections Job To Israel


LENGTH: 560 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 18, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA - The Zambian government has described as
'childish' threats by the opposition to boycott the 1996
general elections over a voters registration contract
allegedly given to an Israeli firm, and denied that it had
given any such contract to anybody.

Information Minister Amusaa Mwanamwambwa said in Lusaka
Sunday that calls by the opposition for the government to
withdraw the alleged contract and their threats to boycott
the elections, were mere 'scapegoat to avoid defeat.'

Mwanamwambwa who is also government chief spokesman, told
local reporters in the capital that government was no aware
of any firm having been awarded the contract which he said is
still being processed by the national tender board. 

'How can they start talking about t boycotting the
elections when facts about this issue have not been made
public by anybody,' said Mwanamwambwa.

Zambia's main opposition United National Independence
Party (UNIP) of former President Kenneth Kaunda on Sunday,
said it would join the boycott of the elections if the
company, 'Nikuv Computers Israel,' said to have been given
the job, is allowed to register the voters.

'If the registration of voters is going to be carried out
by a private company so that the ruling Movement for
Multiparty democracy (MMD) has a majority of voters on the
register, then UNIP would boycott the elections,' said
Sebastian Zulu.

Zulu who is himself a lawyer had earlier this years ought
a court injunction to restrain government from engaging a
private firm to register voters.

He lost the application.

The third largest opposition National Party (NP) and the
newly formed Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC), led by former
Junior Minister Dean Mung'omba have also threatened to
boycott the polls.

The party accused government of 'fraudulently' awarding
the 18-million-dollar contract to the Israelis to help the
ruling party to rig the elections and for personal financial
gain by some government leaders.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


22 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Country Prepares To Import Famine Relief Maize


LENGTH: 347 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 18, 1995
by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA - The Zambian government plans to procure maize
from neighbouring Tanzania and Kenya and is currently
scouting for 75 million US dollars from donors to help import
some four million 90-kilogramme bags of the grain,
Agriculture Minister Suresh Desai said in Lusaka on Sunday.

Desai said that an appeal for the funds has already been
made to the donor community, whom he said were responding
well. 

Lusaka was making arrangements for the maize to be brought
into the country before current stocks run out by next
November, he added.

The minister said that government was working out a scheme
for private dealers to bring in the maize which, he said,
will be more expensive than the local stocks because of the
import expenses and the varying prices from the various
sources.

The government is itself holding some 36,000 tonnes of the
grain to be brought on to the market in case of dire need,
according to Desai.

Zambia has experienced drought over the past several
seasons causing drastic decline in the production of the
Maize which is the country staple, and other crops.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large African Leaders Urged To Secure Peace


LENGTH: 774 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 17, 1995

GENEVA - President Robert Mugabe on Sunday said African
political leaders still had a lot to do to secure permanent
peace in those countries still gripped by internal strife.

Addressing African diplomats and Zimbabweans who came to
see him at the Zimbabwean chancery of the United Nations in
Geneva, Mugabe said the advent of democracy in South Africa
had resolved a major problem for the African continent.

' I was impressed by the team from South said, referring
to the All-Africa Games Taking place in Zimbabwe. 

'It was a mixture of black and white as if apartheid never
existed. You begin to wonder why all this trouble was created
in the first place.'

Mugabe, who is in Geneva for the inaugural meeting of the
South Centre on Monday, said he was encouraged by the
consolidation of the peace process in Angola as well as the
end of the civil war in Mozambique.

However, flash points remained in countries such as
Rwanda, Burundi, Somalia and Liberia. 'A lot remains to be
done by the political leadership in these countries to secure
permanent peace,' he said.

Mugabe briefed the diplomats on the on-going All-Africa
Games but said it was unfortunate he had to leave in the
middle of the games for the South Centre meeting.

'The Games demonstrate what we are capable of doing and
what we are not capable of doing,' he said, adding that the
games would help in preparations for the Summer Olympics in
Atlanta, US, next year.

On the South Centre, Mugabe said it had now reached a
stage where, through collection of data and research, it can
chart a path for interaction and development for third world
countries.

Earlier, President Mugabe met the chairman of the South
Centre, former Tanzanian President, Julius Nyerere.

Nyerere said in an interview later, that 43 countries had
signed the agreement authorising the setting up of the
centre. The constitution required a minimum of ten countries
to do so.

Asked why an organisation dealing with problems of the
South had its headquarters in the North, Nyerere said Geneva
was ideal for the organisation because it was neutral and
host to several international organisations.

Moreover, Switzerland had in the past assisted the South
Commission, he said.

President Mugabe arrived in Geneva earlier than scheduled
taking organisers and the Swiss government by surprise.

As a result, only ambassador Tichaona Jokonya and his
staff were on hand to receive him, themselves having received
the signal only minutes earlier.

Mugabe was scheduled to fly via London, but wen straight
to Geneva after the British denied landing rights to the
Boeing 707 the president is flying because it is not hushHowever, the matter seems to have been sorted out and
kitted (modified to reduce noise).
Mugabe will be able to fly back home through London later on
Monday.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Government To Rationalise Foreign Missions


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 17, 1995

ABUJA - Nigeria's diplomatic missions are to be
rationalised and restructured to cut cost and make them more
effective and productive, Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi, has
said.

The official News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) quoted him
Sunday as saying, 'we (Nigeria) are now rationalising the
embassies and looking at who and who are there and looking at
the situation at headquarters.' 

Nigeria had more than 100 diplomatic missions, which were
pruned in the late 1980's to the present size of around 80,
largely for of economic reasons.

Ikimi did not indicate which missions would be affected in
the latest exercise, but NAN quoted him as saying some of the
missions might be closed down, some expanded or down-graded
while some new ones might be created.

He said the rationalization was being carried out along
with posting of junior and middle level staff to missions and
appointment of new Ambassadors and High Commissioners.

The Nigerian minister also spoke of the need to strike s
'good balance' in the appointment of career ambassadors and
political posting so that the right calibre of staff were
sent to man the country's missions.
'We want to avoid a situation where we might have the
problem of sending a political ambassador to a mission which
is infested with people who cannot give him the necessary
support,' Ikimi added.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria- (Commentary) The Pen And The Sword


LENGTH: 1107 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 17, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS - It is not commonplace to see academics abandon the
lure of the 'Ivory Tower' for the risky political terrain
considered the preserve of politicians.

A group of intellectuals from northern Nigeria apparently
taking a cue from their counterparts in the South have joined
in the race by Nigerian academics to respond to the pressing
needs of society.
Under the auspices of the Swiss Embassy in Lagos in
collaboration with the Association of Nigerian Authors (ANA)
and a Swiss-based cultural exchange programme, a week-long
short story and poetry workshop was recently held in
Maidurugi, capital of the northern state of Borno.

From 21 participants emerged more than one hundred poems
and short stories from which Nigerian author Zaynab Alkali
and Swiss writer and journalist Al Imfeld, co-ordinators of
the workshop, chose the top 30 that formed the basis of a new
literary adventure christened 'Vultures In The Air: Voices
From Northern Nigeria.' 

The 150-page anthology deals with wide-ranging issues
touching on romance, hatred, anger, crime, governance and
misgovernment.

The poems and short stories include 'Student
Demonstrations,' 'A Country Without Home,' 'The Rapist,
''Code Of Silence,' 'Vultures,' from which the book derives
its name, and 'We Shall Rise With The Sun.'

There was even one on 'Children of Bosnia,' by Halima
Adamu, which can easily be adapted to the sorry situation in
the two central African states of Rwanda and Burundi.

Six of the Nigerian authors later came together in Lagos
at a well-attended ceremony under another joint project with
the German Geothe Institut and the British Council, for
theatrical demonstration of their works.

One of the writers, Micky Ibitomihi, who described himself
as a 'poultry farmer,' was particularly impressive in his
rendition of the 'Prophet Divines,' 'The Road,' and 'We Have
Not Changed,' which argues that despite many tribulations and
depression, the African appears not to have changed much, 'we
are what we are.'

'A Country Without Home,' by lecturer Musa Idris
Okpanachi, talks about the ordeal of African children,
'scattered in the four winds in locust multitudes. ''like an
ant street stampeded on by elephants, they (the children)
flee from home ravaged by the hunters...,' reads part of the
poem.

Obi Iwuanyanwu in the 'Scream of Death,' talks about the
ultimate justice that awaits a murderer. It however, leaves
unanswered the question of whether crime could ever be
justified.

Adamu Usman in 'Those In Authority,' captures the sharp
contrast of misery in the midst of affluence, noting that
'the semen (in authority) parade at endless funerals of the
weary masses in their galleries and artful shows.'

For his part, another lecturer Idris Amali, in 'Don't You
See,' reflects the lot of many an African in the 'Naked
Raping of Hopes,' the lingering civil strife, and problems
plaguing the health and the education sectors, as well as the
rising crime wave amid institutionised corruption.

But for some curious coincidence, a recurring theme in
most of the poems rendered by the six authors at the Lagos
exhibition was on military government, apparently a backdrop
from the long military intervention in Nigerian politics.

ANA President Odia Ofeimun defended the choice of topics,
saying the authors tried to reflect the mood of society,
while one of the authors, Amali argued that he and his
colleagues have no apology for addressing the military, which
he described as the major 'stumbling block' to progress in
Africa.

But like a number of speakers in the audience noted, the
ephitet of 'a general without an army' has assumed a national
past-time in Nigeria.

The citizenry certainly deserve something refreshing,
especially from the intellectuals and their work, 'Nigerians
want to relax, go to the beach and talk about peace,' one
commentator added.

By and large, 'Vultures In The Air: Voices From Northern
Nigeria,' may well represent a bold attempt at popularising
poetry and short stories as potential tools to fight societal
malaise. But it remains to be seen how far the intellectuals
can go with their poetic message.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe More Foreign Firms Prospect For Minerals


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 20, 1995

BULAWAYO - The Zimbabwe government has granted 83
exclusive prospecting orders (EPO) for various minerals to
local and foreign mining companies since the start of this
year.

According to figures released by the Chamber of Mines of
Zimbabwe on Wednesday, diamond was the most sought-after
mineral accounting for 53 exploration licences. 

The second most popular mineral was gold with 15 EPOS .The
rest were issued for antimony, copper, cobalt, nickel,
platinum, lead and zinc.

Last year, a total of 46 EPOS for various minerals with at
least 36 for diamonds were issued to several companies.

An official of the mining body said foreign companies were
willing to enter into joint ventures and invest huge amounts
of money in exploration lasting up to three years.

He attributed increased investor interest to improved
world commodity prices, a good investment climate and an
aeromagnetic survey by the Canadian International Development
Agency three years ago.

The Zimbabwe Investment Centre, which promotes foreign
investment in the country, said mining, tourism and
agriculture were major areas which had drawn enormous foreign
interest.

Much of Zimbabwe was now covered by exploration licence or
those awaiting approval.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


27 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Rwandan Refugees Employed In Zambia


LENGTH: 427 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 20, 1995
by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA - The Zambian government has provided jobs for many
qualified Rwandan refugees who fled the civil strife in their
country, Commissioner for Refugees Lameck Mwaba told PANA in
Lusaka Wednesday.

Mwaba said that there were currently an estimated 2,000
Rwandan refugees in Zambia, including some highly qualified
professionals like engineers and doctors who have been
employed by the Zambian government, mostly in the capital,
Lusaka. 

Mwaba also confirmed that the government plans to set up a
camp in Mporokoso, northern Zambia, for Rwandan refugees
whom, he said, were entering the country at the rate of at
least seven persons everyday.

He said that government was finding it increasingly
expensive to transport the refugees from their entry point at
Nakonde to Maheba refugee camp in the north-west.

Government has already done the ground-work and solicited
or the funds to set up the proposed camp, Mwaba said.

In addition, an average 100 Angolans come to Zambia every
month in search of food which is in short supply in southern
Angola, according to Mwaba.
They are currently being resettled at refugee camps as
'economic immigrants', he added.

However, there has been appreciable reduction in the
number of Angolans fleeing to Zambia since last November's
ceasefire in that country's civil war following the signing
of a peace agreement between the government and former rebels
of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA).

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe Young Gymnast Makes History At Games


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 20, 1995

HARARE - Ten-year-old gymnast Chido Mombeshora of Zimbabwe
has made history by becoming the youngest athlete to win a
medal at the ongoing Sixth All-Africa Games in Harare.

Chido, a pupil at Chisipite Junior School in Harare,
collected a bronze in the women's rhythmic competition on
Tuesday. She now hopes to compete at the Atlanta Olympics in
the United States next year.

First daughter of Casper and Irene Mombeshora, Chido owes
her success to her Russian-born coach, Julia Chelephina who
spotted her at Chisipite and convinced her to take up the
sport seriously.

'I did not like gymnastics but was just trying it out at
school, then I got used to it and now I like it,' Chido told
journalists.

The Fifth-Grade pupil has no fears about competing with
gymnasts twice her age.

At the gymnastics event on Tuesday, Chido teamed up with
Megan Robertson, Lauren Falk and Diana Turner to win the
bronze.

29 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Southern Africa In Joint Geological Research


LENGTH: 507 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 20, 1995

HARARE - Southern African Development Community (SADC)
member states, keen to push forward regional economic
integration in the mining sector, have agreed to standardise
geological maps and carry out joint research of geological
terrains across their borders.

A SADC workshop on regional integration in the mining
sector held in Pretoria, South Africa from September 11 to 15
agreed that measures should be put in place to enable any
country within the community to access information on each
other's geological maps. 

According to recommendations of the workshop released on
Wednesday, effective sharing of information would involve: borders; - adoption of a singular regional classification of
geological correlation of adjacent maps across common
rocks; - production of regional remote sensing products and
crystal studies and, - production of common colour codes for
different names of the same type of rocks.

The workshop, attended by mining experts from the private
and public sector, also recommended that the SADC region
should adopt a common approach in the application of
engineering and environmental geology.

This could be achieved by the setting up of standardised
practices including the legal framework and promoting
consultations during the planning and design of major
engineering works, particularly in cases which may have cross
border effects.

There was also need to assess the safety of proposed major
construction activities such as embarkments, dams, roads,
tunnels and waste disposal sites and improve research and
development to achieve cooperation in this field.

Regarding mining and marketing, the workshop recommended
that governments should improve the organisation and
dissemination of information to the private sector.

Marketing of minerals had also to be largely left to the
private sector.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

September, 1995


South Africa South African, Iran Sign Co-operation Agreement


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 20, 1995
by Lionel Williams, PANA Staff Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG - South Africa and Iran have signed a cosigned at Johannesburg International Airport on Tuesday by
operation agreement on minerals and mining. The agreement was
South African Mineral and Energy Affairs Minister Pik Botha
and his Iranian counterpart, Hossein Mahlouji. 

Both Ministers expressed the wish for further co-operation
between South Africa and Iran in the field of trade. Asked
whether the deal would not hurt relations between Pretoria
and Washington which is campaigning for the Isolation of Iran
because of its support to terrorists, Botha pointed out that
several European countries did more trade with Iran than
South Africa.

Earlier this year, the United States criticised South
Africa for agreeing to provide storage facilities for Iranian
oil.

'I thought apartheid was over,' said Botha, 'now I have to
face a different discrimination.' Botha pointed out that
South African companies bought more than 60 per cent of their
oil requirements from Iran at a cost of 1.5 billion dollars.

Trade in other goods between the two countries amounts to
about 10 million dollars a year.

Nigeria American Oil Company Shelves Divestment Plan


LENGTH: 320 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 19, 1995

LAGOS - The American oil company Texaco Incorporated said
in Lagos Tuesday it was no longer divesting its 60 per cent
shares in Texaco Nigeria Plc.

The company's marketing director, Jim Horn, told a news
conference the decision to abandon its divestment from
Nigeria was due purely to business considerations. Horn said
'after careful analysis, it was realised that returns on
business in Nigeria and other parts of the West African subdivest.'
region are fair and adequate, and it will not be wise to

He added that the company was determined to resume full
business activities in the Nigerian company and improve on
its market share in the West African state.

Texaco Incorporated owns 60 per cent of Texaco Nigeria
while some 17,000 other shareholders own 40 per cent of
company.

The company decided to sell its 60 per cent shares in
1993, but did not announce the decision until July 1994.

Reacting to the development, Bridget Holloway, the company
secretary for Texaco Nigeria, said the decision not to divest
'shows that the company still has confidence in Nigeria's
economy.'

Africa News


September, 1995


Angola UN Commander Hopeful of Peace


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 20, 1995

HARARE - The Commander of the United Nations peacekeeping
operations in Angola, Maj-Gen. Phillip Sibanda on Wednesday
said he was optimistic that the third UN Angola Verification
Mission (UNAVEM III) would succeed, ending nearly two decades
of civil war in that country.

Sibanda told journalists in Harare that there was
political commitment from both warring factions in Angola,
UNITA and the government, which he said was an indication
that prospects of peace were brightening. He leaves Zimbabwe
for Angola on Wednesday afternoon for his one-year tour of
duty to take over from outgoing Chris Garuba of Nigeria as
commander of 7,000 soldiers on the Angolan mission from
October 1. 

Last November UNITA and the Angolan government signed a
peace agreement in Lusaka, Zambia, ending nearly 20 years of
civil war, which have since been breached by both parties.

'The mission that I am undertaking is a very difficult
task which requires a lot of support from everyone. I am glad
to mention that the peace accord signed in Lusaka came about
as a result of both parties agreeing on the way forward.
'There is political will to bring peace to Angola. The
mission is not only difficult, it is also a challenge, but
because there is political will from both parties, the
mission will succeed', Sibanda said.

Troops participating in the mission include a Zimbabwean
battalion of 800 soldiers, along with similar units from
India, Uruguay, Romania and Brazil. Zambia is expected to
send its troops by the end of this month. The UN peacekeeping
troops will be engaged in verifying, monitoring, reporting
and investigating any incidents linked with the Lusaka peace
agreement. On the violation of the Lusaka agreement, Sibanda
said it was expected that there would be violations
considering that the country had been at war for nearly 20
years.

Earlier, Sibanda bade farewell to Acting President Simon
Muzanda in Harare.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September, 1995


UGANDA Striking Doctors Defy Government Ultimatum


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 20, 1995

KAMPALA - Doctors and other health workers in Uganda's
government hospitals, who on Tuesday went on strike for
better salaries, have defied a government order to return to
work immediately.

At Mulago, Uganda's largest referral hospital, the health
workers on Wednesday, the second day of the strike, stood in
groups outside the 1,500 bed hospital discussing the
government order. 

A stream of patients and other attendants carrying
mattresses, basins, and saucepans continue to flow out of the
hospital while most wards were virtually empty, expect for a
few frail patients who lay on their beds without attention.

The government on Tuesday directed the health workers to
resume work immediately or face the risk of being sacked.

'You have absconded from your jobs and usual measures will
be taken as per public service regulations and government
standing orders,' the health minister Dr. James Makumbi
threatened at a news conference in Kampala. He implied
possible dismissal of the strikers.

Makumbi said intimidation of health workers wanting to
return to work would be firmly dealt with.

He said government would meanwhile continue to negotiate
with the striking party.

The minister said the strike was inhuman and should be
condemned.

'The lives of many innocent Ugandans have been put
atrisk,' he said.

Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Israeli Firm Wins Voters' Registration Contract


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995
by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA - Zambia's National Tender Board says it has
awarded Nikuv Computers of Israel an 18-million-dollar
contract to register voters for this year's local government
polls, and the 1996 Presidential and parliamentary elections.

Tender Board Director Teddy Mulonga who made the
announcement in Lusaka on Wednesday said the Israeli firm had
met all tender requirements. Ten other local and foreign
companies submitted tenders for the job, he added. Mulonga's
confirmation of the contract comes in the wake of threats of
mass boycott of the elections by opposition parties which
claim that government had 'fraudulently' awarded the contract
to the Israeli company to assist the ruling party rig the
elections.

The main opposition United National Independence
Party(UNIP) of former president Kenneth Kaunda and the
National Party among others, have demanded that the contract
be withdrawn.

They said awarding the contract to a foreign company
breached Zambia's electoral laws which recognise the National
Electoral Commission as the only body allowed to deal with
electoral matters.

UNIP had earlier this year sought a court injunction to
prevent the government from engaging a private firm for the
job. But the application failed on procedural grounds.

Mozambique Canada To Assist Judiciary


LENGTH: 320 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

MAPUTO - The Canadian government has offered to assist the
Mozambican Parliament by providing training for
parliamentarians.

The offer was made on Wednesday by the Canadian Secretary
of State for Latin America and Africa, Christine Stewart,
after a visit to the Assembly in Maputo. 
 Stewart said the training would contribute 'to the
consolidation of democracy in Mozambique'.

Deputy Speaker, Vicente Ululu, who received Stewart, said
the building housing the legislators needed to be expanded to
accommodate the 250 parliamentarians.

A Chinese offer to construct a new parliament building had
been withdrawn and official were presently seeking funds to
upgrade the existing one, he added.

Stewart on Tuesday signed an agreement with Mozambican
Deputy Foreign Minister Frances Rodrigues under which Canada
will provide Mozambique with wheat valued at eight million
Canadian dollars.

Proceeds from the sale of the wheat expected to arrive
next year will be disbursed to the health and education
sectors.

36 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Main Opposition Scores Election Gains


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995
by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA - Zambia's ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy
(MMD) Tuesday lost three crucial parliamentary seats in its
strongholds in north and central Zambia to the opposition
United National Independence Party (UNIP) led by the former
president Kenneth Kaunda.

In eight parliamentary bye-elections Tuesday, Unip
captured Mbala and Mpulungu in the north and Mkushi north in
central Zambia, all previously held by the ruling party led
by President Frederick Chiluba. 
 T he ruling party however made inroads in the east by
scooping the Chama south parliamentary seat that had been
held by Unip. It also retained the Chama north seat. Both are
in eastern Zambia, a Unip stronghold. The MMD retained the
Chilanga and Mandevu seats in Lusaka and was Thursday
reportedly leading Namwala, southern Zambia whose result has
not been officially announced.

Chama south is the first seat to go to the ruling party in
eastern Zambia since the 1991 multiparty general elections
when Unip scooped all the seats in the region.

Political observers attributed the government's loss in
the otherwise 'safe' Mpulungu, Mbala and Mkushi north rural
constituencies to a protest vote by peasant farmers unhappy
about alleged poor management of agriculture by the MMD
government.
Kaunda, who had himself been actively involved in the
election campaigns, is targetting farmers and retrenchees in
his bid to return to power in Zambia's 1996 presidential and
general elections. Kaunda has said he will challenge Chiluba
for the presidency.

Unip will now have 21 seats in the house. Three other by
elections are to be held in October.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

September, 1995


Botswana Newspaper to Pay Compensation


LENGTH: 187 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

GABORONE - A Botswana weekly, The Guardian, is to pay
Quill Hermans, the governor of the Bank of Botswana, USD
75,000 in damages for defamation. 

Hermans had sued the paper for defamation after it
published a 1993 article saying the bank's executive
committee has accused him of improper conduct. The committee
denied ever having made any such allegations.
.In spite an apology for the first article, the newspaper
later made further allegations of improper conduct by
Hermans. He sued again and won his case.

The newspaper undertook never to defame him again.

September, 1995


Ethiopia Leather Products Institute Acquires New Site


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

ADDIS ABABA - Ethiopia has given the Common Market for
Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa) Leather and Leather
Products Institute a 30,000-square meter piece of land for
the construction of its headquarters, a senior Comesa
official has said.

The new headquarters is expected to cost some 4.5 million
dollars, Robert Arunga, the director of the Addis Ababa-based
institute said. 'Ethiopia has already contributed USD
108,000 dollars, outside its yearly contribution, for the
construction of the headquarters,' Arunga told PANA.

He said Ethiopia had pledged a further one million dollars
to the project. The institute, funded through contributions
from Comesa member states, is currently located at the
productivity improvement centre of the Ethiopian Management
Institute.

It was established in 1990 to promote productivity,
competitiveness, trade and regional integration in Comesa's
leather industry through training, research and development,
consultancy and extension, and information collection and
dissemination.

Arunga did not, however, say when construction work would
begin.

September, 1995


Mozambique Military Cooperation with Zimbabwe


LENGTH: 507 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

MAPUTO - Delegations headed by th Mozambican defence
minister Aguiar Mazula and his Zimbabwean counterpart Moven
Mahachi met in Maputo on Wednesday to discuss revising the
1988 military cooperation agreement between the two
countries.

Mazula after the meeting disclosed that 600 members o of
the Mozambican Defence Force (FADM) would be trained as
instructors at the Nyanga Camp in eastern Zimbabwe. The
training will be undertaken by Zimbabwean and British
officers and will be financed by Britain.

On returning to Mozambique, the instructors will train
sargeants at the Boane and Manhica Barracks, both in Maputo
province. Mazula said that the FADM was short of sergeants.
It was also at Nyanga that the 540 instructors (half from the
old government army and half from the former rebel movement
Renamo) involved in forming the FADM's infantry battalions
last year, were trained.

It was believed the presence of a Zimbabwean military
delegation in Maputo could also have to do with measures to
deal with the armed Zimbabwean dissidents, known as
'Chimwenjes', believed to be operating from Mozambique.

The Chimwenjes are believed to have bases in the central
Mozambican province of Manica from which they are said to be
preparing incursions into Zimbabwe. But when Mozambican
television raised the issue with him, Mahachi said he knew
nothing about the Chimwenjes. He clearly did not think they
posed any serious threat to Zimbabwe, and appeared skeptical
as to their very existence. 'We have never faced any attack
from Mozambique,' he said.

The Chimwenjes have proved highly elusive, and the reports
filtering out of Manica have been contradictory --speaking of
a Zimbabwean movement, but at the same time claiming that it
consists mostly of Mozambicans.

The Manica reports say the Chimwenjes owe allegiance to
some Zimbabwean opposition politicians.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe Money Market in Surplus


LENGTH: 307 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

HARARE - Zimbabwe's money market was Thursday morning in
surplus to the tune of Zimdollars 587 million(8.7 Zimdollars
= one US dollar), causing rates to weaken to about 24.75
percent for 90-days, analysts said.

Last week, 90-day paper like negotiable certificate of
deposits were quoted at just above 25 percent. 

Discount Company of Zimbabwe managing director, Ian Helby,
said increased liquidity in the market was good news to the
reserve bank as discount houses were no longer having to rush
to it to be accommodated.

Increased trading activity between discount houses is in
line with the central bank's aim to create a vibrant money
market.

High liquidity in the market is largely due to heavy
maturities of treasury bills and increased inflows of foreign
currency to finance the purchase of tobacco at the auction
floors.
Although rates on money instruments have been weakening,
the end of the tobacco season early next month is likely to
reverse the trend.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

September, 1995


Egypt Wrestler Tests Positive For Doping, loses medal


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

HARARE - Egyptian wrestler Mohy Abdel Hareth has been
stripped of his gold medal won at the Sixth All-Africa Games
in Zimbabwe for failing a drug test.

The Zimbabwe Inter-Africa News Agency reported Thursday
that Hareth was found positive of the banned substance,
Noresterone. 

He mined the gold in the 100 kilogramme Greco-Roman style
competition which ended Wednesday.

African Wrestling Confederation Secretary-General Cheek
told journalists that the International Wrestling Federation
would rule on further punishment against Hareth.

He is the third athlete to test positive for a banned
substances at the 10-day games which began September 13.

South African long jumper Karen Botha and Nigerian
sprinter Paul Egonye were found to have used banned
stimulants.

Both were stripped of their medals. Egonye got a four-year
ban and Botha, wife of former Springboks rugby captain Naas
Botha, was banned for three months.

Zambia Police Hold Kaunda Team Over Minister's Beating


LENGTH: 427 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995
by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA - Police in Chama, eastern Zambia, were Thursday
still holding former president Kenneth Kaunda and several
supporters of his United National Independence Party(UNIP)
for allegedly assaulting a deputy minister during
parliamentary by-election campaigns on Monday.

Zambia police inspector-general Francis Ndhlovu told PANA
in Lusaka Thursday that Kaunda and his entourage were
expected to appear in a police identification parade during
which the deputy minister for education would point out his
alleged assailants. 

Ndhlovu said police in eastern province, a Unip
stronghold, had Wednesday mounted a roadblock to intercept
Kaunda's motorcade which was coming from a campaign tour to
drum up support for its members in the just-ended byIt is alleged that Kaunda's driver, who is also his
elections.
bodyguard, had on Monday beaten and his driver in the
presence of Kaunda.

According to reports, the incident was triggered off by
Ng'uni's give way for Kaunda's convoy to pass at a point
where the gravel road was bad.

This is the third time, since returning to active politics
in 1994, that Kaunda has had trouble with the law.

He was early this year arrested for addressing a rally in
Chongwe, east of Lusaka, without a permit and was again
arrested in July for addressing students at Northern
Technical College in Ndola, on the Zambian copperbelt without
a permit.

September, 1995


Zimbabwe Call for Continued U.S. Military Training


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

HARARE - The United States is ready to continue joint
training exercises with Zimbabwe's military and wildlife
personnel as both countries stand to gain from such
programmes, the country's deputy ambassador to Zimbabwe James
Carigher said on Thursday.

Speaking at a ceremony to mark the end of the third joint
training programme of Zimbabwean and United States soldiers
at Inkomo barracks outside Harare on Thursday, Carigher said
the programme had since it started in 1993 been very
successful. 

'We look forward to continue joint training opportunities
in Zimbabwe with all organisations like the parks and
wildlife professionals who are working hard to preserve the
magnificent resources of your country,' he told the nearly
200 Zimbabwean soldiers who included the Zimbabwe National
Army commander, Major General Constantine Chiwenga.

Over 40 Zimbabwean and 140 United States soldiers received
certificates after completing a six-month training programme
including de-mining and air-borne operations.

September, 1995


Africa-At-Large South Africa Bids To Host Next Games


LENGTH: 440 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

HARARE - The Supreme Council For Sports in Africa (SCSA)
says South Africa has requested to host the Seventh AllSpeaking at Stodart Hall at Mbare in Harare, venue of the
Africa Games in 1999.
demonstration netball competitions, SCSA Secretary-General
Awoture Eleya said 'South Africa has indicated that they
want to host the next games in four years time and we want to
give them the opportunity. They, however, have not yet given
us the final decision,' he said. He said management problems
dogging the Sixth All-Africa Games were because the host
country had left the preparations until too late.

Construction of some games venues were done between end of
last year and beginning of this year while some of the final
touches were not done until the week of the commencement of
the Games.

Eleya said the sporting disciplines in the next games
would not necessarily be reduced, but would depend on what
the host country was capable of managing. 'Host countries
should start preparing the games more than three years before
so that they are ready for the event, 'he said. He said six
zones affiliated to the SCSA, were at the Stodart Hall to
watch the netball match between Malawi and Zimbabwe which the
latter won 55-38.

Senior sports officials said they were impressed by the
high standard of netball displayed by the two teams and hoped
the sport would be accepted as a medal sport by other African
countries. Five countries -- Botswana, Namibia, Malawi,
South Africa and Zimbabwe -- sent teams to the competitions.

'The zone Secretary-generals will work to promote netball
in their areas,' Eleya said.

45 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large States Barred from Voting at UN General Assembly


LENGTH: 440 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 21, 1995

UNITED NATIONS - Fifteen United Nations member countries,
most of them from Africa, have been barred from voting in the
current 50th session of the UN General Assembly because of
their failure to pay their annual contributions. A letter
from the UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to the
president of the assembly said the countries were barred
under the terms of Article 19 of the UN charter. 

Article 19 states: 'A member of the UN which is in arrears
in the payment of its financial contributions to the
organization shall have no vote in the General Assembly if
the amount of its arrears equals or exceeds the amount of the
contributions due from it for the preceding two full years.

'The General Assembly may, nevertheless, permit such a
member to vote if it is satisfied that the failure to pay is
due to conditions beyond the control of the member.' The
Secretary General's letter also contained the minimum
payments that must be made by the banned countries before
they can be allowed to vote.

The assembly exempted South Africa, whose total
outstanding contributions to the UN stood at about USD 61
million at the end of July. It said the country had been
exempted from the ban because the arrears accrued were 'due
to conditions beyond its control'.

The countries that were penalised, and their minimum
payments, in US dollars are: Burundi (47,300), Central
African Republic (98,900), Chad (195,800), Comoros (115,400),
Dominican Republic (568,000), Gambia (114,600), Guatemala
(44,628), Iraq (615,900), Liberia (302,200), Mali (68,300),
Niger (94,500), Sao Tome and Principe (115,300), Sierra Leone
(114,423), Somalia (267,600) and Yugoslavia (6,945,400).
