46 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Games Expose Race Division In Sport


LENGTH: 1014 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 22, 1995

HARARE - The Sixth All-Africa Games in Zimbabwe has
exposed deep-rooted racial divisions bedevilling sport in
Africa, particularly in southern part of the continent.

Botswana, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe, where the
indigenous majority population are still suppressed
economically by a European settler minority, have been
fielding teams of athletes mostly comprising Whites in such
sports as swimming, hockey, tennis, gymnastics, cycling and
shooting.

The assistant head of the South African delegation to the
games, Mvuzo Mbebe, says the complexion of largely white
teams will have to change to reflect the country's rainbow
population. 

'It is our intention that by the time we reach the next
Commonwealth Games (in 1998) the composition of the team
should be drastically changed,' he says.

South Africa has about 25 million blacks and five million
whites. There are also Indians and people of mixed race.

The new African National Congress-led government o
national unity, he says, has started a programme to build
basic sporting facilities in the poor black townships.

Sporting boards of what were viewed as largely elitist
games such as rugby and cricket have started building
facilities in the townships to introduce these disciplines.

The racial composition of Namibia's teams are similar to
South Africa's. The men's hockey team at the games comprises
white players and one of mixed race.

However, Team Manager Neil Dupless is says many black
Namibians are being trained in the sport.

'In seven years time we will see changes in Namibian
hockey. By that time a lot of youths would be playing the
sport,' he says.

South Africa's men's hockey team is predominantly white
with only one coloured. So is its men's and women's swimming
teams.

Racial division among spectators is also evident at hockey
tournaments. When the South African, Namibian and Zimbabwean
teams were playing huge crowds of spectators, mostly whites,
flocked to the Harare hockey stadium for these tournaments.
Few bothered when it was teams from other countries with
black players.

In shooting, Angola brought six contestants, two of them
of mixed race. Kenya brought four people in its shooting
squad --one of Indian origin, the rest whites. Namibia
brought 12 all of them whites. South Africa had eight
contestants, all whites. The same was true for Zimbabwe's 18The president of the Zimbabwe Shooting Federation, James
member squad. However, all 10 from Nigerian were blacks.
Cantlay, the high costs of firearms, pellets and targets was
the reason for the lack of black participation.

But efforts are being made to encourage Zimbabweans of all
races to participate, the chairman of the Zimbabwe Pistol and
Smallbore Association, Robert Green, says.

Already negotiations were underway with government to have
members of the police, the army and the air force
participate. They would reduce their costs by using
government issued firearms and ammunition for training and
competitions.

The president of the African Shooting Confederation,
Mounir Sabet of Egypt, says other African countries are now
encouraging the participation of their military and police in
competitive shooting.

The secretary-general of Athletics South Africa, Banele
Sindani, says while there had been no development of sports
facilities and athletics in black townships, the new
government of national unity is now redressing the imbalances
by providing facilities. This will be spread over 10 years.

But, he says, this would have to be weighed against other
urgent problems like providing social services and houses for
blacks.

'A lot has to be done, but it must be remembered that we
cannot develop sport in isolation, we have to develop other
areas too,' Sindani says.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


47 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Abacha: Uneasy Head That Wears Nigeria's Crown


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 22, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS - The 52nd birthday of Nigeria's military ruler Gen.
Sani Abacha passed off Wednesday without elaborate
celebration, but he used the anniversary to underscore the
burden of leadership in the populous West African country.

Abacha's Council of Ministers gave him a life-size card
and sang the traditional 'happy birthday' to mark the
occasion.

It was one of the few occasions at which the bespectacled
infantry general beamed in public.

Abacha was witty about the occasion, making it clear that
age depends on how an individual feels. 

'People can be 70 years and feel maybe, they are only
40... but for me, I am feeling as if I am already, maybe 80,
'said the man at the helm of the unenviable Nigerian ship of
state for almost two years.

In another word, Abacha was telling those who aspire to
leadership of the West African country, it is not a piece of
cake and can make one age faster than normal.

For a man not given to much public speech, even as head of
state, Abacha should be taken seriously on a subject on which
he can claim a measure of authority.

When he took power on 17 November 1993 in the heat of
political crisis unleashed by the cancellation of Nigeria's
June 1993 presidential election by the previous regime of
Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, Abacha must have hit many Nigerians
by storm.

Before then, critics gave him low marks as a potential
ruler, but those close to him in the army knew Abacha as a
'tough soldier'.

Analysts say Abacha's strength lay in his knowledge of the
workings of the Nigerian army from the grassroots to the top.

When Babangida 'stepped aside' on 26 August 1993, he left
the Ernest Shonekan-led interim government in a chaotic
political climate with Abacha as Defence Minister and the
second ranking member of the lame-duck administration.

The turmoil under Shonekan virtually left the country
rudderless with calls from some quarters for a military takeWhether by coincidence or by design, Abacha did not miss
over.
the opportunity to take control of a sinking ship.

He has gone ahead to demonstrate his toughness in the
subtle but decisive manner he has dealt with the opposition,
especially the striking oil workers' unions, whose executives
were sacked and replaced with government administrators
ending a strike which virtually paralysed the country in July
and August 1994.

With silence as his greatest weapon, Abacha has remained
an enigma, an unpredictable man who should not be
underestimated.

He has shown this in more ways than one. Not least in the
fact that Nigerian heavyweights such as former Head of State
Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo and his former deputy, Maj. Gen.
Shehu Musa Yar'dua or even millionaire-politician Moshood
Abiola are today in detention. Many Nigerians would have
considered this unthinkable a few years ago.

Abiola, who claimed victory in the annulled 1993
presidential election, is facing trial for treason after he
proclaimed himself President of Nigeria in June 1994 in
defiance of Abacha.

Obasanjo and Yar'adua on the other hand, are among a group
of 40 people convicted in July by a military tribunal for
involvement in an alleged plot to topple Abacha in March.

In response to calls from within and outside Nigeria for
the release of Abiola, Abacha said the trial would run its
course, while the fate of Obasanjo and other coup suspects
lies with the reconstituted policy-making Provisional Ruling
Council led by him.

These are already enough problems to make a 52-year-old
man age faster. Abacha also has to worry about Nigeria's
economic difficulties and the unresolved issue of returning
the west African country to democratic rule.

Nigerians may get an idea of where their ship is heading
on 1 October, the country's 35th independence anniversary,
and the day Abacha has chosen to disclose his political
programme.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Pretoria Wants Debts to UN Cancelled


LENGTH: 280 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 22, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - South Africa may be let off the look with
regards to some 100 million dollars it owes the United
Nations in dues accumulated during the 20 years it was
suspended from the world body.

The Johannesburg daily, 'the citizen', on Friday quotes
reports as saying an item to this effect had been recommended
to the ongoing UN General Assembly. 

The agenda item -- proposed by South Africa and approved
without vote by the Assembly's steering committee -- is
entitled 'normalisation of the situation concerning South
Africa', the paper said.

South Africa was suspended from the United Nations in
November 1974, because of its apartheid policy.

Pretoria reclaimed its Assembly seat in June last year,
after the installation of a democratic government led by
President Nelson Mandela.

Since then, it has paid contributions totalling 14.5
million dollars.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


49 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Algeria, South Africa In Hostile Exchanges


LENGTH: 614 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 22, 1995

HARARE - lurking hostility between South African and
Algerian athletes and officials reached breaking point on
Thursday afternoon when the two parties exchanged bitter
words at the Belvedere Teachers' College, venue of the Sixth
All-Africa Games gymnastics championships.

The tense atmosphere during the men and women's artistic
individual apparatus, pommel horse competition, cracked after
Algerian officials disputed a score awarded to their gymnast
and a South African.

The game was stopped for a while as the north Africans
flocked the judges and started pointing out errors made by
eventual gold medalist Zoltan Erdy with 9.0 points, arguing
that the panel comprising, a Chinese, German, Algerian,
Egyptian and two South Africans had favoured Erdy giving him
too high marks. 

In an interview later, they said Erdy sat on the horse,
flexed his knee and on a number of occasions hit the horse,
all faults for which he should have been heavily penalised.

Their gymnast, Mohamed Othmani who came second with 8.950
points, they said, had been cheated and awarded marks too low
for his performance.

South African officials did not take kindly to outbursts
about their gymnast and protested loudly resulting in a din
that attracted the police who moved in swiftly and watched
the brawl without intervening.

Competition Director, South Africa-based Johannes Cloete
quelled the noise without giving an opinion.

Chief Judge, Englishman Tom Smith said he stood by the
scores awarded by the judges, saying there was no need to
take the issue further to the committee of appeal because the
contested difference was small - a fraction of a point.

Algerian Abdelkader Mecellem who was in sixth place
boycotted the medals presentation ceremony and his officials
said the action was in protest of the earlier scuffle.

As medalists and finalists were called out to take the
irrespective places on the podium, Algerians hugged fellow
countrymen or neighbours Egypt while the most of a
congratulatory gesture to a South African was a handshake.

Not to be outdone, one South African finalist kept his
hands tightly clasped before him whenever a north African
gymnast was close enough to shake hands, but held out hands
warmly for compatriots or anyone from southern Africa like
Zimbabwe and Swaziland.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Racial Tension Strong In Soccer Final


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 22, 1995

HARARE - Zimbabwe's under-23 soccer team undertakes a do
or die mission when it confronts Egypt Saturday in the finals
of the Sixth All-Africa Games: The winner grabs the coveted
gold medal.

It will not be the first clash between Zimbabwe and Egypt
in the continent's sporting showcase.

During the 1991 games in Cairo, Zimbabwe's now senior
national team players Kennedy Nagoli and Agent Sawu
spearheaded a 2-1 victory over the Egyptians. 

That defeat prompted some racist remarks by sections o the
Egyptian media which described Zimbabweans as slaves.

In the preliminaries of the current games the Egyptians,
who pride themselves as Africa's soccer giants, were felled
2-1 by a more polished Zimbabweans out to prove that their
feat in Cairo was no fluke.

In Saturday's encounter Zimbabwe will want to prove that
the 'master' can, again, be beaten.

Zimbabwe has every reason to win. There will be a partisan
crowd expected at the 60,000-seat national sports stadium.
Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe has promised the players
generous incentives -- if they win.

Zimbabwe's young warriors are also motivated by the desire
to emulate the senior team which booted the Egyptians from he
1994 World Cup qualifiers in December 1993.

The Zimbabwe squad boasts the services of the exciting
Alois Bunjira and the shaven-headed Muteji twins, Cain and
Able, to deliver the goods.

In a reign of terror, the trio ran rings around Guinea's
defence Thursday in a 2-0 triumph.

Zimbabwe's dreadlocked Methembe Ndlovu is also expected to
dictate the pace in midfield.

Egypt, without their influential play-maker Hazem Emams
should find it difficult to make inroads into the tight
Zimbabwe defence marshalled by Captain Vusi Laher.

But whether or not Zimbabwe lives up to expectations can
only be decided on the final whistle at 5.30 p.m. (1500 gmt).

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Athletes' Huge Appetite Baffles Hosts


LENGTH: 534 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 22, 1995

HARARE - Athletes competing in the sixth All Africa Games
in Harare have baffled games village authorities at the
University of Zimbabwe with their huge appetites.

Since the games kicked off on September 13, the more than
3,400 athletes from 46 competing countries are consuming each
day more than twice the normal food intake of the university
students who are now off the campus on holiday.

Fredrick Kasese, the games village manager, said Friday
that the caterers had had to increase food provisions to
satisfy the demands of the sportsmen and women they are
hosting for the 10-day games. 

'The problem we had was that sportsmen are so different
from the students we are used to. They are eating more than
twice what our students consume normally,' said Kasese.

'These athletes, they have huge appetites, very huge
appetites but we have managed to cater for every taste to the
best of our ability.'

So huge is the appetite of the athletes that each day they
are consuming 2,400 kilogrammes of meat and have so far gone
through more than 12 tonnes of rice, 10 tonnes of mealie-meal
and Zimdollars 200 000 (USD 27,000) worth of fruits and
vegetables.

At least 6,000 litres of cooking oil or 30 drums have been
used in preparing food for the athletes who had to pay USD 30
per day for meals, accommodation, transport and laundry.

For breakfast, said Kasese, the athletes have so far eaten
7,500 dozens of eggs and 2,200 dozens of bread, washing this
down with unlimited quantities of soft drinks provided free
by the official beverage supplier to the games.

Kasese said that apart from a few isolated incidents his
guests have been 'very good, very friendly and sociable'.

The one blemish was when an athlete from a country he
would not name brought in a big bag and helped himself to
forks and plates bearing the university logo.

'We searched the bag and found these items, so we had a
chat with him. He apologised. He assumed the items were
souvenirs because of the university logo,' said Kasese.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

LENGTH: 146 words

HARARE - Zimbabwe's annualised inflation rate increased 2.1
percentage points to 23.7 percent between July and August,
the state-run Central Statistical Office has said.
Analysts projected that the year-on-year inflation rate
would surpass government's predicted inflation rate of 24.6
percent
. An analyst said drought would contribute to the rise in
inflation.

September, 1995


South Africa Multi-Million Dollar Chinese Investment


LENGTH: 227 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 25, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - China is to invest more than USD 60-million
in a South African mining venture.

South Africa's Northern Province Development Council says
China's Eastern Asia Metal Investment Corporation (EAMICO) is
joining it in a joint venture to revitalise the Dikolong
ferrochrome mine. Most of the money will be used to build a
smelter while the rest is spent on new shafts. The smelter
will provide an additional 400 jobs, rising to 750 within two
years. The smelted chrome will be sold in South Africa and on
the export market.

EAMIC, which is headquartered in Beijing, will receive a60
per cent equity stake in the mine for its investment
. The Dikolong mine is on the southern border of South
Africa's Northern Province.

South Africa Draft of New Constitution Due by November


LENGTH: 200 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 25, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - A working draft of South Africa's new
constitution is to be completed by November. 

This was disclosed by Constitutional Assembly chairman
Cyril Ramaphosa Sunday at a function held by Gauteng's Radio
702. Guateng Province includes Johannesburg, South Africa's
economic capital. Ramaphosa said the draft would be made
available for public comment at that stage, and the final
constitution should be approved by May next year.

'We have gone a long way in involving the public in the
constitution-making process,' he said. Ramaphosa said the
constitution would prevent abuses of power and provide for
efficient government.

Development Community countries converge on Harare from
September 29 to participate in a 10 day music festival.

A series of seminars and workshops will run concurrently
with the festival programme. The music festival is the first
ever organised by the regional grouping. A statement from the
festival directorate said 30 musicians from each of the 12
SADC countries had been selected by their respective national
associations.

Zimbabwe National Gallery sculpture gardens where record
companies, sound and lighting companies, instrument outlets,
music associations and other related industries will be able
to display their products,' said the statement.
The music expo is aimed at attracting and coordinating
investment in the music industry of the region. 'It aims to
highlight and strengthen the positive linkages between
foreign support organisations both government and nonthe statement.
governmental and musical institutions in the region, 'said

Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe Author In Hiding, Rushdie-style


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 25, 1995

BULAWAYO - Local author Elson Sibanda is in hiding for
writing a novel that depicts Zimbabwean society's
degenerating moral values.

The author of 'Maye Sidanisile', meaning how sorrowful in
the Ndebele language, is on the run Salman Rushdie-style,
after being harassed by some angry Bulawayo city residents.
They accused him of misrepresenting behaviour and sexual
patterns this, Zimbabwe's second city. 
 The city is the setting of the book that was published by
College Press in 1994. Sibanda told the Zimbabwe InterMutare,' a city in Eastern Zimbabwe, after being
Africa News Agency that he was forced to 'seek refuge in
'psychologically tortured' in August over the book. He
claimed that the Pumula suburb police in Bulawayo could not
protect him. But the police said they received no complaints.
'The incidents were initiated by one honourable within the
city council, in league with some unscrupulous business
people, the ZANU PF youth league and a chairman of Pumula
Residents Association, to name a few,' he said. ZANU PF if
the ruling Zimbabwe African National Union Patriotic Front
led by Rebert Mugabe, the country's president.

A college press official confirmed the allegations of
harassment which the author communicated to them. 'He
sounded very distressed in the letter that he wrote to us,'
the official said.
The official, who asked not to be named, said 'according to
the author some of those who harassed him questioned why he
wrote about Bulawayo in (the) Ndebele language when he is
Shona-speaking.'
Zimbabwe Writers Union Chairman David Mungoshi said he had
not received any complaints from Sibanda. 'But if that is
true it is unacceptable. We cannot have a few demagogues
deciding what a writer should and should no write,' he said.
If informed by Sibanda officially, Mungoshi said, the union
would intervene. Sibanda said he was prepared to testify and
identify the people who harassed him and forced him to flee.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

September, 1995


Burundi Power Lines Sabotaged


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 25, 1995

BUJUMBURA - Pylons in Zaire, from imports a third of its
electricity, have been damaged by saboteurs, Sylvere
Nzoyihera, the technical director of the national water
distribution company 'Regides' has said.

Nzoyihera said the sabotage had resulted in cuts of power
supplies to the industrial zone in Bujumbura and other parts
of the capital. 

Burundi's main hydro-electrical power plant in Rwegura in
the north-west was brought to a stand still after sabotage in
May.

Nzoyihero said Burundi was now functioning on half its
usual power supply.

A result has been frequent cuts in power supplies to
residential areas during the day to ensure regular supplies
to hospitals, water pumping and other vital installations.

Nzoyihero said inadequate security in the northwest could
mean the sabotage and disruption would persist.

Burundi, like Rwanda, has been torn by ethnic conflict
between the majority Hutu and the Tutsi minority.

economic situation in this country,' he said.

He said the delegation was interested mainly in
agricultural products.

The delegation was set to meetings officials from the
Zimbabwe Investment Centre.

Zimbabwe and Egypt now have direct air links.

59 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Politicians Discuss Future Of Nigeria by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent


LENGTH: 734 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 25, 1995

LAGOS - A cross-section of Nigerian politicians met here
Monday on the future of the restive populous west African
country, six days to 1 October, when military ruler Gen. Sani
Abacha is expected to unfold his political agenda.

Octogenarian politician Michael Ajasin, a key member of
the opposition National Democratic Coalition (NADECO), and
the co-ordinator of the meeting said he called the forum
tagged 'Pan-Nigeria Political Summit,' to narrow differences
between the 'conservative and progressive' political class.

The meeting, from which a communique is being expected,
was also called according to Ajasin, a former civilian state
governor, to create a 'formidable front for the survival' of
Nigeria's fourth republic.' 

But a number of key politicians including former Lagos
state civilian governor and an ex-works minister in the
Abacha regime, Lateef Jakande and his former agriculture
counterpart Adamu Ciroma shunned the meeting.

Ajasin told the gathering there would be no enduring
democracy and progress in Nigeria if politicians failed to
work as 'a united front.'

The former governor urged his colleagues to bury their
differences and 'recognise our common brotherhood and
citizenship and make that the basis of interaction and
political relationship.'

He said the military was able to repeatedly abort
democratic experiments in the country because of the 'patent
lack of unity among politicians.'

The army has ruled Nigeria for 25 years of its 35 years
independence from Britain.

Ajasin suggested that politicians of all persuasions 'must
be prepared jointly to frustrate any future ascession to
power by any means other than the ballot box,'.

On how to resolve the lingering political crisis arising
from the June 12, 1993 Presidential election annulled by the
previous military regime, he said the political class should
engage in over the political crisis, with detained
millionaire-politician Moshood Abiola, the acclaimed winner
of the annulled presidential poll playing a major role.

Ajasin also said the government should neither form
political parties nor limit the number of political parties
allowed to seek power under the new dispensation.

The former governor, who has been in the forefront of
NADECO's campaign for the exit of military, called on Abacha
to release all political detainees, including Abiola.

He also called for clemency for a group of 40 Nigerians
including former Head of State, Olusegun Obasanjo and his
former deputy, Shehu Musa Yar'Adua, convicted in July for
involvement in an alleged plot to topple Abacha in March.

Other key politicians at the meeting included another
civilian governor, Solomon Lar, former information minister
in the Abacha regime, Jerry Gana and Anthony Enahoro, another
NADECO leader.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September, 1995


U.S./Africa African-American Publishers Head for Nigeria


LENGTH: 680 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 26, 1995

NEW YORK - A team of African-American newspaper executives
and writers has left the United States on a fact-finding
mission to Nigeria.

Leavell, President of the Black National Newspaper
Publishers Association, said the team would also seethe
release of political prisoners in the West African state.

'We hope to bring back not only accurate news of what is
happening there, but we are seeking to have those who are
being held as prisoners released,' Leavell, who is also
delegation leader, said. 

A statement from the NNPA said the African-American
community in the United States was divided on how to respond
to Nigeria's political crisis.

This, it said, was partly due to its inability to verify
reports on the situation in the country, Africa's most
populous.

'The Black Press has noted that, to date, all reports
coming from and about Nigeria have come through the white
press and we don't feel their reports provide accurate
balance,' the NNPA said in explaining the mission.

Leavell said the trip to Nigeria 'takes place at a time of
historic opportunity to bring an objective, first hand look
at the situation 'offering information that the dominant
white(American) media has not made available to the public.'

Some 40 alleged plotters have recently been detained
following the Nigerian government's allegations of a recently
failed coup attempt.

Moshood Abiola, the millionaire politician assumed to have
won Nigeria's June 1993 presidential election, is also
languishing in jail as he awaits trial for alleged treason
for having declared himself the country's president last
year.

The arrests, including that of former head of state
Olusegun Obasanjo, have stirred international calls for
clemency from the United States President Bill Clinton, the
Pope, President Daniel Arap Moi of Kenya and Robert Mugabe of
Zimbabwe.

President Mandela recently sent South Africa's Deputy
President Thabo Mbeki to personally deliver his country's
appeals for democratization and freeing of alleged
conspirators to the Nigerian leader Gen. Sani Abacha.

Protests against the arrests have led to weekly pickets at
the Nigerian embassy in Washington. These have been organized
by TransAfrica, a black organization that played a key role
in the campaign for American sanctions against apartheid
South Africa.

Leavell's delegation was expected to arrive in Nigeria
Tuesday and leave October 3.

Zimbabwe U.S. Volunteers To Help Fill Manpower Shortage


LENGTH: 347 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 26, 1995

HARARE - An American volunteer organisation, Rafiki
Foundation, signed an agreement with Zimbabwe Tuesday to
provide the country with professionals in areas of critical
manpower shortages.

The foundation offers employment services for Christian
professionals who want to work in Africa. In Zimbabwe Rafiki
will provide staff in the medical, agricultural, surveying,
engineering and other related areas.

'We hope that the professionals will not only fill in the
critical manpower shortage areas by their presence but they
should have capacity building as their primary objective, '
said.

He is the public service, labour and social welfare
secretary and signed the deal on behalf of the Zimbabwe
government. Paul Bowers signed on behalf of Rafiki
foundation.

Where possible, Sibanda said, Zimbabweans should be given
a chance to understudy the Americans.

He said Rafiki had already expressed interest in ostrich
farming.

'These and other such projects will go a long way in
developing some of our underdeveloped areas, especially in
communal areas,' he said.

September, 1995


Sudan Detained Students Freed, Says Government


LENGTH: 280 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 26, 1995

KHARTOUM - Another 35 students detained for involvement in
recent riots have been freed after signing undertakings that
they will not take part in demonstrations or riots for a
year, a Khartoum daily reported Tuesday.

The paper, 'El Sudan El Hadeith', quoted a senior legal
official Amir Mohamed Irahim as saying the attorney general's
chamber had decided that the students be freed after they had
signed the pledges. They were the last still held by the
government, he said.

Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, in early September
witnessed large student protests that degenerated into riots.
Police said three people were killed in the rioting while 60
others were injured.

The government on Thursday released another 22 students
held after the rioting from detention.

They had been charged with disturbing public order, an
offence which carries between six and 12 months in jail,
fines or flogging.

September, 1995


Rwanda UNHCR to Step Up Refugee Repatriation


LENGTH: 347 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 26, 1995

DAKAR - The ministers of Rwanda and Zaire, meeting under
the auspices of the United Nations High Commission for
Refugees, on Monday said they would curb extremist activities
and provide security and protection to returnees.

A statement from the UNHCR cited a joint communique issued
at the close of the daylong tripartite commission meeting in
Geneva as saying the Zairian deputy prime minister Gerard
Kamanda wa Kmanda and the Rwandan Minister for Rehabilitation
and Social Integration Patrick Mazimhaka had reaffirmed
commitments to create the necessary conditions for the
repatriation of Rwandan refugees from Zaire. Kamanda is also
foreign minister.

The communique said Zaire pledged 'to reduce all forms of
intimidation' in the camps in Zaire said to be blocking
repatriation. Zaire is host to 1 million of the 1.8 Rwandan
refugees in Central Africa.

Rwanda had also agreed to ease the return of its refugees.

The UNHCR said its voluntary repatriation programme for
Rwandan refugees had started in December.

'More than 30,000 Rwandan refugees have returned under the
program which had been disrupted on several occasions by
security incidents in both Rwanda and Zaire. Another 220,000
have returned spontaneously,' it said in the statement.

Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Another Party Criticizes Govt Clause


LENGTH: 440 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

NDOLA - An opposition party, The Zambia United Opposition
Front (Zufro), warned that government is courting civil
disobedience by proposing a discriminatory clause in the
country's constitution that would effectively bar former
President Kenneth Kaunda from contesting elections.

Party Chairman Mike Kaira was commenting on a government
white paper on the draft constitution which said only people
whose parents were born Zambians could run for the
presidency. 

'We in Zufro will prove that the silent majority of our
people have rejected the discriminatory clauses, 'Kaira said.

Reporting this Tuesday, the Zambia News Agency said that
the proposal was made by the ruling Movement for Multiparty
Democracy headed by Frederick Chiluba.

Kaira said government should either call a referendum or a
constituent assembly to discuss the draft so the final
document would be legitimate. Failure to do so, he said, was
'undemocratic and unacceptable'.

Labour Party President Chibeza Mfuni said that since the
parliament was controlled by Chiluba's party there would be
no political diversity in the constitution if adopted by the
158-member parliament. Chiluba's party has 130 seats in the
legislature.

The government has rejected suggestions that a constituent
assembly adopt the current draft constitution, which it says
must be done by parliament.

If passed by legislators the law would bar Kaunda, the
country's first executive president, from contesting the
scheduled 1996 elections because his parents were Malawian
immigrants.

Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Hope Dims For Abiola and Coup Suspects


LENGTH: 854 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS - Nigeria' military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha in a
veiled response to mounting pleas on behalf of detained
millionaire-politician, Moshood Abiola and Nigerians
convicted for an alleged coup plot, has said the country's
law will take its course.

Abiola is facing trial for alleged treasonable felony
after proclaiming himself president of Nigeria in June 1994
based on the military annulled 1993 presidential election, in
which he claimed victory.

A group of 40 Nigerians, including former Head of State
Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo and his former deputy, Maj. Gen. Shehu
Musa Yar'adua, were on the other hand convicted for
involvement in the alleged conspiracy to topple Abacha in
March. 

Appeals for Abiola's release and clemency for the coup
suspects have been pouring from within and outside the
country.

Addressing traditional rulers from Lagos in Abuja, Monday,
Abacha said 'there must be respect for law and order in our
nation. Nobody should think that he is above the law.'

On Abiola, he said 'there is no political detainee in
Nigeria. Abiola committed treasonable felony. He swore
himself as a Head of State and was even making preparation to
form a parallel government.'

On the coup suspects, he said the government had taken
time to investigate the involvement of all the suspects 'so
that at the end of the day, justice would not only be done,
it must be seen to have been done.'

'It is time we started putting things right,' Abacha said
adding: 'people will go and incite innocent officers into
this sort of thing (coup plot) and stay behind so innocent
people will be arrested, tried and killed while those behind
them are free.'

A reconstituted policy-making Provisional Ruling Council
chaired by Abacha has yet to ratify the unspecified sentences
passed on the coup suspects by a military tribunal in July.

Abacha warned individuals or groups attempting to divide
the country, they would be doing so at 'their own peril.'

He reminded them that Nigerians fought a 30-month civil
war to keep the country together.

The 21-member delegation of traditional rulers included
the Oba (traditional ruler) Adeyinka Oyekan of Lagos,
chairman of the state council of traditional rulers.

Their visit coincided with a 'Pan-Nigeria Summit' in Lagos
Monday by a cross-section of Nigerian politicians, led by
octogenarian politician, Michael Ajasin, a leader of the proThe politicians issued a communique late Monday in Lagos
democracy National Democratic Coalition (nadeco).
calling for 'an all-civilian government to midwife a credible
transition to democracy,' in the west African country.

The forum suggested that Abiola be involved in the process
and negotiation between the military and the political class
to resolve the country's lingering political crises.

Abacha took power in November 1993 in the heat of the
political turmoil unleashed by the annulled presidential
election.

He has promised to unfold his political programme on
October 1, based on the report of a National Constitutional
Conference which submitted a draft constitution to him in
July.

HARARE - The Zimbabwe government hasten back to the money

'Tenders for the four-year stock issue close Friday. The
government's second stock issue, at the end of August, with a
22 percent coupon rate and a non-tradable five-year period,
attracted tenders worth Zimdollars 266.3 million (USD 31.3
million), but only ZD 84.4 million (USD 9.9 million) was
allotted.

'This is irrational. The government threw away Zd 182
million (USD 21.4 million) only to get back into the market
within four weeks for another stock issue with a higher
price, 'an analyst said.

Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Pretoria Hints It Will Not Join Comesa


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - South Africa will not join the Common
Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (Comesa), a senior
foreign affairs department official has hinted. The
official, Eben Van Rensburg, who is also his country's
Southern African Development Community (SADC) national
contact point coordinator said South Africa has not as yet
made a policy on Comesa membership. 

Van Rensburg told a visiting group of journalists from
SADC countries in Pretoria Tuesday night that it could have
been a great blunder for his country to have joined Comesa
after becoming a member of SADC.

'If we did that we could have slammed the door in the face
of SADC members,' Van Rensburg said.

Asked why South Africa had not pronounced its policy on
Comesa, Van Rensburg said the issue was not an urgent one for
his government has more urgent matters to deal with. The
effectiveness of Comesa, which groups some 22 eastern and
southern African states, is likely to be undermined if South
Africa, the most advanced economy in the region, does not
become a member. Out of SADC's 12 members only South Africa
and Botswana are not members of Comesa. Botswana, which hosts
the SADC secretariat, has made it clear that it will not join
Comesa. Botswana and the SADC secretariat claim that Comesa
is too large to be effective. Meanwhile, South Africa has
suggested that the SADC secretariat be expanded to improve
efficiency.

Van Rensburg said the current situation under which most
of SADC's work is done by sector coordinators was not
effective. Sector coordinators are full-time civil servants
who are preoccupied with their national duties, he said. Van
Rensburg added that most governments did not budget for
sector coordination expenses.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Minister Dismisses Drug Charges Against Athletes


LENGTH: 747 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS - Nigerian Youth and Sports Minister Jim Nwobodo
Tuesday refuted media reports that the country lost three
medals from two of its athletes who allegedly tested positive
at the just-ended Sixth All-African Games in Harare,
Zimbabwe.
Addressing a press conference on Nigeria's performance at
the Pan-African games, Nwobodo, who led Nigeria's 500-strong
contingent dismissed the press reports as untrue.
He said what happened in one of the two cases was that 'we
were informed that a Nigerian athlete had tested positive to
banned drugs in the first test and a confirmatory test was to
be carried out the next day.' 
 However, he added, 'in the letter, the (tournament
identification) number of the athlete did not correspond with
that of the athlete named.'
He said that the number 'did not belong to any Nigerian
athlete.' Nwobodo said the Supreme Council for Sports in
Africa, the only body empowered to make a final decision on
drug use cases, 'has already said that it has not taken a
decision on the matter. As such, Nigeria has not 'repeat not'
been stripped of any medal at all.'
In the case of the second Nigerian athlete alleged to have
tested positive, the minister said: 'The circumstances are
even more questionable than the first because the letter
communicating the result of the test was written even before
the competition in question took place.'
Nwobodo said that the council was 'still considering these
cases and we are confident that justice will be done.'
Nigeria grossed a total of 106 medals, including 37 gold, 26
silver and 43 bronze to place third behind frontrunners South
Africa and second-placed Egypt in the four-yearly tournament.
The West African country hauled most of its medals in
athletics with a total 32 medals -- 15 gold, nine silver and
eight bronze.
It took part in 19 of the 21 events at Harare '95, winning
medals in all but five.
Nigeria, however disappointed fans in the soccer
tournament. It entered the competition as a favourite but
only managed a bronze, with host Zimbabwe as runners-up to
tournament champions, Egypt.
Nwobodo conceded that Nigeria ought to have done better in
soccer.
'I am aware that our team was intimidated and unfairly
treated by match officials, in spite of that, I still feel
that we should have presented a better team,' he said.
According to Nwobodo the 'gains and pains of major
championships such as the All-Africa Games transcend the
arithmetic of gold, silver and bronze. It goes deep into such
areas as politics, diplomacy, public relations and sometimes,
even outright deceit.'
The Nigerian delegation of officials and mainly home-based
athletes to Harare returned home late Monday.

Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Locust Threatens harvests in Africa's Sahel


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Aly Coulibaly, PANA Correspondent

DAKAR - Locust have cut a swath thousands of kilometres
wide across farmland and threaten to destroy thousands more
in the Western Sahel, a area running from Senegal in the West
to Niger in the East. The acting technical director for the
Organisation for Locust Control, Balla Niang, said Tuesday in
Dakar that a large swarm of desert locust was sighted Monday
south of the Mauritanian capital, Nouakchott.

The yellow-coloured crop munching insects, he said, had
already eaten their way over an area 8,200 kilometres long
and 5,500 kilometres wide. There are between 15 and 20
couples of locusts per square kilometre. Just south of
Mauritania, he said, more locusts have been seen in Senegal. 

'The swarms are a serious threat on unharvested crops and
other agricultural activities along the river such as tree
nurseries, forestry and rice farms,' he said. 'The situation
could worsen as the majority of small swarms will be winged
within the next few days,' he added.

Swarms formed in the south-west of Mauritania were
reported in northern Senegal in mid-September destroyed
27,000 hectares of crops.

Locusts, a genus of grasshoppers, have already devoured
crops in Mali, Mauritania and Niger. They were sighted in
Mali April up to a 100 kilometres inland in the far northmid-April in some areas after the March rains. The areas
west of the country. Hatches were reported in Mauritania in
invaded were estimated at some 1,000 hectares. In Niger, very
dense larva spots were sighted in March the same month. West
Africa's locust control body in unable to stem the tide of
the invaders because it lacks money. So, it has made appeals
for international help but so far none has been forthcoming.

The body, known by its acronym Oclalav, was created in
1964. It comprises Burkina Faso, Benin, Cameroon, Chad, Cote
d'Ivoire, Gambia, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Senegal.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


70 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Africans Call For Reform Of UN Security Council


LENGTH: 787 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Staff Correspondent

UNITED NATIONS - African members of the United Nations
security council say they want the group expanded to
represent a greater diversity of world regions and reformed
to make it more efficient.

Nigeria and Rwanda, two of the three African nations on
the 15-member council on a non-permanent basis, said Africa
should get a permanent seat on the body.

'Africa deserves to be adequately represented at the
permanent membership of the council,' Nigerian Foreign
Minister Tom Ikimi said Tuesday. 

He was addressing a special commemorative meeting. to mark
the UN's 50th anniversary.

The council's working methods and procedures, he added,
needed to be improved 'to enhance its effectiveness,
efficiency, legitimacy and transparency.'

Rwanda's permanent UN representative, Manzi Bakuramutsa,
urged the world body to review its objectives and revise its
programmes.

'For as long as equitable justice for all does not
existing the world, there will be no social and economic
development for the enjoyment of all, and peace and security
will remain empty words,' he said.

The council has said that the UN must be strengthen and
revitalised to help meet the challenges facing the
international community.

In a presidential statement read on its behalf by Agnelli,
the council also said there was need to review its own
functions as well as to expand its membership to enhance 'its
representative character and improve its working efficiency
and transparency.'

In reaffirming its commitment to the UN charter, the
council said: 'On the solemn occasion of the 50th anniversary
of the UN, the council, along with other UN bodies,
commemorates what has been achieved so far, but also commits
itself once again to the maintenance of international peace
and security for which it has primary responsibility.

Botswana, Africa's third council member, said that though
the UN had been able to prevent major wars it had failed in
stopping regional ones. These, it said had claimed more lives
than were lost during the second world war.

The country's foreign minister, Mompati Merafhe, said,
however, that the parties to regional wars must bear the
larger share of responsibility for failure of maintenance of
international peace and security.

The meeting, in which 12 of the 15 foreign ministers of
council members were present, was presided over by Susanne
Agnelli, the Italian foreign minister. The country holds the
presidency of the council for the month of September.

The five permanent council members are the United States,
Russia, Britain, France and China. Non-permanent members
represented by ministers were Argentina, Botswana, Germany,
Indonesia, Italy, Honduras and Nigeria.

One member, the Czech republic, was represented by its
deputy foreign minister, while Rwanda and Oman were
represented by their permanent representatives at the UN.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Nigerian Teachers Vow To Continue Strike


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Nigeria Union of Teachers(NUT) says
its 10-day-old nationwide strike will continue until
government responds to the members' demands.

NUT President Brendan Ugwu, who read a communique at the
end of the union's emergency meeting in Lagos Tuesday, said
the teachers decided to continue the strike begun 18
September until specific processes to meet their demands were
instituted by the Federal Government. 

The Union with an estimated 400,000 members has made a
five-point demand, including payment of arrears of salaries
and allowances owed its members, the creation of a Teachers
'Registration Council and a new salary structure.

Ugwu said a committee had been set up to continue dialogue
with the government and its agencies on the teachers'
demands.

He, however, commended the government for releasing money
for part payment of the teachers' relief allowance due from
October 1994.

Meanwhile, Nigeria's National Primary Education Commission
says it has disbursed funds to all primary education boards
in the country's 30 states to pay three out of the six
months' arrears of the relief package.

Most of Nigeria's primary and secondary schools affected
by the teachers' strike are currently on holiday.

They were scheduled to resume classes late September or
early October.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Carter Pleads For Obasanjo's Release


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Gabu Amacha, PANA Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA - Former United States President Jimmy Carter
appealed Wednesday to Nigeria's Military ruler to show
clemency and release that country's former leader, Olusegun
Obasanjo.

'I urge Abacha to release Obasanjo, one of the greatest
leaders of Africa,' Carter said. 

He was speaking at a workshop in Addis Ababa, the
Ethiopian capital, discussing ways of getting African farmers
to use agricultural research to increase crop yields.

Obasanjo, a retired army general and his former second in
command, Maj. Gen. Shehu Musa Yar'Adua, are among 40 alleged
coup plotters being held by the administration of Gen. Sani
Abacha.

Abacha came to power in a coup d'etat.

Obasanjo, who governed Nigeria from 1976 to 1979 after the
assassination of the previous military ruler, is the only
soldier to restore power to an elected civil administration.
He has been a vocal critic of continued military rule.

Several world leaders have appealed to Abacha for clemency
but he insists that the fate of the accused will be
determined by the courts. Abacha has said that the law
applied in trying Obasanjo was enacted by the accused in
1976.

Carter has visited Nigeria to make a personal plea for
Obasanjo's release, and that of other detainees, and
Wednesday urged participants at the workshop 'to join in
prayers for his release.'


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Press Council Wants Detained Journalists Freed


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS - The Nigerian Press Council (NPC)Wednesday urged
the military government to free all detained journalists in
the spirit of the nation's independence celebration.

Nigeria will be 35 years on 1 October. 

The Council in a statement after its 17th business meeting
here said the independence celebration should bring
'forgiveness and re-dedication to the service of the
fatherland.'

A number of journalists have been detained for various
reasons. Among those held for publishing stories linked to
the alleged coup plot in the country in March, is Chris
Anyanwu, publisher of the private weekly 'TSM' magazine.

Two Lagos-based publications, -- 'Concord Press' and
'Punch' have also been banned for more than a year.

The NPC in reviewing the state of the media in Nigeria
urged government to de-proscribe the two newspapers.

It commended the government for de-proscribing a third
Lagos newspaper, 'The Guardian', which is resuming production
in October after an 11 months.

The Council said during the meeting, it adjudicated 18
cases involving false publication and indiscretion in news
judgment.

The Council was set up to uphold professional standards
and recommend remedies from injurious publications.

September, 1995


Cote d'Ivoire Pleimelding Contract With Ivorian Elephants Confirmed


LENGTH: 240 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

Abidjan - The President of the Ivorian Football Federation
(FIF), Dieng Oussenou, has confirmed the appointment of
Frenchman Pierre Pleimelding as Coach of Cote D'Ivoire's
national soccer team, the 'Elephants'.

Dieng said at a press conference in Abidjan Tuesday that
the new coach will spearhead preparations of the 'Elephants'
for the 20th edition of the Africa Nations' Cup (CAN)
scheduled to take place in South Africa in January 1996. 

He said training will commence on 4 December in
Yamoussoukro, the capital.

Thereafter, the team will travel abroad, probably in a
country whose climate is similar with that of South Africa,
for further preparations, he said.

Dieng also promised to stamp out violence during national
soccer matches.

75 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Sudan Government And Rebels Says They Want War Ended


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

DAKAR, Senegal - The Sudanese government and its strongest
political opponents agreed Tuesday to build an atmosphere
conducive to peace in this war-torn country.

The agreement came in a declaration drafted during a
symposium in Barcelona, Spain, on building 'a culture of
peace'. 

Excerpts of the Barcelona declaration, received Wednesday
by the Pan African News Agency, says that 'the cultural,
ethnic, linguistic and religious diversity of Sudan, is a
potential wealth of the country and should positively reflect
in the constitutional and in institutions.'

It condemns 'all kinds of intolerance and totalitarianism'
and urges signatories to cooperate with the Intergovernmental
Authority for Development and Drought Control of East Africa
in negotiating peace in Sudan.

The declaration was adopted unanimously by some 30
participants. They included representatives of the Sudanese
government, the rebel Sudanese People Liberation Movement and
the Union of African Parties of Sudan.

The 12-year Sudanese civil war has claimed 500,000 lives
and left sent thousands into refuge in neighbouring
countries.

The meeting, in Barcelona, Spain, was organized by the
United Nations Education and Scientific Organisation, UNESCO.
It was supported by the United Nations Development Programme
and the Spanish government.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia Political Pressure Group Criticises Constitutional White Paper


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Forum for Democratic Process(FODEP),
a leading Zambian political pressure group, has criticised
government's insistence to have the new republican
constitution adopted by parliament, instead of a constituent
assembly, as recommended by the constitutional review
commission.

Briefing the press in Lusaka Thursday, FODEP president
Foston Sakala charged that the government had an inescapable
moral obligation to listen to the people's aspirations to
have a constitution which would be adopted by all the Zambian
interest groups. Sakala said that this could be possible
only if the draft constitution was submitted to a constituent
assembly and national referendum, as recommended by the
Mwanakatwe Commission which had prepared the current draft. 

"It would be a sheer waste of money and resources and
embarrassingly retrogressive for Zambia to be re-writing the
constitution every time there was a new government in power,
'Sakala said suggesting that the proposed constitution could
be shortlived if it did not enjoy wider consensus.

The government last Monday released a white paper in which
it rejected the idea of a constituent assembly adopting the
constitution but recommended that this be done by parliament.

It also upheld a submission earlier made to the commission
by the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy of President
Frederick Chiluba that only second-generation Zambians should
in future be eligible to run for the republican presidency.
The latter recommendation has been widely criticised by the
Zambian opposition and other sectors of the society who say
it would be an infringement on individual rights. The
submission has also been condemned as aimed at preventing
former president Kenneth Kaunda from challenging Chiluba in
the 1996 presidential election.

Kaunda is a Zambian by birth but both of his parents were
Malawian immigrants who settled in northern Zambia as
missionaries at the close of the 19th century.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia UNIP to Field Kaunda for Presidency


LENGTH: 614 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's main opposition United National
Independence Party (UNIP) maintained in Lusaka Thursday that
it will field former president Kenneth Kaunda in the
scheduled 1996 presidential election despite what it called
'the virulent campaign' by the ruling party against Kaunda
which said was intended to portray him as a foreigner and
'devil'. UNIP Secretary-General Sebastian Zulu, speaking at
a press briefing Thursday, charged that the ruling Movement
for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) of President Frederick Chiluba
had orchestrated a shameless hate campaign against Kaunda.
He said that the campaign has now climaxed in the ruling
party's draft republican constitution seeking to bar Kaunda
from contesting the presidency and vowed that his party would
do everything for Kaunda to stand. 

'We shall use every legal means in our power and
politically so that nothing stops Dr Kaunda from contesting
the presidency next year,' said Zulu who is himself one of
Zambia's most prominent constitutional lawyers.

The government has recommended in a white paper on the
draft constitution that only second generation Zambians
should be allowed to contest the presidency.

Kaunda has Malawian parents but is himself a Zambian by
birth.

Zulu said that it was illogical that the MMD could want to
bar Kaunda from seeking to contest the presidency after 31
years of independence whose achievement Kaunda had himself
spearheaded.

'Kaunda led Zambia for 27 years and everything you see in
Zambia was brought by Kaunda, how can anyone turn around now
and accuse him of being a foreigner?' said Zulu.

He said that the right to choose Zambia's president lay
with Zambians themselves and accused the ruling party of
attempting to usurp this right. He said the move could be a
recipe for civil strife, chaos and social disorder in the
country.

Kaunda himself Wednesday reiterated that he would 'fight
the bitter end' to have the citizenship clause relating to
presidential elections deleted from the constitution.

'We are ready to fight...The people of Zambia have fought
such tyranny before. The settlers (British) thought they
could sit on our rights...They were more powerful but we
fought them and won,' said Kaunda in Lusaka Wednesday.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


78 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large World Bank to Bail Out United Nations ?


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

UNITED NATIONS - The United Nations, its most severe
financial crisis since it was founded in 1945, could borrow
money from the World Bank to pay some of its debts.

Joseph Connor, the UN Under-Secretary-General for
Administration and Management, said in an interview published
by The New York Times Thursday that a World Bank loan was one
of the many ideas being explored 'to lift from our shoulders
the burden of debt.' 

He said although the UN had borrowed small amounts of
money in the past for specific development projects, there
was no precedent for the loan being proposed. Connor's
statement on the World Bank loan confirmed the one by
Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, in another interview
on Saturday, that he planned to meet the World Bank president
James Wolfensohn this weekend to discuss the proposal.

'This crisis cannot be solved unless we borrow money, 'the
Secretary-General was quoted as saying. Meanwhile, the U.S.,
which owes 1.2 billion dollars of the 3.4 billion dollars
owed to the UN in unpaid assessments, is expected to object
to the move to borrow money from the World Bank.

The bank is technically a part of the UN system but
operates with considerable independence.

'The UN and the Secretary-General have no authority to
borrow externally,' the newspaper quoted an American diplomat
assaying. 'Borrowing from the World Bank is restricted to
sovereign governments.'


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

by Mildred Mulenga, PANA Staff Correspondent

Briefing the press in Lusaka Thursday, FODEP president
Faustian Sakala charged that the government had an
inescapable moral obligation to listen to the people's
aspirations to have a constitution which would be adopted by
all the Zambian interest groups. Sakala said that this could
be possible only if the draft constitution was submitted to a
constituent assembly and national referendum, as recommended
by the Mwanakatwe Commission which had prepared the current
draft. 

'It would be a sheer waste of money and resources and
embarrassingly retrogressive for Zambia to be re-writing the
constitution every time there was a new government in power,
'Sakala said suggesting that the proposed constitution could
be shortlived if it did not enjoy wider consensus.

The government last Monday released a white paper in which

It also upheld a submission earlier made to the commission

in future be eligible to run for the republican presidency.
The latter recommendation has been widely criticised by the

Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe Natural Farming Methods Advocated


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

HARARE - With rising input costs beyond the reach of many
communal farmers, an organisation promoting permaculture said
on Thursday natural farming methods could restore Zimbabwe to
its position a leading producer of food for Southern Africa.
While the recurrent droughts have been attributed to
inadequate rainfall, Enita Chimanikire of the Natural Farming
Network (NFM) said yields had been affected by the soil's
increased dependency on chemicals. 
'Right now most of the soils in Zimbabwe cannot produce
anything without the introduction of chemicals like
fertilisers, 'Chimanikire said.
She said NFN was training farmers to revert to old-fashioned
agriculture of crop rotation, composts and inter-cropping.
However, because of the damage done to the soil by chemicals,
at least four or five years were needed for the soil to
recover before benefits of the natural farming methods could
be felt.
The method had proved effective with small gardens and
initial trials to test suitability on large tracts of land
had yielded positive results.
'Composts work for small gardens, but for large fields, we
always say farmers should plant maybe maize, legumes and
other crops to promote inter-cropping and improve nutrition,'
she said. Sometimes worms had to be introduced to speed up
decomposition and eventually enrich the impoverished soil
while plants like mustard that attracted pest eating insects
were grown boost this ecological system.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

September, 1995


South Africa Optimistic Gold Mining Outlook


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - Leaders in South African gold mining are
optimistic about the industry's future, despite the problems
it faces.
Anglo-American Executive Director Bobby Godsell says the
list of challenges facing the gold-mining industry is
daunting, but by no means unmanageable. 
 Goldfields of South Africa Chairman Robin Plumbridge says
in the group's annual review that key participants will have
to work together if the country is to remain a major world
player in mining.
South Africa's mining house heads agree that the industry
could improve substantially if the challenges of labour
demands and aging ore reserves are met.
'It is perfectly possible,' said Godsell of Anglo-American,
'that in a generation's time South Africa will have a
vibrant, profitable gold-mining industry that is both world
class and of world significance'.

Africa News


September, 1995


Comores Island European Mercenaries Invade Comoros


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR - Fighting has been reported in Moroni, capital of
the Indian Ocean Island state of Comoros, where a group of
white mercenaries tried to overthrow the government early
Thursday.

Diplomatic sources in Moroni said President Mohamed Djohar
was still being held by the mercenaries led by the Frenchman,
Col. Bob Denard. 

The prime minister and some members of his cabinet are
reported to have taken refuge in French Embassy in Moroni.

They said gunshots and mortar fire could still be heard in
the capital as government troops tried to dislodge of
fortune.

In Paris the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, Hervede
Charette, condemned the act but failed to indicate if the
government was going to intervene.

France, the former colonial master maintains a defence
pact with Comoros, and French troops are responsible for the
president's security.

Djohar has been in office since November 26 1989 when he
was democratically elected to rule the 500,000 Arabs,
Africans, East Indians who make up the population of the
Archipelago.

The islands were controlled by Moslem sultans until the
French acquired them between 1841 and 1909. They became a
French overseas territory in 1947.

In a 1974 referendum on independence 93 per cent of
Comorians voted for independence. Only the Christian island
of Mayotte, with a 63-percent-vote opted to stay with France.

However, France decided that the voting would be followed
by one on each of the four islands rather than accepting the
results of the overall vote.

Rejecting this arrangement, Comoros declared its
independence in July 1975 with Ahmed Abdallah as President.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa-At-Large Unesco Announced Prizes For Children's And Teenage Literature


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

DAKAR - Unesco initiated on Thursday two literature prizes
for children and teenagers in the service of tolerance,
according to a statement from the organisation released to
PANA in Dakar.

The Spanish Foundation Santa Maria/Ediciones S.M. will
give USD 8,000 dollars to each prize winner. One prize will
reward books for children under 12 years of age, and the
other goes to books for those aged between 13 and 18.

Santa Maria S.M., the statement added, is one of the
leading publishers of books and manuals for children in Spain
and in Latin America.

Unesco will appoint an international jury including
eminent writers, illustrators, editors, translators, book
specialists and people working for the promotion of tolerance
and peace, to pick the prize winners.

Wole Soyinka, the 1986 Nobel prize winner for literature
and a Unesco goodwill ambassador, and Zlata Filipovich, a 14translated into 38 languages, have accepted membership of the
year old girl whose diary on daily life in Sarajevo was
jury.

Starting April 1997, the prizes will be awarded every two
years by Unesco in Elogne, Italy.

In the same statement, Unesco invited publishers to submit
a maximum of one book in each category, for the competition.

Africa-At-Large UN May Have To Borrow From The World Bank


LENGTH: 320 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Segun Adeyemi PANA Correspondent

New York - The United Nations, currently experiencing its
most severe financial crisis since it was founded some 50
years ago, may borrow money from the World Bank to pay some
of its debts, an official has said.

The official, Joseph Connor, the UN Under-Secretaryinterview that a World Bank loan was one of many ideas being
General for administration and management, said in an
explored 'to lift from our shoulders the burden of debt.' 

Connor's statement on the World Bank loan confirmed the
one by the UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, in
another interview on Saturday, that he planned to meet the
new World Bank President, James Wolfensohn, this weekend to
discuss the proposal.

'This crisis cannot be solved unless we borrow money, 'the
Secretary-General was quoted as saying.

Official statistics showed that the UN is owing millions
of dollars, including money for peace-keeping operations.

The World Bank on the other hand is owed some 3.4 billion
dollars in unpaid assessments, with the United States owing
the largest amount of 1.2 billion dollars

September 29, 1995

HARARE - The Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe has approved
applications from eight companies wishing to become foreign
exchange brokers.

The brokers bring together buyers and sellers of foreign
exchange for a fee.

This development is expected to stimulate efficiency in
Zimbabwe's hard currency market following increased
liberalisation of the financial market, a bank representative
said.
