LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


86 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Games Expose Racism Both Sides Of The Saharan Divide


LENGTH: 1107 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Tambayi Nyika PANA Correspondent

BULAWAYO - The fanfare of the just ended Sixth All-Africa
Games in Zimbabwe was at times marred by racial tension
between participants from the predominantly Arabized north
and indigenous Black Africa, diluting the solidarity expected
of the continent.

This animosity is not new though it has scarcely been
acknowledged at official levels where diplomacy takes
precedence. It has maintained an invisible presence that only
erupts when the ego of either side is challenged.

This was evident during competitions involving sub-Sahara
countries against those from North Africa. Racial slurs and
even physical scuffles disrupted the flow of the games. 

The schism extended to spectators with those from the
North backed their counterparts and vice versa.

'He is a terrorist,' shouted Nigeria's head of delegation,
Musa Bogonyaro, at an off duty Tunisian referee who had
assaulted him.

The Algeria/Guinea soccer match exploded into a full-scale
battle during which Algerians hurled racial slurs like 'black
monkeys' and accompanied these with the most obscene and
humiliating signs.

In a fit of rage, Guinean striker Fode Camara spat in the
face of an Algerian player, earning himself a red card.
Algeria's Tarek Ghoul and Holine Bouaicha were suspended for
two matches and their team fined 1,500 U.S. dollars.

The slurs reminded Zimbabweans of Egyptian newspaper
reports during the 1991 Cairo games which said Zimbabwean
teams and brought monkey meat.

As the fight ensued, Zimbabwean spectators joined Guineans
supporters shouting 'Fundamentalists, Fundamentalists' and
'Guinea is Africa.'

Nigeria's vollyball coach Olatunde Fakuade said, 'because
of some traces of white blood, the North Africans always
think of us in terms of slaves.

'In general North Africans do not want to accept defeat
and always think they are superior to Black Africans.'

The assault on the Nigerian head of delegation, Musa
Bogonyaro by an off duty Tunisian coach was a result of a
trivial conflict.

Bogonyaro was cheering Nigeria against Cameroon. The
Tunisian then told him 'shut up.' A scuffle ensued and
Bogonyaro called the Tunisian a 'terrorist' in a spiteful
manner.

Just before the end of the games, the Egyptian Boxing
Federation was forced to apologise after that country's
newspapers reported that their boxers were afraid of
contracting aids if they fought South Africans.

The South Africans hit back and accused Egypt of being
jealous of its performance as Egypt had previously dominated
the games.

While the Egyptians have been quick to apologise to South
Africa and Zimbabwe, the views of their newspapers have been
generally attributed to the 'superiority complex' North
Africans harbours over Sub-Sahara Africa.

Black African soccer teams, which have been the perennial
underdogs of the North, have consistently complained of bias.

The headquarters of the Confederation of African Football
is in the Egyptian capital, Cairo, and is mostly staffed by
North Africans.

Suspicion is such that whenever there is a soccer match
involving teams from North Africa against those of subthe nationality of the referee.
Sahara, the latter's spectators generally first want to know

If he happens to come from North Africa, sub-Saharans
attribute questionable decisions to the North's complex of
superiority and prejudice rather than genuine mistakes.

However, the tension is invisible at the sublime political
level where both sub-regions belong to several bodies like
the Organisation of African Unity.

They even agree on bloc votes at the United Nations
inmates of political and economic importance to Africa.
Apolitical cleavage has only been evident over the Sudan
conflict.

An example of this is Sub-Sahara Africa's support for John
Garang's Sudan People's Liberation Army. The guerrillas
fighting for a secular state want autonomy for the South.

This demand has been attributed to the Garang's opposition
to the spread of rigid Islamic edicts throughout the country
by the regime of Omar El-Bashir.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


87 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa South Africa Condemns Comoros Government Ouster


LENGTH: 827 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

PRETORIA - The South African Government has called for
the immediate restoration of the elected government of the
Comoros.

This follows Thursday's coup in the Indian Ocean Islands
by rebels apparently led by veteran French mercenary Bob
Denard.

A spokeswoman Nicole Kritzinger said in a statement the
South African government 'is most concerned at the events in
the Comoros, which constitute a setback for peace in Africa. 
The South African Government will support international
attempts to restore democratic government in the Comoros'.

The statement added that the South African government
deplored the reported use of force and threat to democratic
order in the Comoros, and appealed to those responsible to
immediately desist from their actions and for life and
property to be respected.

Meanwhile, a decision was expected later Friday on how
more than 100 South Africans in the Comoros will be
evacuated. Radio reports monitored in Pretoria suggested that
the airport in the capital, Moroni, could be opened Saturday.

The latest news from the Comoros was that fierce fighting
was still raging in Moroni, although only 20 mercenaries were
believed to be involved. The rebels were reported to have
seized control of the military base there and were still
holding President Mohamed Djohar.

The mercenaries, said to be Europeans and led by Denard,
were reported to have seized the presidential palace and the
radio station in the capital early Thursday.

Denard, a French national, is infamous for his work as a
mercenary in Africa, the Arabian peninsula and in other
areas.

In Paris, the French Minister of Foreign Affairs Herve de
Charette condemned Denard's action but failed to say if the
government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe would intervene.

France, the former colonial power, maintains a defence
pact with Comoros and French troops are responsible for the
president's security.

has been in office since November 26 1989 when he was
democratically elected president to rule the Comoros
population of some 500,000 Arabs, Africans, and Indians.

There have been 17 successful and failed coups in Comoros
since it gained independence in 1975. Denard, 66, has
participated in all of them.

Denard, who was born in Belgium but later obtained French
nationality, was in 1990 sentenced to five years in prison in
absentia by the French government for trying to topple the
government of Benin in West Africa in 1977.

The Comoros were controlled by Moslem sultans until the
French acquired them between 1841 and 1909. They became a
French overseas territory in 1947.

In a 1974 referendum on independence, 93 per cent of
Comorians voted for independence. Only the Christian island
of Mayotte, with a 63-percent-vote, opted to stay with
France.

However, France decided that the voting would be followed
by one on each of the four islands rather than accepting the
results of the overall ballot.

Rejecting this, Comoros declared its independence in July
1975 with Ahmed Abdallah as President.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


88 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe Journalist In Court On Extortion Charges


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

MUTARE - Sam Shumba, a journalist working for Modus
Publications, in Mutare, Eastern Zimbabwe, has appeared
before a Mutare magistrate on allegations of extorting
zimdollars 15,000 (USD 1,760) from a businessman who did not
want a story on his conviction in court published.

Shumba (35), who is the Mutare Bureau Chief of Modus
Publications, which owns the Financial Gazette and the Sunday
Gazette, was not asked to plead to a charge under the
prevention of corruption act or, alternatively, extortion
when he appeared before senior magistrate Oliver
Mudzongachiso. 

He was remanded out of custody on ZD 500 (USD 60) bail and
October 30 was set for trial.

Prosecutor Teclar Mapota said on May 6, Shumba was at the
Mutare magistrates' court covering a story in which a
Zimbabwean businessman, Robin Douglas Waddacor, was being
charged for contravening a section of the miscellaneous
offences act.

After Waddacor was convicted and sentenced to a fine of ZD
250 (USD 30), Shumba allegedly approached him and threatened
to publish the story unless he was paid some money. He then
allegedly demanded ZD 15,000.

Three days later, Waddacor allegedly paid ZD 15,000 to
Shumba in the presence of one Caesar Manyuchi, who had been
jointly charged with Waddacor.

Waddacor's story never saw the light of day, according to
the prosecution.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


89 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Comores Islands OAU Condemns Comoros Coup


LENGTH: 694 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Gabu Amacha PANA Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia- The Organization of African Unity
(OAU) Friday condemned the attempted coup d'etat in the
Comoros Thursday and said the act constituted a serious and
regrettable set-back to the democratic aspirations of the
people of the island nation.

'The OAU strongly condemns this act of destabilization and
the use of mercenaries in a member state and calls for a
rapid and unconditional restoration of the constitutional
order in the Comoros,' the OAU said in a statement.

The statement quoted OAU Secretary General, Salim Ahmed
Salim as having expressed deep concern that 'a group of
mercenaries are yet again involved in staging a coup d'etat
in the Comoros'. 

Salim called for the immediate and unconditional release
of President Mohamed Said Djohar and other government
officials held hostage and urged the 'international community
to assist in ensuring the return of stability and normalcy in
that country'.

The infamous mercenary Bob Denard and some 20 others were
believed to be behind the coup attempt.

In Paris, the French Minister of Foreign Affairs Herve de
Charette condemned Denard's action but failed to say if the
government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe would intervene.

France, the former colonial power, maintains a defence
pact with Comoros and French troops are responsible for the
president's security.

Djohar has been in office since November 26 1989 when he
was democratically elected president to rule the Comoros
population of some 500,000 Arabs, Africans, and Indians.

There have been 17 successful and failed coups in Comoros
since it gained independence in 1975. Denard, 66, has
participated in all of them.

Denard, who born in Belgium but later obtained French
nationality, was in 1990 sentenced to five years in Prison in
absentia by the French government for trying to topple the
government of Benin in West Africa in 1977.

The Comoros were controlled by Moslem sultans until the
French acquired them between 1841 and 1909. They became a
French overseas territory in 1947.

In a 1974 referendum on independence, 93 per cent of
Comorians voted for independence. Only the Christian island
of Mayotte, with a 63-percent-vote, opted to stay with
France.

However, France decided that the voting would be followed
by one on each of the four islands rather than accepting the
results of the overall ballot.

Rejecting this, Comoros declared its independence in July
1975 with Ahmed Abdallah as President.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


90 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large SADC to Have Drought Relief Fund


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995

HARARE - The Southern African Development Community (SADC)
will soon have a revolving fund to help the drought-prone
member countries react swiftly to drought emergencies.

SADC food security sector co-ordinator Reggie Mugwara said
in Harare Friday the USD 30 million fund would get its seed
money from donors, governments and non-governmental
organisations. 

The SADC Council of Ministers last year signed an
agreement establishing how the fund would operate.

A food reserve had been planned in the late eighties, but
the idea was discarded because of the high costs involved in
the construction of silos and actual storage.

'What we learnt from the 1991 drought was that countries
did not plan for emergencies and the fund will assist them to
avert starvation while they look for money elsewhere,'
Mugwara said.

The region suffered a severe drought in 1991 when rains
stopped prematurely and crops withered and died from moisture
stress.

Mugwara said the fund was not a welfare scheme although
borrowing would be at concessionary interest rates to
encourage countries to utilise the facility.

Under the provisions of the fund, borrowing countries
would be obliged to buy their grain from within the region
and only when the other countries were not able to supply,
would external exporters be approached.

In the early stages, the fund would cater only for the
purchase of maize. This will, however, be expanded to include
other crops when the capital base increased.

Mugwara said the finance facility would encourage
increased production within SADC because it would encourage
supplies to countries with crop shortfalls.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


91 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Namibia and Zambia Launch Joint TB Control Programme


LENGTH: 507 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
September 29, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA - Zambia and Namibia have launched a joint
tuberculosis (TB) control programme under a German-supported
10-year health project expected to cover other Southern
African Development Community (SADC) states.

Health experts from the two counties, including
representatives from the World Health Organisation (WHO) and
the German Government's Technical Cooperation Agency (GTZ)
Friday in Lusaka finalised technical details of the anti-TB
programme to be launched in both countries early in 1996. 

GTZ officials said that the agency has budgeted some 400
million German marks (1.5 German marks = one United States
dollar) for the first phase of the programme to run for three
years before reappraisal.

A statement released at the Lusaka meeting by the WHO
delegation in Geneva welcomed the initiative by Zambia and
Namibia as being in line with the recently mooted Southern
African TB Control Initiative (SATCI).

It said that the project will help to strengthen the
national TB control programmes in the two Southern African
states through the use of modern strategies for prevention
and treatment of the disease.

Health officials estimate that there are about 300-400 TB
cases out every 100,000 population in both countries which
have a combined population of some 11 million people.

Namibia has an estimated 1.5 total population.

The 12-member SADC in 1993 mooted the establishment of
SATCI to coordinate national TB control programmes in the
sub-region.

It is expected to be officially inaugurated in the
Namibian capital, Windhoek, in October.

The WHO says TB now causes about 26 percent of the deaths
in the developing countries and is by far the most important
cause of deaths in HIV positive individuals in sub-Saharan
Africa.

Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large (Document) African Ceramics On Display at UCLA Fowler Museum


LENGTH: 1174 words


 
UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultural History (Los Angeles)
September 1, 1995

Los Angeles - African ceramic traditions will be explored
in two exhibitions, "Ceramic Gestures: New Vessels by
Magdalene Odundo" and "African Ceramics: Selections from the
Permanent Collection," at the UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultural
History Sept. 22 through March 3. African ceramics exist in a
staggering range of forms and functions, and the paired
presentations clearly demonstrate the enormous vitality of
these traditions.

The 15 new works of art featured in "Ceramic Gestures,"
are by the Kenya-born, London-based artist Magdalene Odundo.
These pieces evoke a strong association with the forms and
processes of African pottery, which has been made by women
for thousands of years. The first solo traveling exhibition
in America of Odundo's works, "Ceramic Gestures" features
this internationally recognized artist's sensual and
exquisitely fluid creations. The works reveal unmistakable
traces of a long African tradition, blending multiple
associations and meanings with functional references. 

"Odundo is equally conversant with Euro-American
modernism," said Marla C. Berns, curator of the exhibition.
"She brings to her work a love for the universal language of
clay and a familiarity with the world's ceramic history going
back to the vessels of antiquity, to the pottery of Jomon
Japan, to the Native North American ceramics and, more
recently, to the legacy of Bernard Leach and the early 20th"Ceramic Gestures" incorporates a telling video interview
century British vessel tradition."
with the artist. Odundo has described her work as capturing
the unfurling of a plant, the posture of intimate
conversation, or the silhouette of a Kenyan woman bound in
layers of cloth. Several critics describe Odundo's vessels as
embodying the "stillness of a dancer," suggesting her effort
to capture in the silent medium of clay the energy of
animating living things. Each of Odundo's vessels is hand
built, primarily using a coiling technique. She has
purposefully shunned the wheel, with its restraints of
rotational symmetry.

Odundo reads in the vessels' natural forms clear physical
correlations to the bodies of women. The generous curve of a
pot belly echoes pregnancy. Vessels with sharply angled
mouths, tipping backward in long, graceful sweeps, evoke the
elongated foreheads and flaring coiffures of Mangbetu women
of Zaire.

Although recognizably containers, Odundo's vessels are
destined to remain empty. Conversely, "African Ceramics:
Selections from the Permanent Collection," features a crossfunctions and shaped to aesthetically enhance their use.
cultural survey of ceramics made for domestic or ritual
Dating from 1500 B.C. to the present, 61 objects from 10
countries were chosen from the Fowler Museum's renowned
holdings of more than 700 African works of clay. The vessels
range from food bowls to beerpots, oil lamp to meat dryer.
Ritual works include ornamented pottery for funerary
offerings and anthropomorphic vessels used in healing rites

Especially compelling are three massive royal pipes
representing a human, a rabbit and a ram paying homage to a
king, created for use at the celebrated court of Sultan Njoya
in the Cameroon grasslands. A 600-year-old, terra-cotta
sculpture of a kneeling female figure from the inland Niger
Delta of Mali provides an example of ceramics from medieval
West African urban centers. The oldest work in the exhibition
is a New Kingdom Egyptian vessel of about 1500 B.C.,
excavated next to a household shrine in the Nubian fortress
at Askut as part of UCLA's involvement in the UNESCO Aswan
High Dam Salvage Campaign.
The complete range of pottery from Bonakire, a single village
in Western Ghana, offers a comprehensive study of form and
purpose within one tradition. This group of works is
accompanied by a continuously running slide program that
documents techniques of production and contexts of use.

Not all these works serve as containers. A commanding
19th-century sculpture of a lion from Angola once guarded a
cemetery. Elaborate, open-work ceramics from the Igbo peoples
of Nigeria serve as display pieces for diviners' shrines.
These inspiring works also are used as dance sculptures by
titled women.

"Ceramic Gestures" was organized by the University Art
Museum, University of California, Santa Barbara, curated by
the museum's director Marla C. Berns, and is accompanied by a
fully illustrated catalogue. "African Ceramics" was curated
by Doran H. Ross, the Fowler Museum's deputy director and
curator of African collections.

For information, contact UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultural
History, Box 951549, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1549. Tel: (310)
825-4361. (UCLA-CS308)


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September, 1995


Uganda (Document) Journalist Group Calls for Inquiry in Uganda


LENGTH: 1267 words


 
Committee to Protect Journalists (New York)
September 5, 1995

New York - SENT BY FAX
His Excellency President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni
Office of the President
State House Kampala UGANDA
Your Excellency:
The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) expresses its
deepest concern over the August 28 death in police custody of
Hussein Musa Njuki, the 42-year old editor of the Islamic
opposition weekly bulletin Assalaam. Njuki died four days
after he was detained by state security agents. CPJ also
writes to protest the detention of Haruna Kanabi, editor in
chief of the Islamic opposition weekly newsletter, Shariat,
on charges of sedition. Njuki and Kanabi were arrested on the
same day, on the same charges. 

Njuki was arrested on Friday, August 25, 1995, and
immediately taken to the Criminal Investigations Division
(CID). While CPJ has received several versions of the nature
of his arrest, it is certain that he was taken into custody
by a group of plain clothes men from the Anti-Robbery Squad,
an extension of the domestic government security force, the
Internal Security Organization (ISO). One report to CPJ
claimed that Njuki had been suffering from an illness that
had considerably weakened him, and the shock of the ambush by
the ISO squad exacerbated his sickness to fatal proportions.
Another report states that Njuki was in perfect health before
the arrest and was beaten to death by ISO agents. Yet another
report contends that he collapsed during an attempt to escape
and died in hospital of a heart attack. A police guard
remained in Njuki's hospital room throughout the duration of
his stay.

Njuki was arrested on accusations of sedition stemming
from an August 18 article in Assalaam titled, "Multi-party
democracy will not return to Uganda until Museveni dies." He
was to be officially charged with sedition on Monday, August
28, the day of his death.

In a related matter, Haruna Kanabi of Shariat was arrested
the same day as Njuki, Friday, August 25, for publishing an
allegedly seditious article that also appeared on August 18
titled, "Rwanda is now a Ugandan province." Kanabi was
officially charged with sedition on Monday, August 28. Twelve
days later, he remains in detention, as requests for bail
have been rejected. This rejection was on the basis of a
previous case in which journalist Lawrence Kiwanuka fled the
country, for fear of persecution, during court proceedings --
a move which the court deemed "jumping bail."

The matter of Kanabi's release on bail has been taken to
the higher court: a process which can last indefinitely.

The coincidence of these two arrests have as well an
historical link. In 1993, Njuki and Kanabi were colleagues at
Shariat when they were arrested, charged with sedition and
detained for many days, an incident documented in CPJ's
annual report for 1993.

As a nonpartisan group of journalists dedicated to the
defense of press freedom and the protection of our colleagues
worldwide, CPJ strongly urges Your Excellency to launch an
immediate investigation into the death of Hussein Musa Njuki,
order an autopsy, and to ensure that those responsible in any
way be brought to justice. The Committee also urges Your
Excellency to sanction the release of Haruna Kanabi
immediately.
Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely,
William A. Orme, Jr.
Executive Director

cc: His Excellency Ambassador Katenta Apuli
The Hon. Ambassador E. Michael Southwick
TransAfrica
Newspaper Association of America
American Society of Newspaper Editors
Amnesty International
Article 19 (United Kingdom)
Artikel 19 (The Netherlands)
Canadian Committee to Protect Journalists
Congressional Committee to Support Writers and Journalists
Freedom House
Human Rights Watch
Index on Censorship
International Association of Broadcasting
International Federation of Journalists
International Journalism Institute
International PEN
International Press Institute
National Press Club
The Newspaper Guild
North American Broadcasters Association
Reporters Sans Frontieres
Overseas Press Club
The Society of Professional Journalists

For more information, contact Committee to Protect
Journalists, 330 Seventh Avenue, 12th Floor, New York, NY
10001. Tel: 212 465-1004.
Fax: 212 465-9568.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

94 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa TV market To Open


LENGTH: 1720 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Neil Bierbaum

Johannesburg - THE rush for satellite television is on. If
the Independent Broadcasting Authority reports stands --
bringing a two-year wait before South Africa gets a private
terrestrial television station -- new broadcasters will take
to the skies.

This is the implication of the report released this week
by the IBA into the future of the public broadcaster. The IBA
proposed that the SABC lose one of its channels by the end of
1997 and gain a satellite channel then. On this
recommendation, South Africa will only get a non-SABC
terrestrial channel in January 1988. 

This is a boon for satellite television, which will have
over two years in which to establish its programming and
audience with only limited competition.

The delay is certain to be the focus of debate.
Telecommunications Minister Pallo Jordan signaled this from
the outset by saying he was "concerned that the delay in
introducing the private terrestrial channel might overregulated competition". Jordan added that he was "not at all
protect the SABC and defeat the disciplinary aims of
comfortable with the proposal on the SABC's channels" and
wanted Parliament to examine the IBA's recommendations
closely.

David Dison of Media and Broadcasting Consultants welcomed
the report "as a major step forward in establishing a
diversity of voices".
But he described the television proposals as worrying. "As I
see it, the problem with the delay is that it will have the
tendency to weaken free-to-air television against satellite
broadcasting," he said.
SABC chief executive Zwelakhe Sisulu also spoke strongly
against the loss of a channel.

"I think IBA has done a reasonable job, given the time
they had and the constraints placed upon them in getting the
information they needed," says Jonathan Procter, former
director-general of Bop Broadcasting Corporation. "It has not
taken a populist position. Previous reports on broadcasting
in South Africa were laden with compromise. It is perfectly
understandable that the SABC should be given two years to
prepare itself." He believes there will still be
opportunities for terrestrial broadcasters, although he
agrees that the report could precipitate a rush for satellite
television.

Quentin Green, former chief executive: television at SABC
and now with Free to Air, an outfit which -- as its name
suggests -- is to apply for a terrestrial television licence,
says, "Our general comment is that the report looks very
good. We do agree with the SABC that it should retain three
channels. We also think the entire process should be speeded
up. As it stands it opens the door for foreign broadcasters
to come in via satellite."

Green adds that they are not considering the satellite
option at all. "We are still looking at an advertiserYet the prospects for regional television might have been
supported full-spectrum channel.
significantly enhanced as a result of the IBA report. Such
regional television could take the form of regional windows
within the national public broadcasting service (NPBS),
although there is also the possibility that the new private
commercial channel could be a network of regional stations.

The report suggests that because of the high cost of
television, a regional service should fall to the NPBS.
According to the report, "financial analysis done for the
authority suggested that the new private channel to come on
line in 1998 could not profitably be divided into two or
three regional stations, even with extensive networking and
sharing of costs." According to an IBA official, however, the
opportunity still exists for a regional commercial
broadcaster to apply for a licence to broadcast. This
decision would hinge on whether the regional station could
prove its viability.

The report acknowledges that "regional television could
draw on a whole layer of advertising that has not and will
not be available to national television". It adds that this
would encourage the decentralisation of television
production.

Nick Taylor, who has the CityTV franchise -- a regional TV
station based in Toronto, Canada -- for South Africa,
believes that regional TV is viable if done appropriately.
"We can set up stations with 10 or 15 people," he says. "TV
doesn't have to be high cost glamour ... All you need are
good people who are passionate about what they are doing."

The report recommends that regional windows of one hour a
day be provided for on television. This is expected to cost
R122-million a year. It is proposed that Parliament should
foot the bill. "Regional windows within the public broadcast
service would not fulfill the needs of the provinces. They
would be controlled from the centre," says Taylor.

This view was also held by Bop Broadcasting Corporation
director-general Solomon Kotane. BopBC had hopes of providing
a national backbone service to regional broadcasters, who
could then slot in their own programming as and when it
became available. But many of the regions have not yet
defined their needs in terms of a regional public broadcaster
and many do not have facilities.

"We don't have an ex-homeland broadcaster and it would be
expensive to set up the facility," says Narina Riskowitz,
acting head of communications for KwaZulu- Natal. She adds
that they would encourage the licensing of a private
broadcaster for the region.
Whether it grants a licence to one national channel or a
network of regional channels, it appears that the licence
which will be granted will be a full spectrum rather than a
thematic licence such as a sport or music channel.

The report further specifies that "in selecting applicants
for private licences, the authority will make ownership and
control by previously disadvantaged South Africans an
important criterion." It may also require broadcasters to
serve sparsely populated as well as densely populated areas,
carefully weighing the "public interest and the financial
implications".

The IBA also intends to indicate minimum or threshold
requirements for specific programme categories. The objective
is that, "viewed collectively, television is catering to the
needs of the public".

This would in effect create certain public service
mandates for commercial broadcasters, requiring some level of
educational and informative programming at "appropriate"
times. Subscription broadcasters are "expected to make a
contribution to national development along with all other
broadcasting services".

With regard to community television, the report states
that "the Authority recognises the importance of community
television and will endeavour to licence as many of these as
technological and financial capability permits."


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995

Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Coal Firms Eager For New Eskom Contracts


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Karen Harverson

Johannesburg - Local coal producers will be vying to
clinch the remaining coal contracts for Eskom's R10-billion
Majuba power station which, when completed, will consume some
13-million tons of coal a year.

The power station, which has a design capacity of 40 036
megawatts, will entail the construction of six sets, each
consisting of a boiler, turbine, alternator and unit
transformer, and capable of operating independently. 

The first three sets have already been built and the first
is due for commissioning at the end of 1996. The remaining
two will be commissioned thereafter as demand dictates.

Coal supplier Ingwe has the contract to supply Eskom with
coal for sets 1,2 and 3 but will compete with other local
coal producers to win the contracts for the remaining three
sets in the future.
However, the decision by Eskom on when the last three sets
will be built will only be made around 2000.

By then, Eskom's total coal requirements could rise to 97tons a year grows by the expected four percent a year.
million tons a year -- if current consumption of 76,9-million

"Advances in technology may, of course, enable power
stations to burn less coal to produce the same amount of
electricity," says an Eskom spokesperson.
Managing director Dave Murray says the coal required for the
commissioning of the first unit will be sourced from a
million-ton stockpile which will be sufficient until June
1996 when Ingwe will begin phased deliveries of coal.

LANGUAGE: English

96 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Mozambique Country On Route To Free-Market Economy


LENGTH: 480 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Meshack Mabogoane

Sandton - The road to a full-scale market economy in
Mozambique is, like peace, "irreversible", President Joachim
Chissano said in Sandton recently when he addressed a special
meeting of business people.

He said joint ventures for the development of major
infrastructure were the "only policy option available" and
"we may no longer guarantee the development of our countries
in an isolated manner". 

He said Mozambique had successfully attracted foreign
investment in mining. The country's minerals include bauxite,
chromium and iron ore estimated at 167-million tons. The
rehabilitation of the Moats coal mine was, he said, "most
advanced".

South Africa is playing a major role in Mozambican
infrastructural development. Recently, Minister of Transport
Mac Maharaj, Trade and Industry Minister Trevor Manuel and
Minister of Public Enterprise Stella Sicgau visited
Mozambique to discuss the upgrading of Maputo harbour and the
construction of the Maputo-Nkomati railway and road.

The Development Bank of South Africa made known this week
a R3-million loan, payable over 15 years at 14 percent, to
the Telecommunicatoes de Mozambique to improve
telecommunications between the two countries.

South African farmers, Chissano said, are "looking forward
to moving to Mozambique". Only 10 percent of Mozambique's
arable land is under cultivation. Land is not for sale but
long-term leases are available.

Plans for the Zambezi Valley Development Programme,
broached by the colonial regime to provide a grid system of
dams and electricity and stimulate agriculture, were in the
"advanced planning stage" and could involve Brazil, Portugal,
South Africa and other development agencies.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


97 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Local Banking Industry Is Sitting Pretty


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Reg Rumney

Johannesburg - Foreign competition is the biggest threat
to the margins of the banking industry -- but foreign banks
are unlikely to want to upset the domestic applecart.

Alan McConnochie of broker Ed Hern Rudolph, writing in
accountancy firm KPMG's 1995 Banking Survey, identified
foreign competition as one of three long-term issues for
South African banks.

The other two are the attitude of the Reserve Bank and the
government, and the co-operation on pricing between the
banks.
Whether banks can sustain wide margins between the cost of
borrowing and the cost of lending, essential for good
returns, depends on those three factors. 

McConnochie said he did not see any threat from the
authorities. "We expect that the authorities will encourage
wide margins because without a strong banking industry we
cannot fund the economic growth required or be an
international partner."

Nor did he see an end to the present banking focus on
products and services rather than rate-cutting. "Banks
learned long ago that nobody wins a price war."

If foreign banks entered the South African market in a big
way, used cheap foreign capital to upset local margins and
buy market share, South African banks, small by world
standards, would have a problem.
But, he said, foreign banks were likely to concentrate on
getting good returns rather than undercutting local banks.

Banks performed strongly in 1994, for the sixth year in a
row. Share price growth continued to exceed earnings growth
by a wide margin. In 1994 the Banks Index jumped 30,3 percent
(1993:37,5 percent) while earnings grew 13,4 percent (1993:15
percent). By comparison the Industrial Index rose by 25,5
percent and its earnings by 11,9 percent.

The banking sector, the survey noted, is dominated by the
big four commercial banks: Amalgamated Banks of South Africa,
Standard Bank Investment Corporation, First National Bank
Holdings and Nedcor.

Total banking assets grew by 16,9 percent to R343- billion
last year, according to the survey. Advances grew at a
slightly lower rate at 16,3 percent, with most of the growth
coming from mortgage lending and installment finance.
Mortgage lending grew 19,9 percent, and installment finance
19,4 percent

The survey notes the surge in mortgage lending is
supported by the low-risk weighting it carries for capital
adequacy purposes, and it is likely to see substantial growth
over the next few years as the government and business try to
provide housing to more people.

Overdrafts and loans to the corporate sector increased by
15,5 percent for the year, indicating strong demand for
credit by business, said the survey, albeit lower than the
growth in mortgage lending.

"The level of retail lending remained virtually constant
showing weaker demand for consumer credit other than
installment sales and mortgages." McConnochie expected the
outlook for South African bank profits this year to be fair.
He reckoned the Banks Index should show earnings per share
growth of 20 percent, better than inflation although well
below the 26 percent forecast for industrial shares this
year.

He foresaw strong growth in banks' credit advances and fee
income, reducing bad debts and a lower corporate tax rate
this year as well as a higher return earned on "free"
shareholders' funds as interest rates continue to rise.

These positive factors should more than make up for the
slight squeeze in the banks' margins and a possible increase
in liquid asset requirements, said McConnochie, as the
Reserve Bank tried to slow the rate of growth in bank lending

He noted that margins tend to widen at the bottom of the
interest rate cycle and narrow at the top.

McConnochie, writing before the increase in the prime rate
to 18,5 percent, said he did not expect banks to slow the
growth in advances to 10 percent as requested by the Reserve
Bank, so he believed a further one or two percentage point
rise in interest rates likely.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


98 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Hugh Masekela, The Jazz Man


LENGTH: 1307 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Meshack Mabogoane

Johannesburg - A month after his appointment as coMasekela at Kippie's in downtown Johannesburg last week was a
director of the State Theatre, the appearance of Hugh
fitting reminder that he is both the supreme embodiment of a
cultural stream that has been exiled from stately
consideration, and a musical establishment in his own right.

For his followers -- a rainbow lot who crammed the tiny
Kippie's every session of his four-day sojourn -- this was an
occasion to celebrate the acknowledgment of his contribution
to South African music. But it was also a moment for Masekela
himself to acknowledge their kudos.

He did so by taking his music back to its roots,
demonstrating his indebtedness to the moving spirit and best
tradition of jazz. Masekela is as consummate a jazz musician
as he has been an exponent and developer of local music. This
synthesis is personified in what can be called Masekelia,
just as the musical phenomenon personified by Duke Ellington
has been called Ellingtonia. 

Masekela drew heavily from his classic repertoire:
Stimela, Grazing in the Grass, Ntjilo Ntjilo, Free Mandela,
Nomali, and so on. This was expected, and enthusiastically
received. But there ended Masekela the predictable. The
pieces served only as a canvas on which the musicians were to
demonstrate their craft and colours. The tunes became
vehicles for extensive and elaborate improvisations which
gave the music a sublime depth and density.

Jimmy Dludlu on bass guitar played energetically, yet
maintained a cool restraint that prevented possible excesses
that could have turned his staccato strumming to Jimi
Hendrix-like crescendos. Kwasi Shange on drums, though rowdy
on occasion, managed to return to well- measured timesupportive percussionist, John Hassan.
keeping, and was complemented by the evasive and finely

Khaya Mahlangu, on flute and tenor, the group's musical
director and "philosopher", seemed content to bolster the
deeper coherence and organic substance that the group
produced so well. Mahlangu was the main anchor and stimulus
that enabled Masekela to elaborate on the customary
Masekelian statements.

The potential for this group to be the best that Masekela
has put together so far is enormous. In effect, it could
reduce his dominance while injecting his substance to produce
an organic sound that would be greater than the sum of its
individual parts. The over-towering Masekela would not be so
much subdued as sublimated.

On average, the group played six tunes over one-and-aimprovisation the main course, and the concert a jazz event
half hours -- 10 to 15 minutes a tune. This made
par excellence. And the tunes were liberated from a dance
trance even though the rhythm was dense and strong. This was
intentional, to convey the message that Masekela needs to be
listened to seriously. When a rowdy group shouted "Go, Hugh,
go", he stopped playing and threatened to go home if they did
not stop. At the end of the session, he pleaded that the
"gods of Africa" should help people appreciate music. You
gotta dig, really.

Masekela at Kippie's put paid to the view that he is no
longer creative, but just resting on his reputation. It's a
perception that seems credible, given both his immense
success -- which often spawns complacency -- and middle-age.
Bra Hugh ain't that young no more, and the elder statesman
status has fallen on him with ease. But, at Kippie's, his
format and on-stage playing were fresh and inspiring,
pointing at things still to come.

It is no paradox that Masekela, who for three decades
abroad played an Africentric or home-brewed music, should now
return to jazz-based explorations. He is at the vanguard of a
new musical development that is emerging.

Masekela senses this. In closing the concerts, he revealed
great expectations when he said: "After 30 years of exile, I
am pleased that South Africa can produce good musicians in
spite of isolation." He seems determined to add his stately
weight to their development.

The Sunday afternoon concert at Kippie's by the Soweto
Youth Jazz Orchestra vindicated this hope. The orchestra,
made up of students of the Mano Technical College in
Dobsonville, performed an array of classic jazz pieces. Tunes
by Joe Zawinul (Mercy, Mercy, Mercy and Birdland), Charlie
Parker (Billy's Bounce, Now's the Time) and Thelonious Monk
(Well, You Needn't) were played with vigour and technical
finesse. The group's solid jazz and overall musical grounding
are beyond doubt; so, too, is their rootedness in local
music.

With trumpet virtuoso Prince Lengoasa as one of their
tutors, the orchestra could become a powerhouse in producing
solid jazz musicians, much as Fuba has done. By the way,
Lengoasa's solo on Some Day My Prince Will Come, a tune made
a classic jazz vehicle by Davis, was remarkable for its selfsucceeded is a tribute to the urge to sound original; should
conscious effort to avoid Milesian licks and cliches. That he
this spirit take root among his students, it will contribute
to the search for an authentic jazz sound.

Truly, jazz is alive and set to live long in this country.
Kippie's should continue its safari.

Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large From Apartheid Bully To Co-operative Neighbour


LENGTH: 987 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Stefaans Brummer

Johannesburg - THE irony of their own attendance at
Monday's Southern African Development Community summit could
not have been lost on Constand Viljoen and Pik Botha. A
succession of regional leaders made sure they had no chance.

Both men sat attentively in the large but select World
Trade Centre audience when three presidents, including Nelson
Mandela, made reference to apartheid South Africa's
destabilisation of the region.

From the stage, nine more leaders -- presidents and prime
ministers or their deputies, most of whose countries at some
stage had felt the effects of a decade and a half or more of
South African overt and covert military aggression -- peered
down on Viljoen, who headed the South African Defence Force
during the roughest of that time, and Botha, who as longcampaign estimated to have cost a million lives and more than
serving Minister of Foreign Affairs must have had input in a
a hundred billion rand. 

Mandela thanked other SADC countries in his welcoming
speech for their role in "the liberation of South Africa and
the end of Southern Africa's destabilisation"; Tanzanian
President Ali Hassan Mwinyi referred to "economic and
political destabilisation of the region ... used as a grand
strategy to delay the liberation of Namibia and South
Africa"; and Botswana President Ketumile Masire spoke of "the
impact of apartheid-sponsored destabilisation".

But in a sense, this year's summit was the final farewell
to that period. South Africa, who last year joined SADC --
founded in 1980 as the Southern African Development Codecreasing dependency on a destabilising South Africa -- not
ordination Conference (SADCC) with the express purpose of
only hosted the summit this year, but also played a leading
role.

Mandela, always the great reconciler, made it clear that
the past had to be consigned to the past. "SADC's mission
reflects the reality that Southern Africa has long passed the
stage of lamenting the privations of the past. The challenge
is to find within ourselves the resources to overcome this
legacy, with the co- operation of the international
community."

So the wheel had turned a full circle. There was Viljoen,
now leader of the Freedom Front, the man who has gained
acceptance from those same leaders on the stage for his
scheme to export Afrikaner farmers to the region.

And Botha, now Minister of Mineral and Energy Affairs in
Mandela's Cabinet, had the honour of co-signing with his SADC
counterparts a memorandum on the establishment of a regional
power pool.
Security in the region has come a long way since SADC, and
its sibling body, the Frontline States, joined battle with
the old South Africa. Mwinyi, who is retiring as Tanzanian
president this year, recounted how "when I came to power ten
years ago, Namibia was not yet free. South Africa was still
governed by and apartheid regime. Civil war and discord
characterised life in Angola and Mozambique."

Today, even Angola appears to be on the road to peace.
Democracy is on the upswing in SADC countries and in the
space of 18 months South Africa, Malawi, Mozambique and
shortly Tanzania will have held their first unfettered multiSADC, after South Africa joined it, and with a substantial
party elections.
role played by South Africa, has successfully averted crises
in the Mozambican elections and the Lesotho coup attempt.
Lesotho's prime minister Ntsu Mokhehle thanked his SADC
colleagues for their mediation in his country, "Not because
you re-instated my administration, but because you
demonstrated the supremacy and invincibility of democracy".

Perhaps South Africa's transition from apartheid bully to
a stable and co-operative neighbour, the domino that started
a democratic trend, will yet prove to be SADC's greatest
asset.

Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Southern Africa's Leaders Win A Few, Lose A Few


LENGTH: 1347 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Stefaans Brummer

Johannesburg - This week's SADC summit saw quibbling among
the region's leaders, but a few strides were made
nevertheless. When the Southern African Development Community
heads of state and government postponed their lunch at
Johannesburg's World Trade Centre on Monday, observers
suspected there was serious quibbling in the air.

Two closed sessions of an hour and a half each, originally
to have been broken by lunch, stretched to a solid four and a
half hours, and only well into the afternoon did the leaders
allow themselves a bite.

What the delay meant for the caterers must be clear; what
it signified about unity of purpose and direction in SADC is
any body's guess. For, in spite of SADC's slogan of
"integration through commitment, co-operation and popular
participation", the people of the region do not get to hear
details of what went on behind those closed doors. 

But that there was less than unanimity on the part of the
11 Southern African presidents and prime ministers or their
deputies (12 after Mauritius' membership application was
approved during the summit) can be gauged from the fruits of
the summit.

South Africa's President Nelson Mandela, in perhaps the
most candid admission that not all went as planned, said
afterwards: "There is no doubt that this has been one of the
most significant SADC summits ever ... There are issues where
we may not have reached complete consensus, but they all fade
into insignificance by comparison to the great strides we
have made."

The summit did indeed make "strides", in comparison to
SADC's earlier record of much talk and little action. But not
all would agree with Mandela's judgment that the
disagreements "fade into insignificance" against those
strides.

Here is the scorecard:

-SADC's leaders signed a Protocol on Shared Watercourse
Systems, perhaps the first concrete agreement yet signed by
the body in pursuance of its aim of regional integration. But
the protocol, which is to ensure upstream states do not use
more than their share of water or pollute shared water
systems, was not signed by Angola and Zambia as their
Cabinets "had not yet completed their consultations".

-SADC energy ministers were directed by the summit to sign
an "inter-governmental memorandum of understanding" on a
Southern African Power Pool. While it showed an advance on
the aim to create a common pool of electricity in the region,
the memorandum appeared to be a step down from a protocol
establishing the pool, which had been envisaged to be signed
by the heads of state and government.

-Mauritius' application for membership was granted. Like
South Africa, which joined SADC a year ago, Mauritius is an
economic powerhouse compared to the rest of the region and
may bring muscle and expertise to the block.

-The summit approved a request from Comesa, the Common
Market for East and Southern Africa, for a joint summit with
SADC to remove tension between the two bodies. SADC decided a
year ago that its members should resign membership of Comesa
(thereby creating two, rather than one, trade block), but
many SADC members still retain dual membership.

While Mauritius joining SADC (as opposed to Comesa, which
was also an option) appeared to be a victory for SADC, the
fact that the joint summit was approved and that the
resignations have not happened point to a possible rethink of
the earlier decision, or a reluctance on the part of some
SADC members to make a clear choice for the southern body.
SADC executive secretary Kaire Mbuende said after the summit:
"I am not going to demand from any country to know whether
they have pulled out or not."

-Perhaps most importantly, the Association of Southern
African States (Asas), a political arm to complement SADC's
development aims with a regional conflict resolution and
security co-ordination facility, was not agreed. Last year's
summit approved the creation of such a "sector" in SADC, but
the idea was revised -- and supposedly finalised for approval
by this year's summit -- by SADC foreign ministers at a
meeting in Harare in March.

The March revision decided Asas should be a loose
association with direct input by SADC heads of state and a
revolving chair, rather than the "sector" -- which in SADCSADC's secretariat. As a "sector", it would also have been
speak would have meant it falling under the authority of
co-ordinated and chaired by a single member country.

Monday's summit decided to refer Asas back to the member
states and their foreign and security ministers for more
"consultation". What had been decided twice before had to be
revised again.

The new review appears to be based on the realisation that
security ministers had mistakenly been omitted from the
process earlier, but could also relate to the aspirations of
a state like Zimbabwe, which has been eyeing the chair of
Asas, and the secretariat of SADC, both of whom would benefit
were the body to be a sector (under the secretariat and with
a non-revolving chair).

Whether the above constitutes "great strides" or not, in
the end, will have to be judged by the people of the region.
Mandela acknowledged as much in his closing address, when he
urged the leaders of the region to "move to put into practice
the decisions we have taken".


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Telkom Property Sale Questioned


LENGTH: 1467 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Stefaans Brummer

Johannesburg - The sale of a prime Telkom-owned property,
apparently at a fire-sale price, has the telecommunications
minister lambasting his officials. Posts and
Telecommunications Minister Pallo Jordan has questioned
Telkom's sale of a prestigious Cape Town Waterfront property,
suggesting that the deal lost the state-owned company
millions or rand.

Documents in possession of the Mail & Guardian reveal how
an explanation given by Telkom for the sale was flatly
rejected by Jordan with the words: "Crap. Totally
unacceptable." 

Telkom, though no longer state-run, is still 100 percentthe Cabinet.
owned by the state and ultimately answerable to Jordan and
Jordan last week confirmed the veracity of the documents,
saying: "My concern was that the property had been sold below
the price it could have fetched, given its location. I have
heard nothing thus far that has reduced my apprehension."

The property, the disused Gallows Hill telephone exchange
site and building dryly referred to in the documentation as
"Erf 14501", is now better known as Victoria Junction, one of
Cape Town's most prestigious developments. The documentation
-- mailed anonymously to the M&G -- shows Jordan writing to
Telkom chairman Dikgang Moseneke last November, and again in
February, asking for clarity on the R12-million deal between
Telkom and the directors of developers Newport Property
Group, clinched on October 13 last year.

In the first letter, Jordan said: "From appearances, and I
stress, appearance, this was a deal that could have brought
the company much more money ... I don't want you to start
making enemies in the management board, but if the
allegations here are true, this is a matter that needs
looking into."

In February, Jordan wrote to Moseneke urging an
investigation and asking to be informed of the facts. "In the
context of the demands that will be placed on Telkom to
realise universal service, I cannot take lightly the disposal
of state assets at low prices."

He told Moseneke that from his own inquiries it appeared
the market value was "far greater" than the R12-million
(including VAT) paid for it; that there was no tendering;
that "a leading property developer in this city, who operates
in that precise area ... had not heard about the transaction
until it appeared in the press"; and that it appeared the
property might have been sold via another party, realising a
profit for a third party.

Jordan told the M&G he had not had final word from
Moseneke. "I have to remind him, but he has had other fish to
fry."
Jordan's suspicions appear to have been raised initially by
Cape Town businesswoman Cathy Murat, who had approached
Telkom in the middle of last year for the partial donation of
the property in terms of the company's social investment
programme. Her plan was to set up an interactive children's
museum on the site. She wrote to Jordan in November, and soon
after that Jordan first wrote to Moseneke for an explanation.

He got that explanation -- ostensibly from Moseneke -- in
mid-December. "I am satisfied there was nothing irregular in
the selling of the property and the selling price of R12valuation of R10,4-million," a letter in the name of
million is market-related and well in excess of the sworn
Moseneke, but signed on his behalf by Telkom's then-managing
director Danie du Toit, informed Jordan.

Three days later Du Toit, who left Telkom in March this
year, told Jordan that the letter in Moseneke's name had
"been released by me" in the absence of Moseneke and "in view
of the urgency of the matter" -- but that it was being
withdrawn.

In February, before his second letter to Moseneke, Jordan
was confronted with a response to Murat's objection in the
form of a letter, in his name, which he was supposed to sign.
It appears to have been drafted partly by Pieter Feenstra,
general manager of Telkom properties. Jordan went to the
extraordinary length of crossing out all three pages of it,
appending a note: "Crap!!! Totally unacceptable."

The letter would have had Jordan telling Murat: "A full
report has now been made available to me and, quite frankly,
it is clear that Telkom acted strictly within their sphere of
responsibilities."

Feenstra this week stood by the explanation, saying Telkom
had had "as many as" four valuations done on the property. An
independent valuation had shown it to be worth R10,4-million,
including VAT. He defended the decision not to put the
property out to tender, saying experience had taught "that
with prime property, we often get worse offers (by tender)
than by negotiation".

Feenstra said Telkom and its brokers had negotiated with
some 40 clients over a period of more than a year, and the
Newport directors' offer had been the best. "We had the
valuation, and we used that as our barometer ... At the stage
we did the transaction, there is no doubt in my mind, we
achieved a price independently determined to be above market
value."

Jordan's fears the property had passed from the original
buyer for an extra profit -- which should have been Telkom's
rather than a third party's -- appear to be unfounded,
although based in fact.

Cape Town deeds office records show that in fact three
legal entities now own shares in the property, whereas only
one of them, the 406 Fairweather Trust, had made the deal
with Telkom. But all three entities are owned by the
directors of Newport, suggesting the passing on of the
property had been a technicality and making it unlikely that
further profit would have accrued.

As for Jordan's main apprehension, that the property had
been sold for a song, perhaps only Moseneke's inquiry -- when
he gets around to it -- will tell.

Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Pressure to Resist Toxic Exports Ban


LENGTH: 1227 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995
by Eddie Koch

Johannesburg - The Department of Environment Affairs is
being pressed by the Australian government to help weaken a
proposed international ban on shipments of hazardous
materials from industrialised to non-industrialised
countries.

The department has already been rocked by news that its
consultants have allowed consignments of hazardous waste into
the country, despite an official prohibition on toxic
imports.

Confidential documents leaked to the Mail and Guardian
show that an Australian delegation recently visited South
Africa and met with officials in the departments of Foreign
Affairs and Environment Affairs. Their mission was to discuss
plans by member states of the Basel Convention to ban all
movement of hazardous industrial wastes from OECD
(industrialised) to non- OECD (industrialised) countries. 

A report from the Australian delegation indicates their
government is keen to establish support from South Africa for
an initiative to weaken African support for the Basel ban.

"We raised general issues in relation to the Basel
Convention, in particular the ban decision. We said there
should be no presumption that Australia would waive its
General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (Gatt) rights (of free
trade) as a result of membership of the Basel Convention,"
says the memorandum.

"We raised whether South Africa might be willing to play a
regional role in raising awareness of Basel issues among
African countries in the lead up to the third conference of
parties (states which have agreed to adhere to the Basel
convention) in September ... South African officials said
they understood South Africa might be able to play an
awareness-raising and general co-ordinating role within
Africa. They said they would consider the idea further."

The Australian Financial Review reported this month that
the Australian government is preparing to reverse its support
for the proposed ban. Green Peace officials say Australian
officials have also held talks with Malaysian and Indian
officials ahead of next month's meeting in an effort to win
support from some developing countries for resistance to a
total ban. Australia's trade in hazardous materials is worth
about R525-million a year.

The Basel convention is an international agreement that
places controls on the movement of toxic and hazardous waste
around the world. However, it has been criticised for not
being tough enough. A meeting of member states, due to be
held this month, is expected to come under strong pressure to
include in the agreement a clause that prohibits all northChris Albertyn, representative of green pressure group
south movement of wastes from the end of 1997.
Earthlife Africa, told the M&G his organisation has evidence
that an Australian official had been seconded on a full-time
basis to the Department of Foreign Affairs to help work on
South Africa's waste import policy. Albertyn added that this
official had pressured the Department of Environment Affairs
not to allow non- government groups into the delegation that
will attend the Basel meeting this month.

A foreign affairs spokesman confirmed that an Australian
diplomat is working in Pretoria, but he denied that South
Africa would allow its foreign policy to be decided by
foreign countries.
It is also clear that the United States government has
identified South Africa as a strategic country in terms of
African decisions about the toxic waste issue.

Another secret document obtained by the M&G -- this one a
report from the US embassy in Pretoria to the State
Department in Washington -- suggests recent controversies in
South Africa over toxic waste could have negative
consequences for US interests.

Massive shipments of mercury waste have come into South
Africa from the US over the past few years, ostensibly for
recycling purposes, and have caused serious ecological damage
around the Thor Chemicals KwaZulu-Natal recycling plant.

Last week, the government turned back a ship filled with
500 tons of cupric arsenate from Finland. A US document
reveals that this waste was created by US- based industries
and shipped to Finland for recycling a few years ago.

"In another development, the Environmental Justice
Networking Forum (EJNF), has announced that toxic-waste
shipments are reaching South Africa without the government's
knowledge. As a result, it will lead a private investigation
to track such shipments," says the US embassy document. "The
EJNF is a forum of approximately 180 South African nonamong government circles because of its combative nature."
governmental organisations (NGOs) ... The forum is unpopular

Deputy Environment Minister Bantu Holomisa last week
announced an independent commission will investigate the
toxic-waste scandal that has rocked his ministry and
department.
