Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa "Truth" Commission Delayed


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 1, 1995

Johannesburg - The "Truth and Reconciliation Commission"
is now unlikely to get under way until well into next year,
according to Justice Minister Dullah Omar.

Omar has told the Mail & Guardian that the "process" of
selecting members of the commission would begin shortly and
would "hopefully" be complete by the end of December. 

The commission would then have to set up offices and
decide how to tackle its three main tasks: uncovering "the
truth" about human rights abuses in the apartheid era;
granting amnesty to those who confess; and making reparation
to victims and their families.

"We are not rushing into appointments, because of the
importance of the commission," said Omar in an interview. It
had been hoped that the commission would start hearings by
October. In terms of enabling legislation it has 18 months to
complete its task, extendible by six months.

The minister did not specify the process by which the
commissioners would be chosen, but it is believed the plan is
to create a broadly representative committee which will
advise President Nelson Mandela on nominations.

Answering protests by victims -- that they want "justice"
rather than amnesties for the perpetrators of atrocities --
Omar said all victims of crimes wanted vengeance.

"I am required by the constitution to ensure there is a
law-making provision for amnesty," he said. But he stressed
that amnesties granted would not be automatic, or blanket. "I
want to see there is maximum justice within the constraints
within which I am working."


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


104 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Sudan (Editorial) Carter Seeks the Rehabilitation of Regime


LENGTH: 3720 words


 
Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)
September 30, 1995

LONDON - At the end of July, when former US President
Jimmy Carter returned from his latest visit to Sudan having
failed to secure a second extension to his Guinea Worm ceasethe Khartoum regime's international isolation than he was
fire, it appeared as if her was more concerned with lifting
with securing a genuine peace in the country. The Gazette has
obtained a copy of a document in which Mr. Carter wrote that
he was the middleman in trying to arrange new peace talks
between Khartoum and the Sudan People's Liberation Army
(SPLA). Talks which would have excluded the principles of
Self-determination and Secularism from the outset and which
would have negated all the positive work carried out by the
Inter-governmental Authority for Drought and Development
(IGADD) peace committee over the past three years. Strange as
it may be to say so, Mr. Carter merely succeeded in
demonstrating his naivete in this very long running Sudanese
conflict.

The Guinea Worm cease-fire, although lasting for four
months, was never much more than a propaganda charade. The
National Islamic Front (NIF) regime has regularly violated
the cease-fire, using it to reinforce and resupply its
garrison towns in the South. Surprisingly then, it was the
NIF regime which first recognised that the cease-fire could
not continue in its original form as conceived by Mr. Carter. 
The regime hoped to use Mr. Carter to persuade the SPLA to
extend the cease-fire on new political terms. As the former
US president has always harboured a desire to negotiate a
political settlement of the Sudanese conflict, he was keen to
pursue this avenue, perhaps not realising how the regime was
using him, unless he was a willing candidate.

The Real Architect: The NIF regime has been the architect
of the cease-fire since its inception. It will be remembered
that Khartoum hoped to use Mr. Carter's influence to open
doors in Washington, DC and that was the main reason for
inviting him to Khartoum in March. A second reason concerned
the abject failure of the regime's dry season offensive in
the South. All manner of resources were released for the
attack on the SPLA garrison at Nimule. The regime billed this
as the decisive battle in the war which would shortly be over
with the SPLA defeated. Nimule remained in SPLA hands and the
regime's forces lost thousands of soldiers as well as
equipment. By March the regime was desperate for a breathing
space in the war so that it could regroup, reinforce and
resupply the forces.

The Guinea Worm cease-fire was the ideal solution to the
regime's problems. It had the benefit of being humanitarian
based, so the SPLA would hardly reject it, and Mr. Carter
felt he was contributing to something positive. Also, there
was no need to make any political concessions in the South.
Injecting Politics: When Mr. Carter travelled to Khartoum in
late July, he was confronted by Khartoum's change of tack
over the cease-fire. With the NIF regime wanting to introduce
the political aspects of the conflict into the cease-fire
equation, Mr. Carter was optimistic that the SPLA would also
want to discuss these matters.

Injecting Politics: When Mr. Carter travelled to Khartoum
in late July, he was confronted by Khartoum's change of tack
of the cease-fire. With the NIF regime wanting to introduce
the political aspects f the conflict into the cease-fire
equation, Mr. Carter was optimistic that the SPLA would also
want to discuss these matters. The regime said it had two
preconditions for the SPLA to fulfill before agreeing to a
cease-fire, namely: that the SPLA should agree to fresh peace
talks and also release seventy-two of the regime's soldiers
who had been abducted at the beginning of the original ceaseWhether or not the former US president was aware of all
fire in April.
the facts surrounding these two preconditions before agreeing
to present them to the SPLA is not known. However, if he was
aware of them, then he had far too much confidence in his own
diplomatic ability, if he sincerely believed that he could
persuade the SPLA to accept them. The two preconditions set
out by Khartoum were calculated to insult the SPLA.

Firstly, the Khartoum regime walked out on the IGADD peace
talks in September 1994 objecting to the Declaration of
Principles (DOP) document and in particular the clauses on
Self-determination and the role of Islam in the future
politics of a democratic Sudan. The SPLA considers that the
IGADD peace process is still continuing and has campaigned
for the international community to put more pressure on the
NIF regime to return to the talks. Khartoum's precondition
implies that the regime is ready to make peace while the SPLA
is not, which is a reversal of their positions at IGADD in
reality.

Secondly, the demand for the release of the prisoners of
war outside of any general exchange of POWs ought to have
been recognised immediately as being unacceptable to the
SPLA. It is well known that the regime takes no prisoners and
executes any SPLA soldiers unlucky enough to be captured. The
seventy-two POWs the regime was referring to were captured by
the SPLA when they first violated the cease-fire at Lafon on
1 April. The force was attempting to break through to Kapoeta
and the SPLA, quite rightly, viewed such a large military
movement as an act of war inconsistent with Mr. Carter's own
cease-fire.

SPLA Objection: A statement from the SPLA rejected the two
preconditions and gave a very clear explanation as to why.
The SPLA see the IGADD peace plan as the only workable option
being tabled at present and those talks could reconvene
immediately if the regime wished to participate seriously.
The SPLA had agreed to the original cease-fire partly out of
deference to Mr. Carter but mostly because of its
humanitarian aspects and the facilitation of the immunization
programmes for the eradication of Guinea Worm and River
Blindness. The statement concluded by pointing out that the
regime's forces had persistently violated the cease-fire
throughout the four months but nothing had been done about
this by those who sponsored it.

Despite having announced the failure to extend the ceasehe thought both sides appeared to have developed an interest
fire, Mr. Carter was hopeful that it would still hold because
in maintaining it. It was not many days after Mr. Carter
spoke when Khartoum launched its latest military offensive to
take the border post of Kaya on the Sudanese-Uganda border.

The manner and planning of the attack on Kaya, as reported
in a separate story shows that Khartoum used the four months'
so-called cease-fire lull to plan this attack and many more
the regime said it is about to undertake. The swiftness with
which Khartoum undertook to restart military operations at
the end of the Guinea Worm cease-fire and only days after the
former US president visited Khartoum, should show Mr. Carter
how much respect the NIF regime has for his role. Dealing
with this kind of credibility or international respect is one
of Mr. Carter's real problems in all his efforts in Sudan.

Dry Season Fizzle: For six months from October 1994, the
NIF regime has attempted to overrun Nimule. Using its own
figures, more than 9,000 members of the Popular Defence Force
(PDF) have been killed in the process and more than 15,000
are wounded or in action. These loses can only be explained
by the regime having fallen victim to its own empty
propaganda.

When Lieutenant General El Beshir announced in March that
he was going to recruit a million volunteers to win the war
in the South, this was merely bravado to deflect attention
away from the mounting casualties in the South.

Recruits for the PDF from the North have tended to come
from student supporters of the regime or those in the
professions. They were encouraged to join up in the belief
that the SPLA had been all but defeated. Their fervor for the
jihad was further ignited by the stories that SPLA soldiers
threw down their weapons and ran away when confronted by the
true believers of the Islamic militias. Those lucky enough to
go to the South during the 1994-95 offensive would be the
final heroes in the war against the infidels. The propaganda
also played on the belief that the balance of resources and
numbers were in the regime's favour. The SPLA would be unable
to match the regime's forces having neither anti-tank or
anti-aircraft batteries nor external support.

What the regime had not counted upon was that the SPLA did
not act like a defeated force. The SPLA changed tactics,
refused to take on the attackers conventionally, and in true
guerrilla army fashion split up into highly mobile small
units with strict instructions to target enemy personnel. The
tactic was so successful that the NIF regime issued an order
that the deaths would not be reported to relatives of the PDF
soldiers in the North because of the negative effect this
could have.

Undermining IGADD: The Guinea Worm cease-fire was also
intended to undermine the IGADD peace process. Despite the
humanitarian nature of the cease-fire, the NIF regime was
content that it had orchestrated something which could be
perceived by the world to be a substantial step on the road
to peace, without having to make any concessions. Throughout
the four month period the regime's propaganda referred to the
humanitarian aspects and made no linkage with the IGADD peace
process. Even when the president of Kenya, Daniel arap Moi,
became involved, Khartoum made no mention of his dual role as
chairperson of the IGADD peace committee. Mr. Carter once or
twice referred to Mr. Moi in his capacity as IGADD chairman
but no great issue was made of this.

For his part, President Moi was always careful to insist
that he was acting in his role of chairperson and not as the
Kenyan leader. He was aware of how the NIF regime had
attempted to use him to foster splits among the IGADD
countries by letting it be known that Khartoum could deal
with him on an individual basis, thus making the IGADD
process redundant.

Undermining Neighbours: Part of the NIF regime's efforts
to undermine the security and sovereignty of Uganda and
Eritrea were intended to cause a conflict with members of the
IGADD peace committee on the grounds that they are in dispute
with Khartoum. Such attempts were never likely to succeed
because all the committee members made it plain from the
outset that they had a vested interest in finding a peaceful
solution to the Sudanese conflict. As that became a part of
their national interests, it was naive of Khartoum to believe
that these states would trade off one part of their national
interests against another. The regime's actions have merely
made Uganda and Eritrea more determined to broker a peace in
Sudan.

The attempt to suggest that peace talks could be held
under IGADD's auspices but not based on the Declaration of
Principles was another misguided ploy to thwart the IGADD
process. Fortunately, the SPLA has been resolute in its
response to these games.

Carter's Real Agenda: All the evidence suggests that the
former US president has been less that honest in hi dealings
with the SPLA. His real intention appears to have been to
lift the regional and international isolation of the Khartoum
regime.

After being rushed into a quick visit of the regime's
garrison town of Juba, Mr. Carter declared himself well
satisfied that the South enjoyed considerable exemption from
the Islamic Sharia law being applied in the North. He
believed that such an exemption could be the basis of a
political settlement. In a letter to the former Italian
ambassador who is currently the United Nation's envoy to
Sudan on humanitarian matters, Mr. Carter stated that the
Declaration of Principles was unhelpful to the peace process,
especially the clauses on Self-Determination and Secularism.
These would need to be dropped for the process to continue.
In other words, the former US president wishes to see the NIF
regime rewarded at the peace table with what they had been
unable to achieve on the battlefield.

Bad Timing: Mr. Carter's timing has been unfortunate. It
is inconceivable that the South through the SPLA or its other
representatives would give up all the political gains
achieved in recent years. For the NIF regime to continue in
power would be to add insult and suffering endured by the
Southern people at its hands. It is in the best interests of
the Southern people that a settlement to the conflict is
arrived at with the Sudanese opposition forces. These forces
have finally recognised the right of Self-determination as
the basis for consolidating the future unity of the country,
or for secession, and the only way forward.

Bias for the Regime: On his return from the region, Mr.
Carter's bias for the NIF regime became even more apparent.
In his letter to the United Nations secretary general's
special envoy on humanitarian affairs, Mr. Vievi Traxler, he
asked him to pursue certain matters on Khartoum's behalf. The
letter outlined how Mr. Carter had tried to circumvent the
IGADD Declaration of Principles. It also reiterates his
belief that there is religious freedom in the South, based on
his brief visit to Juba. It is surprising that anyone could
make such clear-cut conclusions when embarking on a carefully
scheduled official visit, and being taken to the places the
regime wanted him to see. The Southern people who have been
persecuted because of their religion, and some even enslaved,
are hardly likely to agree with Mr. Carter at all!

The NDA Factor: The re-emergence of the National
Democratic Alliance (NDA) as a serious political force
following its conference in Asmara in June, is certainly an
unwelcome development for the regime. The NDA has accepted
the right of all the people of Sudan to Self-determination
and now has an extensive agenda for the future once the NIF
has been overthrown. In addition, the NDA has been specific
about how it intends to bring about that overthrow.

Khartoum's reaction has been predictable, attacking the
agenda as intending to undermine Islam. Despite the rhetoric,
the regime knows that it can ill afford to ignore the NDA's
agenda without doing something concrete to counter it.

The attempt to get the SPLA to peace talks that do not
involve Self-determination and Secularism was just one ploy
to counter the NDA. The regime has yet to recognise that the
Asmara conference has brought the opposition forces together
and that the SPLA has little room to negotiate outside the
Asmara agenda. To do otherwise would be top compromise on the
important issues at the base of the Sudanese conflict. A fact
which the Asmara conference has settled once and for all.

Ignoring the Inevitable: The only way out for the regime
now would be to accept that the issues decided at Asmara are
indeed the way forward for Sudan. In the unlikely
circumstances of this happening, the NDA would need to
consider if it wanted to accept a compromise with the NIF
regime, considering all the crimes against the Sudanese
people it has committed.

In spite of all the good intentions of people like Mr.
Carter, who would like to save the NIF regime, the die of
confrontation between it and the rest of Sudan and its
neighbours has been cast. All pointers indicate that it is
now the beginning of the end for the regime.

The Gazette has no doubt of the personal good will Mr.
Carter has for the people of Sudan, but is less confident in
his political understanding of the complexities of the
Sudanese situation. Perhaps it is time for him to end his
involvement and to move on to pastures new.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September, 1995


Kenya Will Rival Deter Council of Churches?


LENGTH: 947 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995
by Nancy Wanjiku

NAIROBI - The latest registration of the Regional
Fellowship of Churches of Kenya (RFCK) may be swept aside as
mere emergence of a splinter group from the main
organisation. But a keen observer will appreciate the
political leanings presented by such a move. Will the
National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK), a long-standing
critic of the government of the day be cowed by the
establishment of a rival church body?)

Ever since a 1986 Pastoral conference organised by the
National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) questioned the
queue-voting system then adopted by the ruling Kenya African
National Union (KANU) party, the Church and state have not
missed issues to disagree about. The state has continually
employed the tactic of playing one church against the other
in a bid to weaken the politically active churches. The
latest of these efforts was in the registration of the
Regional Fellowship of Churches of Kenya (RFCK) on July 28,
1995, two months after the NCCK called for the trimming of
Presidential powers. 

The interim General Secretary of the new body, the Rev.
John Wycliffe Wanga, a former employee of the NCCK, says the
aim of establishing RFCK is to "work closely with the
government and keep NCCK on its toes." But the Rev. Mutava
Musyimi, General Secretary of the NCCK has been quoted
saying, "We are not worried about the new body. Our main
concern is the tone of some of the statements the officials
of the new Christian body are currently making. It is our
strong belief that such a new body should target at
challenging us positively. There is too much yet to be
accomplished in our pastoral mission."

Over the past decade, during which NCCK has been
particularly visible on the social political sphere,
accusations labeled against church leaders especially by
government officials claim that the clergy are serving
"foreign masters". Critics have cautioned the clergy against
mixing politics with spiritual matters because by so doing
they would be serving both God and mammon. And there have
been many calls for the de registration of NCCK including one
in 1992 by President Daniel arap Moi.

But the church leaders are not without defence. They quote
the words of Kenya's first President Mzee Jomo Kenyatta who
challenged them: "If we go wrong and you keep quiet, one day
you may have to answer for our mistakes. The nation today
needs a conscience and you (the church) are that
conscience...."

The clergy argue that when they feed the hungry they must
also ask why there is hunger. And that the NCCK as a
conciliatory non-partisan body seeks to obey the Lord's call
to "come let us reason together" and help establish a
peaceful democratic Kenya where all can enjoy a sense of
security.

During the 1986 conference at which the NCCK strongly
opposed the line-up-behind-the-candidate ballot method, the
clergy also called for a referendum to discuss constitutional
amendments. The then Archbishop of the Church of the Province
of Kenya (CPK) Manasses Kuria described the system as
unchristian, undemocratic and embarrassing. Catholic Bishop
Ndingi Mwana a' Nzeki said the voting system created schisms
within the Church while outspoken clergy, the late Anglican
Bishop Alexander Muge said, in a one party state the Church
must give a voice to the voiceless. The late Bishop, a strong
critic of the government of the day, emphasised that the role
of the church is to stand up against the pressure of
totalitarianism. Soon a chorus of insults by proNicholas Biwott calling for all churches that did not support
establishment figures began with the then Energy Minister
the NCCK move to leave the council.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


106 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Will Beijing Make A Difference?


LENGTH: 2387 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, g1995
by Wafula John and Santino Makur Rot

NAIROBI - As over 30,000 women meet in Beijing for the
Fourth United Nations World Conference between August 30 and
October 15, Africa's track record shows that women on the
continent still lack resources, authority, decision making
powers, are over-worked, underpaid and not appreciated for
their worth.

Today, women in Africa receive 30 to 40 per cent less pay
than men for the same workload according to a UN report.
Besides, much of their daily work is without any remuneration
and the value of their household labour goes unrecorded.
Furthermore about 35 per cent of all African households are
supported by women. According to a report, "Women and Men in
East, Central and Southern Africa, Facts and Figures,"
prepared by the Regional Gender Statistics Project, Nairobi,
48 per cent of households in Botswana, 40 per cent in
Swaziland and 39 per cent in Kenya were headed by women by
1990. 

The document asserts that the "participation rates in
employment" in countries studied, "are higher for men than
for women." It says; "The high employment rates for men imply
that women are not either preferred in the formal job market
or are engaged in informal employment more so within the
households." According to the report, unemployment rates are
higher for women in urban areas. In Zambia and Kenya, for
example, the urban unemployment rate among women is 22 per
cent compared to 12 per cent among men. Worse still, economic
activities in the urban areas are male dominated with men's
participation soaring as high as 82 per cent while that of
women often plunges as low as 24 per cent.

In fact blatant discrimination against women in Africa is
evident through the three sectors of most countries'
economies - public, private and parastatal. Women are
generally less employed compared to men, with Zambia
employing a meager 11 per cent of them in the public and
parastatal sectors.

A general trend in African countries is that as one moves
up the ladder of education the level of education gets lower
for women as it gets higher for men. In Kenya, the level of
education for women gradually falls from 48 per cent in
primary school education to a mere 28 per cent in higher
education. What worsens the situation in Africa is the
absence of women in major decision making roles. With hardly
any government ministers to talk of, a handful of Members of
Parliament (MPs), coupled with an acute shortage of civic
leaders, women are disadvantaged in matters of decision
making and policy implementation.

Even in local administration, which is vital as it deals
with the lower echelons of decision making and the
influencing of people at the grassroots level, women are
grossly misrepresented. Zimbabwe, for example, has only 4 per
cent of women mayors, a scenario that repeats itself in
several African countries. With the rural African woman
shouldering the burden of food production and receiving
meager returns, often through the man, there is need to
address her problems and look for strategies to alleviate her
suffering.

Will Beijing offer a change of direction in the lives of
African women? A culmination of the process that began with
national preparations, at the Beijing conference will
evaluate progress towards the empowerment of women;
politically, economically and socially, since the "Nairobi
Forward-Looking Strategies for the Advancement of Women up to
the year 2000" were adopted in the 1985 conference in the
Kenyan capital.
Participating African states have prepared a document
detailing critical areas of concern for African women. The
document, The African Platform for Action, was adopted by 52
participating member states during the Fifth African Regional
Conference on Women held in Dakar, Senegal from November 16
to 23 last year.

Among its 11 areas of concern are: economic empowerment
and poverty reduction among women, violence against women,
women in education and training, the girl-child, and women
political empowerment and decision making. Other crucial
areas covered at Dakar included property rights, land rights,
inheritance and asset holdings. African delegates are
lobbying for these issues to be included in a global plan of
action which will be adopted by the Beijing conference.

To date, three UN world conferences on women have been
held. The first, in Mexico City (1975) during the
international women's year adopted a plan of action that led
to the declaration by the UN General Assembly, of the
following 10 years as the UN decade for women. In 1979, the
General Assembly adopted the convention on the elimination of
all forms of discrimination against women to which 133 states
are signatories. The second conference held in Copenhagen,
Denmark (1980), adopted a programme of action for the second
half of the decade for women with emphasis on education,
employment and health. The third world conference, in Nairobi
(1985), reviewed the achievements made and obstacles
encountered during the decade for women and adopted the
famous "Nairobi Forward-looking strategies." The strategies
provided a framework for action at the national, regional,
and international levels. The forward-looking strategies were
evaluated by the UN commission on the status of women. It
revealed that while there was greater consciousness and
sensitivity towards issues affecting women, there was loss of
momentum in implementation of the strategies. The fourth
conference attempts to rekindle this momentum while focussing
on other issues like violence against women, sexual
harassment and the girl-child.

However, in the 20 years since the inception of the UN
conference on women, certain undeniable advances have been
made, observers say. Women are now entering the labour market
in unprecedented numbers and pursuing greater roles in all
sectors of public life.

Some observers insist that governments have adopted major
legislations which promise women equal opportunities,
treatment and respect for their rights, that women are
increasingly gaining access to proper health care, and civil
justice. What is more, they say, women themselves have become
more aware of their rights hence are mobilising to fight
discrimination and persistent injustice.

Nevertheless some observers argue that the problems faced
by African women would best be solved at home. But Rosemary
A. Nandi, a Kenyan teacher counters such critics. " A Beijing
enthusiast", she says, "it is important that African women
meet others both for exposure and to hear how other women are
solving their own problems. It is a forum for assessing each
other's strengths and weaknesses," Whether the Beijing
conference will be any different from the previous three,
particularly the Nairobi one, is a great source of concern
for most Africans.

"It is a question we have been asking ourselves too," says
Rose Arungu-Oiende, UN advisor and Liaison Officer for
Africa. "Indeed Beijing is not going to be anything that the
Nairobi conference was not, or say anything that Nairobi did
not say." "But there is one thing it will do," she says
confidently. "Unlike the Nairobi conference which identified
problems and strategies, but did not say how key players
could achieve strategies, Beijing will tell us of
implementation plans that are achievable," she concluded. The
official adds that the Beijing document has a resource
section which discusses what is required for the
implementation of the strategies. The reality of attending
the Beijing meeting is not just in participation but in the
impact the forum will have on individual lives in the long
run. And it is how those policies will be implemented by
individual governments, NGO's and communities that will
matter.

Whatever recommendations Beijing will make, these will
have to come to terms with the African reality, hence there
is more need to sensitize the African man and community as a
whole on the benefits to be accrued with the empowering of
women.

The UN Economic Commission for Africa recognises the
difficulties of implementing internationally agreed upon
policies from its experiences with the implementation of the
Nairobi Forward-looking strategies, whose failures it
attributes to "the absence of appropriate structures for
undertaking implementation activities and the failures to
identify the sources of necessary resources." Whether
"appropriate structures" and resources will be available
after Beijing remains to be seen.

However, the UN also recognises that: "the effectiveness
of these machineries depends on strong political will, such
political will should lead to giving the machinery an
institutional location which will allow it to have a direct
effect on government policy, have access to information, and
reach out to grass roots organisations.

Will African governments take up this challenge after
Beijing? Non-Governmental organisations too have a key role
to play through their programmes. They have to take a more
dynamic approach to translate the UN document into meaningful
guidelines. Above all, the ordinary African woman will play a
leading role by impressing upon the generally male-dominated
community her great worth. However, the positive recognition
of the African woman from a variety of shackles forged over
ages by a male dominated society will not come as a result of
women representatives solely fighting it out on their own.
Such achievements would only be reached through communal
understanding. The awareness that prejudices, domination,
subjugation, and exploitation, be they out of racial,
religious or gender bias, are demeaning and work against
societal progress.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


107 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Family Stability Crucial to Child Education


LENGTH: 2027 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995
by Alex Bagenda

NAIROBI - Providing good education is not always
synonymous with schooling. The kind of family a child grows
up in is crucial to the general well being of the child.

Talk of education and most minds will focus on the school
as the only place where a child must be introduced to
education, with the teachers as the key players in such a
task.

But more crucial to a child, even before he/she starts
schooling is the role a family plays in the 0-5 year stage of
life. In a recent sub-regional workshop for policy makers in
Africa on approaches to Early Childhood Care and Education
(ECCE) held in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, the importance
of the family was highlighted because of the key role this
unit plays in safeguarding and enhancing the rights and
welfare of the child. At the meeting organised by the United
Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
(UNESCO), Mrs Kisamba Mugerwa, Senior Lecturer in the
Department of Sociology at Uganda's Makerere University told
participants from Eastern and Southern Africa that the family
must remain a strong agent of socialisation for the African
child. 

"Its contribution to early childhood care and development
cannot be under-estimated. The family fulfills varying but
always important responsibilities of ensuring that the
children of the preceding generation are equipped with
adequate necessary skills to meet the challenges in modern
society," she said. It is within the family system that a
child is first provided with warmth, security, shelter, food,
clothing, guidance, and identity which are basic needs
essential for proper human development. "The proper
development of a child, as we are reliably informed by
psychologists is influenced by how those basic needs are
adequately met during one's childhood and the child's
relationship with the environment. Without these provisions,
the early childhood development of a child can easily be
jeopardised," noted Mugerwa.

But the current trend in Uganda paints a gloomy picture.
Many families are headed by children under 18 partly as a
result of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
pandemic which has claimed the lives of both parents. In such
cases, the early childhood development of surviving children
has been left in the hands of guardians and young siblings
who are ill prepared to handle the parental functions.

Another aspect affecting the strength of the family today
in Uganda is increasing unemployment and retrenchment as a
result of economic restructuring activities currently being
effected. Problems resulting from restructuring are going to
continue to affect the functions of the family, in that an
increasing number of people may not be able to provide the
essential basic needs for the development of their children.

For those who are employed the conditions of work, rising
costs of essential commodities and threats of unemployment or
retrenchment may leave the family in a position where it is
unable to deal with provision of basic needs of the
children," pointed out the Makerere lecturer.

Rebecca Nyonyintono, a consulting sociologist also
emphasised the importance of the family in early childhood
education. "The family should be accorded the necessary
protection and assistance so that it can fully assume its
responsibility within the community. The family atmosphere
must be right in order for the family to be able to meet its
key responsibility," she noted. Unfortunately in Africa, much
as parents say they love their children, discipline and
authority override the demonstration of real love, parental
understanding, what the child wants to do and why and his/her
point of view in a decision which must be taken. Said Dr.
Nyonyintono, "We have none or little skills in understanding
children, that is why we resort to tough discipline,
manipulation and downright cruelty and negligence of
children."

Many of our African settings do not encourage open
demonstration of emotions including love, for fear of
spoiling the child. Dr. Nyonyintono exemplified loving a
child as being there for the child, parenting the child,
guiding the child into responsible life, accepting the child
as she/he is, and taking the child's opinions seriously.
"This is the essence of affirming the rights and welfare of
the child," she noted.

The United Nations convention on the rights of the child
and the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) charter on the
rights and welfare of the child clearly state that "the child
should be fully prepared to live an individual life in
society and brought up in the spirit of the ideals proclaimed
in the charter and in particular in the spirit of peace,
dignity, tolerance, freedom, equality and solidarity,"
observed Nyonyintono. She went on to say that these values
can be inculcated in children. The UN convention on the
rights of the child states that it is "by reason of physical
and mental immaturity" that the child needs special
safeguards and care including appropriate legal protection
before as well as after birth. The convention and the OAU
Charter spell out the safeguards, provisions for care and
legal framework for protection of the rights of the child
including before birth.

Dr. Nyonyintono noted that malnourished children and
under-nourished adults especially pregnant women undermine
the quality of life of the child before birth. "The right of
the child before birth is therefore a broad concept covering
the right to quality of life across the generations," she
said. The UN convention and the OAU charter are meant to
ensure that every child realises the right to reach full
physical and mental maturation before being saddled with
adult responsibilities.

However, many adults left to their own whims and fancies
would deny children the right to proper maturation before
involving them into adult activities and responsibilities.
Mere children care for their younger siblings because they
are too many of them, too frequent, too early, too long in
the family and the parents must rely on their children to
raise one another.

"Children, sometimes below the age of 14, are married off
or seduced by adults to become lovers or wives and
consequently parents," noted Nyonyintono. In Uganda, some
people base decisions about girls' marriage or involvement in
sexual activity on mere puberty because puberty is mistaken
for physical and mental maturity. "The social indicators of
this country are a clear testimony to the price we are paying
for failure to let children reach physical and mental
maturity before involving them in adult activities and
responsibilities. In other words we are still very far from
protecting the rights and welfare of our children," the
sociologist lamented.

On the important role played by the mother in early
childhood education, Kisamba Mugerwa expressed concern about
the lack of traditional support mothers used to enjoy in the
past. "The mother enjoyed the support of other women in the
household and the community at large. The community assisted
in passing on the cultural practices, the social behaviour
required, the rites, the obligations and expectations of
society during various ceremonies," she noted.

Today, mothers get very little support if any from the
community, a factor that has been made worse by working
mothers who must stay away from their children mostly during
the day. In many cases in Uganda for instance, some children
who would otherwise be attending school have major
responsibilities to care for young siblings or work in the
field. In other cases, children are victims of frustration,
blackmail or ill-treatment by family members, yet a family
should provide security right from early childhood. "A child
needs to live in a stable environment with continuing
affection and fairly well ordered living conditions.

But with the changing roles of the family, it is becoming
increasingly difficult for children to receive adequate
protection from this unit as was the case in traditional
societies. Therefore the need to find an institution which
would provide assistance to those children who may find
themselves in such a predicament might help those in need,"
Mugerwa observed.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


108 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Madagascar Prime Minister Offers To Quit


LENGTH: 1614 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995
by Sam Gonza

ANTANANARIVO - Towards the end of July, Madagascar's Head
of State, President Albert Zafy, alarmed the Indian Ocean
island nation, one of the poorest countries in the world,
with his announcement that weapons were being smuggled into
the country with the possible intention of causing an
insurrection. It was the culmination of a highly damaging
stand-off with his Prime Minister, Francisque Ravony, that
has threatened to split the Armed Forces and the State.

Francisque Ravony, the reformist Prime Minister of the
Indian Ocean island nation of Madagascar has agreed to step
down in mid-September after the damaging stand-off between
him and the Head of State, President Albert Zafy, threatened
to drag sections of the Armed Forces into different camps
with the potential to destroy all democratic gains made
during the past five years. Observers link his offer to quit
office to reconciliation and mediation by the Christian
Council of Churches in Madagascar, FFKM, which organised a
series of meetings between the two leaders. The efforts
appear to have opened up Ravony's eyes to the potentially
explosive situation in the impoverished nation of seven
million people. 

The current stand-off started in June when Zafy brought
into the open simmering suspicions and disagreement between
the President and the Premier, calling the National Assemblythere was irrevocable bad blood between them, Zafy announced
appointed Ravony a liar, hypocrite and corrupt man. Saying
he was calling a referendum on September 17 to ask the
Malagasy people to decide whether the President or the
National Assembly should constitutionally be empowered to
appoint the Prime Minister.

Ravony narrowly defeated a motion of censure against him
on July 12. The Prime Minister says he will step down
regardless of the referendum's outcome. As their disagreement
reached a stalemate, Zafy went on national radio on July 26
to claim that weapons were being smuggled into Madagascar.
Blaming unnamed foreign elements, he linked the increased
robberies, banditry, murders and kidnappings to the purported
smuggled weapons.

But before the motion of censure against him was sorted
out in his favour, Ravony made his point very clear -- if the
President made it impossible for the government to function,
then the Premier would appoint a new one and include the
military.

However, Ravony's threat to involve the military in the
government disturbed many people as it evoked memories of a
similar state of affairs during the rule of President
Phillibert Tsiranana in 1972. Then, the army refused to quit,
and it required the concerted effort and sacrifice of the
Malagasy people which included a great loss of life to
dislodge them in the early 1990s. It so happened that in
1972, in the midst of severe economic difficulties partly
caused by poor international prices for one of the main
crops, vanilla, peasants in Tulear Province revolted and the
country's students soon joined the civil disobedience
campaign. Tsiranana, who had ruled Madagascar since
independence in 1960, acknowledged his inability to rule and
turned over the government to Major General Gabriel
Ramanantsoa.

Ravony's critics point out that as a member of one of the
numerous pro-democracy groups whose concerted efforts removed
the military leadership of Commander Didier Ratsiraka, the
successor of two military regimes, the premier, should never
have contemplated such a naive solution to his stand-off with
Zafy. In fact Didier Ratsiraka's supporters still play a role
in Madagascar's politics under the umbrella of the National
Council of Federalist Groupings. In March, Ratsiraka's
supporters joined a faction in Parliament called Ralaimongo
Active Forces in organising a demonstration against the
government. They were demanding the release from custody of
two opposition personalities who had announced the formation
of "a parallel government" for Madagascar.

Ravony's task as Prime Minister has not been an easy one
in the poverty stricken nation. Apparently in the hope of
retrieving the economy from the abyss, Madagascar under
Ravony has continued to embrace World Bank/International
Monetary Fund (IMF) guidelines which go back to the time when
Ratsiraka assumed power 15 years ago. The ordinary people of
Madagascar have reaped little from IMF programmes. Internal
restlessness has come in the wake of dwindling incomes, high
food prices, rampant epidemics like malaria in some parts of
Madagascar, urban crime and banditry and a stagnant job
market.

The Gross National Product (GNP) is less than US dollars
200. The country is massively indebted, estimated at US
dollars 5,000 million. When the Malagasy franc was floated in
May last year at the insistence of the IMF, the currency
collapsed overnight sending prices of necessities spiraling.
The floatation was done one month after a devastating series
of hurricanes hit the island. Leading cash crops are coffee,
cloves and vanilla.

The World Bank wants reforms in the state controlled
vanilla industry. Investors are now eyeing Madagascar's
pristine forests, home to unique fauna and flora. One such
scheme is already quite advanced and involves the Rio Tinto
Zinc Corp, a Canadian firm which is seeking concessions for
huge tracts of forests to mine a metal used in the aircraft
industry, titanium, from the coastal sands in the south east
of Madagascar.

Critics like the ecology promoting Friends of the Earth,
warn that such schemes will set a precedent for the
destruction of a larger area of Madagascan forests. Friends
of the Earth's field director in Madagascar, Andrew Lees,
lived in a section of the contested forest. He was found dead
last year in mysterious circumstances.
It is estimated that the Rio Tinto deal would earn Madagascar
at least US dollars 40 million per annum.

Like Zafy, the majority in the Assembly, including Speaker
Rev. Richard Andriamanjato, are opposed to Ravony's undiluted
support for World Bank programmes. Both Zafy and
Andriamanjato are reported to be shopping around for
commercial loans as an alternative to those from the Bank.
Observers agree that should Ravony quit as anticipated come
mid- September, whoever replaces him will have no choice but
to go along with the World Bank prescriptions. It is unlikely
that Zafy and his key backers in the Cabinet will be able to
bring into Madagascar's shaky economy a level of investment
that will boost the country's overall recovery process.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September, 1995


Zaire Ecumenical Appeal As Pressure Mounts On Refugees


LENGTH: 1014 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995

GENEVA - The Action by Churches Together (ACT), an
ecumenical organisation comprising the Lutheran World
Federation (LWF), the World Council of Churches (WCC) and
more than 40 major related relief agencies has sent out an
urgent appeal for nearly US dollars 3 million to assist
Rwandese and Burundian refugees in Zaire. The US dollar 2.9
million appeal by ACT comes in the wake of a recent ultimatum
by Zairean authorities' that all Rwandese and Burundian
refugees "must leave the country before December 31.

At a press conference here on August 29, Zairean Prime
Minister, Kengo wa Dondo said "repatriation must be en masse,
without interruption and end by December 31, 1995 at the
latest. In case repatriation is delayed beyond December 31,
1995, Zaire reserves the right to make the refugees leave its
territory." 

ACT which was constituted last year to respond to the
world's growing emergency crises, said most of the funds were
intended for food and non-food items. Purchases listed under
non-food items include plastic sheeting, ropes, blankets,
kitchen sets, jerricans and soaps. "But in order to meet the
most critical needs, ACT has agreed to allocate US dollars
300,000 from unearmarked funds from the Church World Actionof plastic shelter materials," ACT stressed in its appeal.
Rwanda (CWA-R) Advent Appeal towards the purchase and airlift

The ecumenical group also expressed concern that "there is
very little in Rwanda for the refugees when they arrive in
this uncertain and desperate state" and hoped that the funds
appeal would raise the targeted amount. The appeal was
jointly signed by the director of the World Council of
Churches (WCC), Unit IV, Rev. Myra Blyth and Rev. Rudolf
Hinz, director of the Lutheran World Federation/World Service
(LWF/WS)

Zaire's threat against Rwandese and Burundian refugees,
began on August 19. The authorities first used "force" to
effect the operation, but later stopped after the United
Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) among other
international organisations and governments, complained about
the act. But by the time the UN and others intervened, some
independent statistics indicated that close to 15,000
refugees had already been forcibly expelled from Zaire.

At the Geneva meeting between Zairean Prime Minister Kengo
wa Dondo and the UNHCR boss, Mrs. Sadako Ogata, the UN head
refused to accept fixed, numerical targets for a programme
which she said, remained voluntary.
Zaire is said to be hosting one of the highest numbers of
refugees, mainly Rwandese and Burundian most of whom fled
their countries following ethnic killings early last year. By
the time of going to press there were reports of a heavy flow
of refugees from Zaire with some NGOs reportedly shifting
their operations from inside Zaire to Rwanda and Burundi.

A recent Report of the International Council for Voluntary
Agencies (ICVA) on the refugee crisis in Zaire says the
central African state hosts more than one million of the 1.8
million Rwandese refugees in the Great Lakes region. It also
hosts some 72,000 of the 180,000 Burundi refugees in central
Africa. The ICVA report says, Zaire has already expelled
between 15,000 and 20,000 refugees and "there is no reason to
believe the situation will change." Saying that political
relations between Zaire, Rwanda and Burundi have
deteriorated, the ICVA report explains that "the decision
taken by the UN Security Council on August 16 to lift the
arms embargo on Rwanda has further complicated the already
fragile political situation.

The expulsion of Rwandese and Burundian refugees from
Zaire comes barely a month since the All Africa Conference of
Churches (AACC) made a pastoral visit to both countries.
During the visit, AACC emphasised the need for both churches
and non- church bodies to work hand-in-hand towards the
realisation of true peace and reconciliation among the
suffering Rwandese and Burundians.

The AACC delegation was led by the organisation's
President, South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu and its
General Secretary, Rev. Jose Chipenda.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995

September, 1995


Sierra Leone Deaths From Starvation Reported


LENGTH: 614 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995

FREETOWN - Relief agencies in Sierra Leone say food
shortages have reached crisis proportion in several parts of
the country, with about 300 people reported dead in the last
one week or so as a result.

But a spokesman of Capt. Valentine Strasser's government
has denied reports of any deaths resulting from starvation.
Sierra Leone has been experiencing civil war since early
1991. 

The agencies maintain that about 300 displaced people
starved to death in parts of the country which have been cut
off from relief supplies and that many more people were dying
every day. They say continued fighting between government
troops and those of the rebel Revolutionary United Front
(RUF) has severely disrupted food distribution, adding that
the hardest hit are the towns of Kenema and Bo, in the east.

The chairman of a committee for displaced people, Mr.
Ismail Foday, told reporters earlier that the deaths occurred
near the eastern town of Kenema, 240 kilometres east of the
capital, Freetown, and two other towns further east, Segbwema
and Daru. Reports quote Foday as saying: "The entire region
will virtually become empty in a very short while if
something is not done quickly." But a government spokesman,
Dr. Keith Kamara, denied reports that food shortages have
reached crisis levels in parts of the country, and said no
one has died of hunger in Kenema.

However, he conceded in a British Broadcasting Corporation
(BBC) interview that children were dying of cholera in the
region. Relief officials are quoted as saying there is enough
food in the West African country to feed the starving
population, but continuing rebel ambushes on major roads were
keeping many war-affected areas cut off from relief supplies.

The Sierra Leone Red Cross was reported last July as
saying that at least 76 people had died of hunger around the
besieged town of Bo, 170 kilometres east of Freetown. It
blamed the deaths on the destruction of rice and manioc
fields by RUF rebels. In recent months, the Sierra Leone
army, backed by troops from Nigeria, Guinea, and mercenaries
from the South African firm, Executive Outcomes, has claimed
a string of victories against the rebels. Troops are said to
have dislodged the rebels from key positions and captured
several of their bases from the far north to the southeast.
But those efforts have not prevented Foday Sankoh's rebels
from mounting daring raids and ambushes on food convoys.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


111 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Kenya Secrecy Surrounds Sale of Oldest Daily


LENGTH: 1107 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995

NAIROBI - Kenya's oldest mass circulation daily the East
African Standard, previously owned by Lonrho, has been sold
to new investors.
However, to whom, at what cost and how the payments are going
to be made are matters still shrouded in secrecy. The 93
year-old newspaper has been at the centre of speculations
since African Analysis, a London-based newsletter, disclosed
early August that the Kenyan daily would be sold.

African Analysis further reported that the buyer, for an
undisclosed amount, would be Mr. Mark Too whose challenge "is
to make the Standard as upward mobile" as possible with
stepped-up circulation. Mr. Too, Vice-chairman of Lonrho East
Africa and a local, is a close associate of Kenya's ruling
elite. 

But Lonrho, the owners of the East African Standard then,
were concerned that if the paper was sold locally to parties
connected to the ruling Kenya African national Union (KANU)
party, the sale could damage the company's reputation. It was
also feared that the sale of the daily to buyers directly
associated the government could cause problems with the
international community who have already expressed concern at
the concentration of print and broadcast media ownership in
government hands and the overall freedom of the press in
Kenya.
There were also fears in Nairobi that any sale of the paper
could lead to substantial job losses. Mr. Too however denied
he was buying the newspaper.

So when Mr. Bob Holt, Managing Director of the East
African Standard, convened a meeting August 28 to explain the
implications of the takeover by new investors, employees were
not amused. Employees accused him of not being open about the
newspaper's sale. It was only Mr. Holt, they said, who knew
who the real owners of the East African Standard were.

The employees further accused him of having received
generous terminal benefits and of "leaving them in darkness".
The confrontation came just a day after a representative of
the buyers, described obscurely as 'the new investors" and
"the new majority shareholders", visited the newspaper
installations in Nairobi. Mr. Robin Sewell, a London-based
director of the holding company, had pledged a hands-off
policy and said the new owners wished to see the company run
professionally. He had named Mr. Too as the paper's new
chairman.

During the meeting with Mr. Holt employees gave a
September 5, noon ultimatum for the following issues to be
addressed; An early retirement scheme for employees who were
no longer interested in continuing with the work; Payment of
all dues for those wishing to end their contract with the
newspaper and start afresh with the new owner, and; Payment
of all dues to those who wanted to continue. They further
demanded that the company give all staff members job
guarantees in writing as "verbal assurances cannot hold
water."

Holt had earlier described the sale of the newspaper to
new owners as "an enthusiastic and adventurous venture,"
saying that the new London- based investors had bought 53 per
cent of the total shares. He added that the new investors
would be very demanding and would like to see sales and
advertising improve. Contacted over allegations that he and a
few others had been paid terminal benefits, Mr. Holt said, "I
am not leaving."

Later Mr. Holt made it clear that the pension scheme was
governed by specific laws which state that a pension scheme
cannot be released to any worker until he or she leaves the
company service. He reiterated that all employees will have
the opportunity to transfer the pension scheme from Lonrho
into one operated by the new owners, subject to clearance
from the income tax department.

Meanwhile the East African Standard employees have refused
to sign a circular requiring them to indicate whether they
wished to resign or continue working for the newspaper.
Instead, four of the staff representatives wrote to the
Managing Director Bob Holt saying they stood by their earlier
memorandum in which they demanded full terminal benefits
before September 5 (tomorrow).

The paper's sale came after it had improved on its page
designs and colour scheme, adopting a changed approach to the
presentation of news and feature items in an attempt to boost
sales. Speculations were rife that the paper was loosing on
both sales and advertisements.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September, 1995


Somalia Breakthrough As Americans Visit Somaliland


LENGTH: 547 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995

NAIROBI - In what constitutes a major breakthrough for the
self-declared Republic of Somaliland and its leader President
Mohammed Ibrahim Egal, a United States State Department
delegation completed on August 28 a visit to the country over
a number of days. US State Department officials described the
visit as "a fact finding mission."

The delegation was led by senior officials from the
American Embassy in Djibouti. It included an official from
the Somali Desk in Washington as well as USAID officials. 

According to President Egal, the delegation was keen to
learn the problem his country faced since it broke away from
Somalia in 1991. Egal said USAID had pledged food aid to his
country, with a population of about 1 million people. He
added that in future Somaliland's affairs "would be handled
by the American Embassy in Djibouti and not Nairobi where the
American Ambassador to Somalia resides."

President Egal expressed gratitude for the visit which he
described as a tentative sign of recognition of Somaliland by
Washington and the rest of the world. Since it was formed by
a series of elders' meetings in May 1991, Somaliland has
attracted little attention from the United States and the
rest of the world.

Observers believe the American visit at this time is
closely linked to the threat by Somali factional leader
Mohammed Farah Aideed to disarm Somaliland and other areas of
Somalia by force within six months, if the authorities in
Hargeissa failed to do so. It was clear that Aideed was
trying to assert his control over the old greater Somalia
including Somaliland. The Americans are alarmed that Aideed
is in the process of reconstituting an army. There are
reports of Libya's involvement and funding for Aideed's new
army.

Since its formation in 1991, Somaliland has been
relatively peaceful until early 1994, when an insurrection by
a former leader of the country--before it joined a unified
Somalia in 1960--began to cause instability in Somaliland.

Egal has blamed Aideed for the security problems including
the insurrection led by Mr. Ibrahim Tur.

Africa News


September, 1995


Sudan Military Junta Releases Political Prisoners


LENGTH: 894 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995

KHARTOUM - The Sudanese military junta has ordered the
release of former Prime Minister Sadik el-Mahdi and several
other political detainees previously held on alleged
political offenses, the official Sudan News Agency (SUNA)
reported on August 26.

SUNA quoted junta spokesman Abdul-Basit Sabdarat as saying
that El- Mahdi and other political detainees were released
following a government order. "The Sudan is now free of all
political detainees after the concerned authorities carried
out the decision of the National Security Council on the
release of all political detainees," Sabdarat was quoted as
saying. Upon release, El-Mahdi, who was detained three months
ago for having criticised a high-level official, along with
31 other political prisoners, was met at home in Omdurman by
scores of his supporters the same day, witnesses said. 

The former prime minister was arrested in May on charges
of conspiracy against the government of General Omar Hassan
el-Beshir, which had overthrown him in a bloodless coup
d'etat in 1989, after he criticised Hassan el-Tourabi, the
main power behind the National Islamic Front (NIF) regime in
Khartoum.

The seven-member National Security Council, headed by Eldetainees without exception within 72 hours. Of the 32 other
Beshir, decided on August 23 to release all political
political prisoners, 19 were from El-Mahdi's dissolved Umma
Party, eight from the outlawed Communist Party and five from
the disbanded Arab Socialist Ba'athist Party, Sabdarat said.

However, contradictions have arisen as to the exact number
of political detainees in Sudan. State Minister at the
presidency Mahdi Ibrahim put the figure at less than 30, but
the legal advisor and spokesman for the Human Rights
Consultative Council, Ahmed el-Muft, says there were more
than 70 people held on political and economic sabotage
charges.

The release of political detainees in Sudan came only a
day after the military ruler, General El-Beshir, was reported
to have announced that the country would hold presidential
and parliamentary elections next year. State-run radio
Omdurman quoted the President as having made the announcement
at a rally in the west of the country on August 22. Beshir,
who seized power in a coup in June 1989, did not give a
precise date for the elections, and did not say whether he
would contest the presidency.

The recent developments come as the military-led
government in Khartoum face accusations of serious human
rights abuses throughout the country and opposition groups
unite in a final attempt to end the military dictatorship.
Neighbouring governments are also up in arms against
Khartoum, accusing it of sponsoring rebel groups bent on
overthrowing their respective governments. The United States
denounces Sudan for harbouring and training terrorists to
subvert non-Islamic governments in the region.

Last month the London-based human rights monitoring group,
African Rights, accused Khartoum of carrying out genocide of
the Nuba people and appealed to the international community
to intervene "to prevent this crime from being perpetrated".
In its report, African Rights accused Khartoum of carrying
many atrocities in the mainly Christian and animist southern
Sudan, where rebel groups took up arms against Khartoum in
1983. The atrocities included, torching of villages, murder,
rape and mass arrests.

In addition, the southern rebels and the political
opposition decided at the end of June to unite against the
Islamic government.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


114 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Ethiopia Meles Elected Premier as Transition Ends


LENGTH: 747 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995

ADDIS ABABA - Former Ethiopian President Meles Zenawi was
elected Prime Minister of the country by the federal
parliament on August 23, bringing to an end a four-year
transition period that followed the overthrow of Marxist
dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam in 1991.

The previous day, the federal assembly had elected Meles's
Information Minister Negasso Guidada, a Christian member of
the Oromo ethnic majority, to the largely ceremonial role of
president. The new federal assembly, which consists of 540
representatives from Meles' Ethiopian People's Revolutionary
Democratic Front (EPRDF) out of a total 548 deputies, was
elected in the first multi-party elections in May. 

The choice of an Oromo to the largely honorary post was
not a major surprise, but observers had generally expected a
Muslim to be elected to the post. Oromos are divided
virtually equally between Christians and Muslims, while
Tigreans, of which Meles is one, are Christians.

Major opposition parties boycotted the poll, claiming it
was a farce, although it received broad support from the
international community which, led by the United States, had
largely backed the democratisation process that has developed
over four years of transitional rule. Opposition parties
alleged that the transition, which was meant to last only two
years, gave the EPRDF time to turn the democratisation
process to its own advantage. They also accused Meles of
wanting to break up Ethiopia, a reference to the country's
new constitution which provides for the right of Ethiopian
regions to secede along ethnic or linguistic lines.

Two years ago, Meles, who led the mainly Tigrean and
Eritrean forces which overturned the communist military
regime of Colonel Mengistu Haile Mariam in 1991, agreed to
the independence of Eritrea after it waged a 30-year war of
independence against successive Ethiopian governments.
Negasso, in his first statement as president on August 22,
which was declared a public holiday, said his priorities
would be to "reinforce the process of democratisation and
peace" and "economic development".

But in his first speech since election, Meles delivered a
strong warning to opponents at home and abroad not to try to
stir ethnic unrest in the country, and attacked the private
press which, he said, "spread hatred, putting democracy in
danger". "I want to warn those who continue to break the law
and who preach war that the government will take vigorous
measures against them," Meles said, but added that he was
ready to assist "responsible newspapers which criticised the
government in a responsible manner without inventing
stories".

The new premier also urged Ethiopia's intellectuals to
return to work, in return for which his government would
treat them as "rare pearls". Meles also announced a
forthcoming restructuring of the armed forces, "so as to
ensure an equitable representation of ethnic diversity at all
levels".


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


115 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Liberia Ruling Council To Be Sworn In


LENGTH: 867 words


 
All Africa Press Service
August 31, 1995

MONROVIA - Liberia's new state council was expected to be
sworn in on September 1, formally setting off the process of
implementing the latest peace agreement signed on August 20
in Abuja, Nigeria.
At the same time, chief rebel leader Charles Taylor would be
making his first appearance in Monrovia in more than five
years since his National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL)
invaded from Ivory Coast on December 24, 1989.

Taylor is one of six members of a collective presidency
which will rule Liberia for the next one year as per the
Abuja agreement until democratic elections are held. Other
members are University of Liberia Prof. Wilton Sankawulo
(Chairman), 90-year-old Chief Tamba Tailor, Oscar Quiah, both
civilians; George Boley of the Liberia Peace Council (LPC)
and Alhaji Kromah of the Mandingo faction of the United
Liberation Movement of Liberia (ULIMO). 

Taylor calls his planned arrival in Monrovia "a moment
that Liberians have been waiting for" and "peace is finally
at hand in Liberia."
The Abuja accord effectively ended perennial wrangling over
power-sharing between the factions following the signing of
another agreement in Ghana last September.

A high-powered delegation of Ghana's President Jerry
Rawlings, current Chairman of the Economic Community of West
African States (ECOWAS) and joint broker of the initiative
with Nigeria's Sani Abacha, was expected to officiate at the
ceremony in Monrovia. Ghana's Deputy Foreign Minister
Mohammed Ibn Chambas, told reporters earlier that President
Rawlings was personally due to attend the swearing-in
ceremony of the transitional ruling council in Monrovia at
the weekend.

Also expected to attend was the United Nations Special
Envoy to Liberia, Anthony Nyakyi, while the Organisation of
African Unity (OAU) was to be represented by former Zimbabwe
President the Rev. Canaan Banana.

A cease-fire which came into force mid-night on August 26,
is said to be holding with all sides observing it. "Even
before midnight, the factions had been observing the truce.
We are very happy about this," the Ghanaian Deputy Foreign
Minister was quoted as saying.

Confidence in the Abuja accord is so high that the street
value of the Liberian dollar has surged dramatically in
recent days. By the time of going to press it was trading at
25 to the US dollar compared with 59.5 in the previous week.
A Lebanese merchant was reported saying the huge gain in
value by the Liberian dollar had left him unsure whether he
would recover his money from goods bought before the
fluctuations began. "We will experience financial losses if
we continue to sell at reduced prices," he told journalists.

In preparation for the swearing in of the state council,
the ECOWAS intervention force, ECOMOG, has taken control of
several highways leading from rebel-held territories,
including the one from Taylor's inland headquarters at
Gbarnga, in central Liberia. It was not immediately clear
whether NPFL troops and those of ECOMOG will man joint checkOf all the warlords, Taylor is the only one who has eluded
points along the 150 km stretch from Gbarnga to Monrovia.
Monrovia since the beginning of the war, fearing for his life
and claiming that the Nigerian contingent of ECOMOG had been
after him on orders from Nigerian military rulers. But
following his reconciliation meeting with President Abacha,
he (Taylor) said he now felt confident to travel to Monrovia.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


116 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Nigeria Catholic Bishops Censure The Military


LENGTH: 1187 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 15, 1995

ABUJA - The military is to blame for the "continuous
distressing situation" that Nigeria finds itself in, because
soldiers have frequently interfered in the country's
"democratic development at every slight excuse," the
country's Catholic bishops have said.

In a communique issued at the end of their conference held
at Makurdi, Benue State earlier this month, the bishops
censured the military for its role in causing several
constitutional crises and urged them to exercise selfThe bishops challenged the people of Nigeria "henceforth
restraint in their ambition to rule.
to learn and to defend their constitution against any
interference by any group, no matter how well armed." The
bishops observed that experience of other nations has proved
it is possible to do so, "even against tanks and guns". 

Disapproving the current constitutional amendments by the
military regime to set transitional programmes, the
communique issued by the Catholic Bishops' Conference of
Nigeria (CBCN), charged that the consultation should not be
left in the hands of dishonest and selfish people," as to do
so "will for ever continue to be a bone of contention".

"The ills of Nigeria cannot be adequately addressed
outside the frame- work of a solid democratic good government
which can encourage and promote free expression of diverse
opinions," the bishops said.
The Catholic leaders said it was "an insult on the nation for
any group of people, no matter how well intentioned, to claim
monopoly of wisdom and decide for all how things must go".

The bishops criticised the stretch of time for the
transition programme, saying it would merely lead to
political complications that is meant to confuse the people
in the march towards democracy.
Instead they suggested that a year was long enough for
Nigerians to arrive at successful elections "if there was an
honest commitment on the part the present regime to honour
its proclaimed commitment of leaving political power as soon
as possible."

On the outcome of the draft constitution, the bishops said
the confusion and controversy that surrounded the result
appeared to bear their initial expressed skepticism
concerning "the need and appropriateness of drafting the
document."

The CBCN warned Nigerians that there can never be a
perfect constitution, and that a constitution would only work
if there was a minimum of good will and effort to live
together as a nation. There was an urgent need to address the
factors responsible for rendering "our constitutions
unworkable," the bishops stated.

The clerics further noted with concern, the appalling
state of the country where human needs such as food, health,
and shelter were becoming luxurious only available to a few
people. "The quality of life for the majority has continued
to deteriorate, with the unemployed and underemployed people
swelling the ranks of the poor and destitutes."
Because of galloping inflation, people's purchasing power,
noted the bishops, has been drastically reduced and even
high-scale salaries were mere allowances. The people of
Nigeria have been left to hope against hope with little if
any energy to even groan or complain, the bishops lamented.

The bishops vowed to continue condemning the ills in the
country as they have done before as long as those problems
continue to plague Nigeria. They asked Nigerian people not to
relent in their prayers to God to continue saving them as
"the crisis hangs over the nation."

Meanwhile Nigerians are holding their breath as they wait
anxiously for the outcome of the decision of the Provisional
Ruling Council (PRC) on the fate of the alleged coup leaders,
who include former head of state retired General Olusegun
Obasanjo.

The Council's decision is expected to be announced by the
head of the ruling junta, General Sani Abacha, during his
independence anniversary broadcast on October 1.

The military regime has been under pressure from both
inside and outside Nigeria to exercise clemency for the 40
alleged coup plotters, with US President Bill Clinton warning
Nigeria with dare consequences if it went ahead and executed
the plotters. But General Abacha's junta responded to
Clinton's threat by accusing Washington of meddling in
Nigeria's internal affairs and of having no respect for the
country's constituted authority.

Among African leaders who have either met with Nigeria's
leader to plead clemency for the alleged plotters or sent
emissaries, include Presidents Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe,
Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and Nelson Mandela of South Africa,
and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, President of the Nairobi-based
All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC).


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
