117 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zambia New Constitution Clause Threatens Media Freedom


LENGTH: 1507 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 15, 1995

LUSAKA - The entrenchment of media freedom in a new
Zambian constitution is under threat following a move by the
government to avoid holding a referendum on the adoption of
the new constitution and Bill of Rights, the Zambian biThe Post report is technically in breach of a decree
weekly The Post reports in its August 22 edition.
issued by President Fredrick Chiluba on July 17 banning
public debate on the draft constitution.

The Post article, written by the paper's Managing Editor
Bright Mwape, quotes un-named source within government and
the ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) as saying
that the government will by-pass a referendum for the
adoption of the new constitution by retaining the 1991 Bill
of Rights.

Under the 1991 constitution, only a new Bill of Rights has
to be subjected to a referendum, whereas other parts of a new
constitution can be adopted by a simple vote in parliament,
The Post claimed. Recommendations for a new Bill of Rights
are contained in a report submitted by the Constitutional
Review Commission (CRC) appointed by Zambian President
Fredrick Chiluba in mid-1993. The CRC report says this
recommended bill of rights was a "radical departure" from the
existing one, passed in 1991. and was based on the premise
that 'an open society based on democracy and freedom was best
secured by a positive entrenchment of fundamental human
rights in the Constitution". 

The 1991 Bill of Rights only recognises the right to
freedom of expression, and does not include specific
provisions guaranteeing freedom of the press.

The Bill of Rights proposed by the CRC would guarantee:
free expression, media freedom, and the freedom of artistic
creativity; that all media be free from censorship; the
independence of all public media; the right of journalists to
protect their sources; that no laws can be passed restricting
media freedom; and free access to official information.

The CRC started its work in early 1994, and after one and
half year of gathering submissions from all over Zambia, made
public its findings and recommendations on June 26. However,
publication of the report - the final draft of which was only
fully endorsed by three of the original 125 commissioners,
with a further three commissioners endorsing it with
reservations - followed a series of leaks and attempts by the
authorities to keep the report secret.

The weekly Sun newspaper published details of the report
in its 14 edition. The Post followed suit, publishing a draft
of the CRS's constitution in its May 16 editions. The Sun
article revealed that the CRC was recommending that only
Zambians born of Zambian parents could stand for president; a
clause which, if adopted, would bar former president Kenneth
Kaunda from running for the presidency. Kaunda, whose parents
were Malawian, looks set to challenge Chiluba for the
presidency in elections scheduled for next year.

When The Sun's report appeared, News Editor Lweendo
Hamusankwa was called in for questioning by the police on
four consecutive days. However, The Sun's lawyer, Darlington
Mwape, told the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) in
Windhoek, Namibia, the police were unable to formulate any
concrete charges against either the newspaper nor Hamusankwa .

On April 23 the government successfully applied for a
court injunction barring The Sun from publishing any further
information relating to the proposed new constitution.
However, the court injunction was suspended on May 3, and
then overturned completely by the High Court the following
month, by which time The Post had published the CRS's report
in full.

On June 26, the government-owned Times of Zambia also
published the CRS's report in full, apparently with the
blessing of the CRC. Then on July 17, President Frederick
Chiluba banned by presidential decree (Section 58 of the
Penal Code) any further public debate on the draft
constitution pending the completion of a cabinet White Paper
on the subject.

MISA representative in Zambia, Fanwell Chembo, says the
presidential decree has so far had little success in stifling
debate on the constitution. According to Chembo, there is
pressure from civic and human rights groups, the lawyers
association, and the media for a new constitution - or any
amendments to the existing constitution - to be adopted by
public referendum, or broad-based constituent assembly.

President Chiluba appears determined to resist putting the
constitution to a referendum. "We cannot be subjected to a
referendum. After all Kaunda abolished all referenda,"
Chiluba told a press conference, The Post of August 22
reports. "We are government and will decide on the method of
adoption (of the constitution)."

Chiluba further said the new constitution would be adopted
by means of a vote in parliament - a parliament in which the
President's ruling MMD has an 80 per cent majority.

Opposing the government's move, Chairperson of Zambia
Civic Education Association, Lucy Sichome, is quoted by The
Post as saying: "The 1991 Bill of Rights is inadequate. The
proposed bill has enhanced people's rights; doing away with
that is defeating the very essence of reviewing a
constitution at such great cost." The publication of the
CRC's report, and the release of the CRC's draft constitution
has been plagued by other controversies. On June 20 The Post
reported that Chiluba had censured the CRC for making the
draft.

Then on June 23, The Post reported that Chiluba had
censured the CRC for making the draft constitution public
"before government could have access to it". In response,
Commission chairman, John Mwanakatwe, explained that the
commission acted under pressure from foreign donors who
demanded that Zambians see the contents of the document
first. The work of the CRC was largely paid for out of donor
funds.

The draft Bill of Rights drawn up by the CRC also includes
protection of the rights of children and women; economic
rights and the creation of a permanent Human Rights
Commission, which also are not in the 1991 constitution.

Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Wildlife Body Applauds Prosecution of Chinese Herbalist


LENGTH: 574 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 15, 1995

LONDON 15 -The East Africa regional office of the
International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN),
has applauded the recent successful prosecution in the UK of
three people for illegal sale of Chinese "medicine"
containing rhinoceros horn, tiger bone and bear bile.
This is "a major step" in curtailing trade in endangered
species under the Convention of International Trade in
Endangered Species of Wildlife and the Flora (CITES), a
spokesperson of the IUCN East Africa office said.

CITES, a treaty signed by a total of 130 countries, among
them the three East African countries - Kenya, Uganda and
Tanzania - bans all international commercial trade in parts
of rhino, tiger, elephant and many other endangered species. 
By becoming signatories the contracting parties--both
consumers and producers--bind themselves to enforcing it.

The rhino and the tiger are particularly endangered as a
result of trade in their body parts which are much prized in
oriental Chinese medicine. However, there is no scientific
evidence for the efficacy of these medicines. On the contrary
they are generally accepted in the West as bogus.

But the Chinese believe passionately in these medicines--
the rhino horn is largely used for male potency treatment
while tiger bone is used mainly on plasters which are applied
directly to an area of the body with rheumatism.

The products are not just going to the UK, but areas of
the world with sizable Chinese migrant populations are also
targeted particularly in the United States, South East Asia
and the ASEAN region.
In two separate cases heard in the UK early this month, two
Chinese herbalists were fined a total US$ 8000 after
admitting charges of selling remedies containing parts of
endangered animals. A number of other oriental doctors have
been successfully prosecuted on similar charges.

Speaking after receiving the news from London, Mercie
Ejigu, IUCNs Eastern Africa Regional Representative said:
"Although IUCN may support the use of natural resources when
such use is sustainable, the swift action by UK authorities
will serve as a lesson to traders of endangered species and
encourage countries with these species to enforce legal
restrictions more effectively."


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


119 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Roben Island To Turn Into Open University


LENGTH: 734 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 15, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - The notorious Robben Island off the coast
of Cape Town is to South Africa what Alcatraz is to America.
Throughout its history as a prison for high profile
prisoners, it has had no record of an escaped prisoner, much
like the legendary prison of Alcatraz off the coast of
California, USA.

But that image is slowly fading away following the release
of many of its occupants, including President Nelson Mandela,
Walter Sisulu, and many others. A South African cabinet
committee has now been set up to look at ways of turning the
island into a profitable possession when it ceases to be run
as a prison at the end of 1996. 

High on the list of bidders for the island are commercial
tour operators, hotel developers and leisure businesses who
are prepared to invest millions of rands to turn the island
into one of the world's premier tourist spots.

But an unlikely proposal has also been received by the
committee: to turn the island into an Open University. The
proposal comes from Lord Michael Young of Dartington,
England.

Dartington proposes that the island could be made into a
distance learning outfit which could be used to broadcast
programmes to the mainland for thousands of South Africans

Press reports here indicate that Lord Michael has such
brilliant credentials that the committee charged with
receiving the proposals is likely to look at his ideas more
than twice. Among his many accolades, he is credited with
setting up Britain's Open University in the 1960s and since
then he has master-minded the setting up of 30 other
institutions.

Now, at the age of 80, he is chairman of the International
Extension College which has 30 Open Universities affiliated
to it, many of which he founded himself. The proposals to
turn the island into an institution of learning will not be
operated in competition to existing Universities. It will
largely send radio and television signals from Robben Island
to local tutorial centres to be built all over the country
where students could receive their tuition.

It is understood that adequate funding could be obtained
from willing funders abroad, after which the government of
South Africa could take the responsibility to fund the
institution.

At the moment, the island is said to have about 200
buildings in good repair, communal structures, an educational
centre, shops and a regular ferry service to the Cape Town
waterfront, all of which could be used by people to be
employed to write the self-study materials.

Lord Michael also believes that the Open University idea
could be part of the Reconstruction and Development Programme
which was set up by the current government of national unity
to correct the development imbalances of the past apartheid
governments.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Liberia Ceasefire Holding


LENGTH: 1560 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 15, 1995

MONROVIA - The Justice and Peace Commission (JPC) of the
Catholic Church in Liberia has castigated the human rights
record of the out-going Liberia National Transitional
Government (LNTG-1) as "most unimpressive and frustrating".

Headed by Prof. David D. Kpormakpor, the LNTG-1 tenure ran
from March 1994 to September 1, 1995 after rival warlords in
the nearly six year- old civil war came together in August to
sign a peace accord. Three of the warlords were seated in
another interim government on September 1, to prepare for
elections next year.

Charles Taylor, leader of the National Patriotic Front of
Liberia (NPFL) that sparked off the civil war when it invaded
from Ivory Coast on December 24,1989; George Boley of the
Liberia Peace Council (LPC) and; Alhaji Kromah, leader of the
Mandingo faction of the United Liberation Movement of Liberia
(ULIMO) were sworn in along with three civilians in a sixbeginning of the process to implement the latest peace
member collective presidency. The ceremony marks the
agreement signed on August 20 in Abuja, Nigeria. 

Although there have been reports of renewed fighting,
violence and looting, the peace accord appears to be holding
and international aid agencies are feeding the hungry again
in the country's interior.
Aid workers pulled out of much of Liberia's interior last
October, saying their equipment was being stolen for use by
the armed factions and that growing chaos made it impossible
for them to work. The French arm of Medecins san Frontiers
(MSF) has now opened a feeding centre for severely
malnourished children at Totota, 130 km (80 miles) northeast
of Monrovia. The aid organisation took in 112 children on the
first day, September 7.

"Every day we're receiving more and more people as news
travels that we have a feeding centre opened," said MSF
France coordinator Fiona Terry. "Most of them are in very bad
condition. We have space for only 300 but was practically
overfilled in the first three days."
The fighters, some of them belonging to the LNTG-1, are also
pleased about the feeding arrangements, especially in central
Liberia. Further north, however, especially nearer the border
with Guinea, many areas are virtually empty, as people have
left to seek food and security elsewhere.

But in a seven-page statement, the JPC accuses the defunct
out-going LNTG-1, which like its predecessor, the Interim
Government of National Unity (IGNU) headed by Prof. Amos
Sawyer is "leaving the scene with a dismal human rights
record and reckless attitude towards the suffering people and
in particular, "the upholding and dispensation of justice
throughout its tenure."

"It has miserably failed, even with all the resources,
cooperation, and opportunities at its disposal, to establish
the basic guarantee for the respect of human rights and the
dispensation of justice", the JPC statement says.

On December 15, 1994, the statement notes, armed gangs
stormed the Cowfield Duport Road area, killing over 50
innocent civilians mainly women and children. Thousands of
others were made homeless.
Following the massacre, the citizens took to the main streets
of Monrovia denouncing the "heinous act". This lead to the
LNTG-1 announcing it would set up a commission of inquiry to
investigate the massacre. But nothing happened, thereby
fortifying the sense of impunity on the part of murderers.

The JPC, headed by Samuel Kofi Woods, a winner of the
Reebok Human Rights Awards for 1994, maintains that an
investigation into the gruesome murder of innocent civilians
could have marked "a significant beginning to curbing the
mountains of violence directed at civilian populations and
thus demonstrating the LNTG-1 expressed commitment to human
rights and to the welfare of the Liberian people."
The Justice and Peace Commission concludes by urging the
Liberian people to cooperate with the incoming Council of
State officials for the realization of its mandate.

Meanwhile "the United States is prepared to assist Liberia
to reconstruct and assume once again its rightful place in
the community of nations if the ceasefire is maintained and
the new Liberia National Transitional Government (LNTG-2)
moves effectively to disarm all the factions," Dane F. Smith,
U.S. Special envoy to Liberia has said.
Mr. Smith was in Monrovia, along with Colonel Macarthur
Deshazer, Africa Director on the US National Security Council
to represent the United States Government at the seating of
the new six-man Council of State of Liberia (CSL).

Said Ambassador Smith: "United States government also
supports the International Foundation for Electoral System
(IFES) which stands ready to provide technical support
already identified by the Election Commission in 1992 and
1993". In a recent disclosure Nyudueh Monorkorman, Election
Commissioner, said that "about thirty political parties and
independent candidates are expected to contest the
forthcoming general elections slated for October next year."

The USA, Liberia's closest ally in the West, provided over
US$ 500 million in aid to late Samuel Doe's regime. But in
1990, following the out break of the civil war, the Bush
Administration said it would not assist Liberia to end the
war because it was an internal conflict. Since then the US
government has continued to assist Liberia with relief aid
estimated at over US$ 50 million.

Liberia was founded in 1821 as a "haven" for freed
American slaves by the American Colonization Society, with
the first American Negroes arriving a year later. The colony
became independent in 1847, but remained very, very close to
America. In fact, until the 80s the American dollar was the
legal tender or currency in the country.

In 1979, after years of political stability, a proposal to
increase the price of rice, the main staple food, produced
widespread violence. A year later, in a violent coup, Master
Sergeant Samuel K Doe, then only 28, lead a group of
discontented soldiers of national or indigenous origin to end
over 100 years of rule by Americo-Liberians.

But opposition to Doe's brutal rule by Liberians of all
shades and persuasion, developed in 1990 into a full-scale
and later confused war, resulting in the murder of Doe and
descent into anarchy and economic misery. Until last month,
over a dozen peace accords have been signed by the various
warring factions but to no avail.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


121 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Archbishop of Canterbury To Visit Egypt and Sudan


LENGTH: 1000 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 15, 1995

LONDON - The Archbishop of Canterbury and spiritual head
of the worldwide Anglican Communion, the Rt. Rev. Dr. George
Carey, will visit Sudan next month to "recognise the
contribution of Archbishop Yugusuk to the life of the
Episcopal Church of Sudan and to the whole Anglican
Communion."

Benjamin Yugusuk, the aging Archbishop of Sudan announced
his retirement last month after chairing, in Nairobi, a
meeting of the Synod of Bishops of the Episcopal Church of
Sudan (Anglican).
Noting that Archbishop Yugusuk has a record of "extraordinary
courage and commitment to his people during repeated attacks
on his home town, and diocesan base, Juba," Dr. Carey's
office said that Yugusuk's retirement provides the
opportunity for the Archbishop of Canterbury to return to
Sudan.

For a considerable time, the Archbishop Yugusuk's home was
a shallow trench, from which he exercised devoted pastoral
care for the thousands of displaced people in the area. He
walked for many miles into the bush, in the face of much
personal danger, to be with them. "He was also responsible
for leading the two wings of the Anglican Church, which had
split in 1985, to reconciliation." 

When he cancelled his visit to Khartoum in 1994, "out of
distress at the disappointment caused to Christians in the
North of Sudan," Dr. Carey expressed hope that he would be
able to reinstate the visit before too long.

Dr. Carey will arrive in Khartoum from Cairo, Egypt where
he will pay a pastoral visit as a guest of the Episcopal
Church and its Bishop, the Rt. Rev Ghais Abdul Malik, from 1The Rt. Rev. John Dennis, Bishop of St. Edmundsbury and
6 October. The Archbishop will be accompanied by Mrs. Carey.
Ipswich, and Dr. Carey's Bishop for Oriental Orthodox
Affairs; the Rev Dr. Richard Marsh, the Archbishop's
Secretary for Ecumenical Affairs and Canon Andrew Deuchar,
Archbishop's Secretary for Anglican Communion Affairs, will
also accompany Dr. Carey to Egypt.

While in Egypt, Dr. Carey will preach at Episcopal
services in both Cairo and Alexandria and visit social
projects of the Episcopal Church in and around Cairo at
Menouf.

Dr. Carey is also expected to pay courtesy calls on senior
members of both the national and local governments, and also
visit the Sheikh of al-Azajr and the Grand Mufti of Cairo
together with other significant Muslim leaders.

"The friendship between the Anglican Communion and the
Coptic Orthodox Church is long-standing," said Dr. Carey's
office, "and so the Archbishop will pay a courtesy call on
Pope Shenouda III and will visit Coptic monasteries in the
Wadi-al-Natroun."

It is also expected that Dr. Carey will visit the
monastery of St. Catherine's on Sinai and meet Patriarch
Pathenioe of Alexandria and All-Africa, together with leaders
of the Coptic Catholic and Coptic Protestant Churches.

During his two-day visit to Sudan, Dr. Carey will meet
Anglican bishops in Khartoum, as well as leaders of other
Churches. He will also address an open-air service. While in
Khartoum, he will also visit Mandela camp on the southern
outskirts of Khartoum, and also pay a courtesy call on the
President of Sudan.

He will further have discussions with other
representatives of the regime at an informal meeting of the
Committee for Inter-Religious Dialogue, and a lunch given by
the Speaker of the National Assembly.

However, "the Archbishop of Canterbury," his office
stressed, "is visiting Sudan at the invitation of the
Archbishop of Sudan, and will be staying in Khartoum at the
Episcopal Church Guest House." In Juba, capital of South
Sudan, Dr. Carey will visit a camp for displaced people. He
will be accompanied for the trip to Sudan, among others, by
the Bishop of Ramsbury, representing the Salisbury Diocese,
with whom Sudan has been linked for over twenty years.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Pope To Make First Visit


LENGTH: 1027 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 15, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - Pope John Paul II, head of the world's
largest Christian denomination, arrives in South Africa on
16th September as part of a three-nation tour of Africa which
will include Cameroon and Kenya.
This will be the pontiff's first visit to South Africa which
attained liberation in April 1994, following years of white
rule.

In September 1988, the Pope visited the southern African
countries of Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Swaziland and
Mozambique. At the time, he skipped South Africa because of
the racial policies of the former apartheid government, but
promised to come once non-racial democracy was attained. 

The Pope will arrive in the country amidst unprecedented
labour unrest involving public health workers who are
demanding pay increases and improvements in their conditions
of service. He also comes at a time when the country's
political in-fighting between the largest black-led political
parties, the African National Congress (ANC) and the Inkatha
Freedom Party (IFP), are at loggerheads over a number of
issues, notably, the writing of the new constitution, the
impasse over international mediation and other issues.

Partly as a result of this impasse, violence continues
unabated, despite the government's deployment of thousands of
army and other security forces in the volatile areas.
Spiraling crime rate, unemployment, the spread of HIV, the
virus that causes the dread Aids, and many other social
problems also form part of a bleak backdrop to the visit of
the most travelled pontiff in the history of the Roman
Catholic church.
In each of the country the Pope will visit, he hopes to
attend national Bishops' meetings. He also will come face to
face with problems common to the African church:
Africanisation of the liturgy; polygamy and what to do with
polygamous men who want to convert to Christianity; celibacy
and; corruption amongst Catholic and other Christian leaders
and ordinary people.

According to Vatican sources, the Pope is expected to make
a vigorous attack on the rampant corruption in Africa and on
corrupt governments. He is also expected to denounce the
West's neglect of Africa.
The pontiff is further expected to name the World Bank and
the International Monetary Fund in a plea to all creditors to
lighten the debt burden which was "suffocating" African
countries.
Citing wars, despair and frightful deprivation as dominant
problems, the Pope's message will reportedly refer to corrupt
African governments as "thieves" and urge Catholics to play a
clearer part in establishing democracy and the rule of law.

Many African nations live under authoritarian and
oppressive regimes which deny their citizens basic human
rights, the text of the Pope's message says.

It decries to the dishonesty of governments which connive
with local and foreign private interests to siphon off
national resources and transfer public monies into private
bank account abroad.
The Pope will tell international bodies they should make use
of legal means to see that the money is returned.
In South Africa the Pope will be briefed about the country's
role in the development of the region and in African in
general, and its possible implications for the church in
Africa. Among the dignitaries the Pope will meet are
President Nelson Mandela, Deputy Presidents Thabo Mbeki and
F.W. de Klerk.

Speaking about his impending visit to Africa's youngest,
but richest nation, the Pope said: "We take particular
pleasure in sharing the joy in the hearts of the people of
South Africa after so many years of suffering and lack of
mutual understanding. May brotherly dialogue rather than the
use of arms resolve all tensions."

The Pope will be delivering an "apostolic exhortation" to
the regional conferences of Bishops, offering instructions
based on the African synod he chaired in Rome early last
year. The synod drew up a "balance-sheet of the church's
strengths and weaknesses."


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Water: The Crucial Investment For The Future


LENGTH: 1587 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 27, 1995
by Joseph K'Amolo

NAIROBI - Better known for its "strangling" economic
policies, the World Bank has this time round warned the
developing world of the dangers of not investing in water,
one of life's most crucial resources. The warning comes just
five years away from the projected water for All by the year
2000.

Every morning before going to school, Milca Nyambok, 11,
treks to an open water reservoir some two kilometres away.
Like other residents of Asembo, young Milca has to fetch
water on a daily basis, a chore that saps energy and takes
time that could be applied to other productive efforts. 

Not unlike many African villages, Asembo in Siaya
District, in Kenya's Nyanza Province, has a chronic water
problem.
The few available water sources are man-made wells, which
collect water only seasonally. The wells are open places and
domestic animals use the water alongside people. When it
rains both human and animal waste find is washed into the
reservoirs.

During dry spells the dams become empty cracking basins.
Residents are then forced to fetch water from Lake Victoria,
more than 10 km away.
This is a time when bicycle and donkey owners make their
little fortune. They fetch water from the lake and sell it at
around Kshs.10 (0.18 US dollar) per 20 litters. This price
might seem negligible, but for an area whose majority live
below the poverty line, it amounts to a large sum.

The situation of Asembo, some 380 km West of Nairobi, can
be multiplied several times over throughout rural and even
urban Africa.
But apart from the "high" price, the water is dirty and
unsafe for human consumption unless treated. However, out of
ignorance and lack of even the simplest of cleaning
facilities, the water is not treated and is the cause of many
water diseases: typhoid, guinea worm, bilharzia and
dysentery. Unclean water can also cause hepatitis, a disease
that causes the inflammation of the liver.

Early this year, for instance, a mysterious diarrhoearal
disease suspected to have been caused by contaminated water
broke out among the people residing along the shores of Lake
Victoria.
The United Nations estimates that dirty water causes about 80
per cent of diseases in developing countries and kills 10
million people each year.

An outbreak of water related diseases is witnessed each
year at least in one African country. A recent case in point
is the cholera outbreak in Cape Verde Islands in Africa's
north west coast.
Against this background the World Bank warned this August,
that much of the world's population faces a future without
adequate water unless more care and proper investments was
made to protect and make this resource available to more
people.

Although a large percentage of the earth's surface is
covered by water, only a tiny fraction of this water can be
directly used by human beings. This is because more than 95
per cent of it, is salty in both oceans and seas.

In the 1980s substantial gains were made in availing clean
water to the world population. Some 330,000 people in
developing countries gained access to safe supply of drinking
water, official statistics of the International Drinking
Water Supply and Sanitation Decade indicate.
During the same period, about 210,000 people a day achieved
improved means of excreta disposal. The rate of
implementation of the water supply and sanitation more than
doubled that achieved in the 1970s.
Nevertheless, for developing countries, achieving clean water
for all remains elusive largely due to poor economic
performance. In addition, because of rapid population growth
averaging about 250,000 people per day, more than one billion
people are still without access to safe water to date. Some
1.7 billion have inadequate sanitation facilities.

The London-based Earthscan, in a book entitled
"Waterlogged Wealth", confirms that while clean water is
often expensive enough in industrialised nations, it has a
prohibitive cost in the developing countries.

Like the Population Action International (PIA), a United
States-based non-governmental organisation, the World Bank
cautions that under such pressures as population growth,
pollution and rising cost of new supplies, providing clean
water poses a growing economic and health challenge,
especially to developing countries. Already some 80 countries
with 40 per cent of the world's population experience water
shortages that threaten agriculture, industry and health.

Water scarcity and not land shortage, says the Bank, will
be the main constraint of agriculture in future in the
developing countries. Agriculture consumes 90 per cent of all
water used in these countries.
For Africa where poverty and rising food demand are pushing
farmers increasingly into marginal lands, observes the Bank,
drought-resistant corn varieties will have to be developed as
an alternative to typical dryland crops such as sorghum,
millet and cassava.

Emphasizing the seriousness of the water problem, the Bank
predicts that contrary to this century's wars which have been
fought over oil, the next century's wars will be over water.
The Bank notes that engineering and environmental costs of
developing new water resources are much higher than those of
resources already tapped.

"For many cities, the cost of water provided by future
projects can be two to three times the cost of current
supplies, even before environmental costs are factored in,"
says the Bank report.

The Bank also warns that the move by many countries to tap
water for agriculture from non-renewable underground
resources is a self- defeating policy which is likely to
accelerate the process of desertification. Fossil water
resources too can be depleted as quickly as crude oil
reserves, adds the World Bank.

Besides rapid population growth especially in urban areas,
the World Bank further notes that, industrial and
agricultural demands for water, and mismanaged land use, have
also affected the supply of good quality water. The Bank
therefore calls for comprehensive and multi- sectoral
planning and design of water supply projects and programmes


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Rwanda When Women Became Killers


LENGTH: 2800 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 1995
by a Special Correspondent

NAIROBI - At a time when women are increasingly condemning
violence against their lot, a new report on the "active
participation" of women in the genocide in Rwanda by the
London- based African Rights was released on the eve of the
Fourth UN Conference in Beijing, China. The report represents
an indictment of the "extraordinary cruelty" of women on
their fellow women.

Liberata went into labour immediately after she had
escaped a major massacre. She had spent only a few hours with
her new born baby son when an elderly neighbour decided that
the boy had already lived too long.
"She asked me about the child with a lot of sympathy in her
voice. She requested that I let her see the baby. When she
saw that it was a baby boy, she picked up a stick and hit the
child. He groaned only once and then he was dead," narrates
Liberata. 

Liberata's baby boy is but only one of the many victims of
an elderly woman accused of killing more than a hundred
babies, mostly boys. The boys it was feared would be the
future soldiers of the ruling RPF (the Rwanda Patriotic
Front).

After the boy's death, the woman unleashed her sons on
Liberata and her family. Two people died in the incident
while Liberata and her daughter were thrown into a pit
latrine from which they escaped.
In a new 163-page report, Not So Innocent the London-based
human rights watchdog, African Rights, examines the active
participation of women in the genocide and killings which
took place in Rwanda in April-July 1994.
A substantial number of women, and even girls, were involved
in the slaughter in countless ways, inflicting extraordinary
cruelty on other women, as well as children and men, charges
the report.

The report was released on August 26 just four days before
the start of the Fourth UN Conference on women (August 30women was high on the agenda of the Beijing Conference. The
September 15) in Beijing, China. Ironically, violence against
Conference unreservedly condemned violence against women with
participants symbolically standing in candle-lit silence for
an hour to mourn violence against women and share stories of
their pain.

Yet in 1994 in Rwanda, the report, Not So Innocent; When
Women Became Killers, charges that thousands of women were
killed by other women. They were often the victims of
educated women, "the very women who had access to political
power and economic means." Many of the dead were some of
Rwanda's most educated and experienced professionals,
essential to the development of the country and important as
role models for future women leaders.

Studies of the impact of conflict on women's lives has
focused on male violence against women, the disruptive
effects on family life and the additional burdens placed on
women. Little has been said about women capacity for
violence.

But the report with proof, charges that women of every
social category took part in the Rwandan killings. Many of
the women whose crimes are detailed in the report went on
their killing sprees in the company of their children.

Just as some boys accompanied their fathers in the
killings, both boys and girls accompanied their mothers who
had turned into killers, Not So Innocent claims.

Many ordinary women, who did not themselves kill took
their daughters along when they went to "clean out" their
neighbours' houses or to strip and rob the corpses left
behind after large-scale massacres.
The most prominent female killers, such as Minister Pauline
Nyiramasuhuko and Councilor Rose Karushara, says Not So
Innocent, had their sons as their drivers and partners in
crimes. Many of these young men were prominent killers in
their own right, but the reputation of their mothers as
fierce killers heightened their standing among the militia.
"Their status provided them easy access to ammunition and
gave them additional opportunities to kill, abduct, loot and
rape."

"The extent to which women took an active role in the
killings is unprecedented anywhere in the world," the report
further claims.
This is not accidental. "The architects of the holocaust
sought to involve as much of the population as possible to create a nation of extremists bound together by the blood
men, women and even children as young as eight. They set out
of genocide. If everyone was involved - directly or
indirectly - there would be no one to point an accusing
finger at."

Not all women participated of course, and neither did all
men. Many women, as well as many men, refused to kill and
took risks to save their friends, colleagues and neighbours.
But thousands of other women sided with the male killers, as
willing participants.

A number of educated women were known as extremists long
before April 1994. For them, the genocide was an opportunity
to contribute to the "final solution." Some others succumbed,
like men, because of fear and pressure, or because of the
deeply-ingrained habit in Rwanda of obeying official orders.

Others were motivated by greed; they believed the promises
of politicians, ideologues, journalists and local government
officials that those who killed would receive material
rewards, such as inheriting the land of Tutsis.

Women contributed to the massacres and killings in a
variety of ways, narrates the report. Some killed with their
own hands. One of the attacks against refugees driven to the
hilltop of Kabuye in Ndora, Butare, was led by a pregnant
former gendarme, Felicitee Semakuba. "Kneeling," says the
report, "she shot at thousands of unarmed people and threw
grenades at them."

Women told killers where people were hiding, screaming out
their names as the terrified quarry ran for their lives. Some
women provided the petrol with which people were burnt alive.
Other women and girls were seen at roadblocks, checking ID
cards, a prelude to the slaughter of thousands of people
"incriminated" by the fact that their IDs said "Tutsi".

Also the crowds that surrounded churches, hospitals and
other places of refuge wielding machetes, nail-studded clubs
and spears included women.
Women particularly excelled as "cheerleaders" of the
genocide, singing and ululating the killers into action. They
entered churches, schools, football stadiums and hospitals to
finish off the wounded, hacking women, children and even men
to death.

Their victims included their neighbours as well as
strangers whom they stripped of all belongings. Some women
have even been accused of killing their own husbands and
children.

Both educated women and peasants identified the people to
be killed, pointing out who was a Tutsi, or an "unreliable"
Hutu on account of their politically moderate views, the
report asserts.
It adds: "Educated women, made lists of people to be killed
which they gave to the soldiers, militia and local government
officials organising the genocide. Many women also refused to
shelter the hunted and kicked people out of their homes."

The few women who occupied positions in the civil
administration were among the very worst killers. Women like
Odette Nyirabagenzi, Rose Karushara and Euphrasie Kamatumu,
councilors in Kigali, are personally responsible for the
death of thousands of people, many of them killed with a
brutality that defies credibility.
"Their homes became headquarters for the militia," the report
charges adding that: "They distributed weapons and ammunition
and took an active part in selecting men and boys who were
taken out of churches to be massacred."

Rose Karushara, a tall strong woman, is said to have
beaten up the refugees before handing them over to the
militia for the final kill. She was frequently at the
roadblocks in her sector, deciding on whether refugees should
be killed or allowed to live. Women in the media also played
a leading role in the massacre.

But perhaps most shocking is the revelation that "some
nuns are remembered in Rwanda" for their involvement in the
1994 genocide. These include two nuns currently being
sheltered in a monastery in Maredret, Belgium. Sister
Gertrude Mukangango, the Mother Superior in the convent at
the Monastery of Sovu in Butare and Sister Julienne Kizito
from the same convent.

The Sisters closed their door to the refugees and drove
out those who had forced their way in, fully aware of the
killings around them. Many of the refugees they drove out,
including immediate family members of Tutsi Sisters at the
convent, were murdered immediately after they left the
convent.

Sister Julienne, Not So Innocent alleges, is reported to
have worked directly with the killers, standing in their
midst while they massacred refugees, handing out jerrycans of
petrol which were used in her presence, to burn people alive,
including a Tutsi employee of her own convent.

She is also accused of distributing belongings of the
refugees to "the criminals with whom she collaborated." "The
two nuns worked closely with all the leading killers in their
commune," the report adds. The Africa Rights report says that
a significant number of female doctors and nurses supported
the killers. They identified their Tutsi colleagues to the
killers, provided them with lists of Tutsi patients and
betrayed their hiding places.

The report further describes the role of other women
professionals: "Women Government ministers, civil servants,
local academics, school teachers, school inspectors,
students, housewives, domestic servants, traders, nuns and
the staff of local NGOs and employees of international
agencies were all involved."

For instance, the report names one of the best known women
killers as Angeline Mukandutiye, a school inspector in
Kigali. She regularly visited the refugees at the churches of
St Famille and St Paul's, choosing which ones would be
killed.

Not So Innocent concludes by stressing the importance of
documenting and exposing women's participation in the
killings, failure of which would reinforce the impunity that
is enjoyed by genocidal criminals.
The report laments that: "Many of the women named in the
report, and countless others whose crimes remain to be
exposed, are living in comfortable exile in Africa and in
Europe. Some have been employed by international
organisations in the camps for refugees in Zaire, Tanzania
and Burundi."

Until a few weeks ago, Angeline Mukandutiye was working
for Medicin Sans Frontier (MSF) Holland in Goma in their
mental health programme. Pauline Nyiramusuhuko is in charge
of social services in a camp in Bukavu run by Caritas
International, and has responsibility for unaccompanied
children.
But under the general label of "innocence" some of these
women return to reclaim their property, at the same time
providing information for their men folk on their
reconnaissance visits. Hence the urgent need to expose
killers among the women who use the "innocence label" as a
front for men and further mischief .


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Pope Brings the African Synod Home


LENGTH: 2374 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 15, 1995
by Sam Gonza

NAIROBI - Pope John Paul's 11th trip to Africa which
starts on Thursday September 14, will arguably be his most
important visit to the African continent where some 95
million Catholics live. The trip has aroused great
expectations because the Pope is due to release the results
of the controversial African Synod that was held in Rome last
year. The Pope's 15-page "exhortations" will chart the course
that the Catholic Church will follow into the 21st Century.
The hope of many faithful in Africa is that the
"exhortations" will permit an authentic expression of African
spirituality.

When the Pope announces the results of the African Synod
in Yaounde, Cameroon; Johannesburg, South Africa and Nairobi,
Kenya during his tour of Africa this September, it will be
the culmination of 18 years of debate and preparation. 

The Synod itself opened in Rome on April 10, 1994 and
involved interaction of more than 300 people comprising
mostly of African Bishops, missionary and religious
superiors. A number of theological observers and a few women
also attended the Synod.
To sort out the materials, documents and issues into a form
acceptable to the "Supreme Magesterium" of the Church has
taken just over a year. Hundreds of African Bishops from
central and eastern Africa will be in Nairobi to welcome the
Pope on 18 and 19 September at the conclusion of yet another
African tour.

That the Pope would travel to Africa was confirmed earlier
this year. The purpose of the visit would be to present the
results of the Synod on the African soil, at least to allay
fears that the holding of so significant an event in Rome
last year amounted to a vote of no confidence in the maturity
of the African Church.
One of the earliest critics of the Rome venue for the Synod
was Father Sesana Kizito, former editor of the New People, a
Catholic monthly published by the Comboni Missionaries in
Nairobi. He lost his job late last year, a clear signal that
"in Rome someone is not able to accept that within the Church
there may be some legitimate different ideas and experiences
on how to incarnate the Gospel in Africa today."
Fr. Kizito observes that the holding of the Synod in Rome is
now "a fact of history - it is already done." He sees the
Pope's current visit to Africa as an expression of a wish to
have some connection with the continent.

Had the Synod taken place in Africa "it would have been a
sign of recognition by the Vatican that the African Church
had grown sufficiently and was able to chart its destiny."
In many countries in Africa, particularly war or violence
torn countries like Sudan, Angola, Mozambique, Liberia,
Sierra Leone and South Africa, the grassroots never really
took part in the process that led to the Synod or the
"Special Assembly" for Africa.
A document from East Africa calls on the Catholic Church not
to be afraid of African culture and traditions. "If the
Church can shed its fears, very real progress is possible in
many areas covered during the Assembly."

There has been some solid progress in the Church since the
pace setting Vatican II Council documents were published
thirty years ago. For example nowadays people take for
granted the use of local languages in Mass. It used to be
exclusively Latin. African musical instruments and rhythmic
singing are now accepted almost everywhere.

In countries like Zambia and a few others one need not
choose a Saint's name for baptism. A candidate can be
baptised any African or other name of his or her choice. This
incorporation of African cultural values into the message of
the Gospel, was one of the key themes of the Synod.
"The path towards inculturation has already been cleared by
the Supreme Megesterium of the Church," says Bishop
Rakotondravahatra of Madagascar. There was really no need for
further campaigns to urge its necessity, he observes. People
should get on with the work, he says.

The establishment of the voluntary Small Christian
Communities (SCCs) comprising of local parishioners at
grassroots level is one area where the Church is chalking up
good progress, thanks to the dedication of AMECEA Bishops to
the concept.

AMECEA is the Association of Member Episcopal Conferences
in Eastern and Central Africa. Headquartered in Nairobi,
AMECEA covers Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Malawi,
Zambia and Sudan.
According to Father Joseph Healey, an American Missionary and
adopted son of an African clan (the Mbogo-buffalo-clan of the
Baganda tribe of Uganda) there are at least 13,000 SCCs in
Eastern and Central Africa.
The SCCs are the result of local initiatives by neighbours in
a parish. They involve participants often from families, who
meet regularly, for prayer, interaction and biblical sharing
in the tradition of the extended African family. Members
address themselves to local and other social issues affecting
their locality or and their families, and their church and
parish.

They may care for each other in times of crises such as
illness. Together with lay preachers they serve as an
important function in evangelisation.

Father Healey has documented cases where members of an SCC
take turns to care for the gravely ill including AIDS
patients. They have also resolved marriage problems among
their members.
Because they cut across the scope of the key themes of the
Synod, like Evangelism, Peace and Justice, AIDS awareness and
nursing, and Family integrity, SCCs will be critical in
furthering the goals of the Synod.
Father Kizito and Healey believe the SCCs have not fulfilled
their potential. "The right direction depends on the
initiative of the local Bishop".

The African Synod in Rome coincided with the genocide in
Rwanda, a country that is largely Catholic. Priests, nuns,
Bishops and millions of otherwise level-headed Christians
have been implicated in this African holocaust. Where was the
Blood of Christ in all this?
Bishop Bernard Budidira of Burundi observes that for
Christianity to take true root, people in Africa have to
learn to "interiorize" the Gospel, to turn it into a living
force in their lives. Bishop Obiefuna of Nigeria asserts that
"the blood of the tribe should not be thicker than the water
of Baptism". On their face value, these are simple and clear
statements, but they confirm that Christianity in Africa
remains superficial.

Asked by the press whether Christianity had failed in
Africa with regard to the genocide in Rwanda, Rev. Jose Belo
Chipenda, General Secretary of the Nairobi-based All Africa
Conference of Churches (AACC) said "Christianity had neither
been tried nor lived."
Chipenda's answer further confirms the superficiality of
Christianity in Africa, where the quest for personal
salvation has tended to be pursued in isolation of the
biblical teaching: "Love God above All Things and your
Neighbour as Yourself."

How did the Synod and how will the Pope address this
problem and save a continent that cries out desperately for
love, peace and justice?
A recurring criticism of the Synod was that far too few
African theologians (Lay theologians) were in attendance in
Rome. One explanation is a perceived distrust between the
Clergy and theologians. The latter often want to see the
Church free itself from uniformity and hierarchism.

But Father Kizito believes that theologians who are over
critical and radical are the exception in Africa. "It is
unreasonable for anybody to be afraid of them; in any case
even those who are critical are faithful to their Church".

Kizito sees African theologians as key players in the post
Synod interpretation of the Pope's exhortations.
In the indigenous Pentecostal Churches, women play pivotal
roles and sometimes initiate such Churches themselves. In
traditional African societies the "penalisation and
marginalisation" of women in major decision making has been a
major hindrance to social progress.
During the last Synod on Religious Life held in Rome in
October last year, Monsignor Kombo of Brazzavile spoke for
women when he said there is need for greater participation by
women at higher levels of decision making within the catholic
Church.

What have the Pope's exhortations have to say about
women's participation in the Church especially that he is
touring Africa after the UN Conference on Women in Beijing,
China?
The Vatican has already given indications that the major
thrust of the Pope's declarations will revolve around the
Family. Certainly, vexed issues like polygamy, healing,
celibacy of the clergy and many more will be relegated to a
file for future consideration and study. Nevertheless the
Pope's exhortations may spring some surprises as the Church
enters the Third Millenum.

Whatever the Pope's message, Father Kizito says it will be
the beginning. "The Pope is likely to give general direction
and guidelines but the actual work of building the Church millions of faithful in Africa."
that will be the work of the bishops, the priests and the
In some countries they are getting on with the task more
vigorously than in others. For example in Uganda and
Zimbabwe, many customary elements of burial ceremonies have
been incorporated in the Catholic funeral rite.

Father Kizito makes the bold statement that in future "all
Sacraments will be celebrated with African symbols".


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large When Old Age Is A Curse


LENGTH: 2014 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995
by Wafula John

NAIROBI - In traditional and much of rural Africa even
today, age was associated with wisdom and respect. But as the
continent gets more concerned with gender issues and street
children, the elderly-poor in the streets of the "mad" urban
areas remain uncared for. Many of today's elderly pavement
dwellers spent most of their productive years either doing
odd jobs or as street urchins themselves, who now have
multiplied more than ten times.

New Stanley is a five star hotel in downtown Nairobi. But
that has not stopped Peter Gakuru 73, from "setting up shop"
on a pavement next to the hotel, a popular spot for tourists. 

Married to blind Milka Wanjiku and with four children to
fend for, Gakuru's sole income for the last five years has
been alms from well-wishers of the streets. Gakuru is part of
the growing number of elderly people who are increasingly
depending on Nairobi's streets to barely survive.

"When I was able-bodied," says haggard Gakuru, I used to
carry loads for a living. Today I can't." But at least Gakuru
has a "home" and family to return to after a day's "labour."
Hapless Mary Wangui Kararie, 62, has lived on Nairobi's
streets since 1991 with occasional stints in a friend's Chuom
in the sprawling Mathare valley. "Chuoms" are makeshift
polythene paper and carton box "homes".

What brought Wangui on the streets? "Hunger," she says
curtly. Her only child and sole bread winner, Jane Wanjiru, a
mother of two, died in a road accident five years ago. Wangui
had only one choice to make: together with her two small
grand children they took to the streets.

The children were later rescued by the Undugu Society, a
philanthropic organization started by Rev. Father Arnold Grol
in 1972. Undugu Society assists disadvantaged children
through, among other programmes, an educational programme
duped "education for life".

Mary Wangui was left to battle it out on her "pavement
home" upon which thousands of feet tread. Nairobi's night
temperatures often plunge as low as six degrees Celsius. In
addition, Wangui has been alternately arrested for being "a
vagabond" and terrorised by "street urchins" and other night
street idlers and thieves.

The number of aging people drifting onto Nairobi's streets
is growing by the day. Paul Kilonzo, 55, "set up a stand" on
a pavement in a middle class residential estate early this
year.

A former hawker, Kilonzo found to his embarrassment that
he could not raise enough money to neither pay rent for a
shack and to feed his family of three sons. He also found it
difficult to resume his hawking business after a two year
stint in jail.

"It broke my heart the first day I took this corner as a
beggar," says Kilonzo. "I wept with bitterness that I had
come so low. To date, I bow down in shame whenever I see a
person who knew me in better days," says Kilonzo.

Why can't he take up any job that comes his way? None
comes his way, laments Kilonzo. Worse still, he has been
sickly since he left jail. He chooses not to disclose why he
went to prison in the first place.

Indes Wambui, about 70, once peddled basketfuls of farm
produce from door to door in residential estates to eke out a
living. Now she solicits for copper and silver coins to live
on at a pavement opposite Parliament Buildings.

For Wambui, it is a one-person but vain crusade, to prompt
reluctant Kenyan legislators to debate the plight of her
likes including today's "street children and petty traders
who are potential elderly pavement beggars and dwellers of
the future."

However, all she has managed in three years on the streets
is to draw the attention of security officers whenever
parliament resumes, when she is scurried off the area.

Obviously gone are the days when blindness, cripplehood
and deafness were the sole driving forces of the aging
towards city streets. Agnes Syombua, 50, was driven to the
streets five years ago by her blindness and abject poverty.
But Mary Njeri, about 80, set up her "begging stand" next to
the luxury Norfolk Hotel last year because nobody cared for
her any more.

"My husband died during the MAU war of liberation, I have
nobody to take care of me. Nobody cares about me," laments
Njeri, a former vegetable vendor. The extended family system
can not help her because many now consider it as
"burdensome".

The multiplying number of elderly "retirees" on Nairobi's
streets reflects the rapid emission of cultural values in the
Kenyan society. "Modernism has deprived our society of
cultural bonds which tied us to the aged and made them useful
senior citizens," says Mr. Otinda Okeng'o, a leading scholar
in population studies.

In reality, Kenyans are sliding into "sheer selfishness
often epitomised in our hysterical embracing of the nuclear
family and other Western values," Mr. Okeng'o says adding
that: In the name of modernisation the extended family system
which catered for the aged, orphans, disabled and refugees is
dying rapidly. "Those who should be repositories of our
culture and provide the link between our past and the future
are today painfully wasting away on our unsafe streets."

With growing individualism coupled with economic
hardships, and the urban drift of young breadwinners in
search of better living conditions, the "comforting extended
family" is down for the count. This leaves the aging in
danger of neglect and even total abandonment.

Writing about a Kenyan ethnic group with regard to a past
communal enterprise, a prominent Kenyan journalist, Philip
Ochieng had this to say: "The go-getting individualism with
which capitalism has imbued them now solidly stands in the
way of any enterprise with any mere whiff of gentle
communalism. Individuals now invest resources only in
ventures which yield returns to them as individuals and in
which they have a measure of control in accounting." Given
this scenario, the future doesn't look any brighter for the
aged.

In 1990 about half a billion people world-wide were more
than 60 years of age. This figure is expected to rise to 1.4
billion by the year 2000. Most of these aging people will be
in the Third World, Averting the Old Age Crisis, a World Bank
study says.

The future is set to be even more bleak for the increasing
number of the aging in Africa . With family planning
advocates, and especially the electronic media, bent on
extolling the virtues of "the two children family",
"grannies" are set to be distanced even further. Worse still,
the effects of the Structural Adjustment Programmes have
tended to impoverish the average African making him
concentrate more on the survival of his or her immediate
family.

Even more distressing, ironical as it may sound, is the
fact that Africa's heavy investment in population control and
child survival programmes for the last three decades is now
bearing fruit. In Kenya for example, according to the current
National Development Plan, the country's fertility rate
declined from 15 per cent to 6.7 per cent between 1979 and
1987 and stood at 5.4 per cent in 1991.

These figures put Kenya's population in a new development
stage where there is an accelerated aging of the people. By
the year 2005 there will be more Kenyans above the age of 40
than there will be below. This means that there will be more
"older people" than the young as opposed to today's trend
where the young are more.

As the drift of Kenya's aging towards urban pavements
gathers speed, there is urgent need for the current "able"
generation to plan seriously and provide security to these
senior citizens. It won't be long before they too "age", get
neglected or are unceremoniously abandoned.

This flow towards the streets is a mere tip of the iceberg
of the present socio-cultural and political situation on the
African continent. It is a testimony that there are many more
miserable Kenyans, aged or not, tacked somewhere in rural and
suburban hideouts without the courage, energy or
"opportunity" to go on the streets.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Zimbabwe Apostolic Churches Agree to Reform


LENGTH: 1560 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995
by Dingaan Mpondah

NAIROBI - In much of Africa today, the Church remains the
most effective grassroots organisation that is capable of
swaying its followers -- rural or urban, educated or
illiterate -- one way or the other, for good or for worse.
And so when churches or sects that exploited or confused the
"gullible masses" agree to reform, the occasion calls for
some concessions just as the Zimbabwean authorities appear
set to do with regard to the country's Apostolic Churches.

Zimbabwe's independence in 1980 coincided, or indeed
inspired, a new boom. Numerous followers from some of the
country's established churches began to breakaway in
increasing numbers to form their own churches or sects. 

In a television interview in May 1987, the then Minister
of Home Affairs, Enos Nkala, attacked the newly- formed
"dubious" churches which he said were exploiting the
"gullible masses" in the country. The most callous aspect of
some of these and other churches or sects is that they
refused to have anything to do with vaccination of their offIn one incident during a seven-day immunisation campaign
springs.
against the six killer diseases -- measles, whooping cough,
diphtheria, polio, tuberculosis and tetanus -- scores of
members of the Johanne Masowe Apostolic Church in Ngezi town
simply went into hiding.

It is not known how children that were deliberately denied
immunisation in those years have fared since. Today, however,
their counterparts born after July 1995, and their parents
have a reason to smile. But that is if their churches are
part of the Council of the Apostolic Churches in Zimbabwe
(CACZ).

The Council which groups together 23 different sects have
reached an understanding with the Government to abide by all
requirements and regulations including sending children for
treatment or vaccination. The Government has in turn promised
to speed up the process of having the sects registered just
like other churches.

The CACZ used the occasion to castigate faith healers who
demanded money for their services. There is in Zimbabwe
today, a proliferation of faith healers, almost all of them
with roots in Apostolic Churches. A spokesman of the Council
referred to healers as "mercenary healers" who, he said, did
not belong to their member churches.

Formed in 1994, the Council has since appealed to the
Ministry of Education and Culture, now Ministry of Sports,
Recreation and Culture, to have their member groups
registered alongside other churches. Unregistered churches
are prohibited from soliciting for donations and so are
unable to engage in charitable activities.

Other than the Apostolic Holiness Pentecostal Church and a
few others, most Apostolic groups in Zimbabwe have no proper
church buildings or sites. Their prayer meetings are
conducted in open spaces.

But this does not go down well with the requirements of
public health authorities. The groups are, therefore, also
asking national housing and public construction officials to
assist them get land on which to build their churches.

The Government is said to be ready to help the CACZ as
long as the members observe the country's laws and other
requirements. Registration can only be assured if the sects
desisted from undesirable practices such as barring children
from attending school and attending preventive or curative
clinics, a ministry spokesman said.

At a meeting held in Chitungwiza, about 30 kilometres
south of Harare, on July 20, Sebastian Chihera, vicesecretary for the Ministry of Sports, Recreation and Culture
chairman of the CACZ, assured Mark Nkiwane, acting deputy
that the churches would co-operate with the Government as far
as possible in matters affecting them.

"Times are changing and we all see the need to change with
them. We will do our best to make sure that we operate within
the country's laws. Education and treatment in hospitals are
things we should not deprive our children. Elders can be left
to decide for themselves but children should be treated when
it is necessary," said Mr. Chihera. Mr. Nkiwane said the
Government would attend to the churches requests.

Apostolic churches and many other sects have many times
been at crossroads with the Government for one reason or
another. One of the most notorious of these churches was led
by a mysterious tall black man - "Va Jesu" ("The Christ"),
who in the mid and late 1980s, claimed to be the
reincarnation of Jesus Christ.

Another equally notorious sect was called Wapusa Wapusa
(Wake Up in Shona). Both sects were set up in 1986 and were
confined to the countryside, mainly in the central and northVa Jesu was a very wealthy man who owned six large farming
west regions.
estates and a chain of business enterprises including
supermarkets and flourishing grinding mills. He was always
accompanied by twelve young "apostles" - six male and six
female - and had thousands of fanatic followers who seemed to
be under a hypnotic spell.

The man died about four years ago. Nothing much has been
heard about his church lately. His sect is also presumed
dead. Most of Va Jesu's farms were forfeited to the State as
no one could give an account as to how he had acquired that
vast wealth.

Wapusa Wapusa, on the other hand was more obscure and
secretive. It conducted its "services" in places wellabout" the faith was that all its services were nocturnal and
concealed from the public. What was "totally unacceptable
word ran around that before anybody was allowed to attend,
they had to undress completely.

When Minister Nkala told newsmen in the television
interview that he had instructed the police to investigate
"questionable churches" Wapusa Wapusa went underground. It is
speculated that Wapusa Wapusa could still be alive although
nothing much is heard about the sect.

"Some of the churches have unscrupulous leaders who
instruct their followers to do what is in direct opposition
to Christian teachings. They find employment in lying about
God, and cause divorces by their very teachings. Law
enforcement agents will have to come in because these
churches are illegal," said Nkala.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


128 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Book Theme: Dream And Act Big, Honour Your Creator


LENGTH: 1507 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995
by George Mwangi

NAIROBI - Leadership crisis is listed as one of the many
debilitating crises afflicting the African continent, where
the governed and their governments do not usually move handbook simply titled "Leadership" the author offers some
in-hand in the promotion of the common good. In a 524-page
practical guidelines towards developing and exercising
leadership abilities that could prove particularly useful to
the continent's, political, business, community and church
leaders. Though published in 1989, some six years ago, the
book remains a relevant companion to those who wish to lead
effectively and honour their Creator in the process.

The book "Leadership" is primarily a practical guide for
leadership and effective management in a Christian context. 
It seeks to challenge people who are "willing to dream and
help them to fulfill those dreams."

In the book the words of the author, he wants to "help you
to develop and to exercise your leadership abilities so that
you not only dream big, but you think big, plan big, and act
big, and in doing all this, you honour Jesus Christ in the
whole process."

The author, Anthony D'Souza, is a native of Bombay, India.
He is eminently qualified by his training, professional
experience and his total commitment to Christ to be a leader
anywhere in the world.

His lectures on Leadership and Management Skills at the
famous Haggai Institute, have become a part of the vital
ongoing training programme at the Institute. Anthony D'Souza
is a Catholic priest of the Order of the Society of Jesus
(S.J.).

He is a former Director of the Indian Social Institute,
New Delhi, and Rector of St. Xavier's College in Bombay. He
has also been chaplain of the Association of Christian
Executives (ACE) in India and Director of the Xavier
Institute of Management and professor of Organisational
Behaviour.

The book is a three-in-one volume. But the author has
creatively structured the text to ensure a lively, steady and
easy reading. For a serious reader, the book is also easy to
comprehend.

The author uses a variety of techniques which include
active discussions, verse, personal experiences and
observations, and illustrations in form of cartoons and
diagrams to liven up the text. He also ensures the reader
participates throughout the text by brainstorming him or her
(the reader) with interesting thought- provoking questions.
After each major topic there is a self-evaluating or a selfIn Volume I, the book provides materials on being a
assessing exercise.
leader. This volume is offered to enhance greater selfIn this part of the book, the author discusses issues such
confidence and the leader's own ability or potential.
as the key functions and skills of leadership; impact of
contrasting leadership styles, improving interpersonal
relations; communicating and getting feedback.

Volume II which is on leading others, offers practical
basic methods for a leader to lead better. In this volume the
author discusses team dynamics, interaction and building;
developing surbodinates through coaching, counseling and
motivation, and on mastering the dynamics of planned change.

In the third volume the reader is introduced to the role
of a leader as an individual, and how leadership skills can
be developed. This section gives guidelines on how to manage
time, set goals and look ahead leading others effectively.
Fr. Anthony D'Souza S.J. also deals with work-related stress
and "burnout" in this section. He concludes with the concept
of delegation and on developing a winning attitude.

Fr. D'Souza S.J. addresses rather succinctly issues such
as training skills, planning, time management, conflict
resolving, team building and dynamics, delegation and
motivation from a Third World perspective.

For instance, while in Africa the critical phrase "this is
African time" is only laughed at, in the book, Leadership,
the importance of time management is rightly perceived as a
prerequisite for any meaningful achievement to take place.
Time wasting is not only costly but also a sin. The author
explains the "Parieto" time principle and shows the leader
how to prioritise tasks or work, to achieve better time
management.

On motivation, the author explains the application of
Maslow's Needs Hierarchy and the Fredrick Herzberg Two-Factor
theory. This section aims to teach a leader to appreciate
when and how to give a "pat on the back".

In a concluding note Fr. D'Souza S.J. outlines the
qualities of effective leadership as: Tolerance, optimism,
integrity, sincerity, knowledge and understanding,
decisiveness, concern for others, openness, communication,
good example, patience and courage.

It is the hope of the author that leaders and potential or
future leaders will be able to master the art of leadership
after reading this book. Such leaders would then "be at ease
to exercise leadership with transparency, accountability,
productivity and predictability." It draws a parallel with
another book by John Adair, Effective Leadership - a modern
guide to developing leadership.

The book is published and distributed by St. Paul
Publications - Africa, an arm of the Daughters of St. Paul,
an international religious congregation which has
distribution centres in East Africa, Nigeria, Mozambique,
Zambia and Italy. A grant given to the publisher has
subsidised the cover price by more than half. In Kenya, the
book now sells for Kshs.250 (US$ 5) from Kshs.650.

Leadership is a valuable guide for every organisational
chairman or director, corporation manager or officer- inpastoral leader, particularly in Third World countries
charge, school or college principal, religious superior or
because it "meets their need at the point of their need."

The book which is available in paperback is not authored
by the priest in charge of Holy Family Basilica in Nairobi,
Kenya also known as Fr. Anthony D'Souza S.J.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


129 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Chikane Deplores Continuing Racism


LENGTH: 1094 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995

GENEVA - The spirit of racism is still "well and alive" in
South Africa, Rev. Frank Chikane, former General Secretary of
the South African Council of Churches (SACC) has said, adding
that the second phase of the struggle in his country had just
begun. He described this as the phase when those who were
excluded by apartheid can be included in reconstructing and
restructuring the country.

In his address to the 150-member Central Committee of the
WCC, Rev. Chikane was emphatic that racism in South Africa
did not end with the installation of the African National
Congress (ANC) government of President Nelson Mandela. The
last WCC Central Committee meeting was held in Johannesburg,
South Africa in January 1994, when Chikane was still SACC
General Secretary. 

"Racism in South Africa has not ended but is suppressed by
the democratic process that is in place. The political power
(of racism) is gone but the economic power is still in the
places where it was before," Chikane said.

He reminded Central Committee members that the church in
South Africa was the first to globalise the evils of, and the
struggle against apartheid culminating in the current
democratic process in the country. He challenged Committee
members that concerted efforts with even more vigor were
needed to fight racism now.

"Apartheid was an obvious monster, racism is not, racism
is still alive in South Africa, racism is still alive in the
church," he added. The former SACC General Secretary likened
the programme that freed South Africa from the yoke of
apartheid as a time that "God chose to speak to us about
racism throughout the world."

The Rev. Frank Chikane's provoking address to the 46th WCC
Central Committee meeting here (September 14-22) was inspired
by the WCC framework document on racism drafted by the
organisation's Unit III, Justice, Peace and Creation.

"I want to be treated like a human being so that I do not
fight stupid wars everywhere I am," Chikane told a plenary
assembly here in reference to the number of times he has been
subjected to thorough searches at European airports "simply
because I am black."

The WCC framework document summarises the ecumenical
history and the current challenges in the struggle to
eradicate racism. The document examines WCC's understanding
of racism, root causes, subsequent effects, and its (racism)
relationship to global trend in three phases: pre-1968, 1968Throughout the document, key questions are raised to
1980 and 1990 to the present.
stimulate reflection and further discussion. The paper also
examines some of the current dilemmas in relation to focusing
WCC actions against racism and suggests that it is time to
embark on a fourth phase. It singles out issues to be
addressed as, overt as opposed to covert manifestations, the
relationship between various "issues" and new consciousness
of white racism and the role played by "elite" groups in the
South.

On overt versus covert racism, the document notes that
much of WCC's work in the struggle against racism
concentrated on campaigns against apartheid. South Africa
epitomized white power and privilege over marginalised
oppressed blacks (Africans, Indians and so called coloureds).
The paper goes on to say that, apartheid was easy to
understand; its overt manifestations of invited an ecumenical
response.

Today, however, notes the draft document, there are still
cases of overt racism. There are also more subtle covert
expressions of racism. Covert racism is not so easy to
understand, explain or counteract because its manifestations
are less obvious and can be easily denied.

The South African clergy pointed out that goodwill alone
would not change the situation particularly in South Africa.
On the economic empowerment of the majority, he noted, "about
70 per cent of the people in South Africa do not qualify to
get a loan from the bank, they are a bad risk." But despite
these odds, the people in South Africa are determined to root
out racism. However, the question "still remains, can we do
it?"

"As long as Africa remains where it is and there is no
dramatic change, I will be treated like this endlessly. For
change to happen in a dramatic way, we need more concerted
efforts," he concluded.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
