130 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Church Pressure A Factor As World Bank Relents On Debts


LENGTH: 827 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995

LONDON - The World Bank will cancel the debt owed to it by
a small group of countries mainly in sub-Sahara Africa, Dr.
Jeffry Lamb, senior executive of the World largest lending
institution here has said. Lamb did not reveal the countries
in question, but said the move would help them overcome
persistent economic crises.

Asked why the World Bank was taking this step at this time
after years of rejecting pleas by developing nations that
their debt repayments were impoverishing their nations, Dr.
Lamb conceded that the Bank had now accepted critics' views
that the debt burden had become a cause of economic
unsustainability for the small group of countries which are
being offered relief. But as a condition for the relief, he
said, the World Bank/International Monetary Fund (IMF), would
continually monitor performance of the beneficiary countries
to ensure that they stick to the institutions' prescriptions. 

Dr. Lamb emphasised that there would be no blanket relief
on debt owed to the Bank by the majority of Third World
nations saying "such a move would endanger the World Bank's
viability." Lambs statement comes only three weeks before the
annual meeting of the World Bank/IMF to be held in
Washington, USA, in the second week of October.

It also comes amidst growing pressure from churches, both
in Africa, and Europe and America, for reforms in the lending
policies of the World Bank/IMF. The churches want lending
policies that have "a human face", free of some of the
austerity measures that have burdened the poorest of the poor
in the debtor nations.

Already according to the Washington Correspondent of the
Daily Nation in Nairobi, 30 religious groups in the United
States have responded to a call issued by the All Africa
Conference of Churches (AACC) in Nairobi and have formed a
coalition to press for the changes at the top in the
IMF/World Bank.

The ecumenical coalition, the Religious Working Group on
the World Bank/IMF includes Methodist, Unitarian, Mennonite,
Baptist, Episcopal, United Church of Christ, Christian Church
(Disciples of Christ), Catholic and secular organisations,
institutions and individuals.

In addition to sponsoring a public rally in Washington on
October 9, the Religious Working Group will organise forums
wherein they will present alternatives to IMF designed
austerity programmes prescribed for scores of Third World
countries. "The key objective of these activities is to force
the issue of large scale African debt relief onto the agenda
of the World Bank/IMF," reports Kevin Kelly from Washington.

Dr. Lamb's announcement follows an earlier decision by the
World Bank to make available US dollars 200 million as loans
for small scale enterprises in Africa, Asia, and Latin
America.

According to the officer in charge of the new
Microfinances Division at the World Bank, Ms. Malhotra,
thousands of small scale enterprises will benefit from the
scheme which will lend as little as US dollars 50, but whose
lending level will be between US dollars 100 to 150.

"The idea is to help small scale enterprises get access to
working capital. Ordinary micro-enterprises would have to
resort to the money lenders in the village who charge
extortionate interest rates," Malhotra said.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


131 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Pope's Visit Threatens Rift Among Muslim Faithfuls


LENGTH: 800 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995

NAIROBI - The Pope's visit to Kenya has created division
among the Kenyan Muslim community with a section of the
Islamic faithful lambasting their colleagues for opposing the
Pontiff's visit.

The division began when Sheik Ali Shee and other Muslim
leaders who had been invited by the coordinator of Pope's
visit, Father Stephen Okello of the Kenya Catholic
Secretariat, turned down the invitation and returned the VIP
Card to Fr. Okello, claiming the agenda of the visit was a
provocation. 

Interestingly, Sheikh Ali contended his change of mind was
necessitated by the stand of other Muslims even though he had
earlier accepted to attend as official spokesman of the
Muslim community. He said he avoided the ceremony so as not
to cause division among the Muslims. Sheikh Ali is the Imam
of Jamia Mosque in Nairobi.

What infuriated the Muslims, according to Ali Shee, was a
declaration by the Catholic Church to evangelise the whole of
Africa by the year 2000, something the Muslims interpreted as
a declaration of war against Islam and therefore a
declaration of a Cold War between the two faiths. Also cited
by the opponents of the Pope's visit was the 15 century
persecution of Muslims in Spain by the Catholics.

However, other Muslims opposed Sheik Ali's stand. Among
those who rebuked him is Kenya's Assistant Minister for
Information and Broadcasting, Shariff Nassir, who said Islam
was for unity and not division, adding that the Quran
directed all Muslims to respect other religions.

Also reported to have criticised Sheikh Ali Shee, is Chief
Sheikh Nassor Nahdy of Mombasa who quipped that Sheik Ali
Shee, had no right to speak for the Muslim community. Sheik
Nadhy took a swipe at Sheik Shee's criticism of the Catholic
head's visit saying the Pope had a right to visit Kenya and
any other part of Africa and, therefore, his visit was not a
provocation to the Muslim faith as claimed by his Nairobi
counterpart.

Another Muslim leader from a Kibera Mosque in Nairobi also
told-off Sheik Ali Shee and other Nairobi Muslim leaders for
condemning and boycotting the Pope's visit. Reacting to Sheik
Ali's contention, Fr. Okello told the press that what the
Muslims had cited were trivial matters which did not matter
today. He said the catholic Church under the current Pontiff
had made tremendous concessions to all religions, including
Islam and was today very accommodative.

When challenged as to whether Muslims did not have the
same agenda to propagate their faith, Sheik Ali Shee
conceded, but added that theirs was through persuasion and
not declaration as that would mean using force to Islamise
the continent. "Because of the declaration, we Muslims cannot
sit together with the Catholics because there is no good
intention from the Pope," explained Sheik Shee.

Ironically in a rare show of solidarity, the Catholic
Church led by the Archbishop of Nairobi, Cardinal Maurice
Otunga, and the Muslims, led by Sheik Ali Shee, came together
last month in condemning what the two camps felt was not
Godly. The two burnt condoms and books on sex at Uhuru Park,
the venue of the Pope's open Mass during his visit.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


132 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Theologian Proposes Oral Theology For Africa


LENGTH: 1200 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995

NAIROBI - Africa will not be marginalised in the field of
"Christian theology and Christian religious scholarship
generally," a Ghanaian theologian, Rev. Kwame Bediako, has
said adding that the church in Africa should fully embrace
oral Christian theology, "a spontaneous, implicit or
grassroots theology which comes from where the faith lives,
in the life-situation of the community faith."

"I do not see much of a problem on this concept for much
of the theological activity in Christian Africa is being done
as oral theology (in contrast to written theology) from the
living experience of Christians," stressed Rev. Dr. Bediako.

Rev. Bediako noted that following the end of the Cold War
there has been much allusion to the marginalisation of
Africa. Africa it has been argued will hold a less strategic
place in a world no longer dominated by the ideological
rivalries between East and West, between capitalism and
communism, he stated. 

"However," said Rev. Bediako, "it could be argued that one
particular area where Africa will not be marginalised, is in
the field of Christian theology and Christian religious
scholarship generally."

The Ghanaian theologian, who was delivering a public
lecture here contended that "African Christianity cannot wait
for a written theology to keep pace with it." Academic
theology can only come afterwards to examine our Christianity
retrospectively in order to understand it, he said.

Discussing the theme A Gospel Worth Proclaiming in Our
Time: An African Initiative in Christian Theology. in a
lecture organised by the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference
of Churches (AACC), Dr. Bediako referred to oral theology as
the "theology in the open, from the pulpit, in the market
place, in the home as people pray or read and discuss the
scriptures."

Quoting Lamin Sanneh, another scholar in African
Christianity, Bediako stressed that "God was not disdainful
of Africans as to be incommunicable in their languages"
(Sanneh, 1993:166).

God not only imbued African cultures with eternal
significance and endowed African languages with a "valid
carriage for the divine revelation", but also provided preas anyone who knows the origins of African Christian names
Christian Africa with the idiom for Christian apprehension,
for God will understand.

"In contrast for example, to what had happened in the
earlier evangelisation of Europe," he said, "in Africa, the
God whose name had been hallowed in indigenous languages in
the pre- Christian tradition was found to be the God of the
Bible, in a way that neither Zeus, nor Jupiter, nor Odin
could be."

Oral theology, Dr. Bediako argued does not deal with an
oral phase, a transition stage, on the way to the academic or
written theology, which then becomes the real theology.

In addition, contrary to how theology has developed "as
essentially an academic discipline, an intellectual pursuit,
necessarily literary, and near philosophical endeavour that
requires specialist technical knowledge and skills, oral
theology is not found in non-literate societies only."

"We ought to speak positively, of oral, spontaneous,
implicit or grassroots theology, as theology which comes from
where the faith lives, in the life-situation of the community
of faith," said Dr. Bediako, the current director of AkrofiTheology in Akropong-Akuapem, Ghana, said.
Christaller Memorial Centre for Mission Research and Applied

He added: There is no way academic or written theology can
replace this spontaneous or grassroots theology; the two are
complimentary aspects of one reality. The "spontaneous" is
the foundation of the "academic". Without this vital contact
with the spontaneous, grassroots theology, Dr. Bediako
further argued, academic theology anywhere can become
detached from the community of faith and so be not much more
than an exclusive conversation carried on among the guild of
scholars, and incapable of communicating life in Jesus Christ
to others.

Introducing the speaker to the audience, the head of the
Research and Development Unit of the AACC, Professor Jessie
Mugambi, praised Dr. Bediako for his commitment towards
"Africanising or rather localising the Christian theology to
respond effectively to the pastoral needs of the African
people".

Answering a question from the floor, Dr. Mugambi said the
Church in Africa is today "demanding" that she must have its
own theological stand-point in all matters affecting the
Christian life of its followers. According to Prof. Mugambi
Dr. Bediako's lecture is one of the many, the AACC intends to
organise to open up an arena for theologians to come together
to share and listen to theological issues, affecting the
Church in its efforts to serve the faithful.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


133 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Liberia An Epidemic Of Diarrhoea And Warfare


LENGTH: 1120 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995

MONROVIA - An outbreak of diarrhoea in Tubmanburg, Bomi
County some 20 km west of Monrovia, Liberia's capital, left
20 persons dead and fifteen others admitted at a government
hospital in the second week of September.

Aid workers in Tubmanburg City said that most of the
victims were women, children and the elderly whose deaths
were attributed to the acute shortage of food and medicine
for the past few months. In the last three months, over
50,000 Bomi county residents who sought refuge in Tubmanburg
have been without food and essential drugs to be able to
combat any epidemic outbreak.

"Since the last relief distribution several months ago,
relief agencies have been slow in providing emergency relief
food to the civilian population who only depend on relief aid
for their survival," one of the survivals told APS in
Tubmanburg City. 

Dr. George Boakai, working at the city's hospital,
confirmed the epidemic outbreak. He said that the hospital
recorded about 500 cases of diarrhoea in the first two weeks
of the outbreak, adding that most of the victims died enroute
to the hospital, a situation he described as commonplace in
the area.

"The fragile security situation in the county is hampering
the free movement of civilians who are capable of finding
their own food," says Dr. Boakai. They are beaten, raped, and
killed in the towns and villages while in search of food, he
said .

Tubmanburg is about 20 km away from where the UN Observer
Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) and ECOMOG, the West African
peace-keeping force, reported the first cease-fire violations
following the sitting of the interim six-man Council of State
of Liberia (CSC) on September 1.

The violation was between the two factions of the United
Liberation Movement of Liberia (ULIMO), ULIMO-J and K. ULIMOThe ceasefire to silence the guns in this five year old
J controls Tubmanburg with a population of 50,000 people.
blood bath came into effect on August 22, but the two ULIMO
groups led respectively by Gen. Alhaji Kromanh (now a member
of the ruling Council of State) and Gen. Roosevelt Johnson
clashed again. Both sides accused the other of starting the
fighting in the Lofa Bridge and Bopolu areas, about 30 km
from Monrovia. Both are diamond mining towns. When it was
first reported in a local daily, the UNOMIL and ECOMOG
reacted sharply stating that there was no fighting, only to
admit later that there was indeed fighting in the two areas.

Meanwhile the ECOMOG peace-monitoring group announced here
that the disarmament of warring factions in the country's
civil conflict "kicked-off" just over a week after the
sitting of the interim collective presidency.

Ceasefire and disarmament committees have been set up with
representatives of the factions included, ECOMOG's field
commander, Gen. John Mark Inienger told the head of the new
transitional government, Professor Wilton Sankawulo when the
latter called on him at the forces headquarters on Bushrod
Island. Gen. Nienger praised the heads of the various
factions for their commitment and preparedness to adhere to
the terms of the Abuja accord.

In a press release ECOMOG reiterated Gen. Inienger's
earlier statement that ECOMOG was in Liberia to rescue the
people from their predicament and tribulations, adding: "We
have been doing the job wholeheartedly because of the
commitment we have to do it."

Prof. Sankawulo, commended ECOMOG for the sacrifice it has
made so far in Liberia in the quest for lasting peace. He
also expressed optimism, that with the cooperation and
protection of ECOMOG, the disarmament will commence as
scheduled.

He also expressed renewed hope that with the presence of
all key players in the civil conflict in the new government,
he had no doubt that "this is the beginning of the
restoration of the peace that the people of Liberia have
yearned for."

In a related development, the UNOMIL has had its mandate
extended to January 31, 1996. UNOMIL's previous strength of
300 personnel, presently reduced to 70, will be restored in a
bid to assist ECOMOG with the disarmament exercise of some
60,000 combatants in October.

A UNOMIL release said the UN is to shortly set up a
pledging conference for Liberia to raise needed resources for
ECOMOG and other needs critical to the advancement of the on
going peace process.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

134 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Sierra Leone Peace Overtures Sent To Charles Taylor


LENGTH: 747 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995

FREETOWN - Sierra Leone's President Valentine Strasser
will send a high powered delegation to Monrovia, to confer
with the Vice-Chairman of Liberia's six-man Council of State
and head of the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL),
Charles Taylor, to assist in bringing an end to the on-going
civil war in Sierra Leone.

A local daily in Monrovia on Tuesday, September 12,
confirmed that Freetown has already informed its envoy who is
the Doyen of the Diplomatic Corps in Liberia, Ambassador
Wilfred Kanu, to send feelers to Taylor and to make
arrangements for a meeting.

Although there has been no confirmation from Ambassador
Kanu, the Editor in Chief of the Concord Times newspaper in
Freetown, Tony Hermart, was quoted as saying that the
delegation will arrive in Monrovia as soon as word from
Ambassador Kanu was received. 

Sierra Leone's rebels of the Revolutionary United Front
(RUF) have shunned all peace meetings with Strasser. OAU, UN
and Commonwealth officials have either failed to convince or
reach rebel leader Corporal Foday Sankoh to bring him to the
negotiating table, Hermart said.

Sankoh, began his rebellion in the extreme south-east of
the country in March 1991, and according to official figures,
his rebels, have caused the death of over 15,000 people and
forced nearly 40 per cent of the country's 4.5 million people
to flee their homes.

The RUF is believed to have the full backing of NPFL, and
rebels of either groups are said to have fought along side
each other in return for full support when either party wins
control of their respective neighbouring countries.

Sankoh originally wanted to overthrow former President
General Joseph Momoh who now lives in exile in neighbouring
Guinea. The present ruling military junta headed by Captain
Valentine Strasser, 29, came to power in April 1992 and
immediately promised to end the civil war by negotiations or
outright victory.

Meanwhile twenty six cases of HIV/AIDS virus have been
reported in Monrovia since the beginning of the year through
July, bringing to 69 the total number of AIDS cases in
Liberia since 1986, the INFO-AIDS Bulletin, circulated by
Liberia's National AIDS and STD Control Programme has said.

The report comes in the wake of a study conducted earlier
this year, in which it was established that a greater
proportion of students in the Monrovia area were sexually
active. An improved percentage of awareness of the disease in
Liberia, one of the least affected countries in Africa, was
also reported.

The percentage of sexually active youth under 17 in the
city and its environs was put at 83.7 per cent. Chaos,
frustration and redundancy caused by war have been blamed for
the increase in sexual activity. The increased percentage of
those that actually believe that AIDS exists in Liberia was
placed at 78.6 per cent.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Church Body Welcomes Vatican's Commitment to Ecumenism


LENGTH: 2014 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995

GENEVA - Ahead of the official visit by Pope John Paul II
to Africa, the World Council of Churches (WCC) has welcomed
the Pontiff's recent encyclical letter on "Commitment to
Ecumenism" (Ut Unum Sint) and highlighted its importance in
the search for visible unity.

Addressing the 46th WCC Central Committee meeting here
(September 14-22), Dr. Konrad Raiser, the WCC General
Secretary, also accentuated his first official visit to the
Vatican on April 6, 1995 which included intensive
conversations with the Pontiff's Council for Promoting
Christian Unity as well as encounters with "secretariats"
whom the WCC desires to cooperate more with.

Dr. Raiser told the 150-member Committee that in its
active commitment to the search for visible unity the Vatican
acknowledges the WCC. However, the WCC's "comprehensive task
to further the cooperation of the churches in their
missionary and educational efforts, witness to justice, peace
and reconciliation, and in furthering ecumenical renewal"
meets with only limited response.

The basic "asymmetry" between the Roman Catholic Church
and the World Council of Churches "two Christian world bodies
of very different nature, has to be acknowledged and
respected," noted the General Secretary, as he outlined WCC's
commitment to strengthening relationships with member
churches and the wider ecumenical constituency. 

On the flow of communication between member churches and
the WCC, the General Secretary noted that "often the WCC has
been criticised for not communicating effectively with the
member churches."

However valid this claim may be, said Raiser, one must
admit that communication is a two-way affair and without a
sense of mutuality on the part of the member churches,
efforts by the WCC to improve its performance will only have
a limited effect.

Referring to the work of the Council's Office for Church
and Ecumenical Relations, the General Secretary nevertheless
commended new contacts that have been/are being developed
with evangelical, pentecostal and "independent" churches in
Christian communities especially in Latin America and Africa.

Another important aspect of strengthening relations
between WCC and member churches is through personal visits.
In this respect, Raiser particularly mentioned his personal
visits to WCC member churches since he took office in January
1993.

He pointed out that he had travelled repeatedly to all the
ecumenical regions, except the Pacific, and visited member
churches, councils and regional organisations in altogether
38 countries.

Alongside his own efforts, the WCC General Secretary
appreciated the fact that more and more member churches are
adopting the practice of regular visits by church leaders and
ecumenical executives to Geneva for intensive encounters with
the staff here.

Turning to programmes of the WCC, the General Secretary
noted that efforts towards fuller integration of the units
and inter-unit cooperation have continued and are bearing
fruit.

Raiser also reported that the deterioration of the
financial situation of the WCC had given rise to new
questions and concerns, among them whether the Council's
programmes and the structures designed to facilitate the
mandate are sustainable in the long run.

"If budget reductions become inevitable, how do we arrive
at the necessary decisions?" posed the WCC General Secretary.
The financial status of the WCC came particularly to light
following the conclusion of a review initiated in 1992.

Dr. Raiser noted that while recommendations of the review
process suggest only limited structural adjustments for the
time being, "further adjustments may be called for under the
pressure of limited resources." He suggested that "not all
programmes need to be served by full- time staff persons
based in Geneva."

Addressing himself to the search for "Common Understanding
and Vision", Dr. Raiser pointed out that while the WCC is
still the most comprehensive global ecumenical instrument,
the ecumenical movement has in fact become a polycentric
network and the WCC "cannot and should not pretend to be its
main centre."

The WCC General Secretary based his reflections on
convictions that changes which are currently taking place on
the global level in the life of the churches and in the
ecumenical and religious situation challenge all partners in
the ecumenical movement.

Raiser further observed that although many of the
Christian World Communions have played a decisive role in the
ecumenical movement over the last 25 years through the
process of bilateral doctrinal dialogue, these are, however,
not related originally with institutional framework of the
WCC despite the large overlap of membership.

In view of shrinking resources, can the "oneness" or
"wholeness" of the ecumenical movement still be preserved
against the tendencies of fragmentation and competitiveness?
Dr. Raiser asked.

Appreciating the various understandings regarding the
goals, methods and main actors of the ecumenical movement,
Dr. Raiser underscored the oneness of the movement which he
stressed was rooted in "Jesus Christ as the only centre and
nourished by living trust in the presence of the Holy
Spirit." differences of understanding among the partners in a
mutually committed dialogue aiming at clearer discernment and
faithfulness to the common calling.

The common understanding of the WCC should therefore not
only reflect its task of nurturing and deepening the
ecclesial relationships between its member churches, but also
articulate its calling to safeguard and further "the oneness"
or "wholeness" of the ecumenical movement, added Raiser.

Central Committee members responding to Dr. Raiser's
report commended the General Secretary for highlighting
issues that are of fundamental concern for the identity of
the World Council of Churches as a "council of Churches".

Rev. Dr. David J. Mandeng of the Presbyterian Church of
Cameroon, commenting on the WCC future direction vis a vis
its relationship with the member churches and other
ecumenical organisations, and on the question of financial
resources, noted: "Some may think he is asking for too much
but I would say he is not asking enough."

He said that after nearly 50 years, of talking about the
ecumenical movement, it is obvious that a lot of things have
changed and the WCC should acknowledge these changes. Rev.
Mandeng was reacting to the challenges raised by Dr. Raiser
regarding the future of WCC.

Mrs. Sri Winarti Soedjatmoko of East Java Christian
Church, Indonesia, described Dr. Raiser's report as
enlightening and noted that questions raised on the future
direction of the ecumenical movement could not be ignored by
churches in Asia which are currently faced with challenges
from other religions.

The World Council of Churches is a fellowship of churches,
now 324, in more than 100 countries throughout the world
representing all Christian traditions. The Roman Catholic
Church is not a member of Council of Churches but works
cooperatively with the WCC.

The Council's highest governing body is the Assembly which
meets approximately every seven years. Since its first
assembly in Amsterdam in 1948, when it was formed, the
Council's chief legislative body has met in Evanston, near
Chicago (1954), New Delhi (1961), Uppsala (1968), Nairobi
(1975), Vancouver (1983) and Canberra (1991). The eighth
Assembly, which will feature prominently at the current
Central Committee, is scheduled for Harare, Zimbabwe, in 1998
when WCC will also celebrate its 50th anniversary.

The basis of the WCC, with which member churches express
agreement, is a fellowship of churches which confess to the
Lord Jesus Christ as God and Saviour according to the
Scriptures and therefore seek to fulfill together their
common calling to the glory of the one God, Father, Son and
Holy Spirit. The present WCC General Secretary, Dr. Konrad
Raiser is from the Evangelical Church in Germany.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

136 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-At-Large Pope Pleas With African Leaders For End To Arms Trade


LENGTH: 2027 words


 
All Africa Press Service
September 20, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - Pope John Paul II has called on the
international community to stop selling arms to African
countries and has urged African governments to move away from
huge expenditures on weapons.

Addressing 300,000 people who came to hear him on his
first Mass on South African soil, in Johannesburg, on Sunday,
September 17, Pope John Paul said that the international arms
trade is affecting Africa and needs serious attention. "I ask
governments to put the emphasis on education, health and the
well-being of their people," he said.

The South African media gave a generally enthusiastic
welcome to the Pope's visit to the country following the long
struggle to democracy that culminated in the first ever
multi-racial elections, and subsequently government, in April
1994.

In an editorial, one of KwaZulu-Natal's leading papers,
the Daily News, said that the pontiff's visit represented
"one of the final symbolic acts in welcoming South Africa
back into the global community." The paper urged all South
Africans "regardless of their religions, to heed the Pope's
plea and strive for lasting peace and prosperity." 

At an ecumenical meeting at the Cathedral of Christ the
King in Johannesburg, the Pope repeated his plea to the
international community and to African governments. The
pontiff also officially promulgated the proposals made at the
close of last year's Africa Synod held in Rome. He said that
the proposals represented a pastoral plan of action for the
Church in Africa. "At the synod, the bishops testified to the
resilient faith and steadfast commitment of their
communities."

He added: "Often their pastoral experience obliged them to
speak of the particularly worrying situations in which most
Africans live, the widespread deterioration in the standard
of living, the insufficiency of means for educating the
young, the elementary health and social services with the
resulting persistence of endemic diseases, the spread of the
terrible scourge of Aids, the often unbearable burden of
international debt, the horror of fratricidal wars fomented
by unscrupulous arms trafficking, and the shameful and
pitiable spectacle of refugees and displaced persons."

The Pope said the Synod's moral judgment on this situation
was both compassionate and severe. The dehumanisation and
oppression affecting people presented the ecclesiastical
community with both a crisis and a challenge, he asserted.

"It is true," said the Pontiff, "that Africa has a long,
sad history of exploitation at the hands of others," adding
that: "Today the situation continues in new forms -- unjust
trading conditions, the dumping of harmful wastes, and the
overly demanding conditions imposed by Structural Adjustment
Programmes."

The Pope observed that not only the Church, but many
international bodies including the United Nations Summit for
Social Development held in Copenhagen this year, have called
for aid programmes and economic policies to promote real
social progress and development through efforts to eradicate
poverty, stimulate employment and help all sectors of society
to take a more active part in the public debate.

He said that when the Synod called on the Church to become
more actively involved in the struggle for the defence of
personal dignity, for justice and social peace, the African
bishops were giving voice to the unbreakable link between
evangelisation and human advancement.

In Kenya where he arrived on Monday, September 18, the
Pontiff made an impassioned plea to religious and political
leaders to reverse Africa's reputation as a haven of civil
wars, hunger and poverty.

Said he: "Africa is at a crossroads. It's people and their
leaders are being called upon to exercise all the wisdom in
the difficult and urgent task of promoting development which
is not just economic and material but involves building a
civilisation of respect for all of society's members."

Speaking at the country's Jomo Kenyatta International
Airport upon his arrival, the Pope stressed "I come as one
who is deeply concerned for the destiny of Africa's peoples."

"The Church and states (Governments) had a duty to improve
the welfare of Africans," he said, adding that: "The Church
was working for a civilisation founded on African traditions
emphasising the rights of people over material things."

He said that such civilisation should be founded on
understanding, harmony, accommodation not divisive
tendencies, social unity and solidarity. But such
civilisation, he said, was more difficult to achieve when
ethnic, social or political divisions were allowed to
overshadow unity.

Pope John Paul II stressed, however, that Africans were
yearning for a civilisation that encompasses their rights and
freedoms as well as the spiritual nature of every person.

The Pope was in Africa on a six day tour that began in
Cameroon on Thursday September 14. The trip, the 11th to the
continent, was arguably the Pope's most important visit to
Africa where some 95 million Catholics live.

The purpose of the trip that took the Pontiff to Cameroon,
South Africa and Kenya was to "celebrate and announce" the
results of the controversial African Synod that was held in
Rome last year. The Pope's "exhortations" or results of the
Synod, will chart the course that the Catholic Church will
follow into the 21st Century.

While in Cameroon, the Pope publicly issued for the first
time a document, The Church in Africa, which set out the
results of the 1994 African Synod, itself the culmination of
18 years of debate and preparation. He said the Synod
"rightly considered that an authentic democracy which
respects pluralism is one of the principal routes along which
the Church travels with the people."

He assured African nations that the Roman Catholic Church
would not give up urging international solidarity for the
underprivileged continent. But the Pope also denounced "many
African nations" for authoritarian and repressive rule which
denied citizens personal freedom and fundamental human
rights.

He declared bluntly that "Africa's economic problems are
compounded by the dishonesty of corrupt government leaders
who...divert national resources for their own profit and
transfer public funds to private accounts in foreign banks."
This, he said, was "plain theft."

The high point of the Pope's visit in all the three
countries were the open air Masses which in Nairobi, Kenya
was attended by an estimated crowd of between 500,000celebrated with Cardinals and Bishops from the Western,
1,000,000 people. The climax of the Masses, the Pontiff corespectively, was the issuing and handing over to African
Southern, and Eastern and Central African sub-regions
clergy the results of the African Synod.

In his sermon during the Mass in Nairobi, the Pope made a
vibrant defence of the family. The Pontiff later switched
from English to French to refer to the small central African
nations of Rwanda and Burundi, where he warned that terrible
ethnic conflict is still latent after having engulfed so many
innocent victims.

He urged forgiveness and reconciliation between the two
countries' Hutus and Tutsis. "This is the only way to
dissipate the threat of ethnocentrism which looms over
Africa," he said.

Throughout the trip, Pope John Paul emphasised that: "As
the universal pastor for the Catholic Church, I wish to come
to Africa at this time in order to urge my brothers and
sisters in the faith to stand steadfast in the gospel of
Jesus Christ and to assume with unfailing generosity the
challenge which the Synod proposes -- a new evangelisation
with the fresh spirit of service to the people of this
continent."

An interesting aspect of the Pope's 11th trip to Africa,
is that he traveled on national carriers in apparent
solidarity with the continent. Having arrived in Yaounde,
Cameroon on 14th September, on Alitalia from Italy, the Pope
flew to South Africa on Cameroon Airlines. From South Africa
he flew aboard South African Airways to Nairobi, from where
he traveled on Kenya Airways back to Rome on Wednesday,
September 20th at 11;00 a.m.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Brigadier? Just call me Zelda .


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 15, 1995
by Rehana Rossouw

JOHANNESBURG - THERE'S a new way of describing women who
challenge male domination at Safety and Security headquarters
in Pretoria: the women are told they are "doing a Zelda".

The Zelda being referred to is Zelda Holtzman, a
thirtysomething from Cape Town who in June became the
highest-ranking black woman in South African police history.

She was appointed to the South African Police Service
Change Management Team (CMT) at a rank equivalent to
brigadier, but since change in the force now includes the
demilitarisation of ranks, her post is rated as director.
"But I insist that I'm just Zelda and get everybody, from
generals to constables, to address me by my first name," she
said this week. "The police culture in the past held dearly
to rank and authority and by getting them to use my first
name, I am trying to change those attitudes." 

Holtzman believes her prickly task of transforming the
SAPS will be made easier with her belief in leading by
example. So she is particularly careful to ensure her
performance not only inspires other women and blacks to reach
for senior positions in the force, but also encourages
democratic procedures.

She shrugs off criticism that she is under-skilled and
under-trained for her position. Her appointment was met with
some protests from senior police personnel who had undergone
police training and risen through the ranks but had not
succeeded in their applications for her position.

Holtzman's only previous experience in policing was a
stint with the Community Peace Foundation, an NGO engaged in
community work in the field of popular justice and which did
some training of police officers in community policing.

As a member of a network of police officers, she was drawn
into the Minister of Safety and Security's advisory team last
year before she applied for her present post. "I was very
two-minded about applying for the job; at 3pm on the day
applications closed, my CV was still not ready," Holtzman
said. "What inspired me was the fact that women across colour
lines, even those competing against me for the job, rallied
around me and convinced me that strong women were needed in
the department.

"I haven't had much difficulty in getting people to accept
my authority, because I believe so strongly in leading by
example. I have found that black police personnel who have
been subjected to the ideology of domination for so long have
been cheering me the loudest. Now people across colour lines
are beginning to identify with my vision."

Holtzman's cause is a difficult one. The CMT comprises 40
technical teams facing the challenge of amalgamating 11
police agencies into one professional, community-oriented
agency which provides quality service.

The CMT advises the management board of the SAPS on
transformation at police stations, police training colleges,
ethos, distribution of resources, relations with communities,
public order policing, the formation of specialised police
units and the general enhancement of police care.

"Our work is understood and supported by divisional heads,
which is very important at this juncture. But we still find
misconceptions among the broader membership of the force,"
Holtzman said. "This is largely due to our poor
communications and marketing strategies and should improve
once initiatives like a police TV channel get off the ground.
On the other hand, there is a lot of valid criticism about
the process, the same faced by other government departments.
We would like to see it being as transparent, accountable and
democratic as possible, but we are also pressed for time and
the need to deliver results."

Holtzman does not remove herself from the firing line of
criticism, saying much of the work of the CMT was "learning
by doing". As a former anti-apartheid activist who had been
on the receiving end of the worst of police abuse, she has
thrown herself heart and soul into developing new policemen
and women for a new South Africa.

"You can't carry a victim mentality forever. It was
incumbent upon activists like myself to take our struggle to
its logical conclusion, to transform this country entirely,"
she said.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa McNally Sues M&G Over Hit Squad Reports


LENGTH: 507 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 15, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - The Attorney General of KwaZulu-Natal, Tim
McNally, is suing the Mail & Guardian for R250 000 over
reports published last month detailing criticism of his
handling of investigations into hit squad activities.

McNally, charging that the reports "cut at the very heart
of his reputation and dignity", has demanded publication of a
"complete, unconditional and unequivocal retraction and
apology" in this edition of the newspaper.

The M&G has instructed its lawyers to oppose the action,
raising as part of its defence the United States Supreme
Court judgment in the case of the New York Times v Sullivan

The judgment, delivered in 1964, established that a public
official cannot sue for libel in regard to the exercise of
his official duties unless it can be proven that allegations
were published without an honest belief that they were true,
or with reckless disregard as to whether they were true or
not. 

The argument underlying the case was that the threat of
libel action deters free speech and dampens public debate on
policy issues. The principle has been adopted in varying
degrees by, among others, the European Court of Human Rights,
the Indian Supreme Court, the Australian High Court and the
Law Lords in the UK.

In 1988 the US Supreme Court reaffirmed the decision in
the New York Times v. Sullivan with another landmark
judgement which overturned an award of damages against the
pornographer, Larry C. Flynt, for publishing a parody
depicting the Rev. Jerry Falwell having sex with his mother
in an outhouse.

The Chief Justice, William H. Rehnquist, in a unanimous
judgment by the eight- member court, said: "The freedom to
speak one's mind is not only an aspect of individual liberty
- and thus a good unto itself - but also is essential to the
common quest for truth and the vitality of society as a
whole."


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


139 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Crops 'Poisoned' by SADF Herbicides


LENGTH: 1160 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 15, 1995

JOHANNESBURG - The troubled Limpopo River area is in
trouble again -- this time from the effects of herbicides
used by contractors employed by the SADF, writes Stephanie
Dippenaar

ILLEGAL and dangerous herbicides -- used by South African
Defence Force contractors to control 70km of sisal fence
along the Zimbabwe border -- have contaminated farmers' crops
and natural vegetation along the Limpopo River, a Northern
Province inquiry heard this week.

The Agricultural Research Board told a commission of
inquiry, appointed by provincial MEC of Agriculture Dr Tienie
Burgers, that it had found traces of unregistered herbicides
in and around the sisal fence.

"Their research has clearly shown that two products,
Brumisal and Ethidimuron, are present not only in the sisal
fence, but also in the seepage areas, the river bed and the
agricultural crop areas," said the commission's Dr Gerhard
Verdoorn. He also confirmed that the two herbicides were not
registered as required by law. 

The fence was erected in the early 1980s to keep
"undesirable elements" from neighbouring countries from
entering South Africa. Ironically, the area's farmers whom
the "impenetrable" sisal fence was supposed to protect, have
for years claimed that they suffered great crop losses
because of the use of herbicides on the fence.

The fence was the responsibility of the former SADF and
they employed contractors to maintain it from 1982 to around
the end of 1992. For the first three years herbicides with
the active ingredients of Ethidimuron and Brumisal were used.

Among the evidence is a letter dated July 6 1984, in which
the manufacturer strongly advised the contractor against
using these herbicides. The manager of the chemical section
of the manufacturer warned in the letter that the continued
use of the herbicide could be dangerous, "even to the sisal".

The prescriptions on the label of the particular herbicide
also specifically warn that it should not be used in the
vicinity of water, agricultural crops and rivers --
instructions which were clearly contravened. A list of plant
species is mentioned which should not come into contact with
the herbicide. Various of these are indigenous species in the
area.

From about 1986 a herbicide with the active ingredient
Thebuthiron was allegedly used by the contractors. This
herbicide is registered for use on the sisal, but it appears
this, like the herbicides used earlier, was sprayed at a much
greater frequency than the manufacturer recommended.

Ecologist Professor Ben van der Waal said: "If you use the
substances every year at full strength, as it is alleged
happened, for 10 consecutive years, then you'll get an
accumulation of the poison," he said.

Irrigation farmers next to the fence have claimed that
their crops declined dramatically since the application of
the herbicides started in 1982. They complained that yield
dropped up to 90 tons a hectare in the worst years. However,
for many years these complaints were put down to the result
of the bad drought in the area, increased salinity and even
general bad farming practices.

But it is not only the border farmers who are concerned
about the use of the herbicides. Ecologists are up in arms
about the presence of herbicide poison in the sisal fence
where it runs through the Matshakatini Nature Reserve, which
has become all the more important in the context of talks
about the establishment of a trans-national game reserve. The
Matshakatini reserve would form an important link between the
Kruger National Park and the parks of Mozambique, Zimbabwe
and Botswana in the east and north.

Visiting the Limpopo area one can clearly see that the
vegetation on the southern side of the river is in a poorer
condition than on the northern side. This is not the case
further east where the sisal fence is further removed from
the river. But the Department of Agriculture claims infrared
photos taken of the area show no difference -- and say that
even if there is a difference, it is not necessarily linked
to the herbicides.

Van der Waal said the fence in itself had already damaged
the environment in that it disturbed animal migration
patterns. He said if the fence was removed it could leave a
scar of more than 70km in the nature reserve which could take
a long time to recover fully because of the presence of the
poisons.

"It can take anything from 50 to a 100 years to recover. A
long stretch in the middle of a national, possibly
international, park where trees are still dying is totally
unacceptable."


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


140 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Consultants reflect Parliament's problems


LENGTH: 934 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 15, 1995
by Richard Calland

JOHANNESBURG - The consortium of management consultants
hired by Parliament to investigate restructuring, at a cost
of almost half a million rand, is racked by internal
tensions, accusations against one partner of previous
failures to deliver and the defection of a respected team
member.

The South African firm of Kenneth Mgqamqo & Associates
joined forces with the international giant Deloitte and
Touche to win the tender put out by the presiding officers
(Speaker of the National Assembly Frene Ginwala and President
of the Senate Kobie Coetsee) at a price of R430 000 plus
direct disbursements.

In the lead-up to the presentation of an interim report
last week, "significant differences of approach" emerged
between the partners. A source close to Kenneth Mgqamqo and
Associates revealed that it was unhappy with the rigidity of
Deloitte and Touche's approach. 

"They are trying to impose their set methodology on the
problem as if Parliament was just another corporate job. But
it is not. It is unique and needs a more flexible approach."

An informant close to the Speaker's office told the Whip
that Ginwala was "not entirely happy with the way things were
going" and conceded that the process "was a bit of a mess.
They are trying to apply rigid systems on a flexible
situation. Parliament is not a business -- it is more like a
university".

It is in this context that a number of senior
parliamentary staff members expressed concern at the news
that self-employed management consultant Tony Harper, the
third element of the consortium, had left the project team.
According to sources close to the Speaker's office, Harper
resigned because "he felt his principles were being
compromised".

The source said that Harper was "prepared to be flexible,
he had built up good personal relations and had won the trust
of most people. Moreover, he is committed to genuinely
transforming Parliament". Harper himself would make no
comment.

Another informant described relations between Kenneth
Mgqamqo and Associates and Deloitte and Touche as reflecting
the "cultural geography of the parliamentary system".

'The South African representatives of Deloitte and Touche
are white, male Afrikaners. The people of colour on the team
are all from Kenneth Mgqamqo. Thus, tensions on the ground
are reflected in the consulting team."

Questions are being raised over Mgqamqo's capacity to
deliver. In 1994, he was employed by the Western Cape
Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) as a district
electoral officer, but was dismissed on the eve of the
historic April election after a bitter dispute between him
and Western Cape IEC deputy director Kuleleka Lubelwana.

Mgqamqo was responsible for a team of 10 people with
jurisdiction over the critical Mitchell's Plain area of Cape
Town, which included Khayelitsha township. Lubelwana, who is
now employed as Director of SCATT (the Social Change
Assistance Trust), told the Whip Mgqamqo was dismissed at the
end of Tuesday April 26 1994 -- the special voting day for
the elderly, infirm and disabled -- because of his alleged
failure to deliver.

Later in 1994, Mgqamqo was contracted by Lingelethi City
Council -- which also covers Khayelitsha -- to do some
organisational restructuring at a contract price of R300 000.
Again, there was a failure to deliver. A senior source at
Lingelethi City Council said they were "dissatisfied with the
product. They seemed like they could do the work, but the
problems they were hired to solve are still there".


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

141 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


Africa-at-Large Will The Next Pope Be Black?


LENGTH: 3240 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 15, 1995
by Paul Wilkes

JOHANNESBURG - JOHN PAUL II, who survived an assassination
attempt 13 years ago, the removal of a tumour the size of an
orange two years ago and who suffered two bad falls within a
year, still has his faith intact. But no longer can his iron
will command a weakening body to do its bidding.

To talk of John Paul's last days is to begin to consider
the next pontiff -- who, one day, will succeed the most
travelled and most widely known pope in history. When the
next conclave is called and the cardinals are summoned to
Vatican City, there to meet each day in the Sistine Chapel
until a decision is reached, who will have their vote? One
who will continue the legacy of John Paul? Or will they turn
away from his often sternly didactic view of humankind's
halting efforts and enlist a less rigid pastor to guide them?

It will not be an easy choice. Never, in recent history,
has the Catholic Church been so strong and so divided. Among
the papabili, the cardinals who will choose the 265th pope,
as among Catholics throughout the world, there are
essentially two passions at work. 

One is still confident of its power under an enormously
popular pope, who has transformed the Vatican into a
doctrinal clearing house, rewarding the faithful while meting
out punishment to the wayward. The other sees a pope who has
listened to the roar of the crowds but not to the cries and
whispers of individuals who do not share his vision. It is
these two visions that will one day clash in the Sistine.

In the year 607, the Church issued a proclamation
forbidding papal electors, under pain of excommunication, any
discussion of a successor during a reigning pope's lifetime.
But such an edict never did, and never will, stop like-minded
cardinals from seeing one another to talk about the current
state of the church and, by clerical osmosis, to form the
alliances they will take into the conclave.

John Paul seems hardly troubled by such manoeuvring. A
pronouncement last year -- banning divorced Catholics, who
have remarried without obtaining an annulment, from receiving
holy communion -- proves the Vatican's moral sonar is still
functioning. And the wide-ranging proclamation that looked
ahead to the third millennium illustrated the pope's steely
determination that he and his invincible reign will go on for
years.

"He's amazing. The strength ..." says Pio Cardinal Laghi,
prefect of the Congregation for Catholic Education, one of
the offices of the Roman Curia, the body that helps the pope
govern the church.

This congregation has performed masterfully for John Paul,
conducting periodic "apostolic visitations" to seminaries
worldwide to assure purity of doctrine and depth of
allegiance. They have set limits on theological dissent that
some church members have found chillingly repressive. Many
Catholics working in the Vatican and in the church's
administrative diaspora throughout Rome feel that the Second
Vatican Council produced an atmosphere more sympathetic to
the difficulties of living out an imitation of Christ in the
modern world.

Under John Paul, they say, they have seen dedicated people
demoralised, careers ruined and lives shattered. While loyal
to their pope, they are extraordinarily resentful. A
generation of moral moles seems to be in every office,
classroom and espresso bar in Rome, listening for lapses from
the one, true faith. John Paul will leave a powerful
religious empire, but one riddled with distrust.

"Is this a way to run a Church, to live a moral life, when
you have to be careful of everything you say, every friend
you have, everyone you are seen with?" one senior member of
his religious order asked. "We should be in this together;
instead we look at each other as the enemy."

A long-term curia priest noted that under Pope Paul VI he
actually had fun on the job. Now, he said: "It's an attitude
of servile obsequiousness. Daily, I feel nibbled to death."

Interpretations of how John Paul came to forge his
distinct and controversial papacy abound in Rome. One of the
most compelling is from a priest who is in the top
administration of his monastic order and has worked closely
with the pope.

"Know the man and his background and these 16 years are
perfectly in line," he began. "In Poland, you were for
communism or against it. In Poland, to turn out a crowd was
to show you had power. So, there you are: his theology --
black and white, absolute -- and his fixation with the
crowds.

"I would add one other quality of his make-up -- his
penchant for suffering. Poland in the 19th and 20th centuries
suffered as no country suffered. He sees his life as a
continuation of that suffering. He does not avoid it; he
takes it on. Heroic? Yes. But is this what the church needs,
all this suffering? John Paul is a man of his time, but the
next pope must be a man of our time. The Cold War is over."

The next conclave will be entirely different to the one
that elected John Paul in 1978. Of the 166 cardinals, 120 are
now under the age of 80 and therefore eligible to vote. The
number of Italian electors has declined, while the number of
Eastern Europeans, Asians, Africans, South Americans and
North Americans has increased.

Nowhere in the world is Catholicism flourishing as it is
in Africa, where tens of thousands have been converted during
John Paul's reign. The surge of religious vocations often
outstrips the capacity to house and train those who seek to
be priests, brothers and nuns. After Eastern Europe's quick
transformation from legions of righteous freedom fighters to
packs of pleasure-seeking hedonists, it is to Africa and the
rest of the Third World that the pope increasingly looks for
the future growth of Catholicism and an antidote to the
Western world's moral degradation.

So it is that the name of an otherwise obscure 62-year-old
Nigerian, Francis Cardinal Arinze, has been frequently
mentioned as a possible successor. After warning that he did
not want to touch on anything "political" -- his euphemism
for talk of papal succession -- Cardinal Arinze talked of the
reasons for Catholicism's stunning evangelisation in post"Much of African belief is animism, and animism is very,
colonial Africa.
very close to Catholicism, so there is natural attraction, an
affinity," he told me. "In animism, there is one God, spirits
good and evil, worship of ancestors, rituals. I was born an
animist.

"But we must be very careful indeed in this work. My job
is to make sure that other religious groups know our plans,
our techniques for evangelisation" -- he was referring
obliquely here to Islam, with which Catholicism is competing
in Africa -- "and that we are aware of theirs so that we --
how do you say? -- are not stepping on their toes. Yes, we
feel the Catholic message is for the whole world, but we must
propose, not impose. The church in each land must be seen as
a tree growing out of its own soil."

Cardinal Arinze looked out the window as if for guidance
and added: "We have been fortunate to have a holy father who
has helped the world to have a clear picture of what
Catholicism is. People may not do what he says, but at least
they have heard the word.

"We do not need uniformity, but unity." Cardinal Arinze is
given to outbursts of head-thrown-back laughter. These came
forth with his next thought: "And the pope is not a man to
make a discount, so that people will buy!"
South Africa
Frene takes flack for the crisis
(tx
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 15, 1995
by Christelle Terreblanche and Richard Calland

JOHANNESBURG - Our continuing series of extracts from
Parliamentary Whip, the publication of Idasa's Parliamentary
Information and Monitoring Service (Pims), the most
comprehensive Parliament-watching team

THE African National Congress last week rejected reports
that Parliament was in crisis while, off the record, MPs and
chairpersons of committees continued to relate frustrations
over hiccups they have experienced this session.

The most intense frustrations of committee chairs are
directed towards the Speaker, Frene Ginwala, but they also
point fingers at whips and the executive.

The ANC has acknowledged that the process of getting
legislation to Parliament has been too slow, but there is
disagreement on the causes. Said one committee chairperson:
"The vision of the ANC was to create an institution that is
transparent, responsive and efficient. That implies a welland, more importantly, push through the transformation
functioning committee system that can oversee the departments
processes."

Yet some committee chairs are so upset about what they
call the "bypassing of consultation" that they have alerted
other ANC structures like the National Working Committee and
National Executive Committee (NEC) about their concerns. They
say the ruling party will have to make certain political
decisions and step in.

In a range of interviews, everyone was eager to pass the
buck. MPs accuse whips, whips blame the executive, the
executive raises questions about the legislature and chairs
of committees point fingers at the Speaker.

Chairpersons say important decisions and allocation of
funds have, in some cases, been delayed for almost a year.
They said that instead of making them part of her team,
Ginwala "made enemies out of us".

Some chairpersons feel that the two to three million rand
allocated for the committees is far too little. They say most
of them have no secretarial, research or other support, and
that 16 portfolio committees share only 10 committee clerks.

Those committees which have non-government organisation
support staff are unable to renew their contracts because a
new rule stipulates that the Speaker must first approve this.
They also allege that funds are not released for them to
travel to poverty-stricken, distant areas and that,
consequently, it is often only lobby groups representing
affluent sections of the community that are heard.

A number of MPs, mostly from minority parties, jump to the
Speaker's defence. They welcome her commitment to affirmative
action towards women and her determination to give minority
parties a voice. MPs also applaud Ginwala's efforts to make
Parliament a more people-friendly and accessible environment.

The fiercest criticism against her, however, is that many
of the current problems were pointed out to her months ago
and her response to proposals and criticism has been
"negative" and "autocratic". A few went so far as to say that
the Speaker is assuming more power than is appropriate for
the position and that she seems to be threatened by the
committees' expanding power.

Whips were astounded by criticisms levelled against them.
They generally feel that the problem lies with departments
and that Cabinet should take ultimate responsibility for
getting the legislation through in time.

The team of management consultants hired by Parliament to
help it solve its organisational and management problems are
wrestling with a range of issues.

At the heart of the matter is the question of whether the
present secretariat of Parliament should have a management
function and, if so, the extent of that function. Some
members of the consultancy team are arguing strongly for a
new tier of management to be added to the current hierarchy.

One source from within the team said that "there is an
amazing lack of understanding about what democratic
management means. The fact of the matter is that the
parliamentary secretariat has never had to manage before in
the sense of making real decisions. In the old days, they
simply did what they were told. Robin Douglas (as secretary
to Parliament, its most senior employee) is trying very hard,
but he is floundering".

Douglas himself accepts that he and his colleagues in the
secretariat have no experience or expertise in management.
"The problem with a more proactive management style," says
one of the most senior members of the secretariat, "is that
it takes us into the realm of political decision-making. We
are in an impossible position: if we are passive we are
blamed for being obstructionist; if we take decisions or make
recommendations, one or other party blames us either for
being 'old guard' or for being sycophantic to the majority
party."

The leaders of the house, Trade and Industry Minister
Trevor Manuel and Environment Minister Dawie de Villiers,
will play a more hands-on role from now on to co-ordinate the
management of Parliament. Manuel acknowledged that the
departments' limited capacities are partly to blame for the
bottleneck in Parliament.

"Bill writing is therefore taking longer than usual. And
some uncertainty remains while the constitutional process is
not concluded. Original powers of provinces are not well
defined yet. So we are hesitant to have legislation certified
when there is a chance of it getting stuck in the
Constitutional Court. There are complex checks and balances
at play.
