Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa IFP Constitution Envisages A Provincial Army


LENGTH: 1147 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 15, 1995
by Marion Edmunds and Ann Eveleth

JOHANNESBURG - The recently released hardline Inkatha
Freedom Party constitution calls for a provincial army,
exclusive provincial policing powers and the right to refuse
intervention in the province by the South African National
Defence Force. It also claims exclusive powers over all
constitutional, legislative, judicial, and financial matters
and paves the way for an unelected provincial government.

The IFP draft says neither the provincial premier nor
other members of the provincial cabinet need come from the
elected parliament. The Zulu King is mandated, in
consultation with the leaders of majority parties, to choose
the premier, who is then empowered to form a cabinet at his
discretion. The provincial parliament is then mandated to
cast a vote of confidence or no confidence in the cabinet
within 10 days. 

The African National Congress analysis argues this feature
"produces an autocratic monarchist government which is not
really responsible to the parliament and to the people".

The ANC has slammed the IFP constitution in an internal
paper -- prepared for the party leadership but leaked to the
Mail & Guardian this week -- which claims that the IFP
proposal "is a document of secession ... written under the
supposition of and in preparation for secession".

The ANC said of the IFP security provisions for a
Volunteer Reserve Force and exclusive provincial policing
powers: "There is no federation in the whole world which
allows its inherent state to maintain its own army."

The release of the IFP constitution comes amid a growing
rift between IFP provincial "moderates" and national
hardliners over the multi-party constitutional negotiations
in progress in the province.

Provincial negotiators this week defied moves by national
negotiator and IFP deputy national chairman Sipo Mzimela, and
constitutional advisor Mario Ambrosini, to quash the multihardline principles which would surely have set the province
party process and force a parliamentary vote on a set of
on course for fresh elections.

Mzimela last week rejected a compromise document drafted
by all parties, but provincial negotiators this week pushed
ahead with multi-party talks in the constitutional committee.

But provincial negotiators claimed last week that
Mizimela's hardline position had "nothing to do" with their
efforts to secure a negotiated compromise with other parties
including the ANC in the province.

Observers argue that the seismic rift in the IFP casts
doubts on attempts to democratise party structures over the
past year, while the heavy-handed interference of national
leaders in the provincial process casts aspersions on the
party's claims of federalism.

Ironically, a party whose claims to internal democracy are
in dispute, is promoting a constitution that provides for the
government of the "kingdom" to intervene in the internal
affairs of political parties and trade unions whose
structures are deemed undemocratic.

The constitution also says: "The kingdom of KwaZulu-Natal
is a sovereign member state of the Republic of South Africa."

The ANC's rejoinder is that "the notion of a 'member
state' is only used within an international context: "For
example, the European states forming the European Union are
called 'member states' in the Treaty of the European
Community."

The ANC also criticises the IFP claim for "a priority of
the provincial constitution over the (national)
constitution", saying "the only similar rules are to be found
in the separatist constitution of Tartarstan".

The ANC argues these clauses "could only be accepted after
a secession of KwaZulu-Natal ... No federal state (anywhere
in the world) can -- except in danger of its own dissolution
-- permit that the legitimacy of its national actions would
finally be controlled by the constitutions of its provinces
or revised by their constitutional courts. The intention
clearly is in the direction of secession".

The IFP constitution also makes several declarations
regarding the superiority of provincial laws over national
laws. The ANC argues this claim for the "sovereignty of
parliament implies that the Republic of South Africa ...
should only be a composed entity (not a state) consisting of
sovereign provinces with all the attributes of a national
state".

The ANC compares this model to that of the European Union,
"which is also not yet a state, but merely a confederation of
states".


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


143 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September, 1995


South Africa Inkatha's Secret German War Chest


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1507 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
September 15, 1995
by Paul Stober, Marion Edmonds, Eddie Koch and Ann Eveleth

JOHANNESBURG - Evidence has emerged that the Inkatha
Freedom Party (IFP), led by Mangosuthu Buthelezi, plans to
rebuild its paramilitary and intelligence capabilities --
using German funds earmarked for development -- ahead of a
possible showdown with central government over a constitution
for Kwazulu-Natal.

And, in the week that Chancellor Helmut Kohl made a state
visit to South Africa, the Mail & Guardian has learned that
there is serious concern in President Nelson Mandela's office
about the use of German funds in the province.

Sources in Mandela's office say the president has an
"ongoing concern" about German development funds to the IFP
being diverted for intelligence and other paramilitary
purposes in KwaZulu-Natal.

But it is known that there is serious concern in the
Cabinet's inner circle that the IFP may be trying to rebuild
its policing and military capabilities ahead of a possible
showdown with the central government over a federal
constitution for KwaZulu-Natal. 

Despite assurances from the German chancellor that his
government does not interfere in South Africa's domestic
affairs, it has emerged that the Konrad Adenauer Foundation,
the taxpayer-financed funding agency of Kohl's Christian
Democratic Union (CDU), has sunk tens of millions of rand
into Inkatha over the last decade.

At least two intelligence sources have told the M&G this
week that two German citizens currently in South Africa are
involved in trying to devise ways of using money intended for
development projects in Kwazulu-Natal to bankroll a new
Inkatha intelligence unit. The intelligence unit is intended
to replace the once- powerful Bureau of Security and
Intelligence (BSI) which was disbanded together with the
KwaZulu police.

It is understood that Joe Mathews, Deputy Minister of
Safety and Security and a high-ranking Inkatha official, and
IFP Senator Phillip Powell, will play leading roles in the
new intelligence unit and that IFP leader Mangosuthu
Buthelezi has been briefed about the plan.

Also named as a player is a man called Stan Armstrong, who
is said to have played a key role in the BSI before the
KwaZulu homeland was disbanded. Armstrong served as an
administrative chief in IFP leader Buthelezi's office at the
time.

Armstrong was named last year by Rian van Rensburg -- a
former military officer who claims to have been involved in
the training of paramilitary units for the IFP -- as the link
man between his clandestine work and the party's leadership.

There are fears in the president's office that the
proposed new intelligence agency is part of a more extensive
set of contacts between the Inkatha Freedom Party and
conservative organisations in Germany -- a major source of
support for the IFP, especially since access to state revenue
was cut off with the disbandment of the KwaZulu homeland.
Presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana refused to comment on
the reports.

Large sums of money have been donated to Inkatha since
1983 through the CDU's Konrad Adenauer Foundation. The
Foundation receives German taxpayers' money to fund political
and development programmes in the Third World. It is not
allowed to finance political parties as such and the money
has been paid to the Inkatha Institute.

It emerged from the Inkathagate scandal that the Institute
was the channel used by the South African security police for
secret government funding of the IFP. Major Louis Botha, the
security police officer who acted as the link man with
Inkatha, has close family ties with Germany. Botha was
arrested some three months ago and charged in connection with
the murder of 13 ANC supporters in 1987. This month, Botha
asked for his bail conditions to be lifted so that he could
attend the "50th wedding anniversary of his father-in-law" in
Germany.

The Inkatha Institute closed down after the Inkathagate
scandal and has been replaced by the Institute for Federal
Democracy. The Konrad Adenauer Foundation now donates some
R3,5-million a year to the new institute. Sources close to
the Adenauer Foundation say it is currently channelling a
minimum of R9-million a year into political and development
projects in KwaZulu-Natal.

The head of the new-look institute is Rama Naidu, former
head of the Konrad Adenauer office in Cape Town. Naidu
insists his organisation is not a think-tank for Inkatha and
that it offers its services to a wide range of political
organisations.

Ingor Scholz, director of Konrad Adenauer's Africa desk,
said he had been disappointed by past media reports linking
foundation money to "fomenting bloodshed in KwaZulu-Natal".
Scholz stressed that the foundation was now providing
constitutional support to all political parties in South
Africa which requested such assistance.

But it is understood that there has recently been some
concern among consultants hired by the foundation over the
possibility of its funds being "misspent" in the volatile
province.

The history of German links with Inkatha has reinforced
concern about foreign involvement in moves to create a new
intelligence agency linked to the IFP.

The developments come amid reports of a hardline draft
constitution drawn up by Inkatha's national leadership that
grants extensive regional powers to KwaZulu- Natal. The draft
IFP document provides for a right to declare provincial
states of emergency and set up a provincial army. It also
places strong controls on the power of the national army to
operate in the province.

Konrad Adenauer Foundation funds, funnelled through the
Institute for Federal Democracy, have been used to pay for a
number of German consultants to help the IFP draft its
constitutional proposals. The latest draft constitution is,
however, believed to have been produced by the IFP in the
face of criticism from the German advisers.


LOAD-DATE: October 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


144 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zimbabwe- Government To Set Up People's Bank


LENGTH: 1170 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 3, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's National Affairs, Employment
Creation and Co-operatives Deputy Minister Gabriel Machinga has said
government is still committed to the idea of a People's Bank and has
already commissioned a study on the project.

Addressing a Self-Help Development Foundation of Zimbabwe workshop
being attended by 36 co-ordinators and representatives of Savings
Clubs and Co-operatives from the country's eight provinces, Machinga
said the bank would be established after the study.

The four-day workshop begun Monday under the auspices of the
Frederick Adenaur Foundation, will seek ways of making nonMachinga urged workshop participants to come up with
governmental organisations self-financing.
recommendations on strategies the self-help development foundation
could adopt in future regarding credit, social security, training and
counselling so society could stop relying on donors. 

He said particular attention should be paid to the needs of the
disadvantaged in society, such as the disabled, the poor, women and
children.

"More than 50 percent of Zimbabwe's population are women, while
female-headed households account for more than a third of all
households, most of which are among the poorest in rural areas.

"Without a concerted effort to assist and involve them in
development programmes, their situation is likely to worsen,
especially in the light of the ravaging drought currently being
experienced throughout the country and sub-region," said Machinga.

The chairman of the self-help development foundation, Gibson
Munyoro, said since its launch in the 1960s, the number of savings
clubs had risen from 30 to 12,000 while membership rose from 200 to
400,000 people.

Munyoro said savings clubs were popular because of the scarcity
of banks in many rural areas, high minimum deposits and difficulties
in withdrawing funds from financial institutions.

"Where there are banks, the financial institutions are too rigid
and do not serve the needs of the poor, especially women.

"Rural people need liberal banking regulations. Co-operatives or
people's banks which can give loans without asking for collateral are
therefore imperative," said Munyoro.

Officials of similar bank started in Nigeria in 1989 say it now
has 320 branches in 2,700 villages.

Modelled after the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh and the
Neighbourhoood Money Shops in the Philippines, the People's Bank of
Nigeria says it has disbursed some 30 million dollars to more than
460,000 loan beneficiaries, 70 per cent of whom are among the poorest
of some 50 million women in the country.

Individuals or small groups of five people may borrow a minimum of
20 dollars and a maximum of 10,000 dollars repayable in 52 weeks.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


145 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Sudan Livestock Increases Two-fold In A Decade


LENGTH: 547 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 3, 1995

KHARTOUM, Sudan - The Sudanese Ministry of Animal Resources says
the country's livestock have doubled from 50 million to 103 million
in the past decade.

Executive Director in the ministry, Mohammed Salih Gabir told PANA
in Khartoum that these were made up of 30 million heads of cattle, 3
million camels, 37 million sheep and 33 million goats.

Ahmed El Mustafa Hassan, Director of Animal Health and Epedemic
Control, attributes the rise in the livestock population largely to
veterinay care, especially the control of rinderpest, a devastating
cattle disease. 

Hassan said though no up-to-date statistics are available
Ethiopia, with 58 million heads of cattle is still considered to have
the biggest cattle population in Africa.

He said Somalia was until very recently Africa's biggest breeder
of camels.

Another factor contributing to the rise of Sudanese livestock
population was the considerable improvement of rainfall conditions
since 1985. These have given rise to good pastures and made up for
the disastrous droughts of the late 1970s and the early 1980s.

The government in 1991 adopted a programme of economic
liberalisation that deregulated prices of most local products
including meat whose unit price rose by 1000 per cent.

Exporters were motivated by continuous revision of the rate of
exchange of the national currency against the dollar, in their
favour.

Besides, government troops had since 1992 stormed many strongholds
of the Rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), liberating vast
areas formerly held by the rebels, and thereby improving the life of
farmers and cattle breeders in the resourceful areas of the Blue Nile
and Kordofan districts.

Hassan said the national veterenary laboratory had been able to
manufacture considerable quantities of animal drugs which have
impacted positively on the health of the livestock.

Sudan was in 1994 able to export cattle and meat estimated at 37
million dollars. The value rose to 75 million dollars annually in the
1980s, before it dropped drastically in the 1990s.

Analysts attributed this to the reduction of cattle and camels
imports by neighbouring Egypt and Saudi Arabia.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


146 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large Africa's GDP Will Tripple in 1995


LENGTH: 707 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 3, 1995
by Felix Njoku PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - Africa's Gross Domestic Product (GDP), excluding
South Africa and Nigeria, is projected to tripple this year from 1.2
per cent in 1994, the World Bank says in its 1995 report.

The report entitled "' A Continent In Transition", covering the
periods July 1 1994 to June 30 1995, attributes the faster growth to
positive reversals in countries such as Malawi and Zambia.

Others -- Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Mali, Senegal,
and Uganda -- have significantly accelerated the growth of their
economies, it says. 

"Although the recovery has been assisted by good weather
conditions and an improvement in the global Economic Environment,
it also reflects changes that augur well for the future, especially a
big Jump in the Region's gross Domestic Investment," it says.

However, there were the usual variations among countries: In the
Franc zone, the report says, the devaluation of the CFA franc in 1994
has helped put the economies of most of the countries back on the
growth path.

"GDP growth turned around by 2.1 percentage points on average for
the thirteen countries of the zone (Excluding Comoros) in 1994,
compared with 1991-93, and became positive for the first time in this
decade. Specifically, growth was positive in ten of the thirteen
countries," it says.

Agriculture and industry, it says, has responded with the later
growing by by 6.7 per cent in Cote D'Ivoire. Although export growth
has accelerated, it addds, it remains relatively low because
producer still need time to respond to new opportunities.

On specific sectors, the report says there were dramatic
improvement in some activities in 1994, especially in Sahelian
livestock, rice, canned fish, tourism, textiles, and other
manufacturing.

"Cotton production in 1994/95 is up by 50 per cent in Burkina Faso
and Togo and by more than 25 per cent in Mali, and groudnut
production is 40 per cent larger than the year before in Senegal", it
says.

While prices rose sharply in all countries in 1994, for the zone
as a whole inflation was kept below the level anticipated on the
basis of the magnitude of the devaluation.

Elsewhere, a few countries have experienced declines in real GDP
(Burundi, Malawi, and Zaire, in particular), or near-stagnation
(Nigeria).

Several countries registered GDP growth of between 4 per cent and
6 per cent (Mauritania, Mauritius, Mozambique, Tanzania, Uganda, and
Zimbabwe). For some, growth in this range was for the second, third,
or fourth year in a row.

"A Continent In Transition" points out that 21 countries achieved
positive per capital income growth during 1988-93.
This trend continued and spread in 1994, especially in countries
implementing economic reform programs, which, it adds, deserve to be
supported by the donor community.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Zambia Bans Scrap Metal Exports


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 3, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian government, which says it intends to
pass a law to hang copper thieves to protect the mineral from
reported increased thefts, has now banned exports of scrap metal
which it says had been used as cover to smuggle copper.

Deputy Mines Minister Ackim Nkole said Sunday in the northern
region copper-mining town of Kitwe that government had discovered
that scrap metal business had been used by some unscrupulous dealers
to hide and ship out stolen copper. 

Most Zambian scrap metal dealers mainly export to neighbouring
Zimbabwe and South Africa.

"We know what they are doing. They bury copper in a heap of scrap
which they declare", said Nkole who announced that government
intended to legislate copper and cobalt thefts into capital offences
to deter thefts of the country's major foreign exchange-earning
minerals.

Zambia earns the bulk of its foreign exchange from copper and some
cobalt, by-product of copper ore also produced in the region.

The Minisater of Mines, Keli Walubita recently set up a crack
anti-metal theft police unit in the mining region to curb the thefts.

Last week, the government set up a gemstone auction centre in the
capital, Lusaka, to supervise sales of the country's precious stones
currently mined by private small scale investors.

The auction centre will ensure orderly sales of the stones and
enable government recover tax.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


148 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zimbabwe Breastfeeding Code Has Opposite Results


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 4, 1995

MACHEKE, Zimbabwe - The International Breastfeeding Code meant to
improve the nutritional status of infants is having a negative impact
in Zimbabwe as it contributes to malnutrition among orphaned infants
who no longer have easy access to breastmilk substitutes.

A nursing sister in Zimbabwe's Murewa district said in an
interview that because baby-milk companies had stopped donations to
hospitals and clinics, surviving relatives, most of them destitute
and aged grandparents, encountered insurmountable problems sourcing
the highly priced substitutes. 

Hospitals, she said, could no longer provide milk formula and
advised relatives to register the orphaned infants with Zimbabwe's
department of social welfare for monetary assistance.

"The little babies suffer because of the delays at welfare to
register them and at the end of the day they become malnourished,"
she said.

While not ruling out that the increasing number of women dying in
child-birth could be related to HIV infection, she said the trend was
cause for worry.

Zimbabwe subscribes to the International Breastfeeding Code which
sets limits on the promotion of milk formulas through donations to
hospitals and other means by suppliers.

The country's Ministry of Health and Child Welfare is negotiating
with the Zimbabwe Drugs Control Council on how to come up with a
policy that would ease the plight of baby orphans.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


149 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large Demographic Impact of HIV/AIDS in Sub-Saharan Africa


LENGTH: 694 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 3, 1995
by Gabu Amacha PANA Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Like it affects the economy, labour
force, as well as women and children, the HIV/AIDS pandemic also has
severe demographic consequences.

As the pandemic takes its toll, the increased levels of morbidity
and mortality will certainly affect Africa's already overstretched
health infrastructure.

"...living in an HIV/AIDS environment will most certainly lead to
heightened levels of mortality, hence higher estimates of crude death
rate or infant mortality rate and reduced life span," says Kampion
Banda of the population division of the Economic Commission for
Africa. 

"Large proportions of young adult parents succumbing to aids will
leave behind an equally large group of orphans with little economic
support for themselves and grandparents," Banda told a seminar on the
socio-economic impact of the HIV/AIDS on households and families in
Africa which opened in Addis Ababa Monday.

Africa is today the hardest hit region by the HIV/AIDS pandemic.

The United Nations estimates that in the 15 hardest hit
countries in Africa, including Uganda, Kenya, Zaire, Zambia, Rwanda,
Tanzania, Cote d'Ivoire, Malawi and Zimbabwe, some two million people
would have been killed by the pandemic by the year 2005.

In addition, between 1990 and the year 2005, about eight years of
life expectancy will be lost in these countries.

Banda said for Africa as a whole, life expectancy will fall
gradually as a result of AIDS, and will remain below the set target
of 60 in the year 2000.

"Africa will therefore delay by 10-20 years before achieving its
set target," said Banda.

He added, the "eastern sub-region will have lost most years in
life expectancy and may not easily gain until the year 2020 and
beyond."

If adequate and carefully designed preventive measures are not
taken in the whole region then the population growth rate in Africa
may decline from roughly 3 per cent to 2 per cent per annum. The
crude death rate will increase to 21 per 1000 in 1995-2000, while
life expectancy will drop from 51 to 43 years on the average, says
Wambui Karanja of the ECA's socio-economic research and planning
division told the seminar.

Fertility is yet another component of population growth likely to
be affected by the HIV/AIDS pandemic.

"While some infected people may attempt to have many children in
the hope that some may be seronegative and survive, there is the
possibility of fertility decline through... a delay in first
marriage, the erosion of the numbers of women in the prime
childbearing years, a reduction in sexual activity during the
symptomatic phase, and widespread use of condoms to prevent
infection," Karanja told the experts, policy makers and practitioners
who ended their seminar Wednesday. PANA GA/DS 03Oct95


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October, 1995


Sudan Sudan's Traditional Bone-Healing


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 4, 1995

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Conventional wisdom in the Sudanese capital
Khartoum is that "if you have a broken bone or dislocation go to '
Bit Bati' ."

Zeinab Mustafa Ahmed, popularly known as Bit Bati (daughter of
Bati), has inherited the skill of bone-healing from her father and
gained wide fame in a country that still trusts traditional medicine . 

Zeinab, over 80, claims to have cured many Sudanese and foreign
notables who came to her home for treatment after modern medicine had
failed to cure their pains.

In an interview with Khartoum's Arabic language tabloid ' Addar'
Tuesday, the traditional healer said she uses her bare hands to
detect what is wrong with a human body.

"I remember that during a traditional medicine conference I was
asked how I could distinguish a dislocation from a broken bone. I
said my hands can do better than X-ray," she boasts.

She says the world of sport, especially football teams, had kept
her well supplied with customers.

Despite her admiration of Sudan's famous Hilal Football Team, she
boasts, she treats its players on an equal footing with players from
other teams -- in keeping with her humanitarian mission.

When asked whether she had managed to transfer her skills to
other members of her family, as did her father to her, Zeinab said
she was sorry not to have taught the secrets of the trade to any of
her sons and daughters because they were too busy with their
education and away from home for longer period. However, one of her
younger sisters can perform some not very complicated jobs, she says.

Africa News


October, 1995


Rwanda Civil War Brings Ecological Disaster


LENGTH: 614 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 9, 1995
by Isaie Sagahutu Pana Correspondent

KIGALI, Rwanda - The Rwandan civil war, which started in October
1990, has not only caused human deaths but also severely damaged the
country's fauna and other natural resources.

Particularly damaged during the fighting between the Rwandese
Patriotic Front and the regular government army of the late Gen.
Juvenal Habyariman, were the fauna and infrastructure of the Kagera
National Park in the north and the Mutara game hunting reserve.

The damage occured in the course of massive population movements,
as people tried to escape from the combatants or to seek temporary
shelter and relative calm. 

The destruction went unhindered because the park's wardens had
to run away fromn Gabiro further South to Kayonra, to save their
lives.

The withdrawal of the rangers opened the area to penetration by
poachers who joined the displaced population and soldiers in the
plunder of animals and other resources.

The five-year old civil war also negatively impacted on
Agriculture because peasants were forced to neglect or abandon their
farms.

Among park's most damaged infrastructures is Gabiro Guest House,
one of the previously protected area's two magnificent hotels.

The guest house changed hands several times as the RPF and the
government army battled for power.

The situation in the park deteriorated even further by October
1994 as the plunder of equipment and destruction engulfed the entire
zone. Among the infrastructures which suffered around this time were
the fisheries equipment on the shores of Lake Ihema.

Rwanda possesses two two national parks- the Kagera National
Park within which is located the Mutara Hunting sancuary- and the
Volcanos National Park.

The Kagera national Park is located in Northestern Rwanda close
to the mouth of the Kagera river, from which its name derives.

This park dates back to 1934 and was established on marginal
lands with low human activity.The area is infested by the tse-tse
flies and has a dry climate suitable for wildlife.

The Kagera Park and the Mutara Hunting zone cover over 285,000
hectares in which a wide diversity of fauna, including
antelopes,leopards, zebras, buffaloes, elephants, lions and giraffes
used to roam freely.

The Mutara Hunting sanctuary was an alternative home for the
wildlife from the Kagera national park. The animals used to migrate
there annually in search of water and pasture.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

October, 1995


Senegal Large-scale Action to Save Senegalese Forests


LENGTH: 254 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 9, 1995

DAKAR, Senegal - In a bid to conserve diminishin forests, The
governmewnt of Senegal has initiated 16 reafforestation projects and
six others on improved land use at a cost of at 20 billion CFA francs
( 500 CFA = one US dollar).

This was disclosed inn a recent paper on ' Population and the
Environment' presented to seminar for West African journalists in
Dakar by Oussouby Toure, the executive secretary of Senegal's Supreme
Council for Natural Resources and the Environment (CONSERE). 

Logging for household energy needs is one of the main causes of
deforestation in Senegal which consumes some 333,700 tonnes of
charcoal annually, Toure said.

Most affected if the Tambacounda region in the south-east. This
supplies 84 per cent of Senegal's charcoal.

Taxation has also been a problem. Of the 20 billion cfa in annual
sales of charcoal, government recieves an average of some 650 million
cfa, Toure said.

Africa News


October, 1995


Zimbabwe Natural Farming Methods Advocated


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 2, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - With rising input costs beyond the reach of
many communal farmers, an organisation promoting permaculture has
said ' natural farming' methods could restore Zimbabwe as a leading
food producer in southern Africa.

While the recurrent droughts have been attributed to inadequate
rainfall, Enita Chimanikire of the country's Natural Farming Network
(NFN) said yields had been affected by the soil's increased
dependency on chemicals. 

"Right now most of the soils in Zimbabwe cannot produce anything
without the introduction of chemicals like fertilisers," Chimanikire
said.

She said NFN was training farmers to revert to old fashioned
agriculture of crop rotation, composts and inter-cropping.

However, because of the damage done to the soil by chemicals, at
least four or five years were needed for the soil to recover before
benefits of the natural farming methods could be felt.

The method had proved effective with small gardens and initial
trials to test suitability on large tracts of land had yielded
positive results.

"Composts work for small gardens, but for large fields, we always
say farmers should plant maybe maize, legumes and other crops to
promote inter-croping and improve nutrition," said the
permaculturist.

Sometimes worms had to be introduced to speed up decomposition
and eventually enrich the impoverished soil and plants like mustard
that attracted pest eating insects were grown to boost this
ecological system.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large SADC Urged to Invest More in Farming and Water


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 2, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Countries in the drought-prone Southern Africa
Development Community (SADC) region need t invest more money in food
production and harness more water to avert starvation, an
agricultural economist has said.

Regional Early Warning Unit (REWU) project co-ordinator Tendai
Masundire said in an interview that the region lost a lot of water
during the rain season when most rivers were in flood and the water
was left to flow away. 

The region has experienced recurrent droughts, the last major one
being in 1991 when rains stopped prematurely, resulting in severe
food shortages. This forced nearly all countries to make massive
importation of grain worth millions of dollars.

REWU projected a regional cereal deficit of 3.91 million tonnes
for the 1995/96 marketing year and noted that SADC countries had
embarked on drought relief and rehabilitation programmes.

"The only way out of these chronic droughts is to harness the
available water and put more money into food production like
irrigation," said Masundire.

He said before the 1991 drought, countries did not readily use
information from REWU, adding that the attitude was changing and the
unit was flooded with requests for forecasts on harvests.

The attitude change, he said was possibly out of realisation that
adequate planning and preparation was essential if a drought was
imminent.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Mozambique-Zimbabwe Mozambique and Zimbabwe in Water Agreement


LENGTH: 534 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 2, 1995

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The Zimbabwean authorities have pledged not
to divert massive amounts of water from th Pungue river for
irrigation purposes without first conducting a thorough environmental
impact assessment.

This promise came at a meeting in the central Mozambican city of
Beira on Wednesday between Mozambique's Minister of Public works and
Housing, Roberto White, and the Zimbabwean Minister of Land and
Water, Kumbirai Kangai.

Mozambique has complained vigorously at Zimbabwean plans to
divert 70 million cubic metres of water a year from the Pungue to its
Save Valley for irrigated agriculture. 

The plan would dramatically reduce the amount of Pungue water
flowing into Mozambique. cited by the Beira paper ' Diario de
Mocambique', White said this would affect Beira's water supply, the
irrigation systems on the lower Pungue, and the Pungue estuary
ecosystem, which is a nursery for prawns, one of Mozambique's main
exports.

Even without the Zimbabwean scheme, the Pungue can fall to
dangerously low levels in the dry season. As a result seawater
penetrates far upstream. Beira's water supply had previously been
interrupted because the salt content of the water at the pumping
station was too high for human consumption.

The two ministers signed a protocol establishing a joint
commission on water resources of common interest to the two
countries.

The Pungue diversion scheme is thus postponed, perhaps
indefinitely. Kangai told reporters that Zimbabwe would not advance
with the project without Mozambique's consent.

However, the ministers did agreed that Zimbabwe could take what
kangai described as "a small amount of water" from the Pungue to
supply its eastern city of Mutare.

"According to environmental studies, this will not have any
impact," claimed the Zimbabwean minister.

The amount involved, however, is 25 million cubic metres a year,
which is far from negligible.

Mozambique and Zimbabwe will now seek donor funds to carry out a
thorough study of the entire pungue basin.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


156 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zimbabwe Foreigners Show Interest in Major Water Supply Deal


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 2, 1995

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe - International companies have started lobbying
for the proposed construction of a pipeline to draw water from the
Zambezi River to Zimbabwe's drought-stricken Matabeleland region in a
project estimated to cost Zimdollars 2 billion (USD 235.3 million).

Coordinator of the Matabeleland Zambezi Water Trust (MZWT),
championing the implementation of the project, Kingsley Dube, said in
an interview companies from as far afield as Britain, France, Japan
and Scandinavia were continuously inquiring on how they could
participate in the project.

"But we are telling them to hold their horses until full results
of feasibility studies on the project are out in November," Dube
said. Should results of the Swedish-conducted studies to determine
possibilities of piping water from the Zambezi over 400 kilometres to
the north be affirmative, Dube said, the MZWT would then go to tender
for construction purposes. 

"We have not earmarked any company for the job. We will take the
best bidder considering the actual cost of the project," he said.

Initial results showed the project was feasible although experts
were yet to work out finer engineering details such as size, location
of the pipeline and exact cost of the project.

The israelis had already invited MZWT trustees to attend workshops
on water in that country.

The MZWT was formed to lobby government to implement the project,
widely viewed as a lifeline by industrialists in this semi-arid
region.

Bulawayo, once Zimbabwe's industrial capital, imposed strict water
rationing with deterrent penalties early this year to try and stretch
meagre supplies in its reservoirs.

At the peak of a drought in 1992/93, some companies pulled up the
stakes, laid off thousands of workers, and relocated operations to
places where permanent water supplies were guaranteed.

Agricultural experts say the project would also enhance Zimbabwe's
food security as 57 000 hectares of land is envisaged to come under
irrigation.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large Convention on Export of Hazardous Waste Amended


LENGTH: 427 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 2, 1995

GENEVA - The Third Conference of the Parties to the Basel
Convention on the Control of Transboundar Movements of Hazardous
Wastes has ended in Geneva with a ban on the export of hazardous
wastes from developed countries (OECD members) to developing ones.

"This amendment was tough to negotiate, but we finally succeeded
in serving the interests of the environment," said Bakary Kante,
chairman and Director of Environment in Senagal's environment
ministry. 

The ban on wastes destined for recovery or recycling operations
will be phased in before taking complete effect after 31 December
1997.

Support for the measure was based on the need to protect
developing countries from unwanted imports.

"Developing countries lack the financial, technical, legal and
institutional capacity for monitoring the transboundary movement of
hazardous wastes and preventing illegal imports," says the United
Nations Environment Programme said in a communique at the weekend.

"An export ban will help to remedy the weakness of these
countries' existing import bans. It will also act as an incentive to
minimize the generation of hazardous wastes at source," it says.

The debate over the ban was complicated by the difficulties in
classifying a number of wastes in the Convention and the
characteristics that make them hazardous. Further work is still
needed on this. The Technical Working Group will meet next year to
examine such technical questions.

The United States is not yet a party to the convention although
it is participating fully in its work.

The treaty was adopted in March 1989 and came into force in May
1992. It has been ratified by 91 countries and the European Union.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


158 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Sudan Sahara Envelopes More Of Sudan


LENGTH: 307 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 2, 1995
by Yahya El Hassan PANA Correspondent

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudan's drought control unit says that the
Sahara Desert is advancing south into the country at six kilometres
each year and that 60.5 per cent of the nation is now desert.

In a study on desertification it conducted, the unit in the
Ministry of Environment and Tourism, says the rapid desertification
is due mainly to the uncontrolled felling of trees for fuel. This is
a major phenomenon in country's forming the Sahara's southern shores
known as the sahel.

Eighty per cent of the energy used in Sudan is from charcoal and
firewood.

A danger posed by desertification is the shortage of natural
pastures that it has caused.

The executive director of the Animal Resources Ministry, Mohammed
Salih Gabir, told the Pan African News Agency that many of Sudan's
herders were now grazing their livestock in neighbouring countries.

Desertification has also taken a toll on game. The study finds
that many wildlife species, including deer and giraffes, have
disappered from Sudan and moved into Ethiopia a neighbour to the
east.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October, 1995


Tanzania Political Uncertainty Stalls Imports


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 10, 1995
DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Campaigns for parliamentary and presidential
elections due in Tanzania in October have generated so much
uncertainty that it has led a marked decline of goods imported into
the east African nation, according to the latest (central) Bank of
Tanzania review.
"During the month under review imports were estimated to have
declined 9.3 per cent from 135.6 million US dollars recorded in
August 1994 from 123. million in August 1995", the Tanzanian '
Guradian Newspaper quoted the bank as saying in its review for the
month of September.
It attributed the decline in imports to uncertainties in the
business environment, saying alien businessmen mainly involved in the
export-import business were scared by threats from politicians.
"They are scared stiff with threats by policians that they will be
chased away", the paper quoted one official as saying. 
 An investigation conducted by the Guardian found that in Dar Es
Salam, the capital, most businessmen were trying to clear their old
stocks without ordering any replacement.
Many of them confirmed that they were not comfortable to import
anything until after the general elections on 22 October (on the
islands of Zazibar and Pemba), and 29 October on the mainland..
The paper also said it found out that the businessmen also preferred
to hold dollars instead of the local currency, the shilling.
"It would be easier to move with dollars than the shillings if the
situation gets bad" they said.
According the report, the composition of the import bill for the
month under review was dominated by items required for industrial
production.
Industrial raw materials amounted to 28.8 million dollars during
August 1995 as against 24.3 million dollars recorded in the same
month the previous year, according to the review.
The government also ran up a 29-per-cent trade deficit.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Nigeria More European Countries Buy Nigerian Oil


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 10, 1995
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - More European countries have been importing
crude oil from Nigeria in the last 24 months, despite the slash by
the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation of the volume of crude
lifted by individual contract buyers.

According to a report just released by the European Commission, a
total of 32.5 million metric tonnes of Nigeria's high grade light
crude were exported to European markets in 1994, up by 21 per cent
from 26.8 million metric tonnes in 1993. 

The report says Nigeria led an African domination of oil
exporters to the EU market, moving from a 25.6 per cent share in 1993
to 27.3 per cent in 1994.

Oil accounts for some 90 per cent of Nigeria's total foreign
exchange earnings.

The report said total OPEC exports of crude and feedstocks to
Europe was 253 million metric tonnes in 1994, a 7.6-per-cent decrease
in the organisation's share of the EU's overall oil imports.

However, energy experts say the special preference for the high
grade crude from Nigeria, Libya and Algeria by European refiners,
might have accounted for the rise in demand for oil from the African
countries.

Nigeria has come under pressure from some EU members and the
United States over its political crisis, but oil companies in the
country are not towing the hard line of their home governments.

In September for instance, TEXACO of the United States changed
its earlier plans to divest from Nigeria, saying the economic
environment is now profitable.

Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large Ndiaye Plans Set Up Foundation


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 10, 1995
by Felix Njoku PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - Former President of the African Development Bank,
Babacar Ndiaye, plans to sent up a foundation estimated to cost 2.7
million US dollars.

Reports reaching PANA said the outfit, to be called ' African
Foundation For Enabling Stability and Growth (AFESAG)' , will be
based in Abidjan, capital of Cote d'Ivoire which also hosts the ADB. 

The objective of the non-profit foundation will be to foster
social stability and reinforce economic development in Africa, a
reliable source told PANA on Tuesday.

Ndiaye, said to be presently seeking donations for the body,
stepped down as ADB president in August after serving two five-year
terms.

His reputation as an astitute banker was crowned in 1988 when the
bank was rated among the best development finance institutions in the
world.

The Senegalese national also helped establish the African Business
Round Table (ABR), a loose association of eminent African
enterpreneurs, and the African Export-Import (AFREXIM) Bank, based in
Cairo, Egypt.

But Ndiaye's popularity suffered considerably in the last two
years of his tenure following persistent quarrels with the executive
directors of the bank who accused him of mismanagement.

He made a passing reference to the bad blood between him and the
directors in one of two books released in May.

"You know, my dear friend, we must tell the chief what he wants to
hear...this is the secret for longevity and promotion," he said in a
dialogue with an unidentified friend in ' La BAD, L'Afrique et Moi'
(the ADB, Africa and Me).

Analysts say Ndiaye was referring to what is often termed '
Politics of the Belly' , a rationale for mthe crookery that has
seriously undermined many African institutions.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large Development Bank Unveils Restructuring Plan


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 10, 1995

DAKAR, Senegal - The African Development Bank (ADB) will spend
17.8 million Units of Account (about 25 million US dollars) in a
restructuring programme being initiated by its new President,
Mohammed Kabbaj of Morocco, officials confirmed to PANA Tuesday.

They said part of the programme involves the retrenchment of some
240 bank workers between now and mid-January 1996. The move, it is
estimated, will save the bank some some six milion units of account
(about 8.4 million dollars).

Kabbaj, 53, was elected the bank's sixth substantive president on
26 August, taking over from Babacar Ndiaye, the Senegalese national
who managed it for 10 years.
On election, he assured shareholders he would produce a three-year
restructuring plan aimed at enhancing the credibility of the bank
which has suffered in the past two years.

The 25 non-African shareholders had demanded serious reforms of
the bank's operations as a condition for putting in more money into
the institution in which 51 African countries hold controlling
shares.

The non-regionals own 35 per cent of ADB shares and provide all
the loanble funds of the African Development Fund (ADF), the bank's
soft loan window.

Set up by African governments in 1963, the ADB currently has
resources of some 33 billion dollars.

It has committed some 28 billion dollars in loans, equity
investments, grants and techical assistance in 1,800 projects in
Africa.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa-Zimbabwe Textile Agreement in Problems


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 10, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - An agreement to allow preferential access of
Zimbabwean clothing and textile exports into South Africa is unlikely
to come into force before the end of the month, as earlier envisaged,
experts said on Tuesday.

In an interview, chief executive of the Confederation of Zimbabwe
Industries, Joe Foroma, said South Africa was still studying
Zimbabwe's proposals for preferential treatment of its clothing and
textile exports, further delaying the implementation of the
agreement. 

It was now unlikely the agreement would become effective before
the end of October this year as agreed in August.

Foroma, who was part of a Zimbabwean private sector delegation
that met with representatives of business South Africa in
Johannesburg last week, said the South Africans were still making
their own internal consultations on Zimbabwe's proposals.

"At the moment they have not declined the proposals although it is
unlikely the agreement will come into force by the agreed date,"
Foroma said.

The South Africans had in principle offered preferential access of
Zimbabwean clothing and textile exports into South Africa at
preference rates as close as possible to the situation that prevailed
before December 31, 1992.

A technical group was to work out the details.

South African textile manufacturers are however bitterly opposed
to any deal with Zimbabwe, a situation that has caused the delays.

South African Textile Federation executive director, Brian Brink
said in a telephone interview from Johannesburg that the industry in
South Africa was generally opposed to any agreement that would result
in Zimbabwean textiles and clothing inundating their country.

South African manufacturers have argued that their industry is
still very young, and not yet ready for complete exposure to external
competition.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Congo Congolese Government Abandons Fishing Monopoly


LENGTH: 200 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 10, 1995

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - The Congolese government has given up its
monopoly on coastal fishing by winding up the National Office for
Continental Fishing (ONAPEC) and the Management and Fishing Equipment
Public Company (SAGAP), official sources in Brazzaville, the capital,
have disclosed. 

The state-owned companies, liquidated in September, had failed to
meet Congo's demand for fish, estimated at more than 90,000 tons per
year. Their joint average output was 42,000 tons per annum while the
shortfall in demand of nearly 50,000 was met by imports.

The Congolese fishing minister, Jean Prosper Koyo, last week
invited local businessmen to take over the country's fishing
industry.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


165 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 1240 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 20, 1995
by Olu Sarr PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - Farrakhan, Savimbi, Kaunda, Sankara -- all are
colourful figures who have again grabbed the attention of African
newspapers and most likely, their readers.

Louis Farrakhan's Million Man March in Washington D.C. to affirm
self respect of African American men prodded Sud Quotidien (South
Daily), a privately owned daily in Dakar, Senegal, into comment.

It said while African Americans were subject to a range of abuses
and had disproportionate numbers in prison, they were also snared by
views such as those propounded by Farrakhan. These, it said, include
the belief that women should stay at home. 

"But beyond this," it said, "is the importance of (pride in)
ethnic identity."

However, it noted that ethnicity had caused wars in Africa and
Bosnia, as well as xenophobia in France and Italy. Coupled with the
growth and spread of unemployment worldwide ethnicity, it suggested,
had become a threat to peace.

"Poverty has caught up with the middle classes and this has become
fertile ground for all sorts of extremists," it said.

Such extremist tendencies have refelected themselves in the effort
to expel Zambia's first president, Kenneth Kaunda, from the country.
He is experiencing even worse political humiliation than Cote
d'Ivoire's Alassane Ouattara, who was also declared ineligible for
the country's presidential elections for the same reason as Kaunda:
lineage.

"In today's Africa, there are ambiguities and contradictions
intermingled with derisory confusion caused by the very people who
claim to be the champions of African unity," it said.

Given the monopoly over state media and the nationality laws
passed to bar the likes of Ouattara, A.M. News said, "Sunday's
election...appears already a concluded affair."

This, the Lagos paper added, was especially so with the opposition
insisting it would boycott the polls if the electoral rules are not
changed.

"What President Bedie must do to prevent the degeneration of this
landmark election into a farce and a sham is to ease his party's
reign on the state apparatus and allow for a trully free and fair
election without the intervention of frivolous statutes," it said.

"Ivory Coast should break the myth of Africa as a continent
antithetical to democracy by giving the opposition a chance of
participating in Sunday's election," it said.

State-owned Sidwaya of Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, said that
Ivorian candidates were focused much more on personal conflict than
on the issues.

President Henri Bedie can deflate the crisis, Sidwaya said, by
reopening talks with the opposition and agreeing to postpone voting.
This measure, it said, would not be a sign of weakness.

The prelude to the elections, it said, will be difficult for a
usually calm Cote D'Ivoire. The paper urged the protagonists to show
greater tolerance.

Ouagadougou dailies also commented on the eighth anniversary of
the assassination of the Burkina Faso leader, Capt. Thomas Sankara.

The privately owned Le Pays (the Country) noted that through sheer
determination, Sankara had built housing estates for the poor and
instilled values of hard work and a "can do" mentality in Burkina
Faso.

"But as years went by the man allowed power to get to him and
began displaying some tyranical tendencies," it said.

The government-owned Zambia Daily Mail focused on former Angolan
rebel leader Jonas Savimbi.

It praised him for agreeing to join the country's proposed
government of national unity but doubted Savimbi would really allow a
younger UNITA official to accept the second vice presidency.

"If UNITA chooses another leader it will be a dramatic decision
which will put a completely new face on Angolan politics. However, we
are not sure whether Dr. Savimbi's reason for stepping aside to give
room to an energetic young man is real," it said.

Savimbi's readiness to cede the number three spot in the
government was, he said, due to fatigue.

"If this is true, then there is something up his sleeve. We doubt
that Dr Savimbi can sit down and watch the game being played without
his influence," it said.

Savimbi's Union for the Total Independence of Angola, UNITA,
signed a peace accord with Angolan President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos
of the ruling MPLA in 1994 to end that country's almost two decades
of civil war.

The United Nations-brokered ' Lusaka Protocol' also provides for
a transitional government of national unity to be followed by
presidential elections.

For its part, the Ethiopian Herald commented on the 50th
anniversary of the United Nations.

"In a world of numerous philosophies and as many theories of the
world's problems, the golden jubilee of the UN serves to bring people
closer together in attaining the ultimate goal -- a better world to
live in," it said.

In addition to peacekeeping it said, "there's virtually no sector"
in which the UN does not play a major role.

"And as it celeberates its 50th anniversary the people of the
world hope its activities will be boosted even more in the coming
years," it said.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Mauritania New Lease for Fish in Mauritania


LENGTH: 600 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 23, 1995
by Mohamed Salem Ould Elouma PANA Correspondent

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania (PANA) - October has been a month of
tranquility for fish in Mauritanian following a temporary ban on
their extraction from all over the West African country's
territorial waters.

The monthly biological pause,supposed to give various species an
opportunity to multiply, was accepted by Noauckchott after
persistent reports by scintists indicated overfishing.

For several years the government had received warnings that fish
catches were declining. 

To prevent the situation from worsening, experts at the
Mauritanian National Oceanographic Research Centre recommended that
the governemnt should introduce an annual month-long ban in small
and large scale deep sea fishing.

The month of October was chosen because specialists know it as
the period of reproduction and post-reproduction for fishes in this
part of the west African coast.

It is hoped this biological pause will facilitate a regeneration
of endangered especies and subsquently improve catches, says Mr
Yahya Ould Attigh, the Director of Industrial Fishing.

A good number of fish species in Mauritanian waters are coveted
by European and Japanese commercial fishing firms who accepted the
monthly ban with misgivings.

However, knowing what was at stake, Mauritanian authorities
adopted an inflexible position regarding the biolgical pause.

This was reiterated by president Maouya Ould Sid'Ahmed when he
told an interviewer in Paris, France, that the pause was a sovereign
decision taken upon the advise of scientists.

The government's firm position is based on the fact that the
fisheries sector accounts for between 50 and 60 per cent of
Mauritania's export earnings and between 20 and 25 per cent of
government revenue. Its contribution to the Gross Domestic Product
is between 10 and 15 per cent.

Proponents of the fishing ban argue that, even if it momentarily
deprives the country of immediate earnings, the future benefits will
be greater when more fishes are allowed to reproduce and increase
their sizes.

Japanese fish merchants, for example, are known for their
penchant for big fish.

The other advantage is that the one month period gives
shipowners ample time to rehabilitate their fishing gear ready for a
new start on 1 November 1995.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Lack of Rain Raises Fears of Extreme Drought


LENGTH: 1027 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 23, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia, in the throes of a crippling drought
over the past several months, could experience a virtual halt of
economic activites within the next month, unless the unexpected
happens.
Zambia Electricity Supply Corporation (ZESCO) the country's major
supplier of hydro-electric power warned last week that it might be
forced to shut down its Kariba North Bank within 45 days if the
current water level in the dam drops further.

According to ZESCO officials, the water level is receding at a
daily rate of one centimetre and there are fears that operations
could grind to a halt if it fell by a further 1.5 metres below the
current level of 475 metres, which is the minimum capable of turning
the turbines for power generation.

Kariba North Bank dam is losing a minimum of 10 centimetres of
water everyday, according to ZESCO communications manager Lucy Zimba
who has said that a maximum of 487 metres of water is needed for
normal generation. 

"If the loss of water continues and reaches 474 metres, there
will not be enough to turn the turbines," said Zimba who added that
the situation could only return to normal by April 1996 even if
there was rain this year.

Itezhitezhi hydro-electric dam on the Kafue river also in the
south is facing similar water problems. It currently has 1,006
metres of water, barely 10 metres above the minimum level for power
generation.

Zambia currently imports about 2 million dollars worth of
electricity every month from neighbouring Zaire and ZESCO has said
that it will surcharge both industrial and domestic customers who
exceed their allocated electiricty quotas.

The southern African country has experienced intermittent drought
in the past six seasons with the worst being the 1991/92 season
which affected almost the entire southern African region.

Prospects of another dry spell this year has made most Zambians
unusually desperate as the current water shortage in most parts of
the country, particularly in the south, continues to bite.

Reports from Namwala in souterhn Zambia said last week that
teachers at one school have stopped work in protest against lack of
water at their institution.

In Luanshya, in the northern copperbelt, inmates at a prison are
said to be walking 16 kilometres to fetch water while some villagers
in the worst hit southern region are said to have started trecking
northwards in search of water for their cattle.

In Lusaka, the capital, worshippers of various churches last
weekend set aside their "religous differences" and converged at the
Anglican Cathedral of the Holy Cross to pray for adequate rains this
season.

Their prayers seemed to have been partially answered when Lusaka
had traces of rainfall last Friday with reports from other parts of
the country also indicating that there could be normal rains this
year.

Both traditional and conventional weather forecasters are
generally agreed that Zambia and the rest of southern Africa is
poised to receive adequate rains.

Traditional weather watchers normally base their predictions on
movements of certain birds, ants and other animal species and the
presence or absence of some plants just before the rains.

Some parts of the country have reported the arrival of swarms of
the swallow which both scientists and traditionalists say is a
harbinger of "good rain."

Theo Dohse, research manager at the Pretoria-based Agriculture
Research Centre in South Africa who attended an international
agriculture seminar in Lusaka last week told PANA that most farmers
in South Africa were preparing for a normal wet season.

According to him, their hope is based on a little local bird
known in the Afrikaans language as ' quiquit' which, he says, only
lays one egg prior to a dry year. it is laying up to six eggs this
year, he said.

Most of southern Africa receives rains between November and
April.

Meteorologists in the sub-region are also making similar
predictions. It would appear the gods, science and nature would want
to collaborate to send down the rain and breach the spell of drought
afflicting this part of an already blighted Africa, one of them said.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Ghana Shares Close Higher On Ghana Stock Market


LENGTH: 214 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 24, 1995

ACCRA, Ghana - Shares on the Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) ended
generally higher on Monday with gains by three equities sustaining
the market. 

The official GSE all-share index went up by 0.549 points to
close at 320.97.

The market's total capitalisation endned higher at 2,370.56
bilion cedis from the previous close of 2,369.67 bilion cedis (1,340
cedis = 1 USD).

Fam Milk Limited (FML), which led the market, went up 24 cedis
while Ashanti Goldfields Company (AGC) gained f our cedis at 24,005
and Social Security Bank (SSB) went up by one cedi at 5,900.

Trading closed on a thin volume of 14,490 shares with offers of
482,590 and demand of 220,620.

October, 1995


South Africa Development Programme Gains Momentum


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 24, 1995
by Lionel Willams PANA Staff Correspondent

PRETORIA, South Africa - President Nelson Mandela has assured
that his Research and Development Programme will soon reach millions
of South Africa's poor, as various projects get underway.

In a statement released Sunday, the President's office said that
while there have been delays because of lack of planning, management
and money, the framework for economic growth and development was now
in place. 

Some 300 projects providing regular water supply to almost four
million people are scheduled to be completed in the next eighteen
months, it said.

Free meals are being provided each day for 3.5 million school
children, it said, and almost three million people are benefitting
from electrification projects throughout the country.

The release said More than 25,000 families will benefit from land
reform programmes and land re-distribution schemes which will cost
close to 30 million dollars.

Another 30 million dollars will be spent on establishing and
upgrading police stations, aside from some 70 million dollars
earmarked for community policing.

In addition, almost 30,000 people are being employed in some 500
public works projects, the statement said.

It added that three-million people will benefit in the next one
year from over 600 projects to upgrade municipal services, while
free health care will be provided for children and pregnant women.

October, 1995


Africa-At-Large 36 Million Tourists in Africa by 2000


LENGTH: 227 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 24, 1995

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - The number of tourists visiting Africa
each year would rise from 15 million in 1990 to some 36 million by
the year 2010, according to latest projections by world tourism
officials. These figures were given by Kenya's Tourism and
Wildlife Minister Noah Katana Ngala at the Kenya Tourism Day held in
London and Manchester, in the United Kingdom last week. Ngala
quoted the World Tourism Organisation as saying that the east
African sub-region in which Kenya remains the leading destination is
expected to attract nine million visitors up from three million at
the start of the decade. He said income from the African tourism
sector in 1994 grew by seven percent to 6.3 billion dollars despite
a slight drop in arrivals due to bad publicity. In kenya, the
sector recorded an annual average growth of 10 per cent up to the
end of 1989.

October, 1995


Africa-AT-Large EIB Finances Six Projects In ACP Countries


LENGTH: 347 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 24, 1995

DAKAR, Senegal - Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Senegal and
Tanzania are among a handful of African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP)
states that will benefit from new investment loans of 35.5 million
ECU (about 46.15 million US dollars) recently approved by the
European Investment Bank (EIB).

The bank said in a statement issued from its Luxembourg base
that Senegal will receive 15 million ECU (about 19.5 million US
dollars) for the funding of a variety of projects, including the
provision of potable water and drainage. 

The bank said it will give Cote d'Ivoire seven million ECU
(about nine million US dollars) for the reconstruction of a
subregional railway line, and will approve six million ECU (about 7.8
million US dollars) for Burkina Faso to finance its section of the
railway that links Abidjan with Ouagadougou and Kaya.

The government of Tanzania will receive ECU 300,000 (about
390,000 US dollars) for the rehabilitation and extension of Tanzania
Hotel Investments Ltd (TAHI). The EIB said Antigua and Barbuda,
Grenada, St. Kitts and Nevis will share 7.2 million ECU (about 9.4
million US dollars) in both funding solid waste and upgrading airport
projects.

The funds are being provided by EIB under the Lome IV
Convention, a long-standing aid agreement between the 15-member union
and 70 former colonies in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large 353 Families Benefit From Loans


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 24, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The Zimbabwe Women Finance Trust (ZWFT) has
now disbursed 501 loans benefiting 353 families since the inception
of its direct lending programme in 1992, National Affairs Employment
Creation and Co-operatives Minister Florence Chitauro has said.

Opening the Women World Banking (WWB) Africa region meeting in
Harare on Monday, Chitauro said 70 percent of the loans were in the
rural areas where a greater part of the disadvantaged women lived.

Well over 2,000 participants had also been trained, 65 percent of
them in business management and 35 percent in business creation. 
About 75 percent of those trained in business creation had managed to
start their own businesses.

ZWFT is affiliated to WWB, an international organisation
established in 1975 to address the needs of women in micro and small
business around the world, particularly those who have not had access
to credit, savings instruments, markets and business know-how.

The Trust receives technical and financial assistance from nonDevelopment Agency (SIDA), Care International Zimbabwe and African
governmental organisations such as the Swedish International
Development Fund to enable it execute its mandate of uplifting the
status of women.

Chitauro said there was need to find alternative sources of
finance for women's businesses as most financial institutions in
Africa still discriminated against women in the provision of loans.

Concrete action plans were therefore needed to achieve the
economic empowerment of women.

"It is only through these efforts that issues of poverty
alleviation among women can seriously be considered by national
governments," she said.

WWB President Nancy Barry said future strategies should aim to
bring a substantial number of low income women into the economic
arena.

"We need to create internal organisational structures that will
enable us to reach more of the low income women," Barry told the
five-day meeting.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October, 1995


Mozambique Mozambique Set for Gas Agreement


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 24, 1995

NEW YORK - The Mozambican government and the American company
Enron will soon sign a contract for the exploitation of the natural
gas reserves at Pande in the southern Mozambican province of
Inhambane.

Speaking in New York, where he is attending the United Nations'
50th anniversary celebrations, Mozambican president Joaquim Chissano
announced that Enron is prepared to invest "hundreds of millions of
dollars" in the gas project, which involves building a pipeline from
Pande to South Africa, the only conceivable market for the gas. 

A source close to the negotiations, the most recent phase of
which took place last week in Washington, said that Enron could spend
between USD 400 million and 600 million on the project.

At a dinner offered by the company's managing director, Rebecca
Mark, Chissano stressed that exploiting the natural gas is part of
the Mozambican government's five year economic programme and that
the revenue it generates will be key to the country's development
and to improving the social conditions of the Mozambican people.

Chissano urged more American businessmen to invest in Mozambique.

He said the wide range of investment possibilities in the country
covered mining, agriculture and tourism while Mozambican legislation
offers excellent benefits to foreign investors.

Chissano's words seem to end the speculation in Maputo that the
contract with Enron will not be signed, either because the South
Africans are not happy with the eventual price of the gas, or
because Enron will not accept conditions demanded by the Mozambican
side.

Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Fashanu Clinches Zambian Soccer Deal


LENGTH: 480 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 26, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) has
appointed Nigerian-born English soccer star John Fashanu's Blue
Orchid Company as management consultants to take charge of Zambia's
soccer business in Europe.

FAZ interim chairman Simataa Simataa and Fashanu himself
confirmed the deal Wednesday. 

Under the agreement whose financial details are yet to be
disclosed, Fashanu's company will help arrange professional soccer
contracts for budding Zambian players.

He will also help to "dress" the Zambian national soccer team and
arrange the team's international friendly soccer matches in Europe
in a bid to help it improve standards.

Simataa said that the two-year contract with Fashanu will first
have to be ratified by the FAZ.

Fashanu, who played for England's Wimbledon and Aston Villa
football clubs and now runs his own soccer public relations firm,
arrived in Zambia last week.

He said he was in the country to see how he could help the
Zambian team which is currently in camp for the 1996 Africa Cup
soccer finals in South Africa.

Fashanu said in Lusaka Tuesday that he also wanted to "lure"
Zambia's skipper Kalusha Bwalya to work with him in Britain on a
programme to develop Zambian soccer.

Kalusha currently plays professional soccer in Mexico.

Fashanu has been linked to Zambian soccer since the death of most
of the country's original national soccer squad in a plane crash off
the Gabonese coast in April 1993.

He was instrumental in the recruitment of Scottish soccer coach
Ian Potterfield who put together the current squad.

Fashanu had personally travelled to Zambia soon after the crash
and donated some money to the widows of the deceased players,
officials, the crew and a journalist.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


NIGERIA Fifa Delegation Due In Nigeria


LENGTH: 547 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
October 26, 1995
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - A delegation of the world's soccer governing
body, FIFA is due in Nigeria next month for activities marking 50
years of the popular sport in the west African country, a Nigerian
soccer official said Monday. According to the spokesman, the
delegation to be led by FIFA President Joao Havelange is due in
Nigeria 7 November at the invitation of the Nigerian government.

Nigeria, African champions are celebrating the golden jubilee of
football, a sport that has brought international repute to the
country. 

The FIFA delegation is expected to use the visit to resolve its
dispute with Nigeria after the soccer supreme authority took away the
hosting right of the Under-17 World Cup from the west African
country early this year.

FIFA, citing security reasons, cancelled Nigeria's bid in April
for the 16-nation youth tournament, which it later awarded to the
Gulf State of Qatar.

In protest, Nigeria declined a FIFA invitation to participate in
the competition, to put a further strain on relations between the
country and FIFA.

The cancellation provoked anti-FIFA sentiments on the continent,
with the African Football Confederation (CAF), calling it an
"injustice," after Nigeria had spent millions of dollars to upgrade
its soccer facilities for the aborted tournament.

Nigeria's achievements in soccer are legion. They include
winning the Africa Cup of Nations twice. The country's talented
players feature in the world's top continental leagues.

The nation's senior team, the super eagles, appeared in the
World Cup for the first time and gave a good account of themselves
in the United States also in 1994.

Nigeria's under-17 side has won the world championship twice in
1985 and 1993.

But the country has of late seen its soccer fortunes decline at
the senior category mainly from poor management resulting in dismal
international engagements and inaction after the 1994 World Cup.

The team managed a consoling 3-2 away victory against former
soviet member-state Uzbekistan, in the first leg of their Afro-Asian
tie last Saturday. The return leg comes up in Lagos in November.

LANGUAGE: English
