Africa News


October, 1995


Uganda Final Word in October on Asec Soccer Debt


LENGTH: 600 words


 
The Monitor(Kampala)
October 4, 1995
by Hassan Badru ZZiwa
...Kampala - CAF boss, Issa Hayatou has assured FUFA that the new
twist in the Asec Mimosa vs SC Villa debt will be tackled in the next
CAF meeting on October 14 in Cairo and the final word will be given
then.

In Harare, during the All Africa Games, the CAF president told a
"New Vision" journalist that Uganda will be thrown out of CAF interMimosa. and according to Hayatou, FUFA had to pay all the US$ 90,000
clubs competitions unless they paid all the monies owed to Asec
agreed on originally.

FUFA chairman Twaha Kakaire confirmed yesterday that FUFA had
received the message through Dr. James Sekagugo who was requested by
FUFA to contact Hayatou currently in Cameroon to find out the
official CAF stand on the debt. 

This will probably end the misunderstanding between FUFA and CAF
of how much FUFA still has to pay Asec Mimosa. Originally, a flat
figure of US$ 90,000(UShs 90m) was presented to Uganda as the cost of
SC Villa's failure to honour the return leg match, but after friendly
negotiations between former FUFA boss Moses Ali and soccer officials
from Cote d'Ivoire, the fine was reduced to US $60,000(UShs 60m) and
the last installment of US$ 4,500 was paid September 25, at least
according to a release by Peter Wasula last night at Nakivubo
Stadium.

Yesterday, Peter Wasula the man responsible for the collection and
remittance of the Asec debt funds said he had so far remitted $60,000
(Sh 60.m)beating the October 10, deadline.

Uganda's High Commissioner to London, Professor George B. Kirya,
has meanwhile also contacted the Ivorian government over the matter--
and his opposite number in the UK has promised action as soon as
possible.

Meanwhile, Posta and Kobs coach Asuman Lubowa has been picked to
participate in the fourth coming FIFA(CAF elite coaching course,
October 14 in Cairo, Egypt.
...According to FUFA General Secretary Chris Rwanika, Lubowa was
picked because he is the national youth coach. "We have already
received his ticket from CAF," he said.

The course will run from October 14-20.

What FUFA did not say is who will take over the Uganda Kobs from
Asuman Lubowa when the team resume training for the East and Central
African Senior Challenge Cup due next month.

"We have not yet decided, but we shall sit and find a solution,"
Rwanika told "The Monitor" yesterday.

177 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Comores Mercenery Denard's Overwhelming Self-belief


LENGTH: 1347 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Samantha Weinberg

JOHANNESBURG - When "Colonel" Bob Denard rose from the ashes of
his mercenary career, bolder and ballsier than ever, he raised a
finger in the air to the French judicial system, political pundits
and keepers of the "new world order". With Africa marching -- albeit
shakily -- towards democracy, he retook a country, captured a
president and installed in his place a military junta.

The timing may have been unexpected, but the coup itself was not.
When I last met Bob Denard, in a Paris hotel the day after he had
been given a five- year suspended sentence for his role in a failed
coup attempt in Benin in 1977, he was full of confidence. There had
been another coup in the Comoros, he informed me, led by the twin
sons of former president Abdallah, and foiled by the Comorian army
and their French military advisers. The Abdallahs had been imprisoned
along with prominent former ministers, and the populace was up in
arms. "Ask the people of the Comoros what they think of me now," he
bellowed. "Don't you think they would like the Colonel back now?" 

Denard's continued existence as a mercenary leader has always owed
more to immense self-confidence than to military prowess. His career
is littered with the corpses of failed coups: the 1977 Benin
debacle, when a hurried retreat resulted in cases of documents
detailing plans for the action being left on the runway, and a comic
attempt soon after to invade Zaire with a hundred men on bicycles.
Yet the mercenaries -- typically army and society drop- outs, often
brutal and ill-educated -- kept signing up to join him. And so the
myth of his power grew, until he believed it himself, absolutely.

The Comoros had been his first great success. In 1975, he toppled
the new president, Ahmed Abdallah, and replaced him with a young
revolutionary, Ali Soilih. Three years later, Soilih was acting in an
increasingly erratic fashion -- he had sacked the civil service,
burnt all records and turned the running of the country over to
teenagers with guns. On being warned by his favourite witchdoctor
that he would be killed by a white man with a black dog, he promptly
ordered the slaughter of all dogs on the islands. The medicine man's
prophecy turned out to be true: On May 13 1978, Denard, accompanied
by 46 men and a black alsatian dog, stormed the islands at dawn,
killing Soilih "as he tried to escape".

With Abdallah back in power and dependent on Denard and his force
to keep him there, the "Colonel" relaxed. He married a local beauty
(his sixth wife), built a number of homes and developed a paunch.
Pretoria provided the finance for the mercenary-led Presidential
Guard -- and in return, it seems most likely, used the Comoros as an
entrepot for the smuggling of arms to Iran. The old Dog of War was
content, and it was his intention to stay on his island paradise for
the rest of his days.

President Abdallah, however, under pressure from the French and
local grandees -- and with the spectre of a withdrawal of South
African support under a new regime looming large -- had other ideas.
One evening in November1989, after he told Denard that he had to
leave, the president was shot in an "attempted coup". The mercenaries
cooked up an implausible story, but local people placed the blame
firmly at the feet of their now-hated foreign interlopers. A French
navy flotilla was sent in from nearby Mayotte (the fourth Comoro
island, which elected to stay French) and Denard and his men left
their fiefdom in a South African army plane.

I first met him two years into his forced exile. He limped into a
fashionable Johannesburg Japanese restaurant, conservatively dressed
and looking for all the world like a diplomat or captain of industry
-- a far cry from the young Bordelais peasant boy who had lied his
way into the French navy. It was only when he lowered his heavysense the force of his personality.
framed spectacles to reveal piercing turquoise eyes that I could

Despite the fact he knew I had spent the previous months on the
islands researching the events surrounding Abdallah's "mysterious
death", he insisted that his verdict of accidental death was the
correct one. He honestly believed he could convince me, purely
through personal charm and power.

His house in Pretoria was comfortable, but in no way ostentatious,
and he always acted with perfect propriety. It soon became clear,
however, that he was desperate to return to France.

He did so on February 1 1993, to stand trial for Benin. In what
was undoubtedly a pre-arranged deal -- and basking in the praise of
assorted generals -- Denard received his five-year suspended sentence
and went to live in Bordeaux, near several of his seven wives (only
one divorced).

He founded a security company. The introduction letter he sent to
prospective clients began: "When a man's name merges with history it
naturally leaves an echo in his contemporaries' mind ..." Clearly
"the legend's" self-belief had not dimmed.

Still, the audacity of his latest coup is astounding. Either he is
severely deluded, or has decided to die on his beloved "perfume
isles" -- probably a bit of both.

Despite the best efforts of conspiracy theorists, it is most
likely that the funding for the coup came from Comorian opposition
politicians -- not from South Africa or France as has been suggested.
For France signed an agreement underwriting the security of the
Comoros, a deal it is now honouring.

And Paris won't want Denard. He still has stories to tell, of his
days as a quasi-secret service operative. It was to silence these
tales that the suspended sentence deal was struck. The Comoros cannot
survive in an international vacuum -- they rely heavily on foreign
aid -- and what other African country will offer Denard sanctuary?

My guess is that Denard, 66, has waged his last campaign, closing
for good the chapter of major mercenary intervention in Africa. But
that has been said before -- and the phoenix is still there and
flapping his wings.

Samantha Weinberg is the author of Last of the Pirates: The Search
for Bob Denard (Cape).


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October, 1995


Comores Cocktails and Kalashnikovs In Coup-Coup Land


LENGTH: 2080 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Eddie Koch

JOHANNESBURG - The suntanned tourists who arrived back at
Johannesburg International Airport on Saturday, airlifted out of a
Comoros holiday extended courtesy of Colonel Bob Denard and his band
of embattled mercenaries, highlighted a central theme of Pretoria's
relations with the troubled archipelago. Many of them told
television reporters how they sipped cocktails on the beach without
realising people were being shot in a mini-war 20km away.

While South African tourists and businessmen treat the place as a
playground for pleasure, they are reluctant to recognise -- either
through naivete or a hedonistic urge not to have their fun spoilt --
that wretched economic conditions combined with byzantine political
infighting have turned the stormy islands into what one recent
account calls cloud coup-coup land.

That the Comoros suffer from chronic economic and political
instability was shown in Denard's latest attempt to install a shadow
government that would allow his force of mercenaries to rule in the
island's background. After toppling the government of President Sa-d
Mohamed Djohar last Thursday, Denard tried to avert French military
intervention by rapidly handing nominal power over to an interim
government led by a trio of civilian leaders -- Sa-d Ali Kemal,
Mohamed Taki Abdoulkarim and Omar Tamou. 

But, within 24-hours of being appointed, the new government
disintegrated as the three co-presidents squabbled over whether
Denard be allowed to stay on as a citizen of the Comoros. Kemal and
Abdoulkarim said they wanted him, while Tamou, secretary general of
the powerful Udzima party, insisted Denard and the other mercenaries
should get out and let Comorians decide their own future. The result?
A meeting of political parties, called to cement Denard's new
civilian government, dispersed in comic chaos -- and opened the way
for this week's invasion by French special forces.

A crack commando of 600 French troops ended the dramatic week by
storming the island on Wednesday morning. By early yesterday,
Africa's most famous mercenary had released the president and holed
up in a makeshift barracks, trying to negotiate an "honourable"
surrender for his men. The French commanders insisted, however, they
were not there to do a deal with Denard.

If South Africans are naive about the stormy politics of the
Comoros, Denard should at least have had the foresight to realise
that the internecine nature of the island's ruling elites would undo
his latest effort to become king. In an interview with author
Samantha Weinberg -- conducted after he was exiled to Pretoria in the
wake of the 1992 assassination of Comorian President Ahmed Abdallah
-- the Frenchman justified his series of armed incursions by saying
the staunchly Islamic islands have always had more mercenaries and
putsches than priests.

The self-imposed truth of his statement shows in a brief
chronology of coups that have rocked the islands over the last two
decades:

* August 1975. President Ahmed Abdallah is deposed in a coup
after winning the country's first elections three years earlier.
Denard's mercenaries install a young populist leader called Ali
Soilih as president. Denard leaves the islands for three years to
embark on other African adventures.

* May 1978. Denard and a 30-strong commando overthrow Soilih --
who, in the intervening years, imposed a rigid form of socialism on
the islands and tried to smash their traditional Islamic strucuture.
They restore Abdallah to power and Denard effectively rules the
islands by turning his dogs of war into a Garde Presidentielle that
becomes the military, and economic, power behind the throne.

* March 1985. Comorian members of the Presidential Guard stage a
mutiny against their white mercenary commanders. The presence of the
mercenaries -- and accusations that they were plundering the
island's coffers -- leads to another bungled coup attempt in November
1987. Both uprisings are brutally supressed on Denard's orders.

* November 1989. President Abdallah is shot dead during a heated
argument with Denard and a mercenary colleague called Commandant
Marques, after the president comes under strong pressure from France
and South Africa, now led by reformist President FW De Klerk, to get
rid of the mercenaries.

Denard is widely believed to be the assassin, but claims the
president was accidentally shot by one of his own aides -- who was
panicking because the Comoros armed forces were busy staging a coup
of their own! The murder, still unresolved, leads to Denard being
forced into exile. Djohar is elected as president.

Those who believed that the departure of the modern-day pirates
would bring stability to the Comoros were soon to be disappointed.
Djohar almost immediately reverted to the traditional style of ruling
the islands through a complicated system of patronage which revolved
around constantly shifting alliances with the Islamic sultans and
ruling families who control the archipelago and much of its ailing
economy.

Since coming to power in 1989, Djohar's government has been
constantly plagued by allegations that members of his family have
their fingers in the state's coffers while civil servants and
civilians have to endure one of the world's poorest economies. The
islands have a tiny manufacturing sector based on the export of
vanilla, cloves and a plant called ylang ylang, which is used to make
French perfume. But 80 percent of the islanders are employed in
subsistence farming or stagnating cash crop estates and, on top of
that, an austerity programme designed by the International Monetary
Fund and France has caused serious distress for most Comorians.

These tensions came to a head in the months leading up to Denard's
latest coup last week -- and provided the French mercenary with the
pretext he needed to stage what now looks to be his last adventure
in Africa. In July, a crisis was sparked in Djohar's cabinet by
allegations that a deal involving the proposed privatisation of Air
Comores and its merger with a company based in the United Arab
Emirates was riddled with corruption. The president responded by
sacking three of his strongest critics from the cabinet and replacing
them with loyalists.

This was preceded by an expose, published in the Indian Ocean
newsletter in May this year, that Djohar's government had signed a
deal with German and Austrian companies to build a dump for
processing toxic waste from industrial countries. And, to make
matters worse, Comorians were treated to the spectacle of Djohar's
two sons-in-law squabbling with each other over control of the toxic
waste and airline deals: Mohamed Sa-d Mchangama versus Mohamed Sa-d
Sagaf versus Mohamed Sa-d Djohar.

While these fratricidal struggles were undermining the government,
Prime Minister Mohamed Caabi el Yachroutu warned of impending
economic disaster. In a June speech to parliament, he pointed out
that state revenue in the first five months of 1995 had fallen short
of budget forecasts and that $3,2- million had to be saved by the end
of the year. Salaries of government ministers and civil servants were
slashed and massive tax levies imposed on all government and
parastatal workers -- by far the largest segment of the formal labour
force in an archipelago wracked by unemployment.

Not surprisingly, Denard's latest coup was preceded by strikes and
demonstrations in the streets of the island's capital, Moroni, and
followed by reports that a large percentage of the population danced
with jubilation in the same streets when the mercenary force landed.

France's airborne invasion of the stormy isles this week will, no
doubt, be followed by the rapid reinstatement of Djohar and his prime
minister. France will continue to provide a lifeline in the form of
$17-million each year in development aid. And tourists will soon be
able to visit Le Galawa again and return with tales about their
idyllic holiday in cloud coup-coup land.

Meanwhile, the options for France's dog of war have narrowed
dramatically. It looks as though his prediction, made to reporters in
Moroni this week, that he will spend many of his remaining years in a
French jail, will come true. When French troops last chased Denard
out the Comoros, in 1989, the colonel was able to ensure that he and
his men were flown in a South African Air Force Dakota to Pretoria,
where Denard lived in a house supplied by the South African
government.

The favours from Pretoria were designed to buy his silence. When
Denard ruled the islands in the 1980s, he allowed South Africa's
military intelligence to build a listening post to monitor strategic
naval traffic and the ANC's training camps in nearby Tanzania.
Weapons from South Africa were smuggled to right-wing Renamo rebels
from the Comoros and there are reports that the islands were used as
a refuelling point for South African cargo planes ferrying arms from
Armscor to Iraq before the Gulf War.

But there is now a new government in South Africa and the French
are clearly weary of the colonel's antics. French military officers
pointed out this week that Denard was under a five-year suspended
sentence for his role in the 1977 Benin coup and, this time, he has
little chance of staying out of jail.

All of this offers little hope for an end to the persistent state
of political crisis which periodically punctures -- as it did in the
last fortnight -- the South African romance that the Comoros are a
place of perfume and happiness.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996

Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Rural Folk Suffer Worst Health Conditions


LENGTH: 654 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Hazel Friedman

JOHANNESBURG - Two-thirds of South Africa's black population are
subject to poor health conditions. This is among the startling
findings of South Africa's first national household health survey.

A 200-page report, released by the Community Agency for Social
Enquiry (Case) on behalf of the Kaiser Foundation this week,
sketches an appalling picture of continued racial imbalance in the
conditions that make for healthy living. The list goes on: 80
percent of African households have no tap indoors, 16 percent have
no toilet of any kind and nearly 60 percent are without electricity,
while 67 percent live below the poverty line. 

The report, based on the scientific sampling of 4 000 households
across the country, concludes that black South Africans,
particularly those from rural areas, are worse off in every aspect
of their lives compared to other segments of the population.

This inevitably makes them more prone to ill health and povertyaccess to health services, because of the cost of health care and
related diseases. Yet they have the greatest difficulty in getting
excessive distances.

The principal victims of this imbalance are African children
under the age of five, of which 75 percent live in rural ares. Of
these, 76 percent live in households with incomes below the poverty
line, and 23 percent of families are too poor to properly feed
their pre-school children.

But the survey's prognosis for health care in South Africa is not
entirely bleak. Divided into three components, it presents health
reforms in an historical context, describes the critical elements
needed to transform health care in South Africa, and offers a
research and implementation agenda geared towards shifting the
emphasis of health care from a curative approach towards a primary
health care system based on the principle of equal health care for
all.

The obvious conclusion is that the government's primary school
feeding programme is not reaching a substantial number of chidren
from rural households living below the minimum level.

>From the start of this mammoth undertaking in June 1994,
research was hampered by a lack of demographic data and by the fact
that over 65% of African births are unregistered, throwing the
accuracy of any research into health-related issues seriously into
qestion.

Despite these problems, the survey has succeeded in providing a
barometer for measuring the impact of improvements in health and
health services for South Africans in the future. It also gives a
comprehensive analysis of policy developments in the health sector
and attempts to formulate a research agenda towards addressing and
clarifying unclear policy issues.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


180 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Economic Forecasts Signify Bond Rate Decline


LENGTH: 800 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Simon Segal

JOHANNESBURG - Encouraged by declines in the inflation rate and
money supply growth, economists are increasingly changing their
forecasts and talking about the next movement in the Reserve Bank's
(RB) interest rates being down rather than up. This will herald a
decline in the prime and bond rates for the first time since
November 1993. Any action, however, is only likely well into next
year. 

Until recently the consensus among economists was that the RB's
rates had further to rise. Some were expecting that prime rate, now
18,5 percent would exceed 20 percent by year-end.

The bond market too is indicating a rate fall -- rates on the
long-end (maturing in 10 years' time) dropped to around 15 percent
this week, their lowest level in over a year.

Such optimism is fuelled by August money supply figures and
September's inflation rate. Government is also ahead in its funding
targets for this fiscal year which means government supply of paper
is short of institutional demand, hence pressure on bond prices to
rise and rates to fall.

The rate of increase in M3 money supply slowed to 14,84 percent
compared to 15,82 percent the previous month. The inflation rate
dropped to 7,5 percent compared to July's nine percent. An
inflation rate falling to five percent, mentioned by RB Governor
Chris Stals, now does not appear such a starry-eyed idea. Most
economists are still, however, looking at inflation averaging nine
to10 percent this year.

An inflation rate of 7,5 percent and a prime rate of 18,5 percent
leaves the real (inflation adjusted) prime rate at 11 percent. Many
economists are critical that this is too high compared to most
economies and especially punitive when South Africa's development
and growth needs are taken into account.

Real short-term money market rates are 6,95 percent in South
Africa, compared to 2,6 percent in Malaysia, 22 percent in Brazil,
and a negative 4,55 percent in Mexico.

From this sample of developing economies' real interest rates,
one can take a pick to suit an argument. The RB, however, will
remain cautious about relaxing its monetary policy too soon.

Firstly, the deficit on the current account of the balance of
payments is running at some R1-billion a month. So far this is
being more than offset by net capital inflows, hence the improvement
in the RB's reserves from R7,8-billion in August 1994 to R11,9and unpredictable. At R11,9-billion, South Africa's reserves are
billion in August 1995. But short-term capital inflows are volatile
still only worth 1,3 months' worth of imports.

Secondly, with growing social and political pressures to deliver
more on reconstruction and development there are still doubts about
government's commitment to fiscal restraint. The deficit before
borrowing is still five to six percent of the gross domestic product
(GDP).

Most economists agree that monetary policy still has to be
tighter than it would otherwise need to be were fiscal policy
tighter -- whether rates have to be as high is disputed.

Thirdly, there is a danger that the declining inflation and money
supply figures are statistically deceptive as they are off high
bases. When they come off lower bases, as they will be next year
after the present declines, further drops become increasingly
difficult.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Racial Tension Links SA and OJ


LENGTH: 1387 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Justin Pearce

JOHANNESBURG - Could South Africa have its own version of the OJ
Simpson trial? The tensions that shifted the focus of the Simpson
case from murder to racism are equally present in South Africa. And
like the United States, South Africa has a justice system where much
depends on the quality and credibility of evidence, and the relative
skill of prosecution and defence.

Several South African lawyers have noted that the justice system
here is no better able than its American counterpart to accommodate
the racial tensions that pervade both societies. One lawyer pointed
out in an interview this week that the only thing that stops South
African trials from turning into racial flashpoints was the fact that
in this country, court proceedings do not receive the same level of
media attention as the Simpson trial. 

In South Africa, sub judice legislation outlaws the kind of
rampant speculation that took place around the Simpson case, and the
idea of an accused publishing a book to profess his innocence while
the trial is in progress -- as Simpson did -- is out of the question.
It is highly unlikely that South Africa's largely conservative
judiciary will condone the presence of television cameras in
courtrooms in the forseeable future.

The relevance of the Simpson trial to South Africa has been noted
by South Africa's Black Lawyers' Association (BLA), which welcomed
the Simpson verdict as "a very strong signal to racist police
officers that decent ordinary human beings will not rely on the
evidence of such people to convict others".

The BLA statement echoes the line of argument adopted by Simpson's
defendants, who rather than contesting the forensic evidence against
Simpson, focused on the contention that the prosecution's evidence
was racially tainted. The revelation of police racism struck chords
with America's black community, and caused public opinion about the
Simpson case to be split along racial lines: according to polls, 80
percent of black Americans were convinced of Simpson's innocence, and
a similar proportion of whites believed him to be guilty.

In South Africa, race was invoked by supporters of Winnie Mandela
during her trial on kidnapping charges in 1991. A key theme in
Mandela's defence was the accusation that the minister from whose
home the kidnap victims had been removed had been sexually abusing
the boys -- and Mandela's supporters responded with placards reading
"homosexuality is not in black culture".

Racial polarisation was more obvious in Zimbabwe, during the trial
of anaethetist Dr Richard McGown, who was charged with causing the
deaths of black patients through negligence. The trial prompted angry
protests outside the court by demonstrators who saw the deaths as
tantamount to genocide.

Such cases are likely to become more common in South Africa unless
urgent steps are taken to change the situation whereby the majority
of trials involve a white judge passing sentence on a black accused.

The BLA said the result of the Simpson trial demonstrated that
South African justice would be well served by the reintroduction of
juries to redress the racial imbalances in the administration of
justice. But Etienne Mureinik, professor of law at the University of
the Witwatersrand, said a jury system was not ideal. In South Africa,
the jury system was phased out in the 1960s, and while it was still
in place jurors were invariably white. The introduction of a nonas a possible means of making the justice system more accesible. The
racial jury system for South Africa was discussed in the early 1990s
idea lost favour, however, owing to the often arbitrary nature of
jury decisions, and the fact that a representative South African jury
could well be hampered by the lack of a common language.

Rather than reintroduce juries, the Justice Department has since
last year's elections made a concerted effort to increase the number
of black and woman judges on South African benches. However, it is
clear that there are not yet enough suitably qualified black lawyers
to enable the benches to become fully representative of South African
society.

But while in Simpson's case police racism may have ended up
playing into the hands of the defence, in many cases the judicial
system is not sufficient to bring police malpractice to light.

University of the Western Cape senior law lecturer Pierre de Vos
points out that Simpson's acquittal had a lot to do with the skill of
his top defence lawyers, without whom the bungling of the Los Angeles
police might have gone unnoticed. Both in the United States and in
South Africa, black accused are likely to be reliant on pro deo
lawyers. A study conducted by the University of Cape Town before the
abolition of the death penalty showed that accused who could not
afford their own defence were more likely to be convicted, and more
likely to be sentenced to death, than accused who had engaged the
services of a defence lawyer.

"The police make mistakes," De Vos remarked, "but usually they
don't get caught."

And while the police may have been damned by their own racism,
Simpson's acquittal in the face of compelling forensic evidence
points to a prosecution which was left lagging behind by a brilliant
defence. This too has sobering lessons for South Africa, where the
prosecution system is struggling. As state expenditure is cut back,
prosecution will become an even less promising career option for a
law graduate.

The role of the prosecutor is equally crucial in South Africa and
the United States: in both countries, a judge is an arbitrator who
weighs up the merits of the opposing arguments -- which allows the
emphasis of a trial to shift towards an assessment of the validity of
evidence. De Vos contrasted this to the system used in continental
Europe, where judges have greater powers to investigate the case as
they see fit.

One South African judge, welcoming the Simpson judgment as "a
triumph of anti-racism", expressed frustration at the inadequacy of
the material which judges have to work with: "The lesson is that a
new situation needs new methods of investigation -- methods that are
lacking even in a technologically advanced society such as the United
States."


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Depositors Struggling To Save Bank


LENGTH: 427 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Chilombo Mwondela

LUSAKA - Some depositors of Africa Commercial Bank are said to be
doing all they can to save the bank from collapsing through
additional deposits and provision of capital.

"The outstanding thing about ACB is its goodwill. Over ten years,
management has made a good investment in customer relations and this
might save it because there are suggestions that the shareholding be
distributed so that the public can buy shares and the bank would then
be recapitalised," said a Bank of Zambia (BOZ) source in an interview
last Thursday. 

And Post Newspapers accounts and administration manager Patrick
Musengwa added: "The bank tried its best for its customers under very
difficult circumstances and does deserve their compassion. For this
reason we have found it extremely difficult to close our accounts and
ditch the bank in its hour of need. But depositors have the difficult
task of trying to balance their desire to save the bank and risking
their funds in the event of the bank's total failure."

According to an ACB source, a number of companies are supporting
the bank by increasing deposits and taking up shares. The bank was
last week appointed agent of Western Union Financial Services
International to provide an instant money transfer service worldwide.
The bank, through Western Union's computerised network, sends and
receives money in minutes globally on behalf of business houses,
government institutions, international institutions and individuals.

But Bank of Zambia has remained silent over ACB's troubles and the
possibility of a reversal of fortunes. "Only the BOZ bank supervision
department can tell us the truth, but they do not want to give an
account to the public so there is nothing we can do but leave," a
depositor complained in an interview on Saturday.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Investment Firm Opts For Liquidation


LENGTH: 547 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Chilombo Mwondela

LUSAKA - Musa Siame's financially troubled Mutende Investments has
opted for voluntary liquidation to escape 'harassment' by
increasingly uncompromising creditors.

The group, which has been built and maintained by borrowings for
many years, has been failing to meet its obligations with many
creditors. Records at the Registrar of Companies have confirmed
Mutende Investments' voluntary liquidation intentions. 

An extract of a special resolution passed by members of Mutende
Investments Limited reads in part: "That it has been proved to the
satisfaction of this meeting that the company cannot by reason of its
liability continue business, and that it is advisable to wind up the
same and accordingly, that the company be wound up voluntarily."

But some creditors have asked the courts to stop the voluntary
liquidation which they feel is nothing but a scheme to enable Mutende
Group of companies escape liabilities and loss of all assets.

Leading the opposition to this voluntary liquidation is the
Development Bank of Zambia (DBZ). The bank had advanced Mutende US $1
million five years ago. And with the accelerated rise in interest
rates, the balance is now into billions of kwacha. DBZ has applied to
the High Court in Lusaka to stop the voluntary liquidation, claiming
that "the special resolution is not in good faith as Mutende
Investments Limited is the holding company of more than 12 companies,
which themselves are still in business".

"That the special resolution is aimed at evading debt to DBZ which
Mutende Investments Limited can easily, through itself and
subsidiaries, discharge. That Mutende Investments discharge forthwith
its debt to DBZ," read part of DBZ's application. And Mutende's
problems have also been compounded by the coming together of all its
creditors to form a united front for the recovery of their monies.
This Mutende Creditors Committee has appointed Rodgers Sombe to
represent their common interests.

And Sombe disclosed in an interview last week that Mutende
Investments owes over K8 billion to his clients. The debts of the
Mutende Group of companies with Africa Commercial Bank were claimed
by some financial analysts as a contributing factor to the bank's
liquidity problems. Mutende is reported to owe ACB, a bank in which
Siame has an interest, more than K2.4 billion (US $2.4 million).

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Copper Mine Abuse Annoys Donors


LENGTH: 760 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Chilombo Mwondela and Masautso Phiri

LUSAKA - Donors have complained of corruption and abuse of office
in the conduct of the affairs of ZCCM, and have warned that before
the mines company can be privatised the corruption will have to be
stamped out.

The donors expressed their concerns about the running of Zambia
Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) at a consultative meeting with
officials of the Zambian government held in Lusaka's Mulungushi
Conference Centre a fortnight ago. Both diplomatic and Zambian
government sources have confirmed that at the meeting British High
Commissioner to Zambia Patrick Nixon showed great concern about the
corrupt manner in which the affairs of the predominantly state-owned
mining conglomerate ZCCM were being conducted. 

The explanations by the company's chief executive, Edward
Shamutete, were said to have been rejected by the donors in
attendance as unsatisfactory. "I can confirm that the British High
Commissioner, Patrick Nixon, did express concern about the
performance and management of ZCCM. This was said in a private
meeting," said the High Commission's second secretary Russ Dixon in
reply to a Post press query on Monday, adding: "And we do not wish to
comment any further on this matter."

A Zambian government official said the High Commissioner did not
mince his words on the subject of corruption. "There were strong
words on corruption and abuse of office from the British High
Commissioner which were supported by most donor countries," a cabinet
source said in an interview a fortnight ago. "It seems donors are now
getting on to this very strongly."

But Shamutete declined to discuss the donor's ZCCM corruption
concerns. "The chief executive has a right to refuse to be
interviewed," said ZCCM spokesman Francis Musonda. The donors are
said to have raised questions about the apparent corrupt manner in
which some ZCCM subsidiaries and other assets are being cornered
without following the laid down privatisation procedures.

"Corruption too must be stamped out and we pointed to the way
Techpro Procurement and IPX in Johannesburg were closed as being
unacceptable," a diplomat said in an interview last week. "We told
them if ZCCM has to be privatised it must begin to operate
efficiently, like the Chilean mines." The consultative meeting is
said to have been attended by 25 officials from Zambian economic
units which included Minister of Finance Ronald Penza, commerce
minister Dipak Patel, deputy ministers Dan Pule and Mathias Mphande,
Bank of Zambia officials, ZCCM chief executive Shamutete, Valentine
Chitalu of the Zambia Privatisation Agency and some permanent
secretaries.

The donor countries in attendance were the United Kingdom, the
United States of America, the Federal Republic of Germany, the
Scandinavian countries and Saudi Arabia. And a source who attended
the meeting said Penza took most of the flack. "Most donors took it
out on Penza who was visibly annoyed about it but they told him that
he is a senior minister of this government and there is no-one else
they can talk to," he said.

"The donor countries had a common stand on the matter, they told
the government they would like to see some consistency in the running
of ZCCM and other institutions."

October, 1995


Zambia State Intimidates Post Journalists


LENGTH: 494 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by A Staff Reporter

LUSAKA - A Lusaka magistrate heard on Wednesday that the state was
intimidating Post journalists charged with criminally defaming
presidential press aide Richard Sakala.

Defence lawyer Sakwiba Sikota told Lusaka principal magistrate
Meebelo Kalima that on several occassions the court together with the
accussed have been subjected to intimidation when the complainant has
used State House stationary and letter heads in communications on
matters concerning the case. Sikota was replying to an application by
the prosecutor Katonga who wanted the court to rule on what he called
The Post's unfair coverage of the proceedings during the continued
trial of Post managing director and editor-in-chief Fred M'membe,
managing editor Bright Mwape, news editor

Goliath Mungonge and Chronicle reporter Nkonkomalimba Kafunda.
"There has been quite some intimidation coming from the state over
this case. We have tried to ignore the state manipulation which is
definitely orchestrated in an extremely shrewd manner,"=A0he told the
court. He made specific reference to a de facto order which Sakala
made last Saturday on State House letterheaded paper that the trial
"should only commence at 11:00 hours instead of the scheduled 09:30
hours because he had a presidential engagement". 

"These actions have made it clear that the complainant is a
superior one who should be accorded facilities different from others
together with special attention, " Sikota stated. Sikota also
revealed that he had suffered monetary losses arising from the
specialness of the witness and because of what he called a constant
barrage of belly aching complaints.

Kalima refused to grant an adjournment to the prosecution so that
they could reply to Sikota's submission saying "let us not be drawn
into potracted replies and delays, " and set the ruling for October
25, 1995. He however admitted that it would need "a lot of work and a
sober mind" before a ruling could be made considering a number of
important issues that were raised by the prosecution and defence. It
was the 24th adjournament of the case.

Zambia Court Attacks Deplored


LENGTH: 334 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Mukyla Nampito

LUSAKA - The Human Rights Committee of the Law Association of
Zambia (LAZ) has deplored recent attacks by civic education advocate
Lucy Sichone on the integrity of judges calling it a ploy calculated
to mislead the public on the role of judg-es in the administration of
justice.

Chairman of the committee Willie Mubanga said in a statement from
Ndola that the judiciary can only effectively discharge its duties of
dispensing justice if it is not subjected to ridicule, public odium
or disrespect. "The judiciary as the final arbiter in criminal and
civil disputes cannot publicly defend itself from such attacks. This
is also reco-gnised by the United Nations which has established
Special Rapporteur on the independence of the judiciary so as to
preserve the judicial independence and to protect judges,"=A0Mubanga
said in a press statement last week. Sichone had last month advised
judges whose rulings are found to be questionable to quit so that the
bench could maintain its role as the last line of defence for
citizens' human rights.

"What we need are men and women of integrity who will resign on
their own if their judgments are questioned substantially. So
basically we are talking about the integrity of the people on the
bench," Sichone said.

October, 1995


Zambia Barristers Differ Over Kaunda


LENGTH: 467 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Anthony Mukwita

LUSAKA - Calls by legal affairs minister Remmy Mushota to have
criminal proceedings instituted against former president Kenneth
Kaunda have been described as an act of vengeance.

Reacting to Mushota's statements in an interview on Tuesday, human
rights lawyer Roger Chongwe charged that Mushota was not a lawyer but
a politician who likes "throwing his weight around." Mushota said in
a press release last Sunday that: "We have evidence that Dr Kaunda
only renounced his Malawian citizenship on June 19, 1970. Since we
have discovered that he is not a Zambian but he entered high office,
he is liable for prosecution." But Chongwe said: "Mus- hota is just a
vengeful fellow and a bad lawyer. Lawyers are supposed to be
impartial and not take sides the way Mushota is disgracefully doing." 

Chongwe's sentiments were echoed by Foundation for Democratic
Process (FODEP) secretary and Church of God overseer John Mambo who
called the intended charges petty in an interview in Lusaka on
Tuesday. "Kaunda was president of this country for a long time. It
does not make sense to come up today and start accusing him of being
Malawian because this is setting a bad tradition of witch hunting, "
Mambo said. Mambo, who appreciated the fact that he had once been
victimised by Kaunda when he was branded Mozambican in 1990, asked
Mushota to be reasonable and not personalise things.

"Imagine what kind of a country this will be if everyone who
assumed power declared some people alien?" Mambo asked. And Labour
Party secretary general and former commissioner on the Constitutional
Review Commission, Azwell Banda, said it was sad that a whole
government seemed to be bent on destroying one man.

"I see a dangerous trend developing in the doubts being cast on
Kaunda's citizenship. This can give rise to forms of "ethnic
cleansing" which will create divisions in this country. If the
constitution fails to protect Kaunda, it gives him leave to take any
measures he will so decide to protect himself," Banda warned.

188 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Constitution Debate Turns Back Clock


LENGTH: 974 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Carolyn Mwanza

LUSAKA - Two events have generated a lot of debate over the past
two weeks. The first is the publication of the government white paper
on the Mwanakatwe Constitutional Review Commission released by
information minister Amusa Mwanamwambwa.

Most significant in the white paper are the government rejections.
Just to avoid the referendum the government has deliberately turned
back the clock to more than fifty years ago and thrown out all
advances in human rights and the concept of social conscience made by
the international community. When the cabinet objected to Rodger
Chongwe's proposal that a small technical committee should study
constitutional proposals to the Mvunga commission and work out
suggestions for inclusion, the reason it gave was that a commission
of inquiry would be better placed to provide a comprehensive report. 

Several billions of kwacha of taxpayer's money, time and effort
are wasted when President Chiluba and his cabinet reject the report
and tell Zambians there is nothing wrong with the 1991 constitution
after all. The government was just giving some people jobs to tour
the country obtaining views it had no intention to listen to because
all it wanted was to change clauses relating to presidential
candidates.

Debate on the constitution was stopped by the President until, we
were told, the government reaction to the Commission be published in
a white paper. The waiting has ended and the nation is left with the
government's rejections of the public view. The government is willing
to allow debate not of the constitution but of its reaction. To show
how democratic the government is both minister of legal affairs Remmy
Mushota and President Chiluba opened the debate by defending their
own reaction in the white paper. This is what brings out the second
event of the week - they released documents which showed that Kenneth
Kaunda was a foreigner.

According to Luminzu Shimaponda, later echoed by Mushota, the
documents later released to the press revealed that Kaunda ruled this
country for six years as a foreigner before he finally renounced his
Malawian citizenship.

What the government propaganda machine does not tell Zambians is
that the 1964 constitution gave citizenship to all British protected
persons who were in Northern Rhodesia on October 24, 1964 and
secondly that the 1964 constitution did allow for dual citizenship
and this situation did not change until 1969-70. The Zambian economy
at independence was dominated by whites. In 1968 the UNIP government
introduced economic reforms which attempted to give to black Zambians
the economic muscle. The Industrial Development Corporation (INDECO)
expanded its activities to acquiring companies and developing others.
What we take for granted today - in the form of trained manpower or
investment in parastatals - were all developed by the government
during this period.

Lest we forget at independence the only business Zambians dealt in
was tearooms and market stalls. No one today, not even President
Chiluba, can ignore the fact that Zambia is what it is today because
of what UNIP under Kaunda did for this country. There is no doubt
that the men and women who won independence for Zambia had a vision
and a commitment to develop this country.

This is not meant to be an apology for any mistakes they may have
made.

But these are heavily outweighed by their commitment to making
Zambia a country which was proud of itself. Turning back to the
constitution, in about 1970 the UNIP government under Kaunda
introduced an amendment to the Zambian constitution which in effect
removed dual citizenship.

Many Zambians of all colours who had any links with another
country through parentage or birth had to choose to be Zambian or not
to be Zambian. It is in this context that Kaunda renounced his
Malawian citizenship and in doing so he was merely expressing his
commitment to Zambia, the country he had founded with many other
compatriots.

It would be sad if 1995 politicians with no respect for history or
appreciation of what Zambia has achieved as a nation used all means,
including deliberate distortions and falsehoods, to hound a man who
has given so much to the country of his birth.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


189 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Constitution Should Not Be Used To Manipulate Politics


LENGTH: 1507 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Roland Kuchel

LUSAKA - The world economy is growing. Increased trade resulting
from increasingly integrated economies is driving this growth.

No country is immune from this integration and no country can
avoid it for long.

Look at the price of maize to see this link. A government's effort
to hold the domestic maize price below world levels results in
reduced plantings and reduced production domestically, and even
higher prices or larger subsides in following years. You can't beat
the market. But while a nation cannot avoid integration into the
world's economy, the benefits of integration are not automatic. The
output of an economy results from the application of scarce
resources, what economists call the factors of production: land,
labour and capital. 

A nation's land and labour resources are largely God-given. It is
the application of capital-investment, which makes land and labour
productive.Capital is scarce, and every nation's self-generated
supply is limited.

Capital seeks a return and avoids risks. The integration of the
world economy means all nations now compete for the same pool of
capital. Those nations successful in attracting capital - including
that of their own citizens - will prosper. The unsuccessful will
flounder. So what can a nation do to attract this capital? Getting
the macro-economic picture right is essential. Inflation and currency
depreciation are the nemesis of capital. While the economist may
suggest that a little is good for the economy, the businessman knows
'enough is too enough.' Successfully managing an economy is no easy
task.

A balanced budget, control of expenditures, adequate tax receipts
and provision of adequate and appropriate government services are all
essential.

Meeting these often conflicting goals requires the making of
choices, the setting of priorities where everything can not be the
highest priorities.

The macro-economic picture is never complete. It is always
becoming. It can only be heading in the right direction. Capital,
avoiding risks, responds to direction and consistency. Slippages,
particularly those that could be foreseen and were preventable are
anathema to capital flows. While there may be debate on how much
government involvement in the economy is needed, there is a
requirement that government provide a regulatory environment for the
conduct of business and investment. Customs, taxes, environmental
laws,transport and many other areas require government involvement to
establish a predictable framework and climate for business.

For investors, the questions include: How does this investment
climate compare with that of alternate investment locations? Is it
transparent?

Is it conducted on the basis of clear laws, rules and regulations?
How much bureaucratic and political discretion is available? Is it a
level playing field? The rule of law is essential to attract
sufficient capital to produce growth and development. The rule of law
demands fair, effective and consistence enforcement of law, rules and
regulations. Airlines cannot compete when the rules are waived for
one but not the other.

Manufacturers cannot compete when duty is charged to one but not
the other. Traders will not trade if the deep pockets of the
government are available to one but not the other. And investors will
not invest if the tax rules are changed in midstream.Perhaps the most
vexing question and unquantifiable risk facing the investor is that
associated with governance, the political system, the political risk.
The most basic requirement of a democratic system is to provide free
and fair elections in which all eligible citizens can vote.

For the investor, elections must be seen as free and fair so that
the government has the legitimacy and popular support necessary to
govern effectively.

Since political risk cannot be directly measured, indirect
indicators become critical factors in investment decisions.
Suggestions that basic constitutional issues are being used to
manipulate today's partisan political agenda raise concerns. If
government can manipulate the constitution then government can
manipulate the law to pillage an investment. Investors will look at
such countries as poor risks for business.

Africa has too many examples of countries with rich potential for
private investment, job creation and economic development, where
government practices scare off serious investors, leaving the field
to con-artists, money launderers and other criminals who always seem
able to make a fast buck on the backs of others.

Much as media resposibility often appears lacking, the investor
knows a country stands to lose more if media freedoms are eroded.
And, excessive concern and efforts to restrict media freedoms will be
perceived as a basic lack of trust by government in the fairness and
objectivity of its people. Another key political issue for any
investor is the role and actions of leaders themselves. Positions in
government must be seen as service to the nation, not as a key to
personal enrichment. Government needs the support of its people ever
more so when it asks them for sacrifice. Leaders must set the
example. It is important to note that no country is immune from
restructuring.

Articulating a programme and staying the course are key. New
investment will respond but only with assurance - and a track record
- that dying industries won't be propped up, that government will
stay the course, that the process will be transparent, and that good
governance will ensure all members of society participate in the
resulting growth and development. Zambia has courageously embarked on
a truly revolutionary course to transform political and economic
structure. It has made great strides in creating the macro-economic
environment and instituting the reforms of its economy and government
needed to promote business and growth. It has expanded the dimensions
of democracy, be it in multiparty political life, freedom of
expression or toleration of NGOs and other civil institutions.

Transforming a society is extremely difficult. It needs the
support of everyone of good will, Zambians and foreigners alike. In a
time of political and economic change and transformation, every
decision is potentially momentous in character. In Zambia, one senses
that one is always on the verge of a momentous step forward or a
potentially crippling step.
I am certain that with the good will and participation of all of its
citizens, Zambia will move forward on the path of necessary reforms.
If it maintains its commitments and stays the course, business and
investment will surely follow.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


190 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Lawyers Need To Be Qualified To Practice


LENGTH: 547 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by The Jury

LUSAKA - Ever since the O.J. Simpson trial a number of people have
been asking me what it takes to be a lawyer. In some places like
Ethiopia the situation is much like in England during the formative
years of the profession. In Ethopia all one needs is to have the
bravery to stand before the court to argue someone's case. One does
not have to pass or sit for any examinations. 

Guidelines: The International Bar Association has set up the
following guidelines for the entry into the legal professional and
legal education 1. Every person having the necessary qualifications
in law shall be entitled to become a lawyer and to continue in
practice without discrimination. 2. Legal education shall be open to
all persons with requisite qualifications and no one shall be denied
such an opportunity by reason of race, colour, sex, religion,
political or other opinion, national or social origin, property,
birth, status or physical disability. 3. Legal education shall be
designed to promote knowledge and understanding of the role and the
skills required in practising as a lawyer, including awareness of the
legal and ethical duties for a lawyer and of the human rights and
fundamental freedoms recognized within the given jurisdiction and by
international law. 4. Programmes of legal education shall have regard
to the social responsibilities of the lawyer, including cooperation
in providing legal services to the needy and the promotion and
defence of legal rights of whatever nature whether economic social,
cultural, civil and political and especially rights of such nature in
the process of development.

In Zambia the necessary qualification is to have passed the Legal
Practitioners Qualifying Examinations set by the Council Of Legal
Education. Equivalent Enrolment to the Law Practice Institute is upon
the Council being satisfied that the applicant possesses an LLB
degree or its equivalent. Upon being called to the Bar one has a
right to act as an advocate in Zambia.

The course and examinations at the Law Practice Institute are
notoriously difficult to ensure that only high calibre lawyers make
it through. Passing the exam is not the end of the story and there is
a constant need for continuing legal education.

In some jurisdictions it is compulsory and it is high time it also
became compulsory in Zambia.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


191 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Next By-Elections a Challenge to NP


LENGTH: 787 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Elias Nyakutemba

LUSAKA - And so it came to pass that the National Party (NP)
failed to win even a single seat in the last round of eight
parliamentary by-elections.

The United National Independence Party (UNIP), however, cheered
the whole opposition by grabbing three seats from the ruling Movement
for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) in what, originally, was thought to be
the MMD's political heartland, Mpulungu, Mkushi and Mbala
constituencies. And nobody seems much bothered about the NP's loss. 
It appears as if it was expected.

But the next round of by-elections on October 10 are being viewed
differently and are more crucial to the NP's overall political
credibility as a third force. In focus now is the Kabompo West seat,
vacated by Matthews Makayi, an Enoch Kavindele protege for years, who
crossed over to the MMD and has flung himself back into the race.
With Kavindele's full weight right behind him, Makayi is no pushover,
even though nine out of every 10 people I met around the township
(Boma) seem to think he has switched "to the wrong camp, just like
Kavindele when he abandoned the UDP".

For NP president Humphrey Mulemba the race could enhance or undo
his much acclaimed reputation as an expert grassroots party
organiser, or perhaps prove that he is in control of things in Northfigure.
Western Province as its regional political heavy-weight and fatherwith the government's failure to tar the Chavuma-Mutanda road despite

Almost certainly the NP will stand on a platform of real issues is the failed crop marketing strategy, declining living standards and
a load of pre-election promises emerging most prominently. Then there
President Chiluba's failure to give the Luvale people cabinet
representation. NP candidate Benjamin Chipango remains a popular
figure, having served as MP and governor for 10 years under Kaunda
and UNIP whom he ditched earlier this year. And he is widely regarded
as a unifying figure among the seven dialects spoken in the district.
But he cannot dismiss UNIP's candidate Maliti, nor Makayi of the MMD,
whose resources seem to be limitless, even though a local song there
already dismiss electoral bribes as 'gifts for us, but no vote for
you'. Jack Chikwenda, the MMD Independent candidate, is yet another
hopeful for the NP.

But as things stand with MMD, some Kabompo political analysts
believe Chikwenda may soon be forced to fall out of the race to avoid
splitting the MMD vote count further. Most crucial too is the fact
that all the candidates are from the Luchazi-speaking clan, a subZambezi districts, followed by Lunda speakers who are more pronounced
cluster of the Luvale web of dialects which dominates Kabompo and
in the eastern parts of Kabompo.

Traditionally, a Lunda-Luvale (minus Luchazi) swing has always
been the decisive factor in winning any elections in the west. But
whether the NP will mobilise this vote effectively remains open to
debate. According to observers in Kabompo, the MMD is more likely to
rely on Kavindele's immense influence in most Luchazi-speaking areas
and, not surprisingly, on whipping up emotions on such trivialities
as the need to teach Luchazi in schools or to be made the eighth
language on radio.

Whatever happens, it is clear that none of the candidates will
find it easy to win a majority vote in a region already fraught with
abject poverty, disease and hunger, but which still clings to a
rather hazy hope for prosperity and decency.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Politicians and Promises


LENGTH: 507 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Wajid Patel

LUSAKA - Whenever there are elections, aspiring politicians go out
and make a lot of promises to the people. During such times
politicians are usually available to the electorate. Those with any
questions are usually afforded time to pose them and wherever
possible answers are provided. 

During campaigns candidates are generally believed to be free
spenders, and those around them are usually lucky enough to find a
few kwachas in their pockets.

The candidates are quick to remind all who care to listen that the
people are the masters while the politicians are servants. They give
the impression that as far as they are concerned their aim and
purpose in life is work for their masters who are the voters. But
once elected, however, the whole picture quickly changes.

So drastic is the change that one is justified to ask whether
politicians are indeed servants of the people or the people servants
of the politicians. From the councillors to members of parliament
once elected all cease to consult the people. Their ideas become the
standards of what should be done in their communities.

Those who wish to carry any business venture in their areas have
to show they recognise the authority of their councillor.

As for MPs, the situation is even worse. Once elected the MPs,
save for very few, become very scarce in the areas they represent.
When issues affecting the people are about to be discussed such as
the land bill the MPs do not care to get the views of their
constituents. They become the embodiment of collective wisdom of
their constituents even if their remarkable attribute is dullness.

The situation becomes even more serious when individuals who form
the government make up their own mind. It appears the wishes of the
citizens just do not matter. Presently various sections of our
community including churches have said the new constitution be
adopted through a constituent assembly.

The government, who are the people's servants, have said no, and
their refusal will carry the day.Afterwards they will of course sit
back and say they are merely following the people's will.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


193 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia The Plagues of Corruption


LENGTH: 254 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995

LUSAKA - Concerns about corruption in the MMD started even before
the party got into government. Ephraim Chibwe, President Frederick
Chiluba's uncle and interim MMD treasurer, failed to produce audited
party accounts at the party's first convention in February 1991. 

To date the millions the party received from supporters and wellSince Chiluba took office in 1991 corruption accusations have come
wishers has not be accounted for. And Chibwe still remains protected.
both from within and outside the MMD and its government, but Chiluba
has not only continued to deny the existence of corruption in his
government but has also been permissive to it.

Chibwe is still to be prosecuted for alleged theft of public
funds. Health minister Michael Sata was saved from prosecution in
the name "of public interest".

We are glad the donors have finally realised that this dangerous
plague is not transitory and if it is not fought their aid and effort
will be wasted.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996

Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Courts Defended


LENGTH: 720 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995

LUSAKA - Last week's attacks on Zambia Civic Association
chairperson Lucy Sichone by the convenor of the Human Rights
Committee of the Law Association, Willie Mubanga, in defence of the
integrity of judges was hypocritical. It is difficult to be convinced
that Mubanga's main concern was the defence of the integrity of the
judges and not the bringing down of the standing of Sichone in the
eyes of the public.

Any person who has, without political prejudices, observed
Zambia's judicial processes since the Movement for Multiparty
Democracy assumed power in November 1991 will agree that the greatest
danger to the integrity of our judicial officers lurks in the
insidious encroachment on them of the top ranking members of our
executive. 

The attacks of the executive, especially President Frederick
Chiluba, on the judiciary have often been couched in seemingly well
meaning but dangerously manipulative complaints and 'enquiries' on
the performance of the courts on matters in which they have direct or
indirect interests - mainly of a political nature.

But Mubanga has not attacked these encroachments with the
viciousness that he unleashed on defenceless Sichone.

The conduct of some High Court and Supreme Courts judges and
magistrates also undermines the integrity of judicial officers in
general. It would be folly to think these can be left to the judicial
officers themselves to determine and resolve.

We should also be mindful that it is possible for some judicial
officers from the subordinate courts up to the Supreme Court to take
partisan positions in the manner they deal with cases and people
before them. Ask any lawyer or politician today in this country about
where each of our High Court and Supreme Court judges stand, they
will tell you those that are neutral, those that are pro-ruling MMD
and those that they think are sympathetic to former president Kenneth
Kaunda. Of course they won't have the courage to say so publicly. It
has to be in confidence.

Those who are MMD know the politics that were there in the
appointment of Chief Justice Matthew Ngulube as Chief Justice instead
of Bonaventure Bweupe purely on regional or tribal lines. All this
took place at a State House MMD caucus called for the purpose. Those
who are close to the 'inner' circles of the MMD know how a
'sympathetic' subordinate court official found his way to the High
Court. These are the matters that undermine the integrity of judges.
These are the practices that should be viciously fought by all those
who hold dear the ideals of an independent judiciary .

All Zambians, save for those with powers to manipulate, would like
to see practical steps taken to protect and enhance the independence
and integrity of our courts. If Mubanga and his colleagues want to be
seen as champions of judicial independence they have to convince us
they can attack the powerful men of our country who are daily
undermining the integrity of our courts. Taking on defenceless
Sichone is cowardice.

We challenge Mubanga to stick his teeth into the buttocks of the
real and dangerous enemies of the judiciary.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Fun Spoiled at Miss Zambia Contest


LENGTH: 534 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Sundie Sinkala

LUSAKA - Great fun at this year's Miss Zambia was spoiled by five
star Pamodzi Hotel's failure to live up to its expectations when it
could not cope with thousands of patrons who went to watch the
prestigious contest last Friday.

Rather than go by its motto of "you come as a guest and leave as a
friend", most of the night's guests left the place disgusted because
of the shoddy arrangements. Hundreds of thirsty throats thronged the
usually tranquil residents' lounge after both alcoholic and nonhotel's lawns near the swimming pool. As for the seating
alcoholic beverages ran out at the makeshift bars located in the
arrangements, many people stood throughout the four-hour plus
duration of the pageant. 

But resident manager Ranjiv Singh defended the hotel and
attributed the confusion to "disorganisation" on the part of the
organisers. "They told us to expect 1,200 guests but we have over
5,000 people here," an overwhelmed Singh said in an interview during
the confusion. Even the prohibitive price of K1,200 per Mosi bottle
and K2,500 per canned beer could not discourage customers from
waiting for over half an hour before their turn.

"I don't think I can stay here anymore, there are just too many
people. I have never seen such a scene in this hotel," said one
disappointed ex-Zambia National Service captain after failing to buy
his drinks. The situation deteriorated so much that the beverage
manager himself, Singh, had to come to serve customers, some of
whom were already shouting abuse at the management for their lack of
preparation.

One of the organisers defended his colleagues, saying there was
nothing wrong in having so many people at such a function. He said
Pamodzi was a five-star hotel which should have been able to cater
for such a crowd. In fact, he said, it was a good thing that more
people than expected attended the function.

The Miss Zambia crown was scooped by an 'O' level student
Mariyana Bujisic while the second prize went to Muleya Mwananyanda, a
former Post reporter, and the third prize to Annie McCall who works
at Polo Grill. The occasion was also graced by the presence of CBN
News anchor man Victor Oladukun as one of the panel judges.

Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Squad Coaches on Contract


LENGTH: 547 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 6, 1995
by Reuben Tonga

LUSAKA - ALL three assistant national team coaches have been given
four-month contracts in a bid to instill motivation into the
dispirited national squad. It is one of the Football Association of
Zambia's measures to make sure that the local coaches are not ignored
and are motivated ahead of the Africa Cup of Nations next year in
Johannesburg.

Ashios Melu, Fred Nasilele and veteran Boniface Simutowe are
expected to sign the contracts after next weekend's FAZ executive
meeting in Kabwe. "We decided that it was unfair for our local
coaches not to work on contracts, in the past only foreign coaches
were working on contracts but now we have decided that even our
coaches deserve contracts," explained FAZ chairman Simataa Simataa,
adding: "They will also be entitled to winning allowances for each
game just like Poulsen." The three assistants will be paid the whole
amount four months before they do any work with the national team. 

Simataa said the coaches will also be entitled to daily allowances
once they are in camp and the winning bonus for every game played.
Other details of the contract were not disclosed as they were
awaiting approval from the FAZ main committee. "As at now I can't say
how much money the coaches will be paid because we haven't decided as
an executive on that. But we will meet soon to decide how much to pay
them, I think it will give them a lot of encouragement ," says
Simataa. "We want them to go to the Africa Cup with a lot of
encouragement and try their best, if we don't appreciate their work,
then their morale could be down," said Simataa in an interview at the
FAZ offices in Lusaka on Tuesday.

Melu, one of the national team assistant trainers, welcomed the
idea of introducing contracts for local coaches attached to the
national team saying "it was long overdue" "I think we (coaches) must
now give credit where it is due, this is a well-timed move by this
new executive as it will give us job security and motivation. It's
now up to us to try our best ," said Melu in a telephone interview on
Tuesday. Coaches were previously only paid after every game and some
upkeep allowance during the preparation of any game.

"We only used to get very little money. On top of the salaries
paid for each game, we also used to get some up-keep allowances,"
explained Melu, "but I can't tell you how much our salaries were."
