Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Taking Cricket to the People


LENGTH: 960 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Jon Swift

Johannesburg - The United Cricket Board is taking the game to the
people, and not just South Africa's people but to other countries in
Africa as well.

There is a certain strangeness about the notion that international
cricket will be played at Paarl. In the recent South African
experience the Boland town is a place where top cyclists come from
and they have a big Boxing Day athletics meeting.

There is also something novel about the thought that this country
will be playing one-day internationals against Kenya. In recent
memory, that has been the home of Kilimanjaro and nothing much else
except some of the world's best coffee. 

But then, relying on the memeory of history since the Sixties is a
dangerous business in this country's truly remarkable transformation
and the thrust sport has added to the impetus of our changing
perceptions about one another.

It should not be a surprise that Boland have been awarded one of
the limited overs internationals during next year's tours by India
and Australia.

Not when the oft-stated policy of cricket's administrators is to
bring the game to the people.

And then there is the first Test against the English being played
in Pretoria of all places! Again, the more natural association is
with snorting forwards and kicking flyhalves.

But then Centurion Park is one of the most charming venues in the
South African game and has been voted a fine venue by both local
players and touring sides. It is also a fine venue from the
spectator's point of view. You are close to the action and there are
acres of grass to relax on.

There is the feeling that the air you are breathing is neither
bottled nor hemmed in by concrete.

The free-flowing spirit of the game lives at Centurion Park. All
that remains now is to lather the Poms within its green confines.

Adding to this emphasis on the game in Pretoria is the way the
United Cricket Board's Ali Bacher sees it. "We have to help promote a
Test culture, a cricket culture in the province," he says. And so, a
Test match.

Kenya is a different matter al-together, but equally heartening in
the examination. By agreeing to be part of a four-nation tournament,
which also includes India and Pakistan, the game in this country has
owned up to two important things.

First that we are truly African and justly proud of being part of
the promotion of the world's greatest game on the ineptly named Dark
Continent. And second that the traditional ties which kept the game
going in the years of apartheid, while still important, are no longer
the paramount factor.

The UCB is also eager to spread this intial net -- the
quadrangular tournament takes place next September-October -- to our
closer neighbours Zimbabwe and Namibia. This is an equally healthy
move towards real progress as the sporting citizens of the world we
have lately been re-instateed as.

"It is in South Africa's interests to try and help with the
promotion of the game of cricket in Namibia, Zimbabwe and Kenya,"
says Bacher. "If we can create strong structures in those regions it
will upgrade the standard of cricket on the continent." Just so.

The sooner the harsh edges of recent memories are softened by real
progress the better. Making inroads into Africa is a start, just as
is spreading the gate money of the big international matches as
widely as possible.

Hence the game at Paarl.

One senses that it is not beyond the bounds of reason to suggest
that this expansion will not end with our neighbours and the foray to
Kenya. This road, once travelled, could lead to such exotic
destinations as Dar es Salaam and Marrakesh.

And the widening of the international net from the traditional
Test centres can only have the effect of adding further bloom to the
development programme so firmly in place.

I await the five-day Test match in Soweto. For can it really be
that far away?


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


198 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Rugby Board Turns Pro AND Stays Amateur


LENGTH: 760 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Jon Swift

Johannesburg - Youcan't help feeling that the International Rugby
Board (IRB) has done yet again what history shows it to have done
best ... dither.

Certainly, the latest set of guidelines -- predictably, still to
be finalised -- issued by the august body following their meeting in
Tokyo does little to address the real issues of the new pay- for-play
era which must have some delegates weeping into their gin and tonics.

In essence, the IRB has opened the path to professionalism at all
levels. But they have kept a clause which protects countries "that
wish to remain amateur or are less wealthy than others". It looks
very much like a question of having your cake and eating it. 

Certainly, the irony of the guidelines being issued from Tokyo
cannot have escaped the IRB. The Japanese may have been, along with
the Ivory Coast, the whipping boys of the World Cup, but you only
have to look at the flood of All Blacks -- Ant Strachan, Arran Pene
and Jamie Joseph are among the latest -- who are on their way to the
land of the rising yen to know that there is big money in Japanese
rugby.

But it probably doesn't compare with the reported R12-million the
Brisbane Bulldogs offered Northern Transvaal's Springbok scrumhalf
Joost van der Westhuizen to switch to the 13-man game. Van der
Westhuizen turned it down, preferring to honour his contract with the
South African Rugby Football Union. A contract some R9,5-million shy
of the Australian offer.

It would seem that there is equally big money in this country.
But, regardless of the amounts on offer, the IRB has still not
grasped the nettle.

You are either professional or not. No high-minded and undoubtedly
well-intentioned words can change the fact that the game -- at
international and senior level, that is -- has changed for all time.

And yes, that will mean hardships for countries like Western Samoa
and Fiji. but then these rugby nations have served as feeder
countries for their more well-endowed neighbours, New Zealand and
Australia, for a number of years.

All, though, is not gloom and despondency although the flow of
players from the South Sea Islands to the well-paid teams in the
Antipodes will surely increase to a torrent.

One would suspect that we are likely to see more top Five Nations
players arriving for the Currie Cup season too. Especially in the
light of the French federation deciding on a complex system of partThe IRB has made the point that, while players are free to sell
time professionalism as their answer to the lure of the big buck.
their services to the highest bidder, the considerations of national
selection take preference. This seems like a statement which will be
a lot easier to legislate than enforce.

What they need to do is insert a clause in every player's contract
which binds the club, province or state he plays for to pick up that
player's wage bill while he is away on national duty. This would hold
especially for the wealthy nations the IRB has emphasised.

If they fail to do so, the possibility exists of any number of
injuries happening just prior to selection of, for instance, a
touring team which will be away for months on end and potentially
cost the player in question a great deal of money.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Wages Whip Workers Into Strike Action


LENGTH: 920 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Meshack Mabogoane

Johannesburg - Despite the recent nurses' and municipal workers'
strikes, this year's figures show industrial unrest to be at its
lowest in five years.

"The impression of industrial chaos is more a reaction to the
unusually low figures for the first half of this year and the high
profile nature of the strikes that have occurred during this
quarter," says labour analyst, Andrew Sparks of Andrew Levy and
Associates.

Compared to 1992, the peak strike year when more than threeindicate that only 870 000 man-days were lost. The average number of
million man-days were lost, the first three-quarters of this year
man- days lost over a five year period were 2,6-million. 

In the third quarter of this year about 775 000 man-days were lost
as compared to a five year average of 1,8-million man-days. The
third-quarter figures are of greater significance as this is the
period of wage negotiations when the unions show their muscle.

The low level of strike action this year can be attributed to
several factors. Politically- motivated and non-wage issue-based
strikes have become insignificant. Direct involvement of unions in
the anti-apartheid campaigns is something of the past.

The struggle for worker control on the shop floors has abated
largely due to deliberations that have led to the new Labour
Relations Act that would give workers powers within the work place,"
says Sparks. There is also the feeling that the levelling off of
strikes is due to a high degree of sophistication and experience by
both workers and management which has led to a better handling of
grievances, retrenchment procedures and less antagonism between the
negotiating parties.

Non-wage disputes account for only four percent of man-days lost
while strike action triggered by wages takes up to 93 percent. For
1995 this has been the most outstanding feature of industrial action.

For the first time public sector, and parastatal workers have been
at the forefront of wage-related strikes. In contrast to the private
sector actions were large and nationwide and continued for a
relatively longer period.

The lid has been lifted off these workers since the present
government, unlike the previous one, allows public servants to go on
strike.

Besides the relatively low wages that nurses, for example, have
been receiving, the restriction on public sector increases to less
than five percent has meant that they were getting below inflation
salary rises.

In contrast, private sector workers' increases have been settled
at 10 to 12 percent in keeping with inflation. Thus the disparity
between public and private sectors has widened -- leading to toyiOther major factors that helped trigger public sector strike
toying by public servants.
action have been greater expectations of the new government and the
poor state of the public sector industrial relations system.

The past restrictions on strike action by public servants is, of
course, the main cause of the latter. Nurses have not had a union and
the South African Nursing Association, a professional body, made a
top down settlement that was rejected. Calls have been made for
nurses to form a union.

And there are moves afoot to form a super public- sector union for
effective central bargaining. Sources expect the National Education,
Health and Allied Workers Union, Nehawu, and the South African
Municipal Workers Union, Samwu, to lead the way by forming a merger
in November. The Post and Telecommunications Workers Association,
Potwa, had indicated an interest in the umbrella union but is yet to
take the final step once its own struggles with the could- beSuch prospects could spell a difficult period ahead should issues,
restructured Telkom are resolved.
including wages, and public-sector industrial relations systems
remain unresolved.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Technology Gets Boost from U.S. Experience


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Karen Harverson

Johannesburg - South Africa has the opportunity to leap-frog ahead
using other countries' technology and experience to do things right
the first time.

"This country should take advantage of California's advances in
environmental issues, computers, communications and electronics,"
said California Trade and Commerce Secretary Julie Meier Wright,
speaking at the Made in the USA Expo at Gallagher Estate this week. 

With an economy of $887-billion, California is the seventh-largest
economy in the world. This week it became the first United States
state to open an office for trade and investment in South Africa.

Californian exports to South Africa reached about $240-million
last year. "While exports from South Africa have been very small in
the past -- we think it should be a two-way opportunity," said
Wright.

She said the state had been one of the first to support sanctions
and now wanted to be first in aiding South Africa's economic
recovery.

Minister of Trade and Industry Trevor Manuel said a significant
outcome of the rise to globalism was the increased relocation of
manufacturing and production plants to meet regional demands or to
service niche markets in remote parts of the world.

"What this means is that what is deemed as 'Made in the USA' can
be an original American idea now developed and produced in another
country for export to a specific region," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


201 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa France Throws A Lifeline To Film Industry


LENGTH: 574 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995
by Trevor Steele Taylor

Johannesburg - First steps have been taken towards a collaboration
which could be of resounding importance to South African film. At a
symposium in Johannesburg last weekend, organised by the French
Institute, plans were mooted for a film treaty between France and
South Africa which would provide South Africans with access to
European funding and distribution avenues.

The prime mover behind the initiative for official French/South
African co-productions is France's Centre National de la
Cinematographie (CNC), represented at the symposium by director of
international affairs Didier Decaudaveine. Decaudaveine outlined the
proposal, which was then submitted to the Ministry of Arts, Culture,
Science and Technology for consideration. 

Should an official stamp of approval be given to the accord, South
African film-makers will have access to European funding and other
resources as French/South African co-productions will qualify as
European.

Speaking at the symposium, Antoine de Clermont- Tonnerre, producer
of Giuseppe Tornatore's Cinema Paradiso, said that for indigenous
cinema to survive the Hollywood invasion, limitations have to be
placed on American product. France has been a frontrunner in
implementing this policy, endorsing a quota system which promotes
European films on French screens.

Europe is particularly conscious of the need for an infrastructure
for film development, De Clermont- Tonnerre said. Funds such as the
Herbert Bals Fund at the Rotterdam Film Festival and the European
Script Development Fund are critical in terms of providing seed
finance for projects.

Decaudaveine said the French system of film financing has been in
position since 1947, and despite changes in government has always
received official support. French respect for film as an art form has
been largely responsible for the success of the French film industry,
which after Hollywood, India and Egypt is one of the largest in the
world.

Jacques Bidou, an independent producer and specialist in African
co-productions, was also present at the symposium. Bidou, who is
currently working on the first South African/ French co- production,
Fools, to be directed by Ramadan Suleiman, cautioned that, valuable
as the accord will be, the real creative energy for a vibrant South
African film industry will need to come from within.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


202 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Nigeria The Transition TimeTable


LENGTH: 760 words


 
NEWSWATCH
October 9, 1995

LAGOS - The following timetable was announced on October 1, 1995
by Sani Abacha, the Nigerian head of state. The timetable explaines
the steps to the transition to civilian rule. 

1995 OCTOBER-DECEMBER
1. Approval of Draft Constitution.
2. Lifting all restrictions on Political Activities.
3. Establishment of the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria
(NECON).
4. Creation of :
Transitional Implementation Committee;
National Reconciliation Committee;
Federal Character Commission.
5. Appointment Of Panel for Creation of States;
Local Governments Boundary Adjustment.

1996 JANUARY-MARCH
Election and inauguration of Local Government Councils on Non-Party
basis.

1996 APRIL- JUNE
1. Creation of States and Local Governments.
2. Commence process of Political Party Registration.

1996 JULY-SEPTEMBER
1. Registration of Political Parties.
2. Delineation of Constituencies.
3. Production of authentic Voters' Register.

1996 OCTOBER-DECEMBER
Election of Local Government Councils at Party level.

1997 JANUARY-MARCH
1. Inauguration of Party-elected Local Government Councils.
2. Consolidation of new Political Party structures.
3. Tribunal sitting and conduct of any Local Government Bye1997 APRIL-JUNE
Elections.
1. Party-State Primaries to select Candidates for State Assembly and
Governorship Elections.
2. Screening and Approval of Candidates by the National Electoral
Commission of Nigeria.

1997 JULY-SEPTEMBER
State Assembly Elections.

1997 OCTOBER-DECEMBER
1. Election of State Governors.
2. Sitting of State Election Tribunals and Conduct of Bye-Elections.

1998 JANUARY-MARCH
1. Inauguration of State Assembly and State Governors.
2. Party Primaries to select Candidates for National Assembly
Elections.
3. National Assembly Election Campaigns.

1998 APRIL-JUNE
1. National Assembly Elections.
2. Primaries to select Candidates for Presidential Elections.
3. Commencement of Nation-wide Campaigns for the Presidential
Elections.

1998 JULY - SEPTEMBER
Presidential Elections

1ST OCTOBER, 1998
Swearing of new elected President and Final Disengagement.

LANGUAGE: English

203 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Nigeria Abacha Announces Transition to Civil Rule Programme


LENGTH: 4454 words


 
Newswatch (Lagos)
October 9, 1995
by Nats Agbo

LAGOS - Last week was the busiest in Aso Rock since Sani Abacha
became head of state in November 1993. From Wednesday when an
emergency meeting of the Federal Executive Council, FEC, commenced
until 4:00 a.m. on Sunday when the head of state finally recorded his
October 1 Independence anniversary broadcast, the seat of government
was a beehive of activities.

Since Abacha had promised to announce a transition time-table on
October 1, many politicians had converged on Abuja. Most of them, it
was learnt, had hoped that speculations in the press that a prime
minister was to be appointed would become a reality. In fact, some
were seen campaigning for a piece of the action in any political
arrangement. 

It was also learnt that earlier in the week, there were
indications that a prominent politician would be appointed prime
minister last Sunday. Those who were peddling the story even named
Ernest Shonekan, a former head of state and Joseph Wayas, former
Senate leader, as likely candidates. Investigations showed that it
was actually a mere speculation and that Shonekan, who read the
report in a daily newspaper, described it as "rubbish."

For Wayas, however, it was a serious problem. One of his protocol
officers, possibly an aggrieved one, also heard that his boss was
being mentioned in connection with the appointment of a prime
minister. He prepared a dossier on Wayas, detailing some of his
shady deals with the government. The information was said to be very
damaging and could have scuttled the ambition of the former senate
president. His children and some security agents visited several
news media offices in Abuja, hoping to stop the publication of the
information contained in said document.

An Aso Rock source said the meeting of the FEC, the military
administrators and Diya and the PRC were "deliberately long to ensure
that all national issues at stake are properly discussed and
resolved." In all the meetings, there were heated arguments on such
issues as power-sharing, creation of more states and local government
areas, a new revenue allocation formula and the fate of those
convicted for plotting the overthrow of the federal military
government.

According to an Aso Rock source, Abacha's speech was ready by
Wednesday. Some copies were even smuggled out and given to some
reporters. But what they did not know was that what was smuggled out
was just a draft. Abacha himself had planned to modify the draft
after the series of meetings which he held with the various groups
last week.

Although the ministers and military administrators agreed with
most of the issues raised in the original draft of the speech,
members of the PRC had a rancorous debate on all the issues. It was
at this stage that the creation of six new states, earlier approved
by the ministers and administrators, was deferred.

Some parts of the speech were handwritten. The lifting of the
embargo on new employment was, for instance, inserted in red ink by
Abacha just as he was about to start recording his speech. The last
page of the speech was also handwritten by the head of state.

The speech was, therefore, essentially a product of the final
decision of the PRC on Friday and Saturday. In his speech, Abacha
said he was "particularly gratified by the frankness of the
deliberations."

One of the first issues resolved was that of power sharing. At
the ministers level, a minister from one of the Middle Belt states
was said to have opposed the application of the principle of rotation
to all tiers of government. When asked if he did not want a minority
group in his state to be governor, he said: "If the other group
brings up an acceptable candidate, of course, we will vote for him."
This caused laughter at the meeting.

The PRC, however, resolved that the principle of rotation should
"apply to all levels of government." In his speech, Abacha said:
"It is hoped that with the adoption of this system, all segments of
society will feel a sense of belonging."

According to the head of state, the PRC chose a presidential
system in which there shall be president, vice-president, prime
minister and deputy prime minister, along with the senate president
and the speaker of the house of representatives.

These posts will be held on rotational basis among six
geographical zones: North-East, North-West, Middle Belt(initially
erroneously identified as North-Central in Abacha's speech), Southnew power sharing arrangement shall be entrenched in the constitution
West, South East and Southern Minority. Abacha explained that the
and shall be "applicable for an experimental period of 30 years."

Apart from announcing the adoption of the multi-partism, the head
of state outlined a political transition time-table to terminate on
October 1, 1998. According to the programme, the first phase of the
transition will begin this month with the approval of the draft
constitution, lifting of all restrictions on political activities and
establishment of the National Electoral Commission of Nigeria, NECON.

Between October and December, the government would set up a
transitional implementation committee, a national reconciliation
committee and the Federal Character commission. Another panel would
also be set up on the creation of states and local government areas,
and boundary adjustment issues.

Between January and March 1996, elections into local government
councils on non-party basis would take place. In the second quarter
of 1996, new states and local government councils would emerge. The
process of party registration would also commence but it is only
between July and September that political parties would be
registered.

New constituencies would be delineated at the same time that a new
voters' register is being prepared. By the end of 1996, fresh
elections into local government councils on party basis would be
held. What that means is that those who will be voted into office in
January 1996 will spend only nine days in office.

In 1997, the transition programme will be in full steam with the
inauguration of elected council officials, consolidation of new
political structures and conduct of any bye-elections arising from
proceedings of election tribunals. The second quarter of 1997 would,
however witness only party state primaries to select candidates for
state assemblies and governorship elections as well as the screening
of nominated candidates. But while state assembly elections would be
held in the third quarter of 1997, state governors will emerge only
in the last quarter of the same year.

But the governors and state assembly men would not take office
until the first quarter of 1998. Within that first quarter also,
campaigns and primaries for nomination of candidates for national
assembly elections would commence. Elections to the national
assembly would be conducted in the second quarter of 1998, the same
time the primaries to select candidates for presidential elections
would be conducted. Campaigns for the presidential elections would
also begin while the election itself would hold between July and
September, giving Abacha enough room to hand over to an elected
president on October 1, 1998.

The 1998 exit date did not come as surprise. Plans to prolong
Abacha's rule until 1998 unfolded early in the life of the
administration when government seemed resolved to be silent on its
political transition programme. This strategy of remaining silent
worked for the government until April last year when David Mark, a
retired brigadier-general and key participant in the Abacha coup,
punctured the silence.

Mark, in an interview granted Newswatch, alleged that during the
planning stages of the coup, a constitutional conference was seen by
Abacha and Oladipo Diya, his second in command, only as a ploy to
prolong the stay of the military in power.

Government, rattled by Mark's revelation, hastily announced what
it called "the first phase" of its transition to civil rule. If that
programme had been implemented, the new constitution, which is still
in the works, would have been released by December 30, 1994, and on
January 16, 1995, the second phase of Abacha's political transition
programme would have been flagged off. The ban on political
activities would also have been completely lifted by January 17,
1995.

As it later turned out, the constitutional conference, which
Abacha and his officials often said would determine their exit date,
did not only delay the submission of the draft constitution but gave
government a blank cheque on the exit date. The conference submitted
its report(draft constitution) June 27, exactly one year after it was
inaugurated, as against four months that it was supposed to have
lasted. The conference asked the military to fix its own exit date
at its earliest convenience.

Even government's action on the conference heightened fears that
it planned to control the conference to do its own bidding. For
instance, the 369-member conference was made up of 96 governmentconference so that most of the delegates will be strangulated into
nominated delegates was to constitute a pressure group within the
implementing a political transition programme which will terminate in
1998,' says a Newswatch source in its report of January 23, 1995.

Government only fell short of following to the letter the
transition programme which had earlier been canvassed by pro-military
campaigners. If that programme published in the Newswatch edition of
January 23, 1995, was followed to the letter by Abacha, elections
into the local government councils and state houses of assembly would
have been held in early 1997, with the governorship election to be
held within the same period. Government was asked to conduct the
house of representatives election in July 1997, while that of the
senate would have come up in September 1997 and the presidential
election in November of the same year, in anticipation of a possible
handover of power to civilians on January 2, 1998.

The head of state also announced the devolution of more powers to
the states. Although a committee is still to be set up to work out
modalities and guidelines on the issue, he said the lower tiers of
government should be allowed to handle matters relating to health,
education, agriculture, roads and housing. He added that the PRC was
convinced that "the competition for political offices at the federal
level may become less intense, less attractive or acrimonious if some
federal powers are devolved to states and local government councils."

The National constitutional Conference had resolved that all
federal universities be handed over to stated in which they are
located. This policy of devolution of powers may be a reaction to
that recommendation.

Abacha had a few surprises for Nigerians though. His
deproscription of the Punch and Concord newspapers was unexpected. He
said "any fair-minded observer will testify that our news media which
do not go beyond the law, are free to express their views even
sometimes to the extent of astonishing and confusing foreign visitors
who had been led to believe that Nigeria is a police state." He
added that The Guardian, Punch, and Concord newspapers were shut
initially because they were aiding and abetting civil disorder.

Agitators for the creation of new states and local government
areas also had their ambitions punctured. Although the head of state
announced that a committee would be set up on the requests, leaders
of many of the groups were disappointed that the states were not
created immediately. Two weeks before the meeting of the PRC,
leaders of these groups resumed their campaigns in newspapers and
among ministers and members of the PRC.

At the end of the council of ministers meeting, some of the
leaders had received feelers that at least six states would be
created. On the strength of that information, some of the groups had
made elaborate arrangements to celebrate the occasion. Abacha said
"It is consistent with our policy of having a balanced federation
that the aspirations of our people of self-determination which have
been expressed in the demands for new states and local governments be
considered on their merit." According to the transition time-table,
new states would now be created in the second quarter o f1996. The
new states and local government councils would however, be created if
the new committee to be set up by Abacha approves of them.

Another key surprise in the head of state's broadcast is
government's decision to commute the sentences passed on the alleged
coup plotters by the Patrick Aziza military tribunal. The tribunal
had on July 14, convicted 40 of the 51 people it tried. The convicts
included Olusegun Obasanjo, former head of state, Shehu Musa
Yar'Adua, Obasanjo's former deputy, Lawan Gwadabe, former governor of
Niger State, several other serving and retired military officers,
four journalists and a few other civilians.

Fourteen of the convicts, including Yar'Adua and Gwadabe were
allegedly sentenced to death while the others bagged jail terms
ranging from ten years to life imprisonment.

As the nation awaited Abacha's broadcast last Sunday, it was hard
to imagine that there were plans to commute the sentences. Last
Monday, when a delegation of traditional rulers from Lagos State
appealed to Abacha to pardon the convicts, he told them there was a
need to shun sentiments. "We appreciate the personalities of the
individuals involved, but the law is the law. Where there is no law,
we can as well turn into a jungle," he told them.

Speaking further, Abacha said: "Nobody is above the law of this
land, and the sooner we respect this, the better for the stability of
our country." He added that the law is not made for two categories
of people, neither is the law a respecter of persons.

With such hard stance coming from the head of state only a few
days before the independence broadcast, it was suspected in several
quarters that government would carry out the sentences passed by the
tribunal. The suspicion was heightened further when activities were
stepped up at the Kirikiri maximum security prison where nine of
those condemned to death are being held.

More soldiers were drafted to the prison while the execution
ground was cleared. The stakes and the drums behind them were also
prepared for what looked an imminent execution. Soldiers and antithat would erupt after the broadcast.
riot policemen were positioned in readiness for what seemed the chaos

The broadcast, however, made all these an anti-climax. Abacha
attributes the decision to commute the sentences to the "earnest
pleas of our friends and in the spirit of national reconciliation
which has been the centre-piece of this administration's policy."

In the history of coup trials in the country,, this is the first
time the death sentences of those convicted for plotting a coup would
be commuted. In 1976, 32 officers were executed for their complicity
in the abortive Dimka coup. Similarly, 10 military officers were
executed for their role in the botched Vatsa coup. Then in 1990, 42
service men were executed for their role in the abortive Okar coup.

Prevailing circumstances may have influenced Abacha's deviation
from the convention. There had been considerable pressure both from
within and outside the country on the government to commute the
sentences. From within the country, prominent Nigerians, including
former heads of state, retired senior military officers, traditional
rulers, politicians and other prominent Nigerians mounted pressure on
the government to commute the sentences. From within the country,
prominent Nigerians, including former heads of state retired senior
military officers, traditional rulers, politicians and other
prominent Nigerians mounted pressure on the government to commute the
sentences.

The pleas from abroad were even more significant. Some of these
were backed by threats of sanctions. These include those from the
United States of America, Britain and some other Western countries.

On Moshood Abiola, Abacha said those who describe him as a
political prisoner "seek to trivialise the grave offence for which he
is charged." He said politicians had agreed on the formation of the
Interim National Government, ING, adding that "Abiola not only
publicly called upon the military to intervene, he actively
participated in selecting the broad-based cabinet of the new
administration."

Saying that Nigeria had moved beyond the controversy surrounding
June 12, 1993, he added: "We cannot make progress by flogging dead
issues or pretending that matters which long since have been
overtaken by events, should be exhumed and given fresh death."

Saying that Nigeria had moved beyond the controversy surrounding
June 12, 1993, he added: "We cannot make progress by flogging dead
issues or pretending that matters which long since have been
overtaken by events, should be exhumed and given fresh death."

He said Abiola's release from detention would be determined only
by a court of law because "it would be wrong and poor precedent for
the democratic system for which we are laying a foundation to invoke
executive fiat in a matter that is still subjudice."

Whether the new political agenda would pacify leaders of the
National Democratic Coalition, NADECO, other pro-democracy groups
will become obvious this week. But last week, pressure was still
being mounted on Abacha to step aside. On Saturday, Wole Soyinka
told a political meeting in Central London that he had set up an
underground resistance movement in Nigeria. "We are committed to the
removal of the Abacha regime by all means necessary," he said.

Before Abacha announced the transition programme, the Nigerian
Pro-Democracy Network, NPDN, an umbrella organisation of 14
democratic pressure groups formed by Nigerians in the United States
and Canada had indicated that it would not respect the programme.
The NPDN emerged from its first summit held at the Howard University,
Washington on September 23, asked Abacha to announce his "immediate
retirement and the return of the military to the barracks." Failing
that, the group threatened to put more pressure on the US Congress to
pass into law a bill which has gone through second reading to impose
sanctions against Nigeria for "malfeasance regarding drugs
trafficking."

The NPDN whose member-groups have been in the vanguard of the
campaign for actualisation of the June 12, 1993 presidential
election, stated that "a government of national unity should be
installed immediately." Chris
Alli, a major-general and former chief of army staff, retired by
Abacha in September last year is the NPDN's choice to lead the
transition team which will hand over to Moshood Abiola January 1,
next year.

There are indications that the reaction of the international
community to the transition programme would be determined by how well
it is implemented. As Banji Idowu, a Lagos lawyer said last week,
"the international community is already becoming impatient with
Nigeria and the earlier the military leaves office, the better for
this country. Perhaps the international community would have a
change of heart on Nigeria."

Although Idowu held that the transition programme was too long, he
saw the programme itself as a consolation and evidence that in the
end, the military would leave the stage for politicians. Politicians
are however, likening the Abacha regime's transition to that of
former President Ibrahim Babangida. When Babangida started his
transition to civil rule programme a few years ago, he employed the
same method Abacha has now adopted.

The first elections into local government councils were on nonfor the multi-party system. In the end, he refused to register
party basis. He had also given the impression that he had sympathy
political associations formed by politicans. Instead, he formed two
political parties, the Social Democratic Party, SDP, and the National
Republican Convention, NRC, and asked politicians to join them. It
was discovered theat Babangida used such tactics to prolong his stay
in office.

Would Abacha follow the same path? "Yes," says a politician who
added: "All the indications are there, that we are into another long
military rule." but Abacha sees such views as emanating from
"detractors who deliberately persist in a blinkered view of us and
our efforts (and ) fail to take account of all that we have achieved
in so short a time."

Africa News


October, 1995


Kenya Friday Stock Market Update


LENGTH: 627 words


 
Nairobi Stock Exchange (Nairobi)
October 6, 1995

Nairobi - Turnover at the Nairobi Stock Exchange improved further
this week while share prices continued to fall even after the
announcement of the interim results. The NSE 20 share index shed
20.64 points during the week to close at 3246.94. However, it gained
199.66 points this morning following price turnarounds in some
counters. A total of 1.1 M share valued at Shs 59m changed hands
compared to 976,000 shares that were valued at shs 50m traded the
previous week. 

Financial counters dominated trading with a total of 684, 00
shares representing 60% of week volume. Barclays Bank whose pre-tax
profits for the six months topped shs 1.4 billion saw its shares drop
to shs 131.00cd from shs 140.00 with 35,000 shares sold. KCB whose
impressive half year results propelled it shares to shs 74.50cd the
previous week were down to shs 69.50 moving 27,00 shares. Standard
Chartered were fairly stable at shs 53.50cd with 101,000 shares while
National Bank were active with over 211,000 shares at between shs
22.00 and shs 22.75 . National Industrial Credit (NIC) were heavily
dealt at shs 45.00cd down by shs 1.50 selling over 100,000 shares .
With 17,000 shares , ICDC recovered steadily to close at Shs 35.50 up
from shs 34.00.

With 345,00 shares , Industrials had Unga Group and Kenya National
Mills actively dealt again. Unga Group up from shs 109.00cd to shs
125cd had 70,000 shares sold while Kenya national Mills at between
shs 57.50cd and shs 60.00c moved 161,000 shares with 147,000 of these
shares dealt on the three days special board. Kenya Breweries
remained fairly table at shs 65.00 moving 33,000 shares while Bamburi
moved 18,000 shares at between shs 34.00 and shs 35.00. Kenya Power
at shs 130.00 had 5,000 shares while Total (k) up from shs 129.00 to
shs 134.00 moved 2,700 shares.

Commercials moved a total of 83,000 shares. Nation Printers at
reduced prices of shs 80.00 to shs 68.50 had 13,000 shares, Uchumi
supermarket slipped downwards to shs 44.25 from shs 45.00 with
16,000 shares while Standard Newspapers Group were traded at between
shs 12.50 and shs 12.60. CMC were down to shs 40.00 from shs 41.50
trading 25,000 shares while A. Bauman moved up by shs 3.00 to shs
50.00 for 1,400 shares.

Plantations with a total of 29,000 shares had brooke bond move
3,000 shares at between shs 197.00 and shs 198.00 and Sasini 9,900
between shs 68.00 and shs 69.50 . George Willimson recovered to
close the week at shs 74.50xd up from shs 65.00 but moved 2,200
shares.

The Foreign Investor's board had a single lot of 1,925 shares of
Kakuzi dealt this morning at shs 97.00.

Distributed by the African Regional Centre for Computing (ARCC).

205 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Africa-At-Large Art from the Forge


LENGTH: 627 words


 
National Museum of African Art (Washington)
October 9, 1995

WASHINGTON - An exhibition of works by Tuareg and Moor smiths,
renowned for their creativity and mastery of complex metalwork
techniques, opened September 6, at the Smithsonian's National Museum
of African Art, 950 Independence Avenue., S.W. , Washington, DC. "Art
from the Forge," on view through January 2 in the museum's first
level Point of View Gallery, features metal jewelry, ceremonial arms
and objects of personal use.

The Tuareg and Moors are traditionally nomadic peoples who inhabit
portions of West and North Africa. During the 1970s and 1980s a
severe drought caused both peoples to migrate to nearby cities where
many established sedentary lives. Living in close proximity, Tuareg
and Moor smiths, both with distinct artistic traditions, have begun
to incorporate aspects of one another's designs, motifs and
techniques. This is reflected in the works on view. 

All of the objects are made from materials of the highest quality
and have smooth, shiny surfaces and carefully rendered motifs. "These
smiths skillfully balance form and decoration as they in corporate
Tuareg and Moor aesthetic criteria into the objects they create,"
said Andrea Nicolls, curator of the exhibition. For example, smiths
embellished the surfaces of a jewelry box, tea glass cases and sugar
hammer (used to break up prices of sugar) with metal studs favored by
Moors, while they engraved geometric patterns admired by the Tuareg.

Many of the works--such as the Cross of In Gall pendants worn by
Tuareg girls and women-- are made principally of silver, which is
associated with clairity, goodness and divine blessing. Some of the
most visually complex objects are ceremonial arms in which smiths
combined different metals. They embellished the hilts and blades with
encrustations, incised motifs, and layers of variously colored
metals. The leather scabbards that hold the arms reveal several
leatherwork and metalwork techniques. The results are aesthetically
compelling objects displaying striking contrasts of colors and
materials.

Most of the objects in the exhibition are from the museum's
permanent collection, and all were probably produced within the past
three decades. Many of the works were acquired by museum purchase and
by gift of Mrs. Florence Selden in memory of Carl L. Selden.

A free brochure by Tuareg specialist Kristyne Loughran will be
available in the gallery. The publication provides additional
information on the Tuareg and Moor cultures.

The National Museum of African Art is open daily from 10 a.m. to
5:30 p.m., except December 25. Admission is free. The museum's TTY
number is (202) 357-4814. The Smithsonian Home Page on the World Wide
Web, including information on the National Museum of African Art, can
be reached at http://www.si.edu.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Africa, Yebo!


LENGTH: 680 words


 
New Nation (Johannesburg)
September 8, 1995
by Mfundo Ndebele

JOHANNEBURG - South Africa is slowly but surely becoming a part of
the African continent and he rest of the world. Scores of local
artists are participating in the Africa95 festival in which takes
place in Britain for the whole month of September.

Writer and cultural activist Mandla Langa, involved in
coordinating the event's programme, described the participation of
our artists as an historical breakthrough. 

"With the cultural boycott behind us our artists are gradually
taking their rightful place beside other international artists, " he
said. "This event ushers my compatriots into a new era of selfLanga was part of a group of artists which met at the London's
assertion and display of their talent."
School of Oriental and African Studies in 1991 and initiated the
concept of Africa95. At that stage he was the then outlawed ANC's
cultural attache in London.

South Africans featuring in Africa95 include Lucky Dube, Gcina
Mhlope, David Kholoane, Sibongile Khumalo and Jackie Semela.

Charting and inspiring journey to the discovery of creative
energy, beauty and complexity of the arts of Africa is the main theme
of Africa95. The event, the biggest of its kind, places the arts of
Africa in the forefront of the world's artistic expression.

In the visual arts, David Kholoane, who leads the South African
contingent, is among seven curators from Senegal, Nigeria, Sudan, and
Ethiopia, among others, mounting works which have a bearing on the
history and experiences of their countries. Kholoane highlights
politicised South African art.

The all-male Manyanai Dancers from Cape Town present a repertoire
of traditional and contemporary South African dances including
pantsula and gumboot. They share the limelight with dance groups
from Zimbabwe, Nigeria, and Ghana.

A south African theatre production - Marabi by Malcolm Purky- is
being staged in the same venue as The Beautification of Area Boy by
Nigeria's Nobel Prize laureate, Wole Soyinka.

The Africa95 season also marks the emergence of new African
writings. Popular themes of violence, the crumbling of state
institutions and exile in African literature are refurbished by South
Africa's Gcina Mhlope and Abena Buisa from Ghana.

Langa, who leads the South African delegation of writers, will
participate in discussions, seminars, and reading sessions with such
notable writers as Chinua Achebe from Nigeria and Sembene Ousmane
from Senegal.

This event puts to rest the legacy of decades of isolation during
apartheid. It also exposes our artists to international competition
which is essential for their growth and maturity.

"Africa95 showcases our rich artistic talent. But more than that
it creates bridges between the African peoples, out of which we can
all grow," Langa adds.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October, 1995


Kenya What Becomes of Nairobi's Papal Altar?


LENGTH: 254 words


 
All Africa Press Service
October 6, 1995

NAIROBI - One of the most talked about features of the visit by
Pope John Paul II to Kenya from September 18 to 20, was the
construction of the altar from which the pontiff conducted a public
mass at Uhuru Park here.

Constructed mainly with steel and timber and thatched with
papyrus, the structure cost the Catholic Church some KShs. 3 million
(about US dollars 60,000.) 

Today, the structure still stands at the city's Uhuru Park with
many wondering whether it will be of use in the future or it will be
dismantled.

Addressing a group of Kenyan Catholics who participated in various
activities during the Pope's visit here on October 3, Rev. Fr. John
Okello said the Kenya Catholic bishops are yet to decide what to do
with the papal altar.

Pope John Paul II celebrated a public mass here on September 19,
1995.

LANGUAGE: English

208 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Sierra Leone Authorities Avert Coup d'Etat


LENGTH: 614 words


 
All Africa Press Service
October 6, 1995

FREETOWN - Military authorities in Sierra Leone say they have
crushed an attempt to overthrow the government of Captain Valentine
Strasser. Seven soldiers have been arrested and detained following
the abortive coup which happened on the night of October 2.

The government has given few details on how it happened. The
officers, whose names have yet to be disclosed include a major,
lieutenants and captains. It's the second coup attempt against
Captain Strasser's government since it overthrew the civilian
administration of former President Joseph Momoh in 1992. 

Reports quote local observers as saying it is unlikely that the
Revolutionary United Front (RUF), which has been fighting the
government for the last four years was involved in the attempted
take-over.

Although the arrested officers, who are being detained at maximum
security prisons in the capital, Freetown, are yet to be tried to
determine their motive, officials have insinuated that some officers
may be dissatisfied with the planned hand-over of power to democratic
rule early next year.

Captain Strasser has recently announced that he will hand over
power to civilians after democratic elections have been held in
February 1996, but few believe in successful polls against the
background of the continuing rebel war which has killed thousands and
displaced hundreds of thousands.

Captain Strasser has kept Sierra Leoneans guessing about whether
he intends to stand as a candidate in the forthcoming general
elections as he has not stated his stand.

Some analysts fear the failed plot could be an attempt by the
military to maintain itself in power on grounds that it must end the
war before handing the country back to civilian rule.

They liken the latest development to tactics employed by the late
military dictator Samuel Doe of neighbouring Liberia, where fake
coups were the order of the day as a means of entrenching himself and
maintaining a firm grip on power.

The reported failed coup in Sierra Leone comes amid renewed major
offensive launched by the rebels since late September, in which four
towns near the southern provincial capital Bo, have fallen to them
for the first time in months. In the latest fighting about 150
people, including seven government soldiers, have been killed.

Foday Sankoh's RUF rebels are reported to have captured the towns
of Kpetima, Yengema, Serabu and Walihun from government troops,
backed by troops from Nigeria, Guinea and South African mercenaries.
In the past the government has maintained that the rebels were
launching hit- and-run tactics as they were unable to hold any town.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


209 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Egypt Muslim Brotherhood Members On Trial


LENGTH: 747 words


 
All Africa Press Serice
October 6, 1995

CAIRO - An unprecedented crowd packed Egypt's military court
sitting at Huckstep on September 30 in support of 49 members of the
Muslim Brotherhood on trial for underground activities.

More than 800 people, including 309 lawyers as well as
representatives from professional unions, the Sunni Islam authority
Al-Azhar, human rights groups and relatives of the accused came to
back the brothers.

The judges also allowed the public to observe the proceedings, an
unusual move for the military court in the Huckstep army base just
north of Cairo. 

The 49 Brotherhood members, who include several union figures,
former members of parliament and an Azhar official, have been charged
with "directing an illegal organisation aiming to impede the rule of
law and constitution".

But controversy has focussed on Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's
decision to put them before a military tribunal, which started its
sittings on September 16. The tribunal usually considers cases
connected to Muslim militant unrest, even though none of the 49 are
accused of planning "terrorism" or "violence".

Four British barristers, including former Member of Parliament
John Platts- Mills, who volunteered to help the defence team, also
attended the weekend session and thanked the court for allowing them
to observe.

The defence team comprises almost 60 members from the entire
political spectrum, including leftists and three Christian lawyers.
They presented as evidence statements by Mubarak saying he would not
implement emergency law in effect since 1981, which allow military
trials of civilians except in cases of "terrorism".

They also submitted a speech by Brotherhood leader Mamun Hodeibi
before parliament in 1994 in which he supported a third term for
Mubarak as president as evidence that the group was not working
against the state. The defence further asked the court to delay
proceedings until after a court of appeal court rules on a suit to
reverse Mubarak's order for a military trial. The appeals court will
make its ruling on October 24

In 1994 Mubarak accused the Muslim Brotherhood of being behind
attacks by Islamic militants in Egypt. Brotherhood leaders "regulate
the activity of the group's youth and forbid them to resort to
violence or destruction so that the situation does not reach a crisis
as it has in Afghanistan and Algeria," the group's London spokesman
Kamal al-Halabawi said.

Halabawi was quoted by the Arab daily Ash-Sharo Al-Awsat as
denying on September 30 that the Brotherhood backed violence, saying
it had actually saved Egypt from becoming another Algeria.

The Brotherhood, which was founded in 1929 and officially banned
since 1954 says the arrests of dozens of its members is aimed to
sabotage its chances in parliamentary elections set for November.

Meanwhile two other Islamic militant groups, the Jihad and Jamaa
Islamiyya, have called on the Brotherhood to join in the bloody
struggle against Mubarak's secular government.

The bloody campaign by fundamentalists from the two militant
groups against government security forces has already left some 884
people dead since it started in March 1992.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


210 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Kenya Dissident Jailed For Four Years


LENGTH: 1227 words


 
All Africa Press Service
October 6, 1995

NAKURU-KENYA - Kenya's best known political dissident, Koigi wa
Wamwere, his younger brother Charles Kuria Wamwere and a former
military Captain G.G. Ngengi Muigai facing a charge of robbery with
violence, were on October 2 sentenced to four years in jail each and
six lashes of the cane after being found guilty of ordinary robbery.

The trial lasting 20 months was frequently adjourned after
exchanges between the defendants, their lawyers and the trial
magistrate, William Tuiyot, the Chief Magistrate of Nakuru, in
Kenya's Rift Valley Province. The fourth accused, James Maigua,
Koigi's brother-in-law was acquitted.

But the verdict was received with open criticism by a cross
section of the Kenyan society particularly the Law Society of Kenya
(LSK) and some diplomatic missions among others. 

US Ambassador to Kenya Aurelia Brazeal advised the three to appeal
against the sentence. At an official function in Western Kenya, she
said; "I advise Koigi and his colleagues to appeal to the next court
against the sentence for fair trial." Opposition Member of Parliament
Paul Muite, former leading defence lawyer in what has come to be
dubbed "The Koigi Four" case urged all foreign missions in Kenya to
strive and save the accused from suffering corporal punishment.
Amnesty International called for the immediate and unconditional
release of the three whom they said are 'prisoners of conscience".

There were emotional scenes and anger in the courtroom after the
verdict here, some 140 kilometres north- west of the capital Nairobi.
Koigi's elderly mother, Monica Wangu, broke down sobbing
uncontrollably and challenged the magistrate: "Have you no children
of your own? What have my sons done that you must persecute them for
a lifetime."

She also declared that she would not bury her husband's body that
was still lying in the municipal mortuary in Nakuru more than one
year after he died aged 85. At the time of his death, she said she
would await the outcome of the trial in the expectation that her two
sons would be set free and they could then bury their father as per
their Kikuyu tradition.

The "Koigi Four" case attracted a great deal of international
attention because Koigi is a long term opposition activist who had
been detained several times over the last twenty years. Well known
international human rights groups like the John F. Kennedy Memorial
Center cast aspersions on the competence and neutrality of the court
in what they saw as a political inquisition.

Koigi lived in exile in Norway between 1986-1990 where his wife
and children are now naturalised citizens. Norway and Scandinavian
counties have been particularly concerned about his fate and torment
in prison. Norway's Charge d'Affaires, Christian Danbolt, emerged
hurriedly from the court saying he was quite unhappy with the
verdict.

During the trial the prosecution alleged that Koigi, a former
Member of Parliament for Nakuru, with his co- accused and others not
before the court raided Bahati Police Station in Nakuru, on the night
of November 2, 1993 armed with a home made gun. They allegedly sought
to seize guns in the police armoury. Three raiders were shot dead
according to police accounts.

But defence lawyer Paul Muite, who called the verdict "a travesty
of justice", his co-lawyers Mirugi Kariuki and Orlaly Cheche say
police witnesses had perjured themselves. They however did not offer
final oral submissions because the magistrate had demanded a written
submission saying he was taking the step to stop the lawyers making
political capital in court. Defence insisted he was trying to hide
the facts from the world. Koigi himself insisted earlier that Tuiyot
"had already convicted us". He was only going through the mechanics
of the trial process, said the Charismatic 46 year old.

The four accused persons were not in court when the magistrate
returned his verdict. Tuiyot said he did not want a further verbal
exchange with them. However, the three managed to smuggle out of
prison a letter through the acquitted individual maintaining their
innocence. They said they would not mitigate for themselves as doing
so would be tantamount to pleading for mercy, "we have no guilt to
atone for," they said.

They asserted that the case was that of "political and ethnic
persecution". They said the case had been downgraded from robbery
with violence to simple robbery which carries a mandatory death
sentence to placate international donors but the verdict was an abuse
of their civil liberties. "In the struggle for justice and freedom
nothing is so dear to sacrifice - not personal comforts, not jobs,
not even life," said the letter.

It is understood Koigi who wore dreadlocks which he insisted he
would not shave until Moi was no longer in power, was immediately
shaved by warders after the verdict. Mrs. Jacqueline Ngengi, wife of
G.G. Ngengi Muigai, one of the convicted said "the state has
fulfilled what it planned long before they were even arrested."

James Orengo, a lawyer and deputy vice-chairman of the opposition
Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (FORD)-Kenya party called the
case "a sham". Kenneth Matiba of the Ford-Asili (Original) party said
the case "was a shame for the Kenya judicial system".

It recently emerged that Koigi was one of the founder members of
the new opposition party called Safina, (Kiswahili for "the Ark,")
that the government is yet to register. Among its founders is Dr.
Richard Leakey whom president Moi has attacked relentlessly over the
last few months calling him a colonialist.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996

Africa News


October, 1995


Algeria Newspaper Editor Killed By Extremists


LENGTH: 600 words


 
All Africa Press Service
October 6, 1995

ALGIERS - The editor-in-chief of El-Khabar, one of Algeria's top
Arabic-language dailies, was shot dead on October 3 in an apparent
continuation of a campaign against press opposition by suspected
Islamic fundamentalists, Algerian security officials said.

Omar Ouartilan, 36, was shot dead in the head with five bullets
near his newspaper offices in the working class neighbourhood of
Belcourt, near the city centre, the officials said.

Police could not immediately say who had carried out the killing,
but suspicion rested on the Muslim fundamentalist groups who have
since May 1993 killed 42 journalists criticised for opposing the
fundamentalist insurgency ravaging the country. 

Security officials said the El-Khabar editor was shot by a young
man, 200 metres from his daily's building inside former army barracks
where several other newspapers have also made their home. The site is
patrolled by police and protected by barbed wire and metal detectors.

Interior Minister Mostafa Benmansour condemned the "cowardly
attack" by the "forces of darkness", six weeks ahead of a
presidential elections due on November 16.The elections have been
opposed by most of the mainstream and more hardline opposition
groups, while the fundamentalists have vowed to disrupt them.

If the motive for the killing is confirmed, Ouartilan would be the
43rd journalist to be killed in the campaign, and the 19th this year.
He had been editor-in-chief of El-Khabar since 1991. The newspaper
publisher escaped an assassination attempt in 1994.

The last article by Ouartilan to be published in the paper was a
commentary whose headline read: "Oh peace, show yourself". Starting
with a verse from the Palestinian poet Mahmoud Darwiche, it spoke of
the despair of the average citizen, caught between the violence of
the fundamentalists on one side and the military-backed government on
the other.

More than 30,000 people are reported to have died so far in nearly
four years of civil war in Algeria. The fighting was sparked off by
the government's cancellation of the second round of January 1992
elections whose winner appeared to be the fundamentalist party.

More than 150 journalists have fled Algeria to go overseas, most
of them taking refuge in the former colonial power, France. Some
journalists now move around armed, refusing to stay in the same place
overnight for more than a few days at a time and changing their
appearance frequently.

But Ouartilan refused to live in buildings protected by the
security forces, only recently leaving his home in the Bab el Oued
district because it was judged "Unsafe".


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October, 1995


Burundi Three Italian Missionaries Assassinated


LENGTH: 800 words


 
All Africa Press Service
October 6, 1995

BUJUMBURA - Unidentified attackers assassinated two Italian
priests and an elderly Italian lay worker on the night of September
30 in a remote area of southern Burundi, UN Special Representative in
Burundi Ahmedou Abdallah announced on October 1.

The two priests, who were in their 50s or 60s, and the lay worker,
who was in her 70s, were killed in the province of Bururi, Abdallah
said.

The priests belonged to the Xavieriani Order of the Roman Catholic
Church and had been in Burundi for many years, but the lay worker had
only arrived in the country recently, Abdallah said. 

Describing the killings as "just not despicable, but abominable",
Abdalla said that he was concerned by what appeared to be a campaign
against the Roman Catholic Church in some Burundian newspapers which
included "often unfounded accusations".

Abdallah appealed to Burundians to respect religion saying: "As a
Muslim, that is important to me." The motive for the killings was not
immediately clear, but observers said that with ethnic killings
common in this tiny central African nation, it was possible the
Italians had witnessed an atrocity and had been killed to prevent
them from talking.

Two Burundian priests have also been assassinated in the past one
month, Abdallah added. A Catholic priest was also gunned down and
killed on August 21 after celebrating mass in his parish in Ngaraga.
The assassination followed a series of bloody attacks that had rocked
the tiny central African nation in the previous two weeks that left
more than 50 people dead.

The Catholic church was under continuous attack in the mid-1980s
when Jean- Batiste Bagaza was president. Bagaza, who was considered a
Tutsi extremist, remains in Bujumbura since he returned from exile in
Uganda a few years ago and has a considerable following.

The latest killings came amid further reports of violence in
Burundi in which nearly 30 people were said to have died.

A report by the Burundi press agency on September 30 quoted
eyewitnesses as saying that 24 people were massacred by armed Hutu
gangs in eastern Burundi on September 28, while at least four were
killed in separate violence overnight in the capital.

The 24 died in Buygigi province in attacks by gangs who also stole
a large amount of money. Three of the attackers were killed by
security forces, the agency said, but did not confirm whether
civilians were among the dead.

Citing informed sources, Radio Burundi also reported frequent
automatic fire and at least two grenade explosions in the Ngaraga
district north of the capital.

It said an armed gang threw the grenades and caused slight
injuries to four children in an attack on a camp for displaced Tutsis
in Ngaraga, as shots were also being heard in other areas.

The radio also revealed that a man suspected of being a gang
leader was killed in Cibitoke, north of Ngaraga, in as yet unclear
circumstances.

Burundi has the same ethnic mix of 85 per cent Hutu and 14 per
cent Tutsi as Rwanda before the civil war, when between half a
million and one million Tutsis and moderate Hutus were massacred by
the Hutu- dominated army and militia before its overthrow in July
last year.

In Burundi, President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya is a Hutu, but the
Tutsis hold most of the key positions, especially in the security
forces, and the judiciary.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October, 1995


Kenya Group Forms "New" Presbyterian Church in Kenya


LENGTH: 1134 words


 
All Africa Press Service
October 6, 1995

NAIROBI - A splinter group from the local Presbyterian Church of
East Africa (PCEA) has announced the formation of a new church.

Led by outspoken clergy and former editor of a church and later
his own private magazine, Rev. Jamlick Miano of Kirimara Presbytery
in Central Province, some 30 clergy announced October 1st that they
were launching a new church to be known as the Presbyterian
Evangelical Church of Africa (PECA).

But the Moderator of the PCEA General Assembly Rt. Rev. Bernard
Muindi denounced the group saying the PCEA would not allow the
registration of their splinter church using the word "Presbyterian",
as when the alphabets ...PECA.. are re-arranged, the abbreviation
comes to those for the Presbyterian Church of East Africa.

In a statement to APS dated October 3, the PCEA Moderator said the
church did not regret that the group led by Rev. Jamlick Miano and
John Wandimi Wang'ombe had formed a splinter church. 

Criticizing the two leaders of the splinter church group, Rev.
Muindi warned their followers to be aware that the two men have
morally failed in their former church work as pastors and "are hungry
for leadership". The PCEA is looking forward to see what sort of
leadership they are going to provide to their followers," added
Muindi.

In response to questions posed earlier by APS following the
announcement of the formation of the splinter group, Rev. Muindi
noted that ambition for leadership and money were the two main causes
for splits in the churches today.

He described the two vices as great enemies in today's church
adding, "if the Church has to be the Church, these evils must be
fought against vehemently."

The PCEA Moderator noted that people of the calibre of Miano and
Wang'ombe had marred the image of the church, and instead of saying
that the PCEA should be reformed and that it is corrupt, they should
be praying that they be reformed.

Of John Wandimi Wang'ombe, Rev. Muindi noted that the former was
deposed from the church's ministry because of misconduct, as a result
of which he lost his status as clergy and as such had no right to use
the title "Reverend" or "Pastor".

About Miano, the PCEA Moderator noted that the former editor
resigned when he learnt that disciplinary measure were being taken
against him because of misconduct as well as failure to do his
duties. "He has been a controversial pastor, but the PCEA has been
nursing him sympathetically in an effort to see whether he could
reform, but all in vain," added the Moderator. He added that instead
of deposing him immediately, the PCEA transferred him to Kirimara
Presbytery to work as a chaplain at the nearby Karatina hospital.

Miano, a former editor of his own private magazine "Watchman", now
outlawed and the defunct Jitegemea (Kiswahili translation for selfabout 30 others including Wang'ombe, announced the formation of the
reliance), which was a quarterly mouthpiece of the PCEA together with
Presbyterian Evangelical Church of Africa during an open air crusade
in Karatina town, in central province, some 100 kilometres north-east
of here. Eight priests were commissioned to serve in the synod which
would be headed by Miano in his capacity as Canon-General.

Miano edited Jitegemea from 1991 to 1993. The monthly PCEA
magazine began in 1985 and was then edited by Rev. John Mburu. It
closed down in 1990 but was re-launched in 1991 under Miano.
Jitegemea's editorial contents which were clearly critical of the
government did not escape the authorities' pressure, forcing it to
fold up early 1993.

The PCEA which was introduced in Kenya by seven Sctottish
Missionaries in 1891 also runs two theological colleges. The church
began as the Presbytery of East Africa, then became the Overseas
Presbytery before it attained its current status in the late 1950s.

Miano had earlier announced that he was quiting the PCEA citing
frustrations, tribalism, corruption and high- handedness in the
church. By the time of going to press, efforts to get a comment from
Rev. Miano were futile.

Meanwhile, about 50 PCEA faithful were reported to have raided
Miano's house on the evening of October 1, 1995, threatening to throw
him out. The group wanted to know why he was staying in the house
when he had quit the church. He is reported to have said that he
would continue staying in the church house until the church pays his
retirement dues.

If Rev. Miano and his group succeed in registering a new church as
indicated, then this would be the first split reported in the 104
year-old history of the Presbyteraian Church of East Africa.

The PCEA is affiliated to the continental Nairobi-based All Africa
Conference of Churches (AACC), the global World Association for
Christian Communication (WACC), the World Alliance of Reformed
Churches (WARC), the World Council of Churches (WCC) and the local
National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK). It is the third largest
denomination in Kenya with 1.5 million faithful. The Catholics and
Anglicans have over 6 million and 3 million followers respectively.

Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Who Caused the Meridien Bank Downfall?


LENGTH: 867 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 10, 1995
by Mukalya Nampito and Goliath Mungonge

Lusaka - Fresh evidence of debtors of the liquidated Meridien Bank
has revealed howsenior government and leaders of the ruling party,
the MMD, could have benefitted from the demise of the bank they owed
cash.

The leaders include defence minister Ben Mwila, whose company,
Investment Holdings, had a loan of more than K147 million which bank
sources say was suspiciously secured. Transport minister Dawson
Lupunga and MMD's Moped are among other debtors.

Mwila offered a guarrantee of K50 million and his house in Kitwe
together with one of his firms in Luanshya despite having resigned as
director of the named firm in April 1994. 

"Guarantee by B.Y. Mwila for K50m plus interest; First legal
mortgage for K3m plus interest over S/D1092, Kitwe; Equitable
mortgage over stand No. 1091, Luanshya in the name of Gilmer
Engineering Limited," read the Bank of Zambia listing of non
performing credits by customer as at January 31, 1995."

A search at the company registry office, however, shows that Mwila
resigned his directorship of Investment Holdings on April 29, 1994
but was immediately apppointed on the company's Board, according to
minutes found there.

Mwila's company was first registered with the registrar of
companies on April 28, 1975 with a nominal capital of K2,500,000.
Mwila did not reply to two press queries, one sent to his Chudleigh
house and the other through Jack Mubanga, the defense secretary.

"Mr. Mwila has dashed out of the country for an urgent assignment,
so your query can wait," the reporter was told at the defence
ministry. Transport minister Dawson Lupunga offered himself as
security together with his farm in Ndola for a loan of K161 million.

"Joint & several guarantee for K3.5m plus interest by Hon. D.L.
Lupunga & C.M. Lupunga support by: First legal mortgage for K3.5m
over stand No. 12 of S/D Q of Farm No.416A & stand No. 2578, Ndola,"
the listing states.

But a search two weeks ago revealed no Molu Butchery. There was
only Mulu, whose directors are Maxon Bwa Mbwala, Oliver Moono,
Bwabwala and Tenyson Mudabanse, which was set up with an initial
capital of K16,000.

When confronted at a cocktail party on September 26 at Pamodzi
Hotel, Lupunga replied: "I do not speak to The Post because I am
allergic to it."

Moped, the MMD company, owes the defunct bank more than K200
million, chairman Kanti Ranchod confirmed. "It was board decision and
it was minuted," he said.

Central Bank registrar Felix Kani refused to be drawn into
dicussing the matter in details saying he was under oath not reveal
anything regarding a customer's bank account. He also warned the
reporter to refrain from reporting on Meridien bank.

"There is a current investigation going on concerning the bank and
I would like to urge you to refrain from reporting on the bank until
investigations are completed lest the reports prejudice the outcome
of the investigation," read part of his statement dated October 2,
1995.

MMD as a party owed Meridien Bank K744,315,000, almost 25 per cent
of the total K3 billion owed to the bank by 106 debtors as at January
31 this year. But Central Bank sources say the MMD figure has shot to
more than K1 billion after the May audited report.

MMD chairman for economic and finance Enoch Kavindele on September
29, acknowledged the figure MMD owed Meridien but insisted that
arrangements were being made to pay back the amount.

"We are going to make arrangements so that the money is paid bank.
MMD as a party is just like a business house that can borrow," he
said.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996

Africa News


October, 1995


Uganda Netballers Coming


LENGTH: 480 words


 
The Monitor (Kampala)
October 4, 1995
by Hassan Badru ZZiwa

Kampala - Ugandans may watch probably the best netball in recent
decades as Kampala hosts the East, Central and Southern Africa
Netball Senior Championships.

World Cup netball finalist and All Africa Games Netball champions,
South Africa have confirmed they are coming. So are Malawi, Zambia,
Namibia and debutantes Zimbabwe. 

No word yet from neighbours Zanzibar and Tanzania, but reports
from Kenya say the Kenya national side, "Nyayo Stars", are already in
non-residential training at Nyayo Stadium readying themselves to
defend the trophy.

"We have received a good response from NCS, our next step is to
fix the dates," said Lydia Bukenya, the Uganda Netball Federation
boss.

Uganda last hosted a major netball event in 1982. It was until
other member countries threatened to throw Uganda out of the
Confederation unless they also hosted that they realised they too
have to do something.

Still all is not well as the Uganda Netball Federation is cash
strapped and are desperately looking for a sponsor.

"We only received the green light to host the championships from
NCS, but we have no funds. Therefore we have to fund-raise in order
to host this tournament," said Lydia Bukenya.

Uganda and Kenya have dominated this event since its inception
over a decade ago, but with the inclusion of South Africa and the
rapid growth of netball in Malawi and Zambia, the trophy may go down
south.

Rose Kaala UNF General Secretary said that Uganda will be
represented by two teams, "A" and "B". "We are about to summon the
players, but before that we have to play a regional and "She Cranes"
tournaments to select the best girls," she explained.

According to Kaala, the event is slated for December after the
East and Central Senior Challenge Cup in November.

Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia UNIP: Don't Use Voter Certificates


LENGTH: 494 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 13, 1995
By Anthony Mukwita

Lusaka - UNIP has called for an end to the use of voter
certificates during elections charging that the method has been used
and abused by the ruling MMD to rig elections.

The charges come shortly after UNIP lost three of the five
parliamentary by-elections held on Tuesday this week which were
characterised by physical clashes over voters' certificates.

"We have established beyond any reasonable doubt that the MMD are
rigging all the elections they have won so far and the process they
are using is that of issuing excess and fake voter's certificates, "
said UNIP administrative secretary Basil Kabwe in an interview on
Wednesday this week. 

UNIP lost the Kabompo West seat to MMD's Mathew Makayi, the
Bweengwa seat to Nalukombo Keembe and Lufwanyama was scooped by MMD's
Mike Mlongoti.

UNIP has retained the Musanzala and Lundazi seats through their
candidates James Mwale and Bina Moyo respectively.

In the Musanzala seat however the electoral office had to suspend
the use of voter's certificates after it found evidence of massive
reproduction of voter's certificates by an electoral officer.

But MMD member and presidential press aide Richard Sakala
dispelled Kabwe'scharges as groundless.

"We lost in Lundazi and Musanzala, this could not have been the
case had we been issuing fake voters certificates as claimed, so the
accusation is really baseless, " Sakala said in a telephone interview
on Wednesday.

He condemned the violence in Lundazi which he charged was being
perpetrated by unruly UNIP cadres: "there was lots of violence there
were police and innocent MMD members were injured."

Kabwe however feels MMD had a share in the much publicised
election violence "These are issues that are real but the
government media has chosen to turn a blind eye to them choosing to
report on the so-called UNIP violence which is instigated by MMD
members, " Kabwe said.
