Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Editor Wins Press Freedom Award


LENGTH: 814 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 10, 1995
by Catherine Mwewa

Zanzibar - Post newspaper managing director and editor in chief,
Fred M'membe has scooped this year's Media Institute of Southern
Africa (MISA) press freedom award.

The award which was presented to him by human rights lawyer Roger
Chongwe on Saturday night in the Indian Ocean Island is in
recognition for his significant contribution to media freedom in
Southern Africa.

MISA board of trustees chairman, Justice John Manyarara from
Zimbabwe explained that the objective of the prize was to award
excellence in journalism. Justice Manyarara described excellence in
journalism as "the upholding professional ethics at all costs and the
relentless pursuit of truth behind the bare facts." He said M'membe
had showed "courage, depth and foresightedness in his reportage hence
the reason he was nominated for the award." 

Presenting the award, Chongwe hailed M'membe for his relentless
fight against corruption and drug trafficking together with
dictatorship. M'membe said:"this award is not for Fred M'membe alone
but it belongs to all those who have contributed to the production of
and survival of The Post."

M'membe thanked the Zambian people for their continued support of
The Post through sales and Misa for honouring the independent bia lonely profession but interesting at times. There are times when
weekly. "It is a great sign of solidarity with us. Journalism can be
people we write for disown us. When they ignore the malpractices, the
acts of corruption because they are carried out by people they
support" he noted.

He said even fascists and dictators too have received support from
their people citing Adolf Hitler and Idi Amin as some of those who
were backed in their dictatorial governance.

MISA governor for the Zambia chapter, and Editor in chief of the
National Mirror, Fanwell Chembo could not hide his admiration and
respect for M'membe. "It has been a hard road to freedom for us
journalists, truth, perseverance and determination to get to the root
cause of the story are the whole marks of good journalism. "These
qualities have been exhibited by Fred and his team at the Post." He
said only after four years of practising journalism, M'membe has
excelled above the "so called experienced people in the field of
journalism. "He has brought a new brand of journalism to Zambia. It
is no secret that alot of emerging papers have are there because of
the leadership Fred has provided."

Elia Cossa, editor of Demos Weekly in Maputo, Mozambique said it
was a fair award to Fred and his team. "It is a very good example of
what the role of journalists and the press in our region has
contributed to democracy."

Ngozi Awa, chief executive of Colcla Group International and a
MISA consultant appealed to leaders to bear in mind that they were
empowered because of free press. Thus should not silence journalists
like Fred but encourage and support and defend freedom of the press.

Last year's MISA Freedom of the Press award was Basildon Peta, a
Zimbabwean journalist who was courageous enough to refuse to divulge
sources in the face of harassment from the state

MISA is a dynamic member driven network of regional chapters which
seeks through training, monitoring, capacity building, research and
the distribution of information to foster free, independent and
diverse media throughout southern Africa. Member countries include
Namibia, Tanzania, Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique,
South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


218 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Pests Invade Imported Maize


LENGTH: 560 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 17, 1995
by Joe Kaunda

Lusaka - LARGER Gran Borer (LGB) has invaded Zambia's maize
imports at the Tanzanian port of Dar-es-Salam. Director of Zambia
National Farmers Union, George Grey, revealed in an interview on
Tuesday that LGB invasion was discovered in a 2000 tonne consignment
of maize for the government's strategic reserves from Dar-es-Salam
last week.

"We have already informed the government of the LGB situation and
plans to start fumigating at Kapiri Mposhi are underway. The only way
we can contain the situation is to put stringent measures like
fumigating all maize wagons entering the country," Grey said. 

Initially, the wagons were supposed to be inspected on entry into
the country through Nakonde border post but this was however ignored.

Grey added that there were fears of a widespread attack by the
beetles especially that the consignment was derailed in Mkushi, the
largest maize farming area.

"Our fears are that this may affect the grain production in
Mkushi. The pest multiplies very quickly and it poses a serious
threat ," Grey disclosed.

This development may worsen the grain situation which already
stands at a deficit.

Both the farmers union and government have repeatedly warned of a
sever food shortage to be caused mainly by drought. Government urged
the public to begin conserving adequate domestic food reserves and
avoid food wastage in their daily living.

Agriculture permanent secretary, Austin Sichinga has also
confirmed the LGB invasion.

"It is not only the LGB but also other grain pests. The maize that
came in from Tanzania was contaminated and is currently quarantined
at Kapiri Mposhi. The maize was supposed to be inspected by our
counterparts in Tanzania before the shipment was released," Sichinga
said, adding: "The grain is awaiting fumigation and only the grain
certified as fit for consumption will be released to avoid the spread
of the pest."

Grey however warned that the country was on the brink of a
critical maize shortage if the grain was not imported in four weeks
time.

"We need importation in the next four weeks if we are to avoid an
acute shortage," Grey said.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Zambia Zambia Included In Ladies' Golf Tourney


LENGTH: 294 words


 
October 17, 1995
by George Jambwa

Lusaka - Zambia has earned a last minute inclusion into a threecapital, Harare, next month.
nation ladies' golf competition that will tee-off in the Zimbabwean

And more than 18 lady players have entered for a preparatory
tournament to pick players to represent Zambia at the event. 

Zambia's inclusion comes after Botswana's last minute withdrawal
from the annual event normally played among Zimbabwe, Namibia and
Botswana.

This years tournament will be in Zimbabwe where Zambia will now
compete with Namibia and the host on dates to be announced soon.

Locally, the preparatory event has been slated for Kitwe's Nkana
Golf club during the first week of November.

"We are hosting an open tournament in the first week of November
in Kitwe and about eighteen top players are expected to tee. We will
choose who are supposed to go to Zimbabwe to represent Zambia,"
Zambia Ladies Golf Union president, Sue McManus confirmed in a
telephone interview from Luanshya on Friday.

Veteran Hildah Edwards of Lusaka is expected to feature
prominently in the event to lead the Zambians next month.

Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Farmers Warn About Corruption in Mine Corp


LENGTH: 494 words


 
October 20, 1995
by Mukalya Nampito

Lusaka - Farmers have added their voice to the ongoing claims of
rampant corruption in the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines.

The farmers have also warned that Presidsent Chiluba will be
blamed for any loss of donor support because he has continued to be
ineffective in dealing with cases of corruption.

"The allegations (ZCCM) are very serious especially considering
that ZCCM is Zambia's economic life blood and is a public
institution. 

"Our Republican President continues to ask for evidence- yet he
has at his disposal not only the power-but the mechanism to get to
the bottom of the problem," said a statement issued in Lusaka this
week by Zambia National farmers Union (ZNFU) chairman Ben Kapita.

He charged the Presidents's apperent tolerance of corruption does
not justify the declaration of Zambia as a Christian nation which
Chiluba hastily made.

The farmer's reaction follows a story earlier carried in The Post
edition of October 6 saying donors have complained of corruption and
abuse of office in the conduct of the affairs of ZCCM. The donors
also warned that before the mines company can be privatised the
corruption will have to be stamped out.

"If the allegations by the donors expressed at the consultative
meeting are not investigated and if corrective action is not taken,
then Zambians will conclude that the government has something to hide
or is protecting some untouchable leaders," Kapita said and added:

"If this leads to a reduction in donor confidence in the
credibility of our leadership and therefore a reduction in donor
support for Zambia, then the President must be held responsible or
the loss of support," the release read in part.

Kapita retaliated on Wednesday this week that he stood by the
farmers statement but a government minister declined to discuss the
matter.

"I have no comment on that matter of corruption," said deputy
minister Works and Supply, Celestino Chibamba in a telephone
interview on the same day.

221 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Zambia Struggles To Regain Access to IMF


LENGTH: 560 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 20, 1995
by Chilombo Mwondela

Lusaka - The government is struggling to regain access to the
International Monetary Fund (IMF) after failing to complete the
Rights Accumulation Programme last May.

A rights accumulation programme (RAP) allows a country in
protracted arrears to regain membership of the Fund through a phased
repayment schedule until amounts reach the level of arrears
outstanding at the beginning of the programme.

Before the start of the RAP, Zambia's arrears stood at SDR833
million (SDR: Special Drawing Rights). 

Zambia's re-admittance to the fund depends on the completion of
this programme which was postponed to September when Zambia was deBank.
railed off the repayment schedule by the attempted rescue of Meridien

However, government has still failed to meet the deadline despite
numerous easures put in place to boost government revenue especially
through the tax system.

IMF representative to Zambia Eluualeed Taha could not shed more
light on the issue this week as he was reportedly attending meetings
between the government and the IMF mission which are currently going
on.

But a 1995 IMF annual report confirmed that: As of April 30, 1995,
Zambia had accumulated rights of SDR 647 million, under a rights
accumulation programme approved by the executive board in 1992. In
March 1995 the board extended the expiration date of the programme
from March 31 to May 31 to provide more time for Zambia to accumulate
the remaining million and to continue discussions on a successor
Enhanced Structural Adjustment Fund (ESAF)."

However, the IMF mission last month failed to reveal any
developments. Sources at the Ministry of Finance said that Zambia
failed to meet its benchmarks or contribute enough towards the
programme in August and September and the government will remain in a
tight cash squeeze if it is to meet the November and December
benchmarks to finish the programme by December 1995 or early next
year.

Deputy Minister of Finance Koshita Shengamo said last week that
government was committed to the completion of the programme and were
on course.

"I do not think there is anything that will upset us," he said in
an interview on Monday.

LANGUAGE: English

222 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Ivory Coast (DOCUMENT) Groups Critique Sunday's Scheduled Vote


LENGTH: 1947 words


 
African Policy Information Center
October 17, 1995

Washington - With presidential elections scheduled for Sunday,
October 22, in the Ivory Coast (Cote d'Ivoire), all major opposition
parties are boycotting the poll in protest and say they will also
boycott the parliamentary elections next month.

The reelection of Henri Konan President Bedie, successor after
long-term President Houphouet-Boigny two years ago, is assured. In
addition to the lack of an independent electoral commission, the
center point of opposition protest is the electoral code, which
alters the previous practice of allowing African residents of noncode also excluded from candidacy a leading rival for the Presidency,
Ivorian origin (an estimated 40% of the population) to vote. The
former Prime Minister Alassane Ouattara. Ouattara's father was born
in Burkina Faso, and he has been resident outside the country since
1994, as Deputy Director of the International Monetary Fund in
Washington, both bars against candidacy in the new electoral code. 

The following documents include an open letter from opposition
representatives in Washington, and an earlier evaluation, by the
Washington-bsed election monitoring group International Foundation
for Electoral Systems, of the electoral code revision process. The
documents are distributed by the Africa Policy Information Center
110 Maryland Ave. NE, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax:
202-546-1545. Email: apic@igc.apc.org.

Open Letter from Front Populaire Ivoirien and Rassemblement des
Republicains, September 15, 1995 General elections in Ivory Coast
are scheduled for the last quarter of 1995.

In December 1994, however, President Henry Konan Bedie, appointed
one year earlier to complete the term of the deceased President
Houphouet-Boigny until the 1995 elections, approved a new electoral
code. This code, under the cover of the fuzzy concept of "Ivoirite,"
is aimed at destroying the multi-ethnic social fabric of the Ivorian
nation. If nothing is done immediately to minimize the impact of this
devastating electoral code, the foreseeable consequences will be
extremely dangerous for the survival of this multi-ethnic West
African nation of 14 million inhabitants with 4 million Africans of
non- Ivorian origin. Although only a few African scholars,
particularly Ivorian scholars, have stood up vigorously against this
electoral law, Ivorian religious leaders both Christian and Muslim,
have asked the Bedie government to revise the text to remove the
openly exclusive and xenophobic tone.

The electoral code, written by the PDCI (the Democratic Party of
the Ivory Coast), the party in power, with the approval of President
Bedie, is discriminatory against some Ivorians. Its principal
objective is to sow discord and to spread hate among the different
ethnic groups that make up the nation. The code fosters unfairness
against some targeted ethnic groups (the Abbey, the Agni, the Bete,
the Dioula), who are considered to be dangerous because they could
play a crucial role in countering Mr. Bedie's bid to capture the
highest political power in Ivory Coast for the next five years. If
enforced, this law would destroy--for the sake of winning a
presidential bid--a thirty- year-old history of construction of the
Ivorian nation that has made the Ivory Coast a genuine model of
integration in West Africa.

Indeed, all West African nations have a fairly important community
of their own peoples married or living as immigrants in Ivory Coast
and this is unique on the African continent. President Bedie has
bluntly stated that his electoral code was to remain, despite urgent
requests from Ivorian religious dignitaries, from opposition
leadership and from the majority of the Ivorian people.

Given the adamant refusal by President Bedie and the PDCI to agree
upon a bipartisan agenda -- i.e. an amendment to the electoral code
and agreement on a fully independent electoral commission, the
Republican Front, a coalition of the seven major opposition parties,
decided upon a course of actions to bring the Bedie administration
to the negotiations table.

But in response, the Bedie administration banned for a period of
three months "all marches and sit-ins in all streets and public
squares." This means that the wrestling match between the PDCI and
other legal political powers is now underway. This may lead to
bloodshed, because the Ivorian forces of change are determined not to
allow the massive electoral frauds of 1990 go unchecked this election
year. Therefore, if nothing is done immediately, we will be making
our way towards an almost certain social explosion in the months
ahead.

The specter of Liberia, a neighboring country which might have
been saved from the presen human tragedy if one had acted in time,
can only haunt the spirits of all those who love the Ivory Coast and
who wish it to avoid the all too- common fate of civil war. That is
why we would like to call on the great democratic institution of the
American Congress and the Clinton Administration to help Mr. Bedie
understand that his electoral code in its current form and the
rejection of a fully independent electoral committee are a total
denial of the rule of law for free and open elections. This is
contrary to what the Ivory Coast authorities agreed in finally
welcoming a multi-party system of governance in May 1990.

The general elections scheduled for October 22 should be postponed
for six months. The delay would allow the Government and the
Opposition to work out together an electoral system fair to both.
The entire Ivorian population will support the electoral lists that
came out of the last census only if Opposition parties participate
in setting up a genuine independent national electoral commission.

On behalf of the Ivorian Popular Front: Pascal D. Kokora, Ph.D.
On behalf of the Republican Rally, Balla Sidibe. c/o P.O. Box 18110,
Washington, DC 20036. Fax: (202) 234-6074.

Excerpts from election planning report of the International
Foundation for Electoral Systems (IFES) (Elections Today, May 1995,
pp. 23, 25) IFES, 1101 15th St. NW, 3rd Fl., Washington, DC 20005.
Tel: (202) 828-8507; Fax: (202) 452-0804. IFES sent a four-person
technical team to Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire from Oct. 19 to Nov. 4,
1994. The team's primary objective was the review of the ongoing
voters registry revision in preparation for national elections
scheduled for 1995.
... After 35 years of national independence, the 1995 national
elections will be only the second to encourage open, multi- party
competition. President Houphouet-Boigny's passing signaled the
beginning of a new era for the nation, as well as for the sub-region
and the entire African continent. One important indicator the change
in Cote d'Ivoire is the ongoing revision and verification of the
electoral list, and the related debate over the continued extension
of the franchise to non-Ivorians. ... After lengthy debate, it was
decided that for the first time in recent elections, non-Ivorians
resident in Cote d'Ivoire will not be allowed to vote in the national
elections.
... The team's primary concern with the process centered on four
areas: *A lack of openness among the government officials controlling
the process.
* Based on the findings of the IFES team and on the information
provided by the government, the team concluded that, if the
government has nothing to hide, they must improve the quality of the
information that they disseminate to the public. ... *A lack of
proactive participation in the revision process by opposition
political parties and non-partisan civic and human rights groups.
* ... Inaction favors the party in power and the current
administration, permitting them to be accountable to no one.
* A seamless relationship between the government of the Cote
d'Ivoire and the leading political party, the Partie Democratique de
Cote d'Ivoire (PDCI-RDA).
* ... The IFES team feels that a major challenge facing the
Ivorian election administration is the successful balancing of the
intentions of the party in power and the equal participation of the
other political parties and candidates.
* A need for timely publishing of complete instructions for each
step of the registration and the electoral processes to define the
vague procedural and legal guidelines set out in the electoral code.
* ... The electoral code as it stands can be said to create more
questions than it resolves.

IFES' experience in electoral reform and technical elections
assistance in many of Cote d'Ivoire's neighboring nations underlined
for the Foundation the importance of the 1995 elections, not only
for Cote d'Ivoire, but for the entire sub- region. The transformation
to participatory multi-partyism in many of the neighboring countries,
including Liberia, Sierra Leone, Nigeria, Guinea, the Gambia, and
Senegal, will only benefit from the conduct of open and transparent
elections in Cote d'Ivoire.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Black Areas Lure Property Investors


LENGTH: 1294 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 20, 1995
by Meshack Mabogoane

Johannesburg - Prospects for major commercial property
developments in emerging markets, or black areas, could increase
dramatically once black local government has been legimitised.

A morass of technical hurdles, such as identifying owners of land
and registration of title deeds, still remains to be cleared up. So,
too, does the role of numerous community development forums (CDF)
which arose in the wake of the collapse of community councils or
black local authorities.

The lure of black areas is reinforced by feelings that
developments in areas of high and historical investments are
becoming saturated and generating lower returns (about 10 percent)
in comparison with the vistas beckoning in black areas where returns
are estimated to be worth some two percent higher. 

Though some major developers have gone ahead with heavy
investments to build substantial portfolios it will still be an
uphill battle. The enormity of the task, says a black property
developer, will require "innovative public sector directives" to
offset the huge "social engineering that went into the making of
black townships".

He cites the potential role of the new Facilitation Act in cutting
through red tape, a factor that has dampened the enthusiasm of
property investors to move to black areas.

However, he warned against "artificial solutions" that do not take
account of realities and reinforced the view that market forces
should be supplemented, and not supplanted, by local and central
legislative directives.

There is also the reverse prospect of suburban municipalities
delaying applications for development in their own areas and
directing them to areas of less density.

Malls in former white areas are becoming congested, pressure is
mounting on transport and other facilities as non residents are
drawn in; already 40 percent of Sandton shoppers are blacks from
townships. Redirecting property developments would be a boon to both
areas.

Even without these measures some headway has been made. Sanlam
Properties seems to be leading the way. In the Gauteng area only it
has put up two major shopping complexes: the 18 900m2 Dobsonville
Shopping Centre near Soweto, opened in 1994 at a cost of R45-million
and the 17 000m2 Daveyton Mall costing R44-million to be opened by
month end.

Altogether the company's national portfolio in all black areas,
including coloured and Indian, is now

worth R500-million. Major anchors like Pick 'n Pay and franchised
food outlets have been involved. Local entrepreneurs take up the
remaining space.

These developments are motivated by hard business sense
underpinned by extensive research, consultations with communities,
(through the CDFs) social responsibility and their client base.
Sanlam's policy holders are 65 percent black. And "it is well known
that investment in these areas has been neglected in the past," says
Banus van der Walt, managing director of Sanlam Properties.

"We see the lack of proper retail space as a business opportunity,
but also as a chance to contribute to the social and economic
upliftment of thousands of people."

The private sector is geared to black townships' revamp. "Many
developers would like to see black townships becoming normal suburbs
with all property facilities- shopping complexes, office blocks
etcetera, sprouting up," says Andre Viljoen of the SA Property
Owners Association, Sapoa.

"There are many developers eager to move in. Already 11 mediumaverage cost of R30-million -- are known to us to be in the
sized shopping centres -- of between five to15 000m2 at an estimated
pipeline," adds Viljoen.

And whether the rise of black-owned insurance companies, like
African Life, a subsidiary of Real Africa Holdings, and Metrolife of
New Africa Investments Limited, would unleash their financial
resources for real property development in black areas is moot.
African Life burnt its fingers with a project in Orlando West and
caution is at a premium with black economic empowerment companies in
the wake of recent hassles experienced by some.

But Thebe Properties, backed by the massive Thebe Holdings which
has strategic investments in Safrican and other financial
institutions, is geared for new township and other major property
developments in black areas.

Though risks associated with violence have significantly gone
down, says Viljoen, social and legal hurdles still need to be
overcome.

"The biggest problem is land ownership. It is difficult to locate
ownership and the registration of title deeds takes time. Also the
process of consultation with local development forums (made up
mainly of civics and business associations) can be lengthy and
complicated, however necessary it has been. It took Sanlam 2,5 years
to negotiate with such a forum in Dobsonville."

There is also strong opposition from chambers of local traders
which fear that outside (white) developers might snap up all the
land. However, the imperative of having black partners, in the
climate of black economic empowerment, makes nonsense of such fears.
And major financial institutions have substantial black policy
holders.

The key to unlocking real property vistas still depends mainly on
the outcome of local political and social developments, including
the infrastructural revamps that central government has recently
promised are in the pipeline.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Book Claims White Right Has Nuclear Weapons


LENGTH: 587 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 20, 1995
by Eddie Koch

Johannesburg - The right-wing movement in South Africa has
advanced nuclear weapons and can drop these on any town in the
country by using a squadron of Impalas or at least five G6 cannons
which are in their possession. This is the most astonishing in a
string of startling claims presented in a book by Peter Hounan and
Steve McQuillan which is due to be published next week.

The authors of The Mini-Nuke Conspiracy, due to be published
today, say they have been told by numerous sources that an arsenal
of state-of-the-art nuclear bombs is being used by the white right
wing to back demands for an Afrikaner volkstaat and to keep the new
government from making too many radical changes to the country --
and President Nelson Mandela is aware of this. 

The book's claims, some of which have already been published in a
national newspaper, are shocking enough to make governments around
the world tremble and to send the local stock exchange into a
tailspin. That they have not done so is probably because the
allegations come from a string of unnamed "intelligence sources",
"security agents", and "sources close to British intelligence".

A man given the pseudonym Jan, and described as a "senior
intelligence agent", is quoted as saying: "They have more than one
shell -- the standard tactical nuclear shell -- and the present
government knows about their capability ... The G6, the system
designed to deliver a nuclear shell, is the weapon. They have five
of them, and a stockpile of shells, all being moved around the
country to strategic positions -- the majority within easy reach of
Gauteng."

The book adds: "A committee of right-wing retired senior police,
military and Military Intelligence officers, some of them generals,
were commanding the weapons ... 'to prevent even renegade elements
of the right wing from getting hold of them'."

Another source named as Rick, "a government agent who had
penetrated the right wing", is quoted as saying that he had
personally seen a warhead and a long missile like a Scud that was
under guard by the right."

Even the assassination of academic David Webster is attributed to
the nuclear conspiracy. "Hennie, a military agent, said ... he had
heard that David Webster, a Johannesburg anthropologist, was murdered
because he saw too much on field trips near the range. 'I was led to
believe he was killed because he saw a nuclear device that was about
to be fired ...'"


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa Cape Town Olympic Bid in Cost Controversy


LENGTH: 974 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
October 20, 1995
by Rehana Rossouw

Johannesburg - The green light for South Africa's Olympic dream
shone faintly this week when Cabinet decided to support the
preparations for the 2004 Games, but warning lights flashed over the
possible cost to taxpayers.

The Cabinet's decision came in the same week as the organising
committee for the 1996 Games in Atlanta -- the home of megafor making a profit are virtually non- existent.
corporations like Coca-Cola and CNN -- admitted that its prospects

A budget presented to Cabinet by the Cape Town Olympic Bid Company
in preparation for the Cabinet decision required central government
to spend R979-million over the next 10 years, but promised a separate
surplus of R94- million.

The government will now assist the Bid Company to fine- tune its
budget and will provide expertise to examine preparations and report
back to Cabinet for its final decision in April next year. 

Bid chief executive Chris Ball welcomed the Cabinet's decision and
said national and provincial finance and transport experts would now
join his staff to form "Team South Africa" to prepare for the bid
process.

A bullish Ball said the message to the world now was that the
South African bid was proceeding -- it had the full support of the
Cabinet and national business.

But serious reservations about the budget presented to Cabinet
were raised this week by a chartered accountant, who analysed it on
behalf of the Mail & Guardian. He said a major question left
unanswered was how it could be assumed that South Africa could make a
profit out of the Games while other more sophisticated countries
failed to do so.

The Cape Town Olympic Bid Company predicts a total revenue of
R4.2-billion, an expenditure of R2.9- billion, a gross surplus of
R1.3-billion and, after expenditure on sports facilities, housing
subsidies and a contingency fund, a net surplus of R94-million. The
private sector is required to provide R279- million.

"Cape Town's budget is generally optimistic, even though it is
difficult to predict the situation in nine years' time," the
accountant said. "We don't know what the state of the South African
economy will be in 2004 and what exchange rates will be.

"The problem this creates is that the budget is a bit of a
thumbsuck as this is a once-in-a-lifetime affair and there are no
annual budgets to compare it to.

"The accelerated capital budget makes no provision for interest on
loans the government would have to raise if they bring that
expenditure forward. There is a risk that those additional costs will
be passed on to taxpayers."

Another serious problem identified by the accountant was that the
budget predicts that Cape Town requires an additional 70 000 hotel
beds for the Games, a staggering amount for the private sector to
meet and continue to fill after the Olympics.

Although the budget allows for a R150-million subsidy on Olympic
housing, which could be sold to low-income earners after the Games,
he believed not enough thought had gone into the upgrading and
development required outside the site, which he believed the IOC
would require and the new owners might not be able to afford to
support.

He doubted whether the number of tickets sold would come close to
that of the Barcelona Games, which were little more than a train ride
away from Britain and other European countries. Tickets would
probably be relatively expensive for South Africans.

The accountant said he was also concerned that South African
business would not be able to afford to sponsor the Games. Although
the budget predicts sponsorship at 40 percent below Sydney's
projection, South Africa's market was much smaller.

Ball responded by saying he was condifent South Africa would
receive sufficient corporate sponsorship. He admitted that ticket
prices would probably be beyond "Soweto's" reach and that issue would
need to be examined.

"The big difference between our bid and Atlanta's is that Atlanta
received zilch from central and state government. Every cent had to
be raised by their committee," he said.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Uganda Uganda's Coffee Export Market Share Crumbles


LENGTH: 654 words


 
The Monitor (Kampala)
October 4, 1995
by Sarah Mirembe
...Uganda - Uganda has been steadily losing its coffee export market
share since 1990 because of the high risk of its coffee, the
Executive Secretary of the Uganda Coffee Exporters Association
(UCEA), Frederick Mulalila Kawuma has said.

Kawuma who was speaking at a press conference last week said "with
the exception of Germany, Uganda's position has been crumbling
everywhere, losing its coffee market share since 1990, despite the
fact that total European imports of green coffee have been relatively
stable."

Even in Germany, the increase in Uganda imports is part of a
general trend rather than a phenomenon particular to Uganda. 

"Many coffee roasters and importers believe that Uganda's origin
risk has increased since the reforms in the coffee sector were begun.
Several sited delays in deliveries, and the increased number of
private exporters is seen as a factor increasing the commercial
risk." he said.

Uganda's coffee quality has also decreased due to factors related
to post harvest processing. "Earthy taste, cherries, broken beans and
other flaws have been observed in Uganda's green coffee samples.
There has been an increase in the number of quality disputes," he
said adding that some roasters have, for that matter, already
abandoned Uganda's coffee or are considering seeking substitutes,
particularly in Asia.

Reports from UCDA said by the close of last week, prices had
dropped to US$ 2220 per tonne, down from US$ 4100 per tonne last
September.

"The nose-diving of coffee prices to their lowest in a ten week
period last week was due to the refusal of a group of Brazilian
exporters to participate in the private exporters retention plan,"
the report said.

Prices were however beginning to recover due partly to the news
that rain in Brazil was going to be very slight and news of a likely
increase in global demand for instant coffee especially in the
developing countries.

The plunge in world coffee prices has sent shock waves to the
coffee exporters who fear being thrown out of business. UCEA
Executive Director, Kawuma, warned coffee exporters not to commit
themselves on contracts which they will be unable to deliver.

Kawuma said the fall in world prices had also hit hard at the
farmers who were currently getting peanuts out of their coffee.
"Today, farmers are paid between Shs 600-700 down from Shs 1500 per
kilo of kiboko," he said.

Last season, Uganda exported three million 60 kg bags of coffee.
This year, the number is expected to fall to only 2.5 million bags
because of the fall in prices.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


227 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Uganda Finance Minister Joins World Bank Against IMF In Debt Battle


LENGTH: 640 words


 
The Monitor (Kampala)
October 6, 1995
by Richard Tusiime
...Uganda - A rift has emerged between the World Bank and the IMF
over the creation of a Multi-lateral Debt Facility, to help indebted
Third World countries service their debts to Western donors.

The proposal seeks to establish a facility that will refinance
servicing of the debt to the World Bank, IMF and the African
Development Bank, the three major institutions owed most by the Third
World.

It will benefit heavily indebted economies. 

Uganda, Zambia, Cote d'Ivoire, Guyana, Bolivia and Nicaragua have
been billed the prime beneficiaries of the project, according to the
NOVIB.

The fund which will initially be $11 billion could be increased,
the IMF agrees to sell part of its gold.

The facility will be funded from the World Bank extra
profit(windfall) of $800 million but needs enhancement from the IMF.

The proposal will be tabled during the Annual General meeting of
the World Bank and IMF to take place between October 9 and 12.

Documents availed to "The Monitor" indicate that the IMF staff
including its director Michel Camdessus, and key members -- Japan,
Germany and France -- strongly oppose the scheme.

They argue that the scheme will reduce resources to the
International Development Agency(IDA).

Conservatives in the World Bank, including one of its vice
presidents, Johannes Linns, are also strongly against the scheme that
has been produced by the bank's division on Debt and Financial
policy.

World Bank president Wolfensohn has been in Japan to persuade it
to endorse the plan.

Proponents of the scheme communicated to indebted Commonwealth
countries, to use their ongoing Finance ministers meeting in Jamaica
to "strongly support the move and have it as one of their
resolutions."

Uganda's Finance and Economic Planning Minister Mayanja Nkangi did
not mince his condemnation of the IMF, for opposing the scheme, in
his address to the Commonwealth ministers on Wednesday, October 4.

"The IMF is less forthcoming and flexible in agreeing to proposals
for debt relief," Nkangi told the meeting. "Uganda welcomes the
brave step taken by the World Bank (in proposing the facility)."

He said efforts by the Paris Club to cancel and reschedule
Uganda's debt, which stands at $3 billion plus, could not go far
since three quarters of all debt is owed to IMF, World Bank and
African Development Bank.

Nkangi said the new debt relief scheme would meet up to 67 percent
of multi-lateral debt servicing.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa National Park Likely


LENGTH: 414 words


 
New Nation (Johannesburg)
October 6, 1995

Johannesburg - Recommendations for the future management of Table
Mountain and the rest of the Peninsula mountain chain are to be
presented to Environmental Affairs Minister Dawie de Villiers today
and may propose the establishment of a national park.

The recommendations, which could end decades of often acrimonious
debate and divided management, are in the report of the Table
Mountain advisory committee, constituted for De Villiers by Cape
attorney general Frank Kahn and headed by National Botanical
Institute chief executive Prof Brian Huntley. 

The committee finalised its recommendations at a meeting at
Kirstenbosch this week. It considered a proposal by the National
Parks Board that t Peninsula's protected natural environment area
should be managed as a contractual national park in association with
existing landowners.

There were also proposals from Cape Nature Conservation and the
Cape Metropolitan Council, both of which said they did not want to
manage a consolidated nature are and suggested a new body should be
established for this purpose.

Speculation is that the committee will recommend the national park
option.

Huntley said his committee's final meeting had been "very positive
and very constructive".

"It was a bit tricky to handle at times and there was still some
passion and some doggedness too, but it was a good meeting."

At the start of its deliberations, the committee agreed that its
final recommendation would be on the basis of "reasonable consensus".

There had been strong reasonable consensus", this week, Huntley
said.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Uganda New Constitution: Good Independence Gift?


LENGTH: 1227 words


 
The Monitor (Kampala)
October 9, 1995
by Kyazze Simwogerere
...Kampala - Uganda celebrates its 33rd Independence anniversary
today, only 24 hours after completing a 19-month exercise that
brought in the country's fourth and newest Constitution.

There were no sensations similar to those experienced by people at
the dawn of a New Year, yet this new law has quite a few innovations.

One of the most fundamental issues is that of land. The CA
delegates are supposed to have passed an article that vests land in
Uganda, in the hands of the people under the customary, freehold,
"mailo" and leasehold tenure systems. 

But as with many provisions in the new Constitution, the delegates
shied away from resting land. There was a powerful lobby of landabsolute ownership to the millions of peasant farmers living as
lords, whose huge clout made it impossible for the CA to give
"kibanja" on "mailo" land. This also goes for the explosive issues of
the lost counties, where Baganda gentry--Minister Zimula Mugwanya has
a reported area as big as a county in Kibale--have large tracts of
land.

The uneviable task of finding ways of accommodating the interest
of the land-lords and the "kibanja" holders. The delegates had the
temerity to give the new parliament two years from Sunday to complete
a task they even feared to define.

Women were not so terribly upset with what they got out of the
Constitution-making process, after all some of the most progressive
clauses concern their welfare.

None of the previous constitutions had provisions allowing for the
special representation of women in Parliament. This one does. As
things stand now, any new parliament shall have at least 39 women
law-makers--representing the districts.

But as with land, the CA dithered about the manner of electing
these ladies. One of the biggest complaints out of the 1994 CA
elections was that many women unfairly won because of the small
electoral colleges (less than 200 each), whose members they allegedly
bought and manipulated.

Ironically the issue of women went to the division lobby, when
some members argued that they should decide that the women be elected
by Universal adult suffrage in the districts.

All these responsibilities have made the new parliament the
strongest Uganda will have. The law-makers will, for instance, have
powers to veto presidential appointments, impeach the main man if
they had to, change the political system etc...

But the new House also got some unenviable tasks, but the most
eagerly awaited is the relationship the Parliamentarians will have
with President Yoweri Museveni.

For the last nine years, Museveni has been the Chairman of the
National Resistance, effectively fusing the powers of the legislature
and the executive. This was essentially because the NRC was
Museveni's show, which he started in 1986 with about 33
"Historicals".

Nine years and 117 Statutes later, the NRC should wind up business
in the next six months with another nine bills and two resolutions.

Although it passed groundbreaking legislation especially on women
and the press, the NRC has been considered by many as an apendage of
the executive, with no teeth.

The members would make occasional noises and "jam" to pass some
bills. Then Museveni would take them into closed sessions and wave
the big stick. He hardly ever got a negative result.

The new parliament is likely to be a whole new ball-game,
considering they get to elect their own Speaker, that Museveni has no
right to closed sessions, and there will be quite a number of
"opposition" politicians.

The new constitution also guarantees the basic human rights, of
life (except for murderers).

One of the biggest battles was of course on the political systems.
The CA eventually entrenched the Movement Political system, the
Multi-party political and any other, which Ugandans might want to
have.

The catch of course, is that no two systems will operate
simultaneously, and at the end of each, there would be a referendum.

The quarrel that the multi-partyists have is the NRM (or Movement
Political System) has the inside track on the issue since it is in
power. They consider this a violation of their birthright to
associate. Maybe that explains why the National Caucus for Democracy
(NCD), a loose grouping of multi-partyists in the CA, has now changed
to National Convention for Democracy, to evade the clauses that bar
parties from making public announcements of their existence.

And it was not all gain for everyone in the CA. There were the
Baganda, whose "conc federo" demands fell on dead ears, and made the
once amiable "Ssabalangira" Besweri Mulondo a much revilled figure in
the region.

There are still a few things that can be done by government
"public interest," although there is no precedence for any REAL
"public interest" in Uganda's history.

The tough questions should new begin, now that the new
constitution is in force.

As a matter of information, Uganda has now had four Constitutions
in its 33 years, giving us on average, a new document every eight
years.

Let's hope this one lasts.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


South Africa (DOCUMENT) Novel in Afrikaans Wins 1995 Noma Award


LENGTH: 1027 words


 
The African Book Publishing Record (Oxford)
October 11, 1995
...Oxford - Marlene van Niekerk's novel "Triomf," published in 1994
by Queillerie Publishers, Pretoria, South Africa, has been named as
the winner o the 1995 Noma Award for Publishing in Africa. This is
the first time in the Award's fifteen-year history that a work in
Afrikaans has been selected as the prize winner. The book was cited
by the Noma Award jury as "a captivating and innovative novel by a
masterly story-teller, which breaks new ground in describing the ways
in which poor white Afrikaaners, too, were victims of oppression, and
thus ushers in a wholly new way of addressing the past as a prelude
to the new." 

The novel focuses on the humdrum lives of a family in the
Johannesburg suburb of Triomf (Triumph) built on the ruins of the
racially-mixed Sophiatown, bulldozed to the ground by the apartheid
state to make room for cheap housing for 'poor white' Afrikaaners.
looked down on the rest of the white population, they fear the black
population; ignored by both groups, they live their lives with very
little hope of improvement. The novel captures the monotony of their
speech and lifestyles as second-class citizens, but at the same time
the author succeeds in portraying their banal and bleak everyday
existence as often poetic and moving. "Triumph" represents an
important stream within Afrikaans literature of reconsidering the
history of South Africa, and the themes of the novel exemplify key
issues in current postcolonial discourses about identities: national,
linguistic, and gender-related.

Coincidentally it is also the first time that the Noma Award will
be presented in South Africa, and the $5,000 prize will be given to
Marlene van Niekerk at a special ceremony to be held at the
University of the Western Cape in late November. South Africa's
Executive Deputy President Thabo Mbeki has agreed to make the
presentation.

"State of the Environment in Southern Africa," edited by
Munyaradzi Chenje and Phyllis Johnson (Writers: Andrea Booth, John
McCullum, James Mpinga, and Mutizwa Mukute), published in 1994 by the
Harare-based Southern African Research & Documentation Centre
(SARDC), in collaboration with the IUCN-The World Conservation Union
and the Southern African Development Community, was awarded 'Special
Commendation'. The book was praised by the jury as "an important and
timely state-of-the-art report in an area of crucial significance for
the well being of the continent. Easily readable and effectively
illustrated, the book shows evidence of a huge amount of careful
planning and synthesis of knowledge, presenting issues in a way that
challenge decision makers to act."

110 titles, from 49 African publishers, in 14 countries were
submitted for this year's competition. The five-member Noma Award
jury, chaired by Walter Bgoya (Tanzania) met in Weggis, Switzerland,
on 1-2 October to select the 1995 winner. In selecting the Awardindependent opinion and assessments secured from subject specialists.
winning title each year the jury proceeds with the help of

The jury also singled out five further books for 'Honourable
Mention'. They are (in alphabetical order by author): "Maqabane"
(Poetry) by Tatamkhulu Afrika, Bellville, South Africa: Mayibuye
Books, 1994; "Flowering Plant Families of East Africa" by John O.
Kokwaro, Nairobi: East African Educational Publishers Ltd, 1994.
"Lifeline out of Africa. The Art of Ernest Mancoba" by Elza Miles,
Cape Town: Human & Rousseau (Pty) Ltd, 1994; "Nigerian Conveyancing
Practice, Drafting and Precedents" by P.A.O. Oluyede, Ibadan:
Heinemann Educational Books (Nigeria) plc, 1994; "Don't Panic,
Mechanic" (Teenage fiction) by Jenny Robson Cape Town: Tafelberg
Publishers Ltd, 1994.

Established in 1979, the Noma Award is open to African writers and
scholars whose work is published in Africa. It is given annually for
an outstanding new book in any of these three categories: (i)
scholarly or academic, (ii) books for children, (iii) literature and
creative writing. The Award's founder is the late Shoichi Noma,
formerly President of Kodansha Ltd, the Japanese publishing giant.
Mr. Noma died in 1984 after a lifetime's devotion to making books
more readily available in developing countries, to actively promoting
readership in these countries, and to bridging the gap between North
and South. His ideals are shared by his daughter, Mrs. Sawako Noma,
the current President of Kodansha, who has continued to support the
prize generously.

The Noma Award for Publishing in Africa is administered by the
quarterly journal "The African Book Publishing Record" published in
Oxford, England.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


231 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Sierra Leone (DOCUMENT) Letter to H.E. Strasser


LENGTH: 534 words


 
Committee to Protect Journalists (New York)
October 16, 1995

His Excellency Captain E. M. Strasser Chairperson, National
Provisional Ruling Council. Your Excellency, The Committee to Protect
Journalists (CPJ) writes to strongly protest the arrest of journalist
Chernor Ojukwu Sesay who was detained immediately upon return to
Sierra Leone after being deported from The Gambia where he sought
refuge.

Sesay, previously a freelance journalist in Sierra Leone, fled to
The Gambia in early May 1995 due to a well-founded fear of
persecution. He was working with the independent Daily Observer when
he was picked up by Gambian immigration authorities, detained for two
days, then deported back to Sierra Leone on October 12. It is
believed his arrest in The Gambia was linked to an article he wrote
in the Daily Observer about the police beating of two Sierra Leonean
nationals in Banjul. Upon arrival to Freetown, Sierra Leonean police
arrested him and are currently holding him in the Criminal
Investigations Division (CID). 

No official reason has been given for Sesay's arrest. While the
police have stated that his departure from Sierra Leone without
clearance accounts for his detention, no legal regulation has been
cited. Moreover, it is our belief that Sesay is being held due to his
journalistic work in Sierra Leone before he fled. CPJ has documented
the harassment of Sesay and his colleague, Siaka Massaquoi of Vision,
by military police in January 1995.

Out of profound concern for Mr. Sesay's welfare, we called the CID
earlier today and spoke directly with the head of the Division, Mr.
Hallowell.

CPJ has documented at least nine incidents of abuse of the press
in Sierra Leone, the most so far this year in Sub-Saharan Africa. We
have written to Your Excellency twice before this year protesting the
persecution of journalists in your country. We again join the chorus
of voices calling for your government's adherence to minimum
standards of human rights, inlcuding press freedom, as guaranteed by
the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant
for Civil and Political Rights, and the African Charter on Human and
Peoples' Rights.

Thank you for your consideration. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely, William A. Orme, Jr., Executive Director

LANGUAGE: English

October, 1995


U.S./Africa (DOCUMENT) White House Statement on Nigerian Coup Plotters


LENGTH: 414 words


 
White House (Washington)
October 19, 1995

Washington - The following has been released by the White House:
STATEMENT BY THE PRESS SECRETARY.

The United States is deeply concerned about reports that the
Nigerian military regime has moved several alleged coup plotters from
Lagos to an ill-equipped and sub-standard prison in the northeastern
part of the country. We remain concerned about reports of
maltreatment and the failure to afford regular medical treatment to
those detained.

The United States condemns the long prison sentences imposed on
those Nigerian military officers and civilians accused of coupformer President Olusegun Obasanjo and human rights activist Beko
plotting, including four life sentences, the fifteen year terms dealt
Ransome-Kuti and the twenty-five year term imposed upon General Shehu
Musa Yar'Adua.

Since the arrests began last March, the United States, the
international community and a broad spectrum of Nigerians have
consistently deplored the secret trials that have resulted in these
harsh sentences. We continue to question the validity and harshness
of sentences handed down after secret trials in which some of the
accused were not even publicly charged. We are aware of no evidence
to substantiate the charges and do not accept the airing of purported
evidence on Nigerian television as a substitute for fair and open
trials.

The United States reiterates its call upon the Nigerian Government
to speed the transition to democracy, starting by releasing political
detainees. The United States will maintain all existing sanctions
and keep other measures under review as we look for progress in the
transition to democracy and the release of political detainees.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

October, 1995


Rwanda and Burundi (DOCUMENT) Ugandan and Zairean Presidents to Convene Peace Conference


LENGTH: 374 words


 
The Carter Center (Atlanta)
October 22, 1995

New York - Statement by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni and
Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko on Conference to Address Crises in
the Great Lakes Region: We the presidents of Zaire and Uganda, along
with President Ali Hassan Mwinyi of Tanzania, will co-convene a
conference shortly to establish conditions necessary to prevent
further humanitarian tragedies in Rwanda and Burundi and the impact
these situation are having on their neighboring countries. We are
inviting former U.S. President Jimmy Carter, South African Archbishop
Desmond Tutu, and former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere to serve
as mediators for the conference. The Carter Center in Atlanta, Ga.,
has been asked to coordinate the conference.

We believe peace, reconciliation, and justice are the only basis
for a common and harmonious future. We share a deep concern about the
escalating violence in Burundi, the stalemate surrounding the
repatriation of nearly two million Rwandan refugees and the
destabilizing effects of these crises on the region. The problems in
the region are many and complex. But we believe immediate action is
needed to begin to move beyond the violence and build healthy and
prosperous societies.

Recognizing the need for a comprehensive approach to these
problems, we agreed on a general agenda addressing issues in human
rights, refugees, justice, governance, constitutional reform,
land/property rights, security, arms, and the media.

The date and place for the conference will be announced by The
Carter Center in the near future.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


234 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Kenya (DOCUMENT) Kenya Joins Cyberspace Age


LENGTH: 560 words


 
African Regional Centre for Computing (Nairobi)
October 24, 1995

Nairobi - Kenya, being the twelfth African country to do so, has
ultimately joined the Internet - the global Information superhighway.
Disclosing the news, the Director of the African Regional Centre for
Computing (ARCC), Dr. Shem Ochuodho, said this facility will give
Kenyan researchers, educators and businessmen an opportunity never
envisaged before. For several years now, researchers and businessmen
and women from other parts of the world have been able to easily and
readily access valuable information that has eluded their Kenyan
counterparts. The facility, for instance, brings distance learning
(ie. teachers and students across the country appraising themselves
through a non-expensive computer network) and access to export
markets to the fingertip of Kenyan academics and entrepreneurs. 

Kenya, despite its well developed communications infrastructure
and having ventured early into electronic networking, real-time,
interactive access has remained an illusion, largely due to high
long-distance telephone costs. This for a while has been the case in
many parts of Africa, making it today the only continent not
significantly connected to the "Internet". However, this state is
fast changing with recent experiences from various parts of the
continent, with at least two African countries joining the net almost
every month over the past 6 months.

Tunisia and South Africa were the first African countries to hook
onto the Internet about 3 years ago. Since then, other countries to
have joined include Algeria, Egypt, Mozambique, Zambia, Ghana,
Uganda, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Morocco and now Kenya. It is understood
from the Nairobi-based ARCC that this historic breakthrough will
mainly benefit education and commerce, to which its initial access
will be directed. Kenya's entry has been made possible through the
kind support of the British Overseas Development Agency (ODA). The US
National Science Foundation (NSF) also offered technical assistance
by sponsoring a week's visit to Kenya of a world renown networking
expert, Mr. Randy Bush to conclude the set-up.

For nearly 4 years now, a number of institutions have provided or
had electronic mail (e-mail) service in Kenya. However, all these
have been dial-up systems using ordinary telephones to link either to
Europe or United States. The new service relies on a dedicated leased
line rented from KPTC. As other countries move towards higher
quality, greater bandwidth and more cost-effective links, it is hoped
that Kenya will once again be in the frontline.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


235 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Magistrate Throws 0ut Ban Application Against The Post


LENGTH: 454 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 26, 1995
by Staff Reporters

Lusaka - Principal resident magistrate Meebelo Kalima yesterday
threw out an application by the state to ban The Post from covering
the case in which it is prosecuting the paper's journalists for
writing stories critical of President Chiluba's aide Richard Sakala.
Kalima also declined to cite the paper for contempt over previous
stories carried by it on the trail.

"I do not wish at this juncture to be drawn into the issue as to
the reporting of this case in the press, whether it is correct
reporting or otherwise. 

"I make my own recording of the proceedings and I can not be
influenced by what comes out in the press," Kalima said before
ruling; "what I am saying is that those recording should continue to
record or continue to record the truth but should record everything
even what is not in their favour." The prosecution claimed in its
application early this month that The Post was presenting inaccurate
recordings of the case. It also claimed the paper had questioned the
integrity of the magistrate whom it accused of siding with the state
after he revoked bail for managing editor Bright Mwape, his assistant
Goliath Mungonge and former Post and now reporter of The Chronicle
Nkonkomalimba Kafunda as a way of "jolting up their lawyers." The
other accused person is managing director and editor-in-chief Fred
M'membe. Kalima however turned down a counter application by The Post
to be allowed to use audio and video recorders in court as a way of
enhancing their accuracy.

"I can not grant that because there is no such a law in this
country. It is true the law will one day change but for now we shall
abide by what is on record," Kalima said.

Trial could not continue because the Prosecutor Inspector Katongo
has a funeral and was granted leave by the court. Trial continues on
Monday October 30 at 14:30 hours.

October, 1995


Zambia College Students Share Three Text Books


LENGTH: 360 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 26, 1995
by Dan Moonga

Lusaka - Only three text books were used by 19 students for a onebecause of a book shortage there, graduating students complained
year journalism course at the Africa Literature Centre in Kitwe
yesterday.

Leading the attack at the 37th graduation ceremony of 19
journalists and six artists yesterday, one of the students, Joseph
Chanda, said despite having paid the same fees for the courses,
their colleagues in neighbouring institutions received 25 textbooks. 

"This is an issue which we have not been able to get a proper
explanation about and which we wish to inform you that our sponsoring
bodies are going to be informed of accordingly," Chanda said. He said
this in the presence of ALC director Minne Kairu and some ALC board
members who included John Musukuma, Rev Cannon Janda who is also IMF
director and Nkana member of parliament Matildah Chakulya. He pointed
out that this year's theme: "Go thee and prepare the word" cannot be
accomplished unless there is a properly planned programme and
pragmatic actions to improve education at the institution.

Chanda, whose speech was applauded by fellow students some of whom
shouted "Tell them", said there was a need for consistence in the way
the administration handles the students.

The situation was worse in art and design where students did not
cover some topics in graphics because there were no text books and
even the lecturers had none.
