237 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Central Bank Delay Can Cause Serious Food Shortage


LENGTH: 480 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 26, 1995
by Sipo Kapumba

Lusaka - The continued delay to release more than US$26 million
meant to facilitate the importation of the grain by the Central Bank
could lead to a serious maize shortage.

Zambia Grain Growers and Marketing Association chairman George
Lloyd said the money was stuck at the Bank of Zambia (BOZ) because of
disagreements with commercial banks over collateral.

But a Bank of Zambia (BOZ) official said the bank was merely
acting as a custodian of the money and could only release it after
getting instructions from the finance ministry. 

"We would like to see the deadlock between BOZ and private
comercial banks resolved so that we can access Tanzanian grain. If we
don't access it we shall run into sporadic shortages soon," Lloyd
said. The $26 million would facilitate the importation of
approximately 1.5 million x 90 kilogram bags of maize. He was
concerned that because of the delay most of the other sources in
neighbouring countries had run out leaving only Tanzania as the ready
source.

"We hope that the deadlock will be resolved because the issue is
more serious than people realise," Lloyd warned. He said some members
of the ZGGMA had used their initiative to borrow money in foreign
exchange from commercial banks because of the relative stability in
the value of the kwacha but this was only a small measure.

"If the money is released, the private sector has shown in the
past that it can be creative and innovative and could still be able
to arrest the situation," he said referring to the mealie meal crisis
which hit the country in February resulting in price rises and the
return of queues. Agriculture minister Suresh Desai' said through his
secretary he was in meeting together with his permanent secretary
Austin Sichinga.

Lloyd urged Zambians to change their eating habits and start
eating maize substitutes like sweet potatoes, rice and bread to
reduce on maize consumption.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


238 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Mozambique (DOCUMENT) Further Reforms Needed to Guarantee Freedom of Expression


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Article 19, International Centre Against Censorship (London)
October 27, 1995

London - The Mozambique government should introduce a freedom of
information law and take other steps to promote a truly independent
media, ARTICLE 19 said on 27 October 1995 in a new report published
on the anniversary of the country's first ever democratic elections.

The 30 page report, "Mozambique: Freedom of Expression and the
"Vote for Peace,"" welcomes the loosening of official controls over
the media in the run-up to, and following the election, but says that
much still needs to be done to guarantee press freedom.

"Mozambique has come a long way since the agreement which ended
three decades of bitter conflict", according to ARTICLE 19's
Director, Frances D'Souza. "The election last year was a resounding
vote for peace. But further action is needed urgently both to
guarantee freedom of expression and to address the legacy of the
past." 

ARTICLE 19 says the government should rapidly amend the defamation
law, which can be used to imprison journalists who criticise the
President or even foreign heads of state, to bring it into line with
international standards and to take account of the "public interest".
It also questions the absence of any moves to establish a Truth
Commission, like that set up in South Africa, to account for the
hundreds of thousands of Mozambicans who were victims of
"disappearance", political killing or other abuses in the past.

"Those who lost their loved ones in the war should have the right
to information, where it exists, about their fate", said Frances
D'Souza. "And this "consensus for silence", if it continues, must
not be allowed to hamper future efforts to write objective historical
accounts of the war, either in the media or in academic
institutions."

ARTICLE 19's report provides a detailed account of the conduct of
the elections and of the role played by the media, including Radio
Mozambique (RM), the main communications medium. Despite previous
measures to loosen RM's ties with the ruling FRELIMO party, close
monitoring revealed a continuing pro-FRELIMO bias in RM's coverage in
the early stages of the election campaign; however, after meetings at
which this evident bias was relayed to RM. staff a greater balance
was achieved as the campaign progressed.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


239 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Post Editor-in-Chief Wins Press Award


LENGTH: 480 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 31, 1995
by Goliath Mungonge

Lusaka - Post Editor-In-Chief Fred M'membe yesterday became the
first Zambian journalist to win the prestigious International Press
Freedom Award. M'membe and four other foreign journalists will
officially receive their awards in New York on December 6.

The occasion has been set for New York's Marriott Marquis where
United States' best and brightest journalism world honour the
winners. According to a dispatch from the Committee to Protect
Journalist (CPJ) yesterday, the award was in recognition of M'membe's
risking of political persecution and personal hardship to defy
official and unofficial attacks on the independent press in Zambia. 

"This year's winners are on the front line of the battles to
establish a free press around the world," said CPJ executive director
William Orme Jnr."Their award honour the struggle of all journalists
who risk their lives to report news."

"The award presentation is an opportunity for journalists in the
United States to support the courageous colleagues who pursue an
independent voice in the face of attacks, imprisonment, censorship
torture and murder," said Kati Marton, chair of CPJ board of
directors.

M'membe will be joined by Russian journalist Yevgeny Kislyov,
Indonesian Ahmad Taufik, Jose Ruben Zamara Marraguin of Guatemala
and Ireland's leading investigative reporter Veronica Guerin.

The award comes barely four weeks after M'membe was named the
winner of the Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) Press Freedom
award. The awards are given annually by the CPJ to journalists from
around the world who have courageously provided independent news
coverage and view points under difficult conditions.

This year's annual awards will be made by Ted Turner, head of
Turner Broadcasting System - the proprietors of CNN. CPJ is a nonabuses against the press and promote press freedom internationally
profitable and non-partisan organisation founded in 1981 to monitor
with its membership consisting of working journalists.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


240 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia Kaunda: No One Will Deport Me


LENGTH: 560 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
October 31, 1995
by Masautso Phiri

Lusaka - Former president Kenneth Kaunda has broken his silence on
continued harassment by government and declared that no one will
deport him from Zambia.

"There is no way in which anybody can deport me from Zambia and
therefore I don't know what the two Presidents (Chiluba and Muluzi)
are talking about," Kaunda said in an ex clusive interview yesterday
at his Lusaka's Kalundu residence yesterday. Kaunda was commenting
on Malawi President Bakili Muluzi's statement that Kaunda was welcome
in Malawian if he is found to be a Malawian. Muluzi said this during
a stop over at Lusaka International Airport on his way home from the
UN. 

The UNIP president was also reacting to recent statements by MMD
leaders. "My harassment is the work of little frightened men who see
nothing except defeat if I continue to lead UNIP. Otherwise I see no
logic in what they are doing," Kaunda said, adding: "They have no
moral or spiritual grounds for harassing me. Their idea is to harass
me so that out of anger I can leave active politics."

But Kaunda who declared he would not abandon the people of Zambia
for fear of his life also warned President Chiluba and Muluzi to stop
treating their countries as personal property.

"Zambia belongs to the people of Zambia and Malawi to the people
of Malawi. The two men must stop treating the two countries as if it
is personal properties," Kaunda said.

Asked about the statement of "getting rich within four years"
attributed to him by the press in Nairobi the former president said:
"It was a light hearted note, said as a joke. There will be no
vengeance in what I do when UNIP comes back to power. But certainly
the law will take its course. The innocent will be innocent," Kaunda
said on Monday, adding: "I have managed to get commitments from
investors for Zambia even in South Africa, not traders but serious
investment in industry, manufacturing and agriculture." According to
recent press reports in Nairobi Kaunda was asked what new formular he
had for resuscitating the Zambian economy.

"Formular? My colleagues who took over from me in 1991 have become
very rich in four years. They must have a good formular. I will ask
them to tell me what this formular is so that I can give it to every
Zambian to become rich in four years," Kaunda is said to have told
Kenyan journalists.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


241 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Mauritius (DOCUMENT) Letter to Prime Minister Jugnauth


LENGTH: 960 words


 
Committee to Protect Journalists (New York)
October 31, 1995

New York - Honorable Sir Anerood Jugnauth Prime Minister and
Minister of the Interior Office of the Prime Minister. Your
Excellency, The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) writes to
protest the persecution of Namassiwayam Ramalingum, editor of the
weekly L'Independent, by Muslim extremists and Your Excellency's
inaction toward bringing his attackers to justice.

Ramalingum remains in hiding and his paper closed since his May 29
return to Mauritius from Britain where he fled in March. We believe
police response to the following incidents has been unsatisfactory:

On March 10, a group of civilians bought all copies of
L'Independent in the predominantly Muslim Plaine Verte area of the
capital Port Louis and publicly burned them. The organizers of this
display declared a prohibition on selling future copies of
L'Ind?pendent in that area. Police made no response. 

On March 12, L'Independent's printing presses were firebombed and
L'Independent's office set on fire. Guards were placed in front of
the offices, and Ramalingum provided police protection for only two
weeks, after which time he was advised by the Police Commissioner to
flee the country. An investigation was said to have been launched,
but no findings were reported. It is believed the perpetrators are
known to the authorities.

On March 16, a group of people held an unauthorized public
demonstration in Port Louis, calling all followers of Allah to murder
Ramalingum and his family. While police had license plate numbers of
some of the rally's speakers, no arrests were made.

On March 17, Muslim leader Maulana Haroon issued a fatwa (death
edict) against Ramalingum. The fatwa remains in effect; his
photograph has been circulated in all the city's mosques and a
citizen death squad was formed. At this public gathering, which
approximately 3,000 people attended, Haroon challenged the authority
of the Police Commissioner and the Special Mobile Forces to protect
Ramalingum, his family and his colleagues.

Since his return from Britain, Ramalingum has been followed and
threatened. His colleagues have also been harassed in his attackers'
pursuit to track him down. The police have yet to act on any of his
numerous reports and provide police protection.

It is believed these attacks stem from a March 10 article in
L'Independent reprinted from the October 1, 1994 issue of the French
magazine Le Point entitled "The True Life of Mohammad" about the
growth of Islam. Both L'Independent and Le Point are circulated in
Algeria, Tunisia and other predominantly Muslim countries where
reportedly no offense at the article was taken. Because L'Independent
has taken a definitive position against government and corporate
corruption and drug-trafficking, CPJ fears its persecution is
politically motivated.

As a nonpartisan group of journalists committed to the defense of
its colleagues, CPJ is deeply concerned about Your Excellency's
apparent reluctance to respond to the aforementioned attacks against
Ramalingum and L'Independent. Mediation efforts by the European
Union, several European ambassadors, and international journalistsour contention that this unwillingness violates Ramalingum's right to
rights organizations were met by Your Excellency's inattention. It is
free expression, a right guaranteed in Article 19 of the Universal
Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19 of the International Covenant
on Civil and Political Rights, and Article 9 of the African Charter
on Human and Peoples' Rights, all to which, we remind Your
Excellency, Mauritius is a signatory.

Furthermore, we draw Your Excellency's attention to the 1991
Windhoek Declaration on Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic
African Press, which fellow members of the Southern African
Development Community have adopted. CPJ holds Your Excellency's
government accountable to this declaration and the international
treaties.

CPJ calls on Your Excellency to intervene and urge Haroon to
publicly withdraw the fatwa, to bring Ramalingum's attackers to
justice, and to safeguard the right of all journalists in Mauritius
to pursue their work, free from danger.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely, William A. Orme, Jr. Executive Director


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


242 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Nigeria (DOCUMENT) Letter to General Abacha


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Committee to Protect Journalists (New York)
October 27, 1995

His Excellency General Sani Abacha and His Excellency Michael
Agbamuche. Your Excellency: The Committee to Protect Journalists
(CPJ) is writing to reiterate its call for the unconditional and
immediate release of the four journalists imprisoned since May.

Chris Anyanwu, publisher and editor in chief of The Sunday
Magazine and Ben Charles Obi, editor of Weekend Classique were given
life imprisonment sentences in July after being tried before a
military tribunal. Kunle Ajibade, executive editor of The News and
George Mbah, an assistant editor of Tell magazine, whose sentences
were unconfirmed, were also detained since mid-May and tried behind
closed doors by the military tribunal. All were among 42 people
charged for their suspected complicity in an alleged March coup
attempt. 

On October 10, it was announced that the Provisional Ruling
Council amended the sentences of all four journalists to fifteen
years in prison.

We remain particularly concerned about Mbah and Ajibade, whose
health continues to fail, and about the personal safety of Anyanwu,
one of two women brought before the military tribunal. We are
disturbed that all the prisoners are living in sub-standard
conditions, enduring maltreatment and torture, and denied medical
attention. Finally, we are extremely concerned that several of these
prisoners have reportedly been moved from Lagos to a prison in the
northeast whose conditions are worse than the prison in Lagos.

As a nonpartisan group of journalists committed to the defense of
its colleagues, CPJ remains resolute in its call for the immediate
and unconditional release of these journalists. We believe their
arrests were based solely on their legitimate work as journalists.
Their rights to the freedom of expression are guaranteed in the
Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on
Civil and Political Rights, and the African Charter on Human and
Peoples' Rights, all to which, we remind Your Excellency, Nigeria is
a signatory. Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely, William A. Orme, Jr., Executive Director


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


243 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October, 1995


Zambia The Folly of Zambia's 'Nationality Witch-Hunt


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 654 words


 
The Post Of Zambia
October 27, 1995
By Carolyn Mwanza

It is incredible yet discomfortingly true that our government has
drawn up a list of people which it is seriously contemplating
deporting to Malawi. Most of men and women on the list were born in
this country. They have grown up, married and raised their families
here. They have in one way or another contributed to the political,
social and economic development of this country. Their roots are
here, and they know of no other country as their home other than
Zambia. 

I cannot recall one single instance when our leadership was as
deceitful, foolhardy and hypocritical as in this particular instance
in which it sees un Zambianness in some of its own nationals.

Certainly it is not that the people on the list are criminals,
neither have they been shown to be of doubtful loyalty, questionable
patriotism or casual and dubious commitment to the good cause of the
country. They just happened to have opened their mouths a little
wider than most and spoken their minds, as is their right, on issues
that affect our lives.

But this is not the real reason. These unfortunate people are
merely sacrificial lambs, or blinders as it were, to regularise and
justify the eventual deportation of Kaunda. Kaunda's crime is not
that he is not a Zambian but that he and UNIP under his leadership
provide the only possible and credible alternative to the MMD
government.

The folly and senselessness in this whole exercise is that it will
not end with the deportations of a few people to Malawi. Next it will
be those we decide or suspect to be Mozambican, Tanzanian, Zairean,
Zimbabwean or Indian and so on.

Already at the Miss Independence pageant in Kitwe, four 'coloured'
girls couldn't be allowed to participate in the competitions on mere
suspicions of their true nationality.

The witch-hunt could go on indefinitely as questions will be
raised to ascertain the true nationality of people occupying senior
positions in the civil service, army, air force, police and other
government institutions. The unrest and disruptions that will ensue
is unthinkable and frightening. When a people as a nation begin to
question each other's place of origin and ethnicity, you might as
well conclude that there is a very serious problem of insecurity and
envy. The end result of this problem is usually ethnic or tribal
discrimination and national disharmony leading to civil strife.

It is therefore very difficult to believe that the MMD leadership
feels so helplessly insecure that it is totally blind to the grave
consequences to the national social order there will be if it goes to
such lengths to continue to stay in power.

The country stands to pay too high a price for its leadership's
sense of insecurity.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


244 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 1510 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 10, 1995 (19951110)
by Olu Sarr PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin's
assassination attracted considerabe sympathy from many African
newspapers, one of which eulogized him as a "warrior among
warriors who chose the path of peace."

The Guardian of Lagos said "Israel has lost a brave leader, a
patriot and an icon."

It noted that in his fight for peace Rabin brought to this
cause the same strength and intelligence with which he had
distinguished himself as a soldier.

"The purpose of the assassination is to undermine the peace
process but Rabin's death will not erase his achievements," it
said. 

Brushing aside its usual satirical tone, the Ouagadougou
weekly, Le Journal Du Jeudi, compared the death to that of a dove.

"The peace for which Rabin has sacrificed his life will not be
burried with him," it said, meaning the process will go on.

However, it said that the Mideast peace effort may be boxed in
by Jewish and Arab extremists, a situation from which it will be
very difficult to extricate.

A privately-owned daily from the same city, Le Pays, said that
Rabin's death should mark the final stage in making the peace
process between Palestinians and Jews irreversible.

Several papers questioned Israel's future following the
slaying. The Ouagadougou weekly, Le Clef, said the assassination
could push back the peace process between Israel and the Arab
countries.

It, however, said Rabin's demise could also bolster the desire
to rid this region of violence once and for all.

His death, the Kinshasa weekly La Societe said, "should be a
lesson to politicians the world over, who refuse to understand,
that sensible nations now aspire to peace."

It and other papers questioned the legendary efficiency of the
Israeli security apparatus.

"How can it be explained that none of the prime minister's body
gaurds opened fire on the terrorist?" L'observateur Paalga, of
Ouagadougou, said.

For their part, papers in Tripoli, the Libyan capital,
condemned the presence of two Arab leaders and the representative
of five other Arab countries at Rabin's funeral.

"Arab officials who attended the funeral have betrayed the
martyrs of the Arab nation," Al-Fajr Al-Jadid said.

Al-Chams, attacked Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and
Jordan's King Hussein for eulogising in English rather than in
their native Arab language, as other world leaders had done in
theirs.

Abidjan's and Accra's privately-owned dailies, La Paix and the
Ghanaian Chronicle, said Rabin's death showed he was on the right
path and the peace process should be supported by all nations.

"Premier Rabin's death will become a tragic one only if those
he has left behind are not able to sustain the peace efforts," the
Chronicle said.

"The only question now is whether Mr. Peres (will have a free
hand from the considerably influential military), to continue the
peace process," La Paix added. Shimon Peres is Israel's interim
prime minister.

Nairobi's Kenya Times said the killing put the entire MIddle
East peace process "under a severe litmus test". The sole
consolation peace searchers had, it continued, was the assurance
by Shimon Peres that "the road to peace is at a point of no
return."

Adding to this, the paper said "The powers of peace remain
stronger for a better Israel and Palestine."

It said there was more to the assassination than simply "orders
from God" and that "perhaps the subsequent police inquiry will
reveal something more than that ridiculous statement," made by the
killer, Yigal Amir.

One Lagos daily, ThisDay, said, "Rabin may have been silenced
by the assassin's bullet but peace in the Middle East must be the
fitting honour to a life-lived."

It continued: "Now the path of the future must be devoid of the
screeching mortars, the whining of shells and the clatter of
machine guns. So did Yitzhak Rabin want it; so should it be.
Adieu."
-0


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


245 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 24, 1995 (19951124)
by Olu Sarr PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, SENEGAL - Fallout from the hanging of nine Ogoni
minority rights activists in Nigeria November 10 continues from
irate or otherwise troubled African newspapers.

"The Nigerian state could not convince the world that it killed
criminals; it killed people with a cause, a just cause, and
therein lies the difference," A.M. News, of Lagos, said.

"Government and its defenders have since made a noise or two
about laws dealing with murder not being subjected to
international standards. We beg to disagree. No country is an
island, and Nigeria should not be seen as one," it added. 

The privately-owned daily, recalled government's justication of
the hanging was that the nine had murdered four other Ogoni
leaders.

"We at A.M. News believe that murder must be punished but only
through justice," it said.

Recalling sanctions against Nigeria, visa restrictions against
its citizens, and the country's suspension from the Commonwealth,
as well as a freeze in foreign investments in the country, it
said: "Today Nigeria is a pariah without equal in the entire
world. One diminutive man from Ogoni and his comrades have ensured
that."

Another private Lagos daily, Third Eye, said about Nigeria,
"What we are witnessing right (now) is, we admit, not entirely the
fault of the Abacha regime."

His government, it said, "inherited an unviable and unenviable"
political economy.

The beginning of the country's current predicament and Abacha's
many headaches, it claimed, are firmly anchored in the military12 June 1993.
contrived annulment of the now proverbial presidential election of

"We make this point in order to put in bold relief and proper
perspective the current spate of sanctions against the Abacha
regime," it said.

But government, it noted, had been "visibly shaken by the
hurricane of trenchant criticisms" and multiple sanctions.

The regime was, to all appearances, counting on the historic or
traditional ties with some western countries, in particular Great
Britain. It said, too, that the regime may also have expected to
exploit "the legendary western double-speak, double-standards and
hypocrisy" to wriggle out of an admittedly tight corner. But none
of these expectations was met.

"The Abacha regime and, by the play of logic, Nigeria --
hitherto Africa's most respected country -- have been stripped
naked at the bar of global opinion. And the verdict is, to say the
least, unflattering," it said.

"Given the importance of Nigeria in the community of nations
and the movement, worldwide, to liberal democracy and respect for
fundamental liberities, our leaders should not expect the world to
leave us alone, to our whims, caprices and fancies. In a nutshell,
Nigeria is too important a country, however one looks at her, to
be ignored."

It concluded: "We are happy that the head of state, both in his
1 October independence anniversary speech and in subsequent
pronouncements said his administration had not closed the door to
other views aside government's."

That willingness for dialogue, it may seem, proded the
government to send a delegation to London to explain the hangings
to the British government.

But the Senegalese daily, Sud Quotidien, explained it
differently. It said that the military junta had realised that "it
can break a rope by pulling too hard on it" therefore, it had to
ease up on its tough approach.

But this behaviour of acting tough -- the executions -- then
stepping back after the act -- the delegation to London in an
attempt to appease the world -- its said, was just part of
miltiary political brinksmanship.

Then, it attacked Shell Oil for appearing to be the spokesman
of the Nigerian government. Rather than reacting to accusatiion
that Shell was partially responsible for the death of the nine
Ogonis, it said, the oil company had started giving the
international community moral lessons by telling them that
sanctions against it and Nigeria were illconceived.

But, the paper went on, "What is really unacceptable, is the
situation in which the Ogonis find themselves and in which Shell
has played a significant role."
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


246 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Trading on Zimbabwe Stock Exchange Depressed


LENGTH: 280 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 21, 1995 (19951121)

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Local and foreign investors on the
Zimbabwean stock market have adopted a wait-and-see attitude amid
rising concern about the delay to the onset of the 1995/96 rainy
season, stockbrokers said on Monday.

They said in interviews trading was characterised by
nervousness, prompting many investors to sit on the sidelines. 

This contradicts the trend two weeks ago when the market surged
in response to the first scattered showers that fell in most parts
of the country.

The 1995-96 rainy season, which was expected to start in
earnest last week, has not yet shown a clear-cut trend, although
weather experts still believe the country will experience a normal
season.

Due to uncertainty in the market, worsened by disappointing
corporate results released in the last two weeks, the key
industrial index has plunged below the psychological barrier of
4,000 to close at 3,973 on Friday.
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


247 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


New Labour Policy Protested


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 21, 1995 (19951121)

JOHANNESBURG - Lesotho, completely surrounded by South Africa,
has protested against a new South African policy on migrant labor.

The decision by the South Africa late October to grant
permanent residence to some mineworkers from neighboring states
has triggered the sharp reaction. 

The government of Lesotho says it is worried the policy will
cause it a serious financial loss. Its largest source of hard
currency is the money sent home by Lesotho citizens working in
South African mines as migrant labor.

Migrant laborers who have lived and worked in South Africa
since 1986 would be given residence status, according to the new
policy. This could result in many investing their savings in South
Africa instead of sending them back home.

Appearing on South African television Sunday night, Lesotho's
Minister of Finance, Moeketsi Senaoana, said there had also been a
brain-drain of top professionals from Lesotho into South Africa.
-0Zimbabwe


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


248 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Food Needs Revised in 12 Nations


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 21, 1995 (19951121)
HARARE, Zimbabwe - There has been a significant drop in estimates
of drought relief food needs for Southern African Development
Community countries suffering from another devastating drought,
the regional early warning unit says.

The Zimbabwe-based unit said the region's emergency food
requirements in 1995/96 dropped from an initial forecast of 7.1
million tons to 3.9 million tons of aid.

SADC is an economic grouping of 12 countries, all of them
except Mauritius in drought-prone southern Africa. 

The reduction in food needs in the region was due largely to a
change in South African estimates. The shortfall there had dropped
from 3 million tons to 532,000 tons, the unit said in a report.

SADC said South Africa's revised figures where a result of
factors including a 700,000-ton decrease in consumption estimates.

There was also the reduction in cereal stocks by 1.3 million
tons, to be carried forward to the next season.

Tanzania, which expected a shortfall of 444,000 tons, was now
predicting a surplus of 116,000 tons, while Zambia had dropped its
requirement by 260,000 tons.

But for Zimbabwe the shortfall had risen, with harvest figures
falling 116,000 tons below original estimates.

Although South Africa would have to import staple white maize
for domestic consumption it had excess yellow maize for export to
other countries in the region.

All SADC countries were, however, expected to import wheat,
with the greatest shortfalls of 242,000 tons and 427,000 tons in
Zimbabwe and South Africa, respectively.

Meanwhile, there was general concern within SADC over the poor
response from the international community to the appeal for food
aid made in June this year. Only 476,000 tons of food aid was
pledged by mid-August.

"Greater reliance would have to be placed not only on strategic
grain reserves but on commercial imports which would be
detrimental to the region's economic adjustment programmes," the
unit said.
-0Lesotho and South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


249 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


OAU Satisfied With Elections


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 21, 1995 (19951121)

DAKAR, Senegal - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) has
said it is satisfied with the way Algeria's last week's
presidential elections were conducted.

"The elections took place in a calm atmosphere, in freedom and
transparency," the 53-nation organization said in a statement to
PANA Monday. 

It said the facilities in place were "excellent" and voters
turned out in "very large numbers" on Thursday.

The OAU sent in a 50-member observer mission at the invitation
of the Algerian government.

Last Friday Algerian President Laimine Zeroual described the
outcome as a "victory for democracy" and pledged to work for all
in the strife-torn country.

"I will be the President of all Algerians," he said.

He won 61.34 per cent of the votes, making a second round
ballot unnecessary.

The candidate for the Movement for the Islamic Society (Hamas),
Mahfoudh Nahnah, got 25.38 percent of the votes; the Rally for
Culture and Democracy's Said Saadi 9.29 percent; and the Algerian
Party for Renewal's Nourredine Boukrouh 3.7 percent.

The extremist Armed Islamic Group boycotted the polls. This
group has waged a terror campaign against authorities in recent
years.

Following Zeroual's victory, some leaders of the radical
Islamic Salvation Front said they wanted talks with Zeroual to end
the feud between them.

"We are prepared to enter into talks with the government so as
to contribute to the return of peace in Algeria," said Rabah
Kebir, a leading member of the front living in exile.

However, others in the organization are opposed to any
reconciliation.

"Liamine Zeroual's election is the confirmation of a
masquerade," said Anouar Haddam, another exiled leader
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


250 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Government Endorses Carter's Mediation


LENGTH: 614 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 21, 1995 (19951121)

KIGALI, Rwanda - Still shattered by the sight of skulls of
massacre victims in a Rwandan church, former U.S. President Jimmy
Carter Monday expressed hope that forthcoming talks in Cairo will
bring lasting peace to the region.

Carter announced in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, that the
government here had officially agreed to participate in the summit
next week to resolve the crises in the so-called Great Lakes
region.

Addressing a news conference here, Carter hoped the meeting, to
be held in Cairo from 28 November to 2 December, will have a
limited agenda, the Rwandan News Agency (ARP) reported. 

Mr.Carter, who will be the summit's chief mediator, said he
hoped the meeting would encourage the quick return of genuine
Rwandan refugees and an end to intimidation within refugee camps
in Tanzania and Zaire.

An estimated two million Rwandan Hutu refugees have been living
in camps in Rwanda and Tanzania since the massacres which
followed the death of President Juvenal Habyariamana in a plane
crash on April 6, 1994.

He said the meeting will discuss ways of stopping the flow of
arms to the refugee camps. He hoped the discussions will build up
support for the Arusha International Tribunal which is expected to
try the perpetrators of genocide in Rwanda.

Other mediators at the summit will be former Tanzanian
President Julius Nyerere and Archbishop Desmond Tutu of Cape Town,
South Africa.

The summit is expected to be attended by the presidents of
Burundi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire.

Carter told journalists that among the sights that stuck in his
mind during his two-day visit in Rwanda were the skulls he saw at
the altar of Ntarama Parish Church near Kigali.

At least 5,000 people were butchered at Ntarama church during
last year's genocide in which up to one million people, mostly
from the minority Tutsi ethnic group and moderates from the
majority Hutu were massacred by extremists.

Remains of the dead are still inside the church.

Carter said that representatives of non-government
organizations and human rights groups had confirmed to him that
conditions inside Rwanda were ripe for the return of refugees.

The former President and his wife Rosalyn left for Bujumbura
where he will hold similar talks before returning to Uganda. He
will also visit Zaire.
-0Algeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


251 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Bank Failures: Government Moves To Protect Depositors


LENGTH: 547 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 21, 1995 (19951121)
by Mildred Mulenga PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian government has taken stringent
measures to protect bank depositors in the wake of the collapse of
two of the country's major banks within a year.

Finance Minister Ronald Penza has issued new regulations to
back up the current banking and financial services and plug
loopholes in the banking industry.

Under new regulations, banks and financial institutions will be
compelled to surrender 50 per cent of their profits to a reserve
fund before declaring dividends to ensure that the liquidity of
any bank matches its paid-up equity capital. 

Finance houses will also be forced to make returns to the
central bank of unclaimed funds in their suspense accounts whose
owners cannot be traced.

In addition, they must disclose to their customers and the
public all charges in respect of deposit accounts for all the
services rendered.

Government has also raised the initial capital required for
anybody to set up a bank

The review of the country's banking laws follows the closure of
two indigenous banks this year.
Last week, the central bank ordered the closure of Africa
Commercial Bank because of liquidity problems caused by unchecked
insider borrowing.
Meridien BIAO bank, which was the fourth largest bank in Zambia
with over 40,000 deposit accounts, was forced into compulsory
liquidation last September after it collapsed last year.
It has not been able to give depositors their money despite
earlier promises that this was to be done within six months of the
bank's fall.
In 1992 the government liberalized the money market leading to a
proliferation of banks, most of which are feared to be on the
verge of ruin due to increased competition on the money market.
Zambia has 15 major banks and several finance houses, mostly
privately-owned.
Finance experts say the number banks are too large to be
sustained by the country's depressed economy.
-0Rwanda


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

the Cairo meeting will deal with the issues of refugees and crossThe presidents of Burundi, Rwanda, Tanzaniaand Zaire are
border security in the GreatLakes region.
expected to attend the Cairo summit.

Mandela Calls for Southern African Summit on Nigeria


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 21, 1995 (19951121)

PRETORIA, South Africa - South African President Nelson Mandela
has called for a southern African summit to consider possible
action against Nigeria following the execution of nine minority
activists including author Kena Saro-Wiwa.

Mandela told journalists Monday night he had asked President
Ketumire Masire of Botswana, current chairman of the 2-nation
Southern African Development Community (SADC), to call a meeting. 

There was, however, no indication as to when when the meeting
could be held.

SADC is an economic grouping of 12 states including all
southern African countries and Mauritius.

South Africa, United States and 15 members of the European
Union have withdrawn their envoys from Nigeria and slapped an arms
embargo against the West African nation in protest.

Meanwhile, the South African government is awaiting a response
from Shell (South Africa) on the future of the oil company's
activities in Nigeria.

he government says it expects Shell to pressurize the Nigerian
mitary regime.

Mandela has said he was unahappy at the company's silence on
abuses of human rights in Nigeria.
The company has been a major target of attack by the activists,
including Saro-Wiwa, for its involvement in the environmental
damage of the oil-producing areas in southeastern Nigeria.

254 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Lusaka City Stops Mourners from Laying Plastic Wreaths


LENGTH: 547 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 22, 1995 (19951122)
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - As part of the Zambian capital's 'keep the
city clean' and anti-pollution campaigns, Lusaka City Council has
stopped the mourners from laying plastic wreaths at the city's
cemeteries.

Saying they were "dirty" and contrary to the council's
environmental regulations, the city fathers threatened to sweep
clean any graves bedecked with plastic flowers. The flowers would
then be torched. "We shall collect and destroy all the plastic
wreaths at council cemeteries if the public refuse to cooperate,"
said council spokesman Daniel M'soka. 

Officials at the Environmental Council of Zambia (ECZ)
responsible for enforcing the country's environment laws supported
the city's move, declaring the wreaths and plastics in general as
an environmental "nuisance".

The move has however angered wreath sellers, mostly young men
and women who say they make a roaring business selling them.

"The Council should stop being funny. Who says they can speak
for the dead. This is a free economy and anybody is free to use
their initiative to make ends meet," said Charles Tembo, one of
the regular vendors. The plastic wreaths, costing a few cents
each, are assembled using multi-colored pieces of plastic paper,
which are in some cases, picked up from streets.

Funeral wreaths are a relatively new rite among indigenous
Zambians but are now seen as a status symbol for bereaved
families.

A Catholic priest in Lusaka two years ago raised a storm when
he suggested that Zambians were being "brain-washed" into adopting
Western life-styles. He condemned plastic wreaths as irrelevant,
saying they had nothing to do with the honour or social status of
both the dead or the surviving friends and relatives.

The Christian churches, to which most Zambians belong,
generally recommend fresh twigs for wreaths to symbolize life at
ressurection.

Meanwhile, the Lusaka city council insists that if anybody
feels so strongly about "honoring" their departed ones by placing
wreaths on the graves, only natural flowers will be accepted.
-0Nigeria and South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

November, 1995


Chiluba Supports Sanctions Against Nigeria


LENGTH: 427 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 22, 1995 (19951122)
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's President Frederick Chiluba has added
his voice to the international campaign calling for sanctions
against the Nigerian military regime in protest against its human
rights abuses.

Chiluba said Wednesday only economic sanctions could eventually
bring the regime to its knees and force it to restore democratic
governance. 

He said that while it might take long for sanctions to yield
the desired results, they were the most viable course of action
capable of bringing down the military regime.

"Some people might think Nigeria is too economically powerful
for sanctions, but look at what happened to the apartheid regime
in South Africa," he said in reference to the international
sanctions generally credited for forcing the white minority
regime to agree to a new democratic South Africa.

Nigeria was recently suspsended from the 53-member Commonwealth
of Nations following the execution of nine minority rights
activists in defiance of international appeals for clememcy.

Commonwealth leaders meeting in Auckland, New Zealand, gave the
regime led by Gen. Sani Abacha two years to return the country to
democracy or face expulsion from the club which groups Britain and
mostly its former colonies.

South African President Nelson Mandela is spearheading the
sanctions campaign against Nigeria. His government has recalled
its ambassador to Nigeria and withdrawn an invitation to the
Nigerian national football team to participate in a four-nation
international soccer tournament now taking place in South Africa.
-0Zambia

256 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Military Rulers Seek World's Understanding


LENGTH: 667 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 22, 1995 (19951122)
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian military rulers decided in a crucial
meeting late Tuesday to spruce up the country's image abroad.

They said they now have to explain themselves to "friendly
countries" that might have been misled into taking tough action
against their country after the recent hanging of nine minority
rights activists.

It was the first meeting of the country's 26-member Provisional
Ruling Council (PRC), chaired by Gen. Sani Abacha, since the Nov.
10 executions of the nine Ogoni ethnic minority leaders. 

The hangings unleashed international condemnations and
sanctions against Nigeria.

PRC member Commodore Victor Ombu said after the council's
meeting with the 30 state military administrators that they had
reviewed Nigeria's external relations, among other issues.

He said "government resolved to educate our friends, those we
think that were hoodwinked into taking these positions."

On the country's recent suspension from the Commonwealth, he
said "we respect the organisation, we are part of it and it is our
responsibility to make ourselves clear."

The 53-member British-led Commonwealth suspended Nigeria after
the hangings of the nine Ogoni leaders, including the author Ken
Saro-Wiwa. The nine were found guilty by a special tribunal of
murdering four other Ogoni leaders opposed to their Movement for
the Survival of the Ogoni People.

The movement led a campaign against environmental damage to
Ogoni territory in south-eastern Nigeria caused by oil production.
It singled out the Nigerian government and the oil giant Shell as
the main culprits.

The Commonwealth gave Nigeria two years to return to democratic
rule or face expulsion from the organisation.

But the PRC spokesman said the Abacha government would stick to
its three-year programme, ending in Oct. 1998, to return Nigeria
to democratic rule.

Fifteen European Union member-countries, South Afria, and the
United States recalled their envoys from Lagos and imposed arms
embargoes on Nigeria in protest against the executions.

Nigeria retaliated by calling home its ambassadors from these
countries. Foreign minister Tom Ikimi also announced a government
plan to review Nigeria's "Africa-first" foreign policy in view of
the international clampdown against it.

Meanwhile, thousands of Nigerians attended Tuesday a proThe demonstrators criticized Britain, the United States and
government rally in Abuja, the capital.
President Nelson Mandela of South Africa for trying to isolate
Nigeria.
-0Nigeria and Zambia

November, 1995


Improved Economic Outlook


LENGTH: 240 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 22, 1995 (19951122)

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa is experiencing the
lowest inflation rate in 23 years.

The rate -- of 6.3 percent -- is being maintained and the
economic outlook for the country is showing a distinct
improvement, according to latest official statistics. 

Figures released by the Central Statistical Service here show
that the inflation rate dropped from 6.4 percent in September to
6.3 percent in October. Leading economic analysts say that latest
statistics were prompting a growing belief that the South African
economy is on track to raise growth and maintain stability.

Given current trends, economists are of the opinion that
inflation could drop to below five per cent while real economic
growth could rise to almost four per cent in 1996, compared with
the projected three percent for 1995.
-0Nigeria

Africa News


November, 1995


Mwinyi Bids Farewell As Tanzanians Await New President


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 22, 1995 (19951122)
by Lwaga Mwambande PANA Correspondent

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania - Tanzania's outgoing President Ali
Hassan Mwinyi Wednesday bid farewell to his compatriots at a grand
ceremony held here a day before the installation of his successor,
Benjamin William Mkapa.

Mkapa and his party, Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM) or Party of the
Revolution, polled 60 percent in the presidential elections held
on Oct. 29 and repeated Nov. 19 in Dar es Salaam, the capital. 

CCM, which has ruled Tanzania since 1977 when it was formed,
polled 80 percent of the vote in the parliamentary elections. The
remaining 20 per cent of the 232-seat National Assembly seats have
been taken by several opposition parties that took part in the
first multiparty polls since the United Republic of Tanzania was
formed 31 years ago following a merger of mainland Tanganyika with
neighboring Indian Ocean island of Zanzibar.

In his speech to thousands of people at the national stadium
here, Mwinyi paid tribute to Tanzania's founder president, Julius
Nyerere, saying his sound advise enabled him to deal with
difficult situations during his term of office.

"When you voted for me for the presidency 10 years ago, I
compared the father of the nation with Mount Kilimanjaro (the
highest mountain in Africa) and myself as an ant-hill when it came
to leadership. I still hold the same sentiments," Mwinyi said.

He said Nyerere's advice, particularly during the last three
years of his rule enabled him to relinguish the presidency while
the country was peaceful.
-0South Africa

TRIPOLI, Libya - Experts say Algeria could see a major rise in

Official figures just released show that revenues could be up
one billion dollars from 1995.

The experts say that Algeria, a member of the Organization of
Petroleum Exporting Countries, plans to reach the 10.4 billion
dollar goal by increasing oil extraction.

By the year 2000 Algeria could produce one million barrels of
oil per day, compared to the 750,000 barrels currently produced in
the Hassi Massaoud oilfields, located in the south.

November, 1995


Netherlands Will Help Fight Corruption in Zambia


LENGTH: 307 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 23, 1995 (19951123)

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Netherlands government pledged to help
Zambia fight corruption that could derail the country's democratic
process and ruin society.

Netherlands Ambassador to Zambia Jan Peter Dijkstra Thursday
donated 5,000 dollars to help the Anti-Corruption Commission fund
its program that aims to educate the public about how corruption
contributes to widespread poaching of the country's wild animals. 

Justice Robert Kapembwa of the commission said that separate
from the police force, independent institutions like the ACC could
most effectively deal with corruption in African countries.

Kapembwa said corruption facilitated the current situation of
rampant poaching in Zambia.

Zambian security officials said that most commercial poaching
is masterminded by high-ranking officials who work with foreign
agents to poach mainly elephant and rhino for their tusks and
horns.
Whereas rhino horns are said to be used as an aphrodisiac in
East Asian countries, elephant tusks are sold to rich sheiks in
the Middle East.

November, 1995


Opposition Leader Excluded From Elections


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 23, 1995 (19951123)

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast - The constitutional council of the Ivory
Coast has confirmed that a leading opposition leader, Djeni Kobina
Kouame, cannot stand as a candidate in forthcoming parliamentary
elections.

Kouame is being barred under the same rules that were used to
stop viable candidates from standing in the October presidential
election. 

The secretary general of the opposition Republican Rally wanted
to stand in Ajame constituency in Abidjan, the country's economic
capital, in the polls slated for Nov. 26.

The council, whose task is to ensure that all aspiring
candidates are Ivorians whose parents were also Ivorian by birth,
ruled Wednesday that both of his parents were Ghanaians.

The requirement is contained in the controversial Article 77 of
the Ivorian electoral code, which prevented viable candidates from
standing against the incumbent President Henri Konan Bedie in the
polls of Oct. 22.

Among these were former Prime Minister Alassane Ouattara whose
parents are said to have migrated to Ivory Coast from Burkina
Faso.

The presidential polls were boycotted by all the major
opposition parties who attempted to disrupt them using violence.
Bedie went on to win the polls with a huge majority against
Francis Wodie, the lone opposition candidate who stood.

The council rejected Kouame's nationality affidavit, saying it
it was "issued under irregular circumstances".

"Even if the certificate was reliable, it would only prove his
own nationality, not that of his parents who are Ghanaians," said
Noel Nemin, the constitutional council chairman.

He said a commission of inquiry set up by a judge in Bassam
discovered that both Djeny's parents were of Ghanaian origin.
-0Zambia

Africa News


November, 1995


Goods Now Moving Along Beira Corridor


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 23, 1995 (19951123)

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe - The flow of traffic along the Beira
Corridor, the supply line that connects Mozambique to neighboring
countries, has resumed after coming to a halt in September when
Mozambican customs began enforcing rigid procedures to curb
smuggling.

According to the Beira Corridor Group (BCG), Mozambican
authorities returned to normal customs procedures after
representations by the Mozambique ports, railways and freight
agents based at the port of Beira. 

"Customs retained the right, however, to inspect contents of
containers which they suspect are being used to smuggle goods into
Mozambique," BCG said.

Mozambican customs launched a crackdown on smuggling and
demanded that road cargo in transit through the country be
accompanied by a customs officer. This resulted in long delays due
to a shortage of customs personnel.

Angered by delays, trucking companies refused to carry
containers under this procedure for which agents were charged an
additional 200 U.S. dollars per container.

BCG said the delays were also aggravated when Mozambican
customs began to open and inspect every transit container going to
Malawi and randomly inspected containers going to Zimbabwe,
irrespective of whether or not there was a customs escort.
-0Ivory Coast

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


-0South Africa (tx Panafrican News Agency November 23, 1995 (19951123) ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast - King Juan Carlos of Spain and former United States President Jimmy Carter have won this year's Felix Houphouet-Boigny peace prize, the official Ivorian news agency AIP reported Thursday. It said King Carlos would receive the prize for helping Spain's transition from dictatorship to democracy while Carter would be honored for his efforts to help bring peace to troubled parts of the world, including Africa. The prize-giving ceremony will be held Dec. 5 at the Paris headquarters of the United Nations Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organization (Unesco). The prize was first awarded in 1991, to South African President Nelson Mandela. Other winners include recently assassinated Israeli Prime Minister Yitzak Rabin; his successor Shimon Peres, then Minister of Foreign Affairs; and Chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization Yasser Arafat. The yearly prize honors people and institutions making significant contributions to world peace. Draft of New Constitution Released


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 23, 1995 (19951123)
by Lionel Williams PANA Staff Correspondent

PRETORIA, South Africa - After 18 months in the works, South
Africa released the first full draft of its new constitution.

During the launching of the draft Wednesday, chairman of the
Constitutional Assembly Cyril Ramaphosa said the document was "a
report-back to the nation." The four million copies of the 63-page
working draft will be printed in South Africa's 11 official
languages.

Ramphosa said the document is a bridge to future democracy,
peace, development and respect for human rights. He added it would
ensure that the injustices of the past in South Africa were not
repeated.

The Constitutional Assembly will take into consideration public
feedback until Feb. 20, 1996, and will then finalize the
constitution for formal adoption on May 9, 1996, the deadline set
in the country's interim constitution.

The draft constitution, which is written in English, is split
into 15 chapters covering founding provisions, bill of rights,
parliament, a council of provinces, the national executive, courts
and administration of justice.

It also specifies the role of state institutions that support
constitutional democracy and the competency of the provincial and
national legislative and executive bodiess, local government,
traditional authorities, public administration, security services
and financial institutions.

The new constitution, however, will be enforced in May of 1999
when a new South African government is elected.
-0Zimbabwe

LANGUAGE: English

264 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Envoy Warns Against Anti-Nigeria Actions


LENGTH: 1147 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 23, 1995 (19951123)
by Segun Adeyemi PANA Correspondent

New York (USA) -- Pushing the United Nations to act against
Nigeria over the recent executions of minority rights activists
would amount to a misuse of the organization, Nigeria's Permanent
Representative to the world body, Ibrahim Gambari, said Thursday.

He told a news conference at the U.N. headquarters in New York
that Nigeria was ready to enter into dialogue with the United
States, which is leading the campaign against his country at the
United Nations.

The Nov. 10 executions for murder of nine Ogoni minority
leaders, including author Ken Saro-Wiwa, have unleashed
international condemnations and anti-Nigeria sanctions.

But Gambari said "what I am worried about is the misuse of
international organizations such as (the United Nations) to
contravene its own charter provision on non-interference in what
is essentially within the domestic jurisdiction of member states." 

He was referring to the U.N. General Assembly draft resolutions
proposing various actions against Nigeria.

The envoy said the executions did not "belong in the Security
Council", apparently in reference to statements by Washington that
it was holding consultations aimed at getting the council to
consider sanctions on Nigeria.

Gambari added, "Nothing that has been done constitutes a threat
to international peace and security."

He said "Nigeria did not invade any country. We did not kill
any foreigner."

Saro-Wiwa and the eight others who were executed were tried for
murder, rather than offences arising from their political views or
campaign for environmental protection of Ogoniland in southtrial said they were bribed.
eastern Nigeria, he said. However, prosecution witnesses at the

Stressing the need for dialogue, Gambari said the United States
should talk with Nigeria.

"After all, at the height of the Cold War, the Americans were
talking with the Soviet Union. They are talking now with the North
Koreans, the Chinese and with everybody else."

He said that if United States had " problems with us, they
should give us an opportunity to explain our own side of the story
and work out a way in which we can bring Nigeria back to the road
that we have set for ourselves, which is a return to democratic
civilian rule."

The United States has recalled its ambassador in Lagos, imposed
a unilateral arms embargo and extended visa restrictions on
Nigerian officials in protest against the executions.

Gambari said the trial of those accused of murder was carried
out in public and that the 15 defendants, of whom six were
acquitted, were tried with due regard to the Nigerian law.

He said though some people might not like the use of a tribunal
in the case, it was not the first time that tribunals were being
used in Nigeria.

Gambari said "tribunals were not invented by Nigeria." They
were "inherited from Britain which used these tribunals to try
some rioters in the Aba (eastern Nigeria) market women's riots of
1929 and which I understand the British still use in Northern
Ireland."

He condemned what he called the double standard of the
international community in not criticizing Nigeria's use of
tribunals to try drug traffickers while at the same time
disapproving of the use of a tribunal in the Ogoni case.

Gambari, who had also briefed the African group in the United
Nations on the Nigerian situation, criticized the western media's
reporting of events that led up the executions.

He claimed "there's no balance in your reporting and I appeal
to you to show balance and concern."

The diplomat said the Nigerian side of the story, "the story of
the victims of the initial murder", had not been told.

"We don't believe that we have gotten a fair shake," he said.

Meanwhile, some 500 Nigerians resident in Yaounde, capital of
Cameroon, staged a rally Wednesday in support of the military
government of Gen. Sani Abacha.

The placard-carrying demonstrators marched to the residence of
Nigerian Ambassador George Bello. Some of the placards read
'Nigeria refuses your uninvited intervention," "Why are they
sponsoring division in Africa and uniting Europe?"

The protesters criticized the stand of South African President
Nelson Mandela on the issue with the slogan: "Mandela: a victim of
apartheid becomes an apostle of imperalism".

A spokesman, Thompson Okeadu, said the demonstrators were
opposed to Britain and other European countries, the United States
and "neo-colonial African countries" for championing Nigeria's
recent suspension from the Commonwealth which groups together
mostly former British colonies
-0Paris to Host Houphouet-Boigny Prize Ceremony


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

265 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


War Weary Citizens Seek Solace In Beer


LENGTH: 734 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)
by Ferdinand Bigumandondera PANA Correspondent

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - For many in war-weary Burundi life is
dominated by bullets and beer.

More than 50,000 mainly civilians have been killed in crossfire
between rival armies.

And, when the fighting ebbs, many inhabitants crowd pubs, clubs
and beer gardens to drown their sorrows in beer, wine and a fiery
banana-based spirit called waragi. 

Heavy drinking in a land where moderation once was the order of
the day is only one of the symptoms of traumatized society.

The fabric of society has slowly been torn apart in a power
struggle between the majority Hutus and the minority Tutsis, a
replay of a similar conflict between the some ethnic groups in
neighboring Rwanda that cost up to one million lives.

In Burundi, gunmen of rival groups have been battling for
territorial and political control since the assassination of the
first Hutu president, Melchior Ndadaye, in October 1993. Before
that, Tutsis dominated the government, and today they still
control the army and police.

Panafrica, one of the rare weeklies still circulating in the
Burundian capital crippled by the absence of electricity, took up
the issue of the demon drink recently. It warned that alcoholism
may have become as dangerous to local people as the bullets and
machetes wielded by by gunmen.

The newspaper spoke about the very high demand for the quart(Saint Froth).
sized Primus beer which its guzzlers now call "Sainte Mousse"

"The phenomenon of alcoholism assumes wider proportions as the
war goes on. It has now become so important that, for some people,
the pub has become an address, if not a second residence," the
newspaper says.

According to the paper, local beer derived from sorghum once
played a key role in traditional festivities.

Now, war has turned it into another weapon for the destruction
of the family as husbands spend more time in bars.

The pub once was a place to relax, trade gossip and enjoy a
pint or two.

But war has turned tipplers into bingers.

What is most striking is that Burundians, notorious for
reporting late for work, land in pubs with uncharacteristic
punctuality.

Thanks to civil strife, though, a dusk to dawn curfew forces
them to go home early.

"When I do manage to elicit a smile, a look or a word from him,
its like a miracle because he seems to be eternally drunk," one
housewife said of her husband.

But then, what does one expect from a people whose lives have
virtually been ruined by a senseless war between centuries-bound
ethnic groups who suddenly find it difficult to live in peace.

For them, the epicurean dictum "Let's eat, drink and make
merry, for tomorrow we die" has become a religion.
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


266 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Oil Contracts To Share Production


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - The Congolese government signed contracts
Thursday to share offshore oil revenues with two foreign oil
production companies.

The government said the agreement with Agip of Italy and Elf of
France would ensure more stable incomes for the country. 

The contracts will also regulate the two companies' current and
future exploration and production activities.

Congo will under the agreement receive 12 percent of royalties
and 31 percent of revenue from Nkossa oilfeilds exploited by Elf
and the Kitina fields run by Agip.

Relations between Congo and the two companies have up to now
been governed by a convention signed in 1968.

Congo's crude oil production, currently estimated at nine
million tons, could reach 13 million tons in the next two years
after the commissioning of the Nkossa and Kitina oil fields in the
Atlantic Ocean.
-0Burundi


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


267 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Mugabe and Mandela Call For Closer Links


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)

BEITBRIDGE, Zimbabwe - Presidents Robert Mugabe of Zimb Aabwe
and Nelson Mandela of South Africa called Friday for closer
economic ties between their countries, saying they needed each
other for economic advancement.

Officially commissioning the 50-million-Zimbabwe dollar (5.6
million U.S. dollars) Limpopo River Bridge linking the two
countries they noted that they were the two largest trading
partners in southern Africa. 

"The opening of this bridge symbolizes our common effort to
build our economies as partners. It symbolizes an important step
towards integration in the common fight against poverty," Mandela
said.

The 584-meter (1,916 feet) long bridge, a joint venture between
the Development Trust of Zimbabwe and Gusv Company of Bulgaria, is
a landmark piece of engineering work.

It was built to ease congestion during peak periods and to make
provision for the future increase in trade between the two
countries.

It replaces the Otto Beit Bridge built in 1929. The new bridge
was completed in 13 months by a team of 200 engineers, artisans,
technicians and laborers.
-0Congo


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Government Briefs Foreign Envoys On Problems


LENGTH: 774 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi Thursday
told foreign diplomats sanctions against the West African state
could jeopradize regional security.

"If sanctions weaken Nigeria...security and economic growth of
our sub-region as well as our responsibility to the world
community will suffer greatly," he told the diplomats at a special
briefing.

Nigeria -- which has come under international condemnation and
sanctions over the Nov. 10 executions of nine minority rights
activists charged with murder -- has troops in several United
Nations peace missions. 
 It also has the largest contingent of more than 6,000 troops in
the African peace monitoring group (ECOMOG) in war-torn Liberia.

Ikimi led a government delegation to the recent Commonwealth
summit in Auckland, New Zealand, where Nigeria was suspended from
the organization over the executions, including that of the author
Ken Saro-Wiwa.

South Africa, the United States and the 15-membere European
Union have imposed sanctions on Nigeria and recalled their
ambassadors from Lagos.

The country is being threatened with more sanctions.

Ikimi called for dialogue, saying the anti-Nigeria actions by
the international community were based on an inadequate
understanding of events in the country.

He said the Commonwealth's suspension of Nigeria "was unfair
because it was carried out in an undue haste and without hearing
Nigerian side of the story."

The minister said Saro-Wiwa and his colleagues had not been
tried and convicted for seeking a better life for their Ogoni
people.

"They were put on trial because they were implicated in the
murder of four rival Ogoni leaders," Ikimi added.

He said "the death penalty still exists in Nigeria's statute
books and those convicted of crimes are dealt with on the basis of
the laws of the country."

The minister expressed surprise at the role of South African
President Nelson Mandela in leading a crusade for more sanctions
against Nigeria.

The acting dean of the Lagos diplomatic corps, Guinea's Seidu
Jallo, said after the briefing he and his colleagues would report
back to their home governments.
Nigeria has, meanwhile, seen a series of pro-government rallies
denouncing the outcries from the international community.
But local human rights groups say they are in support of the
sanctions, while prominent Lagos lawyer Gani Fawehinmi has taken
government to court over the executions of the Ogoni Nine.

The military government of Gen. Sani Abacha says it is
reviewing Nigeria's Africa-centred foreign policy in view of the
negative international opinion against the country.

Abacha has also held consultations with government officials,
traditional rulers and leaders of thought, and set up a 33-member
committee to advise government on apppropriate responses to
actions by the international community.
-0Zimbabwe and South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


Africa Still Leading in Refugee Numbers


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)

LAGOS, Nigeria - In the last five years more people have been
displaced by insecurity and lack of freedom in Africa, and the
continent still has the highest number of refugees in the world.

United Nations High Commission for Refugees representative
Emmanuel Bentil-Owusu said here Thursday there are 6.75 million
refugees in Africa today. 

Launching of The 1995 State of the World's Refugees Report,
Bentil-Owusu said that while Africa accounted for 30.8 percent of
the global refugee population in 1990, the count had risen to 43.3
percent this.
Apart from Europe, whose figure rose from 5.3 percent in 1990 to
23.9 percent in 1995, the rest of the world recorded a downward
trend in the refugee population, he said.
He said Asia recorded a decrease from 45.6 percent in 1990 to 29
percent in 1995, while Latin America went down from 8.1 percent to
0.4 percent during the same period.
-0Nigeria

Africa News


November, 1995


Benjamin Mkapa Becomes Tanzania's Third President


LENGTH: 574 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)
by Lwaga Mwambande PANA Correspondent

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania - Benjamin William Mkapa, 57, was sworn
in Thursday as the third president of the United Republic of
Tanzania, formed in 1964.

Mkapa succeeded Ali Hassan Mwinyi who stepped down after a
decade at the helm of the East African nation.

The public swearing-in at the National Stadium here was
witnessed by thousands of people, including presidents Daniel arap
Moi and Yoweri Museveni of Kenya and Uganda, respectively. 

Mkapa was Wednesday proclaimed winner of the elections held
October 29 with 60 per cent of the total vote. His party, Chama
Cha Mapinduzi, or Party of the Revolution, won 80 per cent of the
seats in the National Assembly.

In the previous cabinet of President Ali Hassan Mwinyi, Mkapa
was minister of higher education, science and technology.

Prior to that, he headed the ministries of information as well
as foreign affairs. He was managing director of the governmentMkapa served as ambassador in Nigeria and Canada. He was also
owned Daily News before moving to State House as press secretary.
the first director of the Tanzania News Agency which was created
in 1976.

A few hours after Mkapa's swearing-in, the government banned
the Swahili weekly, Rafiki (Friend), for allegedly publishing
information likely to cause unrest in the country.

A government statement said the ban became effective on Nov.
21.

"The government once again reminds journalists to respect the
law of the land and professional ethics as a means of maintaining
peace and avoiding chaos and unnecessary conflicts in the
society," the statement said.

The ban followed an article published by the the weekly tabloid
alleging that the country's defense forces were not satisfied with
the whole conduct of the Oct. 29 general elections.

The weekly claimed the defense forces were only waiting for
final results to be announced before acting.

But its allegations were refuted by the Chief of the Tanzania
People's Defense Forces, Gen. Robert Mboma, and Inspector-General
of Police Harun Mahundi, who dismissed the claims as baseless and
absurd.
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

271 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Plight of Housemaids Explored


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)
by Aminata Toure PANA Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - For close to three months now Khady, 21, has
been anxiously waiting for potential expatriate employers,
preferably whites.

Khady is one of several scores of young women waiting in a
street at Dakar's Point E residential area. They chat all day
long, hoping to be be picked as a house-maid.
Estimated at over 88,000, house-maids constitute Senegal's
largest workforce, second to civil servants who number 60,000. 

A survey conducted in 1993 showed that 80 per cent of these
domestic workers come from the countryside.

Some of them are aged below 15 and earn as little as 4,500 CFA
francs (about 10 dollars), although they work for 9-12 hours and
get no annual or sick leave, let alone maternity leave.

Khady is the only bread-winner for her family back home in the
central region of Sine Saloum.

Since her arrival in Dakar the young woman has worked for local
people as well as foreigners.

"Local people give us a hard time and pay very small wages",
Khady said. "With them, count yourself lucky if you make more than
15,000 CFA francs.

With a Lebanese or a "Niak" (pejorative name for non-Senegalese
Africans) one can earn between 20,000 CFA francs and 30,000 CFA
francs.

In a white household, one can easily make 40,000 CFA francs or
more, plus health coverage "specially when you have a work
certificate."

Some of the local employers of these workers confirmed wage
disparities exist, in spite of an existing law which spells out
the minimum wage and other entitlements.

Those who land in households with an average income of 150,000
CFA francs are generally underpaid, even if they live and eat with
the family free of charge.

This morning, Khady is seating close to Ndeye Lena, a 17-year
old girl who just dropped out of secondary school. This is Lena's
first morning at the Point E labor market.

She preferred to quit school to earn some money so as to help
her younger brothers and sisters complete their schooling. Once
employed, Lena hopes to enrol for evening classes.

Ndeye Lena claims hard work does not scare her because as an
African girl from a poor family she is used to house chores.

She might soon find out how challenging it is to be a house
servant in Senegal. The job entails washing and cleaning, usually
from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m.

Then a scanty dish of rice crust is offered to the tired young
woman. This is usually eaten in a dark corner of the kitchen, some
distance from employers enjoying their lavish meals.

Lena will soon discover that there is a world of difference
between being a domestic worker and washing and cleaning in one's
own home.

Fa, another of Khady companions, narrates how she has had
several sad experiences with her employers.

"You cannot eat with the members of the family as if you are
not clean enough although you are the one cooking what they eat,"
she said.

Sometimes the maid is only fed on leftovers, says Fa.

House-servants are not supposed to fall sick and have sick
leave, she said. They are often branded thieves, abused and even
sometimes beaten.

Raky Kane, a programme officer at the International Labour
Office in Dakar says "the problem for maids is that they are not
protected by a work contract."

Labor relations experts in Senegal believe, however, that the
situation is bound to change with the entry into the maids labor
market of better educated girls like Lena.

Although they are still a minority, these eventually turn out
to be efficient assistants for their employers. They protect the
house, answer the telephone, take appointments, draw checks from
the bank and pay utility bills.

This is the category most sought after by well-to-do families.
But such young women are also more concerned about respect and
rights.

To improve the status of domestic workers, Unicef has initiated
in Dakar a programme to offer training, health care and legal
assitance to 2,000 domestic workers.
-0Tanzania


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.
