Africa News


November, 1995


Civil Servants Pay Suspended


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)

NDJAMENA, Chad - The government of Chad has suspended paying
its civil servants until it weeds outs all ghost employees from
the state payroll.

The finance ministry says a count of civil servants conducted
in September showed that 8,441 of the 26,141 people on the on the
payroll had either retired or gone to non-government jobs. 

For now the government has decided that when payment resumes
only 19,127 civil servants will get their cheques. It did not,
however, say how long the salary suspension will take.

The measure follows an undertaking given to the International
Monetary Fund early September that the government will maintain
low salary levels over the next three years, trim the civil
service, privatise state-owned businesses and broaden the tax
base.

To support this and other reforms the Fund has loaned Chad
77.89 billion U.S. dollars -- on condition that the government
follows the Fund's guidelines strictly.

Chad, an impoverished and semi-arid country of 5.2 million
people, has had a severe economic crisis since 1990 when per
capita gross domestic product stood at 190 dollars.

The country's economic mainstain is cotton, uranium and salt.
-0Senegal

Leading Bank Fires Official


LENGTH: 347 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 25, 1995 (19951125)
by Ali Idrissou Toure PANA Correspondent

COTONOU, Benin - A senior officer at the African Development
Bank has been sacked without benefits for making statements
critical of the Nigerian military government.

The official, Sadikou Alao, was the deputy to the general legal
advisor to the bank, Africa's leading inter-governmental bank. 

The announcement of his firing was made by the Study and
Research Group on Democracy and Social Development in Africa,
GERDDES-Afrique, an non-governmental organization that Alao heads
as chairman.

GERDDES-Afrique, with headquarters in the Benin business
capital of Cotonou, said Alao was fired for demanding sanctions
against "Nigerian dictators to save democrats in that great
African nation."

Alao also said that the best way "to neutralize the Nigerian
dictators" was to "freeze their assets" in the West.

The appeal was made in Alao's capacity as chairman of GERDDESNigeria is a major shareholder in the bank whose authorized
Afrique.
capital in 1994 was 23.7 billion U.S. dollars. The Nigeria Trust
Fund, operated by the bank, had 421.3 million dollars at the end
of 1994.

Africa News


November, 1995


Cuba Sign Sports Agreement


LENGTH: 507 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 26, 1995 (19951126)
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian athletes will train in Cuba before the
1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta, United States, according to an
agreement signed by the two countries in Lusaka Sunday.

The agreement was signed by Zambian Sports Minister, retired
Lt.Col. Patrick Kafumukache and visiting Cuban Vice Minister of
Sport and Recreation Vinicio Quevedo Rodriguez. 

Under the pact, Zambia will send Olympic-bound boxers, judokas,
athletes and other sportsmen to be trained by Cuban experts in
Havana prior to the July 15- August 7 Atlanta Olympics.

Cuba will also conduct short and long training courses for
Zambian athletes in various sports disciplines both in Cuba and
Zambia.

Under a long-term sports development programme, Cuba will send
coaching staff to Zambia to help in the training and formulation
of sports development programmes in volleyball, basketball,
weight-lifting, boxing, baseball and other sports.

Zambia has also asked for some of its soccer coaches to to be
trained in Cuba.

Cuba has also pledged to consider awarding physical training
scholarships to Zambians under the sports cooperation agrement.

The countries also said that they will also study the
possibility of developing joint production of sports materials,
equipment and infrastructure.

In addition, Zambian sportsmen have been invited to participate
in Cuba's national memorial athletics meeting next March and two
national boxing tournaments scheduled for May and June 1996.

The two countries have in the past signed several bilateral
economic, health, educational, scientific and cultural relations
agreements.

Cuba has sent to Zambia some medical doctors and teachers,
mainly science and secondary school tutors.

Sunday's agreement is the continuation of the Cuba-Zambia
sports accord signed in Cuba two years ago.
-0Africa-at-Large

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


Military Fears Role in Nigeria's Isolation


LENGTH: 694 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 26, 1995 (19951126)
by Lionel Williams PANA Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Fears are being voiced in defense
circles here over statements by local politicians that South
Africa should be in the forefront of international efforts to
isolate Nigeria over her recent execution of nine minority rights
activists.

A report by the defense correspondent of a Johannesburg daily,
The Star, says South Africa is unable to take up any military
role, which will almost certainly be a crucial part of the
envisaged blockade of Nigeria.

Senior military officers have pass on this message to the
government in the past week, the report said. 

"They have told cabinet ministers, "the report adds, "of the
huge logistical problems which would face the nation, and
therefore the future of any pan-African force used in an attempt
to isolate Nigeria. The cost to this country in terms of money and
manpower has also been spelt out".

"To place a stranglehold on Nigeria would mean mounting a huge
land, sea and air blockage -- and that is where South Africa may
just have to draw back from active participation," the report
adds.

The key South African force needed for any blockade of Nigeria,
according to the military, would be the navy, one of the three
biggest on the African continent.

But navy chief Vice-Admiral Robert Simpson-Anderson has made it
clear on several occasions that without ships it was impossible to
assist with peace enforcement duties or effectively patrol South
Africa's own economic enforcement zone, let alone help to maintain
regional security or mount naval blockades.

South Africa also does not have the maritime air support needed
to lend support to the navy -- even in our own waters, the report
says.

Meanwhile, National Defense Force chief Gen George Meiring
recently told diplomats that while South Africa was training its
own troops to possibly participate in United Nations peace
enforcement operations on the continent, the problem of logistics
was uppermost in his mind.

"This scenario", the newspaper report concludes, "is one of the
reasons why South Africa's defense establishment is waiting keenly
for policy statements from the politicians.

They hope the order to join in a blockade will never be given.

Disappointed by the decision by Nigerian military rulers to
execute the nine Ogoni activists just as the 53-member
Commonwealth of mostly former British colonies began its summit in
New Zealand, President Nelson Mandela is now campaigning for
Nigeria's international isolation.

Before the executions, Mandela was among leaders who thought
anti-Nigerian sanctions would not be necessary.
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


Huge Drop in Coffee Production


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 26, 1995 (19951126)

CHIPINGE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's coffee production has dropped
by 58 percent, from 9,438 tons last year to 4,000 tons this
season.

Zimbabwe Coffee Mill (ZCM) general manager Greg Shaw said at
the weekend that this year's crop had suffered a 60 to 70 percent
frost damage. 

As a result, he said, the country will export 50 per cent less
coffee although prospects for the 1996/97 season were bright.

Next season, Zimbabwean farmers are expected to produce
between 12,000 and 20,000 tons worth about 45 million U.S.
dollars, he added.

When rains fall normally, Zimbabwe produces more than 14,000
tons of coffee.

Shaw said that ZCM was trying to penetrate the United States
coffee speciality industry.

In 1994 the United States speciality industry was valued at 1.5
million U.S. dollars and according to a market survey by the
Speciality Coffee Association of America, speciality coffee could
be a five-billion dollar-industry by 1999.

"All indications are that the speciality coffee industry has a
bright future," Shaw added.

Already, he said, Zimbabwe has been chosen together with India
and El Salvador to take part in the "Taste of the Harvest"
presentation at the Speciality Coffee Association of America
Conference and Exhibition to be held in Minneapolis in April 1996.

Zimbabawe is the second largest Arabica coffee producer in
Africa after Kenya.
-0South Africa

Africa News


November, 1995


Civic Groups Plan Anti-constitution Protests


LENGTH: 800 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 26, 1995 (19951126)
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's opposition political parties, civic
organizations and churces have united for a political showdown
with the government over the method of adopting a new constitution
for this southern African state.

The groups are opposed to government plans to have the draft
constitution ratified by parliament which is dominated by the
Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD), the ruling party of
President Frederick Chiluba.

They have resolved to stage peaceful demonstrations to force
the government to change its position. 

The demonstrations were announced here Saturday night by the
groups who want the constitution adopted by a constituen
assembly.

The goverment argues that ratifying the constitution outside
parliament would be tantamount to the house abdicating its civic
responsibilities as the country's highest law-making body.

Political analysts say the move by the pro-constituent assembly
groups could be interpreted as a declaration of a vote of noAt the Saturday conference spokesperson for Zambia's
confidence in the government.
traditional chiefs, Chieftainess Nkomeshya made an emotional
appeal to Zambians "not to fear" to challenge the government over
the constitution.

"If you go out hunting game, do not be afraid of strange noises
in the forest. If you are afraid, we (the chiefs) will take the
frontline and are ready to go to prison," she said.

Critics fear the MMD-dominated parliament could formalise some
of the more controversial clauses contained in the current draft.

The most controversial involves a provision that only secondThis provision is being challenged as an infringement on
generation Zambians qualify to stand for the presidency.
citizens rights and is generally seen as a ruse to stop former
president Kenneth Kaunda, whose parents migrated from Malawi, from
challenging President Chiluba in the 1996 presidential elections.

Kaunda, Zambia's founding president, ruled Malawi for 27 years
under a one-party dictatorship. He was ousted by Chiluba in the
multiparty elections of Oct. 1991.

Health Minister Michael Sata, one of Chiluba's closest
political advisors, told Zambian television Sunday that the MMD
was ready to "fight and throw Kaunda back into the political
dustbin."

Many observers believe the MMD, which will hold its third
convention Dec. 17, could back out of the political confrontation
over the constitution.

Recently the government suspended legal procedures it had
initiated to deport Kaunda to Malawi. The government claimed he
had obtained his Zambian citizenbship fraudulently.

The groups opposed to the government's moves held a two-day
conference to chart additional strategies to reverse its intention
to have the draft constitution endorsed by parliament .

The meeting resolved to call a citizens convention Dec. 12 to
further debate the draft constitution and arrange for a planned
peoples constituent assembly scheduled for Jan. 13, 1996.

The proposed assembly is expected to adopt a "green paper"
which would form the basis of a new "peoples constitution,".
-0Zimbabwe

November, 1995


Terrorism Conference Proposed


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 26, 1995 (19951126)

TRIPOLI, Libya - Egypt has urged the United Nations to organise
an international conference on ways to combat terrorism.

The call was made by the Minister of Interior, Hassan Al-Alfi,
at a news conference in Cairo Saturday. 

The call follows the bombing of the Egyptian embassy in
Islamabad, Pakistan, last week in which 16 people were killed and
60 others injured. An Islamic fundamentalist group, Jamaa Islamia,
claimed responsibility for the blast.

Fundamentalists seeking to install an Islamic regime have
launched well-publicized terrorist attacks against Egyptian
government installations and personalities.

The oldest of the Islamic groups is the Muslim Brotherhood
which masterminded the assassination of former Egyptian Pesident
Anwar el Sadat in 1981.

The interior minister called for a review of the status of
people claiming to be political refugees. He accused European
countries of hosting a large number of fugitive Islamists who
wanted for trial back home.

Earlier this week Egypt accused Britain of hosting Yassir Alveterans of the Afghanistan war.
Sirri who heads the Jihad Islamic group and Pakistan for keeping

Arabs volunteered to fight against Russian military occupation
of Afghanistan, which now ranks with Algeria and Egypt as the
bedrock of Islamic fundamentalism.
-0Zambia

279 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Red Alert On Conflict In Burundi And Rwanda


LENGTH: 1174 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 26, 1995 (19951126)
by Felix Njoku PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - An international humanitarian organization has
warned of the possibility of another wide-scale bloodbath in
central African, where more than one million people have been
killed in ethnic fighting in the last two years.

"Another disaster could strike Rwanda, or neighboring Burundi,
in the coming months, warned the group, EARTHACTION.

"Unless there is urgent action by the international community,
many more could die", EATHACTION, a global coalition for the
environment, peace and justice, said in a statement send to PANA

More than half-a-million people, mainly of the minority Tutsi
ethnic group and moderates from the majority Hutu, were massacred
between April and July in 1994.

They were killed by militias of the majority Hutu population
angered by the death of President Juvenal Habyarima (a Hutu) in a
plane crash on April 6, 1994, in which foul play was suspected. 

In neighbouring Burundi, which has the same ethnic
configuration, more than 50,000 people have been killed in feuds
since the country's first elected (Hutu) president, Melchior
Ndadaye, was killed in an aborted coup mounted by the Tutsi
dominated army in 1993.

In Rwanda, the old genocidal regime which was forced to flee
the country last year was re-arming within border refugee camps,
EARTHACTION says.

In Burundi, ethnically-motivated killings by armed gangs and
sections of the Tutsi-dominated army have become more frequent
everyday. The government is weak and no one is being convicted, it
added.

It said some countries, including China, France and Zaire were
breaking the UN arms embargo in the area by re-arming elements of
the former government of Rwamda, thereby creating conditions for
yet another mayhem.

EARTHACTION urged governments to "press for full enforcement of
the U.N. arms embargo on the former government of Rwanda, and
called for wider deployment of U.N. forces to halt the supply of
arms to extremists in both countries".

But the Tutsi-led Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF) government in
Kigali is pushing for the withdrawal of some 2,000 U.N. peace8.
keepers in the country whose mandate is due to expire on December

Government officials were recently quoted as saying what is
needed now is assistance for national reconstruction and not
troops.

However, EARTHACTION says there are two keys to solving the
seemingly intractable problems in the area -- justice and economic
opportunity.

But "Neither justice nor economic opportunity are possible
without international help... without greater commitment from
other governments genocide could begin again in central Africa,"
the organization says.

The organization calls for stong support to the international
tribunal set up to prosecute the leaders of the Rwandan genocide,
and a new international commission of enquiry into previous
massacres in Burundi.

"These two bodies can play a key role in ensuring that crimes
against humanity do not go unpunished, but they are desperately
short of funds and staff...", it said.

Some 50,000 people have been held in prisons for months
awaiting trial for the part they played in the Rwandan killings.

The organization urges rich industrialized countries to
"sharply increase aid to help Rwanda and Burundi build a
functioning and democratic government administration (including a
well-trained, impartial police force and judiciary) and launch
development projects that bring the ethnic groups together to
overcome their poverty."

Experts say the crisis in Burundi and Rwanda are part of the
colonial legacies afflicting many other African countries.

Rwanda and Burundi which share a common history, language,
people and culture were part of German East Africa before being
handed over to Belgium after the First World War.

The Belgians concentrated on educating and empowering the
minority Tutsi, who account for 20 per cent of the population,
over the majority Hutus.

The Tutsi effectively became the priveleged class in both
countries, fuelling resentment from hordes of poor and powerless
Hutus, who overthrew the Tutsi monarch in 1959.

This was followed by massacres which forced many Tutsis to flee
into exile in Uganda and other neighboring countries. It is the
sons of these exiles who forcefully returned to Rwanda in 1990 as
the RPF.

Gen Habyarimana died in a plane crash in Kigali as he returned
from a regional meeting in Tanzania to finalise plans for powerThis touched off the gory killings that outraged the
sharing in Rwanda.
international community.
-0Egypt


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


280 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Man Saves Wife From Crocodile, Tarzan Style


LENGTH: 507 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 15, 1995 (19951115)
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Postcard From Southern Africa: A villager in
Kasama, northern Zambia, could be in line for a national bravery
award -- all for the love of his wife.

Ellias Lesa last week grappled with a marauding crocodile that
had dragged his wife into the muddy waters of one of Zambia's
largest rivers, the Chambeshi.

This was no Tarzan and Jane remake. And Kelya Washeni Lesa, 36,
is now recuperating from multiple leg injuries inflicted by the
reptile. 

Her husband proudly narrated the couple's ordeal to a visiting
government official from the capital, Lusaka.

One evening last week the couple went to the Chambeshi river to
draw water. Kelya dipped her bucket into the water and a crocodile
suddenly grabbed her leg and dragged her into the deep waters.

"I jumped on its back and said to myself, 'I will not return
without my wife'," Lesa said.

Lesa struggled with the reptile for more than 30 minutes while
its jaws held tightly onto his wife's leg.

"The crocodile would submerge taking both of us under water,
but realizing that there was still an unwanted load on its back,
it would resurface and go under again while I held tight," Lesa
said.

Just as Lesa was beginning to feel exhausted, a canoe floated
by. Kelya grabbed it in desperation while her husband pounded the
reptile with his bare hands. The tug-of-war became too much for
the crocodile. It let go and disappeared into the depths of the
Chambeshi.

Chambeshi, like many other major rivers in Zambia, is infested
with man-eating crocodiles.

There is a popular traditional belief among many Zambian river
people that some traditional medicinemen can turn themselves into
crocodiles to grab other people's wives and terrorize their
neighbors.
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


281 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Executions, The Last Straw?


LENGTH: 1187 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 15, 1995 (19951115)
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian military rulers may have been
surprised by the international storm of protest against Friday's
executions of nine of its citizens for murder, but political
analysts say there had been a systematic build-up to the country's
current isolation.

Nigeria had been embroiled in political turmoil since 1993 and
analysts say the hanging of the Ogoni minority leaders, including
author Ken Saro-Wiwa, was "the last straw" that broke
international patience with the regime.

African diplomats in Lagos consider the timing of the
executions "undiplomatic" for a country already under sanctions
and severe pressure from the West to democratize.

It is unclear why the two-year-old regime of Gen. Sani Abacha
timed the executions to coincide with the summit of the
Commonwealth, and amid calls from critics for Nigeria to be
expelled from the 52-member British-led association. 

One possible explanation is that the regime judged the
consolidation of its power at home to be more important than
external criticisms. The other is that the regime was determined
to assert its national sovereignty and demonstrate its wish not to
be dictated to.

But analysts add a third explanation: outright miscalculation
on the part of the military rulers of the consequencies that could
follow the executions.

In one of its toughest measures against a member, the
Commonwealth leaders meeting in Auckland, New Zealand, promptly
suspended Nigeria. It followed this with an ultimatum that Nigeria
free all political detainees and restore democracy within two
years or be expelled from the association.

In their own reactions, Australia, Britain, South Africa and
United States have recalled their ambassadors in Lagos for
consultations. This is a euphemism for a serious strain in
diplomatic relations. Other Western countries could follow.

Washington has extended its existing measures to include a ban
on the sale and repair of military goods and services to Nigeria.

The United States government also says it will block Nigeria's
requests for debt relief from multinational financial
institutions. Nigerian officials visiting United Nations
headquarters in New York are to be restricted to within a 25-mile
radius (40.2 kilometres) of the organization's headquarters.

These measures are intended to isolate Nigeria from the rest of
the world, but they fall short of a U.S. oil embargo.

The U.S. buys some 50 per cent of Nigerian oil, the West
African country's main economic lifeline. That is 10 percent of
U.S. oil imports.

Energy experts say that an oil sanction could also hurt the
Unted States. It is already faced with limited supplies because of
oil embargoes against Libya, Iran and Iraq.

Industry sources also say U.S. petroleum firms are not disposed
to oil sanctions against Nigeria, which could push up prices of
the essential product in the world market.

In addition, American diplomatic sources cite Nigeria's key
role in the peace process in the war-ravaged West African State of
Liberia.

Nigeria, with a little over 6,000 troops there, has the largest
contingent of men in the West African Peace Monitoring Group
(Ecomog) in Liberia. It has undertaken to send two more battalions
-- about 1,200 men. The fear is that any action that could provoke
the Abuja government into pulling out of Liberia could spell a
security disaster in the sub-region.

Above all Nigeria, with some 98 million people, is a huge
country whose possible devastation by indiscriminate external
pressure could provoke far-reaching consequences beyond the
continent.

Nigerian officials have defended the executions saying they
were within the country's law. They have also criticized the
nation's suspension from the Commonwealth as "baseless and
premeditated."

But the truth is that no nation, not even Nigeria, can afford
international isolation.

In realization of this, popular opinion in the country is that
since sanctions hurt the ordinary people more efforts should be
made by the government to reach accommodation with the rest of the
world.

At issue are the government's human rights commitment and
irreversible steps towards returning the world's largest black
nation to democracy.

Government officials argue that Nigeria does not have the worst
human rights records in the world. Abacha, they say, has already
announced a 36-month political transition programme terminating in
October 1998.

Perhaps some Western countries may have over-reacted, and many
observers counsel dialogue rather than confrontation since a
stable Nigeria is an asset to its citizens and to the world.
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


Envoys Recalled In Retaliation


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 15, 1995 (19951115)
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria Monday ordered home its envoys in the
United States, South Africa and 15 European Union member-countries
in retaliation for the countries' recall of their own diplomats
from Lagos.

These countries called back their envoys over last Friday's
execution for murder of nine Nigerian minority leaders, including
author Ken Saro-Wiwa. 

The Foreign Ministry in the nation's capital, Abuja, said
Nigerian envoys "have no business remaining in their countries of
posting."

Also in response to Nigeria's suspension from the 53-member
British-led commonwealth, two Nigerian organisations, the official
Radio Nigeria and the Nigerian Television Authority, have
announced suspension of their membership of the Commonwealth
Broadcasting Union.

The Nigerian executions have unleashed international
condemnations and sanctions apparently directed against the
military government. These have come from the U.S., Britain and
other members of the European Union.

Nigeria's two-year-old military regime of Gen. Sani Abacha has
defended the hanging of Saro-Wiwa and his colleagues for the 1994
murder of four of their Ogoni kinsmen from oil-rich southeastern
Nigeria.

Government officials have slammed the external condemnations
and sanctions as "unfair" and an interferrence in the country's
internal affairs.

Nigeria, with an estimated 98 million people, has diplomatic
missions in some 80 countries after the pruning in the late 1980s
because of economic reasons.

Diplomatic sources in Lagos consider the latest reactions from
Abuja as a face-saving measure, which is however in line with the
diplomatic principle of reciprocity.
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


Brazzaville Taxi Drivers End Strike


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 15, 1995 (19951115)

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - A protest here against police and army
abuse is over. Taxi drivers in Brazzaville, who stopped working
last Monday, ended their strike following an agreement reached
Tuesday between government authorities and the transport workers'
union. 

At the end of the negotiation, the two parties both issued a
joint statement that confirmed several of the strikers' complaints
and agreed that routine police checks and security checks should
continue.

The opposition stronghold in Bacongo and Mfilou, located in
southern Brazzaville, however, was still off the roads today.

The taxi and mini-bus drivers, who called for an end to
security checks and suspension of the state road tax, said the
proceeds from the tax have not been used to improve roads.

In an effort to curb the circulation of arms and escalation of
violence in Brazzaville during the 1993 and early 1994
parliamentary elections, the government of President Pascal
Lissouba introduced the joint army and police checks.
-0Nigeria

284 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Commonwealth Sanctions Protested


LENGTH: 1187 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 15, 1995 (19951115)

ASABA, Nigeria - Hundreds of Nigerians on Wednesday took to the
streets to protest the suspension of their country from the
Commonwealth.

The placard-carrying demonstrators marched to Government House
in the city of Asaba, midwest of the country, where they handed
over their letter of protest to the military administrator of
Delta State, Group Captain Ibrahim Kefas.

Some of the placards read 'We Support Abacha's Transition
Programs', 'Mandela Beware, the West is Cunning', 'Mandela You
Have Bitten the Finger that Fed You' and 'Suspension of Nigeria is
International Gang Up.'

In an address to the military administrator the leader of the
demonstration, Osadume Uwadibie, said the people of Delta State
will support whatever retaliatory measures that the Nigerian
government may take. 

He said that the decision to suspend Nigeria from the
Commonwealth for following and enforcing its domestic law amounted
to undue interference and called on Nigerians to support their
unelected military government.

Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth after Friday's
hangings of the author and minority rights activist Ken Saro-Wiwa
and eight other members of his Movement for the Salvation of
Ogoniland (MOSOP).

MOSOP led a campaign against environmental damage to Ogoni
territory in south-eastern Nigeria, caused by oil production,
source of the most of the nation's export income.

The executions of the nine Ogoni leaders after a special
tribunal had found them guilty of the murder of four eminent Ogoni
opposed to their movement, unleashed international condemnations
and sanctions against Nigeria by the United States and European
Union member-countries.

These countries and South Africa, which has also barred Nigeria
from a Johannesburg invitational soccer tournament, have recalled
their envoys from Lagos. Nigeria retaliated by recalling its own
envoys from their capitals.

The pro-government demonstrations started Monday in the
northern city of Ilorin and southeastern city of Calabar. They
brought together thousands of people who marched to the state
houses in the capitals. But analysts maintain most Nigerians
oppose the regime.

By Tuesday the protests had spread to the mid-western city of
Benin, and Minna, Kaduna and Katsina in the north. The marchers
accused the Commonwealth of "not taking time to understand events
in the country."

The demonstrators, comprising market women, students and
members of non-governmental organizations, roundly condemned
Nigeria's suspension from the Commonwealth, describing it as
unwarranted interference in the country's internal affairs.

The official Nigerian Television Authority Tuesday night
singled out South Africa for leading the campaign of isolation
against Nigeria.

It accused President Nelson Mandela's government of trying to
use the anti-Nigeria campaign to get an African seat at the United
Nations Security Council.

The president of the Manufacturer's Association of Nigeria,
Hassan Adamu, condemned western countries for "scheming" to
isolate Nigeria.

He told journalists in Lagos "the West has shown it is
interested only in taking advantage of every situation to tighten
the noose around the country and to plunge her into more
problems."

The widows of the four Ogoni men murdered in May 1994, for
whose deaths Saro-Wiwa and his colleagues were convicted and
executed, addressed a newsconference in Lagos Tuesday. They
recounted what they claimed to be their ordeals since their
husbands were slain in a factional feud.

In tears, one of them said she and her colleagues had been
ostricized by their community and were living like "lepers".

They claimed their plight was overshadowed by the executions of
Saro-Wiwa and the others.

Saro-Wiwa and MOSOP accused Nigerian authorities and the Anglo"genocide" against the estimated 500,000 Ogonis in south-eastern
Dutch petroleum company Shell of creating environmental havoc and
Nigeria.

Shell, which accounts for the production of some 50 per cent of
Nigeria's estimated two million barrels of crude a day, suspended
operations in Ogoniland after protests against its operations.

In the first public expression of solidarity from a foreign
country, the Philippines' charge d'affaires in Lagos, Hermes
Dorado, said Tuesday his country stood by Nigeria in the face of
international condemnations and sanctions over the executions.

He said: "What is happening to you (Nigeria), we have
experienced, and we sympathize with you. We look at you as our
friend in the Third World who share common problems with us," he
added.
-0Congo


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


285 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Racism Still Thriving


LENGTH: 574 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 17, 1995 (19951117)

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Racism in Zimbabwe is still alive and
flourishing 15 years after independence from Britain in 1980.

"Being white I know them (white racists)," says a human rights
activist, David Coltart.

"They have this theory that if you want prosperity in a black
country you must be seen to support it. Otherwise they have a low
regard for blacks as a community. They believe no black can ever
do any good." 

The smooth transition to Zimbabwe's independence hinged on the
ruling Zimbabwe Africa National Union's policy of reconciliation
which was supposed to heal the racial wounds following years of a
brutal armed struggle.

Political analysts are now saying reconciliation as espoused by
President Robert Mugabe's government has failed to produce
positive results.

The current bone of contention is that while 10 million blacks
account for 94 percent of the population, they control less than
three percent of the economy and only 10 percent of productive
land. The rest is still in the hands of some 100,000 whites.

"When we agreed to wait for some 10 years before reclaiming our
land," says one accountant in the capital, Harare, "we subtracted
10 years of our independence. Whites used that period to
recolonize us economically."

A letter from a Harare resident, Ruzvidzo Mupfudza, published
in a national Sunday newspaper, accused whites of racism and
sparked debate.

Whites accuse blacks of fuelling racial tension, while blacks
accuse whites of having taken advantage of African hospitality to
exploit them.

Some incidents which broke out during the year seem to have
fueled the debate.

Human rights activist Larry Chakaredza was beaten up in a
Harare nightclub frequented mostly by whites.

Harare lawyer Archibald Thandiwa holds strong views on ways of
finding a solution to the question of racism in Zimbabwe. He
thinks "nothing short of a liberation struggle will solve it."

He adds: "We cannot talk about the land issue without
castigating the whites or look at indigenous economic empowerment
without arguing with whites."'
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


286 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Abacha Replies To Critics


LENGTH: 600 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - In his first public statement since Friday's
execution of nine minority-rights leaders, Nigeria's military
ruler called the international condemnations and sanctions against
his regime as "most unfortunate and uncalled for."

"In recent times, we have observed and seen absolute and
deliberate interferences in our national and internal affairs,"
Gen. Sani Abacha said Wednesday in the northern state of Kebbi.

Abacha vowed "to do everything possible to maintain the
nation's unity, dignity, stability and integrity." 

The British-led 52-member Commonwealth of Nations suspended
Nigeria and gave Abacha's government a two-year ultimatum to
democratize or be expelled. Fifteen European Union member states,
South Africa and the United States recalled their ambassadors from
Nigeria. Abuja retaliated by summoning home its envoys from those
countries.

The United States and South Africa also slapped an arms embargo
on Nigeria. South African President Nelson Mandela went further,
saying he would press for oil sanctions against the West African
country. Oil is the nation's main export earner.

Abacha's remarks came amid growing pro-government protests in
several parts of Nigeria. The demonstrators are mainly market
women, students and members of non-governmental organizations who
consider the external measures an interference in Nigeria's
internal affairs.

Defending the executions, which included author Ken Saro-Wiwa,
Abacha's second in command, Lt. Gen. Oladipo Diya, said the
military regime remains committed to the three-year political
transition program announced Oct. 1.

Speaking Wednesday in the northern city of Katsina, Diya
condemned the Commonwealth's suspension.

He said the military government would implement its programs
with diligence to shame their "detractors and their
collaborators."

But there appears to be no stop to mounting international
pressure on Nigeria. The European Commission Wednesday proposed a
resolution calling for an arms embargo and the freezing of
Nigerian military officers' European assests.

Political observers say an oil embargo, which could be painful
for Nigeria, appears unlikely because it also would harm huge
foreign interests there.
-0Zimbabwe

Africa News


November, 1995


Voters Cast Ballots in Presidential Elections


LENGTH: 760 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 16, 1995 (19951116)
by Ali Dellali PANA Staff Correspondent

TRIPOLI, Lybia - Some 16 million Algerians were expected to
vote Thursday in the country's first democratic presidential
election since independance in 1962. According to state Radio
Algeria monitored in Tripoli Thursday, polling stations opened at
8 a.m. local time (0700 GMT), despite threats of violence from
Islamic fundamentalists.

Algerians living abroad cast their ballots Saturday, while
those in the security services voted earlier this week. 

Four presidential candidates are in the race: incumbent
president Gen. Liamine Zeroual; the leader of the Rally for
Culture and Democracy, Said Saadi; the head of the Movement of the
Islamic Society 'HAMAS', Cheikh Mahfoud Nahnah; and the chairman
of the Renovation Party, Noureddine Boukrou.

Zeroual was the favorite in pre-election poll, conducted by the
Algerian newspaper Al-Watan.

The radio reported that about 300,000 policemen, soldiers and
other security agents were guarding the polling sites in response
to threats of violence -- or one for every 4,600 balloters.

In addition, scores of international observers from the United
Nations, the Organization of African Unity and the Arab League are
in Algeria as monitors. Algerian authorities urged voters
in areas with strong Islamist influence to vote in other districts
-- for their safety.

The advice was directed in particular at residents of the Qasba
neighborhood in Algiers, the Algerian capital, considered a
stronghold of the Armed Islamist Group, GIA, which had threatened
to kill voters.

GIA has claimed responsibility for thousands of murders in
Algeria and bombings in France.

A United States-based spokesman of the banned Islamic
Salvation Front, FIS, Anouar Haddam, said his organization will
not recognize the election's outcome. "The armed struggle
continues," Haddam said.

The former ruling National Liberation Front and other major
political parties, including the FIS, boycotted the elections.

The FIS, which wants to create an Iranian-type government with
Islamic rules, was poised to win parliamentary elections held in
late 1991 after winning the first round and leading the second.

However, the military-backed interim government that organized
the polls canceled the elections and arrested top FIS leaders.

Since then, various armed fundamentalist groups have blossomed
in Algeria, killing people and bombing public buildings.

Up to 50,000 people, including foreigners and especially French
nationals, were killed in the politically motivated violence. The
French government ordered its nationals to leave Algeria, a former
colony.

But the FIS took its battle into France, whom it accuses of
financing the regime in Algiers.

French authorities believe GIA saboteurs planted bombs in
underground trains in Paris.

FIS protests prompted French President Jacques Chirac to cancel
a meeting scheduled with Zeroaul in New York earlier this month.
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


Asylum Seekers Suffer as Britain Imposes Visa


LENGTH: 907 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Jeggan Grey-Johnson PANA Correspondent

BANJUL, Gambia - A speeding car kicked up dust towards the gate
of the British High Commission in The Gambia, 42 Atlantic Road, in
the capital of Banjul. When the red dust settled, 12 people could
be seen clustered against the white gate which marks British
"soil" in The Gambia.

All were silently waiting for the new formalities introduced by
the United Kingdom on October 27, 1995. These require intending
Gambian travellers to obtain visas at home prior to departure. 

The policy change was revealed in a statement which said it was
prompted by the 800 or so Gambians, most in their early 20s, who
left The Gambia following the coup on July 22 last year led by Lt.
Yahya Jammeh.

The British High Commission (embassy) stated further that of
all the 800 refugees claims filed by the Gambians "less than ten
were genuine."

As a result, the Foreign Office was forced to regulate the mass
entries of Gambians seeking political asylum.

Even more people now congregate at the entrance to the High
Commission. The entrance is locked and manned by a tall fellow in
blue uniform.

On this day, he ordered the crowd to move back. "Gate Space,"
he barks.

His words fell on deaf ears. There was a young man in a Chicago
Bulls tee-shirt with the word Jordan boldly written on it. "Excuse
me," he said, "I want a form."

"For what?" a voice behind a counter replied. "For a visa," The
Bulls fan answered, somewhat amused by the seemingly obvious.

There are spikes in the lawn of the entrance, lined by blue
ropes, signifying that visa seekers must line up when waiting. But
that requirement was ignored this day.

"It is hot, let us in," a light skinned woman with a child
pleaded. The guard turned around, spoke to the voice in the booth
and opened the gate. The crowd parted and a white Rangegate. There was pushing and shoving. Then an order came from the
Rover exited. After this, the crowd surged towards the closing
booth: "Let only 10 in."

The guard in blue uniform obeyed and barked: "Proper order
here."

Unimpressed, the light skinned lady retorted: "You don't treat
us like this. It is not fair."

The guard replied with a profanity, the others mediated and
eventually nine people wer allowed through the gates.

The young man with the Bulls tee-shirt is one of the unlucky
ones who failed to make it in.

"You know, I want to go to England for further studies," he
said.

Asang, the Bulls fan, has just completed his "O" levels (Grade
12 exams) and apparently did very well. He intends to join the 800
or so others who left the country in search of greener pastures
since the coup.

But getting out of The Gambia is an uphill task, for now he
must make it through the white gates, pass the guard in blue. He
must convince the consulate that his case is genuine. And that he
is not seeking asylum in Britain.

Asang must gather his information and arrange it as asked on
the form. The paperwork is taxing.

An applicant has to pay between 264 and 320 Dalasis (about 25the applicant and length of intended stay.
30 dollars) as "clearance fees". The amount depends on the age of

This policy change has received mixed feelings within the
country, a British colony until 1965 and which still maintains its
membership of the British-led Commonwealth of Nations, although
military leaders have been told to democratize..
-0Algeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


Former President Jimmy Carter on African Tour


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 17, 1995 (19951117)

ACCRA, Ghana - Former United States President Jimmy Carter
arrived in Accra, Ghana, Friday on the first leg of an eightDuring his two-day visit Carter, accompanied by his wife
nation African tour.
Rosalyn, is expected to meet Ghana President Jerry Rawlings who is
chairman of the 15-nation Economic Community of West African
States. 

Then, Carter will go to Benin, Burundi, Egypt, Rwanda, Togo,
Uganda and Zaire.

Carter has been involved in the eradication of the Guinea worm,
a debilitating parasite, in some of the African countries under
his Global 2000 programme

He is also involved in a mediation summit to find a durable
solution to the crises in Burundi and Rwanda that is expected to
take place in Cairo on Nov. 27.

He embarks Saturday on a four-day fact-finding mission to
prepare the meeting, whose aim is to settle long-standing ethnic
strifes in those countries.

Carter will travel to Burundi, Rwanda, Uganda and Zaire Nov.
18-21 to consult major players in the zone, known as the Great
Lakes Region.

While in Rwanda, Carter Center officials also will meet with
representatives of associations formed by genocide survivors and
other non-governmental organizations.

In Burundi, the team will meet political leaders, and in Zaire
with representatives of refugee, non-governmental organizations
and relief officials during a visit to the refugee camp in Goma in
Eastern Zaire.

Zaire has threatened to throw out the estimated over one
million Rwandan Hutu refugees if the United Nations fails their
voluntary rehabilitation.
-0Gambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


290 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Abacha Marks Two Years in Troubled Seat


LENGTH: 1000 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha,
ended his second year in power Friday with the country in deeper
political trouble and under intensified international pressure
than when he seized control, political analysts here said.

The Abacha regime last week inflamed world opinion by executing
nine Ogoni minority leaders. They included author Ken Saro-Wiwa
who accused the government and the Anglo-Dutch oil company Shell
of environmental genocide against an estimated 500,000 Ogoni. 

The nine were convicted for the 1994 murders of four Ogoni
chiefs opposed to their movement.

Abacha, a bespectacled infantry general not given to public
speech even as head of state, took over from an interim
administration installed by former military ruler Gen. Ibrahim
Babangida after Babangida annulled the June 1993 presidential
election.

Babangida stepped down on Aug. 26, 1993, during a political
crisis caused by the cancellation of the presidential poll that
international observers had deemed fair. Millionaire-politician
Moshood Abiola claimed victory in the election, then the military
government arrested him on charges of treason. Abiola's case is
still on trial, and the political crisis caused by that election
is far from over.

Observers say the "ill-timed" Nov. 10 executions, which
coincided with the Commonwealth summit in Auckland, New Zealand,
were the last straw.

The Commonwealth suspended Nigeria and gave the government two
years to democratize or be expelled from the organization.

The Abacha regime defended its actions, dismissing the
Commonwealth's ultimatum as a premeditated "gang-up" by its
critics.

When the 15 European Union member states, South Africa and the
United States imposed arms embargoes on Nigeria and recalled their
ambassadors the Abacha regime retaliated by summoning home its own
envoys from these countries.

The outraged international community appears unimpressed by the
Abacha government's contention that a legally constituted court
convicted the nine of murder according to the country's laws.

Some Nigerians now consider the international measures against
their country an over-reaction that interferes in their internal
affairs.

Small pro-government demonstrations in several state capitals
denounced the anti-Nigeria campaign.

Some Nigerian protesters singled out South African President
Nelson Mandela, accusing him of being "used" by Western countries
and reminding him of Nigeria's key role in the anti-apartheid
struggle in his country.

However, analysts contend the majority of Nigerians are opposed
to the military regime.

The embattled military government is appealing to the patriotic
conscience of Nigerians to see the international campaign as
challenge for them to forge a common front.

"This is a test," said senior military officer Maj. Gen.
Abdulkarim Adisa. "This is a time to know who our true friends
are."

So far, Nigeria has escaped an oil embargo that could cut off
the country's main economic lifeline. Oil is the main export
earner

The huge interests of multinational corporations in Nigeria,
vulnerable to such sanctions, appear to be the only restraint.

But even without an oil embargo, analysts say Nigeria can't
take on the whole world or afford international isolation.

The Abacha regime plans to continue its three-year political
transition program ending in October 1998.

After two years in power, Abacha still has daunting challenges,
including the nation's troubled economy and unresolved political
problems at home.

Nigeria's former leader, Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, his former
deputy, Maj. Gen. Musa Shehu Ya'ardua and 38 other people are
currently serving various jail terms. They were convicted in July
for trying to overthrow Abacha in March.
-0Ghana


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


291 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Opposition Disputes First Algerian Election Results


LENGTH: 454 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 17, 1995 (19951117)

TRIPOLI, Libya - Algeria's opposition Movement for the Islamic
Society, known as Hamas, Thursday evening contested initial
results of the country's presidential election announced on state
radio.

Early results, announced by radio monitored in Tripoli, gave
the incumbent President Liamine Zeroual 68.54 percent of the
vote. 

The Hamas candidate, Cheikh Mahfoudh, received 25 percent, and
the Rally for Culture and Democracies candidate, Said Saadithe,
won 13 percent.

"The results are false because many of our supporters were
either threatened or arrested," the Hamas spokesman said.

The Islamic Salvation Front, FIS, said from abroad the
elections would not resolve Algeria's political crisis. FIS wages
a terror campaign against authorities in Algeria. The movement's
representative in the United States, Anouar Haddam, said the
government's claim of a 75 percent voter turnout was grossly
exaggerated. It said only 30 percent of eligible voters made it to
the polls.

Earlier, FIS said it would not recognize the election's
outcome. FIS, which wants to create an Iranian-type government
with Islamic rules, was poised to win parliamentary elections held
in late 1991 after winning the first round and leading the second.
However, the military-backed interim government that organized the
polls canceled the elections and arrested top FIS leaders. Since
then, various armed fundamentalist groups have blossomed in
Algeria, killing people and bombing public buildings.

The elections are being monitored by scores of international
observers from the United Nations, the Organization of African
Unity and the Arab League.
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


292 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Trading on Stock Exchange Depressed


LENGTH: 280 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Local and foreign investors on the
Zimbabwean stock market have adopted a wait-and-see attitude amid
rising concern about the delay to the onset of the 1995/96 rainy
season, stockbrokers said on Monday.

They said in interviews trading was characterised by
nervousness, prompting many investors to sit on the sidelines. 

This contradicts the trend two weeks ago when the market surged
in response to the first scattered showers that fell in most parts
of the country.

The 1995-96 rainy season, which was expected to start in
earnest last week, has not yet shown a clear-cut trend, although
weather experts still believe the country will experience a normal
season.

Due to uncertainty in the market, worsened by disappointing
corporate results released in the last two weeks, the key
industrial index has plunged below the psychological barrier of
4,000 to close at 3,973 on Friday.
-0Algeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

293 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


New Labour Policy Protested


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 20, 1995 (19951120)
JOHANNESBURG - Lesotho, completely surrounded by South Africa, has
protested against a new South African policy on migrant labor.

The decision by the South Africa late October to grant
permanent residence to some mineworkers from neighboring states
has triggered the sharp reaction. 

The government of Lesotho says it is worried the policy will
cause it a serious financial loss. Its largest source of hard
currency is the money sent home by Lesotho citizens working in
South African mines as migrant labor.

Migrant laborers who have lived and worked in South Africa
since 1986 would be given residence status, according to the new
policy. This could result in many investing their savings in South
Africa instead of sending them back home.

Appearing on South African television Sunday night, Lesotho's
Minister of Finance, Moeketsi Senaoana, said there had also been a
brain-drain of top professionals from Lesotho into South Africa.
-0Zimbabwe


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

294 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Food Needs Revised in 12 Nations


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

HARARE, Zimbabwe - There has been a significant drop in
estimates of drought relief food needs for Southern African
Development Community countries suffering from another devastating
drought, the regional early warning unit says.

The Zimbabwe-based unit said the region's emergency food
requirements in 1995/96 dropped from an initial forecast of 7.1
million tons to 3.9 million tons of aid.

SADC is an economic grouping of 12 countries, all of them
except Mauritius in drought-prone southern Africa. 

The reduction in food needs in the region was due largely to a
change in South African estimates. The shortfall there had dropped
from 3 million tons to 532,000 tons, the unit said in a report.

SADC said South Africa's revised figures where a result of
factors including a 700,000-ton decrease in consumption estimates.

There was also the reduction in cereal stocks by 1.3 million
tons, to be carried forward to the next season.

Tanzania, which expected a shortfall of 444,000 tons, was now
predicting a surplus of 116,000 tons, while Zambia had dropped its
requirement by 260,000 tons.

But for Zimbabwe the shortfall had risen, with harvest figures
falling 116,000 tons below original estimates.

Although South Africa would have to import staple white maize
for domestic consumption it had excess yellow maize for export to
other countries in the region.

All SADC countries were, however, expected to import wheat,
with the greatest shortfalls of 242,000 tons and 427,000 tons in
Zimbabwe and South Africa, respectively.

Meanwhile, there was general concern within SADC over the poor
response from the international community to the appeal for food
aid made in June this year. Only 476,000 tons of food aid was
pledged by mid-August.

"Greater reliance would have to be placed not only on strategic
grain reserves but on commercial imports which would be
detrimental to the region's economic adjustment programmes," the
unit said.
-0Lesotho and South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


295 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


OAU Satisfied With Algerian Elections


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

DAKAR, Senegal - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) has
said it is satisfied with the way Algeria's last week's
presidential elections were conducted.

"The elections took place in a calm atmosphere, in freedom and
transparency," the 53-nation organization said in a statement to
PANA Monday. 

It said the facilities in place were "excellent" and voters
turned out in "very large numbers" on Thursday.

The OAU sent in a 50-member observer mission at the invitation
of the Algerian government.

Last Friday Algerian President Laimine Zeroual described the
outcome as a "victory for democracy" and pledged to work for all
in the strife-torn country.

"I will be the President of all Algerians," he said. He won
61.34 per cent of the votes, making a second round ballot
unnecessary.

The candidate for the Movement for the Islamic Society (Hamas),
Mahfoudh Nahnah, got 25.38 percent of the votes; the Rally for
Culture and Democracy's Said Saadi 9.29 percent; and the Algerian
Party for Renewal's Nourredine Boukrouh 3.7 percent. The extremist
Armed Islamic Group boycotted the polls. This group has waged a
terror campaign against authorities in recent years.

Following Zeroual's victory, some leaders of the radical
Islamic Salvation Front said they wanted talks with Zeroual to end
the feud between them.

"We are prepared to enter into talks with the government so as
to contribute to the return of peace in Algeria," said Rabah
Kebir, a leading member of the front living in exile.

However, others in the organization are opposed to any
reconciliation. "Liamine Zeroual's election is the confirmation of
a masquerade," said Anouar Haddam, another exiled leader.
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


296 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Government Endorses Carter's Mediation


LENGTH: 614 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

KIGALI, Rwanda - Still shattered by the sight of skulls of
massacre victims in a Rwandan church, former U.S. President Jimmy
Carter Monday expressed hope that forthcoming talks in Cairo will
bring lasting peace to the region.

Carter announced in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, that the
government here had officially agreed to participate in the
summit next week to resolve the crises in the so-called Great
Lakes region.

Addressing a news conference here, Carter hoped the meeting, to
be held in Cairo from 28 November to 2 December, will have a
limited agenda, the Rwandan News Agency (ARP) reported. 

Mr.Carter, who will be the summit's chief mediator, said he
hoped the meeting would encourage the quick return of genuine
Rwandan refugees and an end to intimidation within refugee camps
in Tanzania and Zaire.

An estimated two million Rwandan Hutu refugees have been
living in camps in Rwanda and Tanzania since the massacres which
followed the death of President Juvenal Habyariamana in a plane
crash on April 6, 1994.

He said the meeting will discuss ways of stopping the flow of
arms to the refugee camps. He hoped the discussions will build up
support for the Arusha International Tribunal which is expected to
try the perpetrators of genocide in Rwanda.

Other mediators at the summit will be former Tanzanian
President Julius Nyerere and Archbishop Desmond Tutu of Cape Town,
South Africa.

The summit is expected to be attended by the presidents of
Burundi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire.

Carter told journalists that among the sights that stuck in his
mind during his two-day visit in Rwanda were the skulls he saw at
the altar of Ntarama Parish Church near Kigali.

At least 5,000 people were butchered at Ntarama church during
last year's genocide in which up to one million people, mostly
from the minority Tutsi ethnic group and moderates from the
majority Hutu were massacred by extremists.

Remains of the dead are still inside the church.

Carter said that representatives of non-government
organizations and human rights groups had confirmed to him that
conditions inside Rwanda were ripe for the return of refugees.

The former President and his wife Rosalyn left for Bujumbura
where he will hold similar talks before returning to Uganda. He
will also visit Zaire.
-0Algeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


297 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Anti-Poaching Campaign Stepped Up


LENGTH: 667 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 27, 1995 (19951127)
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian wildlife officials have created
additional incentives for villagers living near game management
areas and national game parks who provide information that leads
to the arrest and punishment of poachers.

National Parks and Wildlife Service officials said at the
departmental headquarters outside the capital Lusaka Monday that
the department had introduced a 20,000 Zambian kwacha (about
USD21) "reward" to anybody helping them catch poachers and
retrieve fire-arms used for poaching.

Departmental spokesman, Ternnyson M'simuko, said that there had
been a marked increased in poaching levels, particulary in the
country's western region due to famine caused by recurrent
drought. 

Zambian wildlife officials also attribute the upsurge in
poaching in the area to an illicit trade in fire-arms involving
former Namibian freedom fighters as well as former rebel Unita
fighters in neighbouring Angola.

Some 84 guns, including AK 47 assault rifles, were displayed
Monday by the officials who said they had confiscated them from
poachers in the Western province over the past two weeks.

Sixty-one elephant tusks were also caught in the operation.

The officals meanwhile reported Monday that there had been a
slight increase in the number of elephant in the countrysince its
ban on the trade in ivory under the Convention on Trade in
Endangered Species (Cites).

There are currently an estimated 18,000 to 22,000 elephant
herds in Zambia, from an estimated 1 million about 10 years ago.

Zambia is a popular destination for international poachers,
particulary for the elephant and rhino which are killed for their
tusks and horns believed to be sold on the black market in the
Middle East and Asia.

The tusk is said to be mainly used for ornamental articles by
rich Arab sheikhs. In Asia, the rhino horn is said to be used in
the preparation of aphrodisiacs.

Because of rampant poaching, the black rhino, indegenous black
rhino, could almost be extinct.

The only known rhino population now are six "white rhinos" at
the Livingstone park in the southern tourist town of Livingstone.

They had been imported from South Africa several years ago and
have all since been dehorned as protection against poachers.

Zambian wildlife officials run a wildlife management scheme
under which residents near game management areas share game fees
paid by tourists and from the sale of trophy with the government.
This is designed to encourage them to take keen interest in
wildlife conservation.
-0Rwanda


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


298 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Widespread Rains in Midlands


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 27, 1995 (19951127)

GWERU, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's Midlands Province has received
widespread rains with some areas getting much more than the
required amount for planting, Provincial Agritex officer Joseph
Zishiri said on Monday.

In an interview with ZIANA, Zishiri said the heavy showers
which pounded parts of the province last week has resulted in the
maize crop germinating well. 

"In the areas which got some October showers, the germinating
maize crop is looking beautiful and the condition is good," he
said.

Zishiri said areas which received much more than the necessary
planting rains were Copper Queen in the Nembudziyarea, Nemangwe,
Silobela, Lower Gweru, Shurugwi, the whole of Mvuma and northern
parts of Zvishavane.

He said in other parts of the province there was still need for
more rains to provide adequate moisture to enable most of the seed
to germinate.

On livestock, he said the situation was improving
"tremendously", adding that farmers who could afford to douse
their cattle for internal parasites should do so.

A meteorological office spokesman said on Monday the wet spell
had stopped temporarily because of the unfavourable upper air
circulation.
-0Zambia

November, 1995


Dakar Hosts Workshop on Water Sources


LENGTH: 374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 27, 1995 (19951127)

DAKAR, Senegal - The Senegal River Development Organization
(OMVS) is Monday beginning here a three-day workshop on the
management of water sources in three West african countries.

The meeting is expected to produce an action plan for the
management of water sources, environmental and health matters
within the member countries-Mali, Muritania and Senegal. 

Participants will review existing studies, actions and ongoing
programmes in these spheres so as to reach a consensus on future
actions, their practical modalities, funding and thedistribution
of roles.

The workshop is being jointly organised by the World Bank, the
United States Agency for International Development,
theInternational Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) and
the World Health Organization.

The organisers said the meeting, which ends Thursday,will be
attended by representatives from the three member states and nonThe OMVS was created on 11 March 1972 by the Presidents of
governmental organisations.
Mali, Mauritania, to replace the Organization of Reparian States
set up in 1968.
The organisation seeks to promote cooperation in the management
and development of the river basin's resources.
Its achievements include the construction of Diame (Senegal) and
Manantali (Mali) dams for hydroelectricity andirrigation.
-0Zimbabwe

Africa News


November, 1995


Grain-Eating Birds Wipped Out In Amhara State


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 27, 1995 (19951127)

DESSIE, Ethiopia - An aerial spraying operation has wiped 90
per cent of grain-eating birds locally known as Girisa in
Ethiopia's north Shoa and Orominya zone of Ahmara regional state,
according to an expert in the Ministry of Agriculture.

The coordinator of the operation, Hussien Ali, said a swarm of
Girisa had been damaging crops in the two zones since September. 

He said most of the birds were killed after 425 hectares of
land invaded by the predators was sprayed with 825 litres of
pesticide.

The operation was conducted by professionals drawn from the
Harer and Kombolcha crop protection units and others from the
agricultural departments of the two zones.

Ali said 90 per cent of existing crops in the two areas were
saved as a result of the operation, although the experts decided
Jile, Timuga and Shoarobit were unfavourable for the spraying
exercise.

The expert said the remaining swarm of Girisa could not damage
crops as farmers in the area have already started harvesting.
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


FIFA Suspends Five African Players, Coaches.


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 30, 1995 (19951130)

LAGOS, Nigeria - FIFA, the world's soccer
governing body, has confirmed the suspension of five African
players and coaches from all international matches for periods
ranging from six months to two years.

FIFA News, an official journal of the organization, said
the players are Nigeria's Kennedy Boboye, Algeria's Bilal
Zouani, Lesotho's Seholoholo Mathe and coaches Paulo Maria of
Sudan and Mory Conde of Guinea. 

Boboye was suspended for one year for assaulting the
referee of the Egypt-Nigeria tie during the All-Africa Games held
September in Harare, Zimbabwe. He will be off the hook
Sept. 22 1996.

Zouani is banned until Sept. 19, 1996 for violence
against Guinea's goalkeeper during the Algeria-Guinea match at
the games.

Mathe was banned for two years for assaulting the referee
during an African Winners Cup tie between his club Matlama and
Cadets
of Mauritius.

Maria, coach of Sudan's Hilal, was axed for one year for
encroaching on the field of play to protest the referee's
decision in an African Champions' Cup match against Zimbabwe's
Dynamos.

For taunting spectators during his club's match, Conde of
Guinea's Horoya will remain in the cooler for six months. He
committed the offence when Horoya played Stade Malien in an
African Champions' Cup match.
-0Ethiopia

Africa News


November, 1995


Liberian is African Footballer of The Year


LENGTH: 307 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 30, 1995 (19951130)

LAGOS, Nigeria - Liberian star George Weah has been
named African Footballer of the Year (1995) by the African
Football Confederation (CAF), reports received in Dakar Thursday
said.

The 1994 winner was Nigeria's Emmanuel Amunike. The
Nigerian, who plays for Sporting in Portugal, dropped to fifth
position in CAF's ranking for 1995.

Weah helped his former club Paris St. Germain win the
French cup last season and steered Liberia to its first ever
Africa Nations Cup ticket through his personal motivation, moral
and financial support.

He is now with past European champions AC Milan of Italy's
first division. Chad's Japhet N'doram, the captain of Nantes
football club in France, was ranked second.

Finidi George, who plays for European and world soccer
club champions Ajax Amsterdam in the Netherlands, took the third
position and Ghana's Anthony Yeboah the fourth.

Yeboah last year helped his British team, Leeds United,
notch their first European cup ticket.
-0Africa-at-Large

Africa News


November, 1995


Scientist Produces AIDS Drug


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 30, 1995 (19951130)
by Moses Draku PANA Staff Correspondent

KAMPALA, Uganda - A Ugandan scientist has
discovered a new drug for the treatment of HIV whose results are
said to be very promising, health officials said here Wednesday.

The drug is being tested by the Joint Clinical Research
Centre (JCRC) in Kampala where at least eight other drugs are
being evaluated for safety and anti-HIV potency. 

The unidentified scientist is a cancer specialist who
found out that the drug enhanced immunity in cancer patients. He
has worked with JCRC for two years.

The drug is being manufactured in the United Kingdom
specifically for JCRC's evaluation against the Human
Immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, that leads to AIDS.

Meanwhile, the incidence of AIDS is declining in urban
areas in Uganda but increasing in rural areas, AIDS Control
Program manager Elizabeth Madraa disclosed Monday in Kampala.

She based her conclusion on data from ante-natal clinics
in the country where women are routinely checked for HIV.

"While we witness a decline of HIV infection in urban
areas, infection is on the increase in rural Uganda," she told
legislators at a one-day AIDS seminar in Kampala.

She said HIV was spreading more rapidly among married
women.
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

November, 1995


Cabinet Reshuffled


LENGTH: 227 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 30, 1995 (19951130)

LOME, Togo - Togo's Prime Minister Edem Kodjo
has carried out his first cabinet reshuffle since he was
appointed in April 1994. 

Announcing the change Wednesday in Lome Kodjo, a former
secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity, named 13
new ministers in his 23-member cabinet.

A government statement read on Togolese television
Wednesday night said nine ministers were dropped while two
ministers were elevated to become ministers of state or senior
ministers.

The previous cabinet had 18 ministers.

The senior ministers include Moussa Barque (foreign affairs
and cooperation) and Elome Emile Dadzie (finance and economy).
-0Uganda

Africa News


November, 1995


Refugees To Petition Francophonie Summit


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 30, 1995 (19951130)

DAKAR, Senegal - Black Mauritanian refugees
living in Senegal plan to petition the forthcoming Francophonie
summit of French-speaking countries in Cotonou to exert pressure
on Mauritania to allow them to return home.

The refugees have been living in Senegal since 1989 when
they were expelled from Mauritania following bloody clashes over
communal grazing rights. 

In an open letter to the summit which begins Sunday, the
Association of Mauritanian Refugees in Senegal accuses Mauritanian
authorities of deporting them from the country "because they are
Negro-Africans, especially Wolofs, Fulanis and Soninkes".

"Since then, these landless people have been living
in Senegal and Mali on food assistance, which has been
gradually reduced and will be terminated on 31 December
1995", the letter said.

The association blamed the international community for
turning "a blind eye to this injustice".

Hundreds of black people were thrown out of Mauritania
during the conflict which erupted between Mauritania and Senegal
in April-May 1989 over a border grazing area.

Senegal retaliated by kicking out Mauritanian businessmen,
mostly light-skinned moors who owned most of the retail shops in
the capital, Dakar.

An unknown number of people were killed on both sides
following the inter-communal hostilities.

The two states broke off diplomatic relations in August
1989 but restored them two years later.
-0Togo


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


306 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Third Bank Collapses In Six Months


LENGTH: 574 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 30, 1995 (19951130)
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's central bank closed the
privately-owned Commerce Bank Wednesday and placed it under
receivership after it ran out of cash to meet depositors demands.

It is also being punished for failing to replenish its
central bank clearing account.

The closure brought to three in a period of six months the
number of privately-owned commercial banks in the country that
have
shut down due to liquidity problems. 

The country's fourth largest bank, the Meridien BIAO, was
shut in May followed by Africa Commercial Bank which was closed
in November for similar reasons.

The Bank of Zambia has appointed Delloite and Touche to
act as receivers for Commerce Bank.

Commerce Bank branches in the Copperbelt region
were earlier this week reported to be issuing bad cheques. In the
capital, Lusaka, some government workers who receive their
salaries
through Commerce Bank were unable to get their money when the bank
ran out of cash.

The government announced last week new stringent measures
to protect depositors in the wake of instability in the banking
sector.

According to the country's new banking regulations banks
and financial institutions will now have to deposit half of their
profits in a reserve account before declaring dividends.

This measure, instituted by Finance Minister Ronald
Penza, is intended to ensure the liquidity of any bank
matches its paid-up equity capital.

Penza also raised the minimal investment capital for
setting up a bank from 1.25 million U.S. dollars to 2.5 million
dollars with effect from June 1996.

Financial analysts have blamed low investment capital in
the banking business and a depressed financial market as
responsible
for most of the banks'liquidity problems.

Zambia has 15 commercial banks. The majority were
established following the 1992 liberalization of the economy.
-0Mauritania


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.
