Africa News


November, 1995


Purge Fever Grips Civil Servants


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 30, 1995 (19951130)
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - A government circular announcing
an imminent purge in Nigeria's bloated Federal Civil Service has
unleashed fears among workers as labour unions prepare to oppose
the action.

The chairman of the Federal Civil Service Commission
(FCSC), Shuaib Kazaure, has however, said that jobs will "not
be casually swept away" and that there will be no
"witch-hunt." 

But some government workers who still remember a similar
exercise in 1975 when thousands of civil servants were
retrenched appear unconvinced by these assurances.

Kazaure speaking Wednesday after the government circular
early this month said "we are not going to witch-hunt, all we
are doing is a kind of cleaning up."

There are no available official figures of the strength
of the Nigerian Federal Civil Service, but experts talk of "tens
of thousands."

The Federal Ministry of Works and Housing alone has more
than 20,000 workers in its pay roll. The minister, Maj.Gen.
Abdulkarim Adisa has instituted a staff audit to flush out
"ghost workers" drawing from public coffers millions of dollars
yearly as salaries.

The World Bank and the IMF have since made staff
rationalization a precondition for financial assistance to
Nigeria.
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Opposition Parties Press for Chiluba Citizenship Probe


LENGTH: 774 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
November 30, 1995 (19951130)
by Musengwa Kayaya PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's main opposition, the
United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former president
Kenneth Kaunda, has called for an international commission to
probe President Frederick Chiluba's disputed citizenship.

UNIP secretary-seneral Sebastian Zulu said Wednesday
the commission should comprise Commonwealth, United Nations
representatives and Zambians representing the media, the
judiciary, the law association, the church and non-governmental
organizations.

The independent daily, The Post, published Monday
details of what it claimed were Chiluba's birth certificate. The
details showed he was born in Zaire, of Zairean parents. 

This is contrary to the president's own and his
relatives' conflicting versions. The president says he was born
on the Zambian Copperbelt while some of his relatives say he was
born in the northern Luapula province.

In a simialr statement Wednesday president of the
opposition Alliance for National Reconstruction Rev. Alfred
Sayila also urged a similar probe and advised Chiluba's ruling
Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) to bar him from
contesting the party's presidency at a forthcoming national
convention.

The Zambia Democratic Congress, a break-away
faction of the MMD, said Tuesday it was considering legal options
against the president for alleged fraud in his acquisition of
Zambian citizenship.

UNIP claimed Wednesday that it had been aware since 1968
that Chiluba had lied about his birth and the identity of his
parents.

The Post alleged Monday that both the president's mother
and father were Zaireans who met and married on the Zambian side
of the border. His mother reportedly returned to Zaire to prepare
for delivery and gave birth to Chiluba on June 12, 1944, at
Chibambo mission in Zaire's southern Shaba region.

Chiluba's relatives said Monday they would sue The Post
for lying.

The newspaper also alleged Tuesday that defence minister Ben
Mwila, who is Chiluba's uncle, was also Zairean.

Citizenship has gained critical importance in Zambian
politics with Chiluba's MMD having sponsored a draft constitution
that stipulates that only second generation Zambians can stand for
the presidency.

Former president Kenneth Kaunda, who had Malawian parents
and wants to challenge Chiluba in Zambia's 1996 presidential
election, has vowed to fight to "the bitter end" to block
adoption of the clause.

The Post has since 1994 claimed the Zambian
president was born in Zaire and that he had a forged junior
secondary school certificate.

Political analysts think Chiluba's options will now
almost certainly include dropping the controversial citizenship
clause in the draft constitution. This will mean he will almost
certainly have to face Kaunda in the 1996 elections.
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


(DOCUMENT) Death Sentence for Activists Draws Fire


LENGTH: 1987 words


 
Africa Policy Information Center
November 1, 1995 (19951101)

Washington, D.C. -- Pressure from around the world is mounting
on the Nigerian government following the death sentence handed
down earlier this week for Nigerian activist Ken Saro-Wiwa and his
colleagues. Reaction has come not only from Nigerian pro-democracy
activists and human rights organizations, but also from
environmental groups.

While the major immediate focus is on saving the lives of the
condemned activists, Nigerian pro-democracy campaigners also
stress that pressure on the regime needs to be escalated for
release of all detainees and for an end to military rule. Nobelparticular to lead the international community in imposing strict
prize-winning Nigerian author Wole Soyinka urged South Africa in
economic sanctions on military-ruled Nigeria. 

"There has to be the threat of withdrawal of diplomatic
relations and severe economic sanctions," Soyinka, told BBC radio
from exile in Britain. "It is the only way lives will be saved,"
he said.

The Nigerian Democratic Movement issued the following
statement. The two additional bulletins below, from Amnesty
International and Friends of the Earth, provide additional
background and indicate possible action.
******************************************************************
****

Issued by the Executive Council of the Nigerian Democratic
Movement (NDM), P.O. Box 91291, Washington, DC 20090; Tel:
202/806-4793; 301/989-0016; 202/395-7052; 301/808-0800; Fax:
202/806-4632; Email contact: maluko@scs.howard.edu

---------------- About Ken Saro-Wiwa --------------------

The death sentences announced today on Ken Saro-Wiwa and other
Ogoni activists are simply outrageous, and represent not only a
continuation of the oppressive nature of this regime, but also its
latest manifestation of a new tendency to draw attention to itself
to elicit legitimacy: death sentences, world appeals for clemency,
commutation, relief from international pressure? No one must be
fooled.

The Nigerian Democratic Movement and other well-meaning
Nigerians demand justice, freedom and fair-play in Nigeria, and
will settle for nothing less.

We ask that you join us in vigorously protesting this official
policy of hostage-taking by the military junta in Nigeria, and
DEMAND THAT NO ONE MUST BE OFFICIALLY MURDERED, not the alleged
coupists (for example, in retaliation for their latest
revelations), not Saro-Wiwa or any other Ogoni activists.
******************************************************************
****

AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL URGENT ACTION BULLETIN

For information, contact: Ray Mitchell, rmitchellai@gn.apc.org
(UK) or Scott Harrison, sharrison@igc.apc.org (US)

31 October 1995

Ken Saro-Wiwa, writer and environmentalist, President of the
Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP); Dr Barinem
Kiobel, former Rivers State Commissioner (minister); Saturday
Dobee; Paul Levura; Nordu Eawo; Felix Nuate; Daniel Gbokoo; John
Kpuinen, student; Baribor Bera, farmer.

On 30 and 31 October 1995, after what Amnesty International
believes to have been politically-motivated and unfair trials, the
nine people named above were convicted of murder and sentenced to
death by hanging. Amnesty International considers at least two of
them - Ken Saro-Wiwa and Dr Barinem Kiobel - to be prisoners of
conscience, imprisoned for the non-violent expression of their
political views.

The nine were convicted in connection with the murder of four
Ogoni leaders by an angry crowd in May 1994, for which the
leadership of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People
(MOSOP) was pronounced responsible by the authorities the day
after the murders. MOSOP, a non-governmental organization in
Rivers State, southeast Nigeria, has been targeted by the
government in recent years for its non-violent campaign against
environmental damage by oil companies and for more autonomy for
the Ogoni ethnic group.

The defendants were detained incommunicado and without charge
for at least eight months before being charged; several were
alleged to have been tortured or ill-treated in military custody.

They were convicted in two trials conducted simultaneously by a
Civil Disturbances Special Tribunal in Port Harcourt, Rivers
State. This court, which falls outside the normal judicial system,
was appointed by the military government especially to try these
cases.

The trials contravened Nigerian and international standards for
fair trial to which the Nigerian government is committed, in
particular the right to fair trial by an independent court and the
right of appeal to a higher and independent jurisdiction. The
Tribunal has shown itself to be neither independent of government
control nor impartial. The Federal Military Government has
controlled every aspect of the case: the arrests, investigations,
prosecution, appointment of the tribunal and the progress of the
trial itself. Two key prosecution witnesses alleged that they were
threatened and bribed to give false evidence.

The defence lawyers withdrew from the trials in June and July
1995 in protest at continued bias by the Tribunal in favour of the
prosecution.

Ledum Mitee and four other defendants in the two trials were
acquitted.
******************************************************************
****

FRIENDS OF THE EARTH-US October 31, 1995

EMERGENCY ALERT****EMERGENCY ALERT****EMERGENCY ALERT

For more infomation, contact: Andrea Durbin, tel: 202-783-7400,
ext 209 fax: 202-783-0444.email: foedc@igc.apc.org.

NIGERIAN ENVIRONMENTALIST, KEN SARO-WIWA, SENTENCED TO DEATH

Ken Saro-Wiwa, environmental activist and leader of the Ogoni
people in the Niger Delta, and nine others were sentenced today to
death by a Nigerian military tribunal. Saro-Wiwa, recipient of the
Goldman Environmental Prize and nominated for the Nobel Peace
Prize, leads the struggle of the Ogoni people against Shell Oil,
whose operations have contaminated their land and resources for
more than three decades. Last year, Saro-Wiwa was jailed in
connection with the murder of four Ogoni leaders, which human
rights groups have said are false charges. Amnesty International
has declared Saro-Wiwa a Prisoner of Conscience.

The four year peaceful campaign of the Ogonis has been met by
repression from the Nigerian military dictatorship leading to the
deaths of more than 1,000 Ogoni. Shell Oil has also been
implicated in the violence that has transcended this region.
According to human rights groups, Shell has used military
personnel to defend their oil operations, resulting in some
injuries and deaths. Since 1958, Royal Dutch Shell has extracted
US $30 billion in oil from Ogoniland, but the Ogoni people still
lack basic services, healthcare, and jobs.

ACTIONS TO TAKE:

1. Contact the Clinton Administration and ask that the
Administration come out strongly against this sentencing and
demand the release of Saro-Wiwa and the others. The United States
has political pull with Nigeria, particularly given that the U.S.
consumes 70 percent of Nigeria's oil.
Specifically, we are asking that Clinton call General Abacha of
Nigeria, denouncing the verdicts and warn that if these people are
put to death, it will have profound political ramifcations. Fax a
letter or call: Anthony Lake, Assistant to the President for
National Security Affairs, National Security Council, Washington,
DC 20504, tel: 202-395-3000, fax: 202-456-2883

2. Send a letter to General Abacha, the military ruler of
Nigeria, asking for Saro-Wiwa's immediate release, citing the
international condemnation this sentencing has received. Fax
letter to: General Sani Abacha President of the Federal Republic
of Nigeria c/o The Nigerian Ambassador to the United States
Nigerian Embassy, 1333 16th Street, NW Washington, DC 20036 fax:
202-775-1385

3. Send a letter to Shell denouncing their role in the Ogoni
situation and asking for Shell to come out strongly for the
release of the wrongly accused. Fax letter to: Phillip J. Carroll,
CEO Shell Oil Corporation, Houston, Texas. fax: 713-241-4044

*******************************************************

Africa Policy Information Center 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #112
Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545.
-0Zambia

310 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Two Million Work in Informal Sector


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 3, 1995 (19951103)
by Rowan Callaghan

Johannesburg - The informal sector provides jobs for almost two
million people, according to research by Unisa's Bureau of Market
Research (BMR).

The BMR study found that last year almost 1,6-million, or
around 15 percent, of the total South African work orce was
employed in the informal sector. 

This sector contributed an estimated R26-billion, or around
seven percent of the official gross domestic product (GDP) figure,
the total value of all goods and services produced by the economy.

Activities in this sector are concentrated in trade (48
percent) and community and personal services (17 percent), with
contributions from transport (12 percent), construction (10
percent) and manufacturing (seven percent).

In the traditionally black areas of Gauteng like Soweto,
Tembisa, Kagiso, and Mamelodi the research found that of the
almost R16-billion spent at retail outlets, 28 percent went to
the informal sector.
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


311 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Gold Mining No Longer Glitters


LENGTH: 1867 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 3, 1995 (19951103)
by Reg Rumney

Johannesburg - Working seven days a week will help gold mines
survive in the medium term -- but gold mining is in decline, says
Amgold chairman Clem Sunter.

Gold mining, once the mainstay and still a central pillar of
the South African economy, is in what Sunter calls "managed
decline".

Industrial unrest and public holidays were generally blamed for
bad gold mining results in the second quarter of this year, but
the results focused attention on the malaise in gold mining as
well as the continuing importance of gold to South Africa's
economic growth.

The various mining houses have reported their results for the
third quarter. Unlike the second quarter, which was uniformly
disastrous, third quarter results proved a mixed bag, with Amgold,
among other mining groups, showing some improvement. 

Sunter warns against looking at one quarter's figures in
isolation. He uses a characteristically graphic metaphor to
describe the plight of South African gold mining.

"We were like a 747 flying at 30 000 feet, in the early 80s to
the mid-80s, when the gold price was coming down from $600 to
$400.

"If you hit an air pocket in a quarter you reduced your margins
slightly. and, OK, you made less profit, but you still made a very
healthy profit. Now we're flying at 500 feet. You hit an air
pocket and you immediately run into a loss situation. We did that
at Freegold in the previous quarter. And when you make a loss on
revenue of R1-billion for a quarter its alarming.

"And that is why we concentrated on trying to turn Freegold
around."

Sunter pinpoints the problem: despite extensive exploration
over the last 15 years, using sophisticated techniques, Amgold has
found no new major gold field.

The new gold finds have been in the gaps between gold fields
and near existing mines. And apart from one or two exceptions like
Moab, for which Amgold is putting a shaft down adjacent to Vaal
Reefs in the South East, those deposits tend to be lower grade
and would require a gold price of say $450 to $500 in today's
money -- for some time.

"You would have to have a confidence that the gold price had
moved to a new higher plateau."

"One should never say never in prospecting and there could
still be a major gold field to be uncovered, but working on
probabilities one would say we're into the game of exploiting as
efficiently as possible the remaining gold from existing mining
areas and areas not viable at the current gold price.

"Given that all mines start with the sweeter grades and
gradually work down to the lowest grade portions, we are in a
state of managed decline."

Gold production has already almost halved from the 1000 tons a
year achieved in 1970 to around 550 tons of gold now.

"I think it is inevitable that it will continue down from 550
tons. And that is difficult to manage because of the 'stepped
function' of overheads."

Sunter explains that when gold production on a particular shaft
falls below a certain level, unless a quantum of overheads is shut
down, that reduced level of production does not cover the cost of
shaft.

So if production falls, the rand per kilogram cost of the mine
can actually rise because overheads are not being shed at the same
time.

Many of Amgold's old shafts have fairly uniform grades. If they
do not cut the mustard, they will have to be closed. There has
been speculation that as many as 50 000 jobs might be in jeopardy
at Anglo American mines.

Sunter is cautious. Out of 33 shafts, around a third are
"endangered", although Sunter is at pains to point out that the
situation can be changed.

One of the things that will change the picture is Full Calendar
Operations (Fulco).

Sunter is on record as having said at the beginning of the year
that gold mining must be one of the only industries in the world
with 275 working days out of 365.

His warning then, that costs would exceed revenue by the second
quarter if something was not done, have been borne out.

"We've had a fairly flat price this year, costs have continued
to escalate in rand/kg terms and the margin has been eliminated on
many of the mines."

Will Fulco not merely shorten the life of the mine? Sunter
emphasises it will do the opposite. Fulco will lower the pay load
because of the increased economies

"The grade of the ore you can mine can actually drop and you
can bring into play a greater proportion of the ore body than if
you had stayed on the present 11-shift ortnight. By mining seven
days a week you can actually increase the amount of gold you get
out of a particular ore body."

Fulco has been virtually negotiated with the workers, although
the National Union of Mineworkers still has to give its
imprimatur. "They seem prepared to allow negotiations to proceed
on a shaft-by-shaft basis, even though they won't give their
agreement at the centre. All the mining groups are negotiating
Fulco at shaft level"

Sunter cautions that Fulco is not a panacea. Many old shafts
are not appropriate for Fulco because only mining pillars and bits
and pieces are left to mine. Fulco mainfly benefits new shafts
where mining can continue uninterruptedly on ore bodies, such as
with Freddies No 1 shaft at Freegold.

Moving the appropriate shafts in Amgold's portfolio to Fulco
will absorb labour from some of the other shafts which are in
decline. In terms of slowing the rate of descent of South Africa's
gold production Fulco is important, but unless a major new gold
field is found, there will not be a major turnaround in South
African gold production

Fulco itself, could probably pre-empt a drop of 10 percent to
15 percent in gold mining production.

Given that fixed overheads constitute around 75 percent to 80
percent of mine costs (labour constitutes around 50 percent ),
the marginal costs of working an extra 90 shifts a year is fairly
low, although there will be additional labour, as a roster system
will be in place.

Sunter conservatively estimates that the additional gold will
cost 25 percent less to mine. He notes that Fulco is only one part
of the solution to productivity improvement.

"To really transform prospects, we have to find either a higher
dollar price of gold, that is $420, or change our management
systems to produce a more participative approach"

At Elandsrand, he said a "Wheels of Change" initiative with
different components, such as multi-tasking in the stope teams,
leaves a good part of the handling of tasks to the team's
discretion, putting more of the decision-making in the hands of
the people at the rock face. This has led to increases in
productivity of 30 to 50 percent.

Vaal Reefs No 10 shaft, he adds, has also gone in for modern
participative management systems. Bonus systems, which pass part
of productivity improvements back financially to the employee,
also help. Yet in the end, barring the discovery of a major gold
field, gold mining will decline.

Sunter says Fulco might mean that the 30 to 35 percent
contribution of gold to South Africa's foreign exchange earnings
remains for a while longer, but the country must start
diversifying now.

South Africa must move further away from dependence on a single
foreign exchange earning commodity than it has already, and
towards manufactured exports, which have higher margins and are
more sustainable than the gold, which is finally, it seems,
running out.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


312 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


South Africa Oil Deal On The Back Burner


LENGTH: 1000 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 3, 1995 (19951103)
by Karen Harverson

Johannesburg - Depending on whom you believe, South Africa's
deal to store and trade Iranian oil has fizzled out -- or it has
just been suspended pending the outcome of an environmental study
on the risks of increased tanker traffic to Saldanha Bay.

Two weeks ago Business Day reported that the deal had
floundered over Iran's refusal to offer South Africa an
acceptable cut in trading profits. It quoted overseas sources
which claimed the deal was "dead in the water".

However, Strategic Fuel Fund (SFF) general manager Kobus van
Zyl is adamant that the deal -- which could have earned South
Africa R50-million a year in profits -- is only "temporarily
suspended" and has not been scrapped. 

"The storage agreement has been signed. The joint venture
trading agreement must still be signed although all the main
aspects of the deal have been agreed upon."

He added that the deal was suspended because the South African
government insisted that the outcome of the environmental study
be made a suspensive condition of the contract. "The Iranians are
naturally upset about this late development but both parties have
to respect it."

Industry sources claim Iran's initial interest in the deal was
fuelled by its urgent need to find storage for its oil which was
piling up because of United States sanctions against the country.

Another benefit is the strategic position of the Saldanha tank
farm which is convenient for the African, South American and north
west European markets.

The SFF's deal with Iran entails both storing Iranian oil and
trading it -- and the storage agreement will apparently not go
ahead without the trading aspect being tied in.

"A storage deal based on a storage fee has never been discussed
and is presently not under consideration by the SFF," says Van
Zyl.

Iran's apparent reluctance to conclude a satisfactory joint
venture trading agreement with South Africa may indicate that its
need to store oil is not as desperate as once thought or even that
it no longer has the oil available to place in storage.

In any event, the deal won't get the go-ahead before the
outcome of the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research's
(CSIR) environmental impact assessment (EIA) study which seems
unlikely to be completed earlier than mid-1996.

Last week the CSIR released a Background Information Document
to some 340 affected or interested parties, inviting comment on
the proposed process and on the issues which need to be addressed
by the study.

Comment must be submitted by mid-November, following which a
scoping report will be published describing the agreed process of
the EIA, the viable project alternatives to be assessed and the
key issues to be taken into account.

Thereafter, specialist studies will be undertaken on those
issues identified in the scoping phase.

Finally a documented report will be drafted based on the
findings of the studies and the SFF will then decide if it is to
proceed with plans to expand operations at Saldanha.

The benefits to South Africa of the Iran deal -- besides the
estimated R50-million trading profit -- include improving the
utilisation of an under-utilised asset and using Iran's crude oil
as collateral for export trade to that country from South Africa.

A deal with Iran could also result in a reduction of South
Africa's strategic oil stocks below the target of 35-million
barrels, thus releasing more than $250- million for use by the
government.

At present, South Africa has 53-million barrels of crude oil
stockpiled compared to its highest level of 150-million barrels
in mid-1989.

The SFF plans to reduce the 36-million barrels at Ogies to 10to 25-million, thus reaching its target of 35-million barrels.
million barrels and increase the 16-million barrels at Saldanha
"The present rate of reduction is very low (about 700 000 barrels
a month) and could take about 25 months to achieve," says Van
Zyl.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


313 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Review: Accumulated Horror of the Black Diaspora


LENGTH: 1254 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 3, 1995 (19951103)
by Louise Asmal

Johannesburg - THE BLACK DIASPORA by Ronald Segal (Faber &
Faber, R135)

This extraordinary compendium attempts to compress within less
than 500 pages not only a description of the trade in human beings
from Africa to the colonies of the various European powers, but
also an account of the fate of their descendants up to the present
day.

The resulting book is dense with facts and figures. Indeed, the
author recognises in the preface that the task is virtually
impossible, and that really what he hopes to achieve is to spark
off ideas and inspire fresh insights.

Ronald Segal is a man of huge ability and passion. 
Unfortunately the passion hardly surfaces in The Black Diaspora
except in his preface, in which he presents an apologia for his
lack of political correctness in writing as a white man on such a
topic. If his intention was to eliminate all traces of
Eurocentrism, and to present the facts as they emerge from the
history of the diaspora and the impact of that history on the
development of black society outside Africa, then he has
succeeded.

To my mind, however, he has succeeded at the cost of producing
a book consisting of an unvarnished catalogue of facts, in which
the sheer accumulation of horror almost anaesthetises feeling.

The terrors of the actual slave trade are bad enough. The
cruelty of the colonists is, one is tempted to say, unbelievable,
except that one knows from the recent history of our own country
that no cruelty is taboo when the oppressors treat the oppressed
as less than human.

By contrast, the slaves themselves clung to their hopes of
freedom and often displayed the most extraordinary heroism and
courage in their attempts to achieve it. By and large, slave
rebellions everywhere were far more merciful to their white
oppressors than the oppressors were to them.

Yet in spite of this, the slaves themselves and their
descendants were not immune to the moral corruption of racism. The
colonisers themselves were quick to seize on and foster the
divisions between blacks and mulattos, or between blacks and
Indians. The resulting conflicts proved terribly destructive.
Elsewhere numbers of those who seized power, or their successors,
lost their idealism and succumbed to the same greed and
selfishness displayed by the colonisers. As Segal himself says in
his preface, it is the ultimate injustice that "the victims are
so often also victimisers of one another and themselves".

It is, I think, a major defect of the book that one is left
with such a depressing picture. Attempts by Segal to alleviate
this with chapters on black art, music, sport, and religion do not
really succeed. The chapters on blacks in America, Brazil
(evidently far from the miracle of a raceless society that is
usually presented), and Britain are equally depressing.

Certainly this is partly the result of leading up to a
particular point in time (the book ends in the early 1990s) when
we are past the age of decolonisation and the hope that that
presented. And whether or not the "end of history" has really been
reached, it is true that the world has at present no cohesive
ideology which offers a vision for progress in the future.
Perhaps in South Africa we may aspire to offer an example of race
relations for the future, but South Africa does not fall within
the purview of this book.

However, there are certainly lessons for us in the experience
of the decolonised countries, which future writers may tease out.
So often in the world of the black diaspora class structure
manifests itself most obviously along colour lines, with the
result that where blacks are at the bottom of the pile, and
visibly so, the class structure becomes more rigid and racial
resentments intensify.

Paradoxically, it is in one of the societies where this is seen
most clearly that Segal sees most hope for the future. This is
Jamaica, where virtually all those at the top are white, and
growing richer, while virtually all those at the bottom are
black, and growing poorer. Yet here Segal reflects that the
Jamaican "acceptance" of the slave experience produces a "creative
realisation of identity and meaning for the black diaspora".

Tantalisingly, this concept is not explored further. One is
tempted to hypothesise that Segal has in mind a colonisers' truth
commission. Whether or not this is so -- and it is not an entirely
novel idea -- it is undoubtedly an idea which merits further
exploration, and the book provides a basis for it.

Segal's conclusion that the black diaspora provides hope for a
world torn by ethnic divisions also deserves amplification and
exploration. One may not agree that this contribution is
absolutely unique to the black diaspora, but there is indeed a
spirit of freedom and comradeship inherent in all struggles
against oppression that is inspiring, and that in South Africa in
particular we need to hold on to for the future.

It was the great-grandson of an African slave, Dr WEB du Bois,
who wrote that "the problem of the 20th century is the problem of
the colour line". This book lays starkly bare the bones of the
problem.

Louise Asmal is a former honorary secretary of the Irish Anti-0
Apartheid Movement.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


314 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


No Voter Apathy, But Plenty of Poll Errors


LENGTH: 1187 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 3, 1995 (19951103)
by Gaye Davis

Johannesburg - A new era of local government dawned for
South Africa this week as millions of voters flocked to the
polls, defying predictions that apathy would keep them at home.
But administrative errors in compiling voters' rolls prevented
countless voters from voting and may cast a shadow over the poll.

In a pattern which played itself out across the country,
thousands of voters arrived at polling stations only to find their
names did not appear on voters' rolls. For them, Wednesday
brought frustration and disappointment. 

Apart from resulting in artificially low percentage polls,
voters' roll confusion could impact on the fortunes of political
parties, particularly in narrowly contested areas, and raise
questions about the legitimacy of the poll.

Eastern Cape MEC for local government Max Mamase mooted the
possibility of by-elections to address the problem after hundreds
of thousands of voters were turned away from voting stations in
the former Transkei. But Commonwealth technical advisor Brian
McAndrew told Ecna that given the region's transport difficulties,
poor communications and poverty the election effort had been
"bloody brilliant".

Idasa's elections information manager Liz Findlay said the
organisation's Johannesburg office had been flooded with about 14
000 calls from voters complaining about being left off rolls or
being put on the wrong roll.

"We had complaints from every inch of the country," Findlay
said. Most came from voters in the Greater Johannesburg and Vaal
metropolitan areas: she believed this could explain the low 30
percent turnout predicted for the area early yesterday and said
Idasa would be investigating.

"We don't suspect deliberate sabotage. Perhaps the fault lies
with the computer system or the programmers," Findlay said. "But
the fact is that many people lost the chance to vote. This will
have an impact politically and could well raise questions of
legitimacy."

The ANC's deputy secretary-general Cheryl Carolus, MP Carl
Niehaus and South African Council of Churches' general secretary
Brigalia Bam were among those who could not vote as their names
did not appear. All had checked they were registered.

ANC national elections commission chair Saki Macozoma said the
ANC made a last-ditch request on Wednesday to the Ministry of
Constitutional Development to allow tendered ballots, but this was
refused.

Macozoma said the problem could explain a low turnout in the
North-West Province, where fewer than one-third of registered
voters cast ballots, although intimidation of farmworkers by
farmowners could also be a factor.

Transforming local government -- the "hands and feet" of the
RDP -- depends on new councillors and local authorities being seen
as legitimate, hence the need for a high voter turnout. Without
it, new councillors could feel politically insecure about carrying
out one of their key functions: persuading residents to pay for
rates and services. And residents could continue to regard new
structures as illegitimate.

Voters' roll omissions aside, Macozoma declared the ANC was
"elated" by the way the poll had gone: "At 90 percent of voting
stations things went very well".

Early indications yesterday were that the ANC had made
significant gains in the Western Cape, turning around a coloured
vote that in last year's general election secured the province for
the National Party.

"The ANC did not abandon coloured voters after the previous
election results, despite some voices arguing they were not worth
spending resources on. Instead, we identified the problems and
tried to deal with them and we are now reaping the fruits of that.
It's a triumph for non-racialism." Macozoma said. Macozoma
criticised the election's managers, however, of a "rule-bound"
approach which meant a lack of flexibility in dealing with
grievances and political problems, ranging from the late arrival
of ballot papers and shortages of paraphernalia, to a polling
station being struck by lightning. "We think the inflexibility in
response to problems has cost us a lot of votes," Macozoma said.

Frederik van Zyl Slabbert, co-chairman of the elections task
group, said rules governing the election were negotiated by
political parties. The elections had to take place within
"enormous constraints" in terms of time and planning. "We can
organise the elections up to a point and don't claim to be perfect
-- but in the final analysis, everything depends on the cohave had two or three years to prepare properly."
operation of the political parties. In a perfect world we would

Fears of unregistered voters invading polling stations, and of
taxi blockades and political tensions substantially disrupting the
poll, failed to materialise, though isolated incidents caused
voting stations to be closed in some areas, and delays in
delivering ballot papers and equipment caused lengthy hold-ups.
-0Africa-at-Large

November, 1995


Donors Warn Of Strife as Government Prepares for Elections


LENGTH: 427 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 1, 1995 (19951101)

Lusaka - The donor community has warned the government of civil
strife because of the falling standard of living in the country.
"Social peace is being threatened in Zambia because of living
standards going down," a diplomat is said to have told the
government during Monday's good governance meeting at Lusaka's
Mulungushi International Conference Center. 

And according to government sources the donor community is
worried about persistent falling living standards and has again
appealed to government to deal with corruption. "Donors have
appealed to government to deal with corruption in high places if
good governance is to be achieved," the source said but also
revealed that government's response appeared to be an assurance
that it was still sticking to its 1991 manifesto.

Meanwhile, the government has told the country's donors the
general and presidential elections will be held in September 1996,
it has been revealed. The government disclosure was made during a
Good Governance meeting at the Mulungushi International conference
centre on Monday this week.

"We told them the contract will be signed this week in
preparation for elections in September 1996," a government source
disclosed. But foreign affairs minister Christon Tembo who was
chairman of the Good Governance meeting disputes this. "We merely
said we expect more people to register as voters once this
contract is signed. We did not give any specific date for the
election," Tembo said in a telephone interview yesterday.

But he admitted that he had assured donors that the contract
with Nikuv would be signed this week. "Again no specific date was
given but we are talking of this week," Tembo said.
-0South Africa

LANGUAGE: English

316 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Youths Push Wheelbarrows For A Living


LENGTH: 920 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 2, 1995 (19951102)
by Goodson Machona

Lusaka - The scarcity of jobs in the country has made some
Zambians become increasingly ingenious.

Edwin Banda, 31, is one of the several Lusaka youths who have
turned to pushing wheelbarrows to eke out a living. Surprised?
Well, you needn't be. 

"I make up to K6,000 (about US$6) a day transporting goods on a
wheelbarrow," he revealed in an interview yestarday.

From this money which works out to K152,000 (US$150) a month
Banda achieves a lot.

"I am able to feed and clothe my family and pay rent for my
one-roomed house in Chibolya," he says.

Banda, a rather comely fellow, says he has been pushing
wheelbarrows for two years now.

"I used to work as a guard for AFE Limited," he explained. "But
one night thieves came and attacked us. I quit the job the
following day."

In a constricted job market like Zambia's Banda could not just
walk out of one job and hope to get another tomorrow.

"I walked the streets for about three weeks but was unable to
find a job," he recalls.

However, one day while loitering at Soweto market, he met some
friends with wheelbarrows.

"I asked them what they were doing with wheelbarrows and they
told me that they were waiting for customers," he said. "I didn't
understand what they meant until they explained."

According to Banda, the customers his friends were waiting for
are small-scale traders who buy commodities from wholesalers at
Soweto market for resale at markets within and outside Lusaka.

"They (the small-scale traders) usually don't have money to
book a taxi and resort to us for transportation to the nearest
bus stop," Banda explained.

He says the charges depend on the distance.

"Within town it's K600," Banda said. "From town to the interwe charge up to K3,000."
city bus stop, it's K1,000 but if the customer has a lot of goods,

He normally operates along Freedom Way which is festooned with
wholesale shops.

"Most of my clients buy their goods from wholesalers and I park
my wheelbarrow near the wholesale shops," he said.

He says pushing a wheelbarrow is a very lucrative business
although some people poke fun at them.

"They call us Ba Lubilo. he complained. "But it's better to
push a wheelbarrow than just stay at home or worst of all steal."

A typical day for Banda starts at 06.00 hours.

"I start work at 06.00 hours," he says "I go to Soweto market
where I rent a wheel barrow at K500 per day."

The booming wheelbarrow business has given rise to 'wealthier'
individuals to invest in wheelbarrows which they are renting out
to pushers.

But as Banda has discovered the high demand from pushers has
escalated the hiring cost per day.

"We pay K500 per day for each wheelbarrow but the owner says he
is going to increase the rent to K1,000 per day from November
20," Banda moaned.

Owner of the wheelbarrows, Benson Mwanza, says he has decided
to increase the rental price because of a "rise in demand".

"There has been a marked increase in the number of people who
want to rent my wheelbarrows," Mwanza said. "So I have also
decided to increase the rentals."

He says he started his business in 1990.

"I started with three wheelbarrows," Mwanza said. "But I have
now got over 100 wheelbarrows."

"On a good day I make up to K50,000 per day," he says. "But on
average I make K30,000."
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

November, 1995


Kaunda: UNIP Planned Privatisation Before MMD


LENGTH: 507 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 3, 1995 (19951103)
by Masautso Phiri

Lusaka - UNIP president Kenneth Kaunda has said his party
planned privatisation long before the MMD and it was was intended
to benefit Zambians and not a few ministers.

Speaking in an exclusive interview on Monday this week at his
Kalundu home Kaunda said: "We were going to privatise in the
interest of Zambia and not as a way of enriching ministers as this
government is doing."

He said his party's privatisation programme, which was going to
be in the interest of Zambia and not individuals, started in 1989. 

"We were going to privatise and that was our policy. In 1989 I
wrote to four Merchant Banks to tender for the privatisation of
our parastatals. Rabson Chongo found one such reply when I
transferred him to the ministry of finance."

Kaunda described the role merchant banks were expected to play
in the privatisation programme as an interim measure before
selling to workers, managements and others.

"My own view is that these people would takeover the running of
these businesses and as we developed sell them with workers being
involved and no job losses. Government would then be richer,"
Kaunda said.

Asked to comment on how Chilanga Cement has been privatised and
taken over by a British parastatal the former president wondered
how a government can stop a local parastatal from operating only
to be taken over by a foreign one.

"You are a parastatal and you are told you cannot do anything
but then you are taken over by another parastatal that is foreign.
That to me is strange thinking," Kaunda said.

He dismissed speculation that the donor community was
frightened by his return to active politics.

"I don't think that any High Commissioner or ambassador in
Zambia would be frightened by my return because they know there is
a great deal of difference in governance between Mr Chiluba and
myself," Kaunda said.
-0Zambia

November, 1995


(DOCUMENT) Appeal for Jailed Journalist


LENGTH: 307 words


 
Committee to Protect Journalists (New York)
November 3, 1995 (19951103)

New York - To Nasa Tumwesigye, Director of Public
Prosecutions, Kampala. The Committee to Protect Journalists is
extremely disturbed to learn that Shariat editor Haruna Kanaabi
has been charged with the additional offense of "publishing false
news." This charge, coupled with that of sedition, could land
Kanaabi in jail for 10 years if convicted.
As clearly stated in our previous two letters to President
Museveni, CPJ remains resolute in its call for his immediate and
unconditional release.

Requests to have Kanaabi, who is in ill health, released on
bail have been consistently denied. As a nonpartisan group of
journalists dedicated to the protection of press freedom, CPJ
fears that Kanaabi's prolonged, incommunicado detention is
politically motivated and otherwise baseless. Out of profound
concern for Kanaabi's health and in the interest of human rights,
we strongly urge you to drop the charges against Kanaabi and
release him.

Thank you for your attention. We look forward to your response.

Sincerely, William A. Orme, Jr., Executive Director
-0Zambia

November, 1995


(DOCUMENT) New Exhibit to Feature International Photo Retrospective


LENGTH: 774 words


 
Mother Jones (San Francisco)
November 1, 1995(19951101)

San Francisco - Leica Camera Group and the Mother Jones
International Fund for Documentary Photography continue their
partnership in honoring the world's best documentary photographers
with an awards ceremony at the Centro de la Imagen in Mexico City
December 1. Manuel Alvarez Bravo will receive the distinguished
Lifetime Achievement Award and Fazal Sheikh will be awarded
$10,000 and the prestigious Leica Medal of Excellence. Leica and
the Mother Jones Fund will also honor the work of Ernesto Bazan
and Jose Hernandez-Claire with grants of $7,000 each to continue
their respective projects in Cuba and Mexico. Ralph Hagenauer of
Leica Camera, Germany will present the awards. 

In conjunction with this year's awards, the Centro de la
Imagen, Mexico's first national museum devoted to photography,
will host an exhibit featuring the work of 23 photographers
representing six years of Fund winners. This retrospective global cross-section of the best documentary photography emerging
-including images by Antonin Kratochvil and Nan Goldin -- is a
at the end of the 20th century. The Mexico City exhibit opens
November 16 and is on display until January 1996.

1995 marks the sixth year of awards sponsored by the Mother
Jones International Fund for Documentary Photography, and the
second year that Leica and the Fund have collaborated to recognize
and award outstanding documentary photography dealing with
important social and political issues. The fund is supported
through foundation grants and through a fine-print program, in
which donors receive museum-quality prints given to the fund by
photographers such as Marc Riboud, Sebastiao Salgado, Mary Ellen
Mark and Gordon Parks. The work of this year's winning
photographers will be published in the January 1996 issue of
"Mother Jones" magazine.

American photographer Fazal Sheikh has been photographing the
refugees of Sudan, Ethiopia, Somalia, Mozambique and Rwanda since
1991. His work evolved in response to the media stereotype of
Africa as the "Dark Continent" -- a country full of "wild animals,
exotic people and starving children." Sheikh's photographs offer a
balance to these journalistic cliches, by providing a "broader
understanding of the complexities of the situation," and show that
the "people of these African refugee communities are not wholly
unlike you and me."

Established in 1989, the Mother Jones International Fund for
Documentary Photography helps ensure that the art and practice of
fine documentary photography remain alive and thriving. The Fund
assists outstanding documentary photographers by providing
competitive grants for sustained, serious study of important
social and political issues and by helping grant recipients
publish and exhibit their work.

The Foundation for National Progress, whose goal is to support
progressive change through various media projects, including
"Mother Jones". America's leading magazine of investigative
reporting and progressive politics, "Mother Jones" regularly
publishes documentary photography. Both the magazine and the Fund
are named after a famous American activist and orator, Mary
Harris. The Mother Jones International Fund for Documentary
Photography is a project of the ("Mother") Jones (1830-1930).
-0Uganda


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

November, 1995


(DOCUMENT) African Sculpture Exhibit Opens


LENGTH: 667 words


 
Smithsonian Institution News (Washington DC)
November 1, 1995 (19951101)

Washington - Three recent additions to the permanent collection
of the Smithsonian's National Museum of African Art--a Yoruba
mask, a "Temne" female figure and a Baga ritual object--are
examined in an exhibition opening November 22 and continuing
through February 25, 1996. The museum is located at 950
Independence Avenue, Southwest.

"Three Explorations: Yoruba, 'Temne', and Baga" explores three
unusual and rarely collected works of art in the contexts of their
creation, use and history. The featured works are the focus of
ongoing collections research by three African Art curators who
organized the exhibition: Roslyn Walker, senior curator; Philip
Ravenhill, chief curator; and Andrea Nicolls, assistant curator. 

Each object is studied in its own section of the exhibit and
displayed with comparative materials, including other works of art
and photographs. In the first section, Walker explores the
iconography, attribution, creation and use of a Yoruba
"Olojufoforo" ("owner of the deep-set eyes") mask from Nigeria.
Such masks, named for their distinct, carved eyeholes, appear at
annual Yoruba festivals called Ijesu.

In the second section, the focus shifts to a female figure of a
style formerly attributed to the Temne. Ravenhill examines ideas
of style, corpus, alternative attributions and meaning in the
figure, comparing this work to two other "Temne" works on view--
possibly carved by the same artist.

Nicolls, in a third section, explores a Baga figure known as
"a-Tshol" that combines human and birdlike features. She considers
the figure's original context of use and its prescribed form and
compares it to two other "a-Tshol" figures from the museum's
collection.

The museum's Department of Education is offering a series of
public programs in conjunction with the exhibition.

Lunchtime gallery discussions with the curators will be held at
1 p.m. on Nov. 29, Dec. 6 and Dec 13.

On Feb. 3 from 2 to 5 p.m., the curators will present a panel
discussion, titled "What Makes It Good? What Makes It Real? What
Does It Mean?" in which they address their approaches to
determining the quality, authenticity and meaning of the works in
the exhibition.

"Explorations in Style," a workshop for children (8 and up),
will be held on Jan. 27. To register for the workshop, call (202)
357-4600 ext. 221.

The National Museum of African Art is open daily from 10 a.m.
to 5:30 p.m. except Dec. 25, and admission is free. The museum's
TTY number is (202) 357-4814. The Smithsonian Home Page address on
the World Wide Web, which includes information on the Museum of
African Art, is http://www.si/edu."
-0Africa-At-Large.


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


Africa Auto Contest Returns To Uganda


LENGTH: 894 words


 
The Monitor (Kampala)
November 1, 1995 (19951101)
by Rashid Mudin

Kampala - It is certain now. One leg of the Africa Rally
Championship will be held in Uganda in February 1996. Both the
International Automobile Federation (FIA) and the governing body
FISA, have already approved the event and the rally drivers are
bustling with enthusiasm. 

Back home Augustine Byabashaija, of the Uganda Automobile
Association (UAA), that has been in the grave for years has
climbed out and written to the Permanent Secretary, Ministry of
Transport asking him not to sanction any more rallies in Uganda,
from now on, without his office's consent.

The letter copied to both Uganda Motor Club (UMC) and
Motorsport Africa Club (MOSAC) has caused a stir among the
motorsport fraternity who received the Byabashaija new move with
shock and amusement.

Byabasaija and his AA used to show up at the beginning of
rallies to collect money, until the motor clubs laughed him out of
town.

Tegalya Nsubuga told the motorsport fraternity last Wednesday
that MOSAC was only dreaming of the Africa Rally Championship in
February, because UAA which claims to be affiliated to FISA in
Paris, is the only body with the authority over such an event in
Uganda.

The meeting also learnt for the first time that the UAA
executive include Augustine Byabashaija, Bagonza, Arthur Blick and
Sam Ssali.

The motorsport fraternity demanded that the officials of UAA
produce documents to prove their legitimacy and they should be
invited to brief the drivers and crews of their role in the
motorsport before they can be taken seriously.

The UAA idea was prominent mid this year when the news of
MOSAC's plan to hold an African Championship came up. MOSAC and
UMC set up a team to form a proper UAA, but the plan went up in
smoke in the notoriously cloak and dagger world of Uganda
motorsport.

Last Wednesday, Justin Beyendeza (JB), speaking on behalf of
MOSAC, said the African Rally championship to be held in February
next year was in the bag. He said it had already been sanctioned
by FIA, and it will be held by under the auspices of Burundi
Automobile Association in conjunction with MOSAC. MOSAC has put
its money where its mouth is--it has paid Shs 4 million for FIA
for the event.

That has been the basic conflict in motorsport; the struggle
between those who want to put money in, and those who want to take
it out.

Meanwhile, mid next month, six Ugandan drivers preparing
themselves for the Africa Rally championship, will take part in
the Kenya Caltex Equatorial Rally.
The Uganda team to be lead by "Capo" Karim Hirji and Frank Nekusa
(Celica GT4) include: Gerald Kiddu and Paul Hendrickx (Golf GTI),
Chipper Adams and Justin Beyendeza (Corolla DX), Yusuf Karmali and
Haruna Nsubuga (Subaru Legacy) and Dipu Ruparellia and Isaac
Rwakiseeta (Nissan 240 RS).

In yet another development, the newly formed United Motorsport
Club(UMOSPOC) will hold an auto-cross and a social evening on
Sunday November 12, at Maya. The meet will include a number of
events ranging from short races to special events.

Those without rally cars can come with their ordinary cars and
still have fun. The occasion will be crowned by "muchomo"
roasting, plenty of drinks at give away price. The Maya meet will
be the curtain-raiser to the final round of the Nakisunga Sprints
organised by MOSAC. The sprint is to be held towards the end of
November.
-0Africa-At-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


322 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Ethiopian Head Challenges Uganda President


LENGTH: 1520 words


 
The Monitor (Kampala)
November 1, 1995 (19951101)
by Peter G. Mwesige

KAMPALA - In a speech seen as a criticism of President Yoweri
Museveni's politics, Ethiopia's Prime Minister Meles Zenawi said
Africans cannot wait for a middle class to grow first before they
get democracy.

Zenawi was speaking at a dinner in Washington DC hosted for
seven African Presidents to which Museveni was not invited.

Although the Ethiopian Executive Premier did not directly refer
to Museveni, he challenged two arguments which have been President
Museveni's trademark in his defence of the suspension of multiethnicity.
party politics -- the lack of a middle class and the problem of

"The argument that multi-party democracy fuels ethnic strife
cannot be sustained," Zenawi said. 

"It is rather the unfair treatment of ethnic groups, forceful
attempts at eliminating ethnic identities, and the use of
political power as a means of personal enrichment, or the
perception thereof, which, more often than not, lead to ethnic
strife and conflict."

Although Zenawi said that extreme poverty of the type in Africa
is not conducive to democracy, he did not agree that Africans must
first wait for the growth of a strong middle class, as Museveni
likes to argue.

"...it does not follow that we either can, or ought to,
postpone democratization until such a time as we become rich," he
said.

Zenawi, also Chairman of the Organisation of African Unity
(OAU), was the keynote speaker at the Reverend John T. Walker
Dinner organised by Africare on October 19 in honour of Reverend
Leon H. Sullivan.

Africare is a non-profit organisation engaged in developmental
programmes in rural Africa.

The dinner recognised the contributions of seven African heads
of state toward political and economic development in sub-Saharan
Africa.

The other six leaders who were invited to the dinner were
Ketumile Masire of Botswana, Ange-Felix Patasse of Central African
Republic, Joao Bernardo Vieira of Guinea-Bissau, Bakili Muluzi of
Malawi, Pasteur Bizimungu of Rwanda and King Mswati III of
Swaziland.

The seven leaders also earlier met with US President Bill
Clinton at a reception held before the dinner.

Zenawi's words on democracy came only 10 days after he was in
Uganda for the country's 33rd independence anniversary
celebrations in Fort Portal where he was awarded Order of the
Pearl of Africa Class I.

The award, which Museveni too received, is the highest among
the series of awards the NRM has just introduced.

Museveni that time described Zenawi as one of the illustrious
sons of Africa and commended him for having returned power to the
people before getting elected.

Zenawi's Ethiopian People's Liberation Front captured power in
1991 from dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam and initiated a
democratisation process that saw the country get a new
constitution this year, under which he was elected Executive Prime
Minister.

But at the US dinner, although Zenawi did not directly refer to
Museveni his words were, to say the least, unflattering to the
Ugandan President who is now perhaps the continent's biggest
proponent of the suspension of political parties.

The Ethiopian premier said that democracy (read multi-party) is
not a flawless form of government and that its weaknesses are
plenty.

"But since the alternatives are even worse," he said, "the
challenge is to get democracy to work at its best."

Zenawi challenged those who argue that ethnicity is the major
culprit making development of democracy in Africa difficult.

"There is ...little doubt that managing ethnicity within a
democratic context is one of the major challengers of
democratization have been aborted in Africa due to ethnic tension
and strife."

"But the intimation that ethnicity per se abhors democracy and
vice versa is not borne out by empirical and historical facts,"
Zenawi said.

The Ethiopian Premier admitted that broad-based or governments
of national unity may help overcome the perceived problem posed by
ethnicity.

"(But) the attempt to make it a permanent fixture (like NRM has
done) would naturally result in paralysis and gridlock and would
defeat the purpose of providing alternatives to the electorate,"
he said.

Although Zenawi agreed that the extreme poverty in Africa is
not conducive to democracy, he said it should not be used as a
pretext to postpone democracy.

"I for one know of no conclusive study which proves that
dictatorships do better than democracies in terms of economic
development," Zenawi said.

He said the dictatorships in Africa are not of the East-Asian
type which have tended to focus on wealth creation.

"Ours have been of the predatory type with the proclivity to
consuming the already available wealth to the point of killing the
hen that lays the golden egg," he said.

Zenawi said that democracy can be learned only by engaging in
it and by practicing it.

"So we cannot postpone democracy so that we can think about it
before we practise it," he said.

Zenawi also criticised international donors for what he called
their lack of patience and tendency to overlook how the task of
democratization in Africa is a long-term and complicated task.

"The success of democratization in our continent requires
tender nurturing of the shoots of democracy for years," he said.

"When friends tell us that they support democracy and at the
same time do not do much to relieve us of our enormous debt
burden, and instead cut back support to our development efforts,
we cannot but wonder if their money is where their mouths is."

Still the Ethiopian Premier echoed his conviction that
democratization in Africa has a bright future.

"But we have to proceed with confidence because the shoots of
democracy are sprouting everywhere in Africa," he said, "and with
your support, I am hopeful, over the coming years, they will grow
into mighty and healthy trees."
-0Uganda


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


323 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Presidential Hopefuls To Get Shs 10 Million Each


LENGTH: 1294 words


 
The Monitor (Kampala)
November 1, 1995 (19951101)
by Peter G. Mwesige

Kampala - Each presidential candidate in Uganda's forthcoming
elections will get Shs 10 million from the state if the Interim
Presidential Elections Bill, 1995, is passed into law in its
present form.

According to section 8 of the bill, which is still
"confidential," the Secretary of the Treasury, shall, within two
weeks after the nomination day, "pay to every candidate a sum of
ten million shillings which the candidate shall devote solely for
the purposes of conducting his or her campaign."

However, sub-section (2) proposes that every candidate shall be
at liberty to raise additional funds for his or her campaign
through lawful means.

The money paid to the candidates by the state shall have to by
accounted for by every candidate within 30 days after polling day. 

So far the incumbent President, Yoweri Museveni, DP Chief Paul
Kawanga Ssemogerere and UPC stalwart Adonia Tiberondwa are the
ones who appear serious contenders for the presidency. They have
all declared their intentions.

The Presidential Elections Bill comes at a time when
international donors and opposition politicians are pressing for a
level playing field in the run-up to the elections.

DP Chief Paul Ssemogerere hinted at a press conference last
week that he and his party might boycott the elections if the
ground is not levelled.

"I want these elections to take place, but if the law does not
answer (our demands), we shall do the obvious," he said.

As if to take care of such demands, section 9 of the Interim
Presidential Elections Law proposes that "Except as authorised
under this Act, no candidate shall use government resources for
the purpose of campaigning for election."

Sub-section (2), however proposes that "notwithstanding
subsection (1), a candidate who for the time being is holding the
office of President, may continue to use during the campaign and
shall use only those government facilities which are ordinarily
attached and utilised by the holder of that office."

The section also proposes that it shall be valid ground for
petition if a candidate utilised government resources not
authorised under the law.

Section 7 proposes that "every presidential candidate shall be
at liberty to hold individual campaign rallies in any part of
Uganda in accordance with any existing law."

Sub-section(2), however, proposes that the Electoral Commission
shall prepare and conduct a programme called the Presidential
Candidates Meetings Programmes. All presidential candidates shall
speak at one such meeting in every district.

Sub-section (4) proposes that "no candidate in an election
shall be denied reasonable access, and use of state-owned media
communication" while sub-section (5) says "all candidates shall be
given free and reasonable time and space in the State-owned media
to present their programmes to the people."

To qualify as a presidential candidate, Section 5 (2) says,
candidates must submit to the Electoral Commission, a day before
nomination day, nomination papers which must be supported by one
hundred voters in each of at least two thirds (26) of all the
districts in Uganda. In other words each candidate would require
at least 2,600 signatures of registered voters.

Sub-section (3) proposes that the nomination paper must be
accompanied by, among others, a form for declaration of assets and
liabilities; and a deposit of Shs. 2 million.
Candidates who poll more than 25 percent of the total votes cast
in the election will be entitled to a refund of their Shs. 2
million.

According to our information, the idea of candidates' declaring
their assets and liabilities is the brain-child of President
Museveni who is said to have studied the bill closely before he
left for the United States to attend the 50th anniversary of the
United Nations.

The proposed law provides that a person who knowingly makes a
false declaration of assets and liabilities, commits an offence
and shall be liable on conviction to a term of imprisonment not
exceeding two years without an option of a fine.

According to other provisions in the proposed law a
presidential candidate must be a citizen of Uganda by birth, and
must be not less than 35 and not more than 75 years of age.

He or she, another provision proposes, must have completed a
minimum formal education of Advanced level standard or its
equivalent.

The elections shall be by universal adult suffrage through a
secret ballot.

Section 19 of the bill says that a candidate will need more
than fifty percent of the valid votes cast to be declared
president.

Where there are more than two candidates, and no candidate
obtains the required 50 percent, a second election shall be held
within thirty days after the declaration of the results.

Only the two candidates who obtained the highest number of
votes shall contest in such an election.

The Bill is expected to be tabled before Parliament next month.
The Interim Parliamentary Elections Bill, 1995 is also yet to be
tabled.

"The Monitor" could not reach Minister of State for
Constitutional Affairs Steven Kavuma for comment.
-0Uganda and Ethiopia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


324 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Athlete Might Face Ban From City Club


LENGTH: 307 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 6, 1995 (19951106)
by George Jambwa

Lusaka - City of Lusaka player, Davis Musole could face a ban
from his club for cheating that he was mistreated while attending
trials in Saudi Arabia. The player has been asked to exculpate
himself or face disciplinary action for cheating that he was
mistreated by a Saudi Arabian club where he went for trials. 

"We have asked our player, Musole to explain why he cheated
that he was mistreated by Talwan club of Saudi Arabia where he
went for trials," City boss, Simataa Simataa revealed in an
interview on Wednesday shortly after the FAZ press briefing.

Investigations by City officials hinted the player did not
receive any mistreatment. Simataa said that he had talks with the
Saudi Arabian officials from the embassy and had talked to
Harrison Chongo who also expressed ignorance over the mistreatment
of Musole.

"I personalLy talked to the embassy officials who clarified the
matter. The said that the player was just home sick. "On the same
day, I phoned Chongo who also denied that Musole was starving,"
said Simataa who is also FAZ interim chairman.
-0Uganda

Africa News


November, 1995


'Coach Poulsen Is Killing Zambia!'


LENGTH: 547 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 6, 1995 (19951106)
by Reuben Tonga

Lusaka - just two months away from the Africa Cup of Nations
finals were in shambles yesterday as they trounced Jamaica 4-2 at
Independence Stadium in Lusaka during an international friendly.

The victory was not enough for the usually hostile Independence
Stadium crowd who refused to be fooled by the 4-2 win, and instead
chose to shout at coach Roald Poulsen "You are not building you
are killing Zambia." It was a clear message for the Dane that the
seven months the national squad has been under him, Zambia had not
taken a single step from that grim performance of a 9-0 bashing
against Belgium last year. 

The defence, once strongest unit of the team, was leaking with
goals while generally the team was still short of pace, a thing
that Poulsen admitted because there was no craft and creativity
into the Zambian side.

They badly needed inspirational and Poulsen was looking to
Kenneth "Bubble" Malitoli and added "I will need his services
badly." But Poulsen wondered what the soccer fans were up to
especially that the side was now much better than before.

"I don't know what people want, instead of giving support to
the team, they just started cheering Jamaica, that nearly affected
the players but I was happy that they remained calm. "I am still
working on the team before we finally leave for South Africa, it
will be a better team," he promised. Goals by Andrew Tembo, who
struck twice, substitute Bilton Musonda and Dennis Lota however
managed to save Zambia from further humiliation at Independence
Stadium.

But then Loglten Boyd did all the damage in the Zambian side
for the enterprising Jamaicans to earn some cheers from the crowd.
Boyd led the West Indies attack and pushed his side 2-1 at one
point. The Zambian bench disputed the two goals sent in by Boyd
claiming they scored from an offside angle. So disorganised was
the Zambian side that Aggrey Chiyangi failed to convert a penalty.

Jamaica played without their centre forward Gregory Stewart who
was sent off for punching Malitoli at the edge of their goal
mouth. On Friday Zambia won 1-0 against the Jamaican side at
Arthur Davies Stadium in Kitwe.
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996

November, 1995


The Problem Is With MMD And Not Nikuv


LENGTH: 414 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) (19951107)
November 7, 1995

Lusaka - So much has been said about Nikuv's Mossad connections
and allegations of facilitating election rigging wherever they
have been.

Whereas these concerns may be genuine, or indeed the
allegations of intelligence connections and election claims proved
to be true, the real problem doesn't seem to begin and end with
Nikuv's integrity or lack of it. The problems seem to lurk in the
confidence many critical citizens have in President Frederick
Chiluba and other key leaders of the ruling MMD.Those who have
participated in the parliamentary by-elections have complained
about the MMD's abuse of the electoral process. The MMD has been
accused of using voters' certificates to rig elections.

Zambia State intelligence officers, including policemen, have
been reported to have helped the MMD rig the Malole byto win the hearts of voters in by-elections. This clearly
elections.Drought relief maize has been corruptly used by the MMD
demonstrates that, in the minds of critical citizens, the MMD is
not beyond rigging. They have rigged, and can rig, elections. This
is where the problem lies and not in Nikuv. It is doubtful that if
another firm had been chosen by the MMD government to update the
voters' register complaints, or protests, would not have been
experienced. And since Nikuv is not necessarily the problem,
attention should not be diverted from the real concerns to a small
contract that can be cancelled tomorrow with little penalties, if
any.

Attention should be devoted to the political confidence crisis
that threatens the whole of Zambia's democratisation process.
-0Zambia

Africa News


November, 1995


Israeli Firm Undermines Integrity Of Polls


LENGTH: 614 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka) (19951107)
November 7, 1995

Lusaka - The decision by the government to ignore opposition to
its awarding of a contract to an Israeli firm, Nikuv, to update
the voters register raises many suspicions.

Nikuv has been accused by many of being connected to the
notorious Israeli intelligence organisation, Mossad. And neither
Nikuv nor the Zambian government has denied this charge. All we
have heard, so far, is the government defending Nikuv's ability
and capacity to complete the job in time for the elections. 

Nikuv has not denied accusations of facilitating election
rigging in countries where they have set up electoral systems. The
accusations stretch from Africa to South America.

Clearly Nikuv doesn't seem to have a good reputation, in the
popular sense, in this business, but it certainly must have
something to offer to those who hire or contract them. And the
benefits to a government that contracts Nikuv is what needs to be
urgently established.

It seems, there are only three possible benefits for hiring
Nikuv. The first two have been loudly, but not necessarily well
argued. The firm's ability and capacity, as a benefit, has been
defended by the government as the reason for contracting the firm.

The firm's ability and capacity to help 'contractors' rig
elections has been voiced by many interested persons and
organisations, but with little, if any, substantiation. But what
is undoubtable is the dark cloud that now, or will, hang on the
integrity of our electoral process. And given the persistent
rumours of election rigging by the ruling MMD in by-elections that
have been held countrywide and the general lack of citizen
confidence in the electoral processes in Africa, we find it unwise
for the government to contract Nikuv. W e should always remember
that it is very vital and critical to the democratic process to
create and foster an environment under which those defeated in an
election accept losing and look forward to the next ones. But if
the losers feel they have been cheated or robbed of victory we
have seen what has happened in other countries.

This is not a matter in which one should demonstrate his
mandate gained in a previous election to make decisions and hire
whoever he or she wants. This is also not the kind of issue in
which one shows off one's political muscle. It is an issue in
which all citizens, whether in the political majority or minority,
will simultaneously be losers or winners.

If MMD's motivation, in its deal with Nikuv, is rigging the
danger signs are clearly written on the wall.
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


328 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Democracy Cannot Survive In Poverty


LENGTH: 987 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 7, 1995 (19951107)
by Bandawe Banda

Lusaka - The recent spate of riots and near-riots Zambia has
witnessed clearly demonstrates that democracy cannot survive where
there is a huge gap between political and economic rights.
Economic decline and its attendance poverty experienced by the
vast majority of the people has great potential for cleavage and
conflict.

Last month, youths went on rampage in Lusaka precipitated by
rumours that former president Kenneth Kaunda would face
deportation. Last week Livingstone was on fire because of ritual
murders allegedly committed by the locals on behalf of some
Asians. At the University of Zambia students became riotous on
account of government delays to give them their allowances. 

These spontaneous manifestations of violence are as a result of
discontent in this country. The stiff implementations of the IMF
and World Bank conditionalities by the MMD government has led to
the now commonplace retrenchments thereby enlarging the reserve
army of labour while job creation is at standstill. The
agricultural and manufacturing sectors are on a sharp decline as
the government puts emphasis on opening up the economy to foreign
investors (a euphemism for any trader who happens to be non-black
and non-Zambian).

In the process, prices of basic necessities have shot up making
them inaccessibble to the majority, crime has reached its highest
levels, making a real mockery of Zambia's security wings.
Corruption in high places is so common that the Anti-corruption
Commissionm has become irrelevant. The list is clearly endless.

A sad situation such as this is potentially volatile and
violence prone. Hence, such incidents in normal circumstances do
not bring excitement like the snatching of a women's handbag on
October 18, which almost paralysed Lusaka by rampaging youths.

The government must address the real causes of these problems
and not the symptoms. But does it have the stamina for that?

Good governance and political accountability cannot exist under
conditions such as the ones prevailing in Zambia today. Of course,
Zambia has not reached the stage of overt violence though there is
an undeniably conflict situation in the country. Yet, absence of
war does not mean that there is justice for all. There is a danger
that if the situation coninues to deteriorate, there would be
bloodletting in this country which many uncritical minds would
have thought to be peaceful.

Kaunda was convinced that he had Zambia firmly under his
control until the food riots of 1990. What followed was a fast
flow of human events culminating in the Mwamba Luchembe coup
attempt. The man certainly never knew what hit him. The people of
this country whom he said should never be taken for granted poured
onto the streets celebrating what they thought was his political
demise.

If it had taken place ten years previously, the coup attempt
would have been considered a big joke because Kaunda and his UNIP
were power and fire. As the economic situation got worse along
with living standards plummeted and politically everyone had to
toe the UNIP line. As with Kaunda, the Fredrick Chiluba regime is
convinced that it holds sway over the people of Zambia and that
the riots are simply sporadic and insignificant. No serious effort
is made for a more concrete and profound understanding of the
whole issue. It is vital to handle potentially violent situations
with great care and not emotionally like calling for the expulsion
of Asians suspected of being involved in the Livingstone ritual
murders.

With the retrenchments, poverty and hunger, black Zambians out
of desperation found themselves vulnerable to carrying out these
heinous crimes. That of course does not justify the acts of the
criminals who should be brought to book urgently. No sane mind
could condone the Livingstone murders. What is required is a sober
analysis of the whole matter for the law to take its course and to
find measures that would ensure that there is no repeat both in
the tourist capital and elsewhere. All in all, the MMD government
must brace itself for riots of all sorts as the simmering
political and economic disillusionment rises.
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
