Africa News


November, 1995


Local Mac Leads the Pack


LENGTH: 600 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 11, 1995 (19951111)
by Karen Harverson
_Johannesburg - Pipping United States McDonald's at the post --
the South African version, MacDonald's, opened its doors in
central Johannesburg this week, just 24 hours before the grand
launch of its American rival in Randburg.

The store, situated on the corner of Commissioner and Kruis, is
owned by George Charalambous, a franchisee of 10 Chicken Licken
stores, part of the fast food chain owned by George Sombonos.

Charalambous is also owner of Daxprop which, together with
Joburgers, owned by Sombonos, applied to have McDonald's trademark
expunged from the registrar on the basis of non-use. 

The two Georges won the court case against US McDonald's in
October this year, but the case has since gone on appeal and will
be heard in the Appellate Court next year.

Charalambous is also the owner of MacDonalds in Durban which
has been operating since 1978, a key factor in the case against US
McDonald's, which had not established good will in the country as
it had never operated here.

Speaking at the opening, Charalambous' attorney Sean Ryan said
that this second MacDonald's store was just part of his client's
"orderly" expansion plans. "He is proceeding with his own plans
to set up a chain of MacDonald's."

He said that even if US McDonald's wins the appeal case,it is
unlikely that Charalambous could be sued for infringement as he is
entitled to concurrent registration of the trademark because his
shop had been trading under the trademarks and was entitled to
protection in terms of the 1993 Act which allows use of a well
known trademark before September 1991.

Ryan said the 80m2 store would have opened earlier but was
delayed pending the outcome of the court case. He says the site is
ideal to attract both black and white sectors of the
population,"unlike US McDonald's which is setting up in a white
suburb with a drive-through restaurant which caters for white
people."

Ryan said McDonald's has intimated that court action will be
taken against Charalambous as a result of the store opening but
says he is not sure what the action will entail.

He defended Charalambous against accusations that the opening
was deliberately flying in the face of the US McDonald's planned
launch later this week. "We opened first in Durban and this shop
has opened first in Johannesburg, so who is following whom?"
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

330 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Truth Commission Nominees in the Dock


LENGTH: 960 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 11, 1995 (19951111)
by Gaye Davis

Johannesburg - Human rights organisations are scrutinising the
background and track records of nominees for the Truth and
Reconciliation Commission, and will be making submissions to the
special panel which starts interviewing 46 candidates on Monday.

Indications are that questions will be raised about some of the
nominees in terms of the criteria set down to guide their
selection: that they should not have a high political profile and
should show a demonstrable commitment to human rights.

Pretoria advocate Professor Pieter Oosthuizen, nominated by the
League of Former Police Officials, was a member of the team which
prosecuted Communist Party leader Braam Fischer, who was sentenced
to life imprisonment. He also prosecuted in the mammoth 1967 trial
of Swapo members, including its founder, Andimba Herman Toivo ja
Toivo. 

The trial in Pretoria attracted international attention as it
was the first time the Terrorism Act of 1967, which was made
retroactive to 1962 and put the burden of proof on the accused,
was used. The United Nations declared the trial illegal.

"I was attached to the office of the Johannesburg attorneythe state," Oosthuizen said this week.
general at the time and as such I prosecuted. I was an official of

Freedom Front nominee advocate Chris de Jager enjoyed a high
political profile as an MP and the founder of the Afrikaner
Volksunie (AVU). He was the chief negotiator for the Conservative
Party and the AVU during 1993 and is a part-time member of the
Vokstaat Council. He has already been selected to sit on the Human
Rights Commission and may have to withdraw from it if selected for
the truth commission as it seems unlikely he would be able to
serve on both.

Questions may also be raised about two other nominees,
Mitchell's Plain Uniting Reformed Church (formerly the Dutch
Reformed Mission Church) clergyman Ds Jan Mettler and Free State
University law faculty dean Professor Dan Morkel. Both have served
on the Publications Appeal Board; for some, this raises concerns
about their commitment to transparency.

Another nominee, Professor Jabulani Maphalala, describes his
nationality in his CV as "native African South African of Zulu
extraction". An associate professor of history at the University
of Zululand, which nominated him, he has written about the role of
Inkatha as "a national and cultural liberation movement" and spent
time in Germany on a scholarship from the Konrad Adenauer
Foundation.

University of the Western Cape academic Professor Adam Small's
acceptance of his nomination by the Democratic Party has raised
eyebrows. Writing in a regular weekly newspaper column, Professor
Small has questioned the need for the "melodrama" of a truth
commission and its cost, suggesting matters should be left to the
law.

Azapo has objected to the nomination of theologian Dr Frank
Chikane on grounds that when he was general-secretary of the South
African Council of Churches his involvement with the United
Democratic Front impeded Azapo's access to foreign funding.

The 46 nominees, selected from a preliminary list of 160 names
drawn from a total of 299 candidates, will be interviewed during
the course of next week.

Conducting the interviews will be a panel chaired by
presidential legal adviser Professor Nicholas Haysom. It includes
the South African Council of Churches' Brigalia Bam, Senator
Rossier de Ville, ANC MP Baleka Kgositsile, Jody Kollapen,
Jayendra Naidoo, IFP MP Professor Harriet Ngubane, Senator Ray
Radue and Bishop Peter Storey.

On Saturday, the panel will draw up a list of 25 names to go
before President Nelson Mandela and the Cabinet for the final
selection of "11 to 17 impartial, fit and proper persons".
Integrity, impartiality and trustworthiness will be key attributes
sought, and a willingness to serve on the commission full-time
will stand in nominees' favour.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

331 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Succession Struggle Begins at Largest Newspaper


LENGTH: 1467 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 11, 1995 (19951111)
by Reg Rumney

Johannesburg - The battle is on for the most powerful newspaper
position in the country: editor of the country's biggest paper,
The Sunday Times.

The choice of who will replace Ken Owen, who will retire next
year, is the subject of unbridled speculation, dinner party gossip
and quiet competition among the circle of candidates.

The result, when finally decided, is likely to surprise
everyone.

Succession in newspapers is never clear cut. Witness the
surprise appointment by the then South African Associated
Newspapers board of the selfsame Ken Owen as editor of Business
Day in 1985 _ and his equally surprising removal after only a few
days, followed by an equally surprising reappointment about a year
later. 

Owen, asked if he knew who his successor might be, replied
laconically and finally: "Why not ask the board?"

The board will have to focus its collective mind soon on the
appointment of a successor to Owen. He is due to leave in the
middle of next year, but an accumulation of leave will probably
mean he will depart earlier. Times Media Limited managing director
Roy Paulson could not be contacted for comment before going to
press.

Clearly, complicating the decision will be two factors:

* The need to make good a worrying decline in circulation to a
rumoured 465,000 from the long-established level of half a million
copies;

* A concerted campaign by members of the present government
against white "liberal" editors.

Owen, observers believe, has created a new credibility for the
Sunday Times, and jacked up its political journalism, but the
paper has not escaped the post-election slump in circulation faced
by many English-language newspapers.

Owen's own analysis suggests that whites, the Sunday Times'
traditional readership base, feel disempowered and uninterested.
He has contrasted the decline in English newspaper circulations
with the comparative success of Afrikaans newspapers, indicating
that their anti-government stance strikes a chord with their
readers.

The conundrum faced by the present owners is whether to return
to the frothy, popular formula on which the Sunday Times' mass
market appeal was built, to keep the paper on the present course
set by Owen, or to take a radically different tack and go for the
black market.

The first would mean concentrating on gut-feel issues like
crime, abortion, gossip, reviving the sex scandal-mongering back
page and undressing back page girls whom Owen has covered up.

Here the name of Rick Wilson, at present editor of the Eastern
Province Herald, is listed as a strong candidate.

Wilson is one of the Sunday Times old guard who flourished
under former editor, the late Tertius Myburgh, the raconteur who
ran a supposedly liberal paper which greeted the Botswana massacre
by South African Defence Force soldiers of sleeping African
National Congress supporters with the headline, "The guns of
Gaborone".

If the paper is to continue on the strongly political, liberal,
slightly more upmarket path it has followed so far, an internal
appointment is possible.

Internally, several candidates have been mentioned: Business
Day editor Jim Jones and electronic media general manager Neil
Jacobsohn.

Ex-managing director of TML, temporarily in Australia, Steve
Mulholland is due back in South Africa next year. He too has been
mentioned. Mulholland has an affinity for the Times, having served
there as a reporter, and having founded the Business Times.

On the paper itself, two candidates are mentioned: deputy
editor Brian Pottinger, a survivor of the Myburgh era, and Owen's
protege, Mike Robertson.

No one else in "Stab Alley", as the senior editorial offices
are known, is suggested as a candidate. Deputies are seldom made
editors, and Robertson is reckoned by insiders to be inexperienced
-- and not black enough.

The board must consider government pressure to replace mainly
white editors of the mainstream press with blacks, either under
the erroneous impression that black editors will be less critical,
or to browbeat those white editors into toning down their
criticism.

The Thabo Mbeki inspired campaign has had Black Editors' Forum
head and Black Enterprise editor Thami Mazwai as its stalking
horse. Could he be a candidate?

Observers reckon Mazwai's anti-white rhetoric would alienate
too many staffers, let alone readers. And could the board, looking
to the future black mass market, take the chance of turning its
back on the white market, and appoint an editor who will turn the
Sunday Times into a "black" newspaper?

A compromise would be a black editor who could run the Sunday
Times along popular lines and take a strongly independent stance
which would not offend white readers, while drawing in new black
readers.

This suggests one well-known candidate: Jon Qwelane, editor of
Tribute.

Qwelane is maverick enough not to be identified too closely
with any political party and to tackle tough issues in the
combative, newsy style expected on a popular newspaper.

He surprised blacks and whites and opened himself up to
accusations of subverting black empowerment by exposing executive
shenanigans at National Sorghum Breweries.

One candidate whose name has come up is another successful
Sunday paper editor, City Press' Khulu Sibiya. Sibiya was a
surprise choice as editor, but has managed to lift his paper's
circulation significantly. However, his credibility took a knock
when he resigned as convener of the Conference of Editors, citing
it was proving impossible to unite editors across racial lines.

Whoever the mainly white, conservative board appoints will have
to remember that ultimate control of TML, through Omni Media and,
in turn, Johnnic, will soon be in black hands.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


332 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Doubts over Mandela's Security


LENGTH: 1427 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 11, 1995 (19951111)
by Stefaans Brummer

Johannesburg - The amalgamation of former sworn enemies --
opposing sides of the apartheid divide -- into the police unit
protecting President Nelson Mandela and other VIPs may have
compromised the effectiveness of the unit.

Mandela, in a gesture of reconciliation, uses a team from the
National Protection Service (NPS) composed about half of members
formerly with the African National Congress' Department of
Intelligence and Security (DIS) and half of the old South African
Police Special Guard Unit (SGU).

Mandela trusts them, and his gesture is thought to have
increased their loyalty, but not everyone shares this confidence.
Should the loyalty of, for example, a policeman assigned to
Mandela's protection be doubted, former ANC operatives will ensure
Mandela is "covered" by one of their own. 

Deputy President FW de Klerk so distrusts his old rivals that
he still uses no bodyguards from either an ANC or a PAC
background.

And the Mail & Guardian is aware of instances where operatives
of questionable character have made it into the NPS. There are
strong allegations that an off-duty NPS member "executed" a
criminal in Soweto in September as part of an unorthodox antilater joined DIS, is alleged to direct a "vigilante gang" in a
crime drive, while another member, a former Inkatha "warlord" who
Durban township. Some NPS members from the SGU are known to have a
record of involvement in dubious activities of the old security
police.

News images flashed across the world last weekend showing how
security men shoved Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin into his
limousine, shielding him from further attack, after right-wing
student Yigal Amir shot him twice at close range.

But the action of the security men, acknowledged to be among
the best trained in the world, came too late; the premier, a hawk
turned dove in Israel's peace process, died in hospital soon
after. The assassination sent shock waves around the globe, not
least among the security agencies responsible for the safety of
the world's leaders.

In South Africa, two factors increased apprehension about the
chances of a "copycat" attempt. First, as police commissioner
George Fivaz pointed out when he announced this week he had put
South Africa's VIP protectors on full alert, there are "distinct
parallels" between the political processes in Israel and South
Africa.

Secondly -- a factor which aggravates the "parallels" -- there
are fears of a right-wing backlash, likely to involve security
force personnel, after last week's arrest on third force
allegations of ex-defence minister Magnus Malan and top military
officers.

A secret police document leaked to the media relays Fivaz's
concern over the possibility of a "mobilisation" by former and
serving security force members against the arrests and instructs
the police Crime Intelligence Service to evaluate the threat.

Where the loyalty of members of the police and the military is
in question, it becomes all the more important that the loyalty of
those who protect VIPs is undivided. The spectre rises of the
assassination of Indian premier Indira Gandhi, killed by her own
bodyguards, Sikhs who thought her policies contrary to the
interests of India's Sikh community.

It appears the NPS, the unit responsible for the safety of
Mandela and his deputies, cabinet ministers and their deputies,
some judges, and other public figures, is subject to at least some
of the same factors that have strained the integration process
elsewhere in the police and military.

The NPS is a product mainly of the amalgamation of the old
South African Police SGU (which had close links with the apartheid
security police), members of the ANC's DIS, and members of the
security arm of the Pan Africanist Congress.

But, in the flush of reconciliation between former enemies,
lower standards of security screening may have been applied lest
anyone feels slighted by rebuffs.

The tightrope of amalgamation is reflected in the command
structure. There are "joint commanders" at different levels, and
the NPS, nationally, is commanded by two men: Brigadier Gary
Kruser, formerly with DIS, is in charge of operations, while
Brigadier Riaan Engelbrecht, formerly Special Guard Unit, is in
charge of planning.

Kruser acknowledged there "have been problems, and will
continue to be problems", but said they had been fewer than
expected. He said the first batch of NPS members had been sent
this week on a new VIP protection course, designed in consultation
with international experts, to "cement" the skills obtained in
widely divergent training backgrounds. All members will eventually
have to do the course. Standard security screening procedures had
been used to select NPS members, and some DIS operatives had not
made the grade because of previous criminal activities, Kruser
said.

The amalgamation process -- which is not yet complete --
remains fraught with difficulties. The VIP protection unit of the
old KwaZulu Police, which is supposed to integrate with the NPS as
the KwaZulu Police integrates with the South African Police
Service, has so far remained separate. Its commander, Major
Leonard Langeni, was named before last year's elections in a
Transitional Executive Council report on KwaZulu-Natal hitMalan trial.
squads, and has now been added to the list of witnesses in the

The KwaZulu Police VIP protection unit includes members of the
"Caprivi 200", the group of Zulu warriors trained by the South
African Defence Force on the Angolan border in 1986, and which is
implicated in hit-squad activities in the case against Malan.

In that unit, the distinction between assassin and guard
against assassination appears blurred. When the time comes to
integrate these men into the NPS, will secure screening procedures
override the need for "reconciliation", and will South Africa's
leaders be safe?
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


333 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Catholic Bishop Says "No" To Presidency


LENGTH: 960 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 6, 1995 (19951106)

Nakuru - Outspoken Kenyan Catholic bishop Ndingi Mwana a'Nzeki
has told Kenyan politicians he is not interested in vying for the
country's presidency in the future.

Reacting to recent press reports to the effect that some
opposition parties had already floated his name as a possible
presidential candidate, come the 1997 general elections and that
two senior ministers in President Moi's government have already
approached him for his stand over the issue, the Nakuru Catholic
Diocese bishop said he was "not up for grabs" and "not for
politics."

During the press conference, October 26 at his diocesan office
here, some 140 kilometres northwest of the capital, Nairobi, Mwana
a'Nzeki named two Kenya African National Union (K ANU) government
ministers who had approached the clergy seeking his stand on the
claims by the opposition.

"But on both occasions I told them "NO" never. My priority is
and has always been to be a simple parrish priest and serve the
Lord's flock," he disclosed. 

Bishop Ndingi says he was first approached by a mutual friend
sent by one of the Cabinet Ministers during the visit by Pope John
Paul II to Kenya in September.

"The friend who is also a priest told me that the minister was
anxious to know if the opposition had approached me to be their
joint candidate in the 1997 General Elections to oppose President
Moi," said the bishop. The second time was on October 7 when
President Moi officiated at a fundraising ceremony at Mary Mount
Secondary School in Molo within Ndingi's Nakuru Catholic diocese.
"This time, I gave him the same answer," noted Ndingi.

But the fiery Catholic bishop did not dwell much on claims by
the opposition that they have already floated his name as a
possible presidential candidate for the 1997 general elections. He
would only say... "I agree with them (as reported in sections of
the press) that I am a principled clergyman, who would not abandon
priesthood for political office."

In a lead story, a local influential weekly, Weekly Review, of
October 20, carried a report to the effect that the opposition had
identified and agreed on Bishop Ndingi's candidacy due to his
relentless pursuit of and firm stand on human rights issues and
his acceptability by a cross-section of Kenyans.

"Names of possible clergymen are already being floated, but the
one that keeps on coming up is that of Bishop Ndingi Mwana a'Nzeki
of the Catholic diocese of Nakuru," said the Weekly Review report.

This debate seems to have been sparked by claims by outspoken
opposition Member of Parliament Raila Odinga of the Forum for the
Restoration of Democracy - Kenya (FORD-K) to the effect that the
opposition had agreed to field a clergyman to oppose President Moi
in the coming elections.

On August 6 1995, Raila, a son of the late nationalist Jaramogi
Oginga Odinga, was reported saying that following talks with
another opposition member, the Democratic Party (DP), both sides
had agreed the opposition should field a single candidate to stand
against President Moi in the 1997 general elections.

"Representatives of the two parties now want to identify a
suitable candidate and persuade their colleagues and other
opposition parties that this is the only way they can challenge
the all-powerful KANU government and president Moi," Raila was
reported saying.

Reacting to the suggestion to field Bishop Ndingi's name for a
presidential candidate, a Catholic priest, who chose anonymity
told APS; "There is nothing wrong in floating his (Ndingi's) name,
but they (politicians) have either assumed or are assuming alot.
He is too principled to be swayed too easily on either political
side. I hope they have got the message right now."

Bishop Ndingi, has often locked horns with the government of
the day over numerous issues, the most recent being the 1991-93
land clashes, which resulted in deaths of innocent civilians and
displaced thousands others mostly within the Rift Valley and
Western provinces.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996

Africa News


November, 1995


Religious Committee Censures State Council


LENGTH: 1227 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 6, 1995 (19951106)

Monrovia - The Inter-faith Mediation Committee has accused
some members of Liberia's ruling six-man State Council of engaging
in a media war while their respective security apparatus assault,
harass and intimidate civilians.

The committee which comprises Christian and Muslim religious
leaders was established in 1990 with the objective of mediating
between warring factions in the Liberian conflict which began in
December 1989.

Addressing journalists at the Catholic Church of Liberia
secretariat here late October, the religious leaders also said
that they have noticed with a great deal of disappointment and
dissatisfaction that there are serious attempts to foment
religious hostility between adherents of Christianity and Islam.

At the Inter-Faith Mediation Committee's press conference, the
first since the sitting of Liberia's Six-man Council of State on
September 1, the religious leaders criticized a recent call by the
Elections Commission (ECOM) for political parties to begin
preparing to organise for elections. 

"To ask parties to organize for elections at this time when we
have crucial issues of safe corridors, safe havens, disarmament,
etc. is very disappointing. It is an indication here that we are
on our way to another Angola," noted the Committee headed by Dr.
Rev. Roland Diggs of the Lutheran Church of Liberia. Liberians are
scheduled to hold elections in October 1996.

Said the religious leaders; "If such developments are not
discouraged and brought to an immediate end, they it may not only
derail the peace process, but also lead the Liberian people into
another endless and destructive religious warfare that is even
more sensitive and dangerous than the present civil war."

The Inter-Faith Mediation Committee has therefore called on the
six-man Council of State to understand and appreciate the fact
that unless they learn to work together in unison, good faith, and
love, the chances of genuine peace and the restoration of
democracy in Liberia remains at stake.

The six-man State Council was sworn in on September 1, 1995
with the mandate of running Liberia until elections are held in
October 1996.

The ruling council was a culmination of this year's August 20
peace agreement signed in Abuja, Nigeria, effectively ending
perennial wrangling over power-sharing between warring factions
following an earlier peace accord signed in Ghana in 1994.

Brokered by Nigeria and Ghana, the latter which holds the
chairmanship of the Economic Community of West African States
(ECOWAS), the Abuja agreement was signed by all seven warring
factions. The factions are: the Charles Taylor-led National
Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), United Liberation Movement of
Liberia (ULIMO-K) of Alhaji Kromah, Ulimo-J the Liberia Peace
Council (LPC), Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), Lofa Defence Force
(LDF) and the NPFL - Central Revolutionary Council (CRC). Less
known university professor Wilton Sankawulo was unanimously
endorsed as chairman of the State Council.

In another development, the Archbishop of the Catholic Church
of Liberia, His Holiness, Michael K. Francis has called as to
Liberians to voice their concern about insecurity, continued
harassment and intimidation of peaceful citizens by fighters in
the country, when in fact they (Liberian people) have given them
their demands: "To have political power and give up guns."

"The factionalization of Government and the slow pace in the
peace process will not usher genuine peace in the country unless
Government can address issues affecting the survival of its
people," he added.

Delivering his homily at the Sacred Heart Cathedral to mark
the home-going of five Catholic nuns and one priest killed during
the infamous "Operation Octopus" in 1992, the Archbi shop said,
"The longer the fracticidal conflict continues the more hardened
we will become."

It will be difficult to reconcile with each other if Liberian
factions are not sincere in asking for forgiveness, he said. He
deplored "the unfortunate arrogance on the part of those who have
brought this evil on the Liberian people" and contributed in
"reopening wounds inflicted by them (factions).

The Catholic prelate noted, "evil warlords parade in our
society and in the city that they tried to destroy, treating the
Liberian people they inflicted so much pain on, suffering and
destruction, as if they are brute animals."

He pointed out that more than two months have passed since the
six man Council of State was established yet peace remains
elusive. The outspoken Archbishop regretted that instead of
disarmament, the process of factionalization is going on in the
whole country. He further questioned the sincerity of the warlords
who claimed that once they were on the Council of State they
would start disarmament but instead, they continue to prolong the
sufferings of the Liberian s.

The Archbishop also criticised attacks on the freedom of the
press, freedom of speech, the use of state-owned media to
manipulate citizens, "the immoral values creeping into our
society, the lack of political will to free and fair commission
and armed robberies."
-0Kenya

Africa News


November, 1995


Delay In Setting Up UN Tribunal Office


LENGTH: 627 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 6, 1995 (19951106)

Arusha - The United Nations tribunal set up to investigate the
1994 massacres in Rwanda that killed up to a million people will
not open its offices in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha
until December 1, the tribunal clerk Andronico Adede announced
here on November 1, the same day the tribunal was scheduled to
open office.

Dr. Adede, a Kenyan who works in the political division of the
UN headquarters in New York, said: "I negotiated with the
landlords and we agreed to take a section of the Arusha
International Conference Centre." But the office will only become
operational on December 1 after being refurnished, Adede said. 

Arusha, a town of 300,000 residents, was designated last
February by the UN Security Council as the headquarters of the
tribunal set up to probe the 1994 genocide that killed between
500,000 and one million people, most of them minority Tutsis and
moderates from the Hutu majority.

The tribunal's chief prosecutor, South African Judge Richard
Goldstone, said that indictments would be issued by the end of
1995 and trials would begin early next year.

The Arusha Conference Centre served as the site for peace talks
in 1993 that led to an accord designed to put an end to interof the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF), composed of Rwandan exiles
ethnic bloodshed between Hutu government troops and rebel Tutsis
that had lived in Uganda for more than three decades.

The RPF seized power in Kigali in July last year after the
death in a plane-crash near Kigali of Presidents Juvenal
Habyarimana of Rwanda and Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi, both
Hutus, triggering the Hutu-Tutsi ethnic backlash.

Some two million ethnic Hutus fled Rwanda and took refuge in
neighbouring Zaire, Tanzania and Kenya after the Tutsi minority
took power.

The now RPF-dominated Rwandan government led by Pasteur
Bizimungu has accused Kenya of "protecting" those who organised
last year's massacres in Rwanda. Recently, President Daniel arap
Moi roused a storm of international protest when he said Nairobi
would reject summonses addressed to Rwandan Hutus who fled to
Kenya after the massacre of mainly Tutsis by Hutu extremists whom
the tribunal is now seeking to bring to trial.

The Kenyan leader later toned down his statement saying he
would not protest perpetrators of the genocide, but called for the
mandate of the UN Tribunal to be broadened to include an
investigation of the shooting down of the plane that killed
Habyarimana and Ntaryamira.
-0Liberia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

336 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Thousands Flee Ethnic Backlash After Poll


LENGTH: 880 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 6, 1995 (19951106)

Abidjan - Some 6,000 of Ivory Coast's ethnic Baules have fled
their farm camps in the country's southwest to escape ethnic
violence that erupted there following the October 22 presidential
elections won by incumbent President Henri Konan Bedie of the
ruling Ivory Coast Democratic Party (PDCI).

Unconfirmed reports of massacres committed by members of a
rival ethnic group have not yet been verified.

The Baules, now staying under military protection in the
region's capital Gagnoa, 230 kilometres northwest of Abidjan, have
said they are afraid of attacks by Betes, the ethnic group that
forms the bulk of the region's population, while others also spoke
of massacres and of whole villages being razed to the ground. 

But as of October 30, only two people had been confirmed dead
as a result of the clashes between the two groups since the
October 22 presidential election.

Ivory Coast's opposition is led by a Bete. During the
presidential poll that brought a landslide victory to Konan Bedie,
the opposition's boycott of the poll was most widely and actively
carried out in the Bete area.

On October 19, the day before the Baules began to arrive in
Gagnoa, the national news agency reported that 18 people, mainly
women and children, had been "massacred" in a Baule camp near the
town.

The Ivorian military has said only one body was found when the
incident was investigated, but the news agency has not issued a
correction. According to military officials, villages have been
looted, and some even burnt but the incidents occurred after the
Baules had left. The military described these acts as "vandalism"
rather than systematic or premeditated attacks.

With parliamentary elections less than a month away, the Baulecountry's politicians and the press.
Bete issue has, meanwhile, become a propaganda tool for the

Since independence in 1960, Ivory Coast has been ruled by
Baules. In the late 1960s, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the
country's first president since independence from French colonial
rule in 1960 until his death in 1993, encouraged Baule farmers to
move from their eastern savannah homelands to cultivate cocoa in
more fertile forested regions occupied mainly by Betes.

Both sides are now accusing each other of "tribalising" the
debate and there have been suggestions in the press that
politicians are using both ethnic groups as pawns in their power
games and even providing them with weapons.

On October 30, the pro-government newspaper La Nouvelle
Republique denounced the "direct responsibility of certain
leaders" of the opposition "for these atrocities, while Henri
Dasse, an opposition member of parliament in Gagnoa claimed the
ruling party "would like to see 500 Baules killed in the area to
make devils out of us." Dasse believed that Bedie's party was
running a "brainwashing campaign" in the run-up to parliamentary
elections later this month.

In 1970, some 4,000 people, mainly Betes, were killed when the
army was called in to quell unrest in the Gagnoa area.

The historic rivalry between the Baule and Bete groups, which
mirrors the political divisions in Ivory Coast, was revived in the
run-up to the October 22 presidential election. Although a number
of attempts at reconciliation were made in the years that
followed, the killings did not become a public issue until the
advent of multi-partism in 1990.

Recent events in Gagnoa suggest that the nightmare of the
Baule-Bete issues is not yet over and would probably spill over
during the coming campaigns for the November legislative elections
and the municipal polls in December.
-0Rwanda


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


Rebels Say They Attacked Government Forces


LENGTH: 654 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 6, 1995 (19951106)

Khartoum - In a surprise early dry season offensive, the
mainstream Sudan Peoples Liberation Army (SPLA) of John Garang,
say they overrun Sudanese government garrisons at Palutaka and
Parajob in Eastern Equatoria on October 25.

It was the first victory of its kind for the SPLA since they
suffered a series of reverses, including the loss of their own
garrison town, Torit in 1992.

Reports here confirm that a major battle took place in
Palutaka(Parajok(Bor and Mugui areas, the latter an important
junction town to Juba and Torit in the South. 

However, a Sudanese government statement blamed Uganda for the
attack and charged that the offensive was led by three Ugandan
brigades of the Uganda Peoples Defence Forces (UPDF) comprising
nearly 2,000 men.

The statement pointed out that President Museveni "told Uganda
Parliament two months ago that he was going to attack Sudan."

Museveni's threat to attack Ugandan rebel bases in Sudan
followed a series of attacks by the Lords Resistance Army of
Uganda rebel Joseph Kony, one of which in late March this year
resulted in the massacre of 200 Acholi tribes people in Kitgum
District of northern Uganda.

Museveni says the rebels are armed and supported by the
Sudanese with bases in Palutaka(Parajok areas of Sudan.

Early April, Uganda severed diplomatic ties with the Sudan, her
neighbour in the north. A series of reconciliation meetings
mediated by Libya and Malawi failed to resolve the differences
between the two nations who have traded accusations about rebel
movements on each other's territory.

Rebel spokesperson Pajok Amoun said in the Kenyan capital
Nairobi that they had killed or wounded or captured most of the
3,000 troops at Parajok, while the remaining had been put to
flight.

He claimed large quantities of weapons including three tanks
and over 20 tracks had been seized by the rebels.

Amoun made no mention of the Lords Resistance Army rebels
believed to be at Palutak(Parajok when the camps were attacked.

He also denied that Uganda had helped the Sudanese rebels. "The
reason Khartoum has cooked up stories about the Ugandan
involvement is because they already told their people that the
SPLA is finished as a fighting force," he said.

Observers say if the victory by the Sudanese rebels is as
extensive as they claim, it will seriously disrupt any dry season
offensive that they had in the pipeline.

It will also substantially curtail the activities of the Lords
Resistance Army on Ugandan territory.
-0Ivory Coast

(DOCUMENT) Statement By Archbishop Tutu on Nigerian Executions


LENGTH: 240 words


 
Church of the Province of Southern Africa (Anglican)
November 10, 1995 (19951110)

"I am devastated. This is a diabolical act.

"Nothing could be more humiliating for President Mandela. He
has tried to be sensitive to the military regime's position, to
give them the opportunity of face-saving formulas. They have done
nothing but spit in his face. It is as if they are telling the
world to go to hell.

"Nigeria must be kicked out of the Commonwealth immediately.
Then the Commonwealth must lead the international community
without delay in applying stringent economic, sporting and
diplomatic sanctions against the regime. That is what brought
apartheid down and I have no doubt at all that this regime would
not last long in the face of comprehensive sanctions.

"If the Commonwealth heads of government do not take stringent
action they will deserve to be despised by peace-loving people."

LANGUAGE: English

339 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Decent Housing A Dream For South Africa's Blacks


LENGTH: 1480 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)
by Mercy Wambui
Johannesburg - With the installation of the first democratically
elected government in South Africa last year, expectations for
change were high among the majority black people. And the
country's first black African President boosted such hopes through
the Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) which promises
at least five million housing units by the year 2000. However, the
question many ask is, can the blacks, majority of whom the
programme was intended for, afford to pay even for subsidised
housing.

"He is the worst of them all!: says Michel van Gutten (not his
real name) driving at break neckspeed and pointing at a campaign
mugshot of South African President Nelson Mandela. 

"He promised to build 10 million houses, places to live in, but
not even one has been built.

"He now says that the government does not have money."

As he continues amidst four-lettered words, this writer seeks
to know if Michel is interested in the government's attempt to
racially integrate the running of the country, being part of that
process." Of course there is no such thing as integration as long
as Mandela is president!! Do you expect me (white) to integrate
with the blacks who are building squatter camps everywhere... they
(read Blacks) don't have jobs so they can't live in decent house,
and now they are a threat to us (whites)... they steal, they
kill."

This racist slur cannot get worse than it already sounds. After
years of racial segregation, the South Africa is not about to turn
into a haven for blacks despite the fact that they are exercising
self-rule. Economic disparities run wide and equal opportunities
for blacks are still few and far between.

Like most Sub-Saharan African countries, South Africa though
considered the most developed black-led country in the world, is
not exempt from housing problems. For many blacks who live in
squatter camps, the right to housing as enshrined in the
constitution is a far outcry from the reality they face daily.

Despite efforts by the Nelson Mandela-led government of
National Unity well intended commitment and seven-point plan to
eradicate homelessness, a social ill whose roots were watered by
the former apartheid regime, the challenge facing the nation is
almost overwhelming as is evident from statistics provided by
Wendy Ovens and Abdou Maling Simone, from Planact, a Johannesburg
based non- governmental organisation specializing in human
settlements issues.

The statistics read; the richest five per cent of the
population, mostly white, own 88 per cent of all private property,
two thirds of the African population live below the poverty line,
about 53 percent of the white labour force matriculate compared to
a poor 2.2 per cent of blacks and infant mortality among whites is
7.3 per 1000 against a worrying 52.8 per 1000 among blacks.

While the apartheid regime used housing as an instrument to
manipulate, separate and regiment citizens by denying them access
to living in the city and kept them in townships, this has changed
dramatically since the first all race elections in April 1994. The
breaking down of the walls of apartheid has tremendously increased
in-migration to cities by both South African nationals, refugees
and economic opportunists from other parts of Africa.
Unfortunately, the influx has paralled increase in organised
violence and crime such as drug-trafficking and commercial sex
activity in the search for economic survival.

Currently, the rate of urban population growth in South Africa
stands at 4.3 per cent bringing the total population of urbanites
to 23.6 million in a country of about 42 million people. Available
statistics show that 65 per cent of black dwelling units are
informal, with the majority consisting of backyard shacks in
townships. Evidently, the government has a staggering challenge of
meeting a housing backlog of 1.3 million units. Its Reconstruction
and Development Programme (RDP) has a target of at least one
million houses in the next five years.

Although well-meaning, the implementation of the RDP increment
housing policy is a slow, tedious and frustrating process which is
simply not satisfactory. Its current housing policy comprises
among seven points, a subsidy scheme to provide housing
opportunities.

Critics argue that providing housing through subsidies assumes
that other basic issues are already well taken care of. "It is
based on private sector models whereby people take up mortgages.
The problem with mortgages is that they are dependent on one's
ability to pay back. The large per cent of homeless blacks cannot
afford mortgages at all," they note.

Planact, points out that the number of housing units built in
the last one year is just about 10,000, falling way below its one
million target for the next five years. For the two-thirds of
Africans living below the poverty line and those who have no form
of income however low, subsidies are out of question.

The process of acquiring loans, qualifying for loans, and
eventual payment is already painstaking. There are also many other
issues at stake such as lack of education, adequate health
facilities and general dysfunctioning of communities which means
that people's preoccupation is not just about a roof over one's
head, but about provision of clean water, lighting, education and
basic health.

So what solutions do human settlements experts envision? Wendy
Ovens, suggests that the current housing subsidy programme would
make the process of accessing housing to blacks possible by making
it a down-up approach as opposed to the top-down structure. "The
government should ensure that housing targeted for a certain
location should involve the community right from the beginning."

She suggests for instance, that introducing trust funds to
which community members contribute monthly is a more successful
approach than announcing a free for all housing project. After
several years of accumulated finance through the fund, community
members can afford to purchase low income houses and most
importantly, they own the process right from the beginning.

"Building houses first and then asking poor community members
to buy them is asking for the impossible..." says Ovens. She notes
that such houses end up being bought by the more educated with
better jobs and with access to bank loans for down-payments.
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


340 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Were Elections Free And Fair In Zanzibar?


LENGTH: 1547 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)
by Sam Gonza

Nairobi - The long awaited general election in Tanzania seems
to have generated more confusion than excitement, especially with
the anticipated repeat of the poll in the capital, Dar-es-Salaam.
Can the irregularities prompting fresh polls in Dar-es-Salaam be
ruled out in Zanzibar, Pemba and the rest of Tanzania.

Reliable sources in Tanzania say international observers
representing donor nations, who monitored the first general
elections in the island of Zanzibar on October 22, have now
written to outgoing President Ali Hassan Mwinyi stating that Seif
Sheriff Hamad, the opposition cand idate for the Civic United
Front (CUF) is the winner of Zanzibar's presidential elections.

The Island of Zanzibar (traditionally called Unguja) and its
sister island of Pemba, are members of the union with mainland
Tanzania. 

They held their parliamentary and presidential polls a week
earlier than mainland Tanzania where the elections which started
on October 29 have been described as "absolutely chaotic ." In the
capital of mainland Tanzania, Dar-es-Salaam, an opposition
stronghold, elections are to be repeated.

By the time of going to press, the chairman of the National
Convention for Reconstruction (NCCR-Mageuzi) Mr Augustine Mrema
said that opposition parties would file a court injunction to halt
the on-going general election process in Tanzania. Mrema also
indicated th at the Electoral Commission's call for a repeat of
elections in Dar-es-Salaam was a pointer to possibilities of
irregularities in the rest of the country.

International observers were angered by the whole election
process in Zanzibar where they cited questionable practices such
as police intimidation and refusal to register perceived
opposition supporters in rural areas. Tanzania officials cannot
readily ignore the frustration of donors who provide more than 50
per cent of budgetary support for the economy of this East African
country with a population of 25 million people.

The Zanzibari incumbent Salmin Amour of the Chama Cha
Mapinduzi (CCM) was declared winner by the Zanzibar Electoral
Commission (ZEC), which gave him a very narrow margin of 50.2 per
cent (165,271 ballots) against CUF's Hamad, who got 49.8 per cent
with 163,706 votes.

It was clear that all was not well or transparent. Judge Zubeir
Mzee, Chairman of the ZEC did not entertain any questions from
reporters after his declaration of Amour as winner on October 26.

CCM also won the Parliamentary elections by 27 seats to 23 for
CUF. CUF swept all 20 parliamentary seats in Pemba, meaning they
only managed three seats in Zanzibar. There are 50 seats in the
Zanzibari parliament.

After the elections on October 22 all results were expected in
by the night of October 23, at the latest. The total number of
votes cast was less than 350,000 for the two islands.

However, it took another 36 to 48 hours for parliamentary
results to be declared officially, while the presidential poll
results were announced 72 hours later.

Because of the frustrations caused by silence from the ZEC,
Dar-es-Salaam Television refused to wait any longer and announced
on October 24, that Seif Sheriff Hamad, was the winnner with
164,312 against Amour's 155,787 votes.

Asked where he obtained the results, Mbela Mwanatongoni, head
of Dar-es-Salaam Television said the station relied on impeccable
sources who had witnessed several recounts of the p residential
vote.

His deputy, Mr. Ligulu charged that members of ZEC appeared to
be hiding the whole day. "What do you do as a journalist when they
are determined to hide the information? Will you not find it out
any way you can?" he asked.

Although he was being declared the winner, Hamad had as early
as October 23 dism issed the elections as a fraud.

He demanded a recount of the votes and scrutiny of forms used
at the polling stations.

He pointed out that at a number of stations namely Kitopeni,
Malandege, Kurhani - the number of votes polled exceeded that of
registered voters. He also claimed that illiterate Zanzibaris had
been tricked to vote for CCM and that army and police based on the
Islands had been ordered to vote for the ruling party. However,
Chama Cha Mapinduzi Deputy Secretary General for Zanzibar Ali
Amier, dismissed Hamad's charges out of hand.

But things changed dramatically once it became obvious that
Amour was losing the count in the presidential ballot. Ali Amier
issued another angry statement disowning the elections entirely.
"We are not demanding just a recount; What we are demanding is
that the whole elections be done again."

ZEMOG, constituting a group of local observers in Zanzibar,
said the first multiparty elections in the islands was fraught
with problems right from the beginning.

Prof. Harub Osman of ZEMOG said the whole registration exercise
had been flawed in the run-up to the elections, including
interference by security agents who intimidated many in the
opposition camp.

Prof. Chris Peter decried the poor organisation on polling day
itself. He did not understand why there were only two vehicles for
the purpose of distributing voting material to polling centres.
Although voters arrived at polling stations as early as 6.00 am.
many of the centres opened late , forcing officials to wait
sometimes up to midnight, before counting of votes could start.

International observers are angered that United Nations
Development Programme (UNDP) and the Organisation of African Unity
(OAU) rushed to endorse the results of the Zanzibari elections
despite endless flaws.

Some media outlets in Zanzibar reported that Salmin Amour had
made an unexpected trip to Dar es Salaam to consult with the
overall head of the Tanzanian Electoral Commission Ju dge Lewis
Makame. Judge Makame has been accused of being a CCM puppet, bent
on rigging the vote.Calls for his resignation are growing
following the confusion during the polls in the capital, Dar es
Salaam on October 29.

The CUF is considered the party of the "Arabs" while the CCM in
Zanzibar is the continuation of the old Afro-Shirazi party of the
late Abeid Karume who led Zanzibar after the revolution of 1964.
The revolution ended the reign of the Sultans who trace their
roots to Oman in the Arab Peninsular.

Zanzibar is famous as the "spice islands". In history Zanzibar
is also remembered as the 19th century slave trade market centre
for slaves en route to Arabia, Asia and the Americas.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


341 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Scholar Traces Roots Of Rwanda's Patriotic Front


LENGTH: 1880 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Nairoibi - In 1970 former Uganda President Milton Obote threw
out hundreds of Kenyan immigrant families who had settled in
Uganda for generations. In 1982 he repeated the same act on
thousands of Rwandese immigrants all over Uganda. Our APS
Correspondent reports on a study by an Asian-Uganda scholar who
argues that the enforced eviction against the Rwandese led to
Obote's own eventual overthrow and contributed greatly to the
formation of the Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF).

President Daniel arap Moi's much publicised and criticised
statement on October 2 to the effect that Kenya would be reluctant
to hand over to the United Nations Tribunal on Rwanda those
implicated in the genocide in that country one year ago, has
ignited discussions on an issue of fundamental importance to
justice and peace in the whole region.

The Kenyan leader later softened his stand, indicating that his
country was not working against the Tribunal's efforts to bring to
book those (be it Hutu or Tutsi) responsible for the 1994
massacres in which some one million Rwandese died. However, he
maintained that Kenya wanted to be told who had killed Rwandese
President Juvenal Habyariamana and the Burundi leader Cyprien
Ntaryamira in a mysterious plane crash in the capital of Rwanda,
Kigali, on the evening of April 6, 1994. 

Habyarimana was considered a good friend of President Moi. The
UN War Crimes Tribunal on Rwanda, was due to open in Arusha
Tanzania, on November 1.

Barely four days after the international furore sparked by
Moi's original statement, Zambian officials announced the arrest
of eight Rwandese nationals suspected to have played a key role in
the genocide. Reports say the suspects include a former mayor of
Kigali.

Undeterred by criticism from Kenya African National Union
(KANU) ruling party st alwarts, nine Kenyan opposition Members of
Parliament returned home on October 29 at the end of a three-day
fact-finding mission to Rwanda.

Led by Leader of the Official Opposition Wamalwa Kijana of the
Forum for the Restoration of Democracy (FORD-Kenya) the nine
legislators, who also included Democratic Party (DP) Chairman Mwai
Kibaki and FORD-Asili Secretary General Martin Shikuku, held
discussions with Rwandese President Pasteur Birimungu, Prime
Minister Celestin Rusigema and Vice President Paul Kagame.

Upon their return, the opposition MPs criticised the
governments of Kenya and France for their seemingly uncooperative
attitude in the efforts to restore peace and reconciliat on in
Rwanda.

It is estimated that as many as 400 perpetrators of the carnage
in Rwanda have made homes in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi and the
coastal city of Mombasa. They comprise the cream of former power
brokers in Kigali.

Among those believed to be residing in Kenya, is the man said
to have financed the Radio Milles Collines, the radio station that
incited the panga and grenade wielding gangs against the inyenziindividuals live in exclusive apartments where tenants pay
(cockroaches as the minority Tutsi were called). Some of these
substantial rents.

Uganda's President Yoweri Museveni, whose name has been closely
linked to the formation and support of the Rwanda Patriotic Front
(RPF) that seized power in Kigali after unprecedent orgy of
killings, commenting on Moi's misgivings about the War Tribunal's
terms of reference said it was his (Moi's) business if he did not
wish to cooperate with the tribunal. Museveni continued, "genocide
is a crime against mankind. I think it is an obligation, and not
simply voluntary, to hand over these people."

Rwanda's Vice President and Defence Minister Paul Kagame cast
aspersions on the moral uprightness of the authorities in Nairobi,
accusing them of sharing the same views with the criminals who
killed up to one million Tutsi and moderate Hutus last year."

Kagame advised Moi to look to France for the material evidence
relating to the rocket attack that brought down the executive jet
in which the two presidents were killed. "The fact is, the
material evidence was carried to France." French military
advisors, said to have acted at the behest of hardline elements in
Rwanda are among the suspects thought to have brought down the
presidential executive jet on the evening of April 6.

To many observers, Kenya was clearly targeting Ugandan
President Yoweri Museveni . Zaire, too has criticised Museveni's
links with the RPF. Significantly also, in reply to Kagame's angry
denounciation of the Kenyan stand, a Kenyan government statement
called Kagame "a Uganda." Kagame was born of Tutsi parents who
fled to Uganda after the 1959 upheavals in Rwanda.

But a new study by an Asian-Ugandan scholar, Prof. Mahmood
Mamdani, suggests it is far too simplistic to blame Museveni as
the instigator of the RPF in 1990. Mamdani's study was published
as a series in the government owned daily New Vision in September.

Partly titled "In the footsteps of Hutu Tutsi killing," the
author shows the genesis of the RPF was a complex dynamic of
forces, not least the violent uprooting of thousands of Rwandese
migrants in many parts of Uganda after former President Milton
Obote returned to power for the second time in 1980.

It must be emphasised that Dr. Mamdani's study is primarily an
attempt to understand how peace and justice could be achieved in
Rwanda following the upheavals of 1994.

During his first period of office in 1970, President Obote made
a similar error of judgement when he uprooted thousands of Luo
families from Kenya who had made Uganda their home. The late
President Jomo Kenyatta refused to see Obote when the latter
arrived in Nairobi after he was toppled in a military coup in
January 1971. The Luo inhabit the western part of Kenya,
neighbouring Uganda.

Prof. Mamdami argues that what became known as the "RPF
invasion of Rwanda in 1990 also needs to be understood as an
expulsion of Rwandese refugees from Uganda." Mamdani says that a
refugee self-consciousness became deeply rooted only among the
refugees who fled to Uganda and not those who moved to Belgian
Congo or Tanganyika in 1958.

The reason for this acute awareness of their plight, says
Mamdani, was that "successive governments in Uganda considered the
children of refugees also to be refugees." Many of these immigrant
children had to hide their identities and pretend to be Baganda,
Banyankole, Banyoro..."The anti refugee prejudice was promoted by
the State and shared by many in society at large," he claims.

To many Rwandese, the expulsion of Kenyan Luos by Obote in 1970
heralded their own expulsion. After all, wonders Mamdani, "had not
the Obote I regime, as early as 1969, ordered the registration of
all Rwandese refugees in Uganda, a move many considered a prelude
to their own expulsion?"

The Rwandese expulsion came true, though under Obote's second
period in office later in 1982/1983. It started in October 1, 1982
and involved local chiefs and the youth wing of the Uganda Peoples
Congress (UPC) of Obote, and paramilitary special forces. They
targeted Banyarwa nda all over Uganda's southwest. Mamdani quotes
witnesses who said "there were killings, rapes and maimings" and
their homes were destroyed.

Over 40,000 fled to Rwanda before Kigali closed the door on its
side of the border. Many youths fled into the bush and contributed
to the surge of guerrilla activity by the National Resistance Army
(NRA) of President Museveni who shot his way to power three years
later.

Similar action was repeated against the Rwandese in Masaka,
Teso, Lango and elsewhere in Uganda. This explains why the Luwero
Triangle in Central Uganda, an area whose population included
large numbers of Rwandese migrants, became the focus of the
guerrilla activity against Obote.

Later, the Rwandese who had contributed to the removal of Obote
in 1985 broke away from the NRA and headed south to Rwanda after
Uganda's Parliament barred non-Ugandans from owning land in the
country in the landbill of 1990. The Rwandese then felt betrayed
by Ugandans according to Mamdani's research.
-0Tanzania


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


342 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Ruling Party Wins In Zanzibar Election


LENGTH: 680 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Zanzibar - The ruling Chama cha Mapinduzi (CCM-revolutionary)
party won the election for 50 members of parliament in the
Tanzanian islands of Zanzibar and Pemba in results announced
October 26.

Final figures announced on Zanzibar Radio, three days after the
polls gave the CCM 26 seats to 24 for the opposition Civic United
Front (CUF). The CUF won all 21 seats on Pembaa nd three of the 29
seats on Zanzibar. 

The results opened the way for the announcement of the vote for
an executive president who will have the power to appoint
additional members of parliament.

On October 24, a win for the CCM in these first multi-party
poll since Zanzibar attained independence from British protection
in 1963, had appeared clear-cut to the extent that the ruling
party supporters celebrated in the streets while CUF declared it
had been robbed of victory.

But on October 25, one unofficial count of voting in the last
three constituencies gave victory to the opposition, while another
count-equally unofficial - gave the two parties 25 seats each.

A Zanzibar Electoral Commission official said the results of
the last three constituencies were being counted, recounted and
counted again before being issued.

But key to the results of the elections in the twin Indian
Ocean islands was the yet-to-be announced vote for its executive
president, who will have the power to appoint additional members
of parliament.

Equally crucial to the future of the islands, which are part of
the United Republic of Tanzania, will be the results of the
national vote for the president and vice- president of the union
and the union parliament seated at Dodoma in the centre of the
Tanzanian mainland.

The national elections, on October 29, will also be the first
multi-party poll since mainland Tanganyika's independence from
British colonial rule in 1961.

CUF's presidential candidate for Zanzibar was Seif Shariff
Hamad, a former prime minister who subsequently spent 30 months in
prison on state of security charges, accused of having retained
secret state papers after he was ousted and expelled from the then
sole ruling CCM party.

Hamad had been so sure of losing early last week that he told
reporters that his supporters were "frustrated" because they had
been "robbed of their victory," charging that there was voteSaying that those who voted included "lunatics and the dead",
rigging and called for fresh elections.
Hamad had declared : "We will not recognise nor shall we be
obedient to a government that will be formed as a resu lt of these
unfair elections."
-0Rwanda

Africa News


November, 1995


African Inland Church Celebrates 100 Years


LENGTH: 747 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Nairobi - Some 20,000 African Inland Church (AIC) faithful,
among them President Daniel arap Moi, celebrated a special
thanksgiving and worship service here in late October marking the
100th anniversary of the church in Kenya.

The thanksgiving service held in the city outskirts, marked the
culmination of centenary celebrations which began January this
year throughout AIC's 3,000 local churches.

Apart from President Moi the day-long celebrations were also
graced by Cabinet Members, Members of Parliament, clergy and
visitors from Australia, the United Kingdom, Tanzania, Malawi,
Zaire, Uganda and the Sudan. 

They sang and prayed as they braved a heavy downpour during the
ceremonies which started at 9 am and ended at 4 pm local time.

Bishop Ezekiel Birech, the AIC head in Kenya, and Dr. Dick
Underson conducted the elaborate religious ceremony which included
the cutting of five cakes symbolising the origin of the church,
its plantation in Kenya, its logo, the Bible and evangelisation.

In a brief address, President Moi paid homage to European
missionaries who "endured mosquitoes and the strange tropical
environment" to spread Christianity in Africa.

Noting that Peter Cameroon Scott was only 28 when he founded
the AIC in Kenya, the President urged the youth to take the lead
in evangelisation campaigns.

Established in Kenya as the African Inland Mission (AIM) in
1985, AIC's first mission station was set up in Kalamba, in
present day Makueni district of eastern Kenya. The church which is
said to have started with "no budget, no salaries and no fixed
income" currently boasts of 2,000,000 members and adherents
countrywide, 3,000 churches, runs 18 training institutions, 55
medical and health institutions and 24 children's homes.

Peter Cameroon Scott lived a brief, hectic and very productive
life. Born of poor God-loving Scottish parents in 1867, Peter
Scott was raised in Oshwal Street, London.

In 1889 A.B. Simpson, founder of the International Missionary
Alliance, accepted Scott to train in New York. The following year
the young man was ordained as an Alliance missionary just a day
before he departed for Banana at the mouth of West Africa's river
Congo.

Two years later Scott became so ill that he had to be carried
to Banana unconscious and later to England for treatment.

In 1895, together with a group of missionary enthusiasts,
including Arthur Pierson, and Charles Hurburt they established
African Inland Mission.

The AIC also owns a chain of Christian bookshops, a radio
studio, a popular Christian magazine (Today in Africa), and has
established its own African Missionary Society with more than 50
missionaries serving in Kenya and neighbouring Uganda. Since 1945,
the church has ordained 350 ministers.

Africa Inland Church, which boasts of being "the largest church
in the country with no links to a denomination outside Kenya,"
celebrated its 100 years under the theme, Glory to God-Mission
Unchanged.
-0Tanzania


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


344 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Churches Asked To Help Youth Exploit Talents


LENGTH: 654 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Nairobi - The All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) General
Secretary Rev. Jose Chipenda has asked churches in Africa to help
their young people exploit individual talents.

Speaking at a photo exhibition, mounted by participants in the
1995 Media Production Course at the AACC Communication Training
Centre on October 23, Chipenda said although the youth are highly
talented and full of ideas they need help to exploit their gifts.

The photo exhibition, part of the annual six-month media
production course, was a culmination of a three-week intensive
photography course conducted by a local seasoned photo-journalist,
Sam Ouma. 

Rev. Chipenda challenged the course participants, seven women
and 11 men from 12 African countries, to exploit the knowledge
they had acquired from the course for the benefit of the church
and Africa in general.

"We are today living in a world, where modern mode of
communication such as photography has become part and parcel of
evangelisation. It is up to us to avail this knowledge to
Christians who will later on exploit it effectively for the
benefit of the church," noted the AACC head.

The photographs depicted activities such as sports, cultural
dances, motor rally, wildlife, religious festivities, tourism and
farming among the Kenyan people.

The photo exhibition was attended by among other invited
guests, chief photographers from Kenya's leading dailies.

Mr. Yusuf Wachira, chief photographer with the private-owned
Daily Nation, challenged course participants against taking
photography as a mere hobby.

"It has to be serious business for serious people carrying with
it both challenges and risks. Its impact on the intended consumer
depends wholly on the photographer himself and his tools of trade,
the camera being one of them," said Wachira.

Mr Yahya Mohammed from another independent daily, the East
African Standard commended churches for acknowledging the crucial
role played by photography in Christian ministry.

The six-month media production course is coordinated by a
consultant in communication training, Mr. Polycarp Omollo-Ochilo
who is also a lecturer at the Nairobi University School of
Journalism.

During the course, students were taught various techniques in
communication such as electronic media script writing, drama,
video, the act of interviewing and photography.

Participants were drawn from Rwanda, Sudan, Liberia, Botswana,
Lesotho, Cameroon , Swaziland, The Gambia, Angola, Malawi, Zaire
and Kenya.
-0Kenya
