Africa News


November, 1995


Violence Mars Bedie's Election As President


LENGTH: 747 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Abidjan - Outgoing Ivorian President Henri Konan Bedie won rebut questions were raised about the number of people who turned
election in Ivory Coast's presidential poll held on October 22,
out to vote.

According to provisional results released by the Interior
Ministry on October 23, Bedie won the elections, polling 96.44 per
cent of the votes against 3.56 per cent for his only opponent
Francis Wodie of the opposition Ivorian Workers' Party.

The results of the elections, boycotted by the main opposition,
must be reviewed by the Constitutional Council to become official. 

According to official figures, an estimated 56 per cent of the
country's 3.8 million registered voters turned up to cast their
votes at polling stations throughout the country. Legisl ative
elections are to follow next month.

But celebrations of his victory by the ruling Ivory Coast
Democratic Party (PDCI ) have been dampened by violence before and
during the elections that left more than a dozen people dead,
according to unofficial estimates.

In the weeks leading up to the poll, eight people died in
opposition protests marked by increasing violence as demonstrators
clashed with both police and Bedie supporters.

There were violent incidents on polling day on October 22, when
at least two people died, although most observers were expecting
worse, after the core of the opposition first announced they would
not take part in the vote, but took a hardline and called for an
"active boycott" and instructed supporters to do all they could to
stop the vote.

The call followed the refusal by Bedie to revise rules which
the opposition claimed effectively barred one of their most
favoured candidates, former Prime Minister Allassane Ouattara,
from standing.

At least five other people are said to have been massacred at a
camp in a region outside Abidjan in election-related ethnic
violence before the poll.

In several areas, the opposition succeeded in blocking access
to polling booths by erecting roadblocks, while in others, polling
stations were destroyed and ballot boxes and voting material burnt
down.

In at least two districts, voting was cancelled because the
required equipment never arrived. However, voting at most polling
stations proceeded peacefully, even at opposition strongholds such
as Yopougon, a suburb of Abidjan, where several clashes with
police occurred in the weeks before the election.

It was, however, not clear whether those who stayed away had
refused to accept the legitimacy of the poll, feared violent
scenes at polling booths, or were simply apathetic about an
election whose outcome could be predicted once it emerged that
Bedie would only be opposed by a minor politician.

Bedie, who became president without election when the country's
first president Felix Houphouet-Boigny died in office in 1993, had
been expected to win a five-year term easily, mainly due to lack
of serious rivals.
-0Africa-At-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


346 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Tutu Asks Rich Nations To Forgive Poor Debtors


LENGTH: 760 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

London - South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu conducted a
thanksgiving service for 50 years of the United Nations at the
Westminster Cathedral here on October 24.

The service coincided with the weeklong commemoration events,
parties and speeches, at the UN headquarters in New York. The
birthday events brought together more than 180 leaders from all
over the world. The United Nations started as the league of
Nations in 1945. 

Talking to journalists after the service here, the outspoken
Cape Town Archbishop who is also president of the Nairobi-based
All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) said rich nations should
seek inspiration in the Bible to help solve the problems of
underdevelopment and poverty. He repeated an impassioned plea for
the rich nations to cancel the debts owed by poor nations
particularly at this time when the United Nations was celebrating
its 50 years.

"The leaders of the rich nations should look to the Bible for
inspiration. Every 50 years you make a new beginning - this is the
jubilee principle in (the book of) Leviticus - you cancel any
debts still owed; if there are slaves you set them free - it is a
chance for a renewal for everybody, " he appealed.

Tutu suggested that as a first step in this direction debtor
(poor) nations should be given a moratorium under which they would
be subjected to scrutiny, to see whether funds from cancelled
debts would be put to projects to benefit the people and whether
governments of beneficiary Third World nations would improve their
human rights records.

"If genuine progress is being made, the debts must be
cancelled," said Tutu.

The Archbishop said he was optimistic the leaders of the
industrialised world would see the pragmatism of taking such a
course of action "because of the good inherent in man. Even those
who are agnostics or non believers, you don't have to persuade
them that peace is better than war - this is the nobility of the
human spirit."

Archbishop Tutu's call comes two weeks after a coalition of
American churches and churches under the umbrella of the All
Africa Conference of Churches organised a series of demonstrations
and other activities to increase awareness of the implication of
the "debt crisis" that coincided with the World Bank/International
Monetary Fund annual meeting that began in Washington D C on
October 9.

The churches want debts owed to rich nations repealed and a new
start made.

And during his recent tour of Africa in September, Pope John
Paul II made a special plea for debt burdened African nations. He
urged the rich nations to have the courage to cancel the debt owed
by African nations.

African nations alone owe more than $211 billion to the
industrialised world.

Meanwhile at the UN jubilee celebrations in New York, South
African president Ne lson Mandela reminded the United Nations that
it had failed the poor people of Africa.
-0Ivory Coast


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


347 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Mobutu Says Refugees Can Stay In Zaire


LENGTH: 827 words


 
All Africa Press Service
October 30, 1995 (19951030)

New York - Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko has confirmed
that he is against any deadlines for Rwandese refugees of Hutu
origin to quit refugee camps in Goma, eastern Zaire, and return to
their homeland, Rwanda.

There are more than one million Rwandese refugees on Zairean
territory where they have lived in camps operated by the United
Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) for over one year
now. They fled the country after the genocide that saw more than
one million mainly Tutsis and moderate Hutus murdered by Hutu
hardliners. The massacres were sparked by the April 6, 1994
killing of Rwandese President Juvenal Habyarimana and his
Burundian counterpart Cyprien Ntaryamira in a suspicious plane
crash in Kigali, the Rwandan capital. 

Mobutu told reporters here where he was attending the United
Nations 50 anniversary celebrations: "It is not proper for Zaire
which has treated refugees like brothers to establish deadlines
for them to leave."

His latest stand confirms similar sentiments he expressed
earlier in a Belgian newspaper Le Soir. The Zairean Head of State
is reported saying October 22 that he was opposed to the deadline
set by Zairean Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo for all Rwandese
refugees to leave Zaire by December 31.

Kengo had made it clear that those who will not have met the
deadline would be forcibly evicted by the army.

In August this year, Zairean troops acting on orders from the
Prime Minister forcibly repatriated an estimated 12,000 refugees
across the common border with Rwanda in the west, despite repeated
international calls for Zaire to approach the matter in a
humanitarian way. The UNHCR, other aid agencies and the
international community asked Zaire to help implement voluntary
repatriation.

In his latest interview here, Mobutu did not explain why he had
kept silent when Zairean troops were implementing forcible
repatriation. However, observers believe that his statement is the
final word on the matter and the Rwandese who do not wish to leave
can stay on in Goma without harassment.

Early October Rwandese, Zairean and UNHCR authorities concluded
an amicable understanding to repatriate as many as 20,000 refugees
every day across the border. Exiled Rwandese refugee sources said
were against the agreement and claimed the UNHCR had been applying
strong arm tactics to coerce the refugees to return home.

Meanwhile in what is seen as a diplomatic breakthrough, Zairean
President Mobutu Sese Seko and the Ugandan leader Yoweri Museveni
have agreed to work together "to help prevent further humanitarian
tragedies in Rwanda and Burundi."

With UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros Ghali, they met
former American President Jimmy Carter here and the latter agreed
to convene a peace conference with the active involvement of
Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire to foster reconciliation and peace in
the region.

Carter said he expected to get the conference going very soon
and the priority on the agenda would be "how to prevent further
tragedies."

The former American leader has been actively involved in the
search for peace in much of sub-Saharan Africa with particular
interest in the long-standing conflict in the Sudan.

Early October Carter opened a "Carter Centre" in Nairobi to
facilitate his peace initiatives in the region.
-0Africa-At-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


348 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Mandela's ANC Wins Local Elections


LENGTH: 1000 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)

Johannesburg - South Africa's first democratic local government
elections had by November 5 delivered a resounding win to South
African President Nelson M andela's ruling African National
Congress (ANC) and a mortal blow to white separatists.

Mandela's ruling party had secured 69.1 per cent of votes cast
in the November 1 election, with only about 20 per cent of results
outstanding.

This is significantly higher than the 62.6 per cent the ANC
polled in last year' s first all-race general election, although
it must be considered that boundary and constitutional disputes
resulted in no voting taking place in KwaZulu-Natal province, the
stronghold of the Zulu nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP).

The ANC dominated seven out of eight provinces where voting
took place and even made inroads in Western Cape province,
traditionally a stronghold of the formerly-ruling National Party
(NP). 

The Western Cape results could also change as there was no
voting in the Greater Cape Town area, a powerbase for the NP and
the Liberal Democratic Party (DP).

The ANC will also control South Africa's largest city, winning
outright majorities in the four councils and the overarching
metropolitan council of Greater Johannesburg, despite strong
showings by the NP and the DP, which regained the support of
wealthy whites.

The NP of Deputy President Frederik de Klerk, although
disappointed by its poor showing in the Western Cape, can take
heart that its total share of the vote was 20.5 per cent, slightly
higher than what it achieved in last year's first all-race general
election.

The NP is ecstatic about its strong support among white
Afrikaners-- descendants of the original Dutch and French
colonists who make up about 58 per cent of the white population.

The NP triumphed in the capital Pretoria over both the ANC and
the white right-wing parties, which suffered humiliating defeats.

The pro-apartheid Conservative Party (CP), contesting its first
election under democracy, having boycotted the general election,
was virtually wiped out in Pretoria, failing to win a single war.

It was the same story for the more pragmatic, but still
separatist Freedom Front (FF), which fared better than the CP but
failed to attract large numbers of Afrikaners to its cause.

In the rural heartland where the CP and FF want a "volkstaat"
-- Afrikaner state -- both parties suffered heavily at the hands
of the NP and the ANC, failing to win any towns.

NP leader and Constitutional Development Minister Roelf Meyer
summed up what may political analysts believe about the chances
for a separate Afrikaner state: "The volkstaat idea has been
killed."

The decimation of the white right is certain to lead the ANCwhite homeland.
dominated government of national unity to reject any claims for a

This is tacitly acknowledged by FF leader Constand Viljeon, who
said he would now send his few town councilors on a course to
teach them - "how to deal as Afrikaners with a situation where you
are totally overpowered."

The local elections also dealt blows to the militant black Pan
Africanist Congre ss (PAC), which polled 1.7 per cent of the votes
and failed to capitalise on ANC's failure to speedily deliver on
its social upliftment promises to the black majority.

The racial divide was also shown by the arrest of former
Defence Minister Magnus Malan and 10 former senior military
officers on charges of murdering 13 people in KwaZulu-Natal
province in 1987.

White politicians, including de Klerk, have said the arrests
pose a serious threat to reconciliation in South Africa, while
black leaders have stated that the trial must proceed and there
must be full disclosure of crimes committed in defence of
apartheid.

The row over the arrest of Malan and the others, who were
released on bail after a brief court appearance on November 2, may
have impacted on voting trends and analysts believe the arrests
cut white support for the ANC.
-0Rwanda and Zaire


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November, 1995


Churches Ask All Parties To Maintain Peace


LENGTH: 800 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)

Dar-es-Salaam - The Tanzanian Episcopal Conference (TEC) and
the Christian Council of Tanzania (CCT) have called on all
Tanzanians to conduct themselves peacefully and urged those who
have complaints following the October 29 multi-party parliamentary
and presidential polls to direct them to the National Electoral
Commission or the court.

In a joint statement here on November 2 the Catholics under TEC
and Protestants under the CCT expressed hope that the Electoral
Commission would accord due weight to these complaints and where
courts are involved, justice will be swiftly accorded in the
interests of peace, and tranquility.

The statement signed by Archbishop P. Pengo, chairman of the
Tanzanian Episcopal Conference and CCT chairman Bishop E. Sendoro
of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Tanzania (ELCT) also
appealed to the government to take all the necessary precautions
to ensure that peace is maintained and human rights are
safeguarded. The church leaders further appealed to people of all
beliefs in Tanzania to continue praying to Almighty God that peace
which "has been our bles sing from Him for all these past years
may be maintained." 

The churches' representatives expressed regret at the state of
tension prevailing in Tanzania during what they termed as a
"difficult transition period" which had been prompted by
legitimate complaints concerning several management and
supervisory mistakes which cropped up in the running of the justMeanwhile, Tanzania's ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCMRevolution Party) outgoing President Ali Hassan Mwinyi, has urged
concluded General Elections.
the opposition to accept the results of the country's first multiMwinyi, leaving office after 10 years as president made his
party polls for the sake of the maintenance of peace.
appeal on November 7, on state radio at the same time as High
Court judges listened to submissions by 10 opposition parties who
want the parliamentary and presidential elections declared null
and void.

The opposition is supported by the Tanzanian Election
Monitoring Committee (TEMCO) which declared the country's first
multi-party polls as neither free nor fair, an opinion that was
also echoed by the Commonwealth observers group which said the
confusion and chaos that prevailed in the Tanzanian election had
not been experienced in other Commonwealth countries.

The presidential polls were being contested by CCM's Benjamin
Mkapa, Augustine Mrema of the National Convention for Construction
and Reform (NCCR-Mageuzi), Ibrahim Lipumba of the Civic United
Front (CUF) and John Cheyo of the United Democratic Front (UDF).

Elsewhere in Zanzibar, the main opposition, the Civic United
Front (CUF) on November 7 boycotted the opening ceremony of the
new multi-party parliament.

The 24 legislators from the CUF, widely believed to have won
the October 22 multi-party presidential elections stood firm on
their promise that they would not recognize the Salmin A mour-led
CCM government on the island. They refused to take an oath of
allegiance to the revolutionary government of Zanzibar.

While the CUF won 24 seats, the CCM won 26 seats of the 500.4 per cent margin over the CUF candidate.

Africa News


November, 1995


NGO Says Slavery Continues


LENGTH: 854 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)

London/Nairobi - Christian Solidarity International (CSI), a
British non- governmental organisation says slave trade continues
at a brisk pace in Sudan.

Blacks from the South are forcefully seized by Arab raiders
from the north and are despatched as menial and hard labour
workers in Arab households and farmholdings in the north of the
country. Young men and women are often targeted in these raids. 

Christian Solidarity International has on a number of occasions
been forced to buy back slaves after their families pleaded with
the organisation for assistance.

The government of Sudan regularly denies the existence of
slaves in the country but Christian Solidarity recorded a
transaction involving a trader who bought back 22 slaves for 1
million Sudanese pounds(about US dollars 1,818). CSI provided some
of the money and the event was broadcast on the British
Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) programme Focus on Faith.

Focus on Faith reported that a recent raid by Arabs resulted
in the death of two children whose hut was set on fire as they
slept in the village of Nyam Lel in western Barh el Ghaz al. Abuki
Matiar, a blind Dinka woman who survived the raid said on the
night of the attack, panic broke out in the village and she could
here people crying in the night.

"The raiders spoke Arabic. I tried to run but stumbled over a
stool," the blind Abaki said in a translated version. Nearly 300
women and children were seized that night and transported for sale
in the north.

A village administrator of the Sudan People's Liberation Army
(SPLA) named Chok said in the programme: "These raids are
organised by the government of Sudan. They tell their people - you
go and get these people since they are weak now," an allusion to a
string of victories by the government army in the south of the
country in the last three years.

The Catholic Bishop of El Obeid, Bishop Macram Marx Gassis who
is in London told Focus on Faith: "Sudan is the country of
slavery."

The bishop who did not mince his words said the rulers in
Khartoum were always denying the fact. "But in their Holy War or
Jihad they consider it their right to do what they are doing."

Both the Sudanese embassies in London and Nairobi deny the
claim about the slave trade in Sudan, saying the accusation is not
new and had been found to have little merit.

However, the Bishop of Rumbek Diocese, Caesar Mazzolari told
APS that it was good that a lot of evidence is coming out now
because the Sudanese government routinely denies such accusations.
"Now that we have the evidence, the whole world will be able to
help," he noted.

Asked if he subscribed to the practice of buying back the
slaves, Bishop Mazzolari said it was good in the circumstances
because "it restores people back to their families."

Nyam Lel where 300 women were seized in a recent attack is in
Bishop Mazzolari's diocese.

Meanwhile, the army in Uganda's capital, Kampala, has confirmed
the rescue of some 100 children by the SPLA. The children were
expected to be handed over to Uganda Peoples Defence Forces (UPDF)
in Kitgumtown on November 7.

Sources in Uganda say the children, reportedly aged between 6
and 18 years were held in Sudan by rebels of the Lord's Resistance
Army (LRA) of Joseph Kony in exchange for guns. Government
officials say another 300 children believed to be in slavery in
Sudan may not easily return home.
-0Tanzania


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


351 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Yitzhak Rabin: Tribute To A Man Of Peace


LENGTH: 707 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)

Johannesburg - African leaders have paid glowing tribute to the
slain Israeli leader, Yitzhak Rabin, assassinated by a Jewish
fanatic as he left a peace rally in Tel Aviv on November 4.

A lone gunman, Yigal Amir, a 27 year old one-time paratrooper
in the Israeli Army, who was studying law at an Israeli seminary,
shot Rabin at close range on the night of November 4 . He said he
acted "on God's orders." 

Egyptian leader Hosni Mubarak whose own predecessor, President
Anwar Sadat, was mowed down in 1981 by Egyptian fanatics opposed
to the peace deal with Israel, declared at Rabin's funeral on
November 6; "We must continue the long journey; peace is the only
way." Mubarak who was visiting Israel for the first time said he
had a duty to attend the funeral of a great peace maker.

Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi said the death of Rabin "was
not only a loss to Israel but to all those who were committed to
peace in the world."

South African President Nelson Mandela, lamented that like
another great peace maker of our time, Mahatma Gandhi of India who
was gunned down by a Hindu fanatic nearly 50 years a go, Rabin had
been killed by his own people.

Mandela, himself a great peace maker who has been able to bring
blacks and whites together in post-apartheid South Africa, has
been warned by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, that he could be the next
target of assassins.

And following Archbishop Tutu's warning that right wing
fanatics could kill "Mad iba", as Mandela is fondly known at home,
the South African police have announced that they have redoubled
security around Mandela and all the top leaders in the South
African government.

Police would now be on full alert to protect Mandela whose own
relaxed personal lifestyle will now be severely curtailed.

South African Police Chief George Fivaz said there was great
similarity between the Israeli-Palestinian and the South African
peace process. He could not afford to take chances.

"We must learn from the Rabin assassination," he told the
Sowetan newspaper, here.

Meanwhile in Israel, millions wept openly as the late Israeli
leader was laid to rest at the Mount Herzl National Cemetery in
Jerusalem on November 6.

The death of the man who declared that Arabs and Jews had had
enough of the bloodshed between neighbours, has brought out into
the open the festering differences between the secular and
orthodox Jews.

Orthodox Jews considered Rabin a traitor while some secular
Jews said right wing Jewish settlers on Palestinian lands should
not just be evacuated but shot by the Israeli Army instead.

One Israeli said on Internet, an International computer
network; "We should not let the land of milk and honey become the
land of blood and tears."
-0Sudan

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


Church Vows To Fight Rising Crime


LENGTH: 574 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)
Cape Town - Fed up with the escalating crime wave that has hit
the South African province of KwaZulu-Natal, the powerful Rhema
church has said it will join the growing number of institutions
and individuals calling for mass mobilisation against the
spiralling scourge of crime in the region.

This was said by the church's charismatic leader, Ray MacCauley
in Durban recent ly. He said that his church, which enjoys the
support of thousands of people in the country will mobilise South
Africans to press the government to take drastic steps to curb
crime and violence. 

He said: "We need to get a message to the government that
people have had enough of crime and they feel frustrated. The
government has got to admit that crime is out of control."

Rev MacCauley's concern was echoed by police spokesman in the
province, Col. Bal a Naido who said that 123 people were killed in
the week ending November 5 alone, representing a big jump from the
79 people reported killed the week before.

According to police statistics, an alarming 1,200 murders,
1,000 rapes and attempted rapes and 7,000 housebreakings had been
reported in the city of Durban this year.

Meanwhile, Rev MacCauley's effort has been augmented by
concerned citizens who are mobilising to call for the
reintroduction of the death penalty which was repealed this year
in June by the government of Nelson Mandela.

The church leader said that the country needs something drastic
to be done. "We are trying to get the whole country...20 to 30
million people to come together to channel frustrations and convey
their message to the government."

He added that the government did not admit crime was soaring
because this could jeopardise its image abroad.

He said the church would launch the "Stop Crime" campaign soon.
This would be followed by gatherings of South Africans at nine
provincial government offices on November 29 to submit plans to
combat crime.

Short-to-medium term plans include better pay, training and
equipment for the police and stepped up police and army patrols.

Courts should impose tougher sentences, the slow prosecution
system needed to be addressed and the construction of new jails
should be considered.
-0Africa-At-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


353 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Turmoil As Hundreds Die In Fresh Violence


LENGTH: 974 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)

Bujumbura - At least 300 people have died, 42 of them in a
single incident, after new ethnic violence erupted in racially
divided Burundi early November, humanitarian sources and radio
reports said on November 2.

State Radio Burundi said 42 people, including a soldier, were
killed on November 1 in an attack by unknown assailants on a camp
of displaced Tutsi people in Muruta in northern Kayanza province,
which borders Ngozi.

Dozens more were also reported killed across the country in the
previous 24 hours, a humanitarian agency source said.

In the capital Bujumbura, five people were killed and about 10
wounded in unexplained automatic weapon fire and grenade
explosions overnight on November 1, the national radio said. 

The humanitarian source, which sought anonymity said that 147
people had been killed and 26 injured during an operation a week
earlier by the Tutsi-dominated army in the town of Tangara, in
Ngozi province, and dozens more died in ensuing clashes in the
region.

National radio disputed the figure and quoted security sources
saying only 50 people died in the incident in Ngozi province.
However, other estimates put the death toll as high as 250.

In Paris, visiting Burundian President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya
blamed the killi ng in Tangara on 'complicity" between "certain
elements of the army and the displaced," a reference to Burundian
Tutsis displaced from their homes by inter-ethnic clashes that
have torn the central African nation in the last two years.

Ntibantunganya said the death toll from the clashes in Ngozi
province stood at between "50 and 250," but an enquiry was needed
to verify the final toll. Military investigators were to visit the
region on November 2.

"What happened is part of a cycle of violence in the country
over the last two years. It seems that it is part of reprisal
operations that may be the result of an inter-ethnic malaise ,"
Ntibantunganya said.

Still in Paris, President Ntibantunganya appealed to the United
Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO)
to help stop broadcasts by a "pirate radio station" which the
Burundian President said are inciting his country's people to
violence.

Addressing UNESCO's 28th General Conference on October 31,
President Ntibantunganya said the station called Radio Democracy
was promoting murderous hatred in Burundi which has been torn by
ethnic strife.

The Burundian leader told the UNESCO General Conference meeting
at its headquarters in the French capital from October 21 to
November 17 that he remained confident in the future of his
country and reaffirmed his commitment to a culture of development
and to UNESCO's "concept of tolerance, conceived not as charity of
the powerful toward the weak, but as mutual recognition of
different values."

On his part the UNESCO Director-General Mr. Federico Mayor
deplored the ethnic conflicts in Burundi and challenged the
international community "to rise with all possible means and
resources" to the challenge of democratic transition in that
country. He also promised that UNESCO would pledge US dollars
50,000 to help this impoverished central African country locate
the source of the pirate radio broadcasts and try to jam them.

The central African nation of six million people has been torn
by bloody ethnic conflict between the Hutus, who constitute 80 per
cent of the population, and the Tutsi who, despite their small
numbers, traditionally dominate the government and army.

Most of the armed gangs that clash with the army claim to be
part of a military group linked to the Council for the Defence of
Democracy set up last year by former Interior Minister Leonard
Nyangoma.

The group is allegedly linked to the October 1993 abortive coup
in which President Melchior Ndadaye, the country's first
democratically elected president from the Hutu majority, was
killed.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


354 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Donors Pledge $45 Million (US Dollars)


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)

New York - Donor countries have pledged US dollars 145.7
million to support the Liberian peace process. The amount is 4.3
million dollars short of the total requested by West African
leaders.

And the United States alone pledged 75 million dollars - half
of the US 150 dollars requested by leaders of the Economic
Community of West African States (ECOWAS) for disarmament and
demobilisation.

The administration of President Bill Clinton made the
commitment here recently at a donors' conference for Liberia,
organised by the United Nations and African leaders to coincide
with the United Nations 50th Anniversary celebrations. 

Britain, France and other European Union countries also pledged
support for the peace process. The UN made it clear that Liberia
was in worse shape than Rwanda. "I would compare the severity of
the humanitarian crisis in West Africa with both Rwanda and the
former Yugoslavia," UN Under Secretary-General for humanitarian
affairs, Peter Hansen, told the conference.

The UN on October 4, appealed for relief aid for Liberia,
totalling US dollars 110 million and US dollars 14 million for
Sierra Leone. ECOWAS leaders, led by its Chairman President Jerry
Rawlings of Ghana, want US dollars 150 million for disarmament,
encampment and demobilisation of more than 60,000 Liberian militia
fighters.

The Chairman of Liberia's Council of State, Wilton Sankawulo,
has put forward a reconstruction programme of about US dollars 300
million. Meanwhile, back in Liberia, the UN suspended relief
operations in the central part of the country due to harassment of
aid workers by members of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic
Front of Liberia (NPFL).

The fighters are reportedly becoming increasingly lawless and
out of control, and in one recent incident at Taylor's
headquarters at Gbarnga, they are said to have looted a UN
warehouse containing food for 500 orphans. Although the August 26
ceasefire is generally holding, there have been reports of
skirmishes between different factions.

In recent clashes, Taylor said Gbarnga was attacked by fighters
loyal to Alhaji Kromah's United Liberation Movement of Liberia
(ULIMO) factions and a week of fighting ensued before they were
repulsed, but Kromah denied the allegations. However, a British
Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) reporter, who toured the area, was
shown several identity cards and headless bodies of ULIMO
fighters. He quoted NPFL commanders as saying, retreating ULIMO
fighters severed the heads of their colleagues to conceal their
identity.

Meanwhile, reports from Monrovia say Taylor and Kromah met last
week to iron out differences following a scuffle between their
bodyguards at Monrovia's Executive Mansion (State House). They
also ordered their men to halt fighting at the contentious St Paul
River Bridge, separating Bong and Lofa counties in Central
Liberia. Both men are vice chairmen on the State Council.

Taylor has called for the swift deployment in the area of the
ECOMOG West Africa n intervention force. Relief workers say they
will return to central Liberia only after the deployment of ECOMOG
troops.

In a separate development, a member of a team of journalists
who visited the town of Tapeta in the NPFL stronghold of Nimba
County, has confirmed that 75 people died in a massacre that
occurred there on September 27. The local reporter said most of
the town's inhabitants have fled into surrounding villages
following the killings.

The incident occurred on a market day -- when the town is
normally crowded - following an argument between NPFL fighters and
some residents, which resulted in the fighters opening fire
indiscriminately. Most of the town's now teeming population is
made up of refugees from regions considered to be hostile to the
NPFL.

Politicians from the area have called for the rapid deployment
of ECOMOG troops to stamp out lawlessness. At the same time,
Taylor's deputy, Major-General Enoch Dogolea, has apologised for
the killings and said those responsible have been arrested and
will face a court martial. "Anyone found guilty will be executed
immediately. This nonsense must be stopped," he told reporters. It
is not clear whether the State Council will sanction such
unilateral action by the NPFL.
-0Burundi


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


355 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Dutch Reformed Church Unity Talks Coming


LENGTH: 640 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)

Durban - In a bid to hasten the process of unification in the
racially divided Dutch Reformed Church (DRC) in South Africa, the
mainly white DRC was expected to meet its sister churches on
November 9.

According to press reports, the slow rate of progress in
uniting the church has seen this major grouping lag behind other
church groups which have recently tied their racial knot.

Two years ago the "coloured" (mixed race) and African (black)
branches of the church merged to form the Uniting Reformed Church
of Southern Africa, but several pockets of the church have
resisted the move, with many stating that they want to join the
white church. 

The reports say that within the white church itself, there is
resistance to some of the aspects of unity, including that some
white members would not like to be part of a non-racial, united
church.

In terms of synod decisions in the Dutch Reformed Church, a
regional synod has been held in all of the church's 11 regions.
Among the issues discussed was the question of unity.

According to Rev Willie Botha, who is responsible for
coordinating the unity discussion in his church, members are
largely in favour of unity but express problems with one of the
more important issues in the whole discussion: the Belhar
Confession.

The Belhar Confession was adopted by the Coloured Dutch
Reformed Mission Church during the height of apartheid. It express
the pain suffered during the time and encapsulates the deep-seated
religious revulsion felt for the system of oppression inflicted by
the system of apartheid.

The Uniting Church has declared that unless this confession is
adopted as a full confession by a new church which will
incorporate the DRC, the talks will come to an end.

The press reports say it remains a stumbling block, with almost
all of the 11 synods within the white church stating their
opposition to it being incorporated into a new church order as a
full confession.

At the same time, say the reports, some members are prepared to
see it as a "statement" adopted by the church, while others are
bitterly opposed to its incorporation anywhere in the new church
order.

The meeting was also likely to discuss church property and
finances. This includes the question of pensions in a situation in
which racially differentiated churches mean white clergy receive
more money than black clergy.
-0Liberia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


356 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Condom Campaign Angers Uganda's Catholic Archbishop


LENGTH: 2054 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)
by Kidji Nduku

Nairobi - As the campaign against the spread of AIDS continues
in Uganda, custodians of morality are concerned about
advertisements promoting the choice of condoms as a means of
protection against the human immuno deficiency virus (HIV). The
head of the Catholic Church in this East African country is not
amused by such adverts.

The head of the Catholic Church in Uganda Archbishop Emmanuel
Wamala is an angry man. He is incensed by commercials carried by
the media and the Ministry of Health roadside and strategicallypick from in order to be protected against the Acquired Immune
placed billboards, advertising condoms as one of the options to
Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).

In his anger, Cardinal Wamala has harshly criticised health
officials and the business community for promoting and 'peddling';
condoms as an effective means of preventing the rampaging AIDS
scourge in the country. 

While the Ministry of Health billboards give two other options,
faithfulness and abstinence, a private firm advertises condoms of
a brand name 'Protector' as the "surest way for a modern person to
beat AIDS". The commercials have rekindled a debate on condoms as
a means to fight the spread of AIDS and morality in Uganda.

AIDS was first identified in the country in 1982 in Rakai
District, western Uganda. Today, about 10 per cent of the 17
million Ugandans are said to be infected with the human immunoAccording to the HIV/AIDS surveillance report of the Uganda
deficiency virus (HIV) which causes AIDS.
AIDS Commission, released in March 1995, by December 1994, there
were 46,120 AIDS cases, out of whom 42,437 representing 92 per
cent, were adults above 12 years of age. Out of that number, there
were 19,638 males (47.3 per cent), while 21,921 were female (51.7
per cent).

The multi-sectoral AIDS control approach on population based
studies, indicate that women have shown a much higher rate of HIV
infection than men, AIDS affects women in a special way.

In order to fight the spread of AIDS, the government tacitly
approved the widespread use of condoms and back in 1991, the
government-owned daily, New Vision, ran several advertisements of
condoms. However, the Church, particularly the Catholic Church
protested to President Yoweri Museveni and the advertisers
withdrew their campaign.

However, it is believed in some circles that a staunch
supporter of Museveni, Rev. Misareri Kavuma, the retired Bishop of
Church of Uganda Namirembe Cathedral in Kampala, did not take up
the chairmanship of Uganda AIDS Commission due to the condoms
issue. He was appointed about two years ago.

This time round, apart from New Vision, the two private radio
stations FM capital and Sanyu' State-owned Radio Uganda and Uganda
Television are carrying commercials talking boldly about condoms.
One commercial even portrays the HIV virus inside a condom with
the user about to throw it away in a latrine, lamenting how it is
going to die instead of being hosted by a human being.

It is this particular commercial which many have found
tasteless, in fact disgusting. In a letter to the Editor of New
Vision, Peter Oporia narrates a story of his young son who after
hearing the commercial on the radio asked what condo/kondo (thief)
was and was slapped by an elder sister. "Condoms cause problems
and promote immorality," Oporia sums up the condoms issue.

Michael Kizito a secondary school student and a committed
Christian asks how a parent can give a child a condom as a weapon
against AIDS, as it is being suggested especially by government
officials and advertisers of condoms. He instead suggests the
teaching of morals as condoms are not foolproof. "We young people
should shun what some leaders and parents are telling us as far as
using condoms is concerned."

Kizito is silent on sex education in schools which the
government had started but was opposed mainly by the Catholic
Church. Despite the positive press reviews of the programme, there
is still a debate on sex education. Initially, parents accepted it
when people feared the AIDS epidemic but not any more, as they do
not see why their children should be introduced to maturity by
teachers.

Cardinal Wamala, being a Catholic does not advocate the usage
of condoms but the change of sexual attitude among the people of
Uganda. Ugandans should not be deceived that the use of condoms
would save their lives when they continue to engage in immoral
sexual habits."

He laments that although the country had acquired a favourable
image abroad on the political front, it had an ugly image as far
as the AIDS scourge is concerned. "This is alarming. When you go
abroad people no longer refer to Uganda as the country of dictator
Idi Amin (former president) but as a country which is suffering a
lot under the AIDS killer disease."

He says he will never give up his call for strong family values
and the appeal to people to turn to God as their saviour from such
irresponsible sexual behaviour. Like Kizito, the Archbishop does
not address the problem of the youth and sex.

A Kampala private practitioner Dr. John Worst Kimbowa concedes
that condoms are being used as the main weapon against HIV, a
virus which causes AIDS, together with health education and clean
syringes. "Indeed with such a three-pronged thrust, health workers
in the United States of America too have managed to bring down the
incidence among homosexuals."

So, health workers everywhere have gone out to utilise those
means especially cndoms. In Uganda, says Dr. Kimbowa, the players
are mainly the Uganda AIDS Commission, individual organisations,
many non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and businessmen.

He says that all these advertise, but "Protector" is purely a
business venture. "Somebody brought it and distributed to all
shops. But individual programmes also bring in condoms and
distribute them free of charge."

Dr. Kimbowa views the condom as a harmless gadget without any
medical side effects "but, there is a catch, the user has to be
well motivated to use it and must have some basic idea of micro
biology to understand how it works."

He notes that those who claim to use condoms have failed to
apply this contraceptive method continuously,saying this is lack
of knowledge. He does not object to the advertisements but says
the content should be more explicit or else one gets poor results.
In retrospect he says, nowhere in the world where condoms have
been used to fight the spread of AIDS, "have we seen the incidence
going down except in the homosexual community referred to
earlier."

But since condoms are available and there is no alternative at
the moment, "let us use them." He however believes that the most
effective preventive measure and yet cost free is the fear of
death.

He says that fear has had a tremendous impact and adds, "we no
longer see gonorrhoea even among students as we did before, lodges
are empty. These days I see 20 people a day without any case of
gonorrhoea but before on Mondays, a doctor would see about 10. The
trend today is one wife and a steady girlfriend, and women don't
venture out like men."

Dr. Kimbowa believes that Uganda has gone through the worst
times as far as the AIDS pandemic is concerned. He says this East
African country is on a plateau of AIDS and laments the continued
loss of the working age group which he says could lead to a
shortage of workers. "But on the other hand, there is unemployment
and therefore that cancels out," he adds.

Dr. Kimbowa decries the increase in dependency due to the high
number of orphans in the country. "This has led to more
implications, that is why we have an increasing number of street
children," he argues.

But Josephine Kalule of Organisation AIDS Information Centre
does not share Dr. Kimbowa's optimism. She says fear of death is
no deterrent. "We see more and more young people who are HIV
positive," she notes.

The centre, a non-governmental organisation started in 1990
provides free, voluntary and anonymous HIV test (the open market
fee is an equivalent of US $6, prohibitive to the ordinary
Ugandan), health education, counselling and creates public
awareness. It further provides ongoing support to clients in order
to help their psychological and social adjustment and to promote
behavioural change.

Kalule is bailed out by the Uganda AIDS Commission whose report
stresses "the figures are not accurate and do not represent a
complete picture of HIV(AIDS in Uganda. Epidemiologist in the
country believe the number of cases reported represent as little
as 15 to 20 per cent of the actual number of cases in the
country."
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


357 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Church Group Says Reconciliation Can Heal


LENGTH: 1534 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)
by Sam Gonza

Nairobi - The peace process in Angola that was ushered in by
the Lusaka accord of November 1994 remains fraught with many
problems. A Canadian Church/Peace organisation report says if the
will to reconcile is there, much of the tragedy that is synonymous
with this southern African country following 19 years of civil
war, would be a thing of the past)

Last September 25, the two leaders in Angola's long running
civil war happily sat side by side at the donors meeting in
Brussels, Belgium and made a firm promise to the world - that they
would fully support the one-year old peace process in Angola.

Jonas Savimbi, the leader of the Union for the Total
Independence of Angola (UNI TA), promised that he would never
again resort to the use of arms to solve the problems of Angola.

President Eduardo Dos Santos of the ruling Popular Movement for
the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) said rehabilitation of Angola's
war-devastated economy and infrastructure should be a priority for
the peace settlement reached in Lusaka, Zambia, in November 1994,
between the government and Savimbi's UNITA. 

Unsure that donors would be well disposed towards Angola, where
war flared afresh after the general elections of September 1992,
Dos Santos called for money to be channelled into reconstruction
projects, not handed over in cash.

At the donors meeting, the United Nations Development
Programme, (UNDP) presented a US $700 million programme for
rehabilitation and development. At the end of the meet ing on
September 26, the donor community pledged to give Angola US $800
million.

However, despite an immense amount of international goodwill
and the fact that the Angolan people "are very tired of war,
suffering and restrictions" a lot will need to happen on the
ground in Angola if this country is to achieve a lasting solution
to her peace process.

This is the message of a delegation from the Inter Church
Coalition in Africa (ICCA), an affiliate of the Canadian Council
of Churches who recently visited Angola on a fact finding mission.

Their report focuses on the city of Malanje a potential flash
point area in northern Angola, 80 per cent of which is controlled
by UNITA. The team also visited Bailundo in South Western Angola.
The report of their findings is written by John Kirkwood, a human
rights volunteer with ICCA.

"While the ceasefire has largely held since the November (1994)
signing of the Lusaka Accord, one gets the feeling that this could
be broken at any time, and that a spark here or there might set
off a larger conflagration," asserts Kirkwood.

The observation that the peace process in Angola remains
fragile, is underscored by the seizure last month by UNITA rebels,
of a group of South Africans working at a mining project in the
north of the country. UNITA alleges that the men are mercenaries
working with the South African Executive Outcomes Company.

Kirkwood raises concern about the leadership of the Armed
Forces of Angola (FAA) , the government army who perceived
themselves to be winning the war by November 1994, and have
massively rearmed since.

Most of the countryside around Malanje is UNITA territory. The
two sides have drawn back from battle lines and now face each
other across a 10-20 kilometre strip of "no man's land." Free
passage here is very risky but the non-governmental organisations
(NGOs) and the United Nations are the only ones doing this
(crossing the strip).

"In Malanje, very few NGOs are set up in UNITA territory,
fearing a repeat of the confiscation of vehicles and supplies in
the event of another outbreak of hostilities as happened after the
elections in 1992.

The Lusaka Accord demands that all UNITA troops be disarmed and
housed in quartering camps until they are either demobilised or
recruited into the new national army. It also requires government
troops to be confined to barracks.

By mid-September, around Malanje and Bailundo in the southwest
of the country, reports Kirkwood, "neither side had wanted to be
first to observe this stipulation of the accord though more
pressure seems to be on UNITA , and they are making signs of
movement."

And while they begin to cooperate, UNITA are also demanding
that the Special Mobile Police be disarmed as well. "Most UNITA
civilian supporters were killed by the Mobile Police in late
November 1992 and into 1993 in many government held cities
following UNITA's overrunning of large chunks of territory after
they lost the last elections."

Kirkwood says the United Nations peacekeeping mission to
Angola, UNAVEM, seems determined to do things correctly this time
round in order to avoid the tragic events of three years ago.
"There is determination by the United Nations that demobilisation
will be more completely done before the next steps are taken - the
formation of the national army and government of national unity.
The Canadian international peace worker believes the 7,000 UNAVEM
troops now being assembled will have a better chance to accomplish
the task ahead than did the meagre 400 blue helmets in 1992 .

Right now, with the coming of the rains in October/November the
urgent need is for tools and seeds to plant.

The Lutheran World Federation (LWF) Christian Action in Angola
and other aid agencies continue to make aid available, mainly
through Christian congregations as the instruments of assistance
to the community.

Roofing sheets are very urgently needed for rebuilding houses
now that the rain season is at hand.

Distribution of aid in UNITA areas is fraught with more
problems. "Yet it is in UNITA areas that people need to receive at
least some initial fruits of peace and thus develop some minimal
confidence in the peace process," observes the report.

Kirkwood reports further that many displaced people in or near
Malanje city would like to return to their villages but most are
situated within UNITA control. A woman said some women were
attacked when they went towards the UNITA "border" in search of
cassava.

Kirkwood is convinced that Angola will enjoy peace only if
there is the political will to reconcile and share power at top
levels in the two rival parties because the common people are
"very tired of war and its implication. Otherwise the stand-off
between the two warring parties will continue because of the
atrocities that were committed on both sides.
-0Uganda


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

358 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Military Tricksters That Never Give Up


LENGTH: 2507 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 13, 1995 (19951113)
by Nernlor Gruduah

Nairobi - Nigeria is one of the countries featured prominently
at the Commonwealth Heads of State and Government Summit which
opened on November 9 in Auckland, Newzealand. Opposition parties
from former coloniser Britain, have called for sanctions against
this West African country whose military rule and entire
democratic process have come under heavy criticism from the
international community. The October 30 death sentence passed on
54 year-old leader of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni
People (MOSOP) Ken Saro-Wiwa, only complicates the case for
Africa's most populous nation.)

It appears there is no shortage of military tricksters in
Nigeria. Considering it is now 35 years since the country gained
independence from Britain, perhaps more than 70 per cent of its
population of over 100 million have been born and bred under
military dictatorship. 

Their contact with democracy has only been a glimpse, not more.
There have actually been two short-lived civilian administrations
in Nigeria's entire history. The First Republic following
independence ruled from 1960 to 1966, when the then federal Prime
Minister Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa, was assassinated, together
with several government officials in a military coup. The Second
Republic (1979- 83), led by Alhaji Shehu Shagari, was ended when
Maj. Gen. Muhammed Buhari seized power in a bloodless coup in
December 31, 1983.

For the most part, democracy has remained largely a dream in
the continent's most populous state, and some have come to the
conclusion that Nigeria is synonymous with militarism in Africa.
Most theatrical amongst the military tacticians in recent Nigerian
history have been Generals Ibrahim Babangida and Sani Abacha.

Babangida earned the nickname, "Maradona" for his ability to
manoeuvre in playing on the psychology of Nigerians and the former
strongman led the international community by the nose from 1985 to
1993 until he reached the end of his thither.

When he deposed Bahari (also in a peaceful coup) in August
1985, Babangida promised a seven-year transitional period and a
return to democratic rule in October 1992. Among the conditions
set by the Babangida regime for a return to civilian rule was the
disqualification of all politicians who participated in previous
administrations from standing in the proposed elections.

The military also struck off all existing political parties and
created two new parties, the Social Democratic Party (SDP) and the
National Republican Convention (NRC), which immediately absorbed
the familiar North-South political divide. Although leaders of
both parties had sort of transposed positions to conceal this
division, the obvious was the case. While the SDP received most
support from the south, NRC was boosted by northerners. Meanwhile,
the ban on former politicians was later lifted.

But as the October deadline approached, uncertainty set in as
Babangida postponed the hand-over date to January 2, 1993, arguing
that electoral malpractices and disputes resulting from state
elections needed to be sorted out before presidential elections
could be held. A combination of other delaying tactics was
introduced, including legislation empowering the National
Electoral Commission (NEC) to disqualify any candidate considered
to be unfit.

The process dragged on until June 12, 1993, when the
presidential elections were finally held, pitting SDP candidate
Bashorun Moshood K.O. Abiola, a southerner, against NRC candidate,
Alhaji Bashir Othman Tofa, from the north. Independent observers
described the polls as the most democratic in Nigeria's history.
Midway through counting, Abiola was said to be well in the lead
and headed for a landslide. But, alas, Nigerians were in for a
typical comedy: the military cancelled the results, claiming there
were irregularities, plunging the country deeper into yet more
political turmoil.

Tensions, coupled with international pressure, boiled to the
brink, forcing Babangida to cede power to an "interim government"
led by Chief Ernest Shonekan, who also refused to announce the
results of the elections. He was seen by critics as Babangida's
face in disguise. Life was not any better for Shonekan, as Nigeria
was rocked by a series of riots and strikes in support of Abiola.

In the midst of the chaos, another surprise package emerged.
Babangida's former Defence Minister, General Sani Abacha, wrested
power from Shonekan in November 1993, to "save Nigeria from
further disaster." A man considered to be behind a handful of
previous military coups, Abacha also defied Nigerians and the
international community by refusing to validate the June 12 el
ection results, but instead set up a "national conference" to draw
up a new constitution.

He soon began a crackdown on opposition and the media to
consolidate his hold on power. Venting his frustration at the
continued military intransigence, Chief Abiola declared himself
President to mark the anniversary of the annulled elections - some
say he took the matter into his own hands. He was subsequently
arrested and charged with treason. The trial was on, off and is
still off. The United States and the European Union responded with
limited sanctions, calling on Abacha to step down and restore
democracy.

Going by recent developments, it seems Abacha is the craftiest
of military dictators Nigeria has ever produced. He displayed a
melodramatic subtlety that threw the international community into
a chasm. When he realised pressure from within and outside over
the unconditional release of Abiola had reached its peak, Abacha
announced the foiling of what, analysts say, appeared to be a well
thoughtout, concocted coup plot against his government.

The coup attempt allegedly uncovered in March involved 40
military officers and civilians, including outspoken former
military Head of State, retired General Olusegun Obasanjo. Thus
Abacha effectively diverted the focus of attention and put a gag
in the clamor for Abiola's release. Not only is Obasanjo the only
former military ruler to have handed power peacefully to a
civilian administration, but he has been at the forefront of the
current campaign against prolonged military rule.

Nigeria's 26-member Provisional Ruling Council (PRC) tried the
alleged coup plotters in secret, convicted and presumably
sentenced them to death by firing squad, provoking international
outrage. The Head of State used the men as a bargaining chip amid
widespread criticism of total disregard for international norms
and the rule of law. The regime promised to pardon the convicts in
return for Britain assistance on debt, diplomacy and transition to
civilian rule. But a team that investigated human right abuses in
the country in July called on Britain and other Commonwealth
countries to apply comprehensive sanctions.

"By almost every human rights criterion, Nigerians are excluded
from the guarantees which any Commonwealth citizen expects," says
the group. Commonwealth countries were urged to stop all but
humanitarian aid to Nigeria, including military cooperation and
deny visas to Nigerian officials. And the November Commonwealth
summit in Auckland, New Zealand, has been asked to press Nigeria
to release all political prisoners or face sanctions, including an
embargo on vital oil exports.

In spite of the barrage of strong rebuke, Abacha looks unmoved
as demonstrated in his independence day address on October 1.
Going back on his earlier promise to hand over power by 1996, he
said the military would rule until 1998, but quickly diluted the
anger provoked by the announcement by commuting the death
sentences of 40 convicted coup plotters.

Originally sentences on the 40 were never made public, but
Obasanjo was believed to have been jailed for life while his
former deputy Shehu Musa Yar'Adua and others received death
sentences.

In its latest pronouncement, the military government sentenced
Obasanjo to 15 years, while Yar'Adua got 25 years. The planned
return to civilian rule did not go down well with Nigeria's Nobel
Laureate, Professor Wole Soyinka, who cast doubt on the programme
and dismissed Abacha as "a congenital liar."

The main opposition group, NADECO, was downright in its
rejection of the turn-over date: "The National Democratic
Coalition (NADECO) rejects in its entirety the purported
transition programme deceptively slated to last for three years
but in reality of indefinite duration ."

Said Michael Ajasin, Chairman of NADECO, in a statement: "The
programme contains several provisions designed to make it
indefinitely elastic." However, Abacha came back with counter
punches, telling Nigerians there was no need to complain because a
three-year transition was not too long. "The political programme
itself is out and we believe this is the minimum time we need
because our major problem as a nation is not politics itself. Our
major problem as a nation is the socio-economic aspect."

The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural
Organisation has also joined those voicing their protest against
political developments in Nigeria. UNESCO Director-General
Federico Mayor on November 6 wrote to military ruler General Sani
Abacha to express his concern over the death sentence passed on
writer and minority rights leader Ken Saro-Wiwa. During UNESCO's
28th General Conference, October 21 to November 17, at the
organisation's headquarters in Paris, Mr. Mayor reminded Nigeria
of its obligations as a United Nations member.

The UN Under-Secretary told Nigerian Head of State; "... I
wish to lay stress on the importance that the Member States of
UNESCO have attached to the promotion of tolerance, democratic
values and human rights ever since the founding of the
organisation 50 years ago."

Mr. Mayor particularly singled out the Recommendation
Concerning the Status of the Artist which Nigeria, a UNESCO member
had adopted. This recommendation affirms that artists are to be
accorded protection by international and national legislation on
human rights. The promotion of a culture of peace was a top
priority of UNESCO's bi-annual conference which also coincided
with the UN golden jubilee celebrations.

The UNESCO Director-General also noted that by participating in
United Nations peace-keeping operations, Nigeria is playing an
important role at the international level and especially in
Africa, in favour of a culture of peace "which depends essentially
on tolerance, respect for human rights and democracy."

Mr. Mayor's latest letter is a follow-up to an initial one sent
to General Abacha at the start of the trial last January. UNESCO
officially questioned Nigeria's permanent delegation about the
matter on October 30.

In view of Abacha's determination to hold his countrymen to
ransom, one wonders how long the world will sit and watch Nigeria
slide into a catastrophe of monumental proportions in a continent
that has already had more than enough bleeding.
-0Angola


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


359 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


President's Remarks on Rwanda Tribunal Criticized


LENGTH: 1240 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Nairobi - The Kenya government's stand on the UN established
War Tribunal to prosecute perpetrators of last years's genocide in
Rwanda has elicited scathing criticisms from various groups, among
them, the tribunal judge Justice Richard Goldstone, the Viceopposition Members of Parliament.
President of Rwanda Major-General Paul Kagame and Kenya's

Reacting sharply to a statement by President Moi to the effect
that Kenya would not extradite Rwandese suspected of committing
the genocide in their country unless those responsible for the
root cause of the ethnic killings are also brought to book, MajorRwanda's problems.
General Kagame said the Kenyan leader was not well placed to solve

Major Kagame, who is also his country's Minister for Defence
alleged that President Moi shared all sorts of things with the
Hutu killers wanted in Tanzania to answer charges of Rwanda
genocide.

The Rwanda VP drew comparison between Kenya's ethnic clashes
between 1991 and 1993 in which hundreds of people were killed with
last years' killings in Rwanda and said the two were similar. 

He said if President Moi wanted to get the truth about the
shooting down of the plane in which President Juvenal Habyariamana
of Rwanda and Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi were killed, then he
should look to France and not Rwanda as the evidence material had
been carried to France.

Justice Goldstone on his part wrote to President Moi to clarify
his October 4 comments on the UN War Tribunal on Rwanda's
genocide. The South African judge warned that President Moi would
be breaking international law if the Kenyan government arrested
any of the UN appointed war tribunal members.

Commenting on the same issue, the British High Commission said
that those responsible for the Rwanda killings should face justice
but not by seeking refuge abroad.

Ms. Gillian Uuilson speaking for the British High Commissioner
to Kenya noted that those who participated in the genocide acts in
Rwanda should be held individually responsible for their deeds.

Members of Kenya's opposition parties who reacted to Moi's
stand, among them lawyer Paul Muite, dismissed the president's
utterances on Rwanda's genocide. Muite said that it was not right
for President Moi to allow his personal friendship with the late
Habyarimana to prejudice Kenya's international foreign relations.
He further argued that it appeared as if Kenya' s foreign policy
was based on personal friendships rather than national interest.

Muite, a member of the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy Rwandese criminals sought by the UN Security Council to stand
Kenya (FORD-K) went even further to say he had evidence that the
trial for genocide were staying in a residential estate in
Nairobi.

Another opposition MP Mwai Kibaki of the Democratic Party (DP)
who is also a former Vice President in Moi's government, denounced
the president's stand on the war tribunal as illegal, adding that
if the suspected criminals were living in Kenya, then they should
appear before the tribunal for judgement.

The International Federation for the Rights of Man in Paris in
its condemnation of Moi's statement, noted that for the first
time, a head of state which is a member of the United N ations had
allowed himself to undermine the authority of the international
tribunal set up to try those responsible for the genocide and
crimes against humanity.

The criticisms were triggered by a statement made by the Kenyan
leader on October 4, 1995 while officially opening this year's
Nairobi International Show to the effect that Kenya would not hand
over any Rwandese to the international war tribunal to answer
charges of genocide, since the UN Tribunal had not first
investigated the longstanding crisis preceding the killing of the
Rwandan and Burundian presidents.

Moi said that although Kenya was a signatory to the UN
convention, it would not accept partial application of the
charter. Moi insisted that it was important for the UN to go
beyond the genocide which arose from the killing of the two
presidents last April.

He particularly observed that prior to the shooting of the
aircraft in which the two heads of state died, there were
invasions of Rwanda and many people had been killed. Moi said the
UN should therefore have in its terms of reference the reasons
for these invasions and not just concentrate on the genocide.

The Kenyan Head of State denied he was covering criminals from
facing justice. In a somehow softer tone, he said he was not
against the tribunal set up by the UN as Kenya was neither proAnd Kenya's Attorney General Amos Wako said the government was
Hutu nor pro- Tutsi.
not opposed to the extradition of those involved in the genocide
and pointed out that Kenya would not shelter any suspect.

"No country can hide such suspects. But everything has to be
dealt with in the normal way," said Mr. Wako, adding that all the
president wanted was a comprehensive solution to the problem.

President Moi's view on the UN War Tribunal has since been
supported by among others mainly from his ruling Kenya African
National Union (KANU) party, his Minister for Education, Mr.
Joseph Kamotho.
-0Nigeria

Africa News


November, 1995


New Religious Tension Mounts


LENGTH: 974 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Accra - Tension is rising between Christians and Muslims in
Ghana following a series of religious clashes across the West
African nation in the recent past.

According to reports compiled here in October, inter-faith
clashes have occurred this year not only in Sekondi, 180
kilometres west of the capital, Accra, but also in the country's
second-largest city of Kumasi, 200 kilometres northwest of the
capital.

In Sekondi, a city of 220,000, an evangelist who converted from
Islam said he had been forced into hiding after an attack and
death threats for undertaking a mission "to preach Jesus Christ to
Muslims."

Abdramane Christian Asare claimed he had been forced to go
underground after an attack in July led by Muslim youths accusing
him of apostasy and said: "As they charged on us they were
shouting that I should be killed." 

In early September, a dispute over the appointment of a new
Muslim chief led to fighting in which 12 people were injured in
Dawa, 65 kilometres east of Accra.

Members of both faiths regularly fuel animosity through audio
cassettes containing derogatory remarks about each other's
prophets, Christ or Mohammed -- and which were played so often on
state-owned buses that in March last year the corporation
specifically banned their use. However, they are still often
played by both Muslim and Christian preachers on private public
address systems set up in public places.

The attack on Asare took place in Sekondi during an open-air
"crusade" by Asare 's Christ for the Muslim World Organisation,
with the preacher pointing out that many Muslims regard apostasy
as an offence punishable by death, unless the person concerned
changed his or her mind within three days.

Another prominent Sekondi minister Daniel Agyare has accused
the authorities of lack of interest in the evangelist's plight,
charging: "At the police station after the attack, we had the
impression that the Muslims had a blank cheque to do whatever they
wanted. Even at the police station they threatened to behead
Asare."

Agyare warned that Christian youths in Sekondi were now arming
themselves to resist any further attacks, and pointed out that
freedom of religion and association were both guaranteed under
Ghana's 1992 Constitution.

Local Muslim youths have vowed that they will attack Asare as
long as he continues to "insult and attack Muslims in his
preaching."

Muslim elders have, however, been more conciliatory, offering
to pay for the damage in July's attack estimated to have been 11.5
million cedis (about US dollars 10,000) in a bid to get the matter
settled out of court.

In recent years, Ghana has seen a series of religious and
ethnic disputes, the most serious of which were clashes in the
northeast of the country around Tamale, 420 kilometres north of
Accra.

Fighting between ethnic Konkombas and their traditional
overlords, the Dagombas plus allied Nanumbas and Gonjas left an
official death toll of over 2,000 in February last year. A second
round of fighting there in March this year officially left 129
dead.

Although the dispute then largely centred on land rights, the
rivalries had been made worse by the fact the Dagombas are
traditionally Muslim, while many Konkombas are animist.

Inter-Muslim clashes over doctrinal disputes have also occurred
this year both in Kumas and in Wenchi, 310 kilometres northwest of
here.

Last August, two people died and six were injured in such
renewed religious fighting between Muslim sects in the provincial
town of Wenchi following the arrest of a leading member of a
traditional Muslim group.

Orthodox Muslims had suspected that his arrest had been due to
information given by the rival Al- Sunna reformist sect.
-0Kenya


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


361 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


New Constitution Curtails Presidential Powers


LENGTH: 867 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Kampala - Uganda announced a new Constitution in October at a
colourful ceremony attended by President Yoweri Museveni and his
guest, Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia.

The new Constitution reflects Uganda's past experience with
tyrannical regimes. Consequently it has sought to limit the
concentration of power in the hands of the presidency. For
example, major appointments to public office will now be ratified
by Parliament which will also regulate itself independently of the
executive. 

The new constitution and the occasion marking its promulgation
were blessed by leaders of various religious faiths, among them
Cardinal Emmanuel Wamala of the Catholic Church, Archbishop
Livingstone Nkoyooyo of the Anglican Church (Church of Uganda)
Theodorous Nankyama of the Orthodox Church and Muslim leader
Sheikh Saad Luwemba.

Uganda's new Constitution is the outcome of more than a year
and a half of deliberations by over 285 Constituent Assembly
Delegates (CADs), members of the Constituent Assembly (CA) who
were elected countrywide.

With the promulgation of the new Constitution, the CADs' tenure
as people's representatives has effectively come to an end. The
Constituent Assembly was duly dissolved the same day. Uganda will
hold presidential and parliamentary elections before June next
year.

James Wapakabulo who was chairman of the Constituent Assembly
read the promulgation declaration on behalf of all CADs. But
federalists in Uganda want to see greater power devolved to
traditional kingdoms as was the case under the 1962 Constitution
which former President Milton Obote abrogated unilaterally in
1966.

Under the stipulations of the new Constitution, Ugandan
aspirants to elective office will operate or organise
individually, avoiding a party-style system of democracy for the
next five years. At the end of five years, there will be a
referendum through which voters will determine if the country
should return to party-style democracy or any other representative
system including independents or a mass movement system such as
the National Resistance Movement of (NRM) President Yoweri
Museveni.

Because corruption has been the bane of all Uganda's regimes in
the past including the current one of Museveni, the new document
stipulates that Parliament will have absolute control over public
funds.

The new Constitution spells out radical innovations in the
judiciary. The Chief Justice will no longer be head of the
Judicial Service Commission. This means the Chief Justice will
spend less time on purely administrative matters.

Traditional rulers and the limits of their jurisdiction are
clearly stated in the new Constitution that has eradicated the
decree that abolished them 30 years ago. Federalists in Uganda,
particularly in the populous central region of Buganda, want to
see much more power returned to the old kingdoms.

Speaking at the launching ceremony, Museveni said the new
Constitution had ended the spate of "jungle rule" which he says
characterised the administrations of Obote and Idi Amin. He said
he was happy to have accomplished the goal he set when he came to
power ten years ago -- to return Uganda to constitutional rule.

"The Constitution has restored what Obote took away from our
people, enfranchising the people of Uganda. At the same time power
has been decentralised from the centre to the regions, correcting
the distortions made by Obote in 1966," added Museveni.
-0Ghana


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


362 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Youth Unemployment at 2.5 Million


LENGTH: 467 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 16, 1995 (19951116)
by Sipo Kapumba

Lusaka - There are more than 2.5 million unemployed youths in
Zambia, child, youth and sports minister Patrick Kafumukache told
parliament yesterday. Kafumukache revealed the figure during his
contribution to a motion for the adoption of a report of the
committee on women, youth and child development. 

The motion was earlier moved by Kanyama MMD MP Nakatindi Wina.
He said as part of the government's efforts to solve the problem
it had mobilised money from the World Bank for funding of youth
projects starting next year.

Seconding the motion, Kapoche UNIP MP Rev Ben Zulu told the
house that the youth in the country were "worse off " because the
government has abandoned many projects initially started by the
UNIP government. The report was adopted unanimously. And deputy
finance minister Paul Tembo said about K222.48 billion has been
collected between May and September this year by the Zambia
Revenue Authority.

He said K8.98 billion was contributed by government departments
while K213.50 was from the private sector. Tembo was answering a
question from Kafue MMD MP Yusuf Badat who wanted to know how much
ZRA collected between May and September.

Tembo also revealed that Zambia earned about $324.9 million
from traditional exports of copper and cobalt exports between May
and September this year while it earned $95.1 in the same period
from non-traditional exports.

Between January and April this year, $324.9 was earned from
traditional exports while $53.9 was from non-traditional ones.
Tembo said the government accorded high priority to giving
exporters incentives and promotion of non-traditional exports
through reduction of export formalities and encouraging foreign
exchange retention.
-0Uganda
