Africa News


November, 1995


Soccer: Nigeria Out, Zimbabwe Challenges


LENGTH: 1200 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Lungile Madywabe

Johannesburg - Political turmoil in Africa has for a long time
undermined the continent's ability to fullfil its potential in
world sport, especially the world's number one, soccer, and the
South African Football Association (Safa) decision to withdraw
Nigeria's participation in the annual Simb Four Nations tournament
again throws football in Africa into a state of confusion.

Tournaments of this nature are important because they not only
strengthen our African ties but also test our weaknessess.
Nigeria, currently ranked six and 35 respectively in African and
world football, would have brought their experience in
international competition with them.

Nigeria's status in the finals of the African Nations Cup next
year stays the same until the Confederation of African Football
(CAF) rules otherwise. South Africa cannot refuse them entry if
CAF has not expelled them from the competiton. However, a
difficult problem would arise if any of the 16 finalists refuse to
play Nigeria. 

Nigeria's replacements Zimbabwe are also seasoned campaigners
in international football. When South Africa was re-admitted into
international football in 1992 they were beaten 4-1 by Zimbabwe in
Harare. The secretary general of the Zimbabwe Football Association
Phil Hwata could not confirm that Peter Ndlovu and Bruce
Grobbelaar will be coming, saying:"We have contacted both of them
and they are willing to come." Ndlovu's younger brother Adam has
confirmed his availability.

Since that famous Harare drubbing, the two sides have drawn one
game and South Africa reversed the 1992 beating last year when
Leeds striker Philemon Masinga scored in a friendly international
in Mmabatho to give South Africa a 1-0 win.

Hwata said Zimbabwe's presence in Johannesburg should not be
taken lightly as they hope to show that they should be in the
African Nations Cup to be staged from January 13 to February 3
next year.

Most of the Zimbabwe players, including Ndlovu and Grobbelaar,
refused to travel to Zaire for their CAF qualifying match against
Zaire fearing the Ebola virus. Zimbabwe subsequently lost the
game.

Meanwhile the Zambian squad that arrived on Tuesday were
without four of their international players. Saudi Arabia-based
players Harrison Chongo and Elijah Litana had not joined the squad
and their coach Roald Poulsen said he was still awaiting their
arrival. Johnson Bwalya and Kalusha Bwalya (no relation), who is
based in Switzerland, were absent.

Poulsen said they did not have most of their foreign stars but
they have brought a respectable squad. He argued that one cannot
read too much into these games. "It is a good opportunity to test
the players and the squad as a whole but it becomes a totally
different situation when you play an official match as you will
see when we come back in January."

South Africa have played Zambia four times with Zambia winning
two, South Africa winning the friendly international last year at
Ellis Park and one draw in the CAF qualifying game in Lusaka last
year.

The fourth team in the tournament, Egypt, will be coming here
for the first time and they have never played South Africa in any
capacity. But they have a strong team and will be force to be
reckoned with in the African Nations Cup next year.

South Africa have recalled most of their European-based players
for the tournament, but unfortunately they will only arrive in the
country next week. In the meantime coach Clive Barker will have to
make do with local talent. Eric Tinkler, who plays in Portugal, is
the only one available for the duration of the tournament.

The national team's training sessions ohave been disrupted
because of domestic games, with some of the players having to
return to their teams because of club commitments. Orlando Pirates
requested that their players (Edward Motale, Mark Fish, John
Moeti, Marks Maponyane and Innocent Mncwango), be left out of
these games because of their involvement in the Africa Champions
Cup final against Asec of Ivory Coast on December 2. Assistant
coach Phil Setshedi said: "We are still to make a decision".

Another interesting question for the coach is Doctor Khumalo
who has been ruled out of club soccer because of the botched
transfer deal to an Argetinian team Oeste. He has not played
professional football since the Mozambique friendly but the
indications are that he will be played. Anyway he is training with
the squad.

"He will be considered because of his reputation," said
Sethsedi.

Barker's boys cannot afford to slip up in any of these games.
If they hope to win the public confidence for next years CAF games
they have to start to impress now.

The tournament is played on a round robin system with South
Africa tackling Zambia and Zimbabwe against Egypt in a doublethe FNB stadium next weekend.
header at Mmabatho on Sunday. The next round of matches will be at
-0Zambia

Africa News


November, 1995


Murdoch May Take Stake in Satellite Deal


LENGTH: 814 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Niel Bierbaum

Johannesburg - The South African Broadcasting Corporation
(SABC) could be considering media mogul Rupert Murdoch as an
international partner for its satellite venture. Such a deal could
see the SABC exchanging an ownership share for exclusive rights to
southern hemisphere rugby, which are held by Murdoch.

Although no deal has yet been signed, Murdoch's representatives
have been in the country this week on a "fact-finding mission". 
They have held talks with prospective broadcasters, with the
Independent Broadcasting Authority and, according to SABC chief
operating officer Gert Claasen, were given free rein at the SABC
to "ask anybody whatever questions they liked". Called at his
Sandton hotel room this week, a Murdoch representative, Richard
Dunn said, "There is nothing to say. We are a long way from making
any decisions."

Claasen insisted that "no deal would be possible until we have
decided how to structure our consortium". This consortium will
involve foreign interests, but he reiterated that Murdoch is not
the only player to whom they have spoken.

Others in the industry believe that an ownership share in
exchange for rugby rights would give Murdoch a foot in the door in
the South African market to the detriment of other players. One
industry player proposed that South African channels should
collectively agree to buy the rights from Murdoch rather do an
ownership exchange with him.

According to David Niddrie who is heading up the SABC satellite
initiative, "Just about everbody in the country is talking to
Murdoch. South Africa should have access to broadcasters of
international importance." Claasen seemed to have no problem with
the fact that other commercial operators might see such a deal as
treading on toes. "At the end of the day, it will be a commercial
decision," he said.

Some have questioned whether the SABC as the public service
broadcaster should be getting involved in satellite television at
all, particularly as the decision about its third channel has not
yet been taken. The original idea behind the satellite service was
to compensate for the expected revenue losses that the SABC claims
would occur if it was to lose its third channel. The SABC has
instead asked to retain its third channel, it has asked Parliament
for R496-million and it wants to make money off a satellite
service.

Jonathan Procter, managing director of potential satellite
broadcaster Retcorp International, believes that the process
should happen the other way around. "The SABC would be an
attractive partner in a local satellite initiative. It could offer
terrestrial access to cross-market the satellite channels and so
would warrant a shareholding."

M-Net CEO Gerrie de Villiers points out that if the SABC were
in the private sector they would first ask whether they could
afford to do this. "As a taxpayer I find it worrying that my
public broadcaster could end up making losses of hundreds of
millions of rands." De Villiers believes that such losses were
likely as "the SABC has problems making profits terrestrially."

Niddrie would not comment on the SABC's plans except to say
that the satellite initiative would cost "significantly less than
a third" of the R800-million quoted by this newspaper two weeks
ago.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


365 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


U.S. Sale Puts Platinum Price Under Scrutiny


LENGTH: 840 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Karen Harverson

Johannesburg - The platinum market, although sensitive to
sudden increases in supply, is unlikely to be hit too hard when
the United States sells off its strategic stockpile of platinum as
announced in September 1994.

"The US has not yet decided how much of its 453 000oz of
platinum will be sold off or when but it is unlikely to be
released into the market all at once," said Johnson Matthey
marketing general manager Jeremy Coombes, speaking at the 1995
interim review of the platinum industry.

Coombes reported that platinum demand is expected to reach a
new high this year, increasing four percent to 4,7-million oz
compared with 1994. "Much of the increase is from the industrial
sector, particularly the chemical, petroleum refining, and glass
fibre industry as well as from high-technology industries." 

The jewellery market -- led by Japan -- has moved from second
place to first as the biggest consumer of platinum with 1,8Growth in the autocatalyst market -- the biggest consumer last
million oz consumed in 1995 compared to 1,73-million oz last year.
year -- has declined from 1,87-million oz in 1994 to 1,79-million
oz this year, largely as a result of the switch to palladium
autocatalysts by European manufacturers.

European manufacturers are adopting palladium rich autocatalyst
systems in gasoline vehicles as it offers high temperature
resistance, said Coombes.

He added that on diesel cars -- which make up 25 percent of new
cars in Europe -- there was wider use of platinum autocatalysts
which would improve demand. He reported further increased demand
for platinum autocatalysts from South East Asia.

Demand for platinum investment products is expected to fall by
30 000oz to 365 000oz in 1995 despite increased interest by Japan.
European investment has declined as a result of Austria joining
the European Union in January. Purchases of platinum coins in
Austria formerly attracted no tax but with joining the European
Union (EU), value added tax has now been imposed and demand has
fallen.

In the US, stronger equity and bond markets have diverted
investor attention away from platinum coins.

Platinum supply is expected to increase by eight percent in
1995 to reach 4,89-million ounces as a result of higher shipments
from South Africa -- the world's biggest supplier of platinum --
as well as an increase in Russian supplies which surged 190 000oz
on last year's figure of 1,01-million oz.

"In our opinion, Russian sales are not equal to production and
we expect at least 500 000oz to be drawn from state reserves,"
says Coombes.

On South African supplies, he said the rise in production to
3,35-million ounces was still below 1993 levels (3,36-million) but
represented an increase of 190 000oz on last year's figure.

"Additional metal is available from Amplats which is processing
the concentrate backlog which occurred due to the reconstruction
of its smelter."

Coombes said Implats' production had declined slightly as a
result of an accident at the smelter in August this year and he
added that he did not expect the merger between Implats and Lonrho
Platinum division to affect overall platinum production.

The price of platinum is expected to range between $400 and
$440 an ounce during the next six months. It reached $460 in April
this year but fell to below $420 in early October.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

November, 1995


Bankruptcy Fears for Winnie Mandela


LENGTH: 227 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 17, 1995 (19951117)

Johannesburg - Winnie Mandela's worsening financial situation
has prompted fears she could be close to bankruptcy -- a situation
which would cost her her seat in Parliament.

Mandela owes Absa more than R500 000 in arrears on her Soweto
home. But Absa might not sell the house over her head given that
it will appear on an accounting of Mandela assets when Winnie and
the President are divorced.

However the debts Mrs Mandela has accumulated, including bond
arrears on her house and unpaid legal costs, mean the possibility
of bankruptcy cannot be ruled out.

The Mandela divorce is at a stage where lawyers for both
partners are seeking a financial settlemen to end the 40-year
marriage. Such a settlement could rescue Mrs Mandela.
-0South Africa

LANGUAGE: English

367 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Court Loss Casts Light on Winnie Mandela


LENGTH: 1227 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Justin Pearce

Johannesburg - A prince telling a court of law he took his
orders unquestioningly from "Mummy". A church minister and selffinancial records of an organisation to which he offered his
appointed business consultant admitting he had no knowledge of the
services. Stories of a costly and fruitless visit to a head of
state to buy diamonds, supposedly in the interests of poverty
relief work.

Such revelations in the Witwatersrand Supreme Court this week
painted a chaotic picture of the workings of Co-ordinated Antihave been held together by nothing more than the magnetism of
Poverty Programmes (Capp), the Section 21 company which appears to
Winnie Mandela's personality. 

"I'd do anything for my mother-in-law as long as I thought it
was for a good cause," Mandela's son-in-law Prince Musi Dhlamini
of Swaziland insisted under cross-examination.

"You went to see a head of state and didn't know whose business
this was -- you expect the court to believe this?" Sydney
Nochumsohn, counsel for air charter company Foster Webb Hangars
demanded incredulously.

"Yes," Dhlamini replied, unperturbed. "I was there to introduce
Ben du Preez to the president." The president in question was
Angola's Eduardo dos Santos. Ben du Preez was a prospective
diamond buyer, for whom Mandela had set up a meeting with Dos
Santos. The meeting was to result in a diamond deal on which
Mandela would take a 10 percent commission to benefit Capp.

Dhlamini never once referred to Mandela by name. She was always
"my mother-in-law" or, more frequently, just "Mummy". And the
phrase "that was none of my business" ran through the prince's
testimony like a refrain, as he denied all knowledge of the
reasons for the Angola mission.

"Why was a charter flight used, and not an ordinary aircraft?"

"That was none of my business."

"What was Capp's project?"

"To raise funds in whatever way they thought possible."

"What was the purpose of this trip?"

"I didn't know. I was asked by Mummy to take a delegation to
Angola. I assumed Mummy was working for Capp and part of this
would be Capp's business. I didn't ask Mummy. It was none of my
business."

"Reverend Khumalo -- the Capp consultant -- what was he there
to do?"

"That was none of my business."

Rev Tamasanqa Khumalo, who offered his services as a business
adviser to Capp, revealed that his own knowledge of Capp's affairs
was scanty. Khumalo told the court that he had never seen any
business records which would have indicated whether Mandela had
indeed booked the charter on behalf of Capp.

Yet Khumalo's part-time presence in the organisation seemed to
suggest that he was the only person with any financial skills at
all. Khumalo said he had offered Mandela and Capp his services as
a business consultant at no charge when he realised that Mandela
was being exploited because she was helping companies to establish
business contacts in African countries without demanding payment
for this service. At the same time she was financing Capp out of
her own pocket to the tune of R20 000 a month, he testified.

Khumalo advised Mandela to charge a commission when she set up
business deals. It was one such deal which led Mandela to book a
charter flight to Luanda in June 1993, the costs of which she was
ordered to pay this week.

Through her long-standing associate Peter Mokaba, Mandela had
met Ben du Preez who wanted to buy diamonds in Angola -- Mandela,
as a friend of Dos Santos, arranged a meeting between Du Preez and
Dos Santos. At Du Preez' request, she also arranged the flight to
Luanda.

Capp was set up as a Section 21 company in 1992 by Mandela and
eight other directors, its stated objective being to combat
poverty. Capp was in financial trouble by 1993, amid allegations
that directors were using the company for their own gain. The
Section 21 company still exists, but appears not to have operated
since 1994.

Capp appears to have operated on the basis of ad hoc decisions
made by Mandela, sometimes acting on the advice of Khumalo. The
court heard that the initial arrangements for the flight had been
made by Mandela herself -- the final letter of confirmation bore
Capp's letterhead and was signed by Mandela, but did not state in
what capacity she was signing. Fatally for Mandela, Du Preez' name
was not mentioned in the letter, which pointed to Mandela being
solely responsible for the cost of the flight.

A post-dated cheque was offered in payment for the flight, the
drawer of the cheque being Fortune Real Estate, whose owner, Zac
Brainen, had also met Mandela through Mokaba. This arrangement was
justified on the grounds that Capp had no cheque account. The
cheque bounced.

The Angola trip turned out to be an expensive fiasco. Dos
Santos ended the meeting after five minutes, saying that South
Africans wishing to buy Angolan diamonds could do so through an
agent in Johannesburg.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


368 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Mandela's Serious Miscalculation


LENGTH: 1640 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Phillip van Niekerk

Johannesburg - South Africa's belated determination to get
tough on the Abacha regime should not blind us to the scale of
President Nelson Mandela's miscalculation in initially urging the
Commonwealth to go easy with the criminals of Abuja. South
Africans will have some difficulty understanding the criticism,
but it was picked up by the rest of the world who had looked to
the prsident for moral leadership on the issue. For many Nigerians
it meant nothing less than betrayal.

It would be unfair to imply that Mandela helped send Ken Sarobeen more open to the pleas and warnings of ordinary Nigerians,
Wiwa and his colleagues to the gallows. But if the government had
they would not have proved themselves so deficient in predicting
events on a continent that South Africa aspires to lead. 

We will never know if a strong, principled statement from
Mandela -- calling not just for clemency, but condemning the
whole trial as a set-up -- would have made any difference. Ken
Saro-Wiwa is dead. Nor can there be doubt that Mandela's instincts
would have led him to speak out more forcefully earlier. He was
just hamstrung by a policy that was too clever by half.

It should not have taken the murder of Saro-Wiwa to destroy
South Africa's illusions about the nature of the Abacha regime.
Mandela's own emissary, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, visited Chief
Moshood Abiola in his cell in Abuja in April and witnessed first
hand the delusional, slightly bizzarre behaviour of the ruling
military.

Abiola, after all, is a man charged with "treason" for having
proclaimed himself president after winning an election that the
vast majority of Nigerians participated in. His accusers, who
blithely insist that the "judicial process" should prevail, seized
power through the gun-barrel of a tank.

Tutu found Abiola's "unsalubrious" prison conditions so much at
variance with what he had been led to expect from the generals
that he wondered why they allowed him in at all. The millionaire
businessman, used to the creature comforts of a luxury home at
Ikeja outside Lagos, is no Nelson Mandela.

He was willing to meet all of Abacha's conditions for his
release, and more, including house arrest and a gag on political
statements. But they were never serious about letting out such a
symbol of democratisation and he is still rotting in his cell.

Refusing to be swayed by fancy theories, Tutu read the nature
of the regime correctly and has been consistently spot-on where
the official position has been off the mark.

Abacha's contempt for Mandela's sweet reason prompted not a
tougher official line but a softer one. Instead of supporting the
democratic opposition, South Africa got drawn into a dubious form
of "constructive engagement" with the dictators. When Deputy
President Thabo Mbeki visited Abuja he did not see a single
opposition leader.

It's not as if different views are not there for the taking.
Nigerians have strong opinions and are not afraid to express them.
Nigeria has the most courageous, critical and well-written press
in Africa.

On the day Mbeki saw Abacha, 43 criminals were being executed
by firing squad. The most damning fact about that, from the South
African side, is that Mbeki was surprised. The executions were in
public and were advertised in the newspapers days in advance. Why
didn't the South African High Commission warn Mbeki?

Again, in the case of news about the confirmation of SaroPretoria would have been better served by subscribing to Reuters
Wiwa's death sentence and the determination to carry them out,
or monitoring the BBC Africa Service than waiting for information
from the High Commission.

But these failures belong in the domain of ineptitude which,
one would hope, have their own rules of accountability. The more
serious -- and now discredited -- philosophy underlying the
dialogue approach is that, because we happen to inhabit the same
continent as Nigeria, South Africans have a better understanding
of Nigeria. Well, a thug is a thug on any continent, and Nelson
Mandela has as much in common with Sani Abacha as Mussolini would
have had with Mother Teresa.

The adjunct to all of this -- that the British and the
Americans didn't understand because they are not Africans -- was a
failure to read what had been happening in Nigeria. The West has
had cosy, cynical relationships with successive Nigerian regimes
of every stripe. They folded their arms when the June 1993
elections, the genesis of the present political crisis, were
annulled by General Ibrahim Babangida.

That they were finally stung into taking some kind of a stand
against Abacha by Nigerian exiles and by political lobbies in
their own countries is evidence that democracy sometimes works,
not of western imperialism.

It is a mark of extreme confusion that Deputy Foreign Minister
Aziz Pahad can claim the softly-softly approach was correct as
some sort of payback because "we don't forget the role Nigeria
played in our struggle". Does he not know that Nigerian support
for the anti-apartheid movement came out of the monthly paychecks
of ordinary people? That some of the African National Congress'
strongest supporters, such as Abiola and General Olesugun
Obasanjo, are in jail?

Does he really see no distinction between thieving and
unpopular dictators imposing themselves through terror and murder,
and the broad mass of Nigerian people?

Abacha's attempts to undermine Abiola -- pointing that he too
is tainted by corruption -- have been repeated in these parts as
gospel. The fact is that Abiola won a legitimate election,
declared free and fair by the international community, an election
five years in the making, and -- most hopefully for a divided
society such as Nigeria -- one in which a Muslim southerner won
majority support from all regions, all ethnic groups, all
religious factions.

Instead, South Africa gave the dictators three years to
implement a constitution that was produced by a conference less
legitimate than South Africa's old President's Council. The
document was only concluded after participants such as Shehu Musa
Yar 'Adua, one of the few participants who had shown real courage,
were removed from the conference and sentenced to death.

It is my reading that Nigerians don't want the world, including
South Africa, to solve their problems any more than the ANC wanted
its friends in the international community to draw up the
blueprint for South Africa's new constitution. International
pressure was linked to specific targets: the release of political
prisoners, the normalisation of politics, the creation of a fair
framework to negotiate a settlement.

Nigerians looked to Mandela to take a strong stand, not
because of our trade links with that country, but because the
people of this continent see him as a fighter for justice. It will
be a betrayal of all he stands for if South Africa continues to be
seen as siding with corrupt elites in jackboots.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


369 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Saro-Wiwa Friend: 'You can't blame Mandela'


LENGTH: 640 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Rehana Rossouw

Johannesburg - Naivety and inexperience in African affairs
contributed to South Africa's failure to play a part in stopping
the executions last week. Nigerian-born writer and academic,
Professor Kole Omotoso -- better known to millions of television
viewers as the uppity "Gogo" in a cellular telephone company's
advertisement -- lost his dear friend Ken Saro-Wiwa to the
hangman's noose, but believes Mandela is not to blame.

"I honestly have sympathy with the South African government. 
They didn't create the situation in Nigeria," Omotoso said. "The
ANC and PAC had relations with Nigeria, which were very helpful in
the struggle against apartheid and I find it difficult now to
condemn them.

"You cannot blame Mandela. The South African government is
extremely inexperienced in foreign affairs, particularly as it
applies to Africa."

While many believed the Nigerian government was not capable of
flying in the face of international outrage against the planned
executions, Omotoso said he had warned the government was
bloodthirsty and capable of doing it. "Those who know my country
know how irrational and illogical the military regime is. There
wasn't a chance that it would respond to what Mandela called
'softly-softly'."

South Africa's support at the Commonwealth to suspend Nigeria
and its withdrawal of its high commissioner for "consultation" was
the correct approach, Omotoso said. It sent a strong message to
the military regime that its actions were no longer a "private
affair".

Omotoso welcomed the initiatives being taken by human rights
and political organisations now to isolate Nigeria and support the
movement for democracy there.

"It is difficult for South Africans; there is a different kind
of logic at work in Nigeria. South Africans are tremendously
influenced by Western values and are now shocked that those same
values do not apply in Nigeria and other parts of Africa."

Omotoso said what has pained him every day since Friday, when
his friend Saro-Wiwa died, was that it had taken the deaths of
nine people to wake the world up to what was happening in Nigeria.

"South Africans are beginning to learn that General Abacha will
just laugh in their faces when they preach western values to him."

He supported the call for a boycott of Shell, saying
multinationals could not hide behind excuses of autonomy for each
country's operation -- the spoils all landed up in the home
office's coffers.
-0South Africa - Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


370 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Pretoria Tries to Explain Ogoni Blunder


LENGTH: 1987 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
November 17, 1995 (19951117)
by Stefaans Brummer

Johannesburg - The full extent of government blundering over
the Nigerian crisis began to emerge this week as officials tried
to explain how they allowed the humiliation of Nelson Mandela at
Auckland over the executions of Ken Saro-Wiwa and his fellow
dissidents.

The Mail & Guardian learnt this week that a vital 24 hours was
wasted before South African Foreign Affairs began moving to try to
save them.

There was also major confusion of responsibility within the
Foreign Affairs Department over the crisis. The deputy minister,
Aziz Pahad, said this week that South Africa's high commissioner
in Lagos, George Nene, had instructions to maintain contact with
Nigerian dissidents and had been doing so.

But Nene, re-called this week for "consultations", said he had
not interpreted contact with the opposition as his brief; his duty
had been primarily to liaise on a government level. 

"Not one of the civil liberty or pro-democracy groups has
knocked on my door and said, 'Let's discuss things,' the high
commissioner complained, arguing the onus for contact had been on
the Nigerian opposition.

South Africa's approach to Nigeria exploded in the face of
President Mandela at what should have been a triumphant appearance
at his first Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting in New
Zealand.

The hanging of the nine dissidents came after desperate appeals
from their supporters for a tougher approach.

Figures like Nigerian Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka charged South
Africa with "appeasement" and compared the strategy of "quiet
diplomacy" to the notorious strategy of "constructive engagement"
adopted by the Thatcher and Reagan administrations in dealing with
the apartheid government.

Nigerian expatriates and South African civil liberties group
Lawyers for Human Rights made frantic efforts to get Foreign
Affairs mobilised to save Saro-Wiwa and his comrades after the
Reuters news agency first broke the news on Wednesday last week
that the military junta had confirmed the death sentences. The
Nigerians knew from experience this meant the executions were
imminent.

The Department of Foreign Affairs refused to act, however,
until they had received "confirmation" of the announcement, which
they did not obtain until the following day. High Commissioner
Nene then tried, but failed, to contact the Nigerian government
with the appeal: "Don't do this."

The lack of preparedness of President Mandela in Auckland for
the looming tragedy was demonstrated by his statement on the
Thursday that South Africa was standing by its policy of quiet
diplomacy and there would be "time enough" to opt for stronger
measures if persuasion failed.

Since the executions, virtually nothing has been heard from
South Africa's Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo, and Deputy President
Thabo Mbeki -- the first of whom carries constitutional
responsibility for his department; the latter believed to have
been largely responsible for formulating policy on the Nigerian
issue. Instead, Nzo's deputy, Pahad, has been left to carry the
can.

This week Pahad told a media conference in Pretoria that South
Africa's policy towards Nigeria could not be compared with the
1980s "constructive engagement" of the United States and Britain
towards apartheid. He said those countries had hidden behind the
policy to avoid pushing for real change.

"We do not see anything wrong in principle with constructive
engagement, but that does not mean weak constructive engagement."
Pahad later said: "The entire world was caught unawares ... so I
don't think (Foreign Affairs officials) could have had a finger on
the pulse of such a controversial decision."

Pahad countered criticism that he and Mbeki had not seen
opposition leaders during a visit to Nigeria earlier this year,
saying time had been limited. He pointed to the success of the
mission, which some feel was a deciding factor in Abacha's October
1 commutation of death sentences against former Nigerian ruler
General Olusegun Abasanjo and other "coup plotters".

But Pahad said Nene had instructions to maintain contact with
Nigerian opposition groups. Nene told the M&G that he had had
regular contact with the wives of Obasanjo and Moshood Abiola (the
imprisoned, presumed winner of Nigeria's annulled presidential
elections). He said he saw the wives as "family representatives"
rather than representatives of the opposition.

Rejecting criticism of South Africa by the Nigerian opposition,
he said: "It is easy for them to criticise President Mandela in
the press." Pointing to divisions among Nigerian opposition
groups, he said they could not expect stronger action from foreign
governments if they could not agree on action themselves.

Nene, who was appointed high commissioner in February after
serving as African National Congress representative to Nigeria
since 1989, said Britain and the United States, both of which
"have better systems of getting information", had erred similarly.
"Until the sentences were carried out, all of us thought it would
not happen."

Pahad replied that if Nene had not made contact with opposition
groups, "he must explain".

TIMETABLE

The following are the events surrounding the executions of Ken
Saro-Wiwa and his eight fellow dissidents at Port Harcourt:

* Tuesday October 31: A military tribunal appointed by the
Provisional Ruling Council (PRC) of Nigerian military dictator
General Sani Abacha hands down death sentences, with no option to
appeal, against Saro-Wiwa, Barinem Kiobel, John Kpunien, Baribor
Bera, Saturday Dobee, Felix Nwate, Norde Eawo, Paul Levura and
Daniel Gbokwo. South Africa informs Nigeria's high commissioner in
Pretoria the sentences are unacceptable.

* Monday November 6: Deputy President Thabo Mbeki tries,
apparently without success, to contact Abacha to ensure he will be
attending the Commonwealth summit in New Zealand later in the
week, so the sentences and Nigeria's transition to democracy can
be discussed. (Abacha did not come, sending Foreign Minister Tom
Okimi instead.)
.* Wednesday November 8, about noon: Reuters news agency reports
the PRC met earlier in the day and confirmed the death sentences.

...* Wednesday November 8, after 9pm: South Africa's Lawyers
for Human Rights (LHR) hears from a Nigerian opposition group that
the PRC had confirmed the sentences, and is told by Nigerian
contacts the PRC is not bluffing.

LHR calls the Department of Foreign Affairs, and ends up
speaking to Johann Marx, head of the section dealing with Nigeria.
Marx tells LHR no strong action can be taken until his department
has had confirmation of the PRC decision. LHR tells him Reuters
and other sources confirmed it. He tells LHR he would have to
check it with Nene, South Africa's high commissioner in Lagos.

Marx calls Nene, who says he is in no position to confirm the
PRC decision and suggests they wait for confirmation in the
Nigerian media or work on it in the morning.

...* Thursday November 9, morning: Nene gets the confirmation
in the Nigerian media. He tries to contact senior Nigerian
government officials with the message, "Don't do this". He fails
to make contact. (Only after the hangings does he succeed in
making contact.)

Meanwhile, the Commonwealth heads of government and their
delegations gather in Auckland. Mandela and others appeal for a
stay of execution, but Mandela defends his policy of quiet
diplomacy, saying the time for sanctions and stronger action has
not come -- and that there will be "time enough" to consider
these if persuasion fails.

...* Friday November 10, about 11am: Saro-Wiwa and his fellow
activists are hanged in Port Harcourt, Nigeria. Foreign Affairs in
South Africa gets the news before Nene, who confirms to them later
in the day: "Yes, it looks like it."

...* Saturday November 11, early morning: Mandela and other
Commonwealth heads of government are told about the hangings.
Mandela, in his own words "almost out of control" with anger,
calls for Nigeria's immediate expulsion from the Commonwealth.
(This position is later ameliorated, in consultation with other
heads of government, to a two-year suspension. Expulsion will come
if there are further gross human rights abuses or if Nigeria's
movement to democracy is unsatisfactory.)
-0South Africa and Nigeria

Africa News


November, 1995


Soccer Team Prepares for Nations Cup


LENGTH: 854 words


 
New Nation (Johannesburg)
November 3, 1995 (19951103)
by Dominic Chimhavi

Johannesburg - National coach Clive Barker will ensure that the
South African squad is fired up and ready for action it takes
centre stage in the forthcoming Simba Four Nations Cup.

There has been mixed reaction from soccer critics about the
seriousness with which the participating countries are approaching
the annual tournament, with a lot of pessimists saying it will be
a damp squib.

Four countries -- South Africa, Zambia, Nigeria and Egypt --
will take part in the soccer fiesta, which kicks off on November
18, and which will be a prelude to the grand Africa Cup of
Nations(ACN) taking place from January 13 to February 3 next year. 
 There is speculation that of the four countries, only South
Africa will field the strongest possible side, with the other
three having to opt for makeshift teams.

This is because key players from the three countries, who are
professionals in Europe, will not be available, as their countries
do not take the tournament seriously enough to recall them--let
alone when the continent's prestige ACN is just around the corner.

But what makes the pessimists' argument lose sense is the fact
that a staggering R180 000 will be pocketed by the winner of this
round-robin competition, while the runners-up will go home with an
equally huge cash incentive R80 000.

"There will be al lot at stake and I do not believe these
nations can afford to ignore such incentives, especially as most
of them are going through a lean spell," said Safa's executive
president Solomon "Sticks" Morewa.

Morewa's sentiments were echoed by Barker who dismissed as
"unfounded" allegations that the three countries would send
second-rate sides to such a reputable competition".

"I am not taking chances and I will field my strongest possible
side in the three games," said Barker who hinted that he might
recall all of his overseas-based professionals to beef up the
squad.

Zambia's irreplaceable" captain Kalusha Bwalya is definitely
out as his Mexican club, AS America, are campaigning strongly for
league honors.

But, that does not mean that Zambia are a one-man team,
according to Barker. "They have played several matches without
Kalusha and have done exceptionally well, so his unavailability
does not make much difference."

Zambia which has a population of nine million and more than 200
registered clubs, has one of the most flawless records on the
continent.

They were runners-up for the Africa Nations Cup in 1994, thirdthis year, they beat Korea 3-2 in the Korea Cup. They also
placed in 1982 and 1990, and runners-up in 1994. And on June 10
finished their Africa Cup of Nations qualifying group with a
comprehensive 2-0 win over Mauritius, whom they had earlier
thumped 3-0.

As for Egypt, with or without its overseas-based professionals,
this large north African nation, which has won the ACN three
times, has the potential to assemble a formidable team.

With a population of 55-million, Egypt has approximately 250
registered clubs from which to choose players for its national
side.

Current ACN champions, Nigeria, need no introduction. With a
population of over 90-million and a record 500 registered clubs
from which to select its national squad, the west African country
poses the greatest threat to South Africa's ambitions.
-0South Africa and Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


Rwanda And Burundi Confirm Participation In Soccer Cup


LENGTH: 680 words


 
The Monitor (Kampala)
November 6, 1995 (19951106)
by Charles Sebugwawo

Kampala - The East and Central Senior Challenge Cup is
scheduled to kick off on November 25 and there is already good
news that it will be an expanded version. Rwanda and Burundi on
Friday confirmed that they will be in Kampala.

The regional championship lost some glamour when Zambia, Malawi
and Zimbabwe pulled out due to lack of incentives. Since then
Djibouti, Seychelles, Eritrea and now Burundi and Rwanda have
joined the CECAFA family. 

According to FUFA Chairman Twaha Kakaire, preparations for the
challenge cup have reached final stages and he expressed
confidence that it will be a smooth run during the tournament.

Kakaire further said that so far only eight countries have
confirmed their participation in the two week tournament and they
are; hosts Uganda who are fielding two teams, defending champions
Tanzania, Kenya, Ethiopia, Rwanda, Burundi, Eritrea and Zanzibar.

Kakaire revealed that the information he has from the CECAFA
Secretariat in Nairobi is that, three countries Sudan, Djibouti,
and Seychelles were yet to confirm participation by last Friday.

Twaha also confirmed that Nakivubo and Bugembe Stadium will be
the two venues for this year's Senior Challenge Cup.

The fixtures for the championships will be released after the
CECAFA Secretariat has confirmed the number of teams taking part.
The teams are expected to start arriving from November 22 and
those based in Kampala will be accommodated at the Post Office
Hostel in Nakawa, east of Kampala and at Silver Springs while
those in Jinja will reside at Kalinie and Fairway Inn.

The two Uganda teams, The Cranes and Kobs are in serious
residential training at Lugogo and all stones are being turned in
a bid to recapture the cup Uganda last won in 1992 in Mwanza. That
time, Uganda played without SC Villa players who were engaged in
the CAF Cup finals against Shooting Stars of Nigeria. SC Villa
lost 0-3 on aggregate.

The Cranes beat Kakuona, the Tanzania B side 1-0 to take the
cup for keeps. The Cranes lost in the finals to Tanzania last year
the spot kicks after drawing 2-2. The Challenge Cup was not held
in 1993 due to lack of hosting nation after Ethiopia pulled out.
Uganda would have hosted the meet but because of bad blood between
the Semanobe FUFA and NCS, Uganda government cancelled the offer.

Meanwhile, Express will represent Uganda in this year's East
and Central Club Championships to be held in Tanzania's towns of
Dar-es-Salaam and Mwanza. The regional club tourney starts
December 23 and ends January 13, 1996.

The Club Championships which is always held early in the year
were brought forward to enable executives of various national
soccer associations travel to South Africa for the CAF Congress to
be held during the Africa Cup of Nations.
-0South Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

373 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Tutu Censors African Leaders On Corruption


LENGTH: 960 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Nairobia - South African clergy and Nobel Peace Prize winner
Archbishop Desmond Tutu, has cited corruption, mismanagement and
lack of accountability, among some African leaders as major blocks
to the continent's hope for survival in the next century .

But the Archbishop of Cape Town nevertheless urges Africans to
maintain the hope for survival although total victory, would
depend on their leaders' change of heart.

Delivering a public lecture on October 7 under the topic,
"Africa's dilemma: Conflicts, Challenges and Possibilities,"
Bishop Tutu told his Kenyan audience; "Our leaders must have a
change of heart. They must be ready to say "NO" to issues such as
corruption, mismanagement and lack of accountability if we are to
be assured of our survival in the next century. This is a must
that should be followed with action." 

Criticising African governments in general about their spending
on defence which reflects in most cases a reasonably large share
of the total national budget, Tutu wondered why Africa would want
to be over-militarised and questioned the role of military people.

He dared his audience to show him one army in Africa that has
brought peace. All have dismally failed in their defence against
external aggression, he said. "They are (neo-colonial) masters and
instruments of repression," added Tutu.

Arguing that Africa should endeavour by all means to reduce her
military numbers and spending on defence, Tutu observed; "In a
normal situation, we should have less money allocated for defence
and much of it going into viable and needy sectors such as
education, health and agriculture."

The former regime of Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia, was
said to have been spending an estimated 40 per cent of the
national budget on arms in the name of national security.

"The African persons continue to suffer from the effects of
corruption and mismanagement among the leaders. As a result, we
have a continent, endowed with massive natural resources, but
which is unable to feed her people," lamented Tutu.

The AACC president pointed out that the notion that political
power was the gate way to prestige and riches had corrupted
African leadership. He added, "they (leaders) know that the
minute they step down, things will go bad. Those beautiful convoys
and houses will disappear."

He did not spare such leaders regarding their influence on
democratic systems, through which the people would effectively
elect their leaders. Such systems are so eroded in some African
countries that they hardly work. "We must make our governments
democratic and participatory, strengthen civil societies and make
leaders accountable," added Tutu.

On military coups on the continent, the AACC president said;
"because of the false promises some African leaders have made to
their subjects, people have tended to welcome coups wherever they
occur with one simple thinking that 'this one' will bring peace
and reality to the people."

"When a coup occurs, people celebrate because they have a
natural desire for freedom and when a dictator bites the dust they
are happy," added the South African clergy.

On refugees, the AACC president said although many of them were
as a result of man-made and natural calamities, most of the
problems associated with the presence of such displaced people had
a lot to do with massive violation of human rights.

He nevertheless echoed a message of hope singling out South
Africa as a recent show case. "In a special way South Africa,
should stand out as a sign of hope for Africa. In a special way it
has so far proved to the rest of the world that it is possible to
make colour and race irrelevant in the life of the people and the
country too," Tutu noted.

South Africa's swift transition from apartheid to democracy
should give hope to other countries that have lost hope. "Who
would have thought South Africa would be where it is now? Who
would have known that South Africa's president Nelson Mandela
would be the world's most admired and popular leader?" he posed.
-0Uganda


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


Church Coalition Group Intervenes For NGOs


LENGTH: 880 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 6, 1995 (19951106)

Luanda - A Canadian volunteer with the inter-Church Coalition
for Africa (ICCAF) an affiliate of the Canadian Council of
Churches, has urged the international non-governmental
organisations (NGOs) and the United Nations in Angola to value
Angolan partners (Angolan NGOs) and use every opportunity to
strengthen them.

Jim Kirkwood of ICCAFs human rights working group, at the end
of a two- week mission to Angola in September, says all over
Angola United Nations agencies like the World Food Programme (WFP)
and the international NGOs fulfil the role of government and civil
service "and the people look up to these NGOs and the WFP for
their needs to be supplied.

"It is not much of an exaggeration to say the UN fulfils the
role of government in Angola as far as providing direction and
planning; and the International NGOs are the civil service as far
as providing services is concerned," says ICCAF. 

Kirkwood observes, in the absence of a functioning civil
administration in the northern town of Malanje, the NGOs "are like
new village headmen"- with "this garden area for World Vision,
that one for Save the Children, Caritas or Action for Rural
Development and Environment (ADRA) etc."

All these NGOs are either international or have international
partners who control their work directly or indirectly by the
resources they may choose to make available.

Kirkwood further notes that expatriates have much easier access
to government, UN and NGO offices than Angolans.

With some justification one reason for this is that the UN sees
NGOs as impartial and prefers them for aid distribution. By
contrast Angolan groups may well be thought of as biased towards
their own members.

However, the preference for International NGOs "is very short
signed," warns Kirkwood.

He believes this is the right time to build the capacity and
expertise of the local NGOs because eventually when the crisis
recedes and the international NGOs return to Europe and Africa, it
is the local NGOs which will carry on the work.

The Canadian church worker advocates that however fragile local
NGOs may seem, " we must greatly value Angolan partners and seek
to strengthen them. He lamented that local NGOs in Angola have
learnt to pitch their projects to what the donors want to fund.

They spend a lot of time writing reports to suit the
expectation of donors and do evaluations on demand. "We need to
give as much freedom and respect as we can for local initiative,"
noted Kirkwood.

A peace accord signed November 1994 between Jonas Savimbi's
National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) and
President Eduardo dos Santos ruling Popular Movement for the
Liberation of Angola (MPLA) in Lusaka, Zambia, officially brought
to an end 19 years of civil war that has wrecked the country,
killed some 500,000 people, maimed several thousands of others
and displaced one third of the 10 million population.

And for the second time since the signing of the Lusaka accord,
Dos Santos and Savimbi met early August in Libreville, Gabon, to
try and resolve the latter's possible role in a future government
as well as the fate of his forces.

The Angolan parliament in July passed a constitutional
amendment to pave the way for two vice-presidents, one of whom is
expected to be Savimbi, towards the establishment a government of
national unity.

UNITA and MPLA have often accused each other of violations of
ceasefire. As recent as August this year, both parties reported
fighting in the northern diamond-rich part of the country.
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


White Maize Exported To Southern Africa


LENGTH: 680 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 16, 1995 (19951116)

Nairobi - Kenya's National Cereals and Produce Board (NCPB), a
parastatal buying and selling cereals, is in the process of
exporting 270,000 metric tonnes of white maize worth US dollars
45.2 million (KShs.2,486 million) to southern African countries
between October 1995 and February(March 1996.

Once concluded, the maize export process will facilitate the
clearing of outstanding payment to Kenyan maize farmers totalling
KShs. 1.0 billion (US dollars 18.18 million) as well as the
turnover of stocks currently standing at 7.56 (90 kg) million bags
held by the board. This in turn is expected to clear space for the
1995 bumper harvest. 

According to a press statement October 26, signed by the NCPB
Managing Director Maj. Rtd. W. K. Koitaba, the contracts to export
the Kenyan maize were awarded to two international commodity
dealers following floating of tender in June, 1995.

The NCPB statement further said that there is an acute shortage
of white maize in the southern African region, a situation that
has triggered off high demand for the commodity.

A spokesman from the Zimbabwean High Commission here said his
country needs between 400,000 to 800,000 metric tonnes of white
maize, the staple food. However, he added, "we have not made any
contract with Kenya yet."

Meanwhile, the Trade Commissioner at the South African Mission
here told APS that his country was importing white maize from
Kenya. He did not give further details about the deal between the
two countries.

The southern African region comprising South Africa, Lesotho,
Zimbabwe, Swaziland, Mozambique, Malawi, Angola, Botswana, Namibia
and Zambia experienced drought in 1994(95, with some areas so
seriously affected that livestock and wildlife were reported
dying.

The latest contract brings to 350,000 tonnes of maize sold to
southern African countries this year by the NCPB. The maize, worth
US dollars 63 million (approximately KShs 3.5 billion ) has been
sold through two commodity brokers namely M(S Glencore Grain
Rotterdam B.V of Rotterdam, Netherlands, and M(S International
Commodity Dealers Limited of United Kingdom. Already, some 25,000
tonnes of maize are reported to have been delivered to South
Africa.

Kenya has for the last two years experienced favourable weather
conditions leading to good maize harvests. Mr. J.K. Kemei, public
relations officer with the NCPB said that the board was in the
process of making negotiations to sell a further 3 million (90
kilogramme) bags of white maize in readiness for the new crop.

Meanwhile the southern African region whose crop season begins
in October(November, is said to be experiencing "good rains and
prospects of a good harvest next year."
-0Angola


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


(Document) Senate Bill Calls for Nigeria Sanctions


LENGTH: 1454 words


 
Washington Office on Africa (Washington)
November 18, 1995 (19951118)

Washington - Republican Senator Nancy Kassebaum, Chairman of
the Senate African Affairs Subcommittee, yesterday introduced a
bill which, if passed, would impose additional but still limited
sanctions on the Nigerian government. The bill is co- sponsored by
Senators Leahy (D-VT), Feingold (D-WI), Jeffords (R-VT), Simon (Dto be introduced in the House of Representatives by Representative
IL) and Pell (D-RI). A new bill on the same issue is also expected
Donald Payne (D-NJ) and others.

Kassebaum's bill adds new sanctions, including a ban on all new
U.S. investment in Nigeria, including the energy sector; and a
freeze on the personal assets of top officials of the Nigerian
regime. The bill stops short of the comprehensive embargo on
Nigerian oil which many groups are calling for. But it does call
for the U.S. to build international support for a multilateral
arms embargo, and for consideration of a unilateral arms embargo
within three months after enactment. 

Groups supporting democracy in Nigeria will be considering over
the next weeks whether the Kassebaum bill is strong enough to
deserve support as a first step, or whether there is the
possibility for finding support in Congress for even stronger
legislation.

The measures in the bill move significantly beyond the
sanctions already imposed by the Clinton administration, and are
sure to meet intense opposition from oil companies and others
opposed to economic sanctions against the Nigerian military
regime.

The press release and summary of the bill prepared by Senator
Kassebaum's office are attached below:

Nancy Landon Kassebaum United States Senator, Kansas

For Immediate Release

Kassebaum Seeks Sanctions against Nigeria

Washington, DC - November 17, 1995 - In response to the
executions of nine political activists last week in Nigeria and
deteriorating economic and political conditions in the country,
Senate African Affairs Subcommittee Chairman Nancy Landon
Kassebaum, R-Kan., introduced legislation today imposing a series
of sanctions against the Nigerian government.

"The situation in Nigeria has reached the point where we simply
must respond in a forceful and clear manner," Kassebaum said.
"General Abacha and the Nigerian military leadership must
understand that the United States will not stand idle as they drag
their country into chaos."

The legislation imposes several new, tough sanctions including
a ban on all new U.S. investment in Nigeria, including the energy
sector, and a freeze on the personal assets of top officials of
the Nigerian regime. In addition, the measure urges the President
to build international support for other actions, including a U.N.
arms embargo, a multilateral oil embargo, and a U.N. Human Rights
Commission condemnation.

The bill also codifies a number of sanctions already imposed by
the administration, including a ban on foreign aid, military
sales, and export financing; a termination of air flights between
Nigeria and the United States; an end to U.S. support for Nigeria
the World Bank, IMF and other international financial
institutions; and a visa ban on any Nigerian who formulates,
implements or benefits from policies which hinder Nigeria's
transition to democracy.

"We must send an unambiguous and tough signal to General
Abacha," Kassebaum said. "If you move toward respecting human
rights and instituting a new, civilian regime, the sanctions will
be lifted and we will welcome Nigeria back as a partner and friend
in the international community. If you continue to move in the
wrong direction, the isolation will grow and the economic price
will be high."

Contact: Mike Horak - Press Secretary, Joel Bacon - Deputy
Press Secretary. (202) 224-4774.

Summary of Kassebaum Nigeria Sanctions Bill November 17, 1995

Policy

The United States, working in concert with the international
community, should maintain a policy toward the Government of
Nigeria that is designed to protect internationally recognized
human rights, expedite the transition to democratic, civilian
government, and promote equitable economic development.

Codifies Current Sanctions

* No foreign assistance to the government

* Opposition to loans for Nigeria at the international
financial institutions

* No air flights between the United States and Nigeria

* Visa ban on the Nigerian leadership and their families

* No Eximbank, OPIC or IDA financing or activities for Nigeria

Imposes New Unilateral Sanctions

* Prohibition on new U.S. investment in Nigeria

* Assets freeze for Nigerian leadership

* Sense of Congress that Nigeria should be suspended from
international sports

Encourages Multilateral Sanctions.

The President should* Seek a multilateral oil embargo

* Pursue a U.N. arms embargo against Nigeria

* Pursue a resolution condemning Nigeria at the U.N. Human
Rights Commission

Future Actions

Three months after enactment, the President must report on
progress toward democracy and respect for human rights. If
substantial progress has not been made, he must report on steps
toward a multilateral oil embargo as well as the possibility of
future actions, including unilateral oil embargo, and a ban on the
export of refined petroleum products to Nigeria.

This material is made available by the Washington Office on
Africa, a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights
group supported organization that works with Congress on Africaacknowledgement) is welcomed.
related legislation. Reposting or reproduction (with

For additional information: Washington Office on Africa 110
Maryland Ave. NE, #112 Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961.
Fax: 202-546-1545.
-0Kenya


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


The Belated Din That "Drowned" Saro-Wiwa


LENGTH: 2107 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)
by Othello Gruduah

Nairobi - The brutal murder of Nigeria's minority rights
campaigner, Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other Ogoni leaders, by
General Sani Abacha, has exposed the lack of moral authority and
resolve, and the general cowardice of the present crop of world
leaders.

Although when he was sentenced to death by a military tribunal
on October 31, Saro-Wiwa sounded courageous, he never really
thought the military authorities in Nigeria would have the nerves
to carry out the sentence, given the clout of "powerful friends"
he had in the international community.

One such friend is President Nelson Mandela of South Africa,
who was expected to use his influence with General Abacha to spare
Saro-Wiwa and his co-convicts. Said the writer, playwrite and
environmental activist when the verdicts were announced: "I was
judged guilty even before I was tried. Now you (tribunal) have
confirmed that verdict, I am happy the country has benefited from
the idea which MOSOP (Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni
People) stood for. We in MOSOP have made a very wonderful
contribution to this country." 

But as he arrived in Auckland, New Zealand, for the
Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, Mr Mandela sent out the
wrong signal, arguing that it was too early to talk of imposing
sanctions and harsher measures against the military regime.
Instead, he advocated for a softly diplomatic approach and
dialogue.

Those sentiments stemmed from the fact that during the
apartheid years, Nigeria led the African onslaught against racial
discrimination in South Africa. However, unfortunately, Mandela
failed to separate Nigeria as a nation from a regime which has no
mandate to rule.

And so, the "butcher of Abuja," as Abacha has been dubbed in
some quarters, immediately saw a loophole and lack of coherence in
world opinion and slapped everyone in the face. In a space of just
two years, Abacha has turned Nigeria into an abattoir and marks
this November the second anniversary of his coming to power, his
hands stained with the blood of Saro-Wiwa and others.

The world had been warned when death sentences were imposed on
the nine Ogoni leaders in a murder trial that human rights
organisations considered seriously flawed, lacking due process of
law, and politically motivated. Nigerian Nobel Prize-Winner, Prof
Wole Soyinka, called on Commonwealth leaders to impose "total
isolation" on Abacha and his collaborators.

"The Commonwealth has got surely to stop playing footsie with
this regime," he told British television. "It is a brutal regime
and nothing but the strictest sanctions, total isolation of this
regime will save their lives."

Addressing a news conference two days before the start of the
53-nation Commonwealth Summit, Saro-Wiwa's son, Ken Wiwa, warned
that the summit represented his father's last chance. "It is
important for the Nigerian people...that world opinion and
politicians here at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting
take up this challenge and do something about the human rights
abuses in Nigeria," he said.

"Otherwise...I would accuse them of complicity with the
Nigerian authorities in the human rights abuses in Nigeria."
Declared by Amnesty International as prisoners of conscience,
Saro- Wiwa, who headed MOSOP, and his colleagues were arrested and
charged with murder in May last year following violence in which
four pro-government Ogoni chiefs were allegedly killed by their
supporters.

While the deaths of the four Ogoni chiefs must be condemned,
many Nigerians and international observers believe the hangings of
the MOSOP activists have more to do with silencing dissent than
the murder of the chiefs. If we were to execute all politicians
for the actions of their supporters rather than deal directly with
the supporters, then no politicians will be left in Africa, both
in the government and the opposition.

Throughout the continent, from Accra to Nairobi, and from Cairo
to Cape Town, violence between opposing groups has led to the
deaths, at one time or another of countless numbers of people. The
real crime for which Saro-Wiwa and the eight Ogoni leaders were
executed was their campaign against the pollution and degradation
of Ogoniland by the giant Anglo-Dutch Shell Petroleum Company, and
for a fair share of oil extracted from the land. Mr. Saro- Wiwa,
who had served in various capacities under past administrations,
fell out with the establishment immediately he began raising
awareness about the environmental damage done to his native
Ogoniland in the southern oil-rich Rivers State and their years of
marginalisation by the authorities. He had shaken the foundation
of the status quo.

The authorities felt he was "too loud" as to campaign for the
rights of the 500,000 inhabitants of Ogoniland out of the
country's population of over 100 million. As Tribunal Chairman
Ibrahim Auta pronounced the sentences in the Rivers State capital,
Port Harcourt, the fallen writer's colleagues in Nigeria and
Britain, the colonial power, reacted in the language they know
best - the language of the pen.

Booker Prize winning Nigerian author, Ben Okri, warned of
terrible consequences after the death sentence was imposed on
Saro-Wiwa. "When you hear that writers have been inexplicably
murdered, silenced... that grotesque lies are told about them...
but above all, when you hear that writers have been sentenced to
death by undemocratic tribunals, then you can be sure that the
perils and the demons of war and the angels of fragmentation have
already begun their dreaded descent..." he said.

Said British novelist William Boyd: "It is a measure of the
moral bankruptcy of General Abacha and his junta that they have
had to flout every standard of civilised and judicial behaviour in
order to quieten the voice of one brave writer fighting for his
people's rights." Wole Soyinka described the trial as a "lethal
charade."

But Saro-Wiwa waited in vain for the world to act decisively to
save his life, and in the event, they failed, as insanity
prevailed over the civilised world. Despite pleas for clemency
from various world leaders and governments, including the United
States and Britain, Nigeria's Provisional Ruling Council (PRC)
went ahead and confirmed the sentences on November 8, and Abacha
carried out the executions on November 10, the day Commonwealth
leaders began their meeting.

Saro-Wiwa was betrayed and let down by the world, including
powerful countries like the United States and Britain, who have
the political and economic clout to stop the jungle action of an
individual member of the world community. Unfortunately, the world
faces an unmitigated crisis of human rights abuses, where the
powerful West, in theory, advocates for the upholding of
fundamental human rights, but in practice, it has often allowed
economic interests to take precedence over the sanctity of life.

For example, the United States alone consumes 75 per cent of
Nigerian oil, and so it has tolerated the brutality committed by
the military in that country for years.

Behind Saro-Wiwa's back came the world outrage when
Commonwealth leaders poured out the befitting epithets available
in the English language to describe the Nigerian action. The
hangings were described as "a slap in the face of Commonwealth
leaders", a heinous crime", "a judicial murder", "a travesty of
justice", and Nigeria itself described as "international peril",
among other strong words from world leaders. Human rights groups
called the murder charge "an affront".

Former Nigerian Foreign Minister, Prof Bolaji Akinyomi, termed
the whole affair, "a jungle trial, state murder and state
terrorism." He added that the trial was unfair. "The World must
put a stop to this mindless group of people and their
collaborators," he told the British Broadcasting Corporation
(BBC).

After having been snubbed as a result of his soft approach and
seeing the long, dark shadow the entire event cast over the
Commonwealth meeting, Mandela came back strongly to placate his
critics by recommending the suspension of Nigeria from the body was subsequently suspended and given two years to reform or face
a move supported by British Prime Minister, John Major. Nigeria
expulsion.

Since then, the reaction from around the world to the killings
mainly on the diplomatic front, has been resounding, with many
countries recalling their envoys from Nigeria.

The latest measures against Nigeria, however belated, would
probably put pressure on the Abacha regime to release the
remaining political prisoners, including the Chief Moshood Abiola,
presumed winner of the annuled June 1993 election. Without total
isolation and economic blockade, however, desired results are
unlikely to happen for the foreseeable future.

But Saro-Wiwa and his associates will go down, not only as
martyrs of minority rights campaign, but also of environmental
protection in this decade.
-0United States and Africa


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

378 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Catholics Establish Outstanding Institution Of Fine Arts


LENGTH: 1347 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)
by Sam Gonza

Nairobi - The collective efforts of parishioners in Nairobi's
Eastlands Deanery has resulted in an excellent institution of
creative arts. The centre has tapped previously unexploited talent
among Kenya's young men and women.

The brainchild of Maryknoll missionary Father Tom Burke in the
late 80s the Buru Buru Institute of Fine Arts (BIFA) became the
initiative of the development committee of the Blessed Sacrament
Church Buru Buru, a middle income level residential area in th e
Kenyan capital, Nairobi.

It took the committee many hours of deliberations before
determining the direction BIFA should take. Construction began in
September 1991 on a piece of land donated by the government next
to the church. 

The Archbishop of Nairobi Maurice Cardinal Otunga who is also
head of the Catholic Church in Kenya was the chief guest at BIFA's
first graduation ceremony on September 15 , 1995. During this
occasion, when 51 students received their well deserved diplomas
after a two year course, the Archbishop was visibly delighted by
the progress made by the college in slightly more than two years
of existence.

BIFA admits young men and women regardless of their religious
affiliation. Students then pursue a career in art either by being
employed or as self- employed persons but the curriculum is
strongly tipped towards self-reliance and self- motivation.

The emphasis on self-reliance is deliberate because Nairobi's
Eastlands Deanery is home to countless of idle school leavers who
cannot find work. A growing number of young people who cannot be
absorbed by the ever narrowing private and public job market all
over Kenya are turning to drugs, prostitution and violence. The
situation can only get worse as the job market dwindles. Fr. Burke
is convinced that many youth turn to alcoholism and violence to
vent frustration arising from a feeling of worthlessness. BIFA
therefore underscores the need for young people to gain selfMr. J. Gitau, chairman of the Buru Buru Parish Council and the
confidence and be self-supporting.
BIFA Management Committee recalls the various methods used to
raise money to put up the institute; - chains of coins around the
church, luncheons, sales of calendars and roast meat as well as
"harambees". The later Kiswahili word means pooling resources
towards a funds raising venture. It is based on community spirit
and everybody voluntarily chips in what ever (mainly) monetary or
other contribution towards the programme. "The response of the
parishioners was overwhelming and we began to see the project as a
reality by 1990," adds Gitau.

Through "harambee" the community of Buru Buru alone raised
shillings 3.6 million (more than US dollars 65,000) while
shillings 5.4 million (about US dollars 98,000) was received in
form of gifts and donations from well wishers in Kenya and abroad.
The money was used to put up the institute and equip it with
furniture.

BIFA's curriculum which was drawn up by competent art teachers
in the country compares favorably with that in advanced colleges.
The chairman of BIFA's Academic Board, Mr. John Kariru who is also
a senior lecturer in the Department of Art at one of the state
universities, Kenyatta University, says; "It is a dynamic
curriculum that is constantly evaluated and monitored to see where
it can be improved."

Kariru designed the vestment with African motifs worn by Pope
John Paul II and the Bishops during the papal mass in Nairobi,
Kenya mid-September this year.

He believes institutions like BIFA will help encourage the
formation of authentic art in Kenya. He argues that local art has
been corrupted and quality sacrificed to foreign standards and the
commercialism of curio shops.

"Commercial galleries are mainly concerned with monetary
returns at the expense of authenticity and creativity," laments
Kariru.

Tobias Butama, the Principal of BIFA, who also teaches art at
the institute says his job is "very fulfilling" because one
participates in the blooming of young talent. "It is also
gratifying because our students understand what to do with their
talents. Many earn commissions which we encourage while still at
BIFA," he adds.

The principal is assisted by a team of competent lecturers. A
lot of emphasis is put on developing a wholesome individual. "The
artist must be a good citizen too. Being creative and talented is
not all there is in life," remarks Butama.

To help mould the character of their students, BIFA invites
many professionals including counsellors to speak on various
subjects ranging from the power of prayer to copyright law.

BIFA's main courses are drawing, painting ceramics, sculpture,
textile design, graphics and history of art. Students pay an
annual fee of KShs. 25,000 (US dollars 450).

The school currently has about 130 students, 30 per cent of
whom are young women pursuing the two-year course. "I suppose the
girls are still finding their way," quipped Cardinal Otunga.

To encourage more female participants, Butama hopes to extend
the curriculum to include subjects like interior and fashion
design as well as computer graphics.

BIFA's third phase will take a few more years to develop. This
will involve teaching the performing arts, dance, mime, and ballet
among others.

An aspiring entrepreneur, Jennifer Macharia, a second year
student at BIFA has a lot of praise for the institution; "One's
talent is nurtured because the teachers allow you the freedom to
explore," she told APS.
-0Nigeria


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.
