Africa News


November, 1995


UN Reports On Human Rights Abuses


LENGTH: 2294 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)
by APS Crrespondent

Nairobi - The United Nations has indicted Sudan of "grave and
widespread" human rights violations, including killings,
kidnappings, slavery and religious persecutions, as an armed
conflict looms in the region between Sudanese government and its
neighbours.

The United Nations has warned that Sudan was the site of
"grave and widespread" human rights violations, which included
among other abuses murders and kidnappings.

A 28-page report was compiled after a fact-finding mission to
neighbouring Eritrea, Kenya and Uganda. However, the mission was
refused entry into Sudan. Released at the UN headquarters in New
York on November 6, the report quotes UN Special investigator
Gaspar Biro saying, "grave and widespread violations of human
rights by government agents, as well as abuses by members of rebel
parties to the conflict in southern Sudan, other than the
government of Sudan, continued to take place in the zones
controlled by them." 

In his findings, Biro says the violations included "extraabductions, slavery, systematic torture and widespread arbitrary
judicial killings, enforced or involuntary disappearances,
arrests of suspected political opponents."

The document denounces the "passivity of the government of
Sudan regarding the cases of slavery, servitude, slave trade,
including the abduction of women and children, traffic in and sale
of children, forced labour and similar institutions and practices
brought to its attention."

The UN report estimates that some 1.2 million people have died
in Sudan since civil war erupted in the southern part of the
northeast African nation in 1983, between government forces and
the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) seeking to end
domination of the mainly Christian and animist south by the
Arabised, Muslim north.

The Sudan is divided into three main groups, northerners,
southerners and westerners, with the north being predominantly
Muslim, while the south follows traditional and Christian faiths.
Religious issues, coupled with strains over whether the country
should be associated with North Africa or sub-Saharan Africa, have
fueled the conflict.

"During the past five years thousands of civilians are reported
to have been killed in deliberate and indiscriminate attacks,
including aerial bombardments on civilian targets by government
forces," the UN report says.

In the Nuba Mountains, notes the report, "a large number of
civilians, including women and children, Muslims and Christians
alike, have been killed in these attacks or summarily executed.
Others are reported to have lost their lives as a result of brutal
torture in secret detention centres run by the security organs or
in military barracks, and dozens of army officers have been
summarily executed after secret trials by special courts," writes
Biro.

The investigator says he confirmed previous reports of
prisoners of war abuses, where "those captured have been and are
being tortured and summarily executed. If a prisoner is captured
and he refuses to change sides, he is cruelly tortured and
executed," the report says.

Biro notes in the document that other participants in the
conflict besides the government are responsible for abuses in the
zones they control, and denounced "dissident commanders, mainly
those who had split in recent years from the South Sudan
Independence Movement/Army (SSIM/A), formed last year by former
SPLA deputy leader Riek Machar. The SPLA "bears responsibility for
the violations and atrocities committed in 1995 by local
commanders from its own ranks," reports the UN findings.

Reports from the Nuba region also indicated an escalation of
atrocities, with hundreds of kidnappings, defacing of mosques,
destruction of churches and several attacks on local religious
leaders.

"During 1995, hundreds of political opponents or people merely
suspected of being potential opponents to the regime have been
arrested and held in detention for days, weeks or even months
without warrant or any concrete charges," the UN document says.

The UN report comes in the wake of major gains by John Garang's
mainstream SPLA rebels and looming tensions between the countries
of the entire Eastern African region, threatening to erupt into
political upheavals.

Sudan accuses Uganda of aiding the SPLA rebels, whose leader is
a personal friend of President Yoweri Museveni while Uganda
accuses Khartoum of aiding Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) rebels
currently waging a guerrilla war against Kampala in the northern
and northwestern Ugandan regions bordering Sudan.

Ethiopia has been drawn into the conflict due to Sudan's
turbulent relations with Egypt over Khartoum's alleged harbouring
and training of Islamic militants seeking to overt hrow Egypt's
secular regime and replace it with a fundamentalist one.

Ethiopia blamed Khartoum-based Muslim militants for the attempt
to assassinate President Hosni Mubarak during the Organisation of
African Unity (OAU) summit in Addis Ababa last June, bringing
relations between Egypt and Sudan, and Ethiopia and Sudan to an
all-time low.

Last year the Sudanese junta dismissed as "mistaken" Eritrean
accusations that it was training 700 terrorists to topple the
government in Asmara. Asmara severed diplomatic relations with
Sudan on December 6, 1994 accusing the Khartoum government of
seeking to destabilise the Eritrean government.

Kenya and Uganda have also been at loggerheads in recent months
over accusations that Uganda was preparing to attack Kenya with
the help of South African mercenaries. Uganda has since counterexiles. Nairobi has also dismissed reports by Ugandan governmentowned daily, New Vision, to the effect that Kenya was massing
accused Kenya of preparing a similar plot with the help of Ugandan
troops at the common border in Western Kenya in readiness for a
rebel attack against Uganda.

A follow-up visit by Kenyan journalists to the border town of
Malaba on November 12 turned sour when they were arrested and
later released by Ugandan police. The journalists were said to be
part of a larger contingent that travelled to the border to verify
whether or not Kenya was preparing to attack her neighbour in the
west. And upon his return from the Commonwealth Heads of State
Summit in Auckland New Zealand, President Moi on November 14
castigated local journalists for betraying Kenya by writing
outrageous things about their country. "I am glad the journalists
were arrested in Uganda the country they have been pressing all
along," said Moi, reacting to the arrest of his country's
journalists at the border town.

The Rwandan ethnic genocide has played into the Ugandan-Kenyan
rivalry, with suspicions that Uganda might have been involved in
the death in a plane crash of Hutu presidents of Rwanda and
Burundi on April 6 last year, which sparked massacres that left
between 500,000 and one million people dead, most of them minority
Tutsis and moderate Hutus.

Museveni is a close ally of Rwandan strongman General Paul
Kagame whose minority Tutsi-backed Rwandan Patriotic Front/Army
(RPF/A) swept to power in July last year after defeating the
majority Hutu regime of President Juvenal Habyarimana, a close
friend of Kenyan President Moi.

Tanzania has also warned that it would fight back deep in
Burundi if the Burundi an army carried out a threat to cross into
Tanzania to pursue armed Hutu living in Tanzania. Tension deepened
mid-November when Sudan suddenly accused Uganda, Eritrea and
Tanzania of fighting alongside the SPLA rebels, claims that were
immediately denied by both Asmara and Dar es Salaam, as well as
the SPLA.

Sudanese Head of State, Lt.-General Omar Hassan al-Beshir,
aggravated the situation when he declared a general mobilization,
and threatened to send troops into Uganda in revenge for the
latter's backing of southern Sudanese rebels.

"All youth are asked to proceed to army training camps. The
arms that have plowed the earth and grow the wheat are now
demanded to take up the Kalashnikov," Beshir said in a fiery
speech at a rally broadcast by Sudanese state radio, and accused
Uganda of having sent a division of troops and tanks across the
border to back southern rebels in a new offensive that began midVowing not only to "cleanse the soil of south Sudan" of the
November.
Ugandan troops, but to strike back into Ugandan territory, General
el-Beshir declared: "We shall not content ourselves with repulsing
the invading forces, but will repay the visit. We are not Christ,
turning the other cheek for another slap." We will deal a double
blow and will avenge our faith, honour and dignity.

But the man believed to be at the centre of the regional
conflict has remained as calm as ever, telling the Sudanese leader
that he was not worried about his threat to invade Uganda. Denying
Uganda's involvement in the Sudanese conflict, Museveni said: "If
the Su danese president wants to attack Uganda, he is welcome. We
have been proposing to these people that Sudan should be run as
secular state and a modern country, some do not accept. But when
some section of their people refuse and decide to fight, then they
blame Uganda.

"I have fought many wars and I am, therefore not worried about
the threat, " Museveni said on November 6 in reference to the
five-year guerrilla bush war he fought against successive Ugandan
military regimes before he seized power in January 1986.

But the SPLA believes that Khartoum's tongue-lashing against
neighbours could only come as a result of new developments in the
warfront, where reports say the rebels had regained the initiative
and made major gains that currently threaten the southern regional
capital, Juba.
-0Kenya


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


Christian Communicators Launch Research Project


LENGTH: 854 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

Nairobi - A major research project on Christian communication
in Africa was launched here on November 10.

Dubbed Media Link 2000, the research is being undertaken by the
pan-Africanist Fellowship of Christian Communicators in Africa and
Madagascar (FOCCAM), based here.

Addressing media practitioners and representatives of various
Christian organisations at a dinner organised here to mark the
official launching of the research project, FOCCAM General
Secretary Rev. Dr. Stephen Njiro, said; "We intend to help the
church in Africa get to know who is who and what is available in
Christian communication on the continent." 

He said the research aims to institute a databank on Christian
communication in Africa. "We intend to effectively tell the
churches in Africa how many Christian communicators there are on
the continent, what they are currently engaged in, the available
training facilities on the continent, the number of printing
presses, periodicals (newspapers/magazines), publishers/editors;
and radio stations, where they exist," added Dr. Njiro, a Kenya
trained theologian.

"We seem to be living in the world of massive duplication,
isolation and lack of networking among trained Christian
communicators, which we hope the research undertaken will
effectively help to clarify," he noted.

Phase One of the project will involve the sending out of
questionnaires and making visits to some African countries in the
regions.

To facilitate the research FOCCAM intends to collaborate with
major Christian organisations in Africa, among them the
Association of Evangelicals in Africa (AEA), the All Africa
Conference of Churches (AACC) and the Catholic Symposium of
Episcopal Conferences of Africa and Madagascar (SECAM).

Asked about the significance of Media Link 2000 in relation to
the research, Dr. Njiro said, "it is simply because we want to
limit ourselves to the period between now and the year 2000 and
also towards helping the churches see the challenges ahead of
their Christian communication ministry."

He said the idea of a research project was mooted in 1993,
during the 1st General Assembly of FOCCAM, in Harare, Zimbabwe,
where delegates deliberated on the theme- "Communication
Strategies for Africa."

Addressing the dinner quests on the subject, Abundant Life For
All, Kenyan career diplomat, Mr. Bethuel Kiplagat commended FOCCAM
for the research project and noted that as Christians, "we should
feel duty bound to support it morally and financially."

Mr. Kiplagat lamented that although God expects everyone to
have life and have it abundantly as the Bible teaches civil
strife, famine, corruption, and mismanagement worked against such
intentions.

Mr. Kiplagat, a former Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of
Foreign Affairs and International Co-operation, cautioned Africans
against spending too much time talking about the good old days,
and challenged people to forge ahead and build a better future.

"What counts is where we are now and where we are moving to. We
have to be future oriented rather than being fixed on the past,"
he added.

Established in 1984, FOCCAM, seeks to unite Christian
communicators throughout Africa and Madagascar for mutual
fellowship, encouragement, assistance and the sharing of t he
gospel. It currently has some 400 members who include individuals
and Christian organisations.
-0Sudan


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


381 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Church Workers Propose Committee For Uprooted People


LENGTH: 774 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

Banjul, Gambia - Church refugee workers and administrators in
Central and West Africa have proposed the formation of a regional
steering committee to promote the church ministry among uprooted
people in the affected regions.

The 40 participants at the October 23-25 regional meeting,
organised by the Refugee and Emergency Services Unit of the All
Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) also recommended that
churches immediately begin the process of sensitization on issu es
pertaining to the uprooted people.

The meeting also called on the formation and promotion of
diversified church programmes in healing and reconciliation aimed
at resolving issues related to conflict prevention. 

The participants also accepted in principal the on-going
process towards the decentralisation of the AACC Refugee and
Emergency Services. The meeting was chaired by the vice-chairman
of the Refugee and Emergency Services Committee, Bishop Johnson
Tilewa of the Gambia Anglican Diocese.

The regional meeting recommended that churches identify a group
of eminent persons, to be sent to talk to the Zairean authorities
on the recent decision to have all Rwandese refugees leave the
country by December 31 this year.

They were also unanimous on a decision to identify a group of
eminent persons to talk to the Tanzanian authorities in regard to
the latter's decision to close its borders to Burundian refugees,
seeking political asylum in the East African country.

The meeting also adopted a decision by the World Council of
Churches (WCC) at its Central Committee meeting last September to
make 1997 the Ecumenical Year for churches in solidarity with
uprooted people.

The WCC policy document entitled, A Moment to Choose: Risking
to be with uprooted people, was presented at the Banjul meeting by
Mr. Malaku Kifle the coordinator for the Refugees and Migrant Unit
of WCC.

The Banjul meeting requested churches in the affected regions,
namely Central and West Africa, that make concrete and firm plans
for a "Week of Confession" as a precursor of a concrete plan of
action towards ministering to the uprooted people all over the
world.

A document presented at the meeting proposed the third week of
June, 1996 as a suitable time for the "Week of Confession".

On the "Week of Confession", AACC Projects Officer for the
Refugee and Emergency Services, Mr. Henry Odraa Raga, said, "this
is a time set aside for churches to come together to find out how
much they have done in the field of caring for the uprooted people
and to confess for what they have failed to do in the same
regard."

Odraa-Raga also disclosed that the taskforce entrusted with the
restructuring of the AACC Refugee and Emergency Services Unit has
completed its work. The process began in 1993.

"They have so far compiled their report, shared it with
churches on regional levels and are now waiting to have it tabled
at the December 14-15 extraordinary committee meet ing of the
Refugee and Emergency Services scheduled for Nairobi," he told
APS.
-0Africa-at-Large


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


382 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Church Council Denies Report On Sackings


LENGTH: 907 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

Nairobi - The National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) has
denied reports of massive lay-offs of its employees in a
restructuring process as reported by a section of the local press.

A spokesperson for the NCCK General Secretary Rev. Mutava
Musyimi also dismissed as "untrue and pure exaggeration"
allegations that the council would "sack" 1,000 staff at a cost of
shillings 500 million (US dollars 9 million).

"NCCK NOW SACKS 1,000 EMPLOYEES," was the headline of the lead
story in the November 5 Sunday edition of a daily here. The Sunday
edition reported that as a result of the re-organization, all
current staff at the NCCK with the exception of the General
Secretary Rev. Mutava Musyimi and his deputy Rev. George Kamwesa,
are to be laid off by the end of the month. 

Expressing distaste at such distorted reports the NCCK
spokesperson said, contrary to the newspaper story, the council
currently has 400 staff members all over the country, thus there
was no way it could be sacking 1,000.

True, the spokesperson said, a well-coordinated restructuring
programme was in progress as a result of financial difficulties
which in any case are not exceptional to NCCK, but no employee had
been "sacked" as the newspaper suggested.

The spokesperson said employees have been requested to apply
for voluntary retirement and a handsome package has been offered.

About the KShs.500 million said to be the cost NCCK will incur
as compensation for the retirees, the spokesperson told APS that
this figure was highly exaggerated.

The NCCK, which is an "association of churches and other
Christian organizations guided by scripture, empowered by the
spirit and informed by tradition, sharing and acting together in
the experience and extension of the Kingdom of God", was
established some 52 years ago.

However, its history dates to as far back as 1918 when the
Church Missionary Society (CMS) United Methodist Mission, and the
Church of Scotland - (Presbyterian) formed the Alliance of
Protestant Missions (APM) "with the aim of founding a united
Christian church in Kenya."

In 1924 the Alliance of Protestant Missions formed Kenya
Missionary Council (KMC) "to facilitate activities of all
Protestant missions in Kenya." The KMC became the Christian
Council of Kenya (CCK) in 1943.

In 1957 the Christian Council of Kenya launched its first
Christian newspaper, Rock, which was to be replaced by
Target/Lengo in 1961. The NCCK became the National Christian
Council of Kenya (NCCK) in 1966 which later translated to the
National Council of Churches of Kenya in 1984.

The National Council of Churches of Kenya programmes include
education, economic development, ecumenical outreach and the fight
for social justice.

In the quest for these ideals, particularly for social justice,
the council has often rubbed the Kenyan government the wrong way
up. When Beyond, an NCCK publication, protested against what it
referred to as massive rigging in the 1988 general elections it
was promptly banned by the government.

Then during the 1992 general election the NCCK launched what it
called "Education for Participatory Democracy" in form of a
booklet entitled: Why You Should Vote. This was meant to inform
Kenyans about their rights as voters.

The NCCK sank even deeper into the government's "bad books"
when it set up a task force to investigate the "ethnic clashes"
that plunged Kenya between late 1991 through 1993. The
relationship worsened when the council published its findings in a
report called, The Cursed Arrow - (A report on Organized Violence
Against Democracy in Kenya) which implicated the Kenyan government
in the investigation and fueling of the clashes.
-0Gambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


Peace Talks Resume Boosting Churches' Efforts


LENGTH: 574 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

Luanda - How to merge formerly rival armed forces in the
Angolan conflict will form the basis of peace talks between the
Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) and the ruling
Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA).

Reducing of troops as a prelude to merging them into a single
national army was a key aspect of the Lusaka accord signed between
UNITA and MPLA in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, in November 1994.

The resumption of talks here on November 14 will definitely
please the leaders of Angola Christian Churches (EDICA), who met
in Luanda early September under the theme, " It is time to build
Angola". 

At the conclusion of the church meeting, the delegates sent a
special appeal to UNITA and the government to accelerate the peace
process under the Lusaka agreement, "in order to reduce the
suffering of the great majority of Angolan peoples."

The leaders also appealed to the representatives of the United
Nations peacekeeping force in Angola, UNAVEM-III, the political
parties, the NGOs "and the whole society in general to do their
utmost best in order to win peace, social justice and love among
the people of Angola."

EDICA recommended also that reconciliation should be total "and
a priority task" between individuals and between man and his maker
"putting into practice order of our Lord Jesus Christ as the basis
for this reconciliation and building of peace in the nation. "

A special appeal was made to Angolan people to the power of
prayer "starting with the leadership itself and all church
members."

The Angolan churches also called for an ecumenical trust
between diverse faiths of the Christian family saying, "true
confession, forgiveness tolerance and acceptance of the churches
amongst each other must be encouraged and prioritised for a real
and peaceful living together."

EDICA urged the churches to lay emphasis "on those things that
unite rather than divide." The meeting was organised by the
Evangelical Churches of Angola(AEA), and the Angolan Council of
Christian Churches (CICA).

More than 400 delegates who included church leaders from all
over the country and representatives of local and international
humanitarian organisations participated at the Luanda meeting.
-0Kenya

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November, 1995


Election Boycott Alliance Collapses


LENGTH: 827 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

Dar es Salaam - A 10-party opposition alliance to boycott a
partial re-run of the historic parliamentary elections scheduled
in the Dar es Salaam region on November 26 has collapsed after
several parties decided to participate after all.

The ballot re-run in Dar es Salam's seven constituencies came
after the Tanzanian High Court earlier last week dismissed with
costs a legal bid by the 10 parties to have the entire election
annulled.

Opposition parties claim elections to the presidency and the
parliament in the first multi-party polls in Tanzania's history,
held concurrently on October 29, were rigged. 

Election officials cancelled the results in the capital on
October 30 after admitting widespread irregularities.

However, seven opposition groups have now decided to
participate in the fresh ballot, leaving only the National
Convention for Construction and Reform (NCCR-Mageuzi), the Civic
United Front (CUF) and the United Democratic Party (UDP) still
vowing to snub the poll.

Now taking part are: the Chama cha Demokrasia na Maendeleo
(CHADEMA) - Party for Democracy and Progress), the National
Reconstruction Alliance (NRA), the National League for Democracy
(NLD), the Union for Multiparty Democracy (UMD), the Popular Natio
nal Party (PONA), the United People's Democratic Party (UDPD) and
the Tanzania Democ ratic Alliance (TADEA).

Electoral Commission chairman Justice Lewis Makame has however,
ruled any party boycotting the parliamentary poll will be struck
off lists for the presidential poll, held at the same time as the
ballot for the 232-seat legislature.

The exclusion from the poll of the NCCR-Mageuzi, CUF and UDP
would automatically leave the ruling Chama cha Mapinduzi (CCMcandidate.
Revolutionary Party) candidate Benjamin Mkapa as sole presidential

The three opposition candidates for the presidency were
Augustine Mrema for NCCR - Mageuzi, Ibrahim Lipumba for the CUF
and John Cheyo for the UDP.

According to results published so far, the CCM has crushed the
12 opposition parties that contested the first multi-party
parliamentary elections.

Delivering its verdict on November 13, a three-judge High Court
panel said the petitioners had failed to give sufficient evidence
to prove that the presidential and parliamentary elections were
not fair and free.

The judges said the opposition had also failed to prove that
the polling repeat in Dar es Salaam, which they also wanted
cancelled, would adversely affect the electoral process.

They also ordered the complainants to meet the costs of the
case, and rejected a demand that the electoral commission be
barred from announcing the results of the presidential poll.

The court ruling brought an outpouring of anger from opposition
supporters gathered around the building, with demonstrators
throwing stones and chanting slogans.

A crowd of opposition supporters surged forward in an attempt
to storm the court immediately after the ruling, but they were
stopped by riot policemen.

They later took to the streets, stoning cars and chanting
slogans against the court and the ruling party. Shopkeepers closed
their shutters, fearing possible looting.

A lawyer for the opposition said his clients would appeal
against the ruling.
-0Angola


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

November, 1995


Churches Want Own Radio and Newspaper


LENGTH: 654 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

Luanda - Angolan churches have proposed the establishment of a
frequency modulation (FM) radio station and a newspaper to serve
the church exclusively.

During the conference of Christian Churches of Angola (EDICA)
here last September under the theme, "It is time to build Angola",
church leaders noted that communication is one of the principal
capacities of any individual and the mission of the church is
carried out essentially by communication.

The church leaders recommended that the Angolan government make
a survey of the programmes developed by its organs of
communication namely, Radio Angola, the government press agency
(ANGOP) and national television station, with the intention of
presenting information which upgrades the population and the
nation. 

EDICA also recommended that the council of Evangelicals of
Angola (AEA) and the Council of Christian Churches in Angola
(CICA) jointly with the government, establish a permanent
commission to reform the law into a form that sustains press
freedom and abolishes censorship in Angola.

In addition they said the means of social communications be desocial problems of interest and impact to the population.
linked from politics entirely so as to give equal importance to

Meanwhile a de-mining project by the Norwegian Peoples Aid is
making slow but sure progress in clearing land mines on arable
land around the city of Malanje in north central Angola, according
to a report by Jim Kirkwood of the Canadian Council of ChurchesThe land is very suitable for cultivation but has been unused
affiliated Inter-Church Coalition on Africa (ICCA).
since a land mine blew up there last year. "It is an incredibly
slow process; a team of two persons clears about 90 metres long by
one metre wide a day, by cutting grass down to half an inch and
going over the dirt with a metal detector less than two feet
long," Kirkwood, who visited Angola recently, told APS.

And if the search party should detect anything they must dig
around it with a trowel to determine its size and then only, do
they report it to the specialists who defuse it. So far Norwegian
Peoples Aid have been lucky and have not lost a single person in
those operations.

Kirkwood reports that there was celebration when the road from
Malanje to the capital, Luanda was opened, through territory
formerly held by the opposition Union for the Total Independence
of Angola (UNITA). "Discussions were starting on extending the
road eastwards towards Saurimo in Luanda North provinces, for
which a number of bridges destroyed during the war have to be
rebuilt," noted Kirkwood.
-0Tanzania

Africa News


November, 1995


Two Countries Join Commonwealth Club


LENGTH: 1280 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

Auckland - Mozambique, a former Portuguese colony and the
largely French-speaking Cameroon officially joined the
Commonwealth Club, which theoretically links Britain with former
chunks of its empire.

During its summit in the New Zealand capital, Auckland, the
Club agreed to "warmly welcome" Mozambique as a "unique and
special case," New Zealand Prime Minister Jim Bolger told a press
conference here on November 12.

Mozambique's admission was agreed upon during the Commonwealth
leaders' weekend retreat at the Millbrook resort in South Island,
Bolger said, noting that this southern African country was
surrounded by Commonwealth nations - including South Africa,
Zimbabwe and Tanzania - and had expressed a strong desire to be
part of the Commonwealth.

Two days before the Commonwealth summit opened, the rulingManuel Tome had stressed in the Mozambican capital, Maputo that it
Front for the Liberation of Mozambique (FRELIMO) Secretary-General
was a question of survival that Mozambique must join the
Commonwealth. 

"We live in a highly dependent world and we want to have the
widest options possible... joining the Commonwealth is justified
by the economic and development interests of our country," Tome
said.

"A very dependent country like ours does not want to become
more dependent through exclusivity. Almost 60 per cent of the
state budget is financed by international creditors and that is
not healthy," he added.

Mozambican President Joachim Chissano lamented last July that
of the 12 members of the Southern African Development Community
(SADC), only his country and Angola were not Commonwealth members,
and said; "If we are welcome, we will join."

"We can only see advantages for our country from joining the
Commonwealth. We would not join such an organisation if the
condition was that we have to give up speaking Portuguese. As far
as language is concerned, we will keep fighting for Portuguese,"
Chissano stressed.

Mozambique's claim to linkage with the Commonwealth of EnglishAlthough it was Portugal that eventually set up colonial
speaking countries has roots in its history and recent past.
administration in Mozambique, Britain helped build its major ports
and railways, to serve the neighbouring hinterland British
colonies and South Africa.

In the late 19th century, British-owned companies administered
much of central Mozambique, where the British pound once
circulated.

Mozambique's close relationship with the Commonwealth as an
observer nation also has much to do with the recent political
history of the southern Africa region. The country's first
independence leader Samora Machel, played a key role in the
Lancaster House negotiations which brought about the independence
of neighbouring Zimbabwe, formerly southern Rhodesia.

Mozambique was the founding member of the Frontline States and
the Southern Africa Development and Coordination Conference
(SADCC) now SADC, two regional political and economic
organisations which challenged apartheid in South Africa.

As a victim of aggressive apartheid policies since 1987,
Mozambique received Commonwealth aid mainly directed to
infrastructure linking Mozambique and its Commonwealth neighbours.
The Auckland Summit also saw the formal return of South Africa to
the Commonwealth more than 30 years after the former whiteapartheid.
minority Pretoria regime quit because of Commonwealth criticism of

Cameroon, on the other hand, became the 52nd member state of
the Commonwealth early in November, ending a policy of neutrality
followed since independence in 1960 and reawakening secessionist
leanings in some sectors of its two English-speaking provinces.

For the first 30 years, the government in Yaounde had kept its
distance from such groupings, and unlike the former French
colonies in Africa, it has declined to join the francophone
community set up by General Charles de Gaulle when he was
president.

But in 1990, policy was switched to seek Commonwealth
membership in a bid to win aid and to pacify critics in the
English-speaking community who said the country was too close to
French institutions.

There is a large English-speaking minority in two of Cameroon's
10 provinces. English is an official language, together with
French in Cameroon.

When President Paul Biya took office in 1982, he continued the
policies of his predecessor Ahmadou Ahidjo, Cameroon's first
president, by keeping well away from close ties with either of the
onetime colonial empires.

The decision to join both the Commonwealth and the francophone
community has revived dreams of independence among part of
Cameroon's three million English-speaking residents, who form 25
per cent of the country's 12.7 million population.

Situated in the northwest and southwest, the English-speaking
regions were under British administration in colonial times.

Independence for the adjoining French-administered trust
territories in January 1960 was followed a year and a month later
by a referendum in which part of the British-ruled region joined
Cameroon in a federal republic, while the other part joined
Nigeria.
-0Angola


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


387 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


French Catholic Nun Killed In Algeria


LENGTH: 960 words


 
All Africa Press Service
November 20, 1995 (19951120)

Algiers - Two gunmen shot dead a French Roman Catholic nun on
November 10 and seriously wounded another in a fresh attack on
foreigners, six days ahead of presidential elections in strifeThe dead nun was identified by authoritative sources in Paris
torn Algeria, security officials said.
as Odette Prevost, 63, while the other, Chantal Galicher, 53, was
hospitalised in serious condition in intensive care, church
sources said.

Algiers Archbishop Monsignor Henri Teissier went to the
hospital to see Galicher the same day the nuns were shot.

The two women, from the congregation of the Little Sisters of
the Sacred Heart, were shot outside their home in Kouba district,
a working-class area of central Algiers where Islamic
fundamentalists opposed to the country's military-backed
government are very active. 

The Algerian government condemned the "odious attack aimed at
guests of Algeria" and vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice.

In Paris, French government spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt
described the attack on the nuns as an "unqualifiable act of
barbarism" and an "odious act," adding that "security of French
nationals in Algeria is a responsibility incumbent on the Algerian
authorities... an inquiry must be carried out as quickly as
possible to establish who was to blame .

The French Foreign Ministry urged French citizens in Algeria to
return to France, and for French citizens, especially journalists,
to refrain from going to Algeria.

The nun's death brought to 11 the number of Christian clerics
-- seven French, two Spanish, one Maltese and one Belgian - killed
in Algeria since May 1994.

More than 100 foreigners, including 31 French, have been killed
in Algeria since September 1993.

Officials in France - the former colonial power had feared
attacks on foreigners in Algeria ahead of the election, especially
after a series of terrorist bombings in France that have left
seven dead since July. French citizens last month were urged to
leave, and the Foreign Ministry urged French journalists not to go
to cover the vote.

About 1,000 French nationals remain in Algeria, most of them
elderly and clerics. There are also about 1,000 temporary oil and
gas workers in Algeria but they are heavily protected by the army.

The latest attack came on the Muslim prayer day for the week
and also one day ahead of the beginning of absentee vowing for
Algerians in France, which took place on November 11, 12 and 16.

Algerian head of government Mokdad Sifi called on the same day
of the attack for a "massive-turnout" among overseas Algerians in
order to "put an end to the tragedy. Your votes count enormously,"
Sifi said over state radio. A total of 730,000 absentee voters are
registered, including more than 600,000 in France, according to
Algerian television.

Algeria's 16 million voters cast their ballots on November 16
in the first presidential poll in the civil war that has cost
between 30,000 to 50,000 lives since 1992.

The opposition parties allied to the banned Islamic Salvation
Front (FIS) boycotted what they deride as a rigged election
designed to legitimise incumbent President Lamine Zeroual, who at
a rally on November 9 urged Algerians to unite against "bloody
terrorism." Some are predicting the elections will plunge the
country into full-scale civil war.

Armed movements had vowed that "the ballot boxes would turn
into coffins," but so far their threats had failed to stop the
candidates from holding meetings, and the more fearsome episodes
of bloodletting had been limited in number.

Zeroual, 54, a retired general, is generally viewed as the
front-runner ahead of Islamic candidate Mahfoud Nahnah who
advocates a "tolerant and modern" form of Islam. The crisis in
Algeria began in January 1992 when President Chadli Bendjedid was
forced by military hardliners to resign. The first round of a
general election the FIS was poised to win had just been annulled.
-0Mozambique and Cameroon


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

November, 1995


My Sacking A 'Blessing', Says Bamfuchile


LENGTH: 307 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 21, 1995 (19951121)
by Brian Malama

Lusaka - Former Nkana coach Ben Bamfuchile says his demotion
and his eventual dropping as Nkana coach was a blessing in
disguise and a relief. Bamfuchile hinted in an interview yesterday
in Kitwe that he did not hold any grudge against anybody from
management following his dismissal last week. 

"I had a tough time in putting the team together, I did all I
could to shape up the boys but it was just unfortunate of the team
to have failed to make a grade this year," Ex-national team
assistant coach said. He said it was not his fault that Nkana had
been relegation bound for almost two seasons.

Bamfuchile was not sure what could be wrong with the former
nine times league champions despite the presence of a good brand
of players whom he accussed of failing to hold the grip on the
summit. But Bamfuchile said he was ready to help the new trainers
in Kapambwe Mulenga and Golden Kazika when need arises.

Nkana management last week decided to drop Bamfuchile after
what they called consultation, as the team continued to suffer
some embarrasing defeats.
-0Algeria

November, 1995


Confusion Marks 1st Leg Of Basketball Championship


LENGTH: 480 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 21, 1995 (19951121)
by A Correspondent

Lusaka - Confusion marked the end of the first leg of the third
national basketball championship games in Ndola at the weekend at
which five teams qualified to the next stage of the competition to
be held in Lusaka on Saturday.

First it was the local side Bank of Zambia Celtic who reported
one and half hours late during the first day of the two day event
claiming they had been delayed because they were having breakfast.

Commissioner Frank Saliki was stunned by the explanation and
kept wondering how a Ndola-based team could afford to be late for
a fixture in their home town. 

"Teams from Lusaka have managed to arrive on time but I cannot
understand how a home team can report late especially because they
were having breakfast," Saliki of Luanshya said.

Celtic were fined for the delay and the game finally took off.
Second, a match commissioner caused a scene when he was barred
from officiating a game.

Zambia Basketball Association (ZBA) Northern Zone regional
coordinator Augustine Simonda threatened to disrupt the games for
not being allowed to officiate.

Simonda who plays for Kitwe's Premium Baskets demanded that he
officiate the game between Premium Hawks and BOZ Celtics but Hawks
protested, arguing that he was an interested party as his team had
lost 67-68 to them and he had been sent off after commiting the
mandatory five personal fouls. His behaviour upset Lusaka City
Council (LCC) Looters secretary Richard Simakomo who called the
act as " childish" and suggested that something be done.

The game finally took place after Simonda released the ball
following intervention by ZBA deputy national coordinator,
Boniface Kambi-kambi. Only Mufulira Magnet failed to qualify from
the six teams that had entered the competition whose next round
would be in Lusaka this weekend.
-0Zambia

South Africans Dominate Tennis Seedings


LENGTH: 600 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 21, 1995 (19951121)
by Reuben Tonga

Lusaka - South African tennis players have dominated the
seedings of the International Tennis Federation Central Africa
Men's Satellite with six being ranked among the top eight players.

According to information released by the ITF supervisor, Lugi
Brambilla, who is overseeing the tournament, South African Yonass
Saayman is the top seeded player after collecting 42 points since
the tournament kicked off in South Africa three weeks ago.

Apart from the six South African players, other players seeded
are Balducui, who is seeded second and last seed Bazzics, both
from Italy . The rest of the seeded South African are Rosner, who
is seeded third, Alessanjro, Koenig, Wakefield and Reyndeers. 

But Lugi, the ITF official from Italy was worried that the
rains may disrupt today's tournament at which 24 tennis players
are competing for honours.

"All the 24 players are already in the country. They all
arrived earlier than the expected days. But now the problem is the
rains. We were supposed to have started today but the rains have
completely affected the courts. The courts are now in a terrible
state after the rains," moaned Lugi. Sixteen players are playing
unseeded in the event that is expected to start in the morning
today to make up for yesterday's event which was put off because
of the rains.

Apart from the South African players, the other African country
represented is Ivory Coast, who is represented by unseeded Tomboveteran from Italy who managed a semi final berth at last year's
olino Alessanjro. Among the other players include L' Official a
tournament. America has Borsroon Edwass, Roberts Deninien while
Ullyett Clive, Smith Neil, De Jonah are the others representing
South Africa.

The tournament, which started in South Africa, three weeks ago
and have been played for a week each in Zimbabwe, Bostwana. The
events at Lusaka Club are the finals. Zambia is not represented at
the events. And Austin Fuliwa, the general secretary of the Zambia
tennis association was by last evening still trying without any
success, to get tents to cover the Lusaka Club tennis courts.

"I have only managed to get two tents from National Milling and
I don't know what will happen if it rains and we don't find enough
tents," disclosed Fuliwa to local tennis officials at the Lusaka
Club last evening. Last year's masters winner Brett Dickensen is
among those who arrived in the country at the weekend.

(he Government Criticised Over Nigeria's Action


LENGTH: 454 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 21, 1995 (19951121)
by Reuben Phiri

Lusaka - The government has come under fire for taking what
critics say a soft stand on the execution of Nigerian
environmentalists Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others by that country's
military regime.

President of the Alliance for National Reconstruction (ANR)
Alfred Sayila said in an interview yesterday that Chiluba's
remarks that Nigeria's action was "sinful and shameful" was not
enough . 

"Lack of action by the government is like trying to hide our
heads in the sand or we simply don't care about human rights
violations," he said. He urged the government to imitate countries
like Zimbabwe, South Africa, the United States and Great Britain
who have taken a stronger stand on Nigeria and be "part of the
global political community".

"If this country believes in democracy and human rights, they
should take action against Nigeria for the execution of nine human
rights activists in that country," he said adding: "If big powers
like USA and Britain have cut relations with Nigeria, then who are
we to remain aloof?" asked Sayila. He called for stronger measures
saying "there was nothing better than cutting diplomatic ties at
the time when the country is under dictatorial rule".

But chief government spokesman Amusaa Mwana-mwambwa could not
account for the government's stand because of displeasure with
some Post staff over their stories in the Kalabo by-elections
which his party, the MMD, lost to UNIP.

"I am not answering any questions from your paper until
Masautso Phiri and Mukwita phone me and apologise," he said
adding: "These two owe me an apology," he said without
elaborating.

November, 1995


Nkumbula's Accident Attracts Amnesty's Attention


LENGTH: 467 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 21, 1995 (19951121)
by Anthony Mukwita

Lusaka - The questionable 'road accident' in which former
National Party president Baldwin Nkumbula died has attracted the
attention of Amnesty International. The international human rights
group, Amnesty International, want a full brief on Nkumbula's
death. 

In a letter to the human rights organisation, Afronet, Amnesty
International was keen to know the circumstances of Nkumbula's
death. "What is the latest information regarding the death of
Baldwin Nkumbula? Is any hard and fast information emerging which
clearly points the finger at elements within the government?"
Amnesty International's Jon Lunn asked in a letter to Afronet
yesterday.

Amnesty International also wanted to know if an inquest on
Nkumbula's death has been carried out and if so what the results
have been like.

But the commission, which President Chiluba appointed a month
ago to investigate the circumstances of Nkumbula's death,
adjourned sine die last Friday after President Chiluba's son,
Castro, who was in the car in which Nkumbula died, failed to
appear and give evidence. The commission whose composition
recently raised questions following the inclusion of military
intelligence deputy chief Colonel Timothy Kazembe was last Friday
given new evidence by a Zambia State Insurance Corporation sales
representative Stanely Hamusonde who charged that the late
politician was promised the Republican vice-presidency by
President Chiluba as part of his rejoining the MMD deal.

"Baldwin had however laid down conditions such as the dismissal
of three corrupt ministers who were named as health minister
Michael Sata, finance minister Ronald Penza and Ben Mwila who is
defence minister, " Hamusonde said.
-0Zambia

Africa News


November, 1995


Government Criticised Over Waste Of Donor Funds


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 21, 1995 (19951121)
by Milimo Moyo

Lusaka - An American management expert, Jeremy Cripps, has
criticised Zambia, and other African countries for misusing donor
aid and warned that American citizens will waste no more of their
tax money on them. But the Zambian government says Cripps is
welcome to say whatever he wants about the matter.

Cripps, who is in Zambia to address the business community and
intellectuals on the significance of modern management styles,
said in an exclusive interview with The Post in Lusaka yesterday,
that Zambia and other African governments, particularly in
southern Africa, should blame themselves for the cut in US aid.

"There will be no more aid to Africa. Africa must brace itself
for a 50 per cent cut in aid in the next five years because much
of the aid it has received has not been used to improve the
welfare of the African people. It has instead found itself in the
pockets of government officials," he said. "American taxpayers are
now wondering why they should contribute to donor aid when it only
benefits a small group of politicians." 

He said the aid that went to the private sector was excellently
utilised while "government-to-government" aid has been a wasted
effort.

"This kind of aid just up in the bank accounts of government
officials and does not improve the welfare of the suffering
majorities," he said. He also said any African country which
completely cuts off corruption, privatises its parastatals and
makes people rich will attract great amounts of money from foreign
investors.

"There is much corruption especially where foreign aid is
concerned. In Zimbabwe, for example, donor food is used to promote
the ruling ZANU-PF. This tendency promotes one-partyism when in
fact the aid comes from a multi-party country -- USA," he said.

Cripps described the practice by the ruling party in Zambia to
use donor food as a means to compel voters to decide in its favour
as "corrupt". But finance minister, Ronald Penza, was not bothered
by Cripp's criticism because it was not part of US government's
policy.

"Cripps is free to express his opinion. I would only comment if
his views were expressed by an American government official,"
Penza said in an interview yesterday.

But when reminded that US assistant secretary of state for
Africa George Moose had expressed similar sentiments on US aid to
Africa, Penza replied: "It is not just the American government
that has changed its stance on the issue of aid but governments
all over the world. We have decided to change the scope of
Overseas Development Aid (ODA) and we all agree development should
no longer revolve around donor aid," he said. Moose had said the
American government will now only give aid to countries that were
serious with economic success. Cripps has been invited to Zambia
by the Zambia Chambers of Commerce Trade and Industry (ZACCI) and
the Economic Association of Zambia (EAZ). He holds a free lecture
on "Revolutionising management" at Pamodzi Hotel on November 21.

The management expert, who has worked extensively all over the
world, also said the Zambian economy may not pick up if the
country continued to segregate against talent on the basis of
nationality.

"The secret of America's success lies in its acceptance and
utilisation of people - whether they are American or not -- on the
basis of their talents and not their nationality," he said, adding
the so called "indiginisation" in African countries, was not good
for development.

Cripps said the emphasis on nationality rather than skill may
incapacitate Zambia's ability to produce world class products.
According to Cripps, there is stagnation in the management skills
presently in use in strategic industries in the country and lashed
out at the retrogressive red-tape regulating business conduct.

"Old people must move aside and let new ideas blossom. I find
the case of the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) very
interesting. Bureaucracy is actually what is holding the
privatisation of the conglomerate," he said.

"The people managing the economy and the companies must
themselves make concerted efforts to employ more modern management
styles so that the workers under them work harder. Government
interference and the bureaucratic nature of most management
strategies in Africa have been detrimental to the success of
business," he said.
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Editorial: Little World Attention As Rights Deteriorate


LENGTH: 974 words


 
Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)
November 24, 1995 (19951124)
by Bona Malwal, editor

London - Human rights have all but disappeared in Sudan
following the regime's response to the September demonstrations,
yet the international community has paid little attention. The
exception was the coverage given to the visit of the Archbishop of
Canterbury, Dr George Carey, during September. However, now that
the visit has come and gone, Sudan has once again disappeared from
the pages and screens of the international media.

There are many reasons why the world's attention has been
diverted away from Sudan. Not least because of the regime's
adeptness at promoting its own position. Another reason is that
Sudan has never been a popular topic for the international media. 
Sudan has yet to provide as attractive stories as Somalia, Rwanda
and Bosnia. Besides, successive Sudanese regimes have closed the
door to the international media and the present regime is the
worst. Could the genocidal campaign in the Nuba Mountains have
taken place if the world's media were to be encamped inside Sudan?
Would the regime's forces have been able to violate the Guinea
Worm cease-fire with impunity if the world's media had been
present in Southern Sudan?

The regime has recently attempted to convince the world that it
is aspiring to improve its human rights record. Long term
observers know that these impressions are false but there are many
willing to accept them at their face value. Perhaps the most
outrageous attempt by the regime to curry favour with the world
was the announcement in August that it would shortly release all
its political prisoners from detention.

The regime has thousands of its opponents held in hidden
detention centres, and it would have been particularly naive to
think that it would release all of them in one go. A few high
profile individuals were released in August but the nameless
masses remained incarcerated. Following the September
demonstrations, the regime's jails and ghost houses have swelled
once more, and August's gesture has remained an empty one.

Why has the international media chosen to ignore Sudan at a
time when repression is on the increase? The answer is difficult
to ascertain considering the high profile terrorism trials in
America and the assassination attempt on the Egyptian president,
Hosni Mubarek.

Two events have given some hope. Dr Carey's frank assessment of
the poor human rights situation in Sudan and the religious
persecution of Christians was one. The other was the European
parliament's resolution calling on the international community to
take the regime's human rights abuses seriously by imposing
sanctions. The "Gazette" has called for such action in the past
and endorses the European parliament's moves today.

Hopefully the United States Congress will support the call for
sanctions through its House of Representatives sub-committee on
Africa. That committee has been at the forefront of the
international efforts to highlight the regime's human rights
abuses. Hopefully it will add its support by sponsoring a similar
resolution of its own urging the US administration of President
Bill Clinton to lead the way towards punitive sanctions against
the NIF regime. Without such punitive measures it will be
impossible to change the regime's ways.

Undoubtedly the people of Sudan will eventually rid themselves
of the twin scourges of Islamic Fundamentalism and terrorism.
However, firm international resolve in the present situation will
bring that day closer and reduce the cost that the Sudanese will
have to pay to return their country to democracy.

The lack of real concern from the world for the plight of the
Sudanese people is entirely the fault of the world's media which
has failed to sufficiently highlight the real conditions of
suffering in Sudan. Now that there are signs that the Bosnian
tragedy is nearing a peaceful conclusion, perhaps the media will
switch its attention to the repressed and suffering in Sudan,
where Christians' and non-Moslems are being persecuted and Moslems
are being repressed by Islamic fundamentalists. Fairness and
justice demands that the international media do this.
-0Zambia


LOAD-DATE: January 2, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


395 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


Khartoum Plans Yet Another Dry Season Military Offensive


LENGTH: 1680 words


 
Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)
November 24, 1995 (19951124)

Khartoum - Seasoned Sudan observers have become used to the
National Islamic Front (NIF) regime's annual dry season offensive.
Each year it is planned and billed as the final offensive which
will militarily defeat the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA)
and end the war in the South once and for all. This year's targets
have a familiar ring to them, Nimule on the border with Uganda,
Western Equatoria and civilian targets behind SPLA lines.

The border with Uganda has become an important target for the
regime since the break in relations with the government of Yoweri
Museveni. The regime is supporting and supplying the Lords
Resistance Army (LRA) which is fighting against the Museveni
government in northern Uganda. Control of the border will make the
support easier. 

The Western Equatoria Fronts: The regime hopes to open up
several routes into Western Equatoria, the only part of the South
totally controlled by the SPLA. Following the success last year of
re-taking Kaya by infiltrating troops back into Sudan from Zaire,
the regime hopes to repeat this by infiltrating troops across the
border and towards Maridi. A second column will move from Yei
through the old Ngamunde Mountains road. A third through Lanya and
Mundri. A fifth will move through the old second world war route
from Rumbek through Macharanga. A fourth column will attempt to
move from Wau to Tombura and may make use of a road inside the
border of the Central African Republic.

Opening disused roads, and trying to transport convoys of heavy
mechanised equipment along them will lead to slow progress for the
regime's forces. It will also make them sitting targets for the
SPLA's more mobile guerrilla forces. Even in the dry season,
Western Equatoria's terrain provides more than sufficient cover
for a guerrilla army. In any case, these routes have been tried in
previous offensives did not work.

The regime's forces need to make considerable progress and take
Maridi or Tombura before the end of March when the rains begin
once more. What has happened in recent years is that the
mechanised columns make slow progress and then have to return to
their point of origin or risk becoming stranded en route when the
rains make progress impossible. Those units that have been
stranded in the past have only served to resupply the SPLA with
captured weapons and ammunition.

Progress from Wau to Tombura will be as difficult as ever
because the SPLA still controls the south bank of the River Bo
some sixty miles south of Wau. The regime will have immense
problems trying to ferry troops across. Without achieving this,
the front may be closed in defeat before it is opened in victory.

The Nimule Front: the regime has been trying to capture Nimule
for several years without any success. The only new advantage that
the regime can claim is the control of Kajokeji and Kaya. Even
then it is difficult to see how the control of these two posts
might constitute an advantage if both are under siege by the SPLA.

Perhaps the real advantage and difference this year is that the
regime has well resupplied its bases in the South during the four
months of the so-called Guinea Worm cease-fire. It is known that
three Chinese ships have been unloaded at Port Sudan and they were
believed to be full of weapons destined for the South. They docked
in June and so there has been plenty of time for the weapons to
have been transported to the South.

In addition, China has remodelled the Sudan army's American F5
fighter planes that had fallen into disrepair. The United States
had refused to supply spare parts. The army's American supplied
C130 transport planes and their Soviet made Antonov long range
bombers have all been maintained and will be used for the resupply
of troops and for attacking civilian targets behind the SPLA
lines, respectively.

Iranian Connection: It is far from clear where the money for
the new supplies has come from. China deals with Sudan on a
strictly cash only basis. Iran has paid China for Sudan's weapons
in the past but has shown little interest in doing so in the past
eighteen months.

However, as we were preparing this article, the Iranian deputy
minister for foreign affairs, Mohamed Juaad Lorigan told the
London based Arabic Language daily newspaper "Al Hayat" that his
country is "supplying arms and ammunition to the regime to help
them in their civil war in the South". The Sudanese minister of
foreign affairs, Ali Osman Mohamed Taha, naturally played this
down in another interview with another London based Arabic
language magazine, "Al Wasat", a few days later by only confirming
the earlier military aid.

It is also rumoured that the Gulf state of Qatar has footed the
bill. The NIF regime has had close relations with the ruler of
that state, both the father and the son who deposed him in a coup
recently. The regime has also developed close relations with
Moslem rulers in Asia. Both Malaysia and Indonesia have hosted
visits from Lieutenant General Omer Hassan El Beshir, the regime's
military dictator.

The Impact of the Cease-fire: Before the Guinea Worm cease-fire
was brokered by former US president Jimmy Carter, the regime's
forces in the South were in considerable disarray. The cease-fire
was seized upon as an ideal opportunity to resupply, reinforce and
reequip the regime's garrisons in the South. Such moves clearly
violated the cease-fire but there was no provision for monitoring
it in place in the South. The SPLA had no choice but to accept the
cease-fire, given its humanitarian aspect, although it could have
demanded proper monitoring.

The international community will be able to decide for itself,
once the offensive gets going, whether the advantages of
immunising a few thousand Southern children during the cease-fire
outweigh the havoc wreaked in their communities by the resupplied
troops of the regime.

Not Total Darkness: In spite of the clear abuse of the ceaseThe Lafon Declaration from April instituted an understanding
fire by the regime, it is not all dark and gloomy for the South.
between the forces of William Nyuon in the Southern Sudan
Independence Movement(SSIM) and the SPLA. This has meant a
decrease in the fighting in Upper Nile between the different
Southern factions. As a result it will be far more difficult for
the regime to assist and reinforce its forces in Eastern Equatoria
from Malakal, as was the case in recent years.

Another development has been the switch in allegiance by the
Mundari tribal militia which had been supporting the regime's
forces against the SPLA. The militia is reported to be cothat the regime will have difficulty using the river route to
operating with the SPLA and if this is indeed true, it will mean
resupply Juba from the North. The Mundari militia control a
significant part of the river as it passes through their
territory. It will be good to see the Dinka of Bor and Yirol corule tactics of the regime which caused their disagreements in the
operating once more with the Mundari because it was the divide and
first place.

In spite of the regime's offensive, Southern Sudan is likely to
emerge from the current dry season at the end of the day in much
the same way as it has always done at the end of each dry season,
still a force to reckon with.
-0Sudan

LANGUAGE: English

National AIDS Plan Emphasizes Prevention, Education


LENGTH: 187 words


 
Tunisian Press Agency (Tunis)
November 24, 1995 (19951124)

Tunis - Speaking at a seminar on AIDS prevention organized by
the Tunisian Association to Fight Sexually-Transmitted Diseases,
Health Minister Hedi Mhenni said that Tunisia has been spared
the worrisome proportions of the AIDS disease. He said the
number of people with full blown AIDS has not exceeded 255
cases, 178 (70%) of whom have died. The number of AIDSDr. Mhenni also said that Tunisia is implementing a national
positive people is estimated at 404.
plan of AIDS prevention, information and education, adding that
since 1987, all blood transfusions are tested for the AIDS virus.

Africa News


November, 1995


Africa To Benefit From New Telecom Technology


LENGTH: 320 words


 
Tunisian Press Agency (Tunis)
November 24, 1995 (19951124)

Tunis - African telecommunications officials and
representatives
of international telecommunications organizations met in Tunis
November 20-24, 1995, to discuss ways to improve inter-African
telecommunications, especially through AT&T's "Africa One"
submarine fiber optic cable linking all African coastal countries.

Mr. Ahmed Louayane, secretary general of the
Telecommunications Development Office of the International
Telecommunications Union, said that "Africa One' project will save
African countries 150 to 200 million dollars a year in
telecommunications costs. 

Tunisia's international telecommunications are served through
two main links. The first, created in 1994, is 18,000 kilometer
long, linking the region to south east Asia, through Tunisia's
northernmost city of Bizerte, Marseille (south of France),
Singapore, and several other points. The second link, inaugurated
in November 1995, is a fiber optic cable of 1,000 lines linking
Kelibia (North East of Tunisia) to the Italian city of Trapani
(Sicily).
Tunisia's satellite links are served by INTELSAT and ARABSAT.
-0Tunisia

LANGUAGE: English

Tunisia Participates At Barcelona Conference


LENGTH: 254 words


 
Tunisian Press Agency (Tunis)
November 28, 1995 (19951128)

Tunis - Foreign Affairs Minister Habib Ben Yahia heads
Tunisia's delegation to the Conference on EuropeanBarcelona, Spain. He met on Monday with the ministers of foreign
Mediterranean Cooperation held November 27-28, 1995, in
affairs of Spain, Egypt, Algeria, Lebanon, Jordan and Great
Britain. 

High level officials from 15 countries of the European Union
and
12 Mediterranean countries, will discuss during the two-day
conference, ways to establish "a stable Euro-Mediterranean
space, that is favorable to cooperation and development."

President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali had called in June 1993 in a
speech before the European Parliament in Strasburg, for the
establishment of a new relationship between European and North
Africa countries based on cooperation and partnership.

Africa News


November, 1995


'The Post Being Used By Kaunda'


LENGTH: 774 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
November 28, 1995
by Sundie Sinkala

Lusaka - Presidential aide Richard Sakala and a man claiming to
be President Chiluba's uncle, Maxwell Chisoko Kalesha yesterday
accused The Post of working in collusion with former president
Kenneth Kaunda to discredit the
President as elections were around the corner.

Kalesha said his family would take the newspaper to court so
that the issue
of his nephew's disputed origin was settled once and for all. At a
specially arranged State House afternoon press briefing to deny
yesterday's Post's front page story "FTJ was born in Zaire"
Kalesha complained about the negative reporting by the newspaper
on the President alleging that its motives were to bring him down
from the presidency. "It's a pity that we should allow a bad paper
like The Post to exist in this country. The Post is full of lies,
and no one should believe it, " he said. 

He pleaded with the people not to doubt the origin of President
Chiluba
because he was a true Zambian born in Wusakili and still had some
of his
paternal and maternal relatives alive.

On Kafupi's claims that he was President Chiluba's biological
father,
Kalesha rebuffed these claims, insisting that he (Kafupi) had
failed to
substantiate anything and was consequently convicted by Mwata
Kazembe's
court.

Earlier, Sakala said that The Post were using a Mr Simusokwe
and a Mr
Kapusa, once used by the UNIP regime to investigate President
Chiluba's
origins and warned the paper that the government would soon move
decisively
and prove to the people that the paper was telling lies.

"We are concerned with the manner in which The Post has been
gathering
and fabricating false information about the origins of the because
of the
presidential and general election next year" he said.
He said the newspaper had offered K300, 000 to try and bribe some
people in
Zaire so that they could provide information on the birth records
of the
President.

Sakala the issue of the President's origin had been started in
1981 but
that The Post, together with Kaunda's men, had intensified the
search
because of the forthcoming elections in 1996. He promised to bring
the
people from where The Post bought the information before the press
within
the week.
-0Tunisia

400 of 400 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November, 1995


United States and Africa Be Open, the United States Tells Zambia


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1387 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 1, 1995 (19951201)
by Sipo Kapumba

Lusaka - The United States of America has made a public call to
the Zambian government to be transparent in the handling of the
constitutional reform and the voters registration.

A high ranking US government official said in Lusaka yesterday
that the confidence of citizens in the integrity of the political
process is essential in gaining public support.

"To this end we encourage the government to undertake such
critical programmes as constitutional reform and voter
registration in the kind of open, transparent and realistic
fashion which serves to build this confidence," said Carol
Lancaster, deputy administrator of the United States Agency for
International Development (USAID).

She was speaking at the Lusaka International Airport prior to
her departure after a two-day visit with Zambian government and
non-governmental organisation officials. Her remarks come in the
wake of increased public resentment towards the manner in which
the MMD government is attempting to adopt and enact the next
Zambian constitution against popular will. 

Last week hundreds of members of civic organisations, political
parties, student, women's movement, farmers and chiefs resolved at
a national conference in Lusaka to block government effort to rush
the constitution to parliament.

They have planned counter action which includes their own
citizens convention on December 16, and a Constituent Assembly on
January 13, 1996.

The meeting also resolved to mobilise countrywide protests
against the government move.

Lancaster also warned government against tolerance for
corruption. She said the government should take steps to ensure
the independence of investigatory bodies "in order to eliminate
any perception of the kind of high-level corruption that so badly
corrodes public faith in, and support for, essential reform
programmes on which so much progress has been made."

The US stance comes within weeks of a warning by an American
management expert, Jeremy Cripps, who attacked the Zambian
government for misusing donor assistance in an exclusive interview
with The Post.

But yesterday's official statement is the second open
expression of increasing donor displeasure against the Zambian
government for lack of transparency and good governance.

At the good governance meeting on October 30 donors were said
to be firm in criticising Zambia's record and tied their aid to
specific demands. "A majority of donor countries made it clear
that the amount of aid to Zambia will be related to good
governance," a government official who attended the meeting told
The Post.

He claimed that donors also insisted on a constituent assembly
to adopt Zambia's constitution.

The revelations of donor concerns as published in The Post
displeased the government who warned its, "cooperating partners
that the substance of discussions at such meetings should be
respected and not carelessly discussed with persons not involved."

Lancaster yesterday disclosed that President Chiluba has made
assurances to her about his government commitment to
democratisation, structural adjustment and transparency.She
described her meeting with the President as "good."

But a cabinet minister revealed yesterday that pressure has
been mounting on the Zambian government from donors who are
reluctant to support the MMD programme if it departed from
specific good governance demands.

"The pressure has been increasing as the Paris Club meeting
approaches. I am not surprised at the US position," he said.

This position comes ahead of a consultative meeting in Lusaka
on December 5 next week and a dinner expected to be hosted by
State House for participating donors on December 7 in preparation
for the Paris Club meeting on December 15.

Lancaster however said the MMD government "deserves credit for
broad gains in economic liberalisation,"including parastatal
closures and privatisation. She said the Zambia Privatisation
Agency "will show the way for other African countries struggling
to privatise."

She was flanked by the deputy director of the USAID Center for
Democracy, Jennifer Windsor, who said she was impressed by the
progress made in democratisation in Zambia and the level of debate
on various issues which symbolised real democracy.

Meanwhile, the U.S.government has been assured by the ViceZambia for hunger relief "will be dealt with firmly."
President's office that any sale of food donated by the US to

US embassy spokesman Lincoln Dahl said this in response to a
query about whether his government was aware of claims that 20,000
tonnes of donated sorghum was being sold on the open market.

"As noted earlier, US relief food is not to be sold and 90 per
cent of it is intended for food-for-work programmes," he said.

He expressed confidence that both the World Food Programme and
the Office of the Vice President were capable of securely
distributing the 20,000 tonnes of relief food.

Tuesday, Mpika MP Guy Scott told parliament that 20,000 tonnes
of relief food donated by the US government was being offered for
sale to traders on the open market by the government.

He said this when making a contribution to a speech by Viceavert hunger following the drought.Miyanda pleaded ignorance of
President Godfrey Miyanda on steps the government had taken to
such sales of but offered to investigate the matter to establish
the truth.

"If that is happening I must state that it is wrong and does
not reflect well on the people that donated the food. I will not
allow such a thing to happen, so I will follow it up," he said.

The 20,000 tonnes of relief sorghum was donated last week by
the US government.
-0Zambia
